11.title: Your Personality...

111.content:
You are a hot-headed and brutal warrior! Smash your foe first and ask questions... after some more smashing!

Now we get to the fun part... What breed of dragon are you?

The Juggernaut: Powerfully built, your claws can rip a boulder in half. Aggressive, you've been fighting since you were out of the shell and not much can stand against the heavy bone mace at the end of your short, thick tail. All that muscle doesn't do much for your aerial agility however, and your compressed flame sac is quite small. Colors come mainly in earth tones, particularly reds and browns. Two mighty horns adorn the head either facing forward like a bull or curling backwards like a ram.

The Fire-Lord: You are a bit scrawny for a typical dragon and almost half the normal size standing at a mere nine feet at the shoulder. None dare mock your skinny frame or over-sized wings however as the bulbous sacs to either side of the base of your neck contain liquid, molten death. With your breath weapon, you can lay waste to your foes from afar, but be careful, even your supply of fire isn't indefinite. Those huge flames sacs take a lot of nutrition to sustain, however, giving you an appetite equal to a quite large dragon. Elaborate coat markings of black, red, orange and even yellow give this breed away.

The Deathwing: These dragons have a sinister appearance with their elongated snouts, huge horns and the spikes at their knees and shoulders. A fleshy ruff around the face can create a presentation that will stop a man's heart cold in fear. But more fearsome is their reputation for ruthlessness and guile. Muscular, but not brawny, quick, but with enough weight to get the job done, these intelligent creatures are the objects of horrible fairy tales and superstitions the world over. And that suits them just fine. Always solid black, you are a hunter of the night and while you can see into the blackest abyss, your eyes are sensitive to bright lights without the time to acclimate. A single sharp prong for stabbing exists at the end of your long, elegant tail.

You are brought to a cell. A cow is given to you daily along with whippings. For a week they have tried to tame you but it hasn't worked. You try to break free but you can't. You are prisoner.

You haven't slept the whole time you were here and are tired from stuggling. You decide to rest and when yoy wake up, a slave is brought up to your cage. The king is with him.

Your hear a cheering, but you are unshure where it came from. The thick cage walls come down and you finaly see where you are. A Huge stadium. You realize that this is no ordinary execution but a game of cat and mouse for the peoples entertainment.

Still held by a chain just shorter than the radius of the stadium, you see the slave cowering with fear. A large growl fills the air. You haven't eaten yet.

11111221.title: First meal

choices: A special event is being prepared...
111112211.content:
Without hesitation you open your jaw, and you clamp down on the unlucky slave. You thrash around his body, taking out your frustration on him before messily devouring him. The crowd erupts into cheers at the sight of the gruesome spectacle, and the king seemed pleased with the execution you conducted.

After you finish your meal, you get dragged into the underground dungeon beneath the arena. You get shoved in a relatively large, but barren, cold and damp chamber. You spend your days there, only being brought out when the king needs to make an example out of an unruly subject...

You do not know how much time you spent in your cell, but you have grown considerably. You're now built like a tank, your body is now covered in thick scales and your horns are fully grown and curved forwards akin to a bull. The isolation and whippings failed to break your spirit. In fact, they had the opposite effect. Each day you spent chained up in the cell only made your rage grow more and more.

You struggle against your shackles everyday, everyday they creak and bend more and more. You're sure you'll break out any day now, and when you do you'll slaughter each and every last one of your captors, starting with that fat, crown wearing bastard...

One day, you are awoken from your slumber by a strange noise coming from above
111112211.title: Chained Beast

choices: They are soldiers from a neighboring kingdom
They are something far more sinister...
1111122111.content:
As you raise your head and listen more closely, you hear orders being shouted, savage battlecries and screams of fear and pain, steel clashing against steel... the unmistakable sounds of a raging battle. Now would be the best time to make your escape, while the king's men were preoccupied with fighting off whoever was invading them. You begin madly struggling against the chains, thrashing around and hitting yourself against the wall. And though they creaked and groaned, they refused to yield.

You lie down, feeling exhausted. You try and gather your strength before trying once more, but before you do so the wooden door to your cell opened. You saw the fat king waddle inside, along with a few of his guards. The king was breathing heavily, both from fear and from having to run over to here. He crouches down to catch his breath, and he orders his men: "Guards! Barricade the door, they are coming! And start unchaining the dragon!". Most of the guards began blocking up the entrance, while one of them approached the king and said. "Sire, are you sure unchaining this beast is a good idea?"

"We have no choice! This beast is our only hope of defeating them! Now hurry up!" The panicking king replied. Your eyes instantly widened, the day had finally come. You stayed still as a few guards hesitantly approached you and began unlocking your heavy chains. You stood still, barely able to contain your rage, but attacking them before they set you free would be an extremely stupid idea.

Just before they finished unlocking your restraints, the enemy forces bashed open the door and barged in...

choices: The humanoids attack Blaze on sight
11121.content:
The fire was more intense than anything that Blaze could have summoned up himself. The air was acrid and stank from the chemicals near the collapsing artist's guild. Iskierka… The golden dragoness he'd seen disappear into collapsing stone and dust was surely dead, but Darzhja had rushed back towards the heart of the inferno anyways along with her hulking companion Kaj. Blaze wished he could be brave like her…

The smoke rising from the burning merchant district forced the young fire-lord down still lower. Blaze's scales shined iridescently in the heat of the flames, turning back the heat better than a typical dragon's, but his lungs were no better equipped to handle smog and ash than your average fire-breathing lizard. Coughing, he alighted heavily onto the hard cobbles of a street once so familiar and now a burning hellscape. The screaming of humanoids and dragons filled his ears. They were burning, they were all burning.

A pyromaniac by nature, Blaze never imagined the true horror that fire could visit on a world of flesh and tinder. His insides chured with a manifested phantom guilt, as if the entire tragedy were somehow his fault. But then, maybe it was just the smoke. Blaze shuddered and then emptied his crop and then his true stomach onto the darkened stones. The fluid bubbled and steamed almost immediately among the small round rocks he'd also purged himself of.

It was almost more heat than even he could withstand. Where was the orphanage? Part of Blaze wanted to blame Darzhja for sending him this way on his own. Why hadn't she helped him get back to Lady Ramoth's? The red fire drake, his scales blackening with ash as it settled on him, walked forward blindly in the inferno. He could barely see a tail's length ahead of him.

Blaze stopped again with a fit of coughing and retched up more bile and the last two stones knocking around his crop. He struck out with a claw against a smoldering wagon, the charred remains of a pony still attached to one end, knocking the destroyed heap into the gutted and glowing interior of a one-time proprietor of ceramic pots. He struck out against the pain in his lungs, against his watery eyes, against Darzhja who'd expected him to be able to save himself and against himself for being unable to save himself.

The outburst left him off balanced and Blaze wobbled in the street, feeling more than a little dizzy. At least there were fewer screams now… how long had he been wandering up this boulevard from Hell? Flames were only licking up the larger buildings and skyscrapers now. Most of shops and such were now only glowing coals in the skeletons of their frames. The fires waited, dormant, Blaze knew, inside the wood and even inside the corpses of those who had owned the once magnificent buildings as well as those who had labored in them, now all charcoal and ash. In the artificial night, the glowing embers peeking out from their borrowed homes looked like advertisements and billboards lining the street, beckoning entertainment within for a price.

Blaze crawled through the street, the smoke like a ceiling overhead. He must really be losing it, he thought. Even now, he was entertaining delusions of rescue. Up ahead the street even seemed to end. Of course it couldn't have. Inferno Boulevard had no end as any sensible denizen of the Fire-World knew. The young drake scrambled through a cool snow bank laying in the middle of the road. Ah, refreshing thought Blaze as he paused to rest. But it was odd snow, this. Much lighter than he was used to… and somewhat crunchy in places. There were all these… bones.

Blaze cried out and leapt away, nearly colliding with the cliff face in front of him. He coughed and looked blearily at the stairs cut into the side of the tall Teir. He set his forepaws on them. These were stairs he knew! They led directly up back to Lady Ramoth's orphanage. To home.

The young fire-lord would have cried out if his throat were not baked raw. Delusions fled from his eyes as he gathered the last of his strength for the long climb.

However, before his tail have even cleared ground level, there came a ruckus from below, in the direction were the coals were faintest. Blaze droped his neck down over the edge of the carved stairs and saw humanoids below! How could little creatures such as those survive down there when dragons themselves were reduced to ash!?

Ah, but these creatures had breathing masks on as well as heavy coats to protect them from the heat. They spread out in a deliberate manner, moving quickly through the streets and the rubble, kicking over debris and poking cursorily through the remains of the buildings.

"Rescue workers!" thought Blaze immediately, though he thought it strange that their jackets were a motley collection of brown and black rather than something more visible, like yellow. But he hardly cared, all Blaze wanted was to be away from here, to be safe.

But wasn't safety right up these steps? He wondered. Perhaps he shouldn't bother them, they might rescue someone else in more need than he in the time it takes them to get him away. But how could he be sure that these steps did lead back to the orphanage, or that he would be able to climb up all the way through the smoke? He was so tired…

After all, who was he to think that he could possibly even do something as simple as rescue his own hide? He was 48 years old, but that was barely an adolescent by dragon standards. That's why he lived in an orphanage. No, it'd be safer to put his life in their hands than to trust his own claws.

Blaze slithered over the edge of the stairs and back down to the street. It was easily the worst decision he'd ever made in his life.
11121.title: Blaze

choices: The kidnappers return to chain him up
111211.content:
"Are you lost young Drake?" asked one of the brown clad humanoids.
"I'm trying to get back up to the steps back home..." cried Blaze wearily.

The humanoid shook his head, "I'd advise against that. The stairways been blocked off by some falling rubble..."

Blaze gasped, "Then...what am I going to do? How am I going to get back to the orphanage?"

"I know a safe place you can stay for the time being. Its right down this alleyway. If you'd just follow us..." said another of the brown clad humanoids. Were Blaze thinking straight, he would have known not to trust these rather odd individuals. After all, as an orphan, he was well aware these were untrustworthy people out on the streets. In his panic, Blaze failed to notice the glint in the humanoid's eyes, but rather was thankful that someone cared.

"R-right!!" he replied.

Blaze followed the brown clad humanoids down the chaotic streets toward what he hoped was safety. He remembered going down a number of turns, navigating through a tight corridor that the skinny Fire Drake could barely maneuver through.

"Where exactly are we going?” asked Blaze, tiredly.

“To a safe place. There’s no time for details…” uttered the lead humanoid.

Eventually, Blaze was led to a small cave dug into the side of the terrace.

“Quickly!! In here!!” gestured one of them, pointing to the entrance.

Blaze looked inside, it looked tight and cramped and it made him a little uneasy.

“What are you waiting for!! Get in!!” cried the humanoid again, giving him a slight push inside. Blaze grunted; he sure wasn’t a friendly individual, yet compared to having to face the raging inferno he could care less about comfort or how friendly people were. He gave a nod and scampered inside.

He rested upon his belly, relieved to find the air was rather cool compared to the outside. Yet something didn’t seem right about this place. There was a rather odd smell; a combination of a rotting carcass mixed with that of young drakes… as if that he were not the first to be led here. Furthermore, where did those humanoids that had taken him run off to? Why didn’t they come inside with him?

He soon learned the answer as Blaze shifted his gaze back toward the entrance. Right then, a row of thick iron bars snapped into place, blocking his way out. When he peered back outside, the kidnappers were already scampering back down the alleyway, turning out of sight. His hearts sank as the answer suddenly occurred to Blaze. These weren’t rescue workers… They were kidnappers!! He’d been duped. By the Ancestors!! He’d been duped…

“Somebody!! Get me out of here!! Please help!!” screamed Blaze at the top of his breath. He threw his claws against the iron bars, desperately trying to shake them loose, but the thick metal defied his efforts. He tried blowing fire on the bars, yet not even the flame of a Fire Drake did anything to soften the bars one bit. He yelled and wailed and cried and screamed, calling for Lady Ramoth, Darzhja, Kaj, the Great Ancestors Above, even his non-existent parents in hopes that they would hear him and rescue him. Yet nobody came.

Blaze sunk down into the dark chamber,How could I have been so stupid? Lady Ramoth always told us not to trust strangers, especially during times like these…

Yet as Blaze thought of her, he realized that he might never see her or any of his friends ever again. He was trapped here, with nobody to care for him or love him. Despair overtook the young Fire Drake, as he settled onto his belly and cried.

Several hours later....
111211.title: Don't trust strangers

choices: Blaze awakes chained somewhere outside of New Alveri
1112111.content:
It was very quiet in the cool, slightly musty stone chamber. Blaze barely stirred on the loamy straw scattered about the floor on one side, having exhausted himself battering his body against the iron bars which confined him. The normally regal and inflated sacs at the base of his throat were diminished, emptied of their fire. As a result, Blaze was famished and weak. His irregular cough was the only sounds in the small cave aside from the scurrying of rats in the straw where he lay.

The light filtering in through the bars was crimson and wavering. Outside somewhere, a fire still tore through New Alveri. But no one had come! Not a soul had the young fire drake seen since he'd been led into this accursed cave in one of the back alleys of the burning Merchant District. Was there a slight haze to the air between the bars? A slick film, like soap on the surface of water? It could be that the same barrier than kept the chamber insulated against the heat outside also kept sound from escaping into the streets beyond. It sounded plausible, but Blaze was no student of magic, that was for sure.

At any rate, the only thing that could be seen beyond the bars was the other side of the building which formed the back alley where the cave had been dug. A woven refuse basket lay toppled and half broken on the cobbles just beyond where Blaze could reach by sticking his claw through the bars. Not so much as a bird had passed since he'd been left here, his captors apparently secure in the knowledge that their prize could not go anywhere.

As Blaze drowsed, he could only imagine what horrible things lay in store for him at the cruel hands of indifferent humanoids. Would he be sent abroad to become a slave? Or would he be simply chopped up for parts? The magician's and alchemist's guilds as they were, the latter option seemed terrifyingly plausible. Blaze buried his snout in the odiferous straw and wept.

"Darzhja… anyone… please come find me…" he muttered.

When the red skinned drake saw the figure approach on the cobbles outside his chamber, he soon wished that he had been more specific in his prayer.

Blaze's first thought was it was indeed a dreaded magician. The robed elf strode confidently beyond the bars, a pair of muscly bodyguards at his flanks. Blaze flinched when he waved his hand in his direction, expecting to meet his end at some vile spell from those manicured fingertips.

Instead, a light began to fill the chamber, evenly and without obvious source. Shadows fled before the ubiquitous light. And the elf studied him like a newly weaned colt… or a pig ready for slaughter.

He mumbled and spoke to his contemporaries, but Blaze only knew this because their mouths were moving, otherwise, the chamber was as silent as it was before. He pointed towards various features of Blaze with his delicate fingers, the wings, shoulders and teeth most especially. The young drake didn't know what to make of it. He was a proud citizen of New Alveri, yet he suddenly felt reduced to fodder in the eyes of the haughty, colorful elf.

The light vanished as more humanoids approached. It was his 'rescue team' and - Blaze wished fervently that his eyes were failing him - it almost looked like some of them were carrying round bundles, just the right size for dragon eggs. Their leader strode confidently up to the elf and gestured to the cave where Blaze was confined, a smug look on the human's bearded face.

However, the elf did not look pleased at all. With his left hand, the elf made a swiping motion and the man was blown to the side as if by a great wind. The wave of force blew out the soap bubble barrier between the grates and one of them actually burst. Suddenly, the world had sound again.

"-have a green dragoness twelve blocks away! You were to collect eggs from the designated spots only!"

The man curled on the floor, hugging his ribs, surprisingly, he showed resilience in the face of the powerful elf wizard. "It… was an… and opportunity we couldn't pass up. It was a-alone, and better, an orphan."

The elf glanced back at Blaze. "An orphan? Well, you may not have complicated the situation as much as I'd fear you had, then." He sneered, "Get yourself out of the gutter and take those eggs to the second rendezvous, we can't store them with that adolescent."

The enormity of what Blaze was witnessing pounded on his skull. Humanoids with dragon eggs? It was forbidden! Unthinkable! We're Equals! Blaze yelled inside. And then he realized and remembered. If sound could get in, it must surely be able to get out.

The young drake flowed forward, spreading his wings and puffing the loose skin on his chest. Pointing his snout in the direction of the empty grate, he let loose a mighty roar. However, it came out rather choked for his seared throat and it sent him into yet another fit of coughing.

It was plenty loud enough, however to get the humans attention. The elf remained calm, almost amused, however, despite how Blaze called forth in roaring Draconic. "Help! Child in Danger! Please come!"

"The orb." said the elf, and a meaty orc slipped a round crystalline sphere into the elf's waiting hand.

He came to the gate even as Blaze continued to shout. "Quiet you. You'll learn respect soon enough." The elf slipped the orb into the cell where it cracked on the stone floor; he backed away quickly before Blaze could think to strike through the bars. A heavy mist flowed out of the broken sphere, stopping at the gate and soon building up throughout the small room. It had the sickly sweet smell of a cleaner rather like the one Howard the blacksmith used around the shop. The world began to spin despite his attempts to hold his head high.

The last thing that Blaze saw was the elf's smug smile, grinning up at him. He didn't remember falling.
1112111.title: The Elf

choices: Blaze remains at that safe house for the time being
11121112.content:
(The following chapter is rated 18+, so read at your own discretion, though I doubt it will stop you)


When Blaze awoke, he found himself in a dark place. He tried to open his eyes, yet all he could see was black. The bastards had blindfolded him with a rough leather strap. Blaze tried to move about, only to find that his limbs were extremely heavy. He was chained…as if he were a beast rather than a dragon.

Furthermore, he could smell the foul stench of a small crowd of humanoids gathered about him. In particular, he caught a whiff of that smug, arrogant elf nearby.

"So, it seems as though you're awake now beast," said the elf's unmistakable, slithery voice.

Blaze's hearts pumped with fear and hate at the sound of that voice.

"You'll pay for what you did elf!!” roared Blaze.

Instinctively, Blaze threw himself in the direction of that voice. He did not get far though, as suddenly his body was violently yanked backwards. Blaze tried again, but once again the thick iron chains defied his efforts.

“What was that you said?” taunted the elf.

“If you know what’s good for you, you’ll let me go right now!! My friends will come and get me out!! You'll see!!" cried Blaze through the muzzle.

The elf responded with that irritating laugh of his. "Is that so? Why should they or the authorities care about what happens to an orphan? If they had, would they have not rescued you by now? To them, you’re probably better off dead anyhow," he laughed. The other thugs joined in laughter. Blaze felt both hurt and humiliated. He had no idea how long he’d been out, yet the elf was right that if nobody had managed to find him by now, he wouldn’t be getting free anytime soon. Yet as frightened as he was at that cruel fact, as a drake, he could not afford to show weakness to them.

“You’re…trying to mess with my head aren’t you so that I’d give up!!” retorted Blaze. “You won’t break me!! One day, you’ll get what’s coming to you!!”

All of the sudden, there was a whipping noise, and a piercing pain burst against Blaze’s flank. Blaze let out a high-pitched yelp, both shocked and humiliated at what they’d done. They’d whipped him. By the Ancestors they’d whipped him as if he were a swine. Blaze cried out even louder when the whip came down the second time. Then it came again, and again, and again, until Blaze was left shivering against the cold, hard ground.

“I hope you have come to understand that I will accept no defiance out of you beast…” cried the elf.

“I-I’m not a beast… My name…is Blaze,” stammered the young Fire Drake. That earned him another few whips across the flank.

“You will never refer to yourself with that name ever again. Only people have names, and that being the case you are nothing more than an animal to be used at the whim of its master,” commanded the elf.

All Blaze could do at the moment was remain silent. He was a dragon, not a beast.

“You still don’t think so?” said the elf, sensing Blaze’s stubbornness, “Then I will prove it…”

There was a long, dreadful silence as Blaze prepared himself once more for the crack of the whip. There was the sound of a box opening, and with it the smell of fresh meat. Blaze’s stomach instantly began to churn. He had no idea how long he’d been out, but it surely had to have been quite a while considering how dreadfully hungry he was.

“You smell that don’t you?” taunted the elf. “Yes…its food…”

The elf tossed a batch of meat right in front of Blaze. Yet with his jaw muzzled, he could not reach out with his tongue and snap it up.

“I see that you’re hungry…” the elf continued. To Blaze’s surprise, the front flap that his blocking his snout swung open, and before he could stop himself he threw himself in front of the food and gulped it down. It tasted horrible, and frankly, he didn’t want to know what creature that it belonged to. Back in the orphanage, he’d used to make jokes about the meat packing companies in the industrial district, how they would throw in all sorts of creatures, including the stray vermin or even a stray humanoid if rumors were to be believed, into the meat grinders, pack it all together, and then call it beef. However, if it was between that and starving…

No sooner had he finished when they placed a large bowl of water in front of him. Or, at least that’s what Blaze thought it was, for it had a mildewy aftertaste and thought he could feel things squirm in his tongue as the water went down his throat. Again, best not to think what was inside.

Once he finished, the next thing he felt was a humanoid slide up from his backside and place what could only be a large bucket underneath him. “Now, I want you to defecate…” ordered the elf with the same, neutral voice.

“What?” snarled Blaze, outraged at the crude command. All around him, he could hear the kidnappers snickering under their breath.

“You heard me correctly, I want you to relieve yourself right now. I can’t have you stinking up the cargo during the journey can I?” replied the elf.

Blaze began to shiver. “I…I don’t have to go right now…” he insisted with a shaky voice. That earned him a whip against the flank.

“Do you need me to whip you again beast?” snapped the elf.

Blaze heaved a small breath, “No… I’m not going to poop. Not with all you around…” he said with a small voice.

Blaze prepared himself for the whip once more, yet this time they did something even more terrible. Blaze let out a high-pitched scream and his vision went white as something cold and hard was plunged into his rectum. His muscles flinched, but a moment later he felt a liquid get pumped into him. The water continued to pump in until Blaze's stomach began to cramp terribly, when unceremoniously the prod was yanked out. Suddenly, Blaze started to feel very full.

“Yes, you’re needing to relieve yourself any moment now aren’t you?” taunted the elf, which brought forth a chorus of laughter. He strained his jaw, trying to hold it in as long as he could.

No!! I can’t!! I can’t!! However, he couldn't hold it in anymore. He let out a huge fart as his bowels emptied out in an explosion, snapping his eyes shut in shame mixed with exquisite relief. Blaze felt his pride break then, as he began to wail in the absolute shame and humiliation at his emasculation.

“H-how could you? What have I ever done to you to deserve this? W-why?” whimpered Blaze, tears staining his leather blindfold.

The elf’s answer was short but cruel, “Because we can…”

There was the unhinged laughter of the humanoids, the stink of his excrement, his absolute helplessness to stop them from having done such a horrific thing, that awful, throbbing pain in his rectum. And thus, Blaze cried and cried, begging for his ordeal to end, that by the mercy of the Great Ancestors that he could die and his suffering would end.

As it turned out, Blaze's ordeal had only just begun.
11121112.title: Cruelty

choices: A small voice penetrated the darkness
111211121.content:
Blaze laid as still as a corpse as the cart that carried him continued to clank down an endless dirt road. He'd lost track of exactly how long he'd been carried in this manner, nor where it could possibly be going, yet all he knew was that since he had been tricked into following the kidnappers his life had degenerated into a grisly routine of pain and humiliation. His typical day would go like this. For most of the day, there was the endless boredom of be hauled in his cart, blindfolded and unaware of his surroundings. While the cart was rolling, Blaze never caused trouble. In a twisted sense, it had almost become his proverbial egg-shell; so long as he lay still and unmoving, he was safe from the elf and his evil henchmen.

Yet it was during the times that the caravan stopped that were the most horrible. He would be whipped, slapped and degraded, while he was fed rotted meat and fetid water, and then he’d be asked to defecate. After that horrific enema, he’d never needed to be asked more than once again.

The only thing that was keeping Blaze going was the hope that one day, should Blaze ever get free, he would make sure that each one of those cruel humanoids would suffer a grisly fate. He wanted to hear them scream and suffer and have them call out for mercy, just as they had done to him throughout the duration of the death march thus far.

Yet right now though, he was little more than a beast; cargo that had no right to protest its condition.

As Blaze continued to bemoan his fate, he was suddenly shaken out of his stupor by a flurry of activity. There were numerous humanoids about, but by now Blaze knew better than to scream for help. He knew that nobody was there, and it would only earn him a series of cruel lashings, which the kidnappers always eagerly looked for an excuse to administer at every possible moment.

The caravan slowly meandered to a stop. The cage that he was in was somehow lowered onto the ground, and then dragged along what sounded like a series of creaking, wooden planks. Then, inexplicably, his blindfold was removed from his eyes. Blaze recoiled at the light, having been essentially blind for the past month, but when his vision settled he saw a giant ship moored on the docks. Patrolling the decks were a whole bunch of humanoids dressed with shoddy clothing and armed with crude weapons. Most of the humanoids though were half-clothed males hauling cargo into the giant ship, being encouraged by the whips of their overseers.

“Now then beast, I want you to look presentable for the shipmaster do you understand. Remain in an upright position and do not move…”

“So you want me to look all nice and pretty is that what you’re saying? After all, I’m valuable cargo and you’re looking to make a nice profit from the transaction are you?” sneered Blaze.

That earned him a series of whips from the elf’s cronies. Blaze decided it was best not to provoke the elf any further. The cart was rolled to the edge of a harbor, stopping before a scarred, greasy looking man with missing teeth.

“Ah, so this is the specimen you’ve come to show me?” said the shipmaster.

“Indeed, I present a young male Fire Drake for shipment of sound health,” said the elf.

“Impressive as always, I’d expect nothing less from a Kleave. Of course, we’ll need to inspect the cargo of course…”

“I warn you that this one may prove to be particularly fierce shipmaster. I advise your inspectors to utilize caution,” said the elf, or rather Kleave. A team of humanoids began to approach with sticks, poking and prodding him with impunity.

Blaze growled at the humans. He didn’t care if it earned him a few more whips.

“A defiant one isn’t it?” said the shipmaster. “Ah yes, as you can see, Fire Drakes in particular are violent beasts by nature,” said Kleave, if that was indeed his real name, “It must constantly be reminded who its master is.”

“To the powers below take you!! I’m not an animal!! I’m a dragon!! You have no right to do this to me!! You'll never be my master!!” yelled Blaze.

Blaze came to regret his outburst. Right in plain sight, Kleave ordered a team of his thugs to bring forward a long pole whose rounded tip was doused in a strange liquid. Instantly, images of that horrific enema played out in his mind as panic overtook him.

“No!! Please!! Not that!! I’m sorry!! I didn’t mean to…” screamed Blaze, as the thugs rounded to his backside. He vainly tried to cover his backside and squirm his body away, yet the chains held him in place and cruelly exposed. His body instantly seized up and Blaze screamed louder than he’d ever screamed in his life as the rod was shoved up in his rectum. No sooner could he catch his breath, when the rod was yanked out and then shoved back in again, even deeper, and he collapsed in a heap. The third time, he didn’t even have the energy to resist, as he pissed all over the cage floor. All that came out of his throat by the fourth time was a pathetic mewling noise while shitting out blood-stained excrement, leaving him curled up and whimpering and wishing that the last one had killed him.

He’d been raped. Raped without reason, mercy or purpose. Out of the corner of his eye, Blaze could see the torturers walk away laughing, the edge of the pole stained with a combination of his excrement and blood.

“By the Gods, I hope you did not degrade the value of the cargo,” said the shipmaster, sounding more amused than concerned.

“This one, I’ve found, is a particular glutton for absorbing pain. In fact, I might go so far as to say that it actually enjoys pain of this particular manner…” sneered the evil elf. Blaze didn’t follow the rest of the conversation between the evil elf and the shipmaster, he was in too much pain to care for much of anything anymore as his cage was dragged into the cargo hold. He prayed to the Ancestors, wondering what he had done to deserve such a face, and praying that in their mercy that he could simply die.

The cargo hold door slammed shut with a menacing click. Blaze settled into the tight, smelly cargo hold, shivering at the damp, moldy air. Yet he could not get into a comfortable position. It just hurt…so…so much. As he laid there, he contemplated the various ways he could commit suicide. Perhaps he could slam his head against the bars until his skull broke open… Or, he could somehow get his tail free and cut out his throat. Yet those methods seemed like they would take a long time for him to die and would be extremely painful. Furthermore, the slavers would still be able to use his parts for their nefarious schemes. Drowning seemed a cleaner death, perhaps.

Yet as he was contemplating these grim possibilities,
111211121.title: Shipping cargo

choices: The ship arrives at its destination
The ship needs to stop and get resupplied before continuing on
1112111211.content:
“C-comrade…” said a small voice. Blaze arched his aching neck in the direction of the voice. Chained and caged on the opposite side of the cargo hold was a small, skinny drake about his age with dull brown scales. His hide was covered with lash marks and bruises, just as Blaze’s hide was no doubt.

“So, it looks like they got you too…” sighed Blaze. At this point, he didn’t care if the other dragon had seen him crying and whimpering, likely because his unfortunate companion had experienced the same kind of treatment and done his own share of crying and whimpering.

Neither of them were able to say anything to each other for a long while, but the two young drakes merely stared at one another eyes, united in their mutual misery and despair. What sort of horrors had he already experienced? After a while, the small copper dragon broke out in tears, as did Blaze a short while later. The lives they had previously lived had been shattered, and Blaze cried for the misery the dragon on the opposite side of the room had faced.

Yet for however long this boat ride was, at the very least Blaze had a companion. He might as well got to know his fellow unfortunate prisoner.

“I noticed that you addressed me as ‘Comrade’. Are you one of those barbarians…” asked Blaze. New Alveri was a cosmopolitan city, and he saw merchants come by from time to time.

“I am a Vastnyas!! A proud nomadic warrior of the steppes, not a ‘barbarian’ as you Baschmachi label us as…” the small drake insisted with a scratchy voice and trilling accent. While the 'Vastnyas', (not barbarians) had a reputation of banditry and perhaps even cowardise, when addressing the heritage they would show as much hubris and pride of a bronze dragon, and he small dragon seemed to be no exception.

“I suppose you are… Just not so loud or the torturers will come back won't they?” answered Blaze. The small dragon lowered his head. “Sorry," Blaze was nonetheless glad to see the small drake had regained his spirit, which was all the more important in times like these.

“I won’t make that mistake again…um…”

"My full name is Jinxieregouth…” answered the dragon.

Blaze was getting tongue-tied trying to merely pronounce the name. “Can I just call you Jinx?”

“Its improper, yet if you must I suppose that I don’t mind…” answered Jinx.

“My full name is Blaz-fyrazaird… but I’d rather you call me Blaze…” answered Blaze. That name was the only thing he remembered from his birth parents, before whatever circumstance led to him being abandoned.

“Very well then comrade Blaze. Though indeed the circumstances could be better, I'm glad to meet you nontheless…” cried Jinx, with an ironic smile. Blaze could only grunt with agreement, and for the first time since he'd been kidnapped, his jaw arched into a smile. Having someone to talk to did more to boost his flagging resolve than any display of pride or spontaneous outburst he had shown previously.

“How did you get caught?” asked Blaze.

Jinx’s gaze darkened. “My father was the Khan of the Colshek Clan, strong and feared by all. Then, without warning, we were betrayed by those who had pledged themselves as our allies. During the attack, father told me to flee while he and his host fought against them, and so I did. Yet I could not find another clan who was willing to take me in, or one that wasn’t controlled by our enemies, so I wandered alone, slowly reduced to nothingness. One that does not have a clan may well be already dead. One day, a group of humans found me and offered food; I should have known better than to trust those snaga, yet I was desperate and hungry… Thus, I find myself trapped here in these chains…”

Blaze sighed. The kidnappers always went after those who had nobody to look after them.

“And what of you comrade?” asked Jinx.

“I used to live in New Alveri. I was an orphan, but there were those who cared about me and were my friends. One day, there was an explosion, and I panicked. I followed a group of strangers, thinking they were going to lead me to safety… Turns out I was wrong,” said Blaze. He didn’t feel the need to reveal any more than that.

“Nichevo…” sighed Jinx, shaking his head back and forth. Truly, nothing more needed to be said than that.

“So, you said that you lived in New Alveri?” said Jinx.

“Yes? What about it?”

“I heard tales, about that great city built into the mountains. Our elder spoke of how there are towers made of jade that reach high up into the clouds, held up by ancient, arcane magicks. That it is a city of all peoples, races and creeds, where an individual can grow rich and live like a Great Khan solely by the strength of his ambition and cunning,” said Jinx.

Blaze sneered, “If New Alveri were so perfect, there wouldn’t have been an attack at the center of the city and I wouldn’t be here right now would I?”

“I suppose even a shining city like New Alveri has its dark side…” replied Jinx dryly.

Blaze could only nod in agreement. "That's the understantement of the century isn't it?"

“So, what do you think they’re going to do with us?” asked Jinx.

Blaze thought back to the hellish journey thus far. “Your guess is as good as mine, but it’ll likely involve something that has a lot of pain and torture.”

“Da… yet is there anything you might know of these slavers?” asked Jinx.

“When the kidnappers first held me in the prison, I saw them carrying a whole bunch of dragon eggs. These aren’t your typical street thugs, they’re really powerful and have a whole lot of money to do whatever it is they want to do. After meeting you here, I’m also convinced that there’s a lot of dragons like ourselves that they’ve kidnapped.”

Jinx let out a soft growl as his brows furrowed in contemplation.

“This is indeed alarming. If what you say is true, that these thieves have been able to escape the authority of the Knights, then this conspiracy must be vaster than either of us have imagined. A scheme this vast must have taken many years to plan, and that they have an ultimate objective they want to achieve through this conspiracy.”

“I really don’t care what it is they’re planning to do. I just want to get out of there as soon as I can…” growled Blaze.

“Yet I cannot envision any method to make our escape. You know this as well as I comrade…”

Deep in his gut, he knew that the small drake was almost certainly right. That elf, Elandrias, had already demonstrated his willingness to use the most brutal means to keep him in line, and that they had already come up with a number of safeguards in mind to prevent that from happening.

“What about committing suicide?” suggested Blaze.

“If we commit suicide, then they win. Suicide is the coward’s way out. All we can do right now to defy their will is for us to survive, no matter what it is they attempt to inflict upon us and no matter how detestable the means we must take to ensure this…” vowed Jinx.

“That’s true. We’ve already endured this much, so its pointless to give up now. Besides, one day I’m going to make sure they pay it all back. Mark my words…” growled Blaze, digging his claw into the metal.

Right at that moment, the door to the cargo hold burst open.

“Is that noise that I hear!?” came the captains voice. Behind him were a gang of pirates armed with whips, clubs, poles and other horrific looking devices.

Blaze and Jinx stared at each other and nodded, knowing what was to come. Thus, knowing that there was someone else that would be sharing his suffering, for the first time, Blaze didn’t quite feel as frightened anymore when the beatings began.
1112111211.title: Comrade of misery

choices: Their destination is an archipelago off the southern tip of Nod
11121112112.content:
Cold seawater splashed Blaze as a crewman ungracefully sluiced the deck using a hose and a pump operated by another hand on the top deck. The human's face was disgustingly marred with an enormous purple birthmark, almost a deformity and certainly the reason why he was a crew member on this renagade pirate and smuggling ship. It was, perhaps, also the reason why he took so much pleasure in dowsing the cringing dragon helpless and caged in the ship's main hold.

"Gonna clean you up! Beast!" laughed the man, lisping in an uneducated manner.

Blaze knew three languages as well as arithmetic and some algebra too. He doubted this man could so much as count his toes. Yet that didn't stop the frozen stream of water hitting his worn out and damaged body. He shouldn't have minded really, but the red dragon had lost a lot of weight since being captured as well as valuable muscle tone for being chained and unable to move very much for the last brutal months. He was half the dragon he used to be, his once mighty fire bladders hanging loose and empty at the base of his throat, his body unable to sustain itself fully on his diet of rotten meat and human castoff let alone produce fire. Blaze shivered as the water hit him again, his bony elbows knocking against his ribs.

After a month at sea, Blaze were beginning to wonder if he would even make it to their cursed destination. The beatings had stopped after Blaze and even Jinx himself lost the energy to resist or even talk very much, although brave seamen still came down on dark evenings, daring their buddies to kick the dragons. They mostly resigned this practice to Blaze, ever since Jinx relieved one of the competing men of his foot, boot and all; of course, seeing the was Jinx was molested after the affair, Blaze entertained no such illusions for his own amusement.

Despite the 'better' treatment, however, both dragons' health declined in the gloomy hold far from sunlight or fresh air. Even with daily sluicing, the hold remained a clammy, stinking environment. This was mostly due to the dragons themselves. Blaze had been suffering from a painful, often bloody diarrhea and as far as he could tell by the smell, Jinx himself was only slightly better off. The young red dragon suffered from headaches caused by his rampant thirst. What fresh water they afforded him - precious on the open sea - was tainted. Sometimes it was bubbly, likely collected deck wash or else salty like watered down sea water; once it even tasted strongly of humanoid piss.

Lying on his side was painful, but not the agony that resting on his belly was, with his partially torn vent pressing against the grates of the bottom of his iron cage. Blue bruises showed purple under his red scales, livid across his entire flank on both sides. They were miserably slow to heal and always tender to the touch. His coat of scaly armor remained intact save for two places, on on his left shoulder and another at the base of his tail, where the overzealous whipper had actually managed to break through the scales. The first time it'd happened had been on the trail, less than a day out from New Alveri when Blaze had been vigorous in his resistance. The shipmaster had lain open the dragon's skin with repeated blows from the strong leather whip. That night he'd been tied down and flogged with his own whip until his was bloodier than Blaze.

The reason for this was because the mark would leave a permanent scar on his shoulder, corrupting the seamless overlap of the scales, forever weakening it without major intervention by healing magics and surgery. From the affair, Blaze knew that his captors wanted him whole and as untouched as possible. It had laid to rest his fears of being taken for butchering, though the fact that they would capture him alive should have been enough of a hint. The second time Blaze's tough, armored skin had been broken, that elf who Blaze hadn't seen since being loaded on he ship, yet was certain was aboard somewhere, had strangled the man to death with the leather throng which had so abused the young drake.

It was only marginal satisfaction to watch. Still, what were a few scars compared to what they were doing now? Blaze coughed as the water hit his cage. The youth was certain he was going to get wet lung and die at this rate. Perhaps that would be for the best…

A tall man - tall for a human at least - stutted down the stairs, stepping over the canvas hose. He stared at the laughing idiot wielding the hose for a few moments. When the stream came back up, the midshipman decked Purple-face in the back of the skull, sending him face first into the stinking water that had been building up through his ineffective sluicing.

"Wash the deck only! You worthless cur." roared the minor officer.

The lowly seaman cowered, hands over his head in the filthy water.

His fear seemed only to infuriate the officer who delt him a kick to the midsection. "On your feet!"

Blaze watched with one eye, not daring to smile, as the seaman was shoved upstairs. Later came the cries of public punishment. Blaze numbly absorbed the fact that the humans were at least as brutal to each other as they were to him. He looked at Jinx across from him and exchanged glances. The muddy brown, mottled drake had been watching too. Carefully switching to his opposite flank, Blaze thought that he could survive at least one more day...

The small two masted privateer continued to sail south along the coast. Gradually, the weather got warmer, which was a relief now that Blaze was lacking an insulating layer under his skin. However, during the midday, the hold became almost unbearable hot and humid as the sun beat down on the planks of the deck above. One by one the livestock that were kept in the other side of the hold, separated from the dragons by a thin wooden partition - Blaze could tell by the scent - were slaughtered and eaten. After they were gone, came the dried salted meat. Blaze was soon dreaming about the rancid cast off and bones from the shipmen's tables.

Although they didn't talk much after that first day, mutual suffering created a bond between Blaze and the drake across from him. The barbarian had an odd manner of speaking and had quite a high opinion of himself for an outcast of both the Empire and his own roving tribe. However he was getting it just as bad as Blaze and despite the abuse seemed to possess an unquenchable font of strength and spirit. Intelligently, he kept his head and voice down, but always he would nip at his captors when their backs were turned, winking at Blaze afterwards, as if this were some sort of grand game. His indefatigable soul infused Blaze himself with a need to live, survive where he himself might have foundered.

In fact, their efforts turned into something of a friendly male rivalry. Blaze could not show how weak he really felt, not when Jinx still seemed so viable. He'd show him that he was at least as strong as he was! It was a poor jest, really, but it was better than dying.

Then came a day, particularly warm in Blaze's opinion, when the ship stopped. There was bustling feet overhead and the screeching of ropes and pulleys. Through one of the open sluice ports, Blaze spied a dinghy being lowered over the side, in it he saw the elf! The Kleave!

"Psst." Blaze hissed quietly.

Jinx lifted his head were he'd been dozing. He followed Blaze's stare.

"What are they doing?" Blaze asked.

"Perhaps they are going ashore?" replied Jinx uncertainly. As an inland barbarian, the mottled drake probably had even less experience with the sea than Blaze, although he had one or two decades on him.

"I hope they bring back a few goats..." muttered Blaze. He'd gone from washing the deck with blood tinged effuse to being painfully blocked up on a diet of dried meat. He strongly wanted to gnaw on some spindly, leafy Elf's Hair, or even just ordinary grass.

Gingerly, Blaze lowered his head to the bottom of his cage to see out the tiny sluice port. His vent touched the bars, but it was against the scale side and by now it'd resealed itself as well so he didn't mind so much. Out across the water, Blaze saw a green island... so close! if only he could fly...

"There's an island." Blaze informed his companion in pain.

Jinx grunted an affirmation and said nothing. They were both beyond the world of their ken and he knew it. There was nothing to be said save useless and idle speculation that could only result in more harm.

The ship took on more supplies and sailed on further to the south. No one bothered to inform the prisoners about the island pit stop.
11121112112.title: In the Hold

choices: Jinx rocks his cage and smashes into the crane.
111211121121.content:
The ship carrying the captive drakes did not travel nearly as long from the island supply stop as it had taken to get there. In fact, less than a score of days had passed since Blaze had seen the small ship lowered into the water before there was a flurry of activity above the hold.

Bare human feet pounded the seasoned wood as seamen hushed to and fro about their unfathomable tasks. There were shouts from the middies as well as the bosun, whipping the men into the orderly frenzy of activity that it took to control the wooden, sail-driven ship. It all meant little to Blaze who languished in his cage, sore and ill. Whether this be their final destination or another pit stop, the red drake only hoped that this meant that he could finally be moved from out of his small cage; even if only to be moved to a different cage.

The manacles at his wrists and ankles chaffed despite the protection offered by his scales. He had not been able to open his wings in nearly two months. It'd been over a week since he last shat; though Blaze supposed that he should be grateful, given the circumstances of his most greivous insult and injury. Still, he was cramping so badly on his diet of dried and salted meat that he was almost tempted to turn away his meager rations... almost.

When Blaze was consumed by restlessness despite his general lack of energy nowadays, he took to peering out the tiny sluice port set in the floor. Resting his jaw on the floor, he peeked out at a sliver of the world beyond his confinement and saw something other than the ubiquitous water he'd been expecting. Oh, there was definitely water, but there were also little rocky mounds rising out of the sea. Some were expansive, others only a few feet across, but never did they rise more than a foot out of the water. The stone itself was odd, and below the waves, Blaze could see hints of vibrant color and movement, as if of great schools of fish. What foreign place have these mad humans taken me to? Blaze wondered in despair, though he could not help but appreciate the beauty he saw in the coral reef they were passing through, though he knew not the names for the things he saw.

Once the ship banged loudly against something and Blaze was sent jarring forward until his nose collided with the bars of his cage. There was shouting overhead and rapid nautical instructions called out that the city drake could not begin to decipher; all about "mast-lines" and "port" and "rigs." The young fire drake had lurid delusions of the ship sinking into the abyss, he, the elf and all the wretched humans with it.

Across from him, Jinx lifted his head. He drew in a big draught of air. "The humans stink of fear." He said as if sharing a comment about how pleasant the weather is.

Blaze, still dreaming of vengeance and self-destruction asked hopefully, "Do you think the ship will go down?"

The mottled drake flicked his tongue out and tasted the air, Blaze saw for the first time that it was indeed narrow and forked. He titled his head this way and that. "Doubt it, comrade." he muttered. "Ship still feels true." He paused, "Is good ya?"

Blaze snorted, unwilling to abandon the image of unworthy humans being swallowed by the sea they so worshiped and feared.

Jinx continued, a little more talkative than usual, perhaps sensing Blaze's mood. "I hope the ship does not sink."

Blaze stared at him and lifted an eye ridge. "Why?" He asked. He did not need to list the reasons why it might be nice to never reach their destination, to suffer no more pain or indignity at humanoid hands.

Jinx actually mustered up a grin, though the scales creaked at the corners of his mouth through disuse. "I vant to eat every svoloch' human on this ship. I cannot do this if they all die."

Blaze just stared at Jinx. Something in the drake's eyes told him that he really thought that he was going to have his revenge. Blaze tucked his head against his arm and tried to nap, seeking escape in unconsciousness. Ancestors grant him luck in his revenge, that was all he could think of. Blaze was beyond feeling pity for anyone on this ship, save for perhaps himself.

For the greater part of a day, the ship remained stranded on the coral reef. Eventually however, the crew somehow got the boat off of the submerged obstacle it had grounded itself on and to Blaze's chagrin, it did not immediately sink into the waves. Another day passed before they finally reached their final destination.

Blaze saw little of the place which would become his new home on the approach. It was not until the hatch was opened above and the wooden grate fetched out with hooked poles that he even was able to glimpse the sky for the first time in two months. The tropical sun was blinding. Blaze shut his eyes tight against the luminescence, although the sunlight on his scales felt oh-so-good, almost expunging them of some of the filth ground into his hide.

It took an hour for him to be able to blink his watery eyes open and by that time, they were lowering in a stout cable from the dock crane. They secured his cage at four corners and lifted him out. Despite years of flying the ungraceful rocking of the iron cage in the wind filled Blaze with rampant vertigo. He vomited a thin stream of bile, but it fell uselessly into the water below before he could think to at least aim it.

When he was able to look around, Blaze gasped at what he saw. It was an entirely different world.

It was another island. The young dragon could tell that much from the start. The small privateer was moored in a cove about 120 dragon lengths across, the water a rich, aqua blue, as if pulled straight from a painting. To the north, the cove was nestled against a steep rocky hill; the stone was porous and black, studded with low caves at the water's edge. Fine yellow sand, tinged here and there with streaks of black mingled with white surf all along the cove. Palm trees towered along the shore, the bases of their trunks littered with black detritus and fallen fruit among the sand. Beyond, further into the island, rose a single conspicuous mountain. Steam rose in a thin stream somewhere on its opposite slope.

It was all too much to take in at once. There was a din of calling birds whose songs Blaze had never learned as well as the hoots of several animals he didn't even recognize. There was the groaning of the crane supporting his considerable bulk and that of the heavy iron cage. The hustle and bustle of the docks he was moving slowly towards.

And it was quite an extensive dock. Blaze's eyes widened when he saw two large, what could only be warships, docked alongside the pathetic looking privateer. The ships were oddly designed, with huge flat bows like paddles, almost large enough for a dragon to land on, Blaze would wager. The docks also sported large warehouses and what could only be a drinking house. Looking at the base of the crane, Blaze saw strange blue-skinned humanoids of an unknown type laboring at a large crank. Looking closer, Blaze saw their wrists bound by chains to the poles they were pushing, ever around and around, providing the power to turn the crane.

"Faster, you troll dogs!" cried a human as he snapped a loud crack out of his whip in the air.

"Trolls..." Blaze muttered. He thought they'd been driven out of Nod after the Rebellions. It seemed their kind was still destined for subjugation after all.

The last thing that Blaze noticed before the sails of the ship rose to block his view were the two tall stone towers rising at either end of the cove. One was set on the rocky prominence at the north side, and the other on a lower hill at the western side, but they were built to rise to the same height. Grim faced elves and a couple dwarves kept watch on all that went on below as they strutted back and forth among the battlements.

Blaze was clutching the bars under him tightly with his paws as his cage came finally to a stop on the dock. Though he was weary, he stood, looking around, wanting to memorize his surroundings in case he'd never get the opportunity to see them again. The dock workers didn't mind, secure now in the fact that escape was impossible. The trolls were ordered to reverse direction and the crane cable rose to fetch the next passenger.
111211121121.title: The Island

choices: The entrance of a cave, leading to a top secret facility
1112111211211.content:
There went Jinx, and with a great amount of regret, Blaze watched as the small drake’s cage was lowered onto the dock opposite of the ship. Their gazes met for a brief moment, and Blaze was tempted to call out for the closest thing he had to a friend, and wish him luck in the ordeals that were to follow, but with the guards watching they contented themselves with encouraging nods.

Once the cage had lowered out of his line of sight, Blaze wondered if that was the last he would ever see of the barbarian. Blaze could say with confidence that had he not met Jinx, he may not even be alive at this point, or at the very least his spirit would have been completely broken by now. If there were any drake with the audacity, courage, spirit and intelligence to endure, survive and possibly escape the horrors that were to be in store, it would be Jinx. The very least that Blaze could do was to do the same…

However, Blaze had more immediate concerns now, as the Kleave had now stepped off the boat. Blaze remained silent as the Kleave delivered his customary series of whippings and insults. He kept his gaze down and miserable, hating the elf, but knowing the humiliation that awaited him if he lashed out the way Kleave was trying to provoke him into.

To his relief, Kleave's malicious rage was not reserved for him this day, but rather toward the team of twenty or so half-naked troll slaves assigned to his cage. The trolls hissed and grumbled to themselves in their guttural, trilling language as they fastened Blaze’s cage with a pair of pulling chains. Perhaps as a means to further demonstrate to Blaze the consequences in store should he not remain submissive, Kleave cast a spell, and all of the sudden, their chain collars began crackling a bright red, as the trolls instantly clutched at their necks, groaning and gasping in pain.

Blaze could only watch with held breath as they writhed and choked, until finally, mercifully, the Kleave ended the torture. However, this had been too much for one unfortunate troll as it remained thrashing on the ground while foaming at the mouth. A gang of thugs immediately surrounded the troll, whereupon it was mercilessly beaten with clubs, until nothing was left but a limp, battered body. Blaze was left aghast. He’d thought that he’d been treated badly, but he would have bet that any troll would love to exchange places with him.

“Get that filth out of my sight…” growled the Kleave. A pair of humanoids unhooked the dead troll from its chain and lifted the limp body as if it weighed nothing more than a feather and tossed it into a large bin, in which limbs from several other bodies could be seen sticking out from the side. The dead troll’s space was then replaced by another unfortunate troll.

“Now, I don’t want anymore disturbances from you animals!! Get this cage moving now!!” snapped the overseer.

Blaze immediately felt sorry or the trolls as they laboriously began hauling Blaze’s cage inland. If they had been treated anywhere near as badly when they had been servants to Nod, it was no wonder that they had risen up into violent rebellion. Yet there was nothing he could do to help them, especially when he already had his claws full trying to keep himself alive.

About half an hour later, the cage reached its final destination. He found himself at…
1112111211211.title: The ones even worse off...

choices: The dragon in the cell across from Blaze speaks after a time
Blaze is soon picked up and 'evaluated' by a scientist
11121112112111.content:
The cage squeaked and rattled on its wooden sled as it was pulled laboriously uphill along the narrow jungle path. Three rows of young male trolls were needed to shift the incredible mass of the dragon, iron cage and heavy wooden cart up the hill towards the mountain.

Blaze was in pain, having been freshly beaten through the bars of his cage for the first time since starting the horrid sea journey which had nearly claimed his life; well, he had been whipped that time that Jinx had eaten the sailor's leg, but at least there had been some sort of reason. Now it appeared that things were returning to the standard course he'd experienced on the trail from New Alveri. The sight of the elf - that 'Kleave' - filled Blaze with dread now that he had deigned to depart his - undoubtedly lavish - suite aboard the ship. He walked alongside the cage and the young drake was afraid to so much as look in his direction, as if looking upon the elf's fine features might bring about the whips of the men trundling along behind the cage.

But the Kleave seemed more interested in punishing the trolls ahead of him than the cowering Blaze. The blue skinned humanoids, their legendary ornate tusks clipped and broken just beyond their lips, sweated a smelly lavender liquor as they worked. And yet no amount of effort seemed to be enough as the cage made but slow progress towards the base of the steaming mountain ahead.

A particularly scarred troll second from the rear in the row nearest the elf stumbled to his knees. Wearing nothing but a crude loin cloth, the bedraggled humanoid gasped for breath, and struggled to rise. But not fast enough for the Kleave. The elvish master strode forward with the lithe effortless speed of his kin and savagely kicked the troll across the chest with a twirling, uprising leg. The troll was lifted upward into the arms of the one behind him, wheezing. "No breaks! No rest for misbegotten curs like you. HÃ» Ã lia durth!" The elf spat into the face of the injured troll and stalked back to his place beside the rolling cage.

Despite his own situation, Blaze could not help but feel horrible for the poor creatures forced to pull the heavy weight of the cage. If he could have, he would have gladly walked, even riddled with chains, to spare the smaller folk this task. But Blaze was not daring enough to risk opening his mouth. Jinx might have been, but then Jinx would probably not have cared a whit about the trolls' plight either. So Blaze watched them pull and piled the guilt on his shoulders to endure later.

There was some movement to the side, but Blaze was not paying attention, instead keeping his head down and trying to distract himself with the beauty of the passing jungle. Trails of scent cross the path at intervals, wild boar - of a type strange, and yet familiar - lived on the island. Then a sharp pain afflicted his temple accompanied by a loud crack. Blaze let out a weak, coughing growl of pain as the elf laughed, a hand to his midsection and the whip tangling from his hand. "No sleep for you either dragon!"

The whip lashed again, this time at the thick joint where his wing met his shoulder. "On your feet! That's right, nice dragon, good dragon." laughed the pitiless elf as Blaze stumbled to his feet within the cage, rocking it and making the trolls' jobs harder.

Blaze did not speak. The appearance of dignity was not worth the additional pain. The young drake was so cowed he still did not look down at the little form who so inflicted this pain on him. He was only grateful that there was just the elf alone - for now - and not a dozen more torturers on all sides of him. Who had he become? he wondered vaguely.

The Kleave laughed and comanded Blaze to lift one foot, then another, to cross his eyes. All of which Blaze did without thought, though this did not seem to please the elf so much as irritate him. "Bah! You are no dragon. Le a nor! A worm!" Grimly setting his fine features, the elf lashed out through the bars of the cage repeatedly, not caring where he hit Blaze. All the drake could do was try to keep the delicate bones of his wing out of the path of the whip. Fresh bruises rose beneath his already mottled red scales.

When the elf tired, he wiped his brow with a white cloth, the tropical heat getting even to him. He handed off his instrument of pain carelessly to a dirty human assistant. He sidled closer to the cage, even daring to rest his arm on the lower rim of the shaking cart. If Blaze could just reach out with a single claw… But no, nothing was as it seemed with an elvish mage. This Kleave was never unarmed.

"Dragon… Oh I do so tire of calling you that. Dragon this, dragon that." Blaze almost opened his mouth to speak his name, something not said much in the past three months, even to Jinx. The elf saw but decided not to punish him for it. He waved a hand. "Oh, I do know you think you have a name, beast. But don't worry, they shall give you another very soon. It should be just around the next bend here… Ah! your new home."

Blaze was beginning to wonder if the elf was drunk, speaking to him so; not that he much cared with the stinging bruises under his skin. But he did turn his eyes forward and at the same times realized that the path had leveled out and they were moving faster now.

A dark earthen mouth loomed ahead. Dwarven make obviously, the angles of the stone-wrought arch were geometrically perfect. A trapezoid, however, simply plain and unadorned with dwarfish runes which were so common in New Alveri. Blackness oozed within.

Blaze took a cowardly step back until his tail touched the rear of the 'small' cage. His only recently healed rectum tightened. The adjacent penile sheeth throbbed as he clasped his thighs tightly shut. It remained unmolested so far, but Blaze had the horrible premonition that that might change within the darkness ahead.

The elf laughed seeing Blaze's reaction. "You are afraid, beast. As you should be! My touch will shortly seem as light as a wilwarin; butterfly. Alas, I fear we may never see each other again." said the elf in mock dismay, "I am to return up the coast to retrieve yet more young dragons. We seem to run through them so quickly! Ha!"

It was obviously the elf's intention to frighten him… and it was working. Blaze's spirits sank to a new low and his head nervously tossed this way and that as they entered the darkness under the mountain. Like a rat aboard a sinking vessel, Blaze wished forlornly to be anywhere else.

His dragon eyes adjusted quickly to the subterranean light level. Normally he would have felt at home underground - almost as much as in the air - but not now. All Blaze felt was unbridled dread. A dozen scenarios raced through his head. He wanted to bash himself against his iron cage, kill anything in reach of the bars... but his long voyage had left him weak and lacking energy so there was no hope of breaking the stout bars. Torture and whipping had brutally subdued any fight in him as well... and Blaze was aware of it. It shamed him to know it as well.

There was a right angle turn and now the way was lit with widely spaced lamps. The elf walked briskly in the gloom, but the trolls and the humans stumbled a bit. The cage rattled to a stop when the elf walked forward to knock on a door set in the side of the straight, high-ceilinged passage. He and the room's dwarven occupant exchanged words in Elvish and Blaze wished he'd taken more time to learn it. As it was, he only caught one word, or rather a number. Seven. The dwarf sported a fiery red and twin braided beard and wrote several notes on a large sheet of parchment at the elf's dictation. The last addition was a single ruby scale - one of his! - attached to the paper with paste. The elf must have plucked it early on in the journey for it was bright and unmarred. Afterwards, the dwarf stored the file away in a rack containing many such documents.

After the stone door closed, the elf spoke to the leader of the motley human group. "Take it to cell four in C-wing." The human saluted and began to turn, but the elf continued. He looked disdainfully at the troll he'd kicked earlier. "After you get these things back to the pens, cut off that one's ears and have them brought to me."

The beared human did not so much as flinch at the gruesome command. "Yessir." he said.

Before he was wheeled off and carefully forced into a new stinking cell, the elf spoke again briefly to Blaze. "Well then. Welcome to DarmÃ»t... Flamer-7. If you are strong, and lucky, you just might be a part of history."

The elf's departing cackle seemed to echo in the stone walls long after Blaze was shoved into his cell and left to wallow in darkness.
11121112112111.title: The Cave

choices: Blaze finds himself in a laboratory
He's back in his cell, as are a team of torturers
111211121121111.content:
Blaze laid curled in the darkness of his new cell, shivering and frightened. The temptation was extremely strong to keep his head down and close himself away from the misery that surrounded him. Gingerly, he forced himself to lean his head against the bars of his cell and look around.

The center of the chamber was a bloody, ragged mess of mangled bones, rotting excrement and ever-present flies. Fat vermin the size of a humanoid child scurried about the chamber like kings. Yet the most horrifying and heart wrenching sight beheld him when he gazed to the side. There were several other holding cells identical to his, and imprisoned within were young fire drakes like himself. They laid there dull, lifeless and broken, uncomprehending toward the world. In fact, the Fire Drake in the cell to right was a dead stinking corpse, literally nothing more than a mat of skin and bones. Yet its jaw was screwed into one of intense agony; it had died a horrific death it seemed.

The sight nearly made Blaze lose his mind, and probably would have in short order, when a voice broke out from the opposite side of the chamber.

“Oh, so you’re 7 eh? Don’t worry, you’ll be just like him soon!!” growled a voice.

That shocked Blaze out of his madness, as he raised his head across the dingy chamber toward a thick fire drake that had previously been asleep. His hide was filthy with dirt, grime and dried blood, more brown than red now. There was a predatory glint in the drake’s eyes, one that immediately chilled him to the bone.

“Dragons like you get replaced all the time you know…” he said, in a matter of fact kind of way.

Despite the uneasiness Blaze felt, the drake across from him seemed to be the only one who had his wits about him. “R-replacement? What do you mean?” answered Blaze, though he already suspected what it meant.

The drake across from him delivered a scathing laughter. “The cell you’re in right now used to belong to Flamer 3 and then 5. I’ve watched two losers who used to be in that same cell as you get brought here, waste away and then get replaced.”

Fear once more gnawed at Blaze’s belly as he pondered how long it would take until he became a lifeless corpse like the others. “I can already tell that both of them had more fight than you do. I’m betting it won’t take any more than two weeks for you to become the third… Everyone here knows I’m the strongest dragon here, and the sooner that you accept that fact I might decide to let you live a bit longer,” he taunted.

Blaze was completely taken aback by the drake’s attitude. It was one thing when it was the Kleave tormenting them, as no matter how much he could defy him, ultimately there was nothing he could do against him. Yet the fact that this dragon was openly taunting the fact that he’d taken satisfaction from deliberately breaking the will and causing the deaths of his own peers, fellow prisoners like himself, caused a surge of great anger began to build within his hearts. Back at the orphanage, Blaze had faced his share of bullying from the older fledglings, but back then, Darzhja had been there to stand up to them. Though he wasn’t the bravest dragon in all of Nod, somebody had to tell that bully and not let him do whatever he wanted, even in a place like this, or rather, especially in a place like this.

“Maybe you’re right that I’ll probably be dead before too long, and that there’s nothing we can do against the slavers. That doesn’t mean I have to take shit from an asshole like you!!” snapped Blaze. The outburst shook all the other dragons awake, and while they weren’t exactly energized with great enthusiasm, they were now at least taking an active interest in what was going on in their otherwise dreary and meaningless lives.

“So that’s what you think eh? I’ve heard 4 and 5 say that you know. What makes me think you’ll be different?” he taunted. Blaze knew that calling him out like that would focus all of the attention of Flamer-2 onto himself, but it was clear that he wasn’t out to make friends here. If Flamer-2 would become a sworn enemy, he had to do something that would force the other drake to hesitate before deciding to trifle with him again. In fact, the best way to get their respect was to do something absolutely reckless and insane.

“What is your name?” snarled Blaze, suddenly alert from his stupor.

“Flamer-2,” the drake responded without hesitation.

“Flamer-2” sniffed Blaze with disdain, “I meant your real name…”

There was a sudden intake of breath amongst the others. Blaze hadn’t realized the ruckus he’d caused by asking this simple question. The bully was taken aback, “Do you take me for a fool? I’m not about to get suckered into getting tortured for something like that!! Especially from a dumb newbie!!”

Of course, Blaze didn’t think he would be that stupid; speaking his name out loud would no doubt enrage the humanoids and result in him getting sodomized at best, yet that wasn’t the point. He had unsettled Flamer-2, and Blaze grinned as a result, even though in his heart he was scared out of his mind.

Blaze pressed himself against the bars of his cell, “So, all your boasts about being the strongest dragon here are nothing but a lie. You delude yourself into thinking that you’re the strongest, but in reality the fact that you accept the name Flamer-2 so easily only shows that you’ve fully embraced the fact you are a tool for them. However, if you really think you’re so brave and tough, that you’re actually a dragon instead of a beast, and though I’ve got no choice but to be called Flamer-7, I don’t have to accept it. So how about it? Both of us will say our names!! Will it get us tortured, definitely, but it’ll prove that we really are dragons and not slaves. Are you a drake or are you a beast?”

Flamer-2 hesitated and looked deeply troubled, and Blaze took that opportunity to pull off his gambit.

“My name is Blaz-fyraird. One day I’m getting out of here and make all those bastards pay for what they did to us!!” he shouted. Jinx would likely be proud of him; there was time where accepting pain was worth the point he wanted to get through.

Yet just when Blaze was about to relish in Flamer-2’s uneasy scowl, the collar around Blaze’s neck glowed a sinister blue color. A shattering pain encompassed every inch of his body, as he let out a horrific scream. The high-voltage electric shock had lasted only for several seconds, but it felt like centuries, leaving Blaze literally smoking in his cell and his body twitching, loosing his bowels upon the coarse, stone floor. His vision faded in and out, until moments later he fell unconscious, wondering if his outburst had been worth it.

When he awoke...
111211121121111.title: Are you a dragon or are you a beast?

1112111211211111.content:
"… core temperature." Came a soft voice as if from a great distance. "One-hundred fifteen point six degrees."

"Normal." said another voice, lower and with tones of firm authority. "Wingspan?"

"Twenty-one and a half feet." said the first voice.

The voices were coming closer, getting clearer.

"Weight?" Finer sounds were coming now, the scratching of soft lead on paper or parchment, the light tapping of feet on tile, and other, stranger sounds; the whispering of mechanically moving parts.

"Nine-hundred and thirty-eight pounds, sir."

"Severely underweight for a drake this age." There was a sigh. "What a state they bring these dragons in, especially the drakes." The last comment elicited no response, though movement quieted around the room for a few brief moments.

After the interlude, a younger voice asked. "Shall I start the bloodwork, sir?"
