11121112112111111112.content:
Blaze felt his pride rankle as he turned to face the dwarf, "Is there anywhere I can relieve myself?"

"What?" snapped the dwarf. "An...why should eye let ye do that eh?"

Out of the corner of his eye, he saw Flamer-2 grin, as if anticipating the beating. A pair of the dwarves thugs brandished their whips, while the dwarfs hand fingered a rune that he figured would activate the collar around his neck. Blaze strained, desperately trying to think of some way to avoid a messy and humiliating outcome, and at that moment came an unexpected stroke of genius. He remembered that the guards weren’t treated much better than the prisoners, nor were they particularly smart, nor were they inherently cruel by nature and without either the mad doctor or the cruel transit carriers keeping watch to stir up fear, he was confident he could negotiate some sort of deal.

"Please....I really have to go... I don’t want to end up having to stink the place up and make things miserable for you here.”

“I-I'll work an extra hour in the mines if you let me go!!" growled Blaze. He even meant his last pledge. He'd become skilled at this sort of negotiation when he was helping out in the merchant district, and there was no reason why this couldn't work here. Plus, dwarves in particular appreciated those offering to shoulder extra work voluntarily, and he thought it would be a good idea to get on the handler’s good side quickly.

"Fine then... I'll take you tae relieve yourself, but its back to work right after that!! I'm holding you to your word dragon!!" the dwarf growled.

“Yes sir…” answered Blaze.

He pulled Blaze away toward another tunnel where an wretched stink drifted forth. It was a giant, hastily made cesspool, which was so overwhelming in its stench that it nearly made Blaze vomit. Even though his standards of cleanliness had degenerated greatly since New Alveri, this was a new low in terms of sheer squalor.

He drifted toward a relatively cleaner section of the cesspool, (which currently was being cleaned up by an unfortunate troll slave) squatted down and violently expelled a weeks worth of clogged up sewage, sighing with an almost exquisite relief.

No sooner was he finished did he immediately rush out, whereupon the dwarf handler quickly escorted him back to the edge of the tunnel. Flamer-2 glared at him with a combination of rage and disbelief that Blaze was able to get what he wanted virtually scott free. He’d gotten another leg up upon Flamer-2, but the thinly consumed rage in the rivals eye worried him. No doubt that he was planning some way to get him back for his stunt, so it was best to keep prepared.

Yet for the first couple of hours or so, the two young drakes worked in stony silence. Blaze had done this kind of work every so often in one of the various jobs that Lady Ramoth had assigned to him at the orphanage so after a few initial missteps he got the hang of this work.

When guards attention began to drift, Flamer-2 began his retaliation. It started very subtly at first. As he dug, he would do so in such a way that dirt and pebbles would shower over Blaze with each strike of the claw. It would get in his eyes and into his nostrils. Blaze tried to ignore it at first; he knew in his gut that if drawn into direct physical confrontation with Flamer-2 he’d probably lose. Blaze curved his gaze over toward Flamer-2, yet the other drake gave him an impassive expression, as if he weren’t doing anything wrong. After an hour of this, it got to the point where Blaze felt he had to retaliate or else he’d never stop.

Hoping to catch the larger dragon by surprise, Blaze snatched a particularly large chunk of dirt and rock with his tail and flung it in the direction of Flamer-2. A lot of it caught Flamer-2, as he’d hoped, but unfortunately a large cloud of dust also drifted over toward the guards standing watch. They coughed and gagged, before focusing their gazes toward Blaze. Right then Blaze knew he’d made a mistake and had played right into Flamer-2’s trap.

“Flamer-7!! I’ll have you know that I will not tolerate mischief at this time!!” snarled the dwarf in annoyance.

“But sir… Flamer-2 was…”

Blaze briefly switched his gaze toward Flamer-2, who gazed as if daring him to tattle on him. No, that would be a bad idea. A hatchling would tattle, not a drake, and thus like a drake Blaze had to accept that Flamer-2 had gotten the better of him this time around.

“I apologize sir, it won’t happen again,” answered Blaze, lowering his head.

The dwarf handler grunted, but nonetheless seemed satisfied he decided just to accept whatever punishment he got. One of the human guards strode over and administered a sharp, painful whack across Blaze’s back with a whip. Blaze bit back the pain, conscious not to cry out in front of Flamer-2.

“Be lucky it ain’t worse than that!! Get back to work!!” growled the dwarf.

“Yes sir…”

As Blaze turned to resume his work, he could not help but catch a glimpse of that hideous grin of triumph on Flamer-2’s face.

“Sucker…” he whispered, giving Blaze a poke on the wing joint before getting back to work. Blaze could only steam in frustration.

From then on, Blaze was more careful in his retaliations. The rest of the shift, Flamer-2 contented himself with shoving and nipping at Blaze. He gave it back as best he could, yet when he responded he did so while still worried about the guards seeing him do it. However, Flamer-2 seemed to have an uncanny knack for bumping, shoving and poking without drawing the attention of any of the guards. It also prevented him from getting as much work done as he could have. For all of his constant harassment of Blaze, Flamer-2 excavated a far larger quantity of rock and mineral than Blaze could, a testament to his superior physical strength and his experience.

By the end, Blaze was both physically and mentally exhausted. His claws were raw and bleeding, and every muscle of his body ached, accentuating the small bruises received from Flamer-2’s constant badgering. Yet he couldn’t afford to show how exhausted he was in front of Flamer-2, who didn’t seem to grow tired at all from what he could tell.

However, what really rankled was when a guard (the dwarf handler had ended his shift hours before) congratulated Flamer-2 on a job well done, and promptly having one of his guards bring down a large, juicy slab of meat, which Flamer-2 savored in an exaggerated fashion specifically to torment Blaze. Afterwards, Flamer-2 was manacled and escorted back up toward the cells.

Blaze was left to labor on for the next hour that he had agreed to, in which every minute of that hour felt like an hour in and of itself. By then, he wanted nothing more than to simply collapse into a heap and hopefully never wake up ever again.

Finally, his ordeal was finished, and like a zombie, allowed the guards to escort Blaze back to his cell. Compared to the long day at the mines, being back in his rough, dusty cell was almost like being back in the egg. As he sprawled himself on the ground, his last thought before falling asleep was whether he had successfully held his own against Flamer-2.
11121112112111111112.title: 2 vs 7, Round 1

111211121121111111121.content:
Doctor Moridin gazed impassively down at Blaze, as the Fire Drake found himself held against the examining table.

“You have not answered my question Flamer-7,” Moridin said oily, if there were a receptive drakka here right now, would you fuck her?”

A young fire drakka that resembled a cross between Ophelia and Iskierka gazed at Blaze with a worried, vulnerable gaze, as she swung her hips back and forth and raised her tail.

“N-no…I’d…not without getting to know her first…” he insisted.

“Oh you wouldn’t?” cried a new voice. It was Flamer-2. “If you won’t, I certainly will!!” he growled, and instantly began raping her in the most brutal way imaginable.

“No!! Stop!!” shouted Blaze. Yet the doctor blocked off the scene with that deadly gaze of his.

“You have disappointed me Flamer-7… I thought you a drake, but it seems you are but a cowardly hatchling…” said Dr. Moridin.

“Thus, I see no reason for you to keep your package…” he answered.

Blaze squirmed against his restraints. “Please!! No!! Not that!! Give me another chance!!”

Blaze went delirious with fear as Dr. Moridin’s gloved hand transformed into what could only be described as a long, flexible metallic tentacle with a serrated edge, aimed right at his crotch.

“No!! No!!”

Right then, Blaze’s eyes snapped open, panting at the top of his breath. He was back in his cell, as he quickly discovered. It had only been a bad dream, of which he’d had many of since his imprisonment. Yet it was only after he’d checked between his legs and discovered that everything was where it was supposed to be did he finally breath a sigh of relief.

“I’ve got to get a hold of myself…” Blaze panted to himself. He remembered Darzhja telling him that the worst possible thing to do in the heat of battle wasn’t necessarily being scared. It was panicking. He’d panicked on the day New Alveri was attacked, and that was the reason why he was languishing in a stinking, clammy, vermin-riddled prison.

There wasn’t much time for him to reflect, as right then, the central torch came on. Whether or not it truly signaled the coming of morning or not was irrelevant at this point; there was no way to tell what time of day it was inside this clammy cave, but what he did know was that he had to be alert.

The dwarven handler and his usual team of thugs came forth, but this time they had a team of trolls hauling a large pot. The smell that came from the pot was extremely foul, as if twenty different varieties of meat had deliberately been left to rot, and then injected with fifty different chemicals.

Protruding from the end of the pot was a spigot, which was placed in between the bars, after which a strange, gray substance oozed out and splattered into a deformed ball at his feet. Blaze nearly retched, even considering his low standards nowadays. For a while, he just stared at the mixture, wondering if this was really food or if it was a sick joke from the jailors. Then, each of the other drakes were allotted a large portion of this sticky gray stuff as well, all of whom seemed equally surprised to see this new substance.

“W-what the hell is this shit?” groaned Flamer-2, almost sidling away from the strange gray ooze when it splattered in front of him.

For a moment, Blaze expected that he would be immediately whipped, yet apparently the substance was so unpalatable that the dwarven handler didn't seem to have the heart to administer it.

“Don’ ask me. All eye heard was that its some strange new concoction devised by them doctors. Said it was supposed to make ye strong or something like that. All dat matters is that all of ye are to eat the whole bloody thing, even if we gotta force ye to…”

“Is it just me, or did this stuff just move on its own…” said Flamer-6, the only drake Blaze still hadn’t talked to up until this point.

"Shut up and eat the damn shit you beasts!!" snapped the handler.

“Lets just eat it and get it done with!!” growled Blaze.

He closed his eyes and lowered his jaw into the gruel, trying hard not to think of what exactly was contained within this saturated, wet-cement-like mixture. If anything, it tasted even worse than it looked, so much so that it made his knees grow weak and his eyes tear up. It took every bit of his will power to force himself to swallow, and no sooner did the mixture hit his belly did his vision start to fade in an out. All he could do was to lie upon his side with a horribly severe stomachache, as did Flamer-2 and Flamer-6.

Yet poor Flamer-4 showed a particularly poor reaction to the meal, if it could be called that. Even approaching his portion caused him to immediately make a cogested, choking noise, so the guards had been forced to shove the spigot directly into his jaw and literally pump it down his throat. No sooner had he finished swallowing did the vapid drake begin to spasm uncontrollably while foaming at the jaw.

“Get the nutritionist over here now!!” shouted the dwarf handler in panic. If Flamer-4 took a turn for the worse, as it increasingly looked like he would, then it would not only cost the dwarf his job, but also possibly his life.

Sure enough, the elven nutritionist, Liander, rushed into the center of the room. He gave one look at the writhing Flamer-4 and shook his head.

“It appears that this one had an extreme allergic reaction to one of the substances contained within the growth mixture. There is nothing that can be done with this one…” he said indifferently.

Thus, as poor Flamer-4 was left to chke and drown in his own bile, tthe turned his rage toward the dwarven handler.

“How much of the augmenting mix did you give each of the drakes Dorcas?” he snarled.

“Ye told me to distribute it to all the drakes and make them eat it!!” insisted the dwarf.

“Is that so? Did I not also specifically mention that this batch was to last for the entire week, and that it is to be mixed in with their regular meals rather than administered in its unaltered form?” retorted the elf. The dwarf shrunk before the nutritionist, the look of dismay all too evident on his face.

The now-former handler suddenly tried to make a break for the exit. He did not get far before he began to scream a horrifying scream. The dwarf clutched at his head, which grew a shade of red that was equivalent to the hide of a healthy fire drake, before his head literally exploded with a gory fountain of blood. Just to further make his point, the elf also decided to slice off the heads of three random trolls, before addressing the remainder of the petrified guards.

“The Order of Kleave will not tolerate incompetence of any sort, and the penalty of which is death. The lives of these valuable specimens are worth far more than all of your lives put together. Do you understand?”

“Yes…my lord…” stammered the remaining guards. Blaze hazily watched as Flamer-4’s stiff body was dumped into the pot where the fire drakes had been fed from, as were the bodies of the former handler and the unfortunate trolls and unceremoniously rolled away.

The rest of that day went by in a foggy daze. When he was not lying on his side like a drugged up cinnabar addict, he was crawling over to his litter box and building a small mountains worth of shit.

As for Blaze’s thoughts on the deceased Flamer-4, all he could feel was an alarming indifference. It was one of those unfortunate things that happened; Flamer-4 would not be the last death Blaze would witness, and it was more than certainly possible that the next one may very well be Blaze. After all that he’d already seen, perhaps it just wasn’t worth losing his mind over. Besides, Flamer-4 could even be considered fortunate, for his suffering was now over and his spirit now rested with the Ancestors.

Just another day at the prison…
111211121121111111121.title: A meal that kills

choices: Blaze and Flamer-2 get into a fight
1112111211211111111211.content:
Blaze was still suffering the effects of the undiluted 'nutritional supplement' the day after it had been administered by the incometant - now thoroughly deceased - fire drake handler. The dwarf had been replaced by a younger, black maned human within the day. Blaze watched, sick and groaning like the rest of the drakes, as the man oversaw three trolls whom he forced to clean up the blood and gore of his predecessor from the stone floor. His style of encouragement included techniques such as stepping on fingers and toes with his heavy boots, kicks to the back or behind and just a constant stream of seaman-worthy cursing. When he turned his eyes on the captive dragons, however, his ambitious eyes gleamed with a sort of lust. Blaze did not imagine for a moment that he would be satisfied with his current job slopping out gruel and cleaning up dragon shit. Between the shouts and cursing, he learned the human's name: Wolf.

That day, nothing much happened. They were left in their cells to recover while lanterns burning slowly down and having to be refilled every so often by a troll slave were the only indicator of the passage of time. When Blaze was not thoroughly occupied with the pain in his abdomen or busy utilizing the sand box, he went to the bars and looked out across the hall. With Flamer-4 gone, that left just Flamer-6 across from him and Flamer-2 across and to the left. Of the former five fire drakes, there was now only four. Half of the eight cell wing was now vacant. Would more die before any were brought to this miserable place? Blaze asked himself and then scoffed. Almost certainly. And any who didn't die might just wish they had... Not once when Blaze was able to get up were the other two dragons in any state to talk or, in Flamer-2's case, scowl and cast suggestive gestures at him. In time, when the pain began to ease that evening, Blaze was able to consider the words of the nutritionist, one of Dr. Moridin's exalted staff. "Growth mixture" he'd said. Blaze mulled, curling his tail around so that it draped over the back of his neck. What could that possibly mean? The young drake wasn't sure, but he felt sure that it was tied somehow to Dr. Moridin's grand design and his obsession with dragon breeding.

Late that evening, Blaze's belly was growling after passing the last of the poison which had killed Flamer-4. The squeak of a cart and the grunting of troll laborers alerted the fire drake to the coming of the food cart. Wolf walked at the head of the team of trolls and a pair of dwarven distributers sat at the back of the creaking wagon as it crawled slowly by. It paused in front of Flamer-2's cell. Wolf checked and double checked his clipboard parchment, unwilling to make the slightest error; Blaze could hardly blame the human his caution and allowed himself a slight sneer while the humanoids backs were turned. "Forty-five kilograms... damn these elvish measurements..." muttered the human still loudly enough for Blaze to hear. "Thats about..." Then the human spoke up, "One albacore!"

The two dwarves grunted affirmation and reached into the back of the cart, which Blaze's nose alerted him was heaped with fish, but also other types of meat as well.

The cart crawled ahead to the next cell. "One and a half albacore!" shouted Wolf and a huge blade came down with stout dwarven strength, cleaving the mighty fish in twain with one stroke. One and a half fish was tossed into Flamer-6's cell through the small food port as well. By the time it clanged shut, Flamer-2 was already mostly done, chewing on the spine and skull of the huge fish. He slurped it into his mouth with a disgusting lack of manners and crushed down on the bones with a loud *crack.* Flamer-2 stuck his snout through the bars as the cart made a wide turn, coming down Blaze's side of the room.

"M-master Human..." drawled Flamer-2 - bravely in Blaze's opinion - "Might you possibly spare just another small fish? I am still feeling weak after the old dwarf poisoned us..."

Blaze snorted, his prison mate was laying it on thick, perhaps taking advantage of a new caretaker's leniency. Blaze only wished he'd thought of it first.

Wolf looked up from his feeding regiment. "Still hungry eh?"

"Yes, Master Human, Wise Human..." Flamer-2 groveled, his head low. Blaze turned his nose in disgust.

Wolf held up a smallish fish; at least compared to the tuna. "Hm, how about this? Do you think this Striped Snapper will tide you over?"

Blaze read in the subtle shifts of his wings an in the minute tang of his odor that Flamer-2 really wanted something bigger, really, another whole tuna. But he said, "Oh yes! That would just be great!" He even pressed his face against the bars in mock excitement. As the human moved his arm holding the 20 lb fish, Blaze couldn't believe that Flamer-2 was going to get away with it. But as the human turned, his other arm came up from behind the wall of the cart as well. Wolf hung onto his fish and instead chucked a large smooth black stone at Flamer-2's snout. The drake emitted a quite undragon-like yelp and started back, holding a paw to his nose where a few ruby drops gathered. The dwarves erupted in guffaw and banged their helmets together. Wolf allowed himself a chuckle and moved on as Flamer-2 moved back to the shadowy interior of his cell.

Blaze's meal turned out to be quite different than the others'. Blaze's eyesight for fine letters was not the best, but he could clearly see that when the human's finger stopped at his name, it was highlighted in red. "Underweight..." Wolf muttered. "Looks like your lucky day fella." They sloped several heavy buckets of ground meat into the trough below the cell's feeding door. It was a generous amount of red meat, but immediately, Blaze could tell that it had been treated in the lab prior to being served to him. As he sniffed cautiously, Wolf tried to reassure him. "It's just vitamins and supplements, not that other supplement from the day before. It's not dangerous."

The human sounded sincere, but then humans were famed liars. "Couldn't..." started Blaze, the words rough in his throat from disuse, "Couldn't I have a tuna instead?"

The man hefted another stone from the side of the cart and tossed it casually into the air, catching it again and again with one hand. "You're not going to make my job more difficult too are you?" Blaze shook his head hurriedly. "Then eat it and be glad, red meat is scarce enough on this island. You'll soon tire of fish and be longing for this stuff again." The cart moved on. "Half an albacore for fatty here!" said Wolf referring to Flamer-1 in the next cell. There was some low growling, but the adjacent, unseen dragon said nothing.

As Blaze began to lap up the soft, paste-like meat, Flamer-2 stared at him from the shadows of his cell, eyes gleaming as his tongue snapped up now and again to lick the blood away from his nose. Blaze stared right back and began to eat with a false gusto, pretending to savor the slightly metallic tinged meat.

The meal was, in fact heavy and left Blaze sleepy and turgid afterwards. He'd even licked the trough clean and despite the lack of bones or texture to the meat, he was full and about as happy as he could be considering the circumstances.

Again that night he had the horrid dream, strapped down and watching Flamer-2 rape an innocent, attractive female with devilish glee. Dr. Moridin egged him on, even whacking the drake's behind with wooden paddle as he approached climax and the drakka shrieked in dismay. Blaze stuggled, but couldn't move. Then the dragons were gone and Dr. Moridin was looming over him, half his face covered with a quicksilver mask. He seems deformed, yet still elegant and terrible in the elfin way, half elf, half well polished machine. Then he was sticking needles and tubes into his veins. Blaze watched with horror as his flesh swelled monstrously. "A strong male we'll make out of you yet, you pansy, ball-less, pussy!" His arm grew to the size of a sky-swallower's, rippling with bulky, inflexible muscle. The growth traveled up his shoulder, cracking the bones out of position and sliding up his neck. The elf's silver glove - or was it a silver hand? - rested on his brow. "We'll make a real drake out of you..." Blaze screamed in agony.

And he awoke screaming, to the chagrin of the other fire drakes. Flamer-2 chided, lifting his head from where it had previously curled, "Having bad dreams again are we, newbie?"

Flamer-6 was more considerate. "Just go back to sleep, you'll get used to the dreams after a while..."

And Blaze did try, though he lay awake for long hours, listening to his stomach churn complacently, trying to get back into a healthy rhythm after being starved, clogged and subsequently poisoned. But Dr. Moridin's slim terrifying visage seemed to lurk behind his eyes whenever he shut them. Imagine his dismay when the lamps were lit again the following morning and the lab crew came to collect him.
1112111211211111111211.title: The New Handler

choices: Blaze is led outside for a physical fitness examination
Blaze gets sedated and led to the laboratory
11121112112111111112111.content:
The next couple of weeks settled into one of monotony. Every morning, Blaze would be woken up and taken to perform work. Much of the time, it was excavation in the mines, where he would usually be paired up with Flamers 1, 2 or 6. Other times was the horrifically gross duty of cleaning up the cesspools in the mines, of which the only mercy was that they would spray him off with cold water if only to make sure he didn't catch disease.

Working with Flamer-1 was depressingly dull. The large drake hardly spoke, nor did he ever flash a gaze toward Blaze. Not that Blaze particularly cared about becoming friends with Flamer-1, but Blaze couldn’t help but be somewhat annoyed at the way Flamer-1 always seemed to be perpetually sleepy and completely ambivalent about his situation.

“So how long have you been here?” asked Blaze.

“Too long…” said Flamer-1 dully his eyes only halfway open.

“Well…I was just asking because I figured you seem to be someone who knows the most about the place,” added Blaze.

“What is the point in even thinking about it? Besides…it won’t help anybody to know in any case,” he droned, monotonously shifting back to his work. Blaze did shift back to his work. Flamer-1 was already lost, so far as Blaze could tell. He was so apathetic that Blaze reckoned he wouldn’t have even cared if they neutered him. In that instance, he was even worse than Flamer-2, as at the very least the bully was still out for his own self-preservation. Thus, as far as Blaze could tell, Flamer-1 already was neutered in mind and spirit.

Flamer-6 possessed a similar cynicism as Flamer-1, but at the very least he was willing to talk to Blaze.

“What do you think we’re doing all this digging for?” Blaze asked him one day.

Flamer-6 shrugged, “How the hell should I know?”

“Because they’re obviously have us do this for a purpose. That’s how these elves work. They’re planning on doing something with the caves we’re carving out!!” answered Blaze.

“You think Flamer-7? Obviously, elves love underground tunnels for their aesthetic qualities," he shrugged.

"But enough of this Flamer-7. You might think its worth getting a pole shoved up the ass but leave me out of it. I can see why Flamer-2 gets kind of annoyed with you though. You think too much, you’re too self-righteous and because you do it gets everyone else in trouble. So whatever you’re thinking, keep it to yourself and maybe you’ll live a little bit longer,” he cried.

“All right. I got it…” answered Blaze. He didn’t speak to Flamer-6 about these sort of questions again, but he was willing to give out pointers to Blaze every so often so that his existence was a little less miserable.

Of course, while paired up with Flamer-2, Blaze always had to watch his back to ward off the thicker dragons bullying. It turned out that Blaze received the brunt of his attentions not because he was a newbie; Flamer-2 had decided that after Blaze had given back as much as he had taken, he wasn’t going to simply break like 3 and 5 had, but that Flamer-2 decided he had a particular dislike toward Blaze.

Blaze actually took that as a positive development. It meant that Flamer-2 looked at him with a modicum of respect and fear, a true rival rather than a victim. In fact, more often then not, Blaze would go out of his way to knock Flamer-2 down a peg.

For instance, when Flamer-8 had newly arrived with that hopeless, glazed look Blaze knew only too well, Flamer-2 immediately took to bullying the new arrival.

“Ha!! Looks like we’ve got fresh meat!!” cackled Flamer-2, “Tell me newbie, how many times have they shoved the pole up your ass?”

Flamer-8 whimpered pitifully.

“Oh…you must have liked it didn’t you?” taunted Flamer-2, “I’ll make sure to tell the guards you’re a homo.”

“Shut the fuck up Flamer-2 and leave him alone,” growled Blaze.

“Make me!!” retorted Flamer-2.

“I can. We can have an argument here and then the guards will wake up to shove the pole up both our assess.” retorted Blaze. His heart pounded horribly, but fortunately, it seemed that Flamer-2 didn’t seem up to risk calling Blaze’s bluff, who snorted and went back to sleep.

“T-thanks…” said Flamer-8 softly, but not ungratefully.

Blaze sighed, “Shits already bad enough as it is. Now get some sleep newbie…”

While Flamer-8 wasn’t necessarily fine after that, he at least became functional enough to perform the duties that were required, which was a victory in and of itself. He hadn’t been there much longer than Flamer-8, but what he did know was that once you survived the first couple of days, you’d be able to endure for the long haul.

Flamer-9, unfortunately, was not one of them. He’d been assigned Flamer-4’s old cell, and spent that entire night screaming and wailing for his mother. After a couple of days, he wouldn’t stop, and Wolf the handler had had enough. Wolf ordered his thugs to drag Flamer-9 out of his cell and then had them shove the pole up his butt, which Blaze could not help but watch with a perverse, frightened fascination. Flamer-9 no longer screamed after that, reduced to a broken shivering, miserable wreck.

Upon returning from the mines that evening, he found that Flamer-9’s cell was empty. Blaze could only idly wonder if Flamer-9 had died, or if he’d been neutered and taken wherever they stored neutered drakes.

Though he still felt somewhat nauseous from the chemical additive they spiced his food with every morning, he was nevertheless gaining weight from the dense concentrated food and muscle from his hard physical labor in the mines. His fire sacs were once again filled with oil, and could once again puff smoke out of his nostrils, though he did not think it a good idea to test whether or not he could breath fire yet.

One particular morning, the nutritionist, Liander, took notice of this and congratulated the handler as a result. The elf then turned toward Blaze’s cage.

“Well now, it would seem that you are not quite so skinny anymore Flamer-7, not that I imagine you would show your gratitude toward your benefactors.”

Blaze didn’t care to respond to the elf. All he hoped was that the elf was not here to take him to Doctor Moridin.

Yet what was certain was that as the guards came forward to shackle him, this day would be different from any of the others.
11121112112111111112111.title: Blaze steadily regains his strength

choices: Fly laps and obstacles in a massive outdoor enclosure
Blaze has to compete against another dragon
111211121121111111121111.content:
They let him walk. That in itself was something of a gift. Sure, he was still manacled, but this time his forepaws were not attached to the rear ones, allowing him a much greater range of motion and a bigger, more comfortable stride. The humanoids jogged at his flanks or else rode on mules as he was led along the passage; the mounted warriors were no less intimidating with their long gripping polarms and the slick wooden pole always following in the wake of his tail. Still, Blaze was able to walk with at least a modicum of dignity, his head up and looking forward instead of down at the ground before him.

He could tell almost immediately that they were not heading towards the mines. For one thing, he - being a smaller variety of dragon - always worked in a team to compensate for his - relatively - smaller stature. For another thing, they were headed up. The path sloped steadily upward after they took as side branch from the vast curve of the main hallway. The train then came to another level hallway, just as vast as the one that Blaze's wing branched off of. They walked along some distance, Blaze taking the chance to smell and gawk at the passing traffic.

It was a fast, quiet traffic of feet and hooves and occasionally paws as well. Unlike New Alveri, where people stopped to mingle and talk regularly, everyone here seemed to have urgent business as they walked briskly or even ran alone the echoing stone passages. Troll drudges were uncommon on this level compared to the level below where the dragons were housed. Instead, gangly humans ran about on business along the wide corridor, streaking in and out of holes like mice. Then Blaze was directed into a side passage that once again spiraled lazily upward.

Blaze squinted in the new light coming from the tunnel ahead. The young fire-lord had to tuck in his elbows and knees as suddenly the armed escort pressed in close, even going so far as laying their cold steel weapons on his armored skin. Wolf glanced back at Blaze where he rode ahead, directing the whole party. He rattled the chain and pendant dangling from his hand, the control for his inhibitor collar. Aparently, Blaze was expected to be extra-cautious in guarding his behavior for this next section of the sprawling island complex.

The thrid and topmost level sported - wonder of wonders! - skylights and also splashing waterfalls of cool volcanic spring water. Greenery thrived here to either side of the concourse, tall tropical trees and small, neat plots of grass where elves and dwarves intermingled in deep discussion. There was less frenzied movement, as the obvious patrons of this expedition walked stately from building to building, recessed in the walls of the broad passage. Vines dripped from balconies where there was occasionally a dwarf or two taking a siesta from the warm tropical environment which filtered more readily into the uppermost level than the dank, stifled lower levels; despite obvious dwarvish engineering. It seemed like utter luxury compared to the cramped, stinking dungeons below.

The taste as brief as Blaze was poked and prodded quickly into another side passage. Blaze managed to twist his head as he departed, and just before the wall blocked off his view, he could have sworn he saw a dragon walking free and uninhibited down that wondrous boulevard.

Still the passage climbed up, now much more steeply. Blaze was grateful for the newfound muscle now gracing his frame. Blaze had lost all of his pre-adolescent body fat during his trials, reduced to a boney shadow of his former self. Hard work in the mines had seen to it that the extra Calories he'd been supplied turned into firm, sleek muscle at his now, fairly broad shoulders. But Blaze felt fairly lopsided with overdeveloped shoulders and chest like an Earthrender. He's still been unable to run or fly in the dark, closed passages underground. His firebladder rippled heavy as he walked, its thick muscular lining displaying for all to see the death which was contained within. But Blaze remained uncertain, not daring to have used his gift since being captured. He'd never gone so long without breathing so much as an ember. Though his nostrils were once again stoked with pleasant smog he was able to summon at will, Fiery Death might still be beyond him, if fortune were to provide a chance to utilize his breed's famed skill.

The passageway turned up and up. Blaze kept up with the challenge with only minimal effort, though the mules and walking humans seemed to be getting the worst of it. The party slowed; Blaze was signaled with a cruel tug on his hide by a hooked polarm which reached out to grab his scales. Blaze had to trundle along beside the heavy breathing of the humanoids and their beasts until finally the tunnel ended.

Sunlight poured in from the end of the tunnel, so bright, it made Dr. Moridin's lab look like a feeble wax torch. Blaze could not stifle a hiss after so long living in the dark. Someone behind him dug their tool into Blaze's tail, lifting it...

"Ah! No! I'm going!" Blaze shouted, stumbling forward so that his manacles caught and he almost fell. Living in constant fear of the lubed pole was humiliating and terrible, but in a sick sort of way, Blaze felt he was getting used to it. They'd only had to use it on him once in the past two weeks; after Flamer-2 had executed a devious ploy to get their food assignments switched and he'd had it out with the not-so-much bigger male. By now, the mere threat of the dreaded thing was usually enough; and Blaze thought that the human poleman would rather wave the thing around rather than actually work at ramming his weapon home.

Snickering from Wolf ahead made Blaze feel a fresh surge of shame which was slowly dulling as his internment lengthened, but that did not keep him from proceeding into the terrible light.

Dragon eyes were superior to a human's in direct light - though perhaps only equal to an elf's - and better than a dwarf's in the dark. However, dragons paid for that visual acuity with slow transition. Despite walking up the long ramp into the sunlight, Blaze remained unable to see long after the humans obviously had adjusted. When he emerged, all Blaze could tell as he squinted was that he was surrounded by tall dark pillars which regularly interrupted his eye sight. The sky above looked odd as well, almost dark in places as if the sky itself had cracked, greenery was also abundant, though irregular all around.

His nose told him far more about his environment. He was outside! Truly outside for the first time since the ship had landed with him and his lost companion over two months ago. The atmosphere tasted thinner. They had indeed come a long way, either to the top of the mountain or inside it's caldera. The refreshing smells of plants, recent rainfall and wild animal droppings was enough to warrant punishment just for the chance to come here.

In fact, driven by his nose, Blaze walked forward without instruction, recklessly. To his logical mind's surprise, which was currently taking a minor backseat to his powerful nose-instinct, the humans did not immediately descend upon him. Heady scents filling his snout and making him giddy, Blaze walked up to one of the tall, light-drenched pillars and urinated on it for the sheer pleasure of it, relishing the way his scent mingled with that of the environment.

The very next thing he wanted was to spread his wings. But he was prevented from doing this by the leather harness which hobbled him. Still he strained, panicky instinct threatening to drown out his rational thoughts.

Blaze smelled a rider detach itself from the light-bleached conglomerate of human and mule stink which lingered over by the carved entrance. It was Wolf. Blaze snarled at the pitiful figure, it smell pungently arrogant and challenging. He'd smear nicely over the black volcanic stone...

Pain seized Blaze's throat, like a claw gripping him, invading the muscles lining his long neck and making them seize and spasm. But the pain radiated throughout his body as well, arching his back and loosing his bladder onto the ground as well as his leg. Blaze fell onto his side, twitching. Three pulses racked him, at even half-second intervals. The brevity and abruptness of the pain and its cessation was enough to knock the young drake loose from the instinct-smells which has been arising in fumes to cloud his mind.

Wolf stopped his mount before Blaze as he snuffled, hurt and aching, in the glassy dust. His vision slowly improving, Blaze could make out enough of the man's features to decipher a haughty look of superiority on the man's face as he held the triggering device for the collar around his neck.

"Do you know where you are, Drake? Has the scent-madness left you now? Do. You. Remember. Who's. In. Charge?" For emphasis, Wolf held aloft the magic pendant, and Blaze recoiled, cringing.

"Y-yes. Master Wolf. I-I'm sorry for the way I acted." whimper Blaze, suffering an after spasm in his cramping back muscles.

Blaze saw Wolf then dismount and at the same time, decreasingly blurry human shapes came forward from the tunnels. Though he couldn't see still, there were at least two elves among the small cround now as well.

"Good..." Wolf sniffed, "Now let's see what you can do."

To Blaze's surprise, an assistant loosened and removed the buckles holding his wings in place, allowing them to stretched to their full glory for the first time since being kidnapped in New Alveri. To his infinite chagrin, he found there was nowhere to go...
111211121121111111121111.title: Onward and Upward

choices: Blaze is asked to burn targets from midair
1112111211211111111211111.content:
Joints popped and creaked as Blaze flexed his great wings; the human at his side literally had to jump out of the way as the folded leather unfurled (Wolf said nothing). The only time in the last four miserable months of his life that Blaze had even been able to open his wings had been in his cell, and even there, not completely. Thick muscles which ran smoothly over his rib cage, connecting his humerus to his breast bone which was the anchor for powerful downward thrusts. More muscles connected along his back and in the well sculpted - in Blaze's opinion at least - complex of his shoulders, where the wings sat behind and just above his forearms which, even in their currently well developed state, were far more slender than the big flight muscles.

Blaze relished the feel - almost orgasmic, after so long! - of leathery skin snapping taught along the length of his torso on either side of his spine. He pulled and stretched the durable leather, luxuriating in the tugging, slightly elastic feel of hide which was never meant to remain folded so long. Blood vessels flared automatically, making his wings feel alive again, chilled slightly in the mountain air despite the tropical locale.

The young fire-lord then looked down at wolf, his wings hovering above the ground at about chest height to the tall human. The dragon's eyes were filled with suspicion and cautious joy. How far were they going to let him go with this? But Wolf merely waved his hand in a shooing gesture, apparently unconcerned with the possibility that Blaze might try to escape. In fact, with a display of abject apathy, the fire drake handler turned his mule around and trotted back to join the conglomerate near the side of the mountain where the entrance back into the complex was. It was still hard to see, everything washed out in the abundant light; though every minute that passed, his vision slowly improved.

Blaze was too canny to think that his captors did not have some sort of security in place to prevent his escape. He thought that perhaps they would simply zap him with the collar should he show signs of departing, undoubtedly sending him into convulsions and plummeting to his death. Still, that did not mean that Blaze could not test the boundaries.

As Blaze began to stir the air with his wings, getting a feel for the local atmosphere, the party near the gate moved forward and Blaze could detect speech, mostly between two refined elvish voices. He paid them no mind, however, He's been months out of practice. Of course, flight was as simple to him as walking, but still, Blaze measured the wind carfully with the sensetive surface of his wings. The leather, bare to the casual glance, was actually coated with thousands of fine hairs - acually modified scales - which gave him invaluable information about the air currents moving around them.

Blaze could grip the wind, feel its texture, its shape and density. A lifetime of experience stocked him with the knowledge of how to read the air not just in his local environment but in the greater airscape as well. By the air-pressure - how dense the air felt here - Blaze knew approximately how high they were and how hard he would have to thrust to get airborne. By the eddies stirring the ground here, he could glean something of the bigger currents above. Tasting the moisture in the air with his tongue, Blaze knew that the island would experience rain in no more than 18 hours. Everything he knew at ground level would be amplified ten fold once he got into the air.

He couldn't wait.

They were watching him, but right now, Blaze couldn't care. Even if the zapped him again or shoved the pole up his ass, it would be worth it to get into the air again. Weeds wavered in the wind of his down stroke. The red dragon thrust down again until his chest left the ground. But moving his wings sent an unfamiliar burning through his underused muscles. Something told him that he'd not be able to spend as long in the sky as he might have a few months ago. No matter, Blaze crouched and took off straight ahead, running and leaping with all four legs.

The wind rushed past his face. His chest bulged as the muscles contracted, bringing the big wings down. Once, twice, his feet left the ground, but only for a few ecstatic seconds. It wasn't enough. Three, four... there! Blaze clawed his way up, feeling as ungraceful as a Dodo, but still, there it was. Fine details were still missing from his sight, but Blaze could still easily avoid the large pillars which dotted this region. After gaining some precious altitude at the expense of burning wings, Blaze set them and sighed in absolute pleasure, feeling the wind caress and support his body, like a long lost lover. Dragons might make their abodes under the ground for safety, but truely they were creatures of the air! Dragons were mean to be free, nay, they were freedom itself!

Lost in the sensation of drifting two dragon lengths above the ground, Blaze nearly met his end when a sudden nebulous obstacle loomed out of the whitewashed background. It appeared out of the brilliance suddenly and with deadly solidity. A lattice of interlocking iron bars. A huge wall stretching high from the ground, and - Blaze realized starkly - overhead as well. That was why the sky had appeared oddly cracked, it was the shadows of the beams overhead. He was trapped in a massive cage!!

Despite seeing the lavishly spacious interior of the complex below in the side of the not-so-dormant volcano, it stunned Blaze to see construction on such a scale, to match even the mighty works of New Alveri itself. What weren't these elves capable of? Blaze wondered forlornly. But then, if such a group had ambitions to capture and enslave dragons themselves, that alone proved their power and sheer gall.

Amazement slowed his reaction just a portion of a second, but it was enough. Blaze banked, turning nearly on his side in a desperate attempt to avoid the sudden wall, but his forward momentum would not be changed so suddenly. His clawed hindfeet and tail banged against the wall. Blaze began to fall, but not merely from having lost precious momentum in the collision with the sturdy metal. His collar had sent a single painful jolt through his body on contact with the wall. Fortunately, his legs extended in a jerky motion which propelled him away from the cage - and possibly more shocks - but his wings felt stiff against his back and refused to listen to commands as the ground flew up to meet him.

Desperation and the desire to avoid certain death turned his fall into a hasty glide. Shaking, Blaze forced his wings to move against the pain blocking them. Blaze landed heavily on his forelegs which buckled and then ground his chest into the grass where he was fortunate enough to skid to a halt. Panting, the young drake watched the party of humanoids who had all been observing his blunder.

Blaze caught snippets from the elves as they approached his crash site. "...seems clumsy." said a female voice he recognized as none other than Auyandrith, Dr. Moridin's apprentice.

"...due to confinement. He'll get better shortly, with proper excercise."

"He better... I don't know what the good doctor sees in this one. He should just pick one and be done with it. Any drake with a set of testicles will do."

"You undervalue the male component in producing offspring, dear cousin."

"Don't you get me started, Liander! We shouldn't be wasting time here, crafting a perfect 'Patron.' Not when the drakka manage to smash one in ten eggs before we can collect them, not when the suicide rate is-"

"Hush cousin! Don't speak of such things here!" Liander admonished.

Blaze could finally see well enough to notice a fair skinned humanoid cross her arms and turn away from her companion. The disturbing conversation he'd overhead melted from his mind as Wolf approached.

"Well, don't look like you have enough sense to keep from bashing int'a things in the air." he said sardonically. "You better shape up and right quick if you want to stay in the breeding program, Ha!" he laughed and threw a mock jab in Blaze's direction.

Blaze made a low grinding noise, pebbles grinding together in his crop, a sound of recognized folly and submission to another's judgement. Blaze had no idea if the meaning translated across species, but he added. "It's... been a while since I last flew."

"Obviously." said Wolf snidely and looked back at the observers. "Now no more nonsense, you're making me look bad."

"What is this?" Blaze asked suddenly, "Is this some sort of trial?"

Wolf scratched his beard, as if deciding how much information to share with a lowly prisoner. "...Not as such. Let's just call this a preliminary, and a chance for you to stretch your wings. As you have already experienced, there is no where to go and your collar will activate again with twice the force if you touch the bars again." Pulling a long pointing stick and a whistle from his side bag, Wolf gestured to several of the pillars Blaze could now clearly see holding up the tall ceiling. "Now lets see you weave through some of those pillars. Now!" Wolf punctuated his sentence with a shrill whistle that hurt Blaze's ears. He moved as much to get away from the annoying sound as to comply with instruction. When he was aloft, sadly, flight has lost some - but not all - of its former pleasure.
1112111211211111111211111.title: Child of Air

choices: Blaze is taken to the lab
11121112112111111112111111.content:
Blaze weaved in and out of the pillars. He always considered himself a fairly coordinated flier, about as fast and maneuverable as the other young drakes of his size and age. Still, most of his flight experience consisted of flying to and from the orphanage to the merchant district, and knowing this Blaze decided to focus on ensuring that he wouldn't hit pillars rather than on speed. He had a couple of close scrapes, but all in all, he managed to navigate through the maze of pillars without too much trouble.

This time, he landed softly onto the grass in front of the gathered humanoids. They were furiously scribbling something down on their clipboard.

Wolf folded his arms contemptuously, "I've seen worse, I have to admit..."

That was more than good enough for Blaze. He was happy enough that he wasn't being whipped or raped.

"So, now what?" he asked.

Wolf strode toward a hidden switch, and a large aluminum target popped out of the ground near the side of the mountain wall.

“We may as well check to see if you can flame. If you can’t, well, lets just say you’re out of the breeding program…” he finished with a chuckle. A hot surge of anger coursed through Blaze, as he curved his way toward the sample target. As the naphtha and the hot gasses bubbled in his throat as he took in a smoldering breath, he imagined that the target having the sneering expression of Dr. Moridin, the laughter of the kidnappers, all the pain inflicted upon his body and the daily injustices visited upon him and all the others, all of which festered within him, whereupon he threw his neck forward and expelled a frightening beam of fire.

“FWWOMP!!”

When the smoke cleared, the metal target had been reduced to a pile of smoldering metal. The fire had in fact continued through the target and continued to eat away at the side of volcanic wall as if it were acid. A team of humanoids rushed forward to the scene and frantically began dispensing extinguishing foam upon the simmering foam to put it out. Blaze couldn’t help but grunt with a deep sense of satisfaction, his nostrils smoldering vigorously. Even the elves seemed surprised at the dramatic results, as they furiously scribbled on their clipboards.

“…it would seem that the intensity of the flame varies depending upon the beasts emotional state. Perhaps the doctor’s theory is right in this regard…” he heard one of the elf’s whisper.

"I believe that its more to due with the fact of the shoddy material of the target than any distinguishing ability on the beasts part..." answered Auyandrith. The two once again engaged in a furious debate, yYet Blaze did have time to wonder about what they were saying for long, as Wolf snapped him back to attention.

“So, it does seem you can produce a bit of fire Flamer-7,” said Wolf, though Blaze could tell that he was trying to keep uneasiness out of his voice.

The fire lord handler walked over to another hidden switch. When he flipped it, a series of unlit torches emerged from the each pillars at various heights. Again, Blaze could not help but wonder what kind of complex, intricate machinery the elves had constructed. If only their talents could have been directed to a more worthy cause for New Alveri than for their shady operations.

"You shall fly through the course as you did before, yet this time you will attempt to light up each of the torches as you pass by,” explained Wolf.

“You want me to flame them right?” emphasized Blaze, ensuring that he heard correctly.

Wolf clenched his fists impatiently, “Is that not what I just said!? How idiotic are you beast?”

“Yes, I’m going…” replied Blaze. Despite the circumstances, Blaze couldn’t help but actually be excited that he’d be able to use his flaming breath in this exercise. The only time he’d ever been able to use his flaming breath was to help out Mr. Ebon in the smithy, and as Blaze had so recently shown, the flaming breath of a Fire Lord was by far the most potent of all dragon kind, as not only did it burn the hottest, but it also stuck to any surface, nor could it easily be put out with water. Furthermore, while most other dragons fire breath could only be used in dramatic, but short bursts, Blaze still had quite a lot in the tank.

The naphtha bubbled in his throat as Blaze approached the first target. It was straight on with his flight pass, so despite the fact he’d had absolutely no practice at midair flaming, he managed to angle his head downward and flamed as he passed by overhead. The torch burned merrily as he passed by, but as he moved on through the course, the difficulty grew harder and harder.

The next series of targets were those that were either close to the ground or up near the ceiling, which meant that Blaze had to adjust his normal flight pattern to get to those torches. Blaze slowed up so that he would have enough time to align himself properly, but even then he missed the mark as often as he hit.

Hardest of all were those torches he had to light while he was turning. He would have only a split second to angle his head to the proper alignment, while judging wind current and g-forces. Only a few times did he manage to hit, if only because he sprayed a wide beam in order to increase his chances.

He ended up paying for his profligate use of his fire breath, for near the end he was reduced to spitting out small embers as his ‘fuel’ began to run out. He landed softly in front of the group once he finished his run.

“It would seem that out of a possible total of one hundred torches, you managed to light fifty-eight of them,” said Wolf, gazing at his clipboard. He couldn’t tell if Wolf was impressed that he’d actually had gotten that many on his first time ever attempting trying to flame in mid-flight, or that he was disappointed and should have done better.

What Blaze did know was that after expelling that much flame, he was absolutely exhausted. His body ached all over. Furthermore, the inside of his mouth throbbed with a slight burning sensation, his tongue dry and parched. Yet despite that, Blaze felt more highly of himself than he had in quite some time. If he could master the use of his fire, then maybe he could actually get out of here...

That was when the shock went through his body again, sending him to the ground. While Blaze writhed, a pair of humans came forward with the pole and jabbed it up his butt.

Or maybe not... he sighed.

“Don’t let today go to your head Flamer-7. Any freedom you have is present only because we allowed you to have them. Never forget that… We own you...” snarled Wolf.

Blaze shifted his head down, "Y-yes Master Wolf..."

Wolf then gestured to the crews. "Chain him up..."
11121112112111111112111111.title: Breath of Fire

Blaze moves on to official trials
111211121121111111121111111.content:
Blaze was led away, back into the darkness of the hidden complex, but it was not the last time that Blaze would see the wondrous and terrible iron cage with veritably filled nearly half of the Volcano's wide caldera, 50 acres of flat land, interspersed with light jungle and outcroppings of black rock; and that did not include the inner walls of the mountain which supported much of the massive structure. His rectum was sore as he walked down into the depths of the mountain, stumbling for lightblindness that did not affect humans nearly so much, but Blaze stuck by his earlier assertion. It had been worth it. He had had... fun. No amount of pain could take that away.

Blaze lorded what had happened over Flamer-2 when he got back to his cell. In fact, the young drake felt quite gregarious in describing the beauty of the upper world and what the elves had built and what he had done there; selectively editing certain parts of course. He only paused in his details when he heard the footsteps of Wolf or one of the man's aides coming down the hallway. Flamer-2 only looked at him caustically and escaped to curl up in a dark corner of his cell. Flamer-6 listened with an appreciative, though wary ear; obviously not wanting to fall into the trap of becoming too chummy with any of the other dragons. Flamer-8 however, hung on Blaze's every word. Hiliariously, he was older than Blaze by at least two decades, judging by the length of the horns on his head, and yet, in this place he had pretty much reverted to a younger, more vulnerable state.

"Tell me, what did it Smell like? Up there?" he would ask frequently.

The Common Tongue, originating out of the mass of barbarian human dialects who previously occupied the area in and around New Alveri in the ages before it was founded, is and remains terrible as describing the nuances of olfactory stimulation, despite millennia of dragons intermingling with humanoids and incorporating their culture. Not so for Modern Draconic. I switched to our native tongue to describe the heady scents which had initially overtaken me with their vividness, the way they came together like a symphony, each part recognizable and yet part of a greater whole, a rich, consuming experience that was like reaching out to brush against, to taste, the entire mountainside with the lightest of touches. To smell was to connect, in some basic fashion, with the world around you, to become one with it. This and more I was able to communicate to Flamer-8, in a language of growls, jaw-snaps, guttural pops, tail movement, and some sub-sonic vibrations that a human would find impossible to hear. The other fire drake sighed with the image in his mind of the topside world, leaning against the bars confining him.

It was a while after that that Flamer-8 related his story. Blaze listened stiffly, absorbing the information with a detached ear. He had been meaning simply to show off with his own account, to improve his status and project the image that he was special in the eyes of their captors; mostly for Flamer-2's benefit. Blaze had no desire for more heartache that would come with inevitable separation, either through death, castration or simple transfer. Blaze wanted no friends here. Nevertheless, he learned that Flamer-8 - who dared not speak his name for the collar around his neck which was still programmed to recognize certain words and phrases - was once a signal man for a tribe of 'wild' dragons outside New Alveri. It had been his task to light signal fires in a large area in case of invasion.

"It was a pretty sweet gig." Flamer-8 related, "All the freedom of moving around as our ancestors did, just a small tribe with you, thick as theives. We hunted together, slept togehter on the plains, laid eggs together and then shipped them to the main city. It was a wonderful free life..." He shed a tear then and was quiet for a long time. It was only later, after ruminating on the fact revealed that Blaze gathered that there was a continuing eflux of 'defectors' from the city who migrated into the country side to live a more 'natural' life, closer to nature. Since dragons live so long and because infant dragons are predatory pests when left to roam the countryside, these roving bands of dragons - which were highly unstable, often meeting and trading members - send the eggs they produced back to the city for often generous monetary compensation. They knew their offspring would probably have a better life in the city - many dragon couples being infertile - and also, they could maintain their vaunted freedom.

Blaze could see the logic. 'Wild' dragons roaming around New Alveri's outskirts would provide an invaluable buffer against the continuous barbarian skirmishes. Flamer-8 described the give-take relationship the roaming dragons had with the farmers who lived on the vast plains that were New Alveri's breadbasket. Small, unofficial tributes from the farmers were an incentive for a particular band to linger in the area, and in return, the dragons were expected to defend a certain area around where they were currently habitating; which was natural enough given dragons' normal territorial instincts. Dragon tribes would move on when the hunting in the area grew sparse - forbidden from stealing livestock by the Knights - while especially rich farmers could sometimes afford to hire a dragon, or multiple dragons, as a personal guard or sentry. The price was nearly always simply room and board, and that was enough for most rustic dragons to lead a long and happy life.

"I was a sentry for a rich human." Flamer-8 said, "I spent 25 years living on and protecting his estate. I... loved the man." His voice was cracking as he continued, "B-but, the more I think about it. The more time I spend here... the more I think that he sold me to the men who captured and brought me here, like nothing more than a prize horse."

Blaze lifted his head to look at the fire drake across the hall, but Flamer-8 stopped talking and curled up on a simple matt of hay. He refused to say more.

Blaze's reign of superiority was shortlived. Not two days had passed before Flamer-2 was taken and led up to the training area. He returned looking smug and smelling of grass and dirt, but he did not crow about his accomplishment, instead deriding Blaze as an infant shouting about minor victories that didn't really matter. Blaze really wanted to see how smug he would be with a face-full of the Hellfire he'd produced earlier that had eaten metal and stone as well as wool and tinder. There will be time for that later... Blaze felt assuredly.

And indeed things seemed to be leading to a head. Blaze became busy. Only little was he sent down to the mines, now to work alone, usually when some other dragon was sent to the surface for flying and flaming practice. His overdeveloped fire bladder pulsed continuously and was always warm to the touch as it produced oil and sulfurous hydrocarbons in response to the suddenly high demand for fire. Blaze's appetite doubled and he was fed accordingly. At night, he would feast on four large tunnies or sometimes a pile of snappers, once even half a strange sea mammal Wolf had called a porpoise. He'd go to sleep - or rather was knocked out - turgid and inert and awake hungry, his huge fire bladder once again refilled and ready scorch wood and metal to ashes.

Flamer-1 disappeared one day. He was simply gone and Blaze was ashamed that it was Flamer-8 who told him. Blaze hadn't even noticed that the cell was empty. Though he'd never admitted it, Blaze always assumed that he'd been the first one here. It worried Blaze that the silent, stoic dragon, powerfully built and steady for a fire-lord would fail after his long internment. All Wolf would say on the matter, after Blaze persistently asked, despite threats, was "He wasn't what the wigs upstairs were looking for. You better just worry about you and hope to God that you have it and the others don't." Wolf had laughed and casually tossed a rock which bounced off of Blaze's hard temple. After a second, Blaze feigned pain so Wolf would not feel obligated to try something else. He seemed satisfied with the act and another warned to stop asking questions that'd get them both in trouble. "The light-skins don't like talkin' drakes." He would admonish while dishing out his evening meal or else instructing a troll to sift through his sandbox for heavy packages to trundle away.

Despite this, the chance to go outside made up for everything. He was still a prisoner and littler more than an animal in the eyes of the elves and most humans and dwarves, but the sheer pleasure of flight and the chance to utilize his special skill in new and challenging ways gave him some light in a world formerly crowded with shadows of pain and torment. Blaze quickly became as proficient at flying as he used to be, but the elves were increasingly demanding as well. The obstacle course changed every-time and Blaze's path was modified from a simple display of aerial flaming ability to emphasize both accuracy and endurance in his flaming ability. Blaze had to conserve his resources. He never went at the maze half-assed for the elves were alway dropping hints about how well the other fire drakes were doing. Whether true or not, Blaze could not take the chance, not when his Dragonhood was clearly on the line. They raped him with the pole after every session, so that he would not grow too cocky, but Blaze dourly accepted his punishment, choosing to view it as a price to pay for the chance to fly and burn things, setting his blood roaring.
111211121121111111121111111.title: Flying and Flaming

choices: Blaze awakes with a cone around his head
1112111211211111111211111111.content:
Blaze later only had a vague recollection of waking that fateful morning. The lab crew had rolled down the stone hallway, their flatbed cart pulled by a dozen blue skinned trolls. He knew that they'd come for him when they stopped in front of his cell. Flamer-2 looked across at him, eyes laughing, as the elvish lab crew hopped off the cart. They didn't even ask him to cooperate. They simply tossed a crystalline globe into his cell. There was, of course nowhere to hide from the pale mist which oozed out...

Blaze awoke briefly in the sterile whiteness of Dr. Moridin's lab. Consciousness came as a shock and Blaze gasped as if emerging from deep chilly water. Voices came strong and fast as his head breached the surface.

"...course it's too soon! I wanted to put each drake through a year long trial, to see which has the most potential. But Ingrid will not be diverted, he wants results. Well, I'll show him results." The voice was none other than the dread doctor himself. He continued, "While Xiadir continues playing with his lava and fire elementals and bombs down below, I will lead the Kleaves to a new dawn of progress!"

"No one doubts your importance to the project, Doctor." said Auyandrith on Blaze's opposite side.

"Of course they don't." said the doctor who then interrupted himself, "Dear, have you sterilized the spinal implants?"

"I have." she said.

There came a sound mechanical whining that flared and pitched at variable tones. "But Ingrid only sees my work in so far as it can help him topple New Alveri..." said Dr. Moridin with a sigh. "I don't think that even he truly comprehends what I'm trying to do."

Auyandrith said nothing for a time. Blaze took the time to realize that he was again strapped down securely. There were the sounds of a lot of padded feet around him. There was some elf smell, but it was muted under the rank odor of disinfectant. A sense of dread expectancy filled him with dread. Only more technical murmers that Blaze couldn't hope to follow reached his ears. Then cold metal bits were affixed to the skin on his head with some sort of resin.

"Neural map in place Dr. Moridin..." said Auyandrith casually. Then, more alarmed, she added, "Sir, he's awake again."

Dr. Moridin did not sound surprised. "I suspected he has been. This fire drake has a clever streak, unlike our other champions."

Blaze could not help a telling facial twitch when the female assistant asked, "Shall I put him back under?"

"Not just yet." Footsteps. Then a hand on his cheek and that same electric spark which told him of dire consequences should he try to snap. "Flamer-7. Open your eyes. It's alright."

At first Blaze didn't want to comply simply out of casual insurgence. But then he just didn't see the point in the farce anymore. He lifted his scaled lids carefully, trying to avoid blindness this time. When his vision became less blurry, he saw many elves moving around in bizzare outfit. All of it was pure white cloth. All of them wore tight gloves as well as netting on their hair and paper masks over their faces. It all sent a shiver down Blaze's spine. Something was going to happen... They were going to do something to him.

Dr. Moridin crotched in the foreground, his hand on Blaze's face. That silver glove which let him control his body resting against his skin with implicit threat. Auyandrith stood near on the other side of his snout. Her fair hair was bundled up in a net which still fell to the base of her neck. Her green eyes seemed to sparkle with urgency.

As Dr. Moridin grinned at Blaze, she said, "Dr. we need to proceed with the surgery. He needs to be put under again."

"In time, my eager apprentice." The older elf waved off. She seemed slightly miffed by the rebuttal.

Blaze could not contain himself, fear getting the best of him. His jaw scraping against the floor, he asked, "What are you going to do to me?"

Dr. Moridin stood to his full height, his hand still on Blaze's face. "We are going to make you into a better dragon, my young drake."

Tension seemed to break out across his whole body and Blaze tugged at the restraints which kept him tightly bound to the polished tile floor. He writhed uselessly, a low moan in the back of his throat. "N-n-noooo...." But the time for escape had long past.

"You are only upsetting the patient." Auyandrith said. She reached for a conical mask attatched to a hose, but in two long strides, Dr. Moriding reached her and snatched up her hand in his silver glove. Auyandrith went pale as salt and sagged at the wrist, but she stuck to her guns, even as her eyelids fluttered with some deadly influence coursing through her body. "... think of... the recovery time." she mumbled.

Dr. Moridin's face was an icy mask. Then he threw her hand aside, letting Auyandrith collapse to the floor, cradling her breast. "You do not know everything yet, young apprentice..."

Blaze was still struggling, overcome with fear that the elves were going to manipulate his inside, make him into a monster. The touch of the elvish scientist, however, stilled him. "There is value in understanding, that will aid him in the long run." he said to his cringing assistant. Then he turned to Blaze himself. "Flamer-7... Blaze." he cooed.

Blaze was not about to be fooled a second time. "Don't use that name. You don't mean it." Hot tears were flowing down his snout. He was going to mutilate him with his knives and his 'science.'

Blaze was surprised when it boldy admitted it. "Well of course I don't." Then he said something weirder. "But then I don't put much stock in names in general. They only serve to reinforce the idea that there is something in the body worthy of an indivdual identity. But they do seem to offer comfort in most cases, and comfort is itself a worthy goal."

Blaze grunted, "Is that why you torture dragons? To comfort them?"

"Birthing pains, only, my fellow. Of a new golden age of Dragons and Elves alike. This is necessary work. To find the cure."

"The cure for what?" Blaze asked, baffled.

"The cure for egotism, of course." said Dr. Moridin cryptically. "You are but the first step in a new evolutionary phase of dragon-kind! One which will intermingle our two races as never before. You'll come to understand this in time..."

Dr. Moriding turned away then, but Blaze was stuck with an idea despite the insanity which had just poured out of his mouth. "Wait!" he called.

And Dr. Moridin turned, looking expectantly.

"You said understanding can help, right?"

"Knowledge is salve which both soothes and hinders, yes."

"Then help me understand what you're doing. What is all of this for?"

Blaze had meant the entire project, the capuring of himself and other dragons. The island and the plot against New Alveri, his home. But the doctor obvious took him to mean the oncoming surgery. He gestured to a steel plate over by Auyandrith who was leaning against a wall, her eyes still distant. In it, slender objects gleamed, looking part metallic, part organic.

"These torporgic plates are going to be inserted between specific vertebrae in your spine. The fields they emit will stimulate certain aspects of your physiology over a long period of time in tandum with a series of injections over the next few weeks. The details will no doubt baffle you and they are of no real importance. What you should know is that soon you will feel stronger and more virile than you have ever imagined. It is also my hope that certain illusions will be purged from your adolescent mind. With any luck you or your offspring at least will be cured of your unhealthy egotistical natures."

Blaze's fire bladder pulsed hot for the first time in months. But only bile flowed from his fire ducts, souring his mouth with a sulfer taste. He'd need several more good meals to begin refilling the oily fuel for his fire. Blaze realized there was nothing he could to to prevent this from happening, but he said. "You're the one whose egotistical! Who gave you the right to do this to me? You and all the other elves here!. You have no right!"

Dr. Moridin merely clucked his tongue as if in great disappointment. "Believe me when I say that I know what you are talking about. Most elves would sit around loving the smell of their own farts, if they'd admit that they do, in fact fart. Elvish arrogance is next on my list of projects when I'm done here... and I've already had some successes..." He gestured to the wider room. And Blaze did see that some of the lower level assistants had a sort of mild glazed look to their eyes. "Our twin societies will one day be able to cast off the burden of self-importance and foolish notions of 'the soul.' We'll finally be able to live in peace."

Blaze could only shake his head. "You're insane."

Dr. Moridin cocked his head. "You say that now" He reached for the gas mask and lowered it to Blaze's nostrils. "But in a few weeks or months? Who knows? I have hope that you will see the truth." The surgery room faded into black, and Blaze knew nothing more.
1112111211211111111211111111.title: Surgery

choices: Blaze needs a check up with Dr. Moridin
11121112112111111112111111111.content:
Blaze awoke to hazy surroundings. When he opened his eyes, he found that he was back in his cell. Across from him, Flamer-2 still slept, as did Flamer-6, like usual, and for a moment he wondered whether the doctor's threat to mutilate him had been but a dream.

That was when Blaze noticed the dull, throbbing pain in his back. Instinctively, Blaze tried to curve his gaze back, only to find that he could not move his head at all. That's when he noticed the odd aluminum cone wrapped around his neck. He reached for the thing with his claw, but a voice held him back.

"I would advise you not to attempt to remove the cone. Its to ensure that you don't acidentally cut yourself open again" said a voice. A young elf stopped in front of his cell, kneeling down. Blaze growled resentfully, though he figured he should have been glad that it wasn't the doctor.

"Who are you?" snapped Blaze, his eyes narrowing at the unfamiliar elf.

"Your temporary caregiver during your recovery period. You may call me Fang," answered the young elf.

"I take it that Fang is not your real name," snorted Blaze, "Then again, using ones real name is bad for your health it seems..."

The young elf’s gaze narrowed with intrigue. “Indeed, you found that out for yourself didn't you? I take it that this means you would be Flamer-7?”

“Yes, what about it?”

“The good doctor said that you were more clever than any of the other specimens here, and since none of the other subjects are awake and I’ve got nothing better to do, how about we have a brief chat?”

Blaze narrowed his eyes. He was so used to being treated like an animal that he wondered whether Fang was setting some sort of trap.

“So, where’s Wolf and his cronies?” asked Blaze.

“He’s been given some much needed time off…” answered Fang with a sly grin. Blaze snorted. Time off probably meant something like being ‘re-educated’ or something like that, not that Blaze felt sorry for the wretch.

“So, what did the doctor do to me exactly? I didn’t understand all of the doctor’s technical terms, so I was hoping you could tell me what’s going to happen to me physically…” asked Blaze.

“The doctor has given you implants that are designed to make you grow faster than you normally would. These would include enhanced strength, speed and agility, all designed to make you the perfect fighting machine.” said Fang. Blaze could tell that the young elf was being deliberately vague, and of course, there had to be side effects that would soon become apparent. He was not even half a century old, but in the span of a year he'd grow up to larger than his normal adult size? A hot surge of anger burned through Blaze as he thought about how Dr. Moridin had violated him so. What the doctor had done, it was far worse than being whipped, having the pole shoved up his butt or any like that, but to be manipulated on such a basic level with no control meant that he would never forgive him.

“I suspect that you don’t care for what the doctor has done to you though, and that you wish you could flame us all to the powers below if you had the chance,” said Fang, taking a step back.

“That you’d rather be back where you came from and none of this had ever happened.”

"What gave you that idea?" said Blaze

Blaze didn’t respond. He knew better than to fall for that trap.

“Yet ask yourself this, was your life back then anything truly worthwhile?” said Fang.

“What are you talking about? Of course I’d rather have never gone through this crap!!” retorted Blaze. He expected Fang to immediately reach for the shocking rune, yet he did not.

“Really? Back then, you were a nobody, no different from any other drake and probably would have lived your life in obscurity. Feel free to tell me otherwise, but back then, I suspect you were probably a coward and rather timid and would have remained so most likely had we not intervened,” said Fang. Blaze was about to respond, but somehow he found himself paralyzed. Though he hated to admit it, in some ways he was right. Back at the orphanage, he’d always depended on Darzhja and Lady Ramoth to protect him, and when they weren’t there he’d panicked. When he’d been captured, he remember how much he had cried and whined and begged somebody to save him.
