1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Fang replied with a knowing grin, “Sure, why not? In fact, it might be your best chance to get some…practice in before you begin siring.”

He left the chamber with a wink, and Blaze felt his hearts pound faster against his chest and neck. A few minutes later, he caught Honeysweet’s unmistakable scent, as she entered the room gracefully.

“Honeysweet…”

A smile spread across her jaw, as she strode forward and placed her head against the base of his neck. “Flame…”

“I’m glad that you’re all right,” she whispered. “I was…I was really worried…”

Blaze felt himself shudder as he held her close. “Yup, I’m still in one piece apparently…” he said a bit bashfully.

“How about you? How have you and the others been holding up?”

“After the fight, our handlers moved us to the fire drake’s quarters. Not to be rude, but it really smells awful in there. Frankly, we’re all looking forward to moving to the island…”

“Not because they can’t wait to want to be with me? I'm hurt!” answered Blaze facetiously. Honeysweet snorted, “Well, Starry admitted that she’d seen far worse, as have Rocket and Cherry. I’m a little bit concerned about Sparkles though.”

“She’s…the shy one right?”

“She got really scared when she saw you fight Flamer-2. I know you wouldn’t have a choice really, when the time comes, but if she gets frightened, at least try to understand…”

“I’ve been kind of worried about that too actually,” sighed Blaze, “But with the Ancestors as my witnessed, I’ll do whatever I can so that life isn’t quite so miserable and we all have something to look forward to.”

“Look Honeysweet… once we get onto that island, and I’m going to have to…you know…with the other drakka… I…don’t know how things are going to be like between us then. There’s something about you that’s…different from all the others, but before that happens… I just want it to be about us.”

Honeysweet gave Blaze a rather odd sideways glance. “Don’t you mean to say, ‘I want to have sex with you before we go to the island?’”
“That did occur to me more than once, but since you brought the subject up, it doesn’t sound like a bad idea does it?” said Blaze, grinning more than a little bit.

She appeared to agree with the sentiment, yet Blaze sensed that she still wasn’t emotionally comfortable with having to switch to that subject so abruptly. Mating was a very delicate thing, one that required a great deal of trust.

“Were I back home in New Alveri, you probably would have slapped me by now.”

“Y-you’re from New Alveri?” answered Honeysweet. Blaze took a deep breath, staring right into her eyes, “Back then my name…my name was Blaze…”

Blaze was caught by the shock collar, sending him to the ground. Honeysweet let out a yelp of surprise, lowering herself.

Blaze shakily pushed himself back to his feet, “I’m…all right… I’m fine. Yeah… that…that’s my name, my real name. I… lived my life in an orphanage.”

“An orphanage?”

“That’s where hatchlings without clans or parents are cared for, so they don’t have to live on their own. Lady Ramoth, our caregiver, had me do various odd jobs to help the humanoids in the merchant district. Life…wasn’t easy, but I had friends, people who cared about me… Then, I got captured, and you know the story from there. What about you?”

“When I lived with my clan, with mother, father my sisters and cousins, my name was Ember…” A moment later, she too was seized by her shock collar. Yet Blaze rushed forward to catch her, holding her close so she wouldn’t collapse.

“You all right…Ember?” asked Blaze. He’d said her name before he could contemplate whether saying her real name might shock him, and was pleasantly surprised to find it did not. Ember nodded shakily, and Blaze held her close and protectively, wanting to make her feel safe. He felt much better now that he had shared his story with her, and vice-versa, and seemed much more willing to share now that she knew his real name.

“Ancestors you are so beautiful,” he groaned fondly. Honeysweet purred, her tail swaying slightly back and forth. Blaze couldn’t help but inhale her scent, making his entire body shudder.

“Oh babe, I want you so badly...” Ember let out a slight and extremely cute yelp of surprise.

“If that’s all right with you of course…” amended Blaze.

She seemed to think about it for a moment, before twining her tail with him, purring, “Yes, I’d…I’d like that very much Blaze…”

Blaze could hardly believe his ears, and could not help but feel very worthy of himself. Despite all the cruelty and the pain, the humiliation and experimentation, having the adoration of this beautiful young drakka, ready and willing to mate with him, made all that suffering worth it. Though this was but the fourth time he’d ever seen her, Blaze already felt that if he ever managed to escape the Kleaves, that he would be content to spend the rest of his life with her.

Now was the time of the moment of truth. She stared back at him with wide eyes, struggling to keep her breath under control as she gingerly lifted her tail. Blaze lowered his head and sniffed at her wet, open pussy, the scent driving him crazy. Ancient instincts arose within Blaze. He’d defeated his male rival, and now he would take his rightful prize, mounting her from behind. It wasn’t quite taking her to the sky, but it nonetheless was a surprisingly comfortable position, and he was also quite surprised at just how flexible the tail joints of drakka were. For a good long moment, Blaze gazed down to admire her body, and the bright desire in her eyes as she gazed back at him. Blaze grinned back devilishly at her as he aimed his penis at her entrance.

“Are you ready Ember?” asked Blaze.

“Take me Blaze. Take me as your own…”

Blaze took a deep breath, and then pushed his length forward into her, and Ember let out a gasp of surprise. Given that it was the first time for both of them, their lovemaking was rather awkward at first. It took a bit of fumbling, but eventually they were able to find a rhythm they both found comfortable, and things really took off from there.

Blaze felt his confidence surge as Ember’s moans intensified, her slender body moving in time with. Together, they ascended higher and higher, until finally Blaze unfurled his wings and let out a triumphant roar as he thrust forward as far as he could and exploded within her with several powerful bursts, Ember singing in tune beneath him. At that moment, Blaze felt like the King of all of Nod, no, greater than Gyramond himself!!

The next thing he consciously remembered was that he was laying upon his belly with a huge smile on his jaw. He shifted his gaze toward Ember, holding heragainst him possessively.

“So, did I meet your expectations?” asked Blaze with a grin.

Ember only purred contentedly in response, and Blaze felt like Gyramond himself. Yet in the back of his mind, he knew that some of his pride was illusory. He and Ember were both prisoners of the Kleaves, subject to their every whim. Tomorrow, he might find Ember gone; never to be seen again.

“Someday…Ember, we’ll get out of this place, and we’ll take off together in the sky. You can meet all my old friends in New Alveri, and I can meet all yours…” Blaze vowed.

Ember smiled longingly, “Yes…that would be very wonderful…Blaze. Won’t father, mother and my dear sister be surprised when I return with you by my side hmmm?”

“Hopefully, he won’t try to flame my balls off. Or maybe he’ll be so impressed that he’ll ask me to court all the other females in your clan as well… I heard polygamy was legal amongst the clans…” he teased, unable to help but tease her with a lick in the neck.

Ember stuck out her tongue. “Sorry,” Blaze apologized, not really sounding sorry at all, “That came out wrong…”

“I’d be angrier if not for the fact he probably would ask such a thing…” snorted Ember. “Strange how these things work hmmm? I actually left my clan because he wanted to pair me up with a thin male twice my age, and he warned me that if I did, I could end up being kidnapped or raped.”

“I hate to say it, but…he certainly was right on one account… Yet think of it this way, if we hadn’t been caught, then we probably would never have met each other. I’d probably still be a frightened runt, not really amounting to anything and living a dull life. Not that I think its fun getting tortured or having the pole shoved up your ass, but its more like seeing the positives that came out of this whole mess.”

The two young drakes continued to gaze at each other, absorbed in each others presence. “You know…Ember, I still don’t think we should use our real names unless we’re by ourselves.”

“You’re probably right about that…Lord Flame…” answered Ember, her voice much more business like now.

“Flame would be all right. Besides, I’ve got to honestly admit that Honeysweet is a cute name…” teased Blaze.

Ember/Honeysweet sniffed, playfully smacking Blaze with his wing. They spent the rest of that day together, in that little room, talking and joking with one another. Had it not been for the guards watching from outside the room, the rows of chained trolls marching just outside, and the faint screams of pain from Dr. Moridin’s room just down the hall, one would have almost thought they were talking on the streets of New Alveri again, like a regular young adolescent couple.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Blaze and Ember

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Yesterday had been, quite frankly and more than a little ironically, Blaze’s best day ever. Losing ones virginity was a giant milestone for any male drake, and he’d done it with the drakka he dreamed of doing it with. Not just once. After that first time, they’d talked for a while longer, learning about each other and sharing secrets and when night came both had found that they still had quite a bit of energy to burn, so they’d licked and moaned and groped and fucked non-stop until they had almost quite literally collapsed from exhaustion.

So when Fang came to fetch for him that morning, he’d found the two young dragons sprawled against each other. Blaze didn’t bother to conceal himself from the handler, who couldn’t help but be also stare at Blaze’s groin for a moment. Perhaps he was jealous at the comparative size difference?

“Good morning Fang. As it turns out, I seemed to have taken your advice…” said Blaze, not bother to conceal his wide grin, while at the same time, rubbing his wing along Ember’s form, who purred in response.

“I can definitely see that for myself. Anyhow, I hate to be a third wheel, but I’m going to have to ask you put your nethers back where they belong, step away from the female and follow me to the docks,” cried Fang with an amused grin.

“Will we be coming on the same boat?” asked Ember.

“Unfortunately, we don’t have a boat large enough for you two lovebirds while also carrying a full load of supplies. Even if we did, we’d rather not have two horny dragons shaking up the boat while its sailing,” answered Fang. Blaze shifted his gaze, while Ember swished her tail slightly.

“All right then, I’m coming…” said Blaze, allowing himself to be harnessed. Fang took a seat upon Blaze’s withers, seemingly making himself at home. He shifted his gaze back to Ember and gave her an encouraging nod. Ember’s handler came into the room right afterwards. She was a female elf, Blaze observed, and was harnessed in a similar way as Blaze had been, and was glad to see that the staff that handled her was considerably much gentler.

While a dragon would never express pride in having a humanoid ride them like a beast of burden, it sure beat being dragged in a cage. As he headed down from the mountain, Blaze didn’t even bother to hide the confident spring in his step, nor that smug grin on his face, puffing his chest outwards and holding his head up a bit higher than he usually did.

Behind him, her handler led Ember, who while not strutting like Blaze was, nonetheless was in high spirits. He remembered how the bronze drakka had looked when Lord Azimoth had led them away, with heads down and lifeless eyes; nothing of the sort with Ember, and hopefully, the other fire drakka as well. Blaze could feel her eyes upon him the entire way, and every so often, he would shift his gaze backwards to try and catch her gazing at him. She blushed, very deeply, clearing remembering that night, not so subtly hinting that she’d like to do it again sometime, and ideally sometime soon. His only concern was that he’d gone at it so hard and passionately with Ember, when the time came that he had to mate with the rest of the harem, he’d feel like he was cheating on her. Then again, there were an untold number of former drakes who would have loved to have Blaze’s dilemma.

He then switched his gaze back toward Fang.

“Don’t mind me asking Fang, but what exactly were you doing while we were…um going at it?” asked Blaze.

“A little of this, and a little of that. Mostly administrative stuff…” answered Fang, vaguely as usual.

“A bit more specific?” wondered Blaze.

Fang smiled his enigmatic grin of his, “I’ll tell you, in exchange for you telling me more details about what went on between the two of you yesterday…” Blaze realized he was asking for more than just the juicy details, but rather the personal nature of the conversation that he and Ember had shared. While Fang was not bad as far as Kleaves went, Blaze didn’t feel the need to give Fang any personal information that could be used as leverage against not only him but also Ember.

When Blaze arrived at the docks, three large state of the art sailing ships were moored. The crew, both human sailors and troll slaves, were busy stacking supplies onto the ship. As Blaze was walking the plank, he passed by a large cage, and within it laid a dragon he did not expect to see.

“Flamer-6? You’re alive!!” said Blaze, his wings nearly unfurling in surprise. His body was heavily bandaged, and looked even thinner and more feeble than ever. More dismayingly but not surprisingly, Flamer-6’s scent had weakened to an inoffensive odor, which meant they had neutered him.

“Yes…that…does seem to be the case doesn’t it?” said Flamer-6, sounding far from happy that he still was. Blaze curved his gaze back toward Fang, “Would it be all right if you gave me a minute to speak with him?”

“Sure… you might as well catch up…” answered Fang. Frankly, Blaze suspected that Fang wanted to observe so that he could learn more about the dragon he held ownership over. Ember’s handler seemed to share that sentiment as well, and in fact appeared to take up a light conversation.

Flamer-6 then took a sniff. “It would seem you have really enjoyed your first day as breeder male…Lord Flame…”

“”Well, it wasn’t bad…” shrugged Blaze, trying to make a conscious effort not to make Flamer-6 feel too bad.

Flamer-6 snorted, “B-bet you fucked her all night… Can see why you’d have the hots for a drakka like her, it was…Sweet…sweet something?” inquired Flamer-6.

“Honeysweet,” corrected Ember, trying to be encouraging.

“Right…I always thought you were a bit on the tall side for me. Personally, I liked the shy, tittering one…”

“Really?” cried Ember, surprised, “You should have said something to Sparkles while you were there then. She probably wouldn’t have been as afraid of males otherwise…”

“Maybe, but not that it matters now,” he sighed. “Still, better she ended up with you… Lord Flame. I’m guessing that means Flamer-2 got what he deserved right?”

“I’d rather you still call me Flamer-7, or Flame is fine. As for Flamer-2, the powers below are taking him up the ass with a thorny, flaming pole really slow and agonizingly,” growled Blaze.

“Indeed…” agreed Flamer-6. While Blaze was glad Flamer-2 was suffering in hell where he belonged, it didn’t gain favor with the Ancestors to gloat too much on misfortune of even the most evil, condemned souls.

“I lucked out actually. Flamer-8 took a blow that would have killed me. He’s…with the Ancestors now. Never learned his real name,” Blaze said with genuine regret.

“Its just as well for Flamer-8. He died a drake…and not…” Flamer-6 averted his gaze downwards.

“Come on 6, don’t say things like that!! I know it’s easy for me to say because it didn’t happen to me, but I don’t want you thinking ‘woe is me’. I don’t want you to become all dull and lifeless like Flamer-1 is.”

Flamer-6 puffed. “I’m not that far gone, not yet anyhow. Apparently, the Kleaves still have a marginal use for me. I am designated to be a ‘harem guard’ it would seem, since I’m physically incapable of performing any combat duties anymore…”

Blaze didn’t know what to feel at that. It would feel very awkward to have Flamer-6 outside the room while he was fucking Ember. Still it was reassuring to have another drake, well, he wasn’t quite one now, that he knew and could reasonably hope to trust.

“Now that I think about it, that works out pretty well. You’re a really smart drake six and you know how to get stuff done, to keep track of things. I’d love to have an exercise machine like the one you built back in our old lair.”

“I-I suppose that beats being cut up for parts…” he shrugged.

Just then, Fang tugged on Blaze’s reins. “We’re going to be boarding ship now…”

“I’ll…catch you later Flamer-6,” said Blaze, looking over his shoulder with a friendly nod. He then switched his gaze toward Ember and gave her a fond growl, and she answered back with a purr of her own.

When he entered the cargo hold, it wasn’t as smelly or dirty as it was like last time. In fact, they didn’t even chain him up as expected. The ship did have an anti-fire spell upon it, but other than that he felt more like a passenger than cargo. Fang was up on deck, directing the sailor crews. Blaze grunted; the most trying portion of his time with the Kleaves had passed, and things actually were turning out for the better now.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Unexpected company at the docks

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
This ship ride was not nearly so terrible as the months long journey Blaze had nearly died on coming from the main port city of the Alverian Empire. However, Blaze still found the ship's hold uncomfortably cramped. The close quarters only served to remind Blaze of his great size. It was hard to believe that at roughly a half-century-old, he was already at his full adult size... and absolutely ripped to boot. He already weighed perhaps half again as much as he would have in adulthood without modification, if Blaze's memory of his old stringy self were anything to go on. "And I'm not done yet..." thought Blaze unsurely as he rested, coiled in the gently rocking bowls of the large flagship. "Soon I'll be as large as Honeysweet... perhaps larger still. Ancestors, I hope it stops..."

Blaze, after all his trials had only a small portion of hope left, but Dr. Moridin had said that the process would take roughly a year and in just 60 days or so, that time will have passed. "Ancestors, has it been that long already?" He wondered dejectedly. Despite being a dragon and thus having a millennial lifespan (if he was lucky), and having a dragon's sense of time, his stint with the Kleaves had seemed both tortuously long and incredibly brief. Blaze was content only that he was on his way from the place of his torment, even if he was simply passing from one jail cell to another.

He had few visitors, other than to give him food and water. The sailors seemed to recognize that Blaze, despite being a dragon under the Kleaves control, had earned some status in the ranks as breeder male and thus might be less inhibited from eating low ranking tormentors. Blaze was more than fine with that; and in fact he actually contemplated relieving one of the sailors of their foot like Jinx had done (briefly, he wondered what had become of Jinx, if he was now a breeder male like himself now, or was one of the many eunuchs) if one got too uppity. At the same time, Blaze already had too many bad memories of having the pole shoved up his butt, and he didn't feel the need to get a reminder of that horrible feeling.

In the meantime, Blaze occupied himself with thoughts of New Alveri and the orphanage, lest the memories fail him and he fall into darkness. One scene from Blaze's past that he went over time and again, replaying the sequence of events in his mind, was that day of the attack. Darzhja had been there, her face fearful and yet bold and serious at the same time. She'd known what she was doing, almost more than Kaj who himself was a member of the city guard. She hadn't hesitated to leap into danger when Blaze had reported what had happened to Iskeirka. He'd seen the building collapse on her himself and yet she didn't hesitate... He used to be such a pussy, a useless coward that would sooner leave one of his close friends to die than try and do anything to help. He’d instead tried to save his own hide, and in the end, he hadn't even accomplished that. Perhaps getting captured was a just reward for his cowardice.

Blaze rested his chin on his paws and sighed, his tail curling up around his jaw. His fire bladder pulsed. For amusement, Blaze coughed a small fireball out onto the wood. The fire played on the surface of the wood, which was protected by a rather complicated enchantment. Blaze watched the tort burn and sizzle on the wood, skimming along its surface like a water droplet on a hot pan until it used up its fuel and went out. After that he occupied himself with picking the dried blood out from under his claws, and after that, he scoured his teeth with sand and water...

It was a three-day journey, all told and by the end of it, Blaze was eager to be out. He hadn't once been able to stretch his wings during the trip. In fact, the upper decks had to be disassembled just to let him out. Blaze groaned when the sunlight finally stabbed down to meet him. There was one thing on his mind: Ember.

"Not so fast young drake" came a cool collected voice.

Still squinting in the light, as the sailors labored to move the planks constituting the decks above, Blaze couldn't see Fang at all until he stepped into a patch of sunlight. He was wearing a rather ostentatious crimson robe with gold dragons emblazoned on his shoulders and chest. The young elf smelled quite content with himself. "What? Are you afraid that I'll burst through this planks and make a run for it?"

Unbeknownst to Fang, Blaze had already considered the ploy in his head and rejected it for one simple reason: Blaze was not going to leave the Kleaves without Ember. But Fang just chortled. "Nothing of the sort. However," and now the elf stepped forward and placed a cool hand on Blaze's foreleg. "There is a sense of propriety which must be maintained here. This is the first time the inhabitants of the colony will see you, the reason why they are all here. There will be appearances to maintain. You are not Flamer-7 anymore. You are Lord Flame now, the perfect Fire-drake..." he paused, ever so slightly and added, "And I am your master."

Blaze looked down at the young elf and snorted. "So your true colors are finally coming out then? I'm to be your slave, after all of that help you gave me back there."

Fang grinned and crossed his arms, leaning his hip on Blaze's leg as he did so. "How can you be sure these are my true colors? Or that those were my true colors, for that matter?"

The large dragon shook his head slightly. More beams of light pierced the gloom in the hold of the ship from above. "I'm not sure about anything with you, to be quite honest."

Fang just smirked affably, like always. "Maybe that's how I like it."

"Obviously." said Blaze dryly.

The elf waved a loose-sleeved arm. "Enough posturing. I just came down here to tell you about what to expect from here on out."

"I'm listening." said Blaze, tilting his massive head.

"This place... It's little more than a fort at the moment and my father is expecting us to turn it into a self-sufficient colony within three years. In addition, he'll be expecting clutches of fire drakes in the next five."

Blaze clutched his forepaws and shifted his wings, causing Fang to back away a few steps. "Five years?! That's impossible! They won't have even left the nest yet, never mind have their wings emerge... Not that you'll ever set your filthy hands on them!" Blaze growled. Of course, Blaze should have seen this coming, but he nonetheless his instincts drove him to irrational rage. It was one thing to torture him, or even to hurt Honeysweet, but for the Kleaves to unleash their diabolical plan on his little ones, unforgivable...

It was a tight space, but Blaze snaked his head forward towards Fang, prepared to end him right then and there. Fang, however, seemed well prepared for a violent reaction. Without even flinching, he reached into his sleeve and withdrew some powder. Quick as a flash, he spread it on the ground before him and there sprang a wall of fire, which towered in front of Blaze's nose. The fire drake recoiled, the wall was radiating heat, though his scales were coping; he was forced to turn his face away where the scales were thinnest, however. The flames seemed weird, much more solid looking than usual. It was obviously enchanted fire and Blaze had no fancy to try sticking his claws through it.

Despite the heat the Blaze felt, Fang seemed quite comfortable behind his wall. His right hand was twisted in an arcane gesture as he maintained the spell. "Blaze of New Alveri!”

The madness of Blaze's first reaction faded quickly, especially with that horrible fire right in his face. Yet more than that there was the fact that Fang had spoken Blaze’s real name; and him having that knowledge was a greater deterrent than any spell or restraining device the Kleaves could devise.

“I understand that this is hard for you, and your instincts would drive you to protect your young. Yet you must understand your position in all of this. Will resisting now get you any closer to freedom? Will resisting now, protect Honeysweet or anybody else you care about?"

He lifted a claw to better shield himself from the heat as his face grew uncomfortably warm. However, Blaze was sharper than most and he recognized the play in Fang's words. "Resisting now? So you’re saying that I’d have to wait for the right moment might be better?" Blaze asked

Fang growled, or whatever it is that elves and humans call "growling," "I said nothing of the sort."

But Blaze wasn't through. "You also mentioned your father... Who is he? He must pretty high up if he really organized all of this..." Blaze hesitated and decided to follow through on his train of thought, "Might he even be the leader of the Kleave Order?"

Fang relaxed his hand and the tall flames immediately vanished. Blaze lowered his paw and made no action to resume aggressions. Oblivious to the small confrontation occurring below, sailors were calling to each other as they began lifting the last segment of deck from above.

"Yes…why yes he is,” said Fang.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Fang's true colors

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Blaze couldn’t tell if he said that in a way to threaten him, or if it hinted some sort of conflict between the two. Like all things, perhaps it was both. There was a chance that he could be bluffing just to unsettle Blaze, yet the narrowing of his gaze and the sharp, dangerous conviction in which he spoke said otherwise. “Funny that you should mention that...Blaze... you are too clever by half."

"I'll take that as a compliment," answered Blaze, trying to maintain composure, yet the young drake couldn’t help but feel the chill down his spine.

"Don’t get too clever drake. You know the old saying, what excessive curiosity killed. I’d like to imagine that I’ve been quite lenient and generous with you, Flame, and to be honest I’d like to keep things that way. Yet if that’s not getting the necessary results; that can change…” he finished with a low growl, and that conversation instantly died right then and there. Now, Blaze saw the reflection of the father, of the man who had started this operation and had imprisoned so many young dragons and the ruthless ambition to see his will be done. It explained in one sense why Fang was so talented, so clever, able to read people so easily, if he’d gotten his tutelage from the man himself.

The elf who ran this, Lord Ingrid, was an undeniably evil humanoid, yet to have run such an operation required unparalleled intelligence and will, and perhaps more ominously, and if the Fang was indeed a reflection of the father, then the leaders most potent ability was not necessarily being adept with magic, of which he undoubtedly was, but an ability to convince a mass following of people into his order, to make the irrational and immoral sound like the most perfectly natural thing in the world. Regardless, Blaze would have to re-evaluate how he approached Fang, and for better and for worse, he felt in his hearts that he was stuck with him.

Then, as if they’d never had this hostile conversation, the young elf grabbed the heavy leather saddle from where it hung on the wall. He handled it with surprising grace despite its obvious weight. Too intrigued to resist, Blaze lowered his head so that Fang could throw the padded thing over the base of his neck. As Fang was fastening the straps, he spoke.

"We will have to have a long conversation about how things are going to be handled on the island." He yanked a belt until it was snug around Blaze's neck.

"Ugh!" grunted Blaze.

"Hm... We are going to have to get bigger saddle, you are already too thick for this one it seems."

"Is that some subtle way of saying that I have to lose weight?" Blaze mocked.

"Not by half. Dr. Moridin will be pleased when he sees your full size... as will my father."

Blaze frowned but didn't speak. He knew Fang well enough now to see that the young elf was done answering questions. Then, once again, he quickly switched from his menacing tone to his usual upbeat one, "Once we get off the ship, the first thing you will have to do is unload her hold. Then you can assist with unloading the other two ships and carrying the supplies to Fort Carmile.

Blaze was about to say, "Lovely, I get to be ship crane and draft horse in one day." but what actually came out of his mouth was: "Is Honeysweet going to be here?"

He must have known that he already knew the answer, but Fang obliged the longing drake. "Yes, she will be here, as well as your new harem guard, that 'Six' if I recall. Though, honestly, I don't know how much use such a dragon is going to be..."

Blaze frowned, and grunted, "You'd be surprised."

"I may be at that, I will judge his usefulness by his actions" admitted Fang.

With that, the last section of deck was lifted away and Blaze crawled stiffly out of the hold of the ship. He used forepaws and wing talons to grip the decks and placed his feet carefully to minimize the rocking of the vessel. He crawled out into the sunlight and beheld a marvelous vision.

They were anchored about half a dragon-length off from the shore of the island. A tall craggy mountain rose in the distance, all covered with green. White vapor rose from its peak. The ship was nestled in a narrow cove surrounded by tall rocky cliffs. Just ahead there was a small pier serviced by a simple wooden elevator supported by the cliff above. Blaze could see why now he was expected to assist in unloading the ship.

"They're still building the dragon tower, or so I'm told," said Fang in Blaze's ear as he stood up in the gently rocking boat. "We'll be receiving most of our supplies by air in the future, God willing."

"God?" thought Blaze confusedly, but had little time to dwell on the odd thing Fang had said, nor did he think it the appropriate time to emphasize his reverence for the Ancestors. The elf immediately had Blaze arrange himself in the hold so that some of the sailors could hitch some big leather satchels to the dragon's underbelly. They were quite afraid to get near Blaze at first, especially since now he was spread through all the decks in the middle of the ship, but after the Bosun whipped a man into a bloody heap, the rest fell in line.

It was quite a burden, but Blaze managed to extricate himself from the ship, he bent his knees in preparation to lift himself into the air. "Careful with the pier," said Fang, "It won't support your weight."

Blaze absorbed the fact silently as he spread his wings. The phalanges of his limbs gripping the heavy, moist air of the cove, Blaze lifted himself as gently into the air as he could. The boat made big ripples in the water, inadvertently causing a few of the workers to lose their balance and fall into the water, as he flew up and away.

Even the heavy weight dragging on his belly could not damage the natural splendor of the island when Blaze crested the sea cliffs. The place was certainly volcanic! Blaze could feel in the air currents that there were some major hotspots around here. The greenery spread out below, as he gained altitude, flapping tirelessly up into the atmosphere, was dense and tropical. Unlike the main island, there were neither fields nor pastures... not yet anyways. In fact, if Blaze was not sure otherwise, the place almost looked uninhabited.

Fang bewitched his hand and spoke into it so Blaze could hear his little voice over the wind. "If you want a den, you are going to have to dig for it. You'll be sleeping outside or under a pavilion until then."

Blaze just grinned. "Sleeping outside!" The idea sounded like wish come true!

Fang directed Blaze to the fort. Even from a distance, Blaze wasn't impressed. The place looked like it hadn't existed for more than a year. A wooden palisade penned in a few buildings and a small winding trail was cut through the jungle down to the small pier and that was about it. Blaze grunted and spoke back to Fang. "This is it?" he scoffed. "What exactly is supposed to keep me and Honeysweet from just flying away from this pile of sticks?"

Blaze couldn't see it, but he sensed Fang grinning behind him. "All is not that meets the eye." said the elf. "Your collar still works, remember and they have the means for recharging and maintaining them down there. In addition to that, there are many other safeguards in place for keeping dragons around."

"Really?" said Blaze shrewdly over the wind. "And what means might those be?"

"If I told you what those were, that would rather defeat the purpose now would it?” answered Fang. Blaze did not pretend for a moment that Fang did not have the means to make good on his threat. “Right now, though, we are going to meet the colonists and your subjects- under me as well." Blaze felt Fang's hand on his neck, rubbing the scales fondly, "Do try to look regal won't you?"

"I'll try to imagine there's as large a stick up my butt as Lord Azimoth." said Blaze. That one actually earned a chuckle from Fang as they circled lower over the small settlement. When they landed...
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Fang's true colors: Part II

choices: Humans come to take the bags off of Blaze
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Having grown up in the wondrous city of New Alveri, the settlement appeared rather pitiful indeed in comparison as Blaze circled above, both dropping speed and displaying himself for the rabble below to see. There did not appear to be too much development as of yet. Most of the buildings inside the palisade were wooden and crude at that. They were so ramshackle, in fact that Blaze feared that the breeze of his passage might be enough to collapse some of them. But there were already the foundations for a larger settlement in place… literally. Not one of the stone buildings were complete, but there were several spread out around the village. The most conspicuous of these was the large circular foundation located just outside the village. Cranes hovered over that one and it looked like a lot of construction had already gone into it. Blaze assumed this was the dragon tower Fang had mentioned. The young drake tried to imagine most of the trade of the island one day passing through that pile of square stones, but failed.

Below, a gaggle of humans gawked up at him, actually pointing at him and many with open mouthed wonder… or was it terror? Their wide-eyed stares annoyed Blaze. In New Alveri, one did not bat an eye at a dragon coming in for a landing and yet these wretches were gathering as if for a freakshow. Blaze felt dreadfully conspicuous, but also angry that these unlearned Kleaves should gape at him so. Especially when their unwashed stink rose even to Blaze’s considerable height.

The only place suitable in the village for landing was the very center which was empty save for a single tall obelisk of unknown purpose. Blaze angled himself as steeply as he thought was safe. He wanted to reach the square before it became too clogged with unwitting bystanders. The design of the village already irked the large drake. None of the streets were wide enough for a dragon to pass save the main one leading to the southern gate. That was one of the first things that Blaze intended on mentioning to Fang when they had some time alone.

Alighting a little heavily, Blaze bounced a bit and wound up accidently crushing part of a wagon with his right hindfoot. He paid it about as much mind as a human would stepping on a stray branch; if anything, it was their fault for forcing him to land in such cramped conditions. Blaze glanced at the pale stone obelisk which was the sole decoration of the sparten village. Fang straightened himself up in his saddle at the base of Blaze’s neck. Remembering Fang’s words, Blaze lifted his head and tried to imagine himself “regal.” It wasn’t too difficult, really, considering the surroundings. When Blaze lifted his head, he realized that he could see over most of the single story buildings.

Blaze’s very first coherant thought about the settlement after taking it all in was, “What a dump.”

Fang seemed on an almost identical wavelength. Despite being behind him, he could sense Fang’s obvious dismay. “I’m supposed to make a city in five years with this?” he whispered in Blaze’s ear as the people gathered. Blaze said nothing. Unlike the elf, it was difficult making his voice inconspicuous and already the square was filling with the town’s inhabitants.

In just a few minutes, what seemed to be the entire population of the settlement had been gathered, only about a few hundred at the most; though it was always a little hard to tell with humanoids. Some of the colonists were dressed differently and some had armor on, indicative of the guards Blaze remembered from the main island. Most, however, were dressed in simple linens and hemp; perhaps woven right here on the island. Now that he was on the ground with them, though still towering over their small formed with his many horned head, the staring was even more intense. A hushed silence pervaded the square where the colonists stood just beyond the obelisk at the center. The entire crowd flinched when he moved towards them; many seemed on the verge of panic.

Blaze frowned disdainfully as the colonists fixed upon him with fear and awe in their ignorant eyes. One would think they’d never seen a dragon before! And yet… as the moments lengthened and Fang did not speak - Surely no one expected Blaze to speak - Blaze began to wonder if indeed any of these backward humanoids had indeed seen a dragon before. The young drake tasted the air with his tongue, the crowd reeked of ignorance and rural superstition, and for a young drake used to interacting with the confident citizenry of New Alveri, he felt more than a little contempt. Where they had come from, Blaze couldn’t know, but he thought they were refugees, vagabonds, bumpkins and perhaps other dregs of society. Did they know about the shining jewel that was New Alveri? Did they even know who it was they were working for? From the looks on their dull, dirty faces, Blaze doubted it. Whatever circumstances had led them here, these people had no idea of what they were caught in the middle of, surely if the mere sight of a dragon could inspire such terrible, openmouthed awe. These people were prisoners in the truest sense of the word, so much so that they weren’t even aware of it.

Finally the tension broke on their side. In the rabble, a man rose a walking stick over his head and cried in barely coherent Common, “Itsa winged Demon! Ye Gods protect us from it!!” Blaze heard Fang let out an audible sigh.

“Flame, if you would please, give them a roar to get their attention…” commanded Fang.

The young drake could see the wisdom in such an order. Before his slit eyes, the panic seemed to spread outward from the first addled man. Blaze raised his head into the air and let out a roar that sent birds flying from beyond the palisade. Immediately, the panicking townsfolk froze to a shocked silence. Somewhere a child began sobbing.

Seated upon Blaze, Fang finally began to deliver his speech. The adolescent dragon turned slightly so that the small elf on his back was more visible.

“Greetings, colonists of Fort Carmile. I am Lord Fang, and from henceforth I am the ruler of this island. For those who decide to support me and heed the commands of their new ruler, I promise prosperity and wealth. For those who decide to oppose me or subvert my rule in any way:”

Instead of answering directly, Fang conjured up a ball of fire in his hands and launched it straight up into the air whereupon it burst into a great many burning stars. Seeing the effect, Blaze decided to snort some smoke from his nostrils and sink his claws into the earth for a bit of extra emphasis.

Nothing more really needed to be said after that. Even the arms-men in Kleave-garb seemed impressed by Fang’s mastery of fire. As for the townsfolk, a man appearing out of the sky on the back of a fire-breathing dragon seemed a qualification for godhood really. With disgust, Blaze watched those nearest him get on their knees and bow before Fang in a most servile manner, lowering their heads all the way to the dirt. Worse, they made their children practice the kowtow as well! Any respect Blaze might have had for these people was dead before they’d spoken a word. Citizens from New Alveri would have never behaved in such a degrading manner. Blaze was also a little frightened at the way Fang seemed to glow in the light of their submission as well.

After Fang’s little speech, the settlers drifted back to their chores, and those that lingered were helped along by men with swords. Fang descended from Blaze’s saddle with usual elvish grace and met with a man, who unlike the other armed guards had a red handprint on his left shoulder. The man saluted Fang and waited to be addressed.

The elf spoke while keeping his hands clasped inside his overlarge sleeves. “Am I speaking to Cheif Armsman Seymor?”

The man deeply inclined his head and placed his closed fist on his heart again. “You are, Master Fang. We’ve been expecting you. Granted, we thought we would have a little more time before you arrived with the fire dragons.”

“There were some unexpected… developments on the mainland, Sergent, that need not concern you.” The man looking at the elf swallowed, but bravely held his pose. Fang continued, “I need to be briefed on the status of the colony.”

“We have our book of records and our head masons on standby, my lord. It will only take a few minutes to gather them.” Said Seymor.

In a slippery voice, Fang said, “See that you do.” The man frowned and bowed again taking his leave. Quickly, he sent out half a dozen men to different locations before returning to the young elf.

“If you will follow me, Master Fang, we can hold conference in your new temporary quarters.”

Fang said nothing, but headed inside a small wooden building that smelled of lantern oil and pig grease, much like the other shacks. While the townspeople had been easily impressed with Blaze, the Kleave guards eyed him warily, and he noticed that the two white shouldered corporals kept special pendants close at hand; Blaze was not at all sure what they would do, but he had no interest in finding out. He curled up in the square, resting his head on the ground but tilted towards the building into which Fang had dissapeared in hopes of listening in on what Fang had to say with the local town prefecture. The details quickly bored the young dragon, however as the humans started off with over a half hour of niceties and gratifying remarks about their new lord and master, Fang.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Ignorance

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
During this time, Blaze was interrupted in his eavesdropping when a couple of armed men poked him in the shoulder with the tips of their long pikes. Blaze lifted his head and growled softly, but a corporal waved his pendant threatening. “Move, beast. We need’ta get them bags offa yer gut.”

The other corporal punched his comrade in the arm. “What’re you talking to it for? Just zap it. That oughta get’it roll over quick.”

Becoming very aware of the inhibitor collar around his neck again, Blaze rolled over onto his flank before another word could be spoken. In truth, he’d forgotten about the heavy bundles affixed to his underbelly. He hoped he wouldn’t be blamed if anything were slightly squashed. Predictably, the guards didn’t lift a finger, but instead got some frightened villagers to undo the straps and haul off the burden. Everything about the way they did it was wrong.

For starters, the men were almost pissing their trousers getting this close to Blaze; He knew because he could smell it. Only sharpened steel could motivate them to get near. Then, instead of opening the vast leather satchels and unloading them, they seemed intent on unbuckling the whole thing from Blaze; which they hadn’t the least idea how to do. They just started undoing buckles every which way, and of course, that led to something pulling or pinching the large dragon. Twice all of the men scattered when Blaze shifted his weight due to the bungling and twice the townsfolk were re-gathered at sword point to continue. But Blaze remained still and placid and escaped getting shocked and that was all that really mattered. The village idiots would up dragging the entire mess of leather, belts and buckles a short distance away before they began to unload it right in front of Blaze. The dragon let out an excruciating sigh.

Back inside the house, Blaze was only mildly consoled with finally listening in on what Fang was talking about. Rather than some grand, dragon related schemes, however, the adolescent drake was met only with a long list of proposals and locations on maps he obviously couldn’t see. Basically, Fang had inquired about the progress of the landing platform, mineral surveys for potential mining operations, land clearance proposals, and other projects aimed at expanding the settlement.

Finally, after what seemed like forever, a rather weary Fang exited the small house and re-mounted Blaze.

“Sorry to keep you waiting Flame…” apologized Fang.

Blaze merely harrumphed. “I hope you won’t have me standing watch like this too often. This place is quite claustrophobic…” he couldn’t help but comment.

“What, were you expecting this to be New Alveri?” snorted Fang.

“No, but I’d rather be hanging out with trolls than with these ignorant colonists. Frankly, the less I have to do with them, the happier I’ll be…” replied Blaze. He lifted his head and smelled the breeze “So where are we off to now?”


That first day on the island was both busy and rather lonely for Blaze. It was simply the first time in his life that he didn’t have any other dragons around; even in the ships hold, there had been Jinx. The lack of familiar dragon-smell in the environment was slightly disconcerting, but Fang kept his charge busy, as if sensing his malaise.

Blaze could unload supplies from the ship ten times faster than the sailors could using the dinky little elevator. However, hauling supplies up fifty-foot cliffs with nothing more substantial to grab onto than the air itself was back breaking labor in and of itself.

By the late afternoon, Blaze found himself famished. He hadn’t eaten anything since he had arrived upon the island.

“How about a break Flame?” said Fang, noticing Blaze’s weariness. Left unsaid was the fact that Fang looked as if he could use a break as well. Despite riding upon Blaze, Fang hadn’t been idle, using his magic to lift boxes out of the boat, while having to yell profusely at the workers.

“Yes, please!!” answered Blaze, almost desperately.

“Lucky for you, there’s no shortage of wild animals to be found. According to my map, there should be a small stream about a half mile north from here…”

Fang proved to be correct in his assertion, as Blaze spotted a gathering of water buffalo around a small pond. Mouth watering, Blaze quickly descended and pounced on a tasty looking water buffalo - Fang still attached to his back -and then setting down next to the stream. Back when he’d lived in New Alveri, where one bought meat at the market, Blaze had very few opportunities to actually hunt for the first half-century of life, much less hunt for animals roaming free in the wild. He nearly sucked the small stream dry, such was his thirst, so much so that Fang commented upon it.

“You know, fresh water supplies aren’t exactly ample around here…” commented Fang wryly.

“Yeah? Well you try lifting up a thousand pounds of supplies up and down fifty foot cliffs with nothing but the air to grab…” answered Blaze wearily. “I’m not exactly a Sky-Swallower here…”

Fang responded, “Even so, I might remind you that size is relative as well. A boulder for me is rather like a pebble for you… In the same way that the 200 volt charge in your collar is an inconvenient sting for you, but would easily kill an elf or a human.” The young elf’s voice was solidly smooth the entire time he said that, though Blaze winced all the same. “So really, you are capable of much more than what you give yourself credit for.”

“Um, thanks…” Blaze had replied with a grimacing smile. With that Blaze finished off the last of his meal, and he found his stomach bloating nicely.

"I'm going to find a place to bury the bones somewhere... would that be all right?" said Blaze.

Fang snorted, "Go right ahead. Oh, but if you're going to need to take a shit, just don't do it anywhere near the river... Might be detrimental to the health of the colonists."

"Got it..." Blaze rolled his eyes, walking a short ways before digging a hole.

When Blaze returned to the stream, he found Fang busy dipping a few tropical herbs into a pot, adding water from the stream and then placed a small fire spell underneath, making a improvised soup.

“You don’t find herbs like these back on the main island,” commented Fang, putting a spoonful of the soup into mouth.

“No meat?” cried Blaze.

“Of course not,” answered Fang, almost violated at the suggestion, “Would you even think of eating plants?”

Blaze made a face, “Good point…”

Indeed, had Blaze been starving and in the middle of a cornfield, it wouldn’t have even occurred to him that the corn was edible. Dragons didn’t eat plants, and elves didn’t eat meat.

Fang continued to enjoy his surroundings for a while longer, “Pity that this meadow will have to be cleared for farmland. Many Kleave’s don’t appreciate beauty of nature anymore…” said Fang with a small but genuine measure of regret.

“Better enjoy it while it lasts then right?” answered Blaze, not that he disagreed with Fang’s point.

“Indeed.”

After finishing his soup, Fang then checked his pocket watch.

“It would seem that we should get back to the settlement and help direct the night shift. We wouldn’t want the laborers to forget whose in charge now would we?” he cried, leaping back onto Blaze. Blaze let out an understanding growl, before taking off.

Upon returning, Blaze continued to transport supplies up until the village. All in all, Blaze wound up transporting two and a half tons of supplies into the village before nightfall put an end to the effort, for him at least. The sailors continued working all through the night by lamplight. Of the cargo which had been able to be stuffed aboard, besides Blaze, barely a tenth had been unloaded so far.

Although Blaze’s keen eyesight might have allowed him to work in the dark, the humans who had to load and unload his belly harness were not and no one really trusted Blaze to land on the ship in the pitch dark, including, surprisingly, Fang. Granted, his elf patron Fang had other uses for him.

After delivering a small speech to the night workers, about the good of the colony and building their future, and whatnot, Blaze had the lovely opportunity to work as a makeshift crane as some of the settlers put up a small lumber mill using parts he had already unloaded from the ship. Obviously, there was some sort of mechanical saw in the structure, which was powered by the same small stream that Blaze had hunted further upstream. As Blaze did not have the slightest aptitude for machines, unlike Flamer-6, he could hardly begin to understand how it worked, but he hefted the heavier metal parts for the small humans so they could be assembled into the mill, which had already been constructed.

Seeing as all that was required for the lumber mill to begin functioning was the missing machinery, the dawn brought a ghastly thrumming noise as the circular saw wound up for the first time. When Blaze peered into the unassuming shack and saw a spinning blade neatly sever a whole tree trunk the settlers fed into it as a test, the dragon could not help but shudder a little at the ingenuity of the smaller species. In addition to feeling slightly humbled, Blaze lamented the fact that he was currently working for people who were working to increase the divide between their species as equals.

The sun was up again, so Blaze reported back to Fang in the small town. There he was met with yet more news. The second ship had arrived!
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Unpacking the Future

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
When he spotted the second ship arrive in the backdrop of the rising sun, all of Blaze’s weariness vanished, as his attention was directed toward that ship. A wide grin rose on his jaw as he sniffed the air. It was Ember’s scent, sweet and spicy, as Blaze imagined her smooth body curled up against him, purring affectionately.

He was snapped back to reality by a low-intensity shock.

“Now, now Lord Flame… there will certainly be time for that later,” cried Fang, clearly sensing Blaze’s mood, “I hope that your affection for her will not distract your work duties…”

“Of course not!!” answered Blaze. Whatever wariness he’d felt from working the entire day and night he’d felt had vanished. He could not afford to show himself as idle or lazy with Ember watching.

“Still, there is the necessity of bringing Allorah up to speed on the progress of the work thus far, so I suppose you'll get a chance to catch up…” added Fang.

“That's great!! But who's Allorah?”

“She’s the handler of the drakka. Though I thoroughly appreciate spending time together, there will be moments when I’ll be called away for other duties. Thus, she’ll be the one you answer to when I’m not around…” answered Fang. Blaze nodded briskly, as he hovered toward the pier. He did not pretend for a moment that she wouldn’t be up for the task, nor could he afford to make the assumption that he could hope to get away with things because she was female. Lady Ramoth and Darzhja were two prime examples of females not to cross.

Blaze waited anxiously as the workers removed the cargo hold plank by plank. Finally, after what seemed like forever, Ember emerged onto the pier. Blaze was glad to find that she’d been treated well on her voyage; if she hadn’t then he’d surely have had a word or maybe a spark of fire with the crewmembers. She stepped carefully onto the docks; despite being a rather large female, she was graceful to the point that the planks didn’t even seem to budge with her weight. Nonetheless, the dock workers, who had already been on edge with having to work in close proximity with one dragon, were seized by a fresh wave of panic when they realized there would be two and possibly more.

“Excuse me Flame while I restore order alright?” sighed Fang with exasperation.

Blaze nodded, not trying hard to conceal his amusement at the impression that Ember made on them, while Fang and an elven female who Blaze guessed could only be the drakka handler cursed, threatened and overawed the laborers back to compliance. Ember also seemed quite satisfied with the humanoids response.

“Seems like you’ve made quite the first impression Honeysweet…” growled Blaze softly, leaning forward to place his head alongside hers. For some reason, he liked the ring that ‘Honeysweet’ made, even if it was a harem name given to her by the Kleaves. Ember growled with satisfaction.

“Its just as well to see the two-legged ones wary of us again,” she puffed with a slight but satisfied plumb of smoke. Her jaw then curved into that wonderful smile of hers. “I’m glad to see you again Flame…” Blaze wholeheartedly agreed. With Ember, one could almost rationalize that everything the Kleaves had made him endure was worth it. Already, he could not imagine what life would be life without her around.

While Blaze and Ember caught up, and after Fang had managed to restore order, he gave the drakka handler a run-down of the progress that had been made at the island thus far, and what her duties would be.

“Six will be arriving on the next boat at around noon-time to help out…” she cried.

“Really? That’s good to hear. He was still in pretty rough shape the last I saw him, so that can only mean he’s been healing well…” answered Blaze. Indeed, he’d feared that Flamer-6 had been surely dead after taking that grievous blow from the late, unlamented Flamer-2, and that he was fit enough to work now was great news indeed.

“What about the other drakka?” asked Blaze.

Ember shifted her gaze uneasily, “They won’t be arriving for another week at least. I don’t know exactly what was going on, but Allorah said that they each needed to be given an additional evaluation before being transported.”

As Blaze had long since learned, vagueness was a terrifying concept when being a prisoner of the Kleaves. It was a stark reminder of exactly what this place was, despite the apparent appearance of paradise. He remembered how hysterically frightened they’d been during his fight with Flamer-2. He doubted it was because they were weak-willed; any dragon who had been weak-willed was probably long dead, but what had happened that fateful day would shake up anybody. It also made him wonder what exactly happened to the drakka while they were in captivity on the main island.

As if sensing that he was wondering about that grim subject, right then, both he and Ember were hit by a light shock, and Blaze grunted in annoyance when he saw the female elf holding a pendant. It was Ember’s handler, Allorah.

“That will be enough chit-chatting Honeysweet. Those sailors require your help in transporting the goods to the settlement…” she said strictly. She did not show a trace a fear around the two drakes, when even Wolf had been wary from time to time.

“I understand mistress…” answered Ember, lowering her head. Now, Blaze had a chance to appraise the drakka handler. For an elf, she was not especially pretty, as her face was rough and there was a long scar that covered her cheek. She was also far more muscular, almost dwarf-like, in comparison to other female elves, who were invariably lithe and graceful. Some of the low-ranking elven Kleave guards noticed as such, and gave the female handler a disgusted look, but a swift glance from her was all that was needed to make them pretend as if they’d never given her a disdainful look in the first place.

“Lady Allorah I presume?” cried Blaze. Having lived under Lady Ramoth in the orphanage, it was habit for him to address any female of authority with ‘Lady’.

“What is it?” she said tersely, hand close on the pendant. As Flamer-2 had eaten the old drake handler, Wolf, Blaze couldn’t blame her for her caution.

“With your permission, I can show her how to better transport the cargo. I’ve been doing it all day yesterday and I figured we could get the job done faster that way…” answered Blaze. The female elf didn’t seem to expect for Blaze to address her so politely and formally and relented. He figured it was a good idea to get on her good side quickly, as with any and all people in positions of authority. Well, maybe not with Dr. Moridin or the Kleave transporter, both of whom were quite insane and cruel to a fault, but Allorah, like Fang, struck Blaze as a rather rational individual.

“Ah yes, quite the gentleman you are… I see that your reputation as a smooth talker is by no means exaggerated…” answered Allorah, in a very Lady Ramoth-like way. “Yet if you must…”

Blaze made his way toward a large pile of crates, where the still nervous humans watched him warily, while Ember watched intently. “Now then, you want to attach the cargo like so…”

He quickly showed Ember the most efficient way to attach the cargo along with lifting it into the air. Blaze was glad to see that Ember learned quickly, and indeed after only about half an hour was performing her job nearly as well as Blaze was, the difference only being that Blaze could carry a larger load capacity than she could. Even with the weight of the cargo holding her down, Blaze couldn’t help but note that she was very graceful in flight. He was glad to see that despite the people she was working for, Ember nonetheless took pride in seeing that the job was done properly, and indeed Blaze could sense that she was trying to prove as much to him as to the Kleaves that anything Blaze could do, she could more than hold her own as well. Blaze grunted with a grin. Well, there was no way he was going to allow himself to be outdone by a female. Was he not a breeder male? The strongest male fire drake on the island?

Blaze scoffed. It was rather ironic to take pride in that. After all, it served to remind him that he was still a prisoner, and that whatever freedom he had only extended as far as Fang allowed him to have.

Nontheless, the hours seemed to fly by quickly, and the large pile of cargo dwindled quickly. Then, at around noon-time, the third ship arrived. Blaze sniffed the air. The scent that reached his nostrils belonged to…
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: My sweet Ember

He's out observing a construction project
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Even with Ember’s newfound help and sheer exuberance speeding along the disemboweling of the ships, the stout galleons were still emptied but slowly. Each of their cargo holds had been reduced by roughly half to accomodate one dragon, however, that still remarkably left over 100 tons of tightly packed supplies left in each ship. It would be a while yet before the supplies could be unloaded, even with the help of multiple dragons. As Blaze hefted heavy crates and sacs up the cliffs endlessly, all he could think was that Flamer-6 better be in good enough shape to help. There wasn’t going to be any time for slacking, at least any time soon.

The ship rolled into the cove just past noon. Blaze watched while he was having a series of small crates hitched to his under belly where he sat in the hold of the ship. Scenting the air, he could just make out the mild inoffensive - and yet unnaturally mild - flavor of the neutered drake. Blaze frowned slightly. Flamer-6 had suffered a lot of hardship only just recently. Been maimed twice - first by Dr. Moridin, and then by Flamer-2 - and then had his dragonhood taken away carelessly before his wounds had even closed. And yet, he was still around wasn’t he? Blaze felt a strange mix of pity and esteem towards him. He hoped he could be as strong as him if things came down to it… and yet Blaze hoped that he would not have to be so tough.

Ember touched down lightly on the ship she had come on as the sailors were finishing up on Blaze. She rocked her ship less than half the amount Blaze did when he landed, doing an odd little movement with her wings just before she alighted. The movement of her luscious wings as she folded them was entrancing. Ember cocked her head as she sniffed the breeze. Turning her head, she saw the ship. “Is that…?” she asked over the barking of the sailors below.

“Yes, Flamer-6.” Said Blaze. Below someone kicked his haunch so he’d know that the loading was finished. Blaze began to extricate himself from the ship’s hold, being mindful of the boxes strapped to his underside. Although he took his time, looking at Ember across from him on the other side of the pier.

A worried expression passed over the drakka’s strong, and yet finely chiseled features. “He looked terrible the last time I saw him…”

Blaze understood Ember’s unspoken worries. “Don’t worry about him. Four days rest inside the ship will have done him some good.” Blaze planted his hindfeet carefully on the upper deck and crouched below the rigging, making ready to leap. “He’s quite tough… smart too. You’ll see when you get a chance to get to know him better.”

But Ember didn’t look very assuaged. Perhaps she didn’t like being reminded of the depths of cruelty the Kleaves were capable of, or perhaps it was something else entirely. At any rate, Blaze lifted himself carefully up into the air, his shoulders burning as he carried himself and his cargo up and away, over the cliffs and down to the town of Fort Carmile.

Like Ember, it took a while for the decks to be disassembled and Flamer-6 to emerge. The eunuch creapt out of the hold slowly and stretched his wings with the same jerky motion that Blaze had gotten used to seeing from Six. Still, it was something of a shock when the dragon emerged fully from the ship and displayed his collection of scars. Blaze was taking a brief break at the top of the cliffs when he saw him, and he hissed a sharp intake of breath. Flamer-6 was so badly scarred, he was almost ugly. Bright red knotted tissue and terrible black stitches lined gouges in his shoulder and neck where Flamer-2 had mauled him and on his opposite side, he could see deeper indents in the flesh of his abdomen where he’d been impaled on the same dragon’s horns. Indeed it was a miracle that he was alive. When Six flew upwards, Blaze could even make out the fresher scar cut horizontally just below his penile slit. Unlike mammals with indecently exposed glands, dragons kept their equipment hidden. However this turned the neutering process into rather invasive surgery and made Blaze wonder momentarily if they were indeed better off after all.

And still there were obvious signs of neurological damage. Flamer-6’s left eye still slumped and he had a tendency to pull to the left while flying, one side of his body less responsive than the other. However, despite all his hurts and irreparable damage to his body, a casual grin spread unevenly on his face when he angled up and saw Blaze sitting on the cliffs above him. It was only a few seconds before the dragon landed beside him, bouncing off the stone slightly as he did. Blaze noticed his sunken-in belly. Six looked like he’d lost four or five stone since he’d las saw him.

Blaze coughed slightly then spoke, “Still holding together, I see.”

Six looked at him sidelong as he folded his wings; the left one rather awkwardly. “Barely…” breathed Flamer-6. “Although, I suppose I must be happy they didn’t cull me on the spot back there.”

Blaze didn’t want to talk about their last great trial on the main island. “How was the voyage, Six?” Again he glanced at the dragon’s sharp abdominal tuck up. “You look famished.”

Six snorted, “They fed me… enough.” However, his eyes betrayed the hunger he felt.

Blaze stretched out his wing and bumped Six’s flank. “Let me assure you that there is excellent hunting on the island, real hunting!” Blaze stepped around in front of Six and inclined his head for emphasis. “They obviously haven’t been hunted by dragons before. They don’t even look up when you’re circling. It’s easy pickings.”

That got a grin out of the banged up dragon. Six rotated his right shoulder and Blaze noticed another deep gouge. However, unlike the rest of Six’s injuries, it looked like the surgeons had taken a substantial amount a muscle along with it, possibly due to infection. The movement seemed to pain him, but Six kept at it several more times as he spoke, “They better be. I’m not exactly in the best shape of my life.”

Blaze frowned and couldn’t think of how to reply. Six saved him the effort though.

After stretching his back and hindlegs like a cat and turning his head side to side so that Blaze could hear the crackling in his vertebrae, Six said, “Well, as much as I’d like to elope for a bit of lunch. I was told that I was supposed to report to an elf called Claw or some-such.”

“Fang.” Blaze corrected. “And I guess you’re right.” However, Blaze glanced back at the nightmare patchwork of stitches lining Six’s flank and felt suddenly uncomfortable. “However, I’m still intent on getting a decent meal into you before putting you to work.”

Six snorted with disbelief. “And you think you can tell this elf what to do?”

Blaze shrugged with his wings, “I have some sway with him. And I am Lord Flame now after all.”

“Oh yeah, new name, new title. I almost forgot…” Six’s good eye went a little hazy for a moment and then he commented with a flare of his own wings. “You know, I remember when you were just a scared little wimp back when they tossed you into that cell, vent bleeding and all.”

Blaze’s nostrils flared and he might have gotten angry if Six had still smelled like a male. As it was, however, he took the comment in stride. “I’m not that dragon anymore. I’m stronger now.”

Six frowned and creased his head eye ridges. He spoke quietly. “Don’t say that.”

“What?” asked Blaze, leaning in closer to the other dragon.

Six reached out with his wing and laid it across Blaze’s back. “Don’t forget who you are.”

Before Blaze could think of what to say, the moment was over. Six spread his wings and turned around, ready to leap off the cliff and into the air. “Come, let’s meet this elf chum of yours.”

“Um… all right…” Blaze muttered numbly, but Six was already gone. Suddenly Blaze felt less like Lord Flame than an ignorant child. And he didn’t like the way it felt. Rather than cheating by leaping off the cliff, Blaze sprang into the air using the strength in his haunches and angled his way towards Fort Carmile. He swung in line just ahead of Six and led the way, the tropical forest passing below them like a warm felt carpet.

Blaze passed right over Ember, who was being unloaded right outside the town's gates and landed in the square. When Six landed on the other side of the obelisk, nearly all of the free space was used up. A man with a painted shoulder came sprinting up. Blaze recognized Sergeant Seymor. "Lord Flame..." said the human at once giving a slight bow and gripping a control pendant which dangled from his belt.

"Where's Master Fang?" asked Blaze simply.

The human replied...
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Flamer-6

choices: Fang has some other task for Blaze
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
The sergeant was spared from having to answer when Fang emerged from the small town center, busily arranging papers back into his robes. Apparently the landing of two massive dragons in the town square had not escaped his notice

“So you would be Flamer-6? Flame’s told me a lot of good things about you…” said Fang in a very affable manner, looking up at the scared dragon. Flamer-6, who was no doubt used to the more brutish variety of Kleave, initially didn’t know how to react to Fang’s apparently friendly greetings.

“Surely, he is exaggerating about my worth. I can only hope that I may be of some marginal use here…” answered Six, keeping his head lowered.

“Come on Six, don’t sell yourself short. You made a complex pulley system with nothing more than scrap metal and troll laborers,” encouraged Blaze. Truthfully, with Flamer-6 being the way he was, he didn’t think that employing him as another physical laborer would be getting the optimal use out of him, and wanted to emphasize these traits so that he could be put in a position to succeed.

“Until Flamer-2 destroyed it and led to me being…” Flamer-6 let out a sigh.

There was a short awkward moment, but Fang was quick to break the silence, “That being said, I’m very curious in hearing how you managed to accomplish that in detail… Such a feat would require uncommon knowledge of engineering and physics.”

Flamer-6 shifted his gaze. After seeming to mull over it, he evidently couldn’t resist any longer.

“Well… it wasn’t terribly complicated.” Started Six. “The only metal available was slag, metal shavings and broken tools. I began with heating and folding the metal to squeeze out the impurities…”

Six then delved into a long detailed analysis of how he’d built the machine, the materials he’d used, how he utilized the trolls to perform the more delicate labor, and other aspects using engineering terms that Blaze could only vaguely understand. Nonetheless, once he began talking about a subject that interested him, Six’s prior anemic attitude vanished.

“You did all that without any blueprint or precise measuring tools? You’ve really got talent Flamer-6! Once we get the ships unloaded, I’d actually like to have your expertise in designing some of our infrastructure. As it turns out, we’re sadly lacking in architects and engineers on this island, and I could use the expertise of someone who really knows what they’re doing…” said Fang, deeply impressed. However, Blaze could not help but notice the gleam in the elf’s eyes, already calculating the best way to use Flamer-6 in his machinations.

“I don’t really have a choice in this do I?” cried Six. He seemed understandably wary of the offer, but also hopeful, though Blaze could not help but notice how his eyes lit up.

“If you’d rather, I can use you as a draft animal…” replied Fang off-handedly.

“Er… I mean I’d be honored to fulfill this task! Thank you Master Fang!!” answered Six, swinging around a bit too slavishly in Blaze’s opinion.

“Good!!” answered Fang with a grin, as if he’d expected that he’d accept all along. “Anyhow Flame, before you return to your duties, would you be so kind as to show Six a decent meal? He really looks as if he could use one…”

Although it was obvious, the fact that the elf both noticed and cared enough to mention feeding Six surprised Blaze. he replied with a grunt, “Very well Master Fang…. You mind if I grabbed something to eat as well?”

“Sure, you’ve been working since we landed.”

He then turned to Six. “Come on Six. I’ll show you where those water buffalo are…”

The two drakes then took back off to the sky. A moment later, Blaze arrived at the small stream where the water buffalo were, upstream of the new lumbermill.

The animals again were stupid and slow to react, although they did at least manage to look up this time. Six dived down like a falling arrow and landed with his forepaws crushing the life out of a large bull. Blaze followed down a few moments later at the animals started to flee; he’d actually been taken off guard by the speed at which the injured dragon had fallen. Even with the warning, it was too little, too late for the buffalo, Blaze snagged his while it was floundering in the stream. He carried it a short way over to where Six was already digging in and broke its neck with his teeth. Across from him, Six bit into one of the buffalo with violent gusto, quickly devouring it to stripped bones. He ate his meal so quickly that he actually had to catch his breath after his effort.

“By the Ancestors!! Have you eaten anything at all since we were back at the lair?” gasped Blaze. He almost felt ashamed to eat his own meal after seeing how hungry Six had been.

“That doesn’t matter now…” Six quickly dismissed, “Got to admit though, I haven’t had anything this good since I got kidnapped…”

He then lifted his head and began to gaze around. “You know what, I’ve just noticed that there aren’t any humans currently watching us right now…”

Blaze looked startled. “You’re right…” he said carefully.

“Of course, I’m not stupid enough to think this is a chance to escape, not that a eunuch would have a place in civilized society anymore, but that means either Fang is negligent or he’s smarter and more dangerous than I imagined…” replied Six.

“What do you mean by that?” cried Blaze. He’d already understood in his guts just how formidable Fang was, but he did want to know what Six thought of him.

“He’s not like the other Kleaves, Seven,” answered Six, inadvertently calling Blaze by his previous moniker. “Fang, that elf’s a master of manipulation. I mean, he had me wagging my tail like an enthusiastic dog when he started talking about architectural projects. Worse, I’m actually looking forward to doing it; to helping the Kleave’s with their nefarious goals.” His voice was gravely and strained with a real mix of emotions. Blaze wasn’t sure if Six had ever opened up this much to him before, but he was glad that he did.

Blaze grunted, “You think I don’t know that Six? I know full well just how dangerous Fang is. He knows my name and where I come from and don’t think for a moment he doesn’t know yours. Now that I think about it, he probably figured that the two of us would be having this conversation right now and probably set up some spell so he could listen in.”

Six took a couple even breaths, he was still a little worked up from his gorge and his belly was bulging with buffalo. “He may have…” Six said slowly, “But we have to remember that realizing that he can do something like that is different from assuming that he did do something like that. We’ll never escape if we assume he’s omnipotent.”

Blaze blinked. For him Six’s words were a bit of a shock. He hadn’t realized how much Fang’s machinations had gotten to him recently. He had to take a deep breath to steady himself. In fact, he twisted his head and lapped from the cool stream for a few seconds before he spoke. “You are right.” He said finally. “But the elf is as smart as sin and just as calculating. I still have no doubt that the illusion of freedom is just that: an illusion.”

Six cocked his head. “Unless he’s bluffing…”

Again, another thought that hadn’t occured to Blaze. Although the young drake was glad that Six was here, suddenly he didn’t like so much the demonstration of their own gap in intelligence. Blaze frowned, “I don’t think so. Fang wouldn’t risk us dragons to something so flimsy.”

Six nodded, “I agree, but it does well to remember that keeping your opponents cowed by apparent strength is an excellent way to prevent them from seeing their own power.”

Blaze gnawed on that bit of wisdom, but not knowing what to do with it, set it aside for later use. He spoke, “Anyways, he knows that even if I were to think about escaping, I wouldn’t because I’m a caring sap; because he knows that I’d never leave Honeysweet behind and risk her being raped by another drake. …”

“You’ve really got the hots for her don’t you?” replied Six, looking at Blaze askance. His tail lifted a little higher as well

“It’s more than that…” answered Blaze, more defensively than he realized.

Six back up a step, then sighed, “Its not like it matters to me anymore… For obvious reasons.”
