Blaze realized his instinctual reaction just reminded Six of what he was no longer capable. The young drake wondered for a moment how it felt. Is his desire gone? Do drakka look the same as drakes to him now? Is he incapable of seeing feminine beauty anymore? Admittedly, the last was something of a potential relief, especially in regards to Ember. Still, Six didn’t deserve what he was doing to himself.
“You better believe it does matter.” answered Blaze, “Regardless of what you think of yourself, I’m still going to treat you like a drake. You deserve that type of respect and Fang sees that as well…”

Six didn’t reply right away, but nonetheless seemed to appreciate that.

“Anyhow Seven, why don’t we just get back to the docks? Its ungentlemanly to leave Honeysweet laboring all on her own…” said Six with a wink.

Blaze couldn’t help but feel a thrill of the old male rivalry, despite Six’s mild odor. To his surprise, he liked it. Blaze grunted, “You’ve really got a point there…" They left the stained bones and gore where it lay and took to the air. Six followed Blaze back down to the ships. There was another hundred tons of cargo to unload after all…
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: A proposal

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Work continued the rest of that afternoon, went straight through the night, and throughout the following day as well. No matter how many packages of supplies he hauled up to the settlement, the pile of supplies did not seem to grow any smaller. As the sun began to slowly sink below the horizon, Blaze was lying upon his belly as the humans unloaded yet another load of supplies from the twin leather straps along his flanks. His shoulders ached from all the heavy lifting and he rested his head on the hard pan earth under him, his wings akimbo on the ground to either side. He heaved a sigh and let his heavy scaled eyelids sag as the humans labored to extract his cargo. It’d been three days since he’d last slept. He’d needed to conserve what stamina he could when he could.

By fortunate coincidence, Blaze found himself accompanied by both Ember and Flamer-6, both of whom were also being unloaded. The flattened dirt plateau that was to become the landing platform of the dragon tower was just large enough to hold the three young dragons and the team of humanoid laborers which surrounded them.

“Hurry up you slack-jawed wretches!!” screeched Allorah, the current taskmaster with an almost witch-like voice. The whip she carried cracked like an explosion at the feet of a peasant leaning against Blaze’s shoulder, causing him to all but leap several feet into the air. Unfortunately for the dragon, the noise was enough to start him from his half doze and he wearily opened the eye facing the humanoids to watch the scene.

Either this peasant had not been here long or he’d never met Allorah. Landing on his feet with a mild stagger, he looked at the woman holding the whip and apparently decided to play the pity card. After a full second of conspicuous hesitation, he fell to his knees and said, “Bu’ ma’m, we’ve a’been working since dawn. Can’t ye give this poor sinner a break?” Though the human drama hardly interested the dragon’s tastes, Blaze could not help a small inward smile at this human’s blatant stupidity.

Allorah’s eyes lit up with an inner fire and for a moment, Blaze thought she might open her mouth and breath flames all over the kneeling man. Then her hate-filled quivering stilled and with powerful self control she sauntered up to the man beside the large red scaled dragon. Despite the fact that the taskmaster was wearing baggy leggings and an open leather vest - neither of which accentuated the human female’s natural figure in the slightest - the man developed a devious grin at the sight of her approaching; Blaze could have sighed in exasperation had he energy to spare.

His arms draping to the ground before him, the worker lifted his head to Allorah as she stopped before him. She reached down a gloved hand to touch the man’s greasy, unshaven face with the back of a hand, shortly after pressing her coiled loop of a whip firmly to his shoulder. As she pulled her hand back and the quite horny man - Blaze could smell it coming off of him in waves from the sweat on his brow - melted in her grasp, Allorah said, “Aw, So you’re tired are you?”

By this point in time, the labor of the surrounding humans had crawled to a standstill. Everyone was staring to where Allorah had this man backed against the towering flank of a dragon. They all seemed to know what was coming; all except one, however. “I am… But not so tired I can’t warm up a lil’lady like your-“ That was as far as he got before Allorah lifted her arm, coiling her whip around the man’s neck with careless ease and choking off his lusty words.

With leverage and a simple motion of her shoulder, the taskmaster flipped her captive down onto his belly. She began to walk away, dragging him by the neck across the packed dirt as he squirmed, flailing and groping at the whip, at pebbles, at anything at all. His face turned red and then purple.

As if she were in the middle of a stage, Allorah sauntered with almost as much grace and power as any drakka. It was actually quite remarkable in Blaze’s opinion. When she stopped, the man was flat on his back and wheezing pathetically through the reduced constriction. Allorah turned and put her boot down on the man’s cheek, grinding his face into the earth. “Still tired?” she asked, looking down at him as if he were nothing more than a bug under her heel.

Still gasping, the man shook his head feebly.

“Good…” said Allorah and then with a twist of her whip, sent the man rolling across the dirt like an unleashed top. Then she shouted at the on-lookers, “Work is over when I say it is, and not a moment before!!” She punctuated her roar with another thunder-blast crack from her whip that sent the laborers cowering and then moving double-time. Blaze wondered if Allorah’s length of braided leather was enchanted or whether she was simply that skilled.

"Almost feel sorry for the poor wretches..." commented Six on the other side of him

“Almost..." emphasized Blaze, then he turned his head to look at his beloved since there was no more hope of resting his eyes. "Hey Honeysweet…” spoke Blaze, switching to Drakine to hopefully befuddle the many potential eavesdroppers surrounding them, “Is Allorah always like this?” Given her performance just now and the fact that Allorah seemed to be swiftly becoming Fang’s second on the island, Blaze could not keep himself from asking.

Ember curved her gaze sideways. “I suppose she is…” she said, answering in the same, though quite differently accented tongue, “At least around other ‘umans.” The drakka snaked her head back around towards Blaze and shifted her wings a little uncomfortably before adding, “She is firm with her drakka as vell, but she ‘ardly goes out of her vay to ‘umiliate us.” Then Ember got a funny look in her eye as she looked at the elf stomping down the flattened earth of the foundation of the future tower. “Sometimes, I get the feeling that she is proud of us… in ‘er own vay.”

Blaze, looking at the same female, cocked an eyebrow. To him, Allorah seemed far more an unpleasant handler than even the conniving Wolf had been. That Ember had any soft feelings towards her struck him as odd and perhaps even a little unbalanced.

Though he daren’t say such thoughts aloud to his lover, Flamer-6 apparently lacked any such reticence. He did a double-take, looking at the taskmaster and snorted, “I think I’d rather deal with a grumpy orc with a crossbow bolt in his ass than that particular elf.” Six lifted his snout in the air and commented to Ember, “Are you sure you aren’t suffering a touch of disambiguation with this particular taskmaster?”

Ember ruffled her wings, causing the human workers around her to start and retreat for a few moments. “And vhat, pray tell is zat supposed to mean?”

From the way her tail tip was lashing back and forth, Blaze could tell that she was agitated. She probably didn’t understand what Six had meant… Blaze certainly did not himself.

“Well…” said Six, scratching the underside of his jaw with a heavy claw which caught sometimes on the scars marring the smooth surface of dark red scale. He did not seem like he was very interested in an explanation, but at the same time apparently could not resist the temptation to reveal his cleverness in using a term unknown to the other two dragons. “Disambiguation simply refers to the phenomenon wherein a person, typically a prisoner or young hatchling, can - after a period of usually prolonged suffering - begin to mistake a mere lack of torment for acts of kindness and thereby develop empathy for their captor or antagonist. It’s far more common among humanoids, humans and elves especially. Almost unheard of in any fully fledged dragon, really, but then, whoever heard of taking dragons prisoner, eh? Heh.”

Six gave something of a weak chuckle, though it seemed to pain the injury to his abdomen. Neither other dragon joined in. In fact, Ember looked at Six crossly down the length of her snout. “That sounds like a silly and frankly implausible situation to me, Six.” She hissed, slipping back into the common tongue. She lifted her head a little more and the humans around her paused in their movements to looked uneasily towards her; the fear-stink that usually pervaded the platform in any case seemed to reach a peak from the workers. Shifting her body a little on her elbows to more directly face Flamer-6, she said, “And if you think I’m that foolish-!”

Blaze couldn’t let the situation escalate. He interrupted Ember’s growing tirade, though he felt quite uncomfortable while doing it. In fact, he felt more like the inexperienced young drake he’d thought he’d left behind in New Alveri. “Honeysweet, I… uh.”

She rounded on the large, muscular drake before he could collect his thoughts; though for all his newfound mass, he could have been hardly more than a mouse in her eyes. “What’s that? Don’t tell me you’re taking his side.”
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: The Bitter Taskmaster

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Blaze was sure that Ember wasn’t meaning to be bitchy, but they were all tired and on edge for all the work unloading the ships of their many tons of supplies, so he was willing to forgive her on that account. However, presently, the way to diffuse the situation escaped him. He was sure that only the presence of the fragile humans surrounding them and the watchful taskmaster was the only thing stopping the powerful drakka from springing over and clouting either himself or Flamer-6. “N-no,” stammered Blaze, instinctively lowering his head. “All… all I meant was that, that… you…”

“Yes?” asked Ember impatiently.

Oh, how to say what he simply meant in the right words! Why was this so hard?! Blaze was filled momentarily with the thought that this would be so much easier if Ember were another drake; they’d simply scuffle for a bit and that would be the end of it. But a drakka’s ire was known to smolder long after the fire seemed quenched and dead.

But she wasn’t letting him off the hook. To the side, Six’s good eye leered at him, offering no help at all and Blaze regretted saving him a few moments earlier. “I meant to say… That is… oh… Look! There’s Fang!”

And indeed it was the elf and master of the island coming around the bend in the dirt road leading to the walled town. Blaze’s shoulders slumped with relief as the heated words were soon forgotten. Today, he was dressed less lavishly, though still quite fine in the makings of a young noble. His silk leggings and shirt were red of course and of such vibrance that a robin would be jealous. His quilted jacket was less colorful and left open at the center, though still clasped with three thick golden laces down the middle. Blaze wasn’t sure why he was paying so much attention to Fang’s appearance, however, he thought privately that he’d seen other elves cut far less sharp a figure.

The elf bounced lightly on the sturdy horse he was astride. The creature was black all over and Blaze was almost expecting red glowing eyes. However the eyes of this large beast were merely dark. To the young drake’s eye, the stallion merely looked like a hearty supper and immediately disliked it. It nickered and strayed as it approached the foundation of the dragon tower and Fang had to rein it into line to get it to approach the strong reek of dragon which pervaded the area. As he became aware that he was in danger of traumatizing the animal, Fang dismounted a short distance up the road and tied it to a low hanging branch; unfortunately, there wasn’t enough give in the reins to allow it to feed on the rich tropical undergrowth. Blaze snorted a thick plume of white smoke.
At about the time that Fang arrived onto the foundation proper, Six had finished his unloading and the dragon looked uneasily down at the elf, clearly unsure whether he was expected to stay or go. With a wave of his palm, Fang put Six at ease. Relieved of his burden, Six raised himself to his haunches and stretched his wings. Everyone had to wait for the elf to initiate conversation; including Allorah and the rest of the humanoids.

Although the elvish taskmaster had stepped forward promptly and even stamped her booted feet in attention, Fang began by speaking openly to Blaze. “Good Evening, Lord Flame. It looks like the debarkment is proceeding well.”

Blaze’s eyes wandered about the scattered boxes and carts already half full and ready to take the crates and lengths of seasoned timber or metal ingots and tools up the road to Fort Carmile. “What brings you here, Master Fang?” asked Blaze, aware of the fact that of the dragons, he had the be the first to speak as well. “Especially so late in the day.”

Fang did not answer immediately. Blaze was conscious of the many eyes surrounding them, though most were directed at Fang’s boots as they should be or averted entirely. With some of the peons even falling to their knees or hiding their faces, the young muscular drake wondered if this was more a description of the power of Fang’s presence or the sheer wretchedness of his subjects. Face warmed by the golden glow of the sunset over the distant waves, Fang finally deigned to answer, “I think I have the authority to be wherever I wish on the island when I choose to be there.” The elf’s voice was not hostile or condescending, but rather simply aloof. “At any rate, the town has been simply flooded with new supplies since you three have been working. We’re at the point where more boxes and crates and materials will simply be in the way until we can get what we have now sorted away.”

Despite their unusual relationship, Blaze was not so presumptuous to attempt to take credit for his and his compatriots’ hard work in front of the elf. “That’s… excellent news.” Said Blaze, not entirely sure what Fang was building towards.

Six apparently did, however and took his chances in speaking. “Then I take it that this means we’re done unloading the ships presently?”

The elf turned his head to the large scarred dragon. There was a slight pause and then a small smile spread itself across his thin lips. “That’s exactly right.”

Blaze sniffed in Six’s direction, feeling a bit miffed that the lame dragon had jumped to what Fang had implied. Before anyone else could speak, Blaze blurted, “So where are we going to be staying?”

Fang, Blaze was mildly surprised, seemed to take the question quite seriously. He rubbed the smooth skin of his chin. “I’ve been giving that a great deal of thought. There are presently no dragon-friendly facilities on the island and of course, you can’t stay in the town.”

Blaze looked around momentarily and then planted his claws and tail down firmly on the ground. “Why don’t we just camp outside. I’m sure that we’ll be perfectly comfortable in this climate.”

Blaze was expecting some sort of rebuttal, but rather than Fang, it was Six who spoke, “In the short term maybe, but what about in a storm? The tropics are known for bad storms, I believe.”

Then Ember cut in with a comment which caused the words to die in Blaze’s throat. “And we’ll need someplace more secure for laying eggs as well.

Eggs… The word echoed around in Blaze’s skull for a few moments, choking out his wits. Then Fang nodded his head up to each dragon. “Yes. We are going to need proper facilities and fairly soon as well.”

Blaze was still wondering how the conversation had taken the turn that it had, considering that it had merely started with Fang announcing a pause in their labors, when Six again proved himself capable of following the undercurrents of the elf’s tongue far better than Blaze himself. “I suppose that with the lull heavy labor needs, now would be a good time to survey the island for a good place to dig out some shelter.”

A huge grin spread on Fang’s face as he turned to face the damaged drake. “And you have surveying experience as well I suppose?” he asked and the large red scaled drake nodded. “That’s quite a resume you have.”

“And I’m sure that you already know as much about my background as I do.” Said Six adventurously.

Fang snorted and surprised them all with an admission of sorts, “We do have an extensive dossier, however, nothing is ever perfect, and I’m not so arrogant as to believe that it can’t be improved.” He paused a little to let that sink in and then asked directly, “So, Flamer-6, are you telling me that you can effectively scout out and survey a location for a dragon den? It will have to house the entire colony’s dragon population, you know. I’m not interested in riddling the mountain with dragon-sized holes cookie cut out of it.”

Blaze looked at Six who raised a claw and rubbed thoughtfully at the scales on the underside of his chin again. His right eye seemed to glow with curiosity, and perhaps opportunity. “I have done the type of work before.” He said, “But I lack any of my old tools and I’m afraid my vision has gotten weak in my left eye…”

It was a credit to either his composure or his indifference that Fang did not react to the reminder that the Kleaves had left Six with permanent nerve damage across the left side of his body. “I have tools available for survey work, however, I seriously doubt that they would be useful at all for a dragon. Which is a shame, because finding a suitable site for excavation would be many times faster by dragon wing…”

Blaze, wanting to get back into the conversation, racked his brain for a solution to the quandary. However, the only thing he had ever built before were mud forts in the dirt outside New Alveri as a hatchling.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: The Need for a Home

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
“What if I accompany him, my Lord.” Said a high clear voice. It definitely wasn’t the deeper, rumbling voice of a dragon and Blaze had to look down and around for a few moments before he spotted the tall, straight form of Allorah stepping out from behind Ember’s bulk. She walked briskly up to Fang and bowed low, waiting for him to release her. When he did, she continued. “I can accompany Flamer-6 and operate the instruments for him if he’ll tell me what to do, Master Fang. Besides, it is your humble servant’s opinion that the beast shouldn’t be allowed to roam freely about without supervision. I’ll be able to keep an eye on him as I help him with the scouting.”

He didn’t know how he hadn’t noticed before, but as he glanced down at the two humanoids, Blaze noticed that Allorah was actually significantly taller than Fang, though it didn’t help that she was standing ramrod straight at attention before him. Still, it struck Blaze that Fang was still actually quite young for a member of his species. It was odd that he had forgotten, but then Fang seemed to harbor airs about him that projected experience, even veiled wisdom despite his years. And now, he was sizing up Allorah as if there was no size difference between them, but then again, if this was an elf that could stare down a dragon with ease… “I appreciate your concern in the matter, Allorah, but rest assured that there are measures in place that will not allow ready escape from this island.” Although he did not look up, Blaze was sure that comment was meant more for the three dragons than the elvish female. He continued, “However, if you could function as an aide for Flamer-6 to perform his survey, it would save us perhaps weeks of time and resources.” Now he turned back and looked up at Six. “I’m not going to throw away any resources I have at my disposal. You all can be assured of that.”

Fang sent Allorah to run up the road to Fort Carmile to fetch a list of instruments with odd sounding names that Six rattled off easily. The elf ran with the speed and grace renowned of her kind and soon vanished around the bend in the road behind the lush green foliage.

As it was likely that Six would be leaving with Allorah as soon as the elf returned from the nearby town, Blaze did not waste any time in speaking. “What are Ember and I supposed to do while Six is out searching for a place to dig out a new den?”

Fang raised an eyebrow when he looked up at Blaze and the drake thought for a moment that a lewd light crept into the elf’s eyes. However, he said, “Well, I assumed that you would be going with him. You all are companions now aren’t you?”

Blaze blustered silently with an awkward rearranging of his wings. He had been thinking of attending Six with his work, since he thought that the injured might need some assistance at some point, no matter how determined he’d been during the last couple days’ work; or as a result of it. However, just at that moment, he realized that he’d actually been hopeful for some time alone with Ember. Real time alone with her, for really the first time. The remarkably smooth set of her scales just seemed to cry for his clawed fingers to probe them…

“Well of course we’re going to join him, aren’t we Blaze?” Ember spoke and her voice dispelled any lingering hopes as to a romantic - though illusory - escape, although this came as a relief to Blaze’s conflicting thoughts. “After all, I haven’t even had the chance to see the island yet save between the town and the pier.”

“Yes, we’ll join Six and we’ll help out any way that we can.” Said Blaze, though in his mind’s eye, all he was able to see was Ember winging her way beside him on a clear cloudless night.

“Excellent,” proclaimed Fang. “I’ll give you all two days to complete the survey. You don’t all need to return, but I’ll expect Allorah and those tools back by then. If you could break first ground while you’re at it as well, that would help tremendously.”

“Speaking of breaking ground,” spoke Flamer-6 once more, “depending on the type of stone we encounter, there may be need for a humanoid labor force, especially if we’re to construct more delicate features such as running water or air shafts.”

Blaze licked his chops when Fang crossed his arms. Uh-oh. “We have only two dwarf engineers on the island and both are being worked to capacity, particularly on this very tower. I’m afraid that I’m not going be able to offer very much help, especially if the place you find is very far from Fort Carmile.”

Six mantled his wings. “I just felt I ought to mention that difficulty before we get started in earnest.”

Fang waved off the big dragon, “We’ll discuss it more in detail if it becomes absolutely necessary. But try to make do with what you can do yourselves. It’s to be your quarters, after all.”

“Understood… Master Fang.” Punctuated Six for good measure and Blaze felt a corner of his lip move up in a momentary half snarl.

But Six’s head was turned in the direction of the road, down which Allorah ran as though unburdened with the overlarge knapsack she had strapped across her shoulders. She snapped her booted feet together before Fang. “I’m ready to leave immediately, Master Fang.”

“Then grab onto one of these dragon’s harnesses and get going. We don’t have any time to waste in constructing this facility!”

Just a minute after that, Allorah had attached herself via a bronze ring in Six’s harness and all three red dragons were up in the air and soaring away.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Together Searching

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Despite the days and nights of non-stop labor since arriving on the island, being up in the air with Ember and Six felt like liberation. It would have been easy enough to pretend that the three of them were simply soaring free across the lush green volcanic landscape save that there was an elf female straddling the neck of Blaze's former rival.

Six flew high with Allorah, performing some sort of survey work between the two of them and that was fine with Blaze; It left room for him and Ember to flap more closely near each other. Frequently, Blaze shot amorous looks in her direction as he plowed ahead, forming the slip stream into which she settled; usually she caught them.

The island was preternaturally lush; every surface was covered with green, save for the ocean on the horizon which was such a dark and rich shade of blue that Blaze was still in awe of it. Open plains would have made for easier hunting, but it was apparent that there was room for the large game here as well. Closer to the central mountain, where the ground was rockier, trees gave way to large rolling fields of tall grass as high as the shoulders of the buffalo and other grazers wandering in it.

Despite the lushness of the jungle, there was not a terrible abundance of water, or so it appeared from the air. When Six directed the dragons to fly up and over the caldera of the volcano, inside they found a rain water lake of some size; large enough for Blaze to get a few laps in before anyone could tell him otherwise! Other than that, however, there just seemed to be a few streams rolling down the sides of the mountain and that was it.

Six brought up the issue when they touched down on the sides of the caldera water reservoir. Blaze was climbing out of the water into which he'd dived, prompting the stop. Ember laughed and slapped him with his wing and then Blaze growled playfully, having half a mind to throw her into the water next.

"C-considering that this is the only r-reliable source of drinkable water on the island, I wouldn't recommend f-f-fouling it, Flame." said Six while Blaze was shaking himself down. The dip had felt delightful on his sore muscles despite its brevity.

"I wasn't going to-" started Blaze but halted himself when he decided what he was about to say was childish. "Anyways, one dip won't hurt."

"Well..." grimaced Six, scratching the scars under his chin, "R-relative size has to be taken into account in c-cases like-"

Suddenly Allorah squawked from the base of Six's shoulders. "Is there a point to this landing or can we continue the survey? I still haven't verified the accuracy of our maps of the island yet."

Blaze was resentful of the elf woman breaking the illusion that they three of them were on their own. In fact, he could picture clearly himself walking over and relieving Six of his burden... in the very easiest way possible. "Well, I just assumed we were stopping when I saw Lord Flame dive." said Six innocently.

Blaze stared at Six, annoyed that he would put this on him. But then the water had just seemed so cool and inviting, and it had been. Blaze coughed. "Well, I just thought that building our den near fresh water might be a good idea, and we'd have a higher vantage up here as well."

Predictably, Six began to dismantle his idea at once. "I'm not sure that's a great idea. While some water is good, a lot can be terrible for digs. Building down next to a lake is a sure way to guarantee flooding."

Ember decided to come to the rescue when Blaze's mind seemed to freeze up on him. Walking beside him and brushing him suggestively with a wing, she said, "What about digging into the sides of the caldera?"

Looking out over the trees, the rim of the caldera was barely visible from lake side. "Hmm..." rumbled Six, "There doesn't look like there's a lot of space on this side of the rim, however. Really, digging into the side of the mountain would be the best choice, preferably if there was already a natural cave system that we could expand..."

"Well... Let's see if we can find one of those." said Blaze, a little irritated that Six hadn't simply said as much before they'd head out. As he was bracing himself for a leap into the air, however, Ember touched him again with her wing. "Hm...?" he grunted. "What is it, Honeysweet?"

"I'm not sure..." she admitted and then she walked off a few paces, sniffing the air and then the ground. "There's an odd flavor in the air."

"Honeysweet, I don't-" Blaze started, but as he moved after her, he caught it as well. It was a metallic, spicy and intriguing odor, one which Blaze was unsure of and yet seemed oddly familiar. It went right to his head, in fact. "Woah, what is that?"

Ember lead the way a few steps down the shore and then turning up a rocky crest cutting through the jungle. Ember walked on the rocks while Blaze pushed his way through the springy plants and pseudo-trees beside her. As the scent grew stronger, the more heady Blaze felt and the more he wanted to discover the source. "Guys!" shouted Six from behind them, but Blaze wasn't about to abandoning the interesting scent now. It didn't take long to find the source.

At the highest point in the outcropping, Ember stopped and sniffed and clawed at an upwelling of stone which was threaded thickly with a crimson metallic rock of some sort. "What on earth is this?" Asked Ember as her claws racked across the stone, the grit liberated from the stone found its way into Blaze's nostrils. Blaze sneezed, but the instant that he did, he felt quite different. It was as if the crimson powder had settled onto the top of his skull, leaving a tingly sensation that quickly spread through the rest of his body, turning his muscles to warm butter. The scent seemed to fill him with its warm biting essence, a spirit of the earth settling casually over his consciousness, numbing worrisome thoughts and leaving only pleasant feelings behind.

A couple seconds later, Blaze found himself sitting before Ember, a foolish grin spread on his face. He knew it'd only been a couple seconds he'd lost touch with himself because he could see Six still catching up with them, struggling somewhat with the rough terrain. "Ember?" asked Blaze quietly, but she didn't respond, apparently having gotten a larger dose than Blaze. However, she did suddenly decide to lean against him and Blaze caught his breath when she decided to wrap her tail around his thigh; all the way around.

When Six finally caught up, he was slightly winded, but he was also wearing a smug grin. He walked up the outcropping and eyed the red threads in the stone below him. "I see you two are discovering the effects of cinnibar."

"Cinnibar? Really?" asked Blaze dumbly, part of him was still drifting along easily.

Ember raised her head slightly, eyes soft and distant, "Cinni-what?"

"Cinnibar." said Six. "It's a drug that's fairly common here in the south-eastern sea. For dragons, anyways. For humanoids, its poisonous."

"Oh no! Is it dangerous?" asked Ember, noticeably reacting more than she was wont to do.

"Not really. I mean, yes it's subject to abuse, but in Damnescara, it's usually prescribed to stressed dragons to help them relax. It's also known as an aphrodisiac." said Six, adding a knowing look as he said the last.

Blaze spoke up, feeling more like himself as the rest mist drained from his heedy conciousness. "Yeah, It's around in New Alveri as well. It's the swinger's drug."

Ember took a few deep breaths and to Blaze's disappointment removed her tail and seemed to compose herself a little. "Well... my curiosity seems to have gotten the better of me. I apologize for leading us down here."

Her comment was mostly directed towards Allorah, however, the elf woman didn't seem very displeased at the delay. In fact, she asked. "Might this be a resource that would be worth harvesting?"

Six spun his head around. "Well, if there's surgery that must be done, cinnibar can be substituted as a weak anesthetic for dragons..."

The elf stood up taller in her saddle. "Actually, I was speaking of the aphrodisiac qualities. I saw what the drakka was doing with her tail just now."

Ember closed her wings more tightly about herself in embarrassment, and Blaze felt a renewed surge of impotent anger towards the elf. Six choked. "Well... um, er. Really, that would depend on each individual dragon. I could speak about the effects of cinnibar in... ahem, that regard."

"Very well." said Allorah, settling back into the saddle. However, she made it quite clear that the issue was not resolved as she withdrew a small notebook and began to jot down notes.

Blaze coughed, "Well, lets see if we can't scout around the rest of the mountain. Maybe we'll find a natural cave like Six was saying." Suddenly, Blaze had no more desire to think about the uncanny red rock that had such a powerful effect on him. However, he could not forget the feel of Ember's tail against him either.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Cinnibar

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Blaze led the way back down the mountain, cutting the wind for both dragons behind him. The rejuvenating effect of the cinnibar turned out to be fleeting, for it was not long back up in the air before the tired ache began to creep back into Blaze's body.

About half an hour into the flight, however, Six roared over the wind and turned about towards the west. It was a classic cue to follow and Blaze did. Some feature of the terrain must have caught the maimed dragon's eye, for he seemed to be following a shallow trough cut into the side of the mountain, perhaps a stream, but then with the jungle, it was hard to tell. Without warning, however the land suddenly gave way to empty space. Water charged out into air, falling easily twenty dragon-lengths to a steaming pool at the base of a rugged cliff.

The cliff itself was composed of black stone and was pockmarked with holes small and large. Blaze felt the air under his wings stir, a current rising from below the cliff. It felt like this was another of the island’s hotspots. The dragons circled down, Six leading the way. Blaze wondered if this was the sort of place the engineer was looking for. It was certainly a place he could imagine digging out a suitable lair.

However, Blaze was shocked when he saw Six veer towards the cliff face. The maimed drake seemed to have trouble braking and before Blaze could do anything about it, he landed hard against the rocky surface of the cliff, scrambling with his claws and wing talons for purchase.

“"Six!"” Blaze shouted as he dived in for a landing below his companion so fast that the membranes of his wings ached with the effort to stop. Above, Six’'s efforts to cling to the Cliffside began showering him with black pebbles.

Although Blaze was fearful of his friend falling, Six gained purchase in the time it took to respond. "“L-look here!"” said Six excitedly. "“I b-believe this place has p-potential."”

Blaze shook his head as Ember landed lightly next to him. “"Are you trying to get yourself killed?"” His feet were getting wet standing so close to the pool of water at the base of the cliff.

Six only waggled his stiff tail down at them and then lifted himself up a few claw-holds. “"The stone here is m-mostly basalt. Strong, but very w-workable."” The red dragon fell to muttering. He cocked his head as Allorah on his back said something, but Blaze didn’’t catch her comparatively small voice.

Content with the appearance that Six was not about to fall and injure himself - probably killing Allorah in the process, but that was less of a concern - – Blaze turned to Ember at his side. Breathing in a deep breath of the misty air at the base of the waterfall, he said, “"This certainly looks like a nice cliff side.”"

Ember looked away, perhaps still embarrassed by her earlier behavior. "“It’s better than the side of the mountain or digging down into jungle turf."” She said noncommittally.

Blaze frowned slightly. What was wrong with this drakka? Back at the fort she’d been almost as enthusiastic about constructing a lair as Six. Blaze, who honestly still wouldn’’t have minded simply sleeping in the open, found himself in the uncomfortable position of defending this location. "“I like this pool."” Said Blaze lamely, “"And the clearing is nice. I’m sure we could make improvements here and there. Plus this waterfall’s pretty special.”"

Ember sighed and looked back at Blaze. The way that her eyes reflected the light in the shimmering mist that landed on her was almost enough to make Blaze groan with desire for her. She smiled a little, but it seemed forced. "“I'’m sure we can make something here. It’s a better spot than any we'’ve come across so far and we'’ve flown over nearly the whole island already.”"

“"I don’t fancy settling into some smelly sea caves."” Said Blaze giving a small shiver.

Ember trilled a laugh “"Nor do I. I just... Well, one spot on this island has to be pretty much the same as any other, doesn’’t it?”"

Her voice was one of resignation rather than a question and Blaze suddenly had an understanding of what had soured her mood suddenly. He struggled for a way to ease her worries. “"Well... maybe that’s true. But we have an opportunity here to make ourselves comfortable. Even if we can’t be free, yet."” Blaze made sure to emphasize the last word.

Ember agreed that there was at least some value in comfort after all that both of them had been through. Before she could say more, however, Six crowed from above. Blaze looked up to see that Six had climbed up about half a dragon length from where he’d been, but more, his upper torso was out of sight. “"Six?"” cried Blaze.

“"Climb up here, you t-two. You must see this! M-mind the l-ledge."” Called Six from above who promptly began to disappear into the cliff side.

Blaze shared a look with Ember and then reared up to scale the cliff. It was an easy climb, especially with some help from his wing talons. In fact, with his increased musculature, Blaze felt like he could have run up the side of the cliff if he'’d really wanted to. When he got to where Six had vanished, Blaze found a large circular hole opening into the cliff side, adjacent to the waterfall. It hadn’’t been apparent with the black stone composing the cliff and the darkness within. The ledge was slippery with moss and wet that had accumulated there due to the falling water. A step inside, however was cool and dry; however, Blaze noted that it was not as cool as the outside temperature should have made it.

Pulling himself up easily, Blaze turned back immediately to check on Ember’'s progress. She was right behind him and easily bushed off Blaze'’s proffered claw. Turning towards the interior darkness of the cave, Blaze made out at once its strangeness.

The opening was circular and so was the interior, which did not bubble out or constrict, rather continuing straight and linear until even the power of dragon eyes petered out into darkness. The floor was curved and smooth, though a bit crumbly under a dragon’'s weight. Here and there, the stone rippled and pooled as if it were black water, frozen in place. The cylinder of the cave seemed to go on forever, ascending ever so slightly into the blackness. Six had already traveled a considerable distance down the tube.

Blaze and Ember were able to walk abreast if they didn’’t mind their wings touching – which they didn’’t – and when they caught up with Six, he greeted them excitedly. "My friends, I believe what w-we have here is an ext-tinct lava tube."

Blaze, although he could see plainly that this place was some sort of tube, did not immediately catch Six's meaning. Ember was faster. She said, "So liquid rock once flowed through this place?"

"Yes, just like a r-river." Six agreed, stepping forward into the dim light.

Blaze reached up and scratch his head against the side of the passage. "If it was a river, then why's it underground?" Blaze was also wondering why the place was hollow instead of solid rock if magma had once moved through here and then cooled.

"Well... As I've been told, the lava is so hot that it actually melts the ground over which it's flowing, causing it to slowly sink into the rock. When the flow begins to lessen, the lava on top cools and forms a shell, sealing the river of rock into a underground tube." Six rattled off, his usual stutter strangely absent while reciting scientific details.

Blaze still had difficulty imagining how the place could have formed, but he did know what he could see and feel now. He ran a claw up a smooth wall to his left. "We could easily make branching chambers off the main tube..."

"T-that's just what I was t-thinking." said Six.

Ember spoke again, "But what are the chances of lava once again flowing through here?"

"V-very small, I'd say." said Six. "I've smelled rodent and b-bats about. G-generations of waste. There's been n-no lava here for a long time."

Blaze sniffed, he was as ready to move in here as any other place. "Sounds fine with me. Where do we start?"

Six began to wax on about various possibilities for lair design, including places to break through the ceiling to let in light and air as well as running water from the adjacent stream. It quickly became more complicated than Blaze could follow. Ember remained relatively quiet and Blaze sensed that this may be becoming too real for her too quickly. Thus it fell largely to Allorah to not so much fuel Six's imaginings so much as reign them in. Blaze could tell the eunuch was having fun with this; not that he didn't deserve it of course.

Finally, it was Allorah who piped up over Six's elegant design. "And how exactly are you going to construct all of this?"
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Home Site

choices: Allorah thinks Blaze needs further correction
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Six scratched his scarred jaw as he was wont to do. "Well. We have three d-dragons here and three more on the way. We'll b-be able to claw our way through the stone fine enough."

"But once you're outside the tube? Into the soil? You'll need supports, lumber. What about all the fine ducts and shafts and the plumbing? Dragon claws are too clumsy for that work."

Six lifted his jowls unevenly. "I am quite capable of carving fine holes and troughs."

"You are, or you used to be?" asked the elf female harshly. The effect on Six was repugnant. The maimed dragon stalled for once in his constant stream of musings and lifted a claw to observe its obvious trembling. "And really, even if you could," Allorah continued, sitting straight in the leather saddle. "You're only one dragon. You're going to need an entire work force."

Blaze couldn't stand to see Six being treated this way. It was all too familiar. Recklessly, Blaze walked up to where Six was sitting. He addressed the elf on his back. "Allorah, stop. You don't need to badger him like that-ack!"

Blaze convulsed, his tail slapping so had against a wall that it stripped a large section clean of brittle volcanic stone. The large, muscular red dragon fell to his knees as the current flowed through him. Allorah removed her thumb from the control talisman. "Master Fang has been far too lenient on you if you think you have the right to speak to me as if you could tell me what to do Lord Flame." said the elf derisively.

Blaze growled softly from the ground, feeling nauseous and certain that he'd pissed himself more than a little. Six, however, barked sharply. "Stop it, Seven. Allorah is right. This p-place isn't going to be anything more than a h-hole in the g-ground without a proper workforce. We need humanoids in here."

The state of workforce on the island was something that Blaze was more knowledgable about than the formation of lava tubes. He slowly shook his head as he eased himself off the floor, sharing a cold look at the elf, but nothing else, "Fang's got more work already than he has workers. I don't think that he has any to spare for us."

"Well... W-we're going to have to think of s-something." said Six ominously.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Correction

choices: Six is gone for a few days
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
It wasn't long before Allorah decided that she needed to report back to Fang all of the day's findings. The sun was going down, the three dragons had spent the entire day out and about and then hanging around the lava tube and the pool at the base of the waterfall. Six volenteered to ferry the elf away while Blaze and Ember could remain behind and begin some initial excavation. He claimed that it was because he was already wearing the saddle and he'd be of limited use in carving stone and while these were true, Blaze suspected that Six only really spoke up after he caught his and Ember's glances at one another.

Blaze was reclining in the pool, allowing the water to slush heavily onto his head. His back and wing muscles ached. It was nice to close his eyes and let the cold water run over him. "I'll r-request that Fang accompany me when I ret-turn." Six said as he prepared to take off from the ledge of the lava tube. "Maybe I'll even have one or two more drakka when I get b-back."

"Ah-hum." Blaze grunted without opening his eyes.

"Just dig straight into the walls of the tube where I marked, Lord Flame. There'll be enough w-work to occupy both of you until I r-r-r... get back." Six finished.

Blaze just nodded, but he heard Ember reply, "We'll be able to manage on our own." This was followed by the sound of leather tightenning as Six flapped away. Then there was silence. At least until someone put their claw on Blaze's tail, about halfway up the thick part. Blaze released a grunt and opened his eyes.

Ember was climbing in with him. With their two volumes together, the small pool began to overflow and spill its banks, but neither dragon particularly cared. Blaze said nothing, letting the drakka do as she would. When she slid in alongside him, he did think that she fit against him rather nicely, though it was a bit odd that he was the bulkier of the two of them now. "Ember..." he whispered, still a little cautious of the restraining collar on his neck.

Thankfully he wasn't zapped. Emboldened, Ember said, "Blaze..." seeming to relish in the freedom of at least being able to say each other's names, even if they couldn't say their own aloud. She move her claw to Blaze's breast, running down the slick scales there. At her touch, Blaze was filled with passion so that it was an effort to restrain himself, or even think of a reason to restrain himself. But it just didn't feel like the proper moment for that. Blaze sighed and relaxed more into the pool. Due to its size, his tail was left beached on the far end of the rocky cistern.

The sky overhead was deeping into a rich lavender. Blaze could have drifted off to sleep right there. Ember broke the quiet between them. "What's going to happen now?"

Blaze looked at her out of a corner of his eye. His active hormones sensed an oppertunity, so he said, "Whatever you'd like..."

She pushed his snout away gently. "I mean with us, on this island... We still need to think about a way to escape... don't we?"

Her voice was strangely stressed on the question. Blaze, however answered mellowly, "Of course we'll get out of here. We just need to play along and wait until the right moment."

"But when is that moment?" asked Ember, adjusting herself against Blaze's heavier body.

Blaze shrugged in the water. "I don't know. But we'll know when we see it." Ember still seemed distant, so he added, "But the point is that the worst is over. We survived! We'll have time to settle in and think about things later."

"But what if the best time to escape is now?" Ember persisted to Blaze's mild annoyance.

Blaze huffed. "I think they'll be expecting that. We ought to wait until their guard is down."

"Well, when will that be?" said Ember, he voice slightly strained.

Blaze looked at her again. "Ember, how could I possibly know that?" He wanted to ask what was with her all of a sudden, but bit his tongue because he didn't want to ruin the mood they'd had just a few moments ago. "We just need to hold out until the right time."

But Blaze's efforts seemed in vain, Ember looked to be on the verge of tears as she said, "Blaze, do you understand what you're saying? Don't you remember what they brought us here for?"

Oh, right. Blaze had almost forgotten that they were here specifically so that they could be bred. He swallowed a sip from the water pouring over then and then said, "It's a hard thing, sweet Ember. I don't have an answer except that we're not in cages anymore, and I think that has to count for something."

Ember said nothing. Instead she clung tighter to Blaze, wrapping her forpaws around his chest and entwining her tail with his. After a little while, she said quietly, "I just want to be away from this place... I miss my family."

Even though the only home he'd ever known was an orphanage in New Alveri, Blaze said, "I do too." Then he placed his claws around her as well, the water supporting them both. It felt so nice to hold her that Blaze never wanted to let go.

Blaze found himself awakening unexpectedly, not having realized he'd drifted off. Ember was still in his arms, the water still pouring over them both, boucing off their scales obliviously. Despite the tropical climate, Blaze was a little cold. Despite the cold, Blaze felt familiar longings with his drakka companion so close at hand.

Blaze found himself adjusting his hips before he half understood what he was doing. But when the large slit on his abdomen pressed against Ember's belly, the heat of passion built up a pressure in the drake's head that ached to followthrough.

Ember stirred at Blaze's touch. At first she was responsive, even reaching out her wing to enfold Blaze and pull him closer. Blaze would have grinned, but there was little happiness in him just now, but rather a single minded, animalistic need. In just a few moments, Blaze had escaped his sheathe and with his claws around Ember's shoulders, began to beg entry.

Before he could, however, Ember became fully awake. "Blaze... what... Oh! hey, stop!"

Blaze almost didn't. It would have been easy enough, despite the fact that Ember was only slightly smaller than himself. However when Ember pushed him away and his desire strongly fought to pursue anyways, the image of Dr. Moriden came back to mind. A memory from over a year ago and a question. "What would you do? If there were a horny drakka, right in front of you?"

The memory repulsed him utterly and he let go. Ember discreetly exited the pool and shook herself off, but more quickly than was really needed. She took a breath to steady herself. The sight of her lean frame and her extended wings, dripping with water was not helping Blaze pull himself back together. "Sorry. I thought you-"

Ember cut him off. "It's alright, it's..." She let out a breath, turned back to Blaze still sitting stupidly in the water and put a small smile on her face. "Really, it's alright. It's just me, ok?"

Blaze took a couple breaths as well, waiting until he was alright to stand. He clamored out over the edge of the pool and shook like a dog. "S'fine." Blaze said, though his body still ached with the anticipation of moments ago.

Neither of them said anything for a few moments, so the tension was palpable. Blaze just wanted to forget this as soon as possible, but couldn't so long as there was hope...

Ember took a deep breath, looking up she said, "The sky's lightening. We ought be be able to start some excavation."

"Ah, yes! Let's get to work building our new den." said Blaze. With hope dead for now, he felt relieved, ambiguity was torturous. Blaze took the lead in scaling up the cliff to the hole. Really, it was a relief to vent his energy into the dark stone.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Alone and Awkward

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Six was gone for three days. It was so long, in fact, that Blaze was strongly considering flying back to Fort Carmile to see what was happening. He didn't mostly because he was enjoying the "freedom" away from Fang and the rest of the Kleaves too much. That and the time he was able to spend alone with Ember.

After the incident in the waterfall pool, Blaze made sure to reign in his passion, however, it was a constant challenge. Blaze could not help but fantasize endlessly of caressing Ember, grasping her, and much much more. He was sure that the lust and cravings for Ember's body that he felt whenever she was near was far more extreme than was normally called for, thanks to the diabolical tampering of Dr. Moridin. In all honesty these frenzied desires that were increasing day by day scared him. Dr. Mordin words rang in his head again and again, that he was no better than an animal and that day by day he was turning into what Flamer-2 had been, a prisoner of his own bestial lusts. The work on the tunnel was a godsend rather than a chore. The menial labor helped relieve Blaze of the constant temptation of his partner and so he would throw himself into the work when he was feeling particularly frustrated.

Ember chatted about the domicile they were crafting. She seemed soothed by the idea-work in opening the closed spaces rather than the actual work. As a result, she did less work than Blaze and had a tendency to stand by and instruct him, but honestly, Blaze didn't mind. With his great strength, the basalt gave way under his claws as if it were clay. While she did not have the same mind for the specifics of ducts and troughs for running water as Flamer-6 did, Blaze nonetheless found himself deeply impressed with her ideas for the layout of the lair, utilizing the long straight passage of the lava tube.

"We'll keep the floor flat here, but about two wing-lengths away, we can include a ledge for sleeping on." Ember would say and Blaze would be left trying to visualize distances into solid rock; usually with only marginal success. When the first chamber was opened up, Ember found more enthusiasm for smoothing the floor and walls and ensuring that there was a proper shelf for sleeping on. As for the excess stone and debris created from the excavation, Blaze just threw this down at the base of the lava tube, not knowing what else to do with it.

The time that was not spent inside the lava tube was typically spent out and about the island. Blaze followed more than led during their flights about the island (besides, the view of Ember was good from behind). They circled the place more than twice, soaring on coastal breezes and climbing on warm thermals. They didn't talk much in the air. Ember often seemed lost in thoughts and emotions that were mysterious to Blaze. He was treading carefully around her, but ever his own feelings and impulses drove him to get closer. They hunted twice in the time that Six was gone. The first time, Blaze snagged another buffalo and Ember chowed down on a sow that she'd found some place. The second time they went fishing for dolphin along the shores on Ember's suggestion that they be more careful in harvesting the island's supply of meat.

In the mornings and the evenings, they found time to talk. In all honesty, they didn't really know each other all that well. Ember was shocked to hear that Blaze was an orphan and also somewhat disappointed to learn that he remembered nothing of his parents and that his life had been pretty unremarkable before being captured by Kleaves. However, Blaze was surprised to find how fascinated Ember was about the city of New Alveri, it being a wondrous and exotic realm of endless wealth and opportunity. Blaze, having lived there all his life, frankly he saw many of these things as mundane and also as a struggle. All the same, Blaze told her not only of the city, but all the different dragons, like his friend Darzhja who he’d always looked up to and who had aspirations of joining the Holy Knights, Iskierka and her artistic talents, Lady Ramoth and the humanoids and the things that happened within the city.

As for Blaze, Ember told him many, many things about the wild tribes of dragons from beyond the Alverian border from which she hailed. When she told him of her story of how she'd been captured and under what circumstances she'd been away from her tribe at the time, Blaze was floored. Quickly, Blaze equated, "Chieftain's daughter" with "princess" and his respect and awe for the drakka grew even more intense, as did his feelings for her.

"I can understand why you left. I wouldn't want to be sent away from the only other dragons that I knew and cared for either." Blaze said as they sat beside the caldera lake the evening Ember found time to finally recite her story.

Ember sniffed. "Leaving was the biggest mistake of my life. I should have listened to my mother. If I had, then I would never have ended up here."

Blaze almost said, 'But then we would've never met,' but caught himself before he did. It would have been hollow and also rather selfish. They had both suffered too much pain and rape.

“You know, I’ve often thought about the same thing…day after day… How I should have been stronger, fought harder, and wasn’t such a scared little coward that day… Neither of us could have known that then, or could have conceived the hell that was waiting for us, yet here we are. I wish I could tell you that things are going to be all right, or that we’re building a better tomorrow. Yet no matter how much we could pretend otherwise we’ve still got those rings around our neck…” replied Blaze, his claw went to his neck, a reminder that even though life had taken a façade of being tolerable, their freedom was only illusory.

Ember sighed and buried her face in her forepaws, grinding her chin into the loose soil at the edge of the lake. “So you’re saying there is no way we can escape…”

“We’re not fortunate enough that the island is being run by an idiot…” he replied with a hollow laugh. “I’ll tell you one thing though… there’s a difference between being a prisoner and being a slave. Dr Mordin, that demented elf who altered me, told me that he could dictate my will like a sweet instrument or bend it out of tune, that ultimately we dragons just slaves to our lusts and impulses and that eventually he’d turn me into little more than a beast. He tried…by the Ancestors he tried… The things they did to me, the things they’ve yet to force me to do…”

He shook his head and scrunched his teeth together, “I’ll have nightmares about them for the rest of my life… however long that is. Yet they won’t turn me into an animal like Flamer-2 was. I won’t be a slave…"

Ember shifted her body and merely gazed at Blaze long and hard. Blaze, acting on impulse, flowed forward, laying a wing on Ember's crimson scaled back and grasping an elbow in a strong claw.

"Sometimes, I don't know how I can go on." She sobbed once. "Sometimes I don't know if I want to go on. Yet you gave me a reason Blaze… A reason to keep going no matter how bad things get..."

Blaze could only concur with that as he held her close, greatful that the Ancestors had given him that reason to continue to live…

‘clap’ ‘clap’ ‘clap’ ‘clap’

The two dragons suddenly curved their heads around. There stood Fang, clad in his flowing red robe with that clever smile on his face.

“Very inspiring speech Blaze!! I can see why she likes you so much…” he cried, with almost genuine pride.

“Fang!! How by the Ancestors did you sneak up on us like that?” Blaze cried, instinctively shielding Ember with his wing. Though the elf was no taller than the top of his extended elbow, he nonetheless exuded an aura of authority that even a breeder male would be wary of.

“If I told you, it wouldn’t be so effective anymore now would it? To tell you the truth Blaze, I agree wholeheartedly with the content of your speech. You’re no good to me as slaves; in fact, as we’ve seen we get a lot more done when you’ve got something to look forward for…”

“I must say, that’s quite ironic coming out of you…” he replied with an eye roll. “Is there anything else you’d want us to do?” he added. Blaze knew that Fang often enjoyed bantering with him, but at the same time he didn’t want to push too far either. In the meanwhile, Ember stayed silent through the exchange. She was still unused to Fang’s unconventional style of ruling, compared with Allorahs strict and direct regime.

“Anyhow, I figured I’d let you know that the other four drakka have all arrived on the island right now and are working on the lair.”

“Sparkles, Starry, Cherry and Rocket are all here now?” cried Ember, seeming both surprised and also slightly alarmed. The news had also caught Blaze off guard, and also rather resentful that he would have to share now.

“That’s right. You two have been doing quite a good job so I figure you deserve this time off. I must also add that the friend of yours, Flamer-6, he really knows his stuff. Had I known he was a Damescaran architect beforehand…well…perhaps its best we not go into that discussion hmmm? If you really must have orders, I’ve been curious about the properties of this cinnabar and its effect upon dragons…”

Fang pulled out a large pouch the size of a camping pack and levitated it over to the two young dragons. Already, Blaze could taste the slight scent seeping out of the bag….
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Reason to live

choices: Several days later, unexpected visitors show up on the island
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
"Cinnibar..." Blaze muttered under his breath as the heavy looking satchel of the unseen, but smelt red power floated closer towards him. Weightlessly, the sack flew up to land casually on the red dragon's broad snout, Fang not even bothering to wiggle his fingers, but rather staring smugly up at him. Blaze's mouth watered, he knew already the effect of cinnibar on him, while Ember hovered closely at his side, watching and unreadable.

The weight of the bag settled onto the scales of his nose as Fang released the power suspending it. The muscles in Blaze's body tensed. How nice it would be to float free in the grip of the cinnibar, and how nice also might it be if it eased Ember's sense of reservation, if she might allow him to...

The muscular dragon snapped his nose upward, sending the bag soaring into the air, where it crashed with a thud at Fang's feet. Red dust sparkled upward from where it had shot out from under the flap closing the satchel. Fang crossed his arms, but he did not look displeased. Blaze stared down at him, defiantly, not caring if Fang decided to punish him.

"I'm surprised that you are still so reserved. I thought you might desire some comfort after all you've been through." said Fang simply and hauled up the leather sack by one of its straps as if it weighed no more than a feather pillow.

"Cinnibar is false comfort." said Blaze, standing firmly upright and towering over the smaller elf. "And I know that you only want the eggs Ember and I might make if we let our guards down using it." Ember shot him a look after he spoke that made Blaze think he might pay for his presumption later.

Fang only shrugged. "Naturally." Now he slung the sack of mineral powder over his slender shoulder. "But just because something might benefit me, doesn't mean that it automatically hurts you. Consider this also." said the elf as he began to turn and leave the two dragons beside the quiet lakeside. "You'll be making eggs anyways. Why not make it easier for yourselves?"

A sudden chill ran down Blaze's spine at Fang's words. But this was shortly followed by a surge of rage. Not thinking at all, but unable to restrain himself, Blaze reared up, his fore paws shaking in the tropical breeze and then charged down the elf. Fang was already ahead of the two dragons by a good margin and before Blaze could reach Fang, to offer at least a gesture of disobediance and force Fang to defend himself, the elf turned behind a tree. Blaze grabbed at it, claws slicing through the air where the elf had been, but they found only the bark of the tall tree, into which his claws rended deep grooves and almost stuck. It was as if the earth had swallowed up the elf, leaving no trace.

"I wonder how he does that." said Ember, waltzing up behind Blaze and placing her wing gently on the drake's quivering shoulders.

Blaze turned in anger, ready to strike her, but Ember's face and the cant of her wings chilled the rage in Blaze, transmuting it into softer emotions. But she started, she'd seen the hate on Lord Flame's face. There was a moment of tension, but it passed. Blaze cleared his throat and said, "If we knew that, we'd be a step closer to being able to defeat him."

Then Ember said something that surprised Blaze. "Maybe it doesn't have to come to killing." Blaze gaped, lost for words and she spoke again, withdrawing her wing, "I'd be fine with simply being away from here."

Blaze wanted to argue the point, but the words he wanted didn't come. He wanted to tell her that killing Fang was the only real hope of escape, and that he ought to pay for what he did. But Ember's face told him that an argument for revenge wasn't what she wanted to hear right now. Blaze's mouth continued to stand open stupidly, it was as if the old words, the old feelings were slipping through his paws, and he could not pin them down, make them real.

Suddenly, a crash of pain filled Blaze's head and he covered his eyes with his wing, eyes smarting in the late afternoon sun on the ocean. "Blaze?" asked Ember, her sweet voice filled with concern.

The pain seemed to go on for a time, blotting out reality and making Blaze feel numb and empty, as if he were nothing so much as a hollow egg. There was nothing to his thoughts but confusion and a sense of loss, but underlying that, a glowing coal of rage that would have reminded Blaze of those burning eyes he'd seen in the pool of lava he'd created by the power of his breath. That is, he would have if he was capable of assembing something so complex as a recollection in that moment when the threads of his thoughts seems frayed by a howling wind.

Then, just as suddenly as it had come, the headache passed. Blaze stared at Ember, watching her mouth move and hearing sounds, but not making any sense of what she was saying. "...you alright?" said Ember.

The words snapped into place, like a lens setting in. Blaze shook his head like a dog, as if he could remove the moths that had seemed to settle between his ears. "I'm alright." he said, though he didn't really feel alright. His mind felt somehow hot, as if his brain were still settling back into place. "It's nothing." said Blaze.

Ember looked at him curiously, but didn't press him. The red drake stared off at the visible crest of ocean which was framed by the rising sides of the volcano, calming himself, but wondering what on earth had just happened to him.

"I think we have time for a quick swim." said Ember, her voice cutting through the fog and drawing Blaze up like a drowning man. "Fang shouldn't be expecting us back too soon. Hell he might even want us to spend more time to..."

Blaze silenced her by placing a wing tip to her lips. "Don't say that." said Blaze and then moved the wing tip with its smooth talon down the scales of her neck to first caress and then gather her up by the shoulders. In this way, he guided her down the flat bank and into the cold waters of the basin.
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: No Excess

1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Blazes back arched as he forced his clawed hands into the dark stone. It crumbled in his paws like chalk, but after several hours of excavation, the red drake was hot and weary with the effort. Pulling back from the wall where he’d been expanding the latest chamber off the chute of the lava tube, the dragon flexed his paws, trying to work the ache out of them. Heaving a great sigh that expanded the drakes deep chest, Blaze turned away from his work. The last effort was to sweep away the basalt chunks with his tail. The brittle stone that landed on the curved ridged stone of the central tube sounded almost like glass breaking.

“Hey, watch where you’re throwing that stuff!” came a shout from the tube.

Blaze looked curiously sidelong. He’d almost forgotten about the crew. Fang had assigned them here a couple days ago, to help with the excavation work. Six had them mostly carving air ducts and water spills. Some of that work required raw material to be added to certain areas, so a few men were constantly in and out of the tube, scavenging for proper sized rocks to bring to their projects. Blaze thought a moment about apologizing, but then reconsidered. After all the man was here to assist him and the other dragons who lived here. He ought to be more observant and not force Blaze and the others to be constantly watching their toes, in fact, he was lucky that he hadn’t decided to kill the offending human for talking back to him. “I thought you wanted more rocks?” said Blaze flippantly, and immediately regretted the words that had spilled out of his mouth.

But rather than a retort, Blazes comment was met with silence. The man averted his eyes and then seemed to find urgent business elsewhere. Blaze remembered just then that his proper title was indeed Lord Flame, and that carried significant weight around here. The young dragon still felt uncomfortable wearing such a name, but then there was nothing to do about that.

Blaze slithered out of the perfectly circular entrance of the lava tube and down the steep path that led to the stream basin. His wings flared a couple times as he skipped down the slope, black pebble following in his wake. It wasn’t anything like a good flight, but the fresh air rushing past the red dragons face was lovely none the less. At the bottom of the slope, Blaze braked and let himself into the pool with only a medium sized splash; medium for a dragon, that is.

The pool walls had already been raised and reinforced from what they had been and now the pool was deep enough for a shallow dive, even if it remained rather too narrow for laps. The cold water was bliss on his dusty scales and when Blaze lifted his head free from the water, he guzzled gallons of fresh water from the trickle of stream which fed the pool.

It was only after he’d slacked his thirst that Blaze realized that he was not alone in the pool. Green eyes met his, but rather than surprised, they seemed interested and calculating. “Well, hello there,” said the drakka in the water.

Blaze curved his head to the other drakka.

Well now, this is going to be interesting...
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.title: Work...work...work...

choices: Unknown attackers come out of the woodwork
1112111211211111111211111111211111112121.content:
Blaze seemed momentarily stunned. Seeing only the head above the surface of the rippling water, he could not at first gather the identity of the stranger so near to him that he could feel their tails mingling at the bottom of the pool. But then her scent floated into his nose and the memory came free like a chuck of quartz stuck in the basalt. “You’re…um… Starflare aren’t you?” said Blaze.

“Its Sparkles actually,” said the drakka coyly. Blaze curved his head away, a little bit embarrassed he’d forgotten her name.

“I saw you flying some supplies here from the colony,” said Sparkles, “I imagined what it’d be like meeting you up close, but wow, you’re seriously hot…”

The way she said it caught Blazes attention in the way that Embers usually did. That is to say, he grew more aware of his own loins in response. “Truthfully, I’m still not used to drakka thinking of me like that. Believe it or not, I used to laughed at for being a 1000 pound weakling,” he replied with a chuckle, unable to resist the temptation to flex his chest and stomach muscles in response. “Now that you mention it, I think you’re quite comely yourself… I can't believe I haven't gotten to meet you until now,” said Blaze. Below the surface of the water, he thought she was beginning to play with his tail with her own, but it could have been his imagination.

“Well, I’ve only been here a few days,” she said bashfully, “Allorah has me taking directions from that scarred drake...”

“You mean Six,” said Blaze automatically. Below the water, he felt the drakkas tail pause and then slowly begin to wrap around his own. He noticed how her own tail was more slender than his, but softer.

“Yeah, Six,” said Sparkles offhandedly. Then, with unknowing cruelty, she added, “He doesn’t smell really like a drake anymore though, does he?”

He knew that she hadn’t meant to anger him, or perhaps she had meant to embolden his masculine pride, yet Blaze let his head sink into the water until only his nostrils, eyes and horns were above the surface. A tangled mixture of anger, pity, empathy and relief flowed through him at the reminder of what had been taken from Six. Anger, because the handicapped drake was his friend, but at the same time relief that clearly there was no competition for maleness on this island.

The drakka seemed to realize the error of her comment and said, “I’m sorry. Honeysweet told me that you and him are close.“ Then she drifted closer to him, paddling with her feet until Blaze could feel the tips of her toes making eddies which collided with his body with the softness of clouds.

“It isn’t his fault” said Blaze, lifting his head and looking directly at Sparkles. “It could have easily been me,”

“To tell you the truth, before he got, well, scarred, he actually told me that he thought you were really cute.” Sparkles’ eyes grew very wide and she let in a breath. How odd that her face should seem small and thin; he really was gigantic for a male fire drake. He wasn’t that much bigger than Ember, but now that he thought of it, Ember was the biggest out of all the females there.

He turned his snout away then, to look off into the jungle. But a clawed hand on his jaw turned him back. Sparkles had come yet closer, she was almost belly to belly with him as they floated in the water. The closeness of her and her scent cause the water about his nethers to warm in a way that was beyond Blazes control. “I think that its amazing that you care for him, after the way you males were treated back on the other island. I heard stories...”

Sparkles retreated, and Blaze was briefly angry at this too. The pull away from her was like a magnetic tug, but he forced himself to allow her distance. The drakkas claws rose and splashed water against her cheeks, which had begun to dry. The droplets were like rubies glistening on her hide. “I don’t like to talk about what they did to us. It was the closest thing to the hell humans speak about sometimes that I could imagine. But they didn’t force us to kill each other. And they didn’t do... other things.”

The drakkas lower jaw quivered and strangely, Blaze felt like comforting her, though it was he that these heinous things that she darent speak of had been done to. “I’m just happy that we all managed to make it through alive. I think thats all can be said about what happened.

"Yes, we made it out alive... "said Sparkles, now a little distantly. A long moment past then with neither of them talking. The only sound was of the parrots chattering in the dense trees overhead. Then her claw was on his shoulder, her digits gripping the wing joint where it sprouted from his flank. “I can see why Honeysweet likes you, Lord Flame. You actually care about us,” He put weight on his wing joint and lifted herself a little out of the water, enough to get her face close to the side of his head.
Blaze drew in a deep inhalation of breath. The lust filling his body up from his stomach was almost impossible to ignore. If he turned now, and if she did not resist, he would take her, right in the pool. But what would Ember say if he did?

Blaze lowered his nose into the pool and blew bubbles, not trusting himself to say anything. Slowly, Sparkles lowered herself from his back and drifted away on the current, coming to rest against one of the artificial sides of the pool. After about a minute holding his breath under water, he felt calm enough to speak. He paddled to the opposite side of the pool and though their tails still mingled, their hips were comfortably far apart. Sparkles looked disappointed, but thankfully she also seemd to understand why he might have been reluctant to be placed in a situation where he’d cheat on Ember.

“What do you think of the new workers?” asked Blaze because he simply could not think of anything else to talk about. Might as well talk about the shapes of the clouds really.

As expected, the drakka turned her snout and sighed. But she said, “I don’t really like them. I don’t like the way they smell. Or the way they talk. They’re too smug, almost like they think they’re better than us,”

Blaze nodded grimly, he had gotten that sort of vibe from a couple of the new workers, come to think about it. But Fang was always going on about the lack of workers on the island and deadlines and such other mind boggling affairs. He probably couldn’t afford to keep only the good ones which knew their proper place around dragons.

“You know, Six has told me that he and Fang were talking about gathering trolls from nearby islands. But if Fang treats them anything like the troll slaves back on the other island, I don’t want anything to do with them,”

Sparkles surprised him with a more cavalier response, “Oh, slaves can be fine, at least after a few generations. You can breed the rebelliousness out of them, you know, then they’re just as docile and useful as you like.”

You mean just like us right?
Blaze cocked his head. “You sound like you’ve had slaves before…”

The drakka brushed the side of her face with the knuckles of one claw and Blaze could almost imagine the fine gems which might have once sat on them.

“Well naturally. On the west coast of the continent, trolls will run amok if they don’t have strong leadership. It’s part of keeping the basic law and order really. Then the drakka lifted herself so her smooth, clamshell colored chest was exposed and stretched her arms out on the sides of the pool. She drew her claws down the stone shelf of that side, eliciting a screech that sent another pulse of delightful agony down to Blazes crotch. The smooth muscles of her lean arms stood against the scales of her arms and chest as she stretched and sighed before sliding back down into the water. “I think they appreciate having the stability in their lives, in their own fashion.”

While it was fine for Sparkles to talk about slaves like that, all that came into Blazes mind were the whips and shrieks of pain from the trolls he’d seen when he was first brought to the other island over the long sea journey from Damescara which seemed so long ago now.

Blaze was finally feeling comfortable and rested now and was beginning to contemplate how he might excuse himself from Sparkles without offending her. He knew he’d be having sex with all of them eventually, yet he’d still rather do it with Ember first before going to any of the others.
