"I....can't, it hurts," she wailed. It was only then that I noticed a puddle of blood pooling around her belly. Her back leg was twisted at a terrible angle, as was her right wing. That allowed me I to duck into the path Kaj had created and gingerly made my way to Iskierka. Her body was wedged under a series of metal beams. Frantically, I began shoving the rubble out of the way.

"Am...am I going to die?" she murmured, her eyes grazed and frightened.

"You're not going to die Iskierka!! You're going to be all right!!" I screamed back. "We're going to see Blaze and Ophelia and the others again."

Iskierka merely gave a shuddering breath in response.

"Hurry up Darzja!! I can't hold it up forever!!" Kaj called, straining under the weight.

Finally, I managed to get enough rubble free that I could move her. I had to be extremely careful, or else she could get even more injured.

I grabbed Iskierka underneath his front claws and pried her out from the rubble. Iskierka let out a wail of pain as I did so. Lifting her limp body over my back, I staggered out of the rubble, just as Kaj let go of the balcony, back onto the street.

"Iskierka! Iskierka!!" I called out. She wasn't moving on my shoulders. Was I too late?

"She's only unconscious Darzja," said Kaj. I let out a sigh of relief.

"She's going to need help soon... Get your friend back to the orphanage," said Kaj. "I've got to report with the rest of my unit to find out what's going on..."

I nodded, and quickly made my way through the streets. It would have been faster to fly, but it was too risky considering her condition. Though I had taken the route from the marketplace to the orphanage thousands of times, it felt like forever.

"Lady Ramoth!! Lady Ramoth!!" I screamed.

"Darzja!! Thank the Ancestors you're safe!!" the old matron cried.

"I'm all right, but Iskierka's badly wounded!!" I wailed out.

"Get her inside quickly then!!" cried Ramoth. I nodded, and rushed into the chapel. I set her down at the altar, where the priests immediately rushed forth to tend to her.

"Darzja, make sure that the younger orphans are within their dorms. I'm counting on you to keep them safe understand!?" ordered Ramoth.

I nodded and headed inside. The younger hatchlings scurried about, scared and panicked. Quite a number of them were crying.

"Darzja!! Is Iskierka going to be all right!!" asked Ophelia.

"She was hurt pretty badly when the skyscraper collapsed on the artists guild. She'll at least live, but I don't know how she'll end up from there. I'm just glad that you and the others are safe."

"I'm still worried about Blaze though. He hasn't come back since the attack..." said Ophelia.

"What? I saw him on the streets and I told him to return to the orphanage. You're saying he hasn't shown up yet!!"

I hoped that it was only because he was late, or that he decided to ignore what Kaj and I had told him and decided to help out the civilians, but I couldn't help but fear if something had happened to him.
1141211111.title: Rescue efforts

choices: Iskierka was to lose her wing
11412111111.content:
I just couldn’t sit still at the orphanage, not after I’d heard that Blaze had yet to return. People were still running amok. The humanoid priests were doing what they could for the injured dragons coming in, but it was too much. I realized then that adult dragons were coming in, some collapsing on the landing and others walking up the steps with broken wings. The hospitals in the area were full, they were saying, and there was nowhere left to go. So many dragons, and yet these were the ones yet able to move and talk. How many more were left in the burning rubble like Iskeirka? How many hundreds or thousands of smaller bipeds were killed or injured where they did not have the strength of a dragon to see them through? I had to find Blaze.

Lady Ramoth wouldn’t have let me go, so I didn’t beg her pardon. Besides, I was technically no longer under her authority anyways, but it still bothered me to disregard what she would have wanted. Hopefully I could find the wayward fire drake and be back before she noticed. I slid out the side entrance and took the stairs down, leaving worried and crying orphans behind me.

It was a good thing I hadn’t taken to the air. I saw the Knights flying in formation overhead. They were stopping civilian dragons and directing to the center of New Alveri, the Temple itself. I knew the dragon populace was being conscripted and recruited for rescue efforts, while at the same time, the humanoid half of the Knights were on the ground compelling the two-legged populace to evacuate the district. It might not have appeared fair on the surface, but dragons were outnumbered by the faster breeding races fifty to one and most dragons understood that it was their duty to help in an emergency. Such was the price of power.

I longed to fly up and be organized into the effort. To the Knights now securing the skies over New Alveri, I’d be nothing more than another useful body and pair of wings, but at the same time I’d be a useful body and a pair of wings, an equal to everyone caught in this nightmare storm that had thrust the world I knew into destruction and chaos. But I had to find Blaze first and see him safely home.

The fires were spreading as I reached the bottom of the clifface where the market district was. The air was dense and uncomfortable. But as a dragon, I could handle a good deal of smoke. The humanoids who hadn’t fled already were not so fortunate. People, people I knew were stumbling blind along the sidewalks, choking to death, but I couldn’t help them! The bodies of those who’d died in the explosion or soon after still littered the streets like refuse. It hurt my heart to see them, so I closed my watery eyes. “Blaze! Blaze!” I called and coughed.

A blackened window burst from the heat beside me and the resulting back draft lifted me off my feet. The side of my neck felt seared even through my fire resistant scales. I lay stunned on the cobbles for how long I didn’t know. Water from the sky revived me. I woke, the side of my neck still burned and raw, and saw overhead a passing formation of Knights. The riders were magicking water to cling to the underbellies of their airborne partners so they could spread it over the burning district.

I got to my feet and called for Blaze, but my voice had gone. I had to close my water lids for the acridness of the air and I realized that I was coughing constantly. Where was Blaze? Where was the way back? I tripped over my left wing which I’d inexplicable left dragging on the ground. I felt dizzy and my neck was starting to blister under the scales. This was a foolish mistake. How could I have thought that I could have rescued Blaze? I couldn’t even beat Raj in a fair fight.

There was a crash and for a moment, I thought that another building was crumbling down to cinders. Then I saw a large group of humanoids. They were dressed in thick yellow coats and orange suspenders. Their faces were blackened by soot, but around their noses and mouths, translucent bubbles clung to clean skin. A tall, muscular grey scaled dragonborn emerged from the doorway he’d kicked down. “Clear.” He said. Across the street, I saw a team of sturdy dwarves carrying axes perform the same function.

An elf, his eyes stained red and watering ran forward to me with the speed of a deer. He waved his arms as I bobbed my head woozily. “What are you doing here? You have to get out, the whole district has caught fire!”

“B-blaze…” I muttered. I coughed and spat out a thick black wad on the street cobbles. ‘M-my friend.” I subsided into more coughing and lay down before the elf, feeling wretched.

The elf raised his left arm and twirled the fingers in a complicated loop pattern, then uttered a single word. A bubble formed itself around my snout and I found that I could breathe again, though my mouth and throat remained raw. “If your friend’s here, we’ll find him. Leave but don’t fly, things are still burning and exploding in the city. We have to keep the fires from reaching the alchemist’s guild! If you see anyone alive help them get out, now go!”

I nodded once then turned tail. It was still difficult working my way back, but my water lids protected my eyes despite making my sight blurry and nearsighted. Water was coming down now every half minute, drenching me and everything in the district as the Knights flew their patterns nonstop. As the fires burned down to cinders, dragons were landing here and there to help sort through the rubble. I found no sign of Blaze on the way back nor anyone else alive. The couple of people I’d seen earlier on the street were collapsed dead face down in the ash. I wept, leaving bronze tracks on my blackened cheeks.

Lady Ramoth was livid when she discovered my condition and I told her what I’d done, naturally. I received a smelly green poultice for my neck, but no other care. In fact, I was put right to work as an orderly to help with the heavy bulk of the dragon patients occupying as many of the rooms as could be spared. The orphans and staff were shunted to the closets and even hallways as the orphanage was converted into a makeshift infirmary. Even Lady Ramoth gave up her personal quarters. Again, I could not help but notice how many dragons lay injured on the cool stone of the caverns.

Some sense was beginning to emerge from the conflicting tales of the dragons. The explosion had happened during some sort of meeting of the four major trade princes, three of which were dragons of incredible wealth and power. Rumors ranged from saying that all four princes had died in the explosion to only the dragons had died, the fourth having been spirited away by magic to none had actually died and that they had been using doppelgangers to conduct the meeting. Regardless, people were saying this was a deliberate attack against the dragons of New Alveri. “Curse the short-livessss!” a crotchety old deathwing hissed, “Curssse them and the holesss they crawled from… ahh!”

“Shush now, grandfather.” I said and squeezed water into his mouth from a rag and placed the cool cloth on his face. He was burned over half of his body, the black scales curling away from the skin, revealing tender red and yellowed flesh underneath. He wouldn’t survive the night.

I was quickly called away, however by a human priest in blood splattered robes. He told me…
11412111111.title: Rescuer or Rescuee?

114121111111.content:
"No!! She can't lose her wing!!" I wailed, "She'll never be able to fly again!! Isn't there anything else you can do to fix it!!"

"I'm sorry Darzja... I truly am. We've already tried everything we could think of, and even had a mage tried to look at it. Yet, her wing was crushed beyond repair, if it isn't amputated we risk it becoming infected and that would surely cost Iskierka her life..." the priest sighed.

I curved my gaze over to the young gold dragoness and could only watch with horror as a team of humans lifted a giant saw. My gaze shifted toward her broken wing. It was a mess. All of the wing bones had been shattered, while its membranes looked like torn curtains. Two thirds of the connecting tissue had already been ripped out from her back, leaving only the twisted bone that connected it with her spine. My mind told me that amputation was indeed the only thing that could be done, but the fact that it was Iskierka that this had to be done to; Iskierka who was my dear friend, and knowing that she would never fly again, never find love with a mate and likely condemned to a life of poverty was too much.

Iskierka curved a pair of pleading and scared eyes at me. "Darzja... I... please don't let them take my wing," she moaned weakly.

I wished I could tell her to be strong. That everything was going to be all right. I even thought about outright lying to her and telling her that she would be getting a brand new wing. Yet I couldn't.

The priest came up to me again.

"I'm sorry that I have to ask this of you Darzja, but would you please keep your friend still while we perform the amputation?" the priest whispered. I could only nod numbly; they were severely short of staff, and besides it was only right that at the very least, Iskierka had somebody to cry against as the grisly deed was done.

"N-nno!! Make them stop!! Please!! No!!!" begged Iskierka, sensing the saw approach her joint. She vainly attempted to thrash and kick the priests away from her, and it took all my power and discipline to keep her still, rather than to stop them.

"I'm sorry Iskierka..." I murmured, placing my larger body over her and keeping her pinned. The next moment, the entire chamber echoed with an ungodly scream of incoherent despair, her tears pouring out in rivers, yet the sound that would give me nightmares for the rest of my life was that awful scraping sound, of flesh and bone being rended so unceremoniously. I wanted to close my eyes, but found that I couldn't, and I watched as they slowly and agonizingly ripped through her bone, her blood pour out in a grisly display, splattering the priests and most of my body. The whole while, Iskierka writhed and kicked underneath me, her hearts beating with fear and panic.

The whole operation lasted less than a minute, yet it had seemed to have lasted forever. Finally, mercifully, the amputation was over, as the priests whisked the broken wing away, setting it to a corner of he chamber along with a three others that had been amputated earlier that night, before rubbing the wound clean with alcohol, stopped the bleeding and bandaged it tightly. Beneath me, Iskierka whimpered softly and helplessly, her eyes tightly shut.

"Its all over Iskierka. Everythings going to be all right..." I assured, whispering in her ears. She didn't sound too reassured, as she could not have mistaken the quavering and fear in my own voice. Iskierka let out a few shuddering breaths, before collapsing unconscious in exhaustion.

I gazed about the chamber, suddenly finding the chamber too confining. I rushed outside and took a few shuddering breaths, my thoughts scrambling over all the horror I had seen today. All the dead humanoids. The city in ruins. The orphans, crying in fear. Blaze gone missing. Iskierka losing her wing... So I angled my head into the sky and screamed.

"Darzja..." said a voice. I curved around to face Lady Ramoth.

"Please come back inside would you?" she said. Yet her voice lacked the usual sharp sting to it, but rather it seemed forlorn and sympathetic. I tried to hide my tears from her, yet I could not.

I placed my head against the base of her neck, allowing her to stroke my head like she had when I was a hatchling.

"Its...its not fair..." was all I could sputter out. "S-she didn't deserve this..."

"Were life fair, it would have been I to have given my wing, that the victims should be the old rather than the young. If life were fair, Iskierka would have been born with a mother and father to love her. Yet, that is not the way of the world. We must deal with the hand that we were dealt with, not the one that we would have liked to have. Because above all else, life must move on my child..." said Ramoth.

I sniffled back. Ramoth, in her long centuries of life, must have seen an entire lifetime worth of sadness and misfortune, yet she always seemed to carry on, and remain just as strict and disciplined as she always was.

"Now then, lets come back inside Darzja, I'm sure you could use some rest..." she cried. I did come back inside. I gave a glance toward Iskierka, and shook my head for a moment. Thankfully, all the orphans were already asleep, and did not have to hear the surgeons carve out Iskierka's wing. That is, everyone except Ophelia. She was curled up into a ball, as if wishing she could return to the comfort of the egg shell, her bloodshot eyes glazed, seeing, but not seeing. As the only one of the four older orphans to escape completely unfazed, I knew she was blaming herself; that somehow she too should have gone missing or had her wing amputated.

"I must look so pathetic..." she murmured, "Curled up in a corner instead of helping out like you are..."

"Ophelia..." I cried, "Please don't blame yourself for what happened..."

"But...but...but" she stammered.

"Look Ophelia. Even if you think you were to blame, it doesn't matter anymore. Iskierka lost her wing, Blaze has gone missing, and after tomorrow, I'm going to be gone for good. That means you have to be the one to take care of everybody now..."

"M-me?" she stammered. "B-but I'm not strong like you. I get scared easily..."

I let out a sigh, "Perhaps, so, yet at the very least, you have to pretend to act like you're strong and brave for the younger ones, for Iskierka."

Ophelia shifted her gaze up. "I suppose when you put it that way I don't have a choice now do I? Lady Ramoth can't be everywhere can she? I know I'm not a good leader like you, but I'll definitely won't let the others down, not without giving it my all..."

I gave her a hug, "That's all I could ever want out of my friends. I knew I could count on you..."

And thus, I felt a little less worried, knowing that I would be able to leave the orphanage and that they were in capable claws. Thus, I was finally able to sleep...
114121111111.title: Broken wings

1141211111111.content:
When I awoke, the side of my neck was a mass of blisters that burned as if the fire were still upon me. I tried not to cry out, however, because I remembered that some dragons had received much more severe and irreparable hurts than a simple burn yesterday. Iskierka…

I wanted to go and comfort her, but at the same time, I was afraid to see her, afraid to see her disfigurement. My weakness sickened me, but I could not will the feelings away. I got up gingerly as I could because the warm bodies of young dragons surrounded me on three sides were we’d bunked down in the hallway. I stepped over tails and wings and Ophelia’s outstretched neck as I made my way to the mess hall; I was starving for all of the events yesterday.

First, though, I stopped in the main living area where injured adult dragons were sleeping as closely together as their natural alignments and injuries allowed. I noticed the unconscious segregation, metallics in that corner, fire drakes smoking near the landing, the two venomers were shunted to the side, but given the most space of all. My hearts skipped a beat as I saw a great Sky-swallower reclining against the length of a whole wall; in his generosity, he let smaller dragons rest on his body so he would not occupy as much space. I thought it might be Raj, but a quick sniff informed me it was a stranger. I asked a priest, now in fresh white robes, for more poultice for my neck. The bald human, engraved with a dragon emblem that stretched from the crown of his head to his forehead smiled and went to retrieve it. The priesthood of the Dragon Cult was mainly composed of humans – primarily because the faith offered the shortest lived species of all eventual reincarnation as a proud dragon – and they were some of the most humble and compassionate humanoids I’d ever met. It was comfortable having humanoids around who shared the draconic faith in our Ancestors. The man obliged me by applying the smelly green paste with his soft hands.

When I was treated, he said, “Iskierka is doing well, Darzhja. But she is still sleeping with the other intensive cares and Lady Ramoth has asked you not to disturb her or the others.”

I nodded and lifted myself from the floor, feeling relieved that I would not have to confront the golden dragoness yet. She would ask me questions I had no answer for.


In the mess hall, I found only a thin beef stew available. The priests were stretching the meat store to its limit it seemed. I quaffed down the watery soup like it was my last meal. I shouldn’t have expected more. Dragons usually took but one meal a day and typically in the evening; the better to digest during the night. I returned my wooden bowl, a cauldron for the dish washing team, and let out a sigh. Perhaps it was for the best, a heavier meal would only make me turgid and I felt that I was going to be flying a lot today. Blaze remained missing – the priest I’d spoken to had confirmed his absence – and I wanted to see if Raj had found any actual information beyond the crazy rumors being tossed around the orphanage.

I was about to leave out the side entrance so I wouldn't disturb the sleeping dragons when I head Lady Ramoth shout, “No! You can’t have them!”

The part of me that was still a hatchling could not resist padding quietly down the hallway to eavesdrop. I saw Lady Ramoth’s large, green scaled figure silhouetted in the light of the door in front of her. It was the door leading to the priests’ dormitories, the humanoid half of the compound, across their meditation garden. It was also the primary way in which humanoids entered and left the orphanage as the stairs outside were cut too large for bipeds. In between her legs, I could see two richly dresses humanoids. One was an arrogant looking elf in flowing robes, the other a pale green skinned orc with black powder burns permanently scarring the side of his wide face.

The elf said, “It is the right of the Alchemists’ Guild and the Circle of Magi to claim the bodies of fallen dragons. You would defy the law?”

The more even tempered orc placed a meaty hand on his companion’s shoulder, taking a step forward before the towering green dragoness. “You can rest assured that the deceased’s families will be well compensated. Very well, as you know the value of dragon tissues and bones.”

Lady Ramoth appeared to keep an even temper in front of the two delegates, but I saw her tail lash in the hallway, inadvertently slamming it against the wall and sending stone flakes flying. Her voice was harsh, but controlled. “Most of these dragons don’t have families and you know it. We took in those the hospitals turned away when they began to fill up. You won’t have to pay a penny for their corpses.”

The elf from the Circle of Magi inclined his head as if to say that was the point. The orc said, “Lady… Ramoth. This is a desperate time for the city. Our magical and alchemical component stores are nearly running dry with every officer running about casing levitating spells on rubble and every citizen seemingly in need of bandaging and repairing. You know as well as I that dragon parts supply over half of the city’s demand for magical power.”

The mistress of the orphanage cocked her head. I shrunk into the shadows at the end of the hallway as she turned her head sideways. “We lost twelve dragons last night and twice that number are injured. Some will never be able to fly again. And you wish to come here and disturb the orphans and the injured before the bodies of their comrades are even cool?”

The orc paled even more and rubbed a hand through his grey strands of hair. The elf stood like stone. “It is necessary that we begin the collection process as soon as possible. Dragon blood will spoil in 18 hours after death and if it is not collected and removed, all of the other organs will be lost as well.”

“Then I will send a courier to you both when you may come to collect the bones after the proper rites have been observed.” Said the Lady with a tone of finality

While the mage looked as though he’d been slapped, the orc took a step forward. He spoke so quietly that I could barely hear him. “I know that the orphanage is close to bursting at the seems. Can you imagine what it will be like with the new wave of orphaned hatchlings that is sure to come as a result of the tragedy yesterday? I can see to it that our two guilds make a generous donation to your organization if we could remove the bodies.”

“Dar’zhul! You can’t-“ started the elf, but the orc silenced him with a fang-toothed snarl.

“I can and you will as well, Elandrias. The blood money has to go somewhere. It may as well serve living orphans rather than fill the guilds’ coffers.” The alchemist lifted his head to Lady Ramoth, “What say you, Lady?”

Lady Ramoth’s face was more twisted with emotion than I’d ever seen it. She turned away from the two representatives and wiped an eye with the edge of her wing. Then she took a deep breath and puffed out her chest, though overall, she seemed diminished. “Do your work quickly and begone. I will eat anyone who lets the children see what you are doing.”

The Lady said the last with a matter of factness that left the two gaping. The elf took a step forward, as if to protest further, but his partner put a hand on the elf’s slighter chest and stopped him. The orc bowed low before Lady Ramoth. “These are grim, desperate times, M’lady.”

Lady Ramoth said nothing and the two turned to go. I scrambled to escape the small hallway as Lady Ramoth carefully turned herself about in the narrow space. Her eyes came forward…
1141211111111.title: Blood Money

choices: The Holy Knights were actively recruiting for new members
He's willing to offer a job and a place to stay
11412111111111.content:
If there was one thing she had been adept at over the years, it was knowing when and where unruly hatchlings were hiding and listening in.

"You heard what transpired here did you not?" said Lady Ramoth.

"Yes my Lady..." I answered.

Her gaze flashed back toward the elf and the orc, as they call forth the laborers to gather the body parts of the dead. The rage and disdain were all too apparent.

"Look at those fiends skulk about," she hissed, "Profiteering from this horrendous tragedy. Have they no sense of morals and sanctity for the dead?"

I couldn't help but agree, especially when I watched a pair of humanoids scoop up Iskierka's distended wing and place it in a box as if it were a product to be bought and sold on the market. That's what we were to those people; products. Considering the number of dragons that had died yesterday, the guild would certainly have no shortage of raw material. Come to think of it, the Alchemists Guild was one of the few buildings to escape the tragedy undamaged... I hoped that this wasn't any sort of conspiracy, as Lady Ramoth seemed to be implying, or else New Alveri had a far worse problem on its hands than the attack itself.

Lady Ramoth let out a sigh; it was her method of regaining her composure, "Never mind that. Some things cannot be helped..."

I then looked about the orphanage again; they would need people to help out with all the wounded, and take care of all the little ones that were coming in. "Lady Ramoth. If you need me to stay to help the staff,"

"Darzja, as much as I would like you to stay to help care for the wounded, I sense that you would do far more good for all of us elsewhere," she said. "Your future lies in bigger and better things young dragoness. Yet before you leave, at least you should say goodbye to the orphans..."

With that, I made my tearful goodbye to the orphanage, this time for good. Of course, they, and in particular, the younger ones, pleaded for me to stay. I was like their second mother to them. I wished I could say that I had the courage to visit Iskierka and say goodbye to her, yet I still found myself unable to bring myself to see her in such a state. There would be no going back for me now.

That morning, I made my way through the city streets. Most of the fires had been contained, but only now were the cleanup crews beginning to clear out the devastation.

I headed back to look for Kaj, and found his unmistakable figure present at the gate. He was currently overseeing one of the huge tent cities that had sprung up outside the city walls; comprised of the humanoid refugees whose homes had been destroyed during the attack. I had the feeling that many of them would be stuck living like that for a long while...

"Darjza, I'm glad you're all right," said Kaj, "How are things at the orphanage?"

I took a moment to gather myself, before explaining to Kaj what had happened during the previous night; how Blaze had gone missing, Iskierka losing her wing and the other occurrences of that night.

"I'm sorry to hear about that..." he answered.

"Its...its...."

I shook my head to gather myself, before switching subjects, "Have you heard of any information about who might behind the attack?" I asked.

"Truthfully, you probably know as much about it as I. The Holy Knights have not given out any official statement as to who might have been behind the attacks. For instance, if they were to accuse one an orcish terrorist group without any solid evidence behind it, then the general public will direct their rage unfairly on orc population as a whole, and then we'd have an even worse problem on our claws. Furthermore, no group has claimed resonsibility for the attack either, and they would have done so by now. All we can do right now is keep New Alveri from degenerating into chaos and helping its residents rebuild their lives," said Kaj.

I"So, it would seem that nobody has any clue as to who might have orchestrated the attack..." I growled. I quickly told Kaj about the mage circle and the alchemists guild, and Lady Ramoths implicit suspicions about them.

"I've heard several rumors of the sort already this morning involving some type of conspiracy between the mage guild and the alchemists for more dragon parts. Of course, the mage guild in particular is not well liked by the draconic population even during the best of times, considering that they use our body parts for their various enchantments, and its a knee jerk reaction that blame would be shifted onto them. Besides, I very doubt that even they would go to such lengths for fresh supplies. You must remember that for every dragon killed during the attack, about one hundred humanoids also perished, so whoever did this, did so without regard to whether one was a dragon or not," said Kaj.

"Yes, I know...its just when I saw that elf stuff Iskierka's wing into a box, I just felt so..."

I clenched my teeth tightly, but forced myself to calm down.

"Again, I'm sorry that I wasn't able to tell you more."

"That's all right, its just good that I was able to speak with you..."

Kaj smiled for a moment.

"Anyhow Darzja, you might be interested to learn that...
11412111111111.title: Who'd done it?

choices: Try to find a Knight and ask.
114121111111111.content:
‘That’s certainly some news!’ I thought with excitement. The Holy Knights of Nod had not actively recruited new members for over four centuries, not since the great troll rebellions. I fluttered my wings with elation. “Truly Kaj?!” I asked.

The big dragon smiled and inclined his head. “Yes. They are accepting applications from any citizen, but they tell me that the testing process is intensely difficult.”

I didn’t care what I had to do. I’d fly over the ocean itself to become a Holy Knight. This was a once in a lifetime opportunity since dragons were generally barred from joining due to the long lives of the existing Knights and even their partners’ positions were typically handed down generation to generation or otherwise chosen internally. I was already spreading my bronze wings. I paused to ask, “Kaj, do you think you could put in a good word for me?”

Kaj snorted, “I doubt a Knight would think much of what a civilian militia guard would have to say, but I can’t today anyway, Darzhja. I’m too busy organizing the refugees on this side of the city. Sorry.” The large dragon wore a sad look on his face.

I uplifted a wing and placed it on his shoulder. I smiled, “I will be a Knight, Kaj. And I’ll find out who cost Iskierka her wing and tear them apart piece by piece.”

Kaj reached around with his tail and pushed me forward. “I know you will, now go! They’re accepting applicants at the main gate. Remember to…”

I couldn’t hear the rest of his statement because I was already drifting away on a strong easterly breeze. As I rose over the city walls and the devastation of the trade district spread out ahead of me, however, I realized I hadn’t asked Raj where exactly to go…
114121111111111.title: High Hopes

choices: I was in a dungeon cell
1141211111111111.content:
So I shortly found myself standing where I had been just yesterday morning, yet it seemed like a lifetime ago. Before, the Temple had seemed pristine, magnificent and inert, a monument to the symbolic strength of New Alveri and the tenacity of her people. Now, I realized that all of those landings and buttresses were more than symbolic. The Temple had become a seething hive of dragons flying in and out and all around, carrying passengers, messages and shipments to and fro. Horses and other magicked conveyances rushed back and forth through the main gate. Several statues had tumbled to the ground and shattered and the lawn was a mess with dragon footprints, but no one seemed to mind. The Temple had become alive in the wake of the destruction of yesterday.

In front of me and in between the bi-directional flows of foot traffic was a familiar face. The guard who had trounced me soundly yesterday looked no less confident and grim today as he watched me approach slowly on foot.

“And who told you this rubbish?” he said when I’d explained why I was there.

I frowned, I knew Kaj wouldn’t have lied to me, not about this. “A very good friend of mine.” I said heatedly. “I’d trust him with my life and he told me the Knights were recruiting new members.”

“The Holy Knights don’t recruit new members.” The guard intoned as if the words were written on a stone plaque somewhere; which they may have been, I realized.

‘This has to be some sort of test.’ I thought desperately. I took an aggressive posture and raised my tail. “You lie! I’ve been dreaming about this my entire life and I’m not going to let you stop me! I’m going into that temple!”

The armored guard puffed out his chest and cockily angled his head. “Is that so, hatchling? Do you need another lesson so soon?”

I growled and waved my tail. The pedestrians to either side of us sudden gave us a wide berth. Inside, however, I was so afraid. Afraid because I wasn’t as strong as I was even yesterday for my raw throat and burned neck and afraid that Kaj was wrong and Lady Ramoth was wrong and that I didn’t really have a future. I was afraid that Iskierka had lost her wing for nothing. But I had to let my fears and doubts go. I would be a Knight and all that stood between me and my destiny was the guard standing on the bridge. "I'm not a hatching!" I cried as I rushed forward.

The guard reacted as quickly as he had yesterday, but this time I was expecting a counter. I dodged his tail and leapt into the air, letting my tail collide into his armored flank. I had no time to feel good about actually hitting him, however as he was right on my tail behind me, much faster than Kaj; maybe faster than me despite the armor. I used my height advantage before he overtook me. I whipped at his head with my tail, but he dodged easily and snapped at it so I was forced on the defensive to keep his teeth from sinking into my tail. He continued to gain on me as we both rose higher before the massive gilded Temple.

I remembered my fight yesterday with Kaj, realizing that he was going to catch me. I prayed to my Ancestors and hauled myself straight up. I stalled and fell right as the guard was coming up behind me. The top of his helmet hit my belly and I scratched at his neck with my hindlegs. I tried to stop him biting my underbelly by reaching down with my forelegs, but he grabbed one of them instead and bit down hard. I felt his fangs break through the scales. He was flapping his wings frantically under my weight, but we were still descending. He pulled my foreleg and I slid forward over his head. Before I fell into space, I reached out with my wings, blinding him. My hind legs still around his neck, I came around towards his armored belly and hugged his waist tight, still kicking with my clawed feet against his head and neck. I didn’t even try to bite through the silver enchanted metal, but I did sink my teeth into his unprotected haunch. The momentum of my fall turned the guard face down. Now we were really falling, tumbling around and around. He pushed and shoved and I stubbornly refused to let go, I bit him again and again where ever I saw scale, not caring how he scratched and bit my flanks and hindquarters. I was mad with battlerage, sinking my claws into chainmail, ripping it away and biting whatever was underneath. My teeth sank into something soft and the guard howled like a demon. I’d just realized what I’d done when we crashed into the moat. I sank…

When I next awoke…
1141211111111111.title: Denied Again

11412111111111112.content:
I woke up in a very cold, dank place. My mind spun, as I gazed about. The first thing I noticed was a huge set of bars blocking my path out. Secondly, there was a rather faint, but prevalent mildewy smell. I rose to my feet and tried to move, when I felt something hold me back. A large chain tightly wrapped around my back leg, attached to a giant iron ball. Furthermore, my jaw was muzzled with another metal device.

I was in a dungeon!! By the Great Ancestors, why a dungeon of all places!! Immediately, my first impulse was to snap at the chains that bound me, yet the tough metal defied my efforts. I wanted to cry. I had sought to gain entry into the Holy Knights, only to end up in a dungeon, possibly for the rest of my life.

"Give it up, you're not going to escape," said a voice.

Only then did I notice a guard perched in front of my cell. In fact, it was the very same guard that had denied me entrance twice now. I could make out a bandage wrapped around the midway point of his tail, the spot I had bitten before we both had tumbled into the moat. Yet all I could do was to glare at the dragon hatefully. After about an hour of this, I turned away from his gaze for a while, trying to pretend he wasn't there, yet the guard continued to watch me intently, he never even moved. It was both irritating and rather creepy, and honestly made me feel uncomfortably vulnerable.

"Do you enjoy seeing me like this?" I snarled at the guard.

The guard stepped forward into the light. Without his mask and his thick armor, I couldn't help but admit that the young bronze dragon was actually pretty good looking, and quite muscular, so much so it actually made me pause for a moment. That only served to make it even worse than it already was.

"As a matter of fact. Yes, I do rather enjoy seeing you languishing in your cell, and if my superiors decided that they'd throw away the key to keep feral amazons like you away from civilized society, I'd be a rather happy dragon indeed" he answered haughtily. I couldn't tell if he was being facetious or not about the first part, or if he was fulfilling some type of control fantasy.

"I'm not feral," I snapped. "And I have a name!! Its Darzhja and don't you forget it!!"

The guard huffed, folding his wings against his back.

"What is your name?" I said through clenched teeth.

"And why should I tell you that prisoner?" he replied.

"What are you so afraid of that you cannot give me your name?" I replied. The guard huffed, "I suppose you're going to be annoying me all night about it, so I shall give you my name. I am Fangorn of the Ironwings, Holy Knight of the Fifth Order."

"Fangorn?" I snorted, and I couldn't help but chuckle a little bit. He frowned.

"Why would a Holy Knight, albeit a low ranked one, be given the duty of watching over me?" I wondered. "Did you get demoted perhaps?"

The Knight's eyes narrowed, which likely signified a yes. "Trust me, this was not my idea. The wound you gave me was not inconsiderable, and sidelined me from my usual duties, and considering how unstable of mind you are, it was deemed that you should be watched in a secure location before your fate is ultimately decided," he answered. At the very least, it meant I wouldn't be spending the rest of my life in the dungeon. Or at least I hoped that was the case.

"Tell me, Darzja," he asked, scorn mixed with a fair amount of curiosity, "Why is it you want to become a Holy Knight so badly?"

"Why do you care?" I snorted back.

"Would you rather me tell my superior that you attacked me based on the reasoning that you were of frenzied mind?" Fangorn replied, cocking his head sideways.

"At first, I wanted to become a Knight so I would be able to fight all the time. Yet when the attack came.... I saw my friends get hurt. Iskierka lost her wing!! Blaze went missing!! I don't want anything like that ever to happen again, and by becoming a Knight I could protect them, give the other hatchlings at the orphanage hope!!" I cried out.

"Is that so? I have to admit that I find your resolve admirable, yet make no mistake I do not find you Holy Knight material...

"So, you mean to tell me that I've been wasting my time!!" I retorted, interrupting him. "Is it because I wasn't born to some ancient noble lineage, or that...that..."

"Enough Darzhja... I don't need to hear your tantrum about how deprived you've been all your life and that I should be feeling sorry enough for you that I would let you join the knights out of charity. I heard your reasons for wanting to become a Holy Knight and shall put them into consideration..." he responded. I wanted to slash him so badly; and he was so tantalizingly close. Then, he smiled; as if he wanted me to try. I knew at this point it was useless and frankly quite degrading to continue to rage against this recalcitrant stiff. Thus, I curled up and glared at the bronze dragon who had given me so much grief and humiliation.

"I hate you so much..." I growled.

"Trust me, the feeling is mutual," responded Fangorn, continuing to keep his expression impassive.

The next moment, a dragon-shaped shadow appeared from around the corner...
11412111111111112.title: Dragons and Dungeons

114121111111111122.content:
A grim looking dragon came crawling around the corner. He was missing an eye, and missing a front claw, which meant he walked with an unsightly gait, and had numerous scars all along his body. I tensed up immediately. Was he here to torture me or...or worse?

"Fangorn, is this the one that attacked you at the gate?" said the dragon.

"Yes it is Warden Sydroth," said Fangorn grimly.

"Are you here to tell me that I'll be stuck here forever? I'll get out one day!! I'll get out and I'll become a Knight!!" I began to yell.

"Consider yourself fortunate young one. Apparently there is this Lady Ramoth who is negotiating upon your release," said the Warden.

"L-lady Ramoth!?" I cried out in surprise. I felt both relieved, but also somewhat ashamed that she had to bail me out. By the Ancestors, she was going to be so angry.

"What? You mean the Lady Ramoth?" cried Fangorn.

"How would you know her?" I cried.

Fangorn gave me a look. "What do they teach you at the orphanage? Lady Ramoth was only one of the most famous Holy Knights ever to serve the Kingdom!! You'd never heard of the battle of the Durandal? She and her rider Lessa were the ones who slew the Troll Chieftain Razhan and his beserkers and turned the tide of battle? Or when as an apprentice knight, she rallied the Knights from certain defeat to a miraculous victory during the Makuran invasions?"

"No...that can't be. Lady Ramoth? A Holy Knight?" I cried, shaking my head.

"Believe whatever you want to believe then. The point is the Wardens going to let you out, unless you'd rather stay of course..." replied Fangorn.

I watched as the warden called in a team of humanoids to undo the locks, as Fangorn watched to make sure I wouldn't try to lash out at him, and afterwards follow him out of the dungeon. Yet I was still too much in shock to process this new information that Lady Ramoth was a Knight. Granted, the commoners didn't know that much about the Holy Knights in general, yet if Lady Ramoth had been so famous I figured that I would have at least heard about it. Yet then I remembered, just how long ago it might have been when Ramoth was a Knight. Ramoth had always been the strict, fierce caregiver, never seeming to age one bit. It had never occurred to me to realize that as old as Ramoth was now, there was once a time she was young dragoness like myself, never mind ask what she had done when she was young. I tried to picture it in my mind; Ramoth as a Holy Knight, defeating hordes of Nod's enemies in battle.

By that time, I had been led to the foyer. Lady Ramoth was waiting at the ledge. She spoke to the warden for a moment, and watched him return to his post, before she shot that venemous glare in my direction.

"Darzhja, you should have known better than to do something so utterly reckless!! Do you realize how selfish that is of you, that I would have to leave the orphans and the entire staff in order to bail you out of the dungeon?"

"I'm sorry Lady Ramoth," I replied, keeping my head down.

Ramoth let out a angry sigh. She must have had to pull all sorts of strings in order to get me out of trouble.

"Wait...you are the Lady Ramoth? This cannot be!!" said Fangorn, his expression disbelieving and scornful.

"So, all you see is a senile old crone is that it fledgling? If you are uncertain of my claim, I dare you to hit me as hard as you possibly can!! Come at me as if I were your worst enemy," she challenged. Fangorn froze in place, while Ramoth's gaze remained impassive.

"Go on..."

"I'd perfer not to find out the hard way..." he answered.

"It would seem you are not as much of a fool as I imagined," she responded.

"Lady Ramoth, did you really used to be a Holy Knight?" I asked. Of course, I had seen enough evidence from my surroundings, yet I needed to hear it from her. There was a long silence, as her eyes began to wander for a moment.

"Yes. I was once a Knight. Yet that was a long, long time ago. So long that to the short-lives it would be but myth and legend, so long ago that," she answered. She took a deep breath.

However, her neck instantly snapped back toward Fangorn, "In any case hatchling, I do not appreciate the fact that you belittled Darzhja in such a manner and did not provide her with the information she needed. Would you at least be decent enough to escort her to the Cloister of Trials?" she snapped, seemingly back to her usual demanding self. It seemed to be a deliberate effort to avoid remembering what she once was. Yet at the same time, I couldn't believe how lucky I was, that I would truly get the opportunity to become a Knight!

"Well, yes, but this is assuming that since she'd be bypassing the recruiters that you'd be sponsoring her," replied Fangorn.

"You're really sponsoring me Lady Ramoth!! Thank you so much!!" I cried out in excitement.

"So long as I'm here, I might as well. Besides, I don't have time to drudge through that wretched beuraucratic red-tape the Knights are known for, not at my age," answered Ramoth, trying to appear stoic, but I couldn't help but feel a sense of pride.

"Is she even ready for that trial?" insisted Fangorn.

"If even an addle-brained hatchling like you passed the trial, then I don't think Darzhja would have too much trouble, and you don't seem smart enough to have cheated," answered Ramoth. Fangorn flinched.

"Now, I have my duties back at the orphanage to attend to, now let me be on my way..."

She took off faster than I had ever seen her take off, as if she wanted to escape the Temple, escape her past. Meanwhile, Fangorn breathed a sigh of relief, as if he'd just escaped the eye of a tornado.

"Would you follow me if you would be so kind?" said Fangorn.

"Of course sir Knight..." I replied.

"You enjoy mocking me don't you?" growled Fangorn. "Perhaps you'd like it back in your cell then Darzhja..."

"If you do, I'll make sure to take you with me," I sniffed. Probably a bad idea though. It was more than possible that he had a particular fetish for chained up young dragonesses.

"Lets just go..." he growled.

He took off into the air. I followed close behind, and I got to see the inside of the Holy Temple for the first time. The first thing that struck me was that I had never seen so much green grass before. A river passed down the center of the valley, and I saw numerous dragons and humans interacting together. I searched for the skyscrapers that were characteristic of New Alveri, yet I noticed that all of its structures were built into the very walls of the Temple itself. One would have never guessed that outside the Temple walls, New Alveri had been attacked. Fangorn merely looked stoically forward; he was no doubt used to all this wealth and lavishness, yet to my eyes, it was a draconic paradise, a fantasy world.

"This is no time for sightseeing. Keep up now..." said Fangorn.

I growled back. Arrogant jerk. How did somebody like him become a knight? It had to be bloodlines, that he was born to parents that were already knights and had all the money in the world.

While on the way, a dragon came forth. He was a blue dragon of similar size as Fangorn, and looked to be the same age.

"Huh, never seen you around here before," said the blue dragon.

"I'm Darzhja, I'm here to take the trial..."

"Really? Is that so Fangorn?"

"Yes, as unbelievable as that sounds..." said Fangorn.

"Wait, so this the dragoness that gave you that injury? Really Fangorn? From what I heard from you, one would have thought you'd gone up against some hardened criminal."

I couldn't help but grunt with amusement at Fangorn's expense. Apparently, I wasn't the only one who thought Fangorn an arrogant blowhard.

"Looks can be deceiving with this one Lorath, I must warn you that she has an unfortunate uncontrollable urge to bite people," replied Fangorn.

"Only if they're jerks like you," I snarled back.

"If she's that much trouble I can take her there for you Fangorn," answered Lorath.

Fangorn grunted, "I can take care of it Lorath, you need not worry,"

"Whatever you say. Anyhow Darzja, good luck to you..."

"Thanks, I'll need it..."
114121111111111122.title: An unexpected sponsor

choices: I was led to a chamber to begin the trial
1141211111111111221.content:
I followed Fangorn into a shrine. Like the rest of the buildings within the Grand Temple of the Holy Knights, the structure was built into the very walls of the extinct volcano.

The inside of the chamber resembled the prayer room of the orphanage in many ways. I spotted humanoid priests, professing their faith in the dragon cult. In the center of the circular chamber was a statue of Gyrimond, whose holy manifestation represented the collective will of all the Ancestors who had passed on. Upon its walls were murals of famous Holy Knights and their humanoid partners; the majority of which depicted them in battle against the Kingdom's foes. There was Valinor, the Uniter of the Kingdoms. The Great Sky-Swallower Maximus, who had held back a raging landslide on a mountain pass to allow the villagers below to escape to safety. Yet there was one mural in particular that caught my eye.

It depicted a young green dragoness, fierce, mighty and beautiful in her full battle armor, with her jaw open as if in the process of letting out a fearsome battle roar, and claws ready to strike, wings fully extended as she swooped down upon a horde of amorphous foes. Riding upon the base of her back was a human female in armor, aiming a lance that should have been far to heavy for a human to possibly carry, never mind wield in battle.

Ramoth and Lessa, the Maidens of Victory, the depiction read in draconic. It was absolutely striking and also somewhat eeriee to see an image of Lady Ramoth, when she was no older than myself. Yet that dragon was unmistakably her. What might have been going through her mind, at the time this mural was painted? What aspirations did she have for herself then? I then curved my gaze toward the human female that rode upon her back. I remembered that Dragon Knights frequently formed partnership with their humanoid companions, and I could tell that Ramoth seemed especially close with her partner. Their movements seemed in rhythm and in time with one another, as if they could have read each others thoughts. Knowing that the humanoids had rather short lives, Lessa certainly had to be dead, and it may have been one of the factors that had led her to leave the Knights and start an orphanage. There were so many things about her life that I had not even suspected, and so many things I wanted to know.

An elderly silver dragon approached, clad in priestly robes. It made him look as if he were covered by a large carpet, yet even I knew better not to comment on that and pay respect.

"These walls commemorate those Holy Knights who have gone above and beyond the call of duty, whose feats are celebrated for all time." he said with a sagely voice.

"May I ask though, what has brought you here?"

"I am Darzhja, and I am here to take the Cloister of Trials, Holy Father," I answered. "Lady Ramoth is my sponsor."

The old dragons unfurled his wings slightly, "Ramoth?" the dragon said with surprise, his gaze shifting back toward the mural for a moment, "She has not been heard from ever since she left our order!! Surely you don't mean to play a jest on this old dragon. How would you have come into her acquantence?"

"Lady Ramoth raised me along with all the others at the orphanage at New Alveri. I consider her the closest thing I have to a mother... None of us knew that she was a Holy Knight at one time, and I only found out a little while ago," I answered.

I quickly explained the circumstances in which I made the decision to become a Knight, how Lady Ramoth had bailed me out of the dungeon and had agreed to sponsor me.

"Can you confirm this tale Fangorn?"

"Yes Father Quazios. Lady Ramoth came by personally to the dungeon to bail her out, and I have confidence that all the paperwork is in order as well," answered Fangorn."

"I take your word for it Fangorn, yet if you do not mind, allow me to take a moment to confirm what you have said..." said Quazios. Quazios waved his claw in a slight circle, and a moment later, a scroll materialized. I couldn't help but be amazed at this act of magic, never mind fathom how he had done it. I made my way to the side of the old bishop and read draconic characters depicted on the large leather sheet.

Dear Father Quazios

I know it has been a long time since I ended my association with the Holy Knights, yet know that I am well. After having lost my dear Lessa and my eternal Knight, Lord Mnementh, it took many years of soul searching, until with the aid of the Great Ancestor, I discovered my new purpose in life, providing care and shelter for abandoned hatchlings. I never intended to gain any sort of recognition for my efforts; that I was able to give hope for those who would not have it otherwise gave me all the reward I needed.

Having intended to fully put my past as a Knight behind me, I find it ironic but perhaps fitting that one of the hatchlings I raised in my orphanage would dream of becoming a Knight one day. So here I find myself once again, having come full circle, returning to the order I have devoted the majority of my life towards, to submit this reccommendation.

From the day she arrived at the orphanage, Darzhja has been a clawful for myself and my staff to handle. She is excessively adventurous and daring, and delights in taking part in the most reckless shenanegins imaginable. Keeping an eye on her has been an ordeal as challenging as any opponent I had ever faced in the field of battle. Yet from the beginning, I sensed a strong spirit within her, a willingness to do good, to stand up for others regardless of the circumstances. In many ways, she reminds me of myself when I was that age.

Thus, I declare that I shall give my sponsorship in that Darzhja be allowed to undergo the Cloister of Trials, so that she may prove herself worthy of protecting the denizens of Nod as a Holy Knight. I have full confidence that she will succeed not only as a Holy Knight, but any worthy endeavor she sets her mind toward.

With all regards

Lady Ramoth

"It is a boon to hear from her once again. I say without reservation, that when Lady Ramoth left the Knights, we were diminished. It does my hearts well to know she has found contentment in her life, and that you should take great pride that she speaks so fondly of you," said Quazios. I couldn't help but feel heartened as well. Lady Ramoth had always been extremely strict with us, and especially with me, but I realized that she was only doing it to push us to be the best that we could be, and that she truly cared about us. For a long time, I had bemoaned the fact that I had never known my birth parents, but I realized how truly fortunate I had been.

"The only question to be asked now, Darzhja, is whether you are fully committed to take the trial, come what may?"

"Absolutely. I will take the trial and become a Holy Knight, and if I am successful I will devote my entire life to protect Nod's people and the people I care for," I answered without hesitation. Of course, I had absolutely no idea what would await for me inside, yet there was no turning back now. This was my chance. Failure, was not an option.

"Very well then..."

"Fangorn, would you escort the clergy from the chamber?" asked Quazios. Fangorn nodded, as the priests silently left the chamber.

"Darzhja," said Fangorn, as he headed out. "I bid good luck to you. I am certain that you will succeed."

"Am I hearing things?" I called out in surprise, "What ever happened to 'someone like you can't possibly be holy knight material?"

Fangorn tilted his head away and led out a short grunt, as if he couldn't recall that he'd said anything like that at all.

"Thank you anyhow Fangorn," I answered. Then, more to my surprise, he returned an smile encouragingly, it was the first genuine smile that I'd ever seen from him. Then, he exit the chamber and take off.

I then focused my attention back toward Father Quazios.
1141211111111111221.title: Legacies

11412111111111112212.content:
I stood around the chamber, watching the old dragon. I first thought he was going to lead me to some hidden door, to begin the trial, but then it occurred to me that perhaps the trial had already begun. Only, I didn't have the faintest idea of what I should do!!

"Father Quazios, could you give me a clue?" I asked. My hearts beat nervously, hoping that I hadn't messed things up already.

"You need only ask Darzhja. If one cannot find answers on your own, it is never unwise to seek help," he answered.

"My advice is that you should look toward the Ancestors, and perhaps they may tell you more..." answered Quazios. I tilted my head sideways. Look toward the Ancestors? How was that a clue? Deciphering out riddles and cryptic messages was never my strong suit, yet that was all I had to work with.

"Look to the ancestors? Could you be a bit more specific about what you mean by that?" I asked. Yet when I looked back up, Father Quazios had vanished, leaving me alone in an empty chamber.

Perhaps it was one of the murals? However, that didn't seem likely. Not all the dragons depicted in the murals had passed on to join the Ancestors, Lady Ramoth being chief among them. However, that did not stop me from searching for some type of secret door, of which I found none.

After searching fruitlessly, I was forced to once again think about Quazios' last riddle, Look toward the Ancestors, and perhaps they may tell you more...

It was only then that my gaze shifted toward the towering statue of Gyrimond that dominated the center of the chamber. After all, Gyrimond was the manifestation of the collective will of the Ancestors. Though I doubted that I would find some secret switch, it was all I had, so I crawled forward so that I was facing them. I found myself staring at the statue for a while, half-expecting it to come alive or something like that, yet it did not. Perhaps 'look' was a more metaphorical term?

I searched my mind, trying to think of anything that might have given me a clue. Every week, Lady Ramoth would lead us in prayer for the blessings of the Ancestors. I never could stay still for those silent prayers, as I would often poke the human priests next to me for fun and watch them not react at all. Plus, I always thought that the proper stance one should take while in prayer was rather ridiculous, so I also put myself in strange stances as well. After prayer, Lady Ramoth would always scold me afterwards. She was a deeply religious dragoness, and took exception if anyones piety was seen as lacking. Later on, I behaved a bit better, but I still didn't take the prayers all that seriously. Yet now I knew that Lady Ramoth had once been a Holy Knight, and it obviously stood to reason that a strong faith to the Ancestors was a vital component of the order.

Thus, I closed my eyes and tilted my neck to the sky, pointing my chest forward to bare my soul before the Ancestors, and I prayed. I prayed that they would hear me and for them to guide me on my path, and also prayed that they would forgive me that I had not prayed enough. Most of all, I thanked the Ancestors for already allowing me to come this far, and that I would live my life in the service to others...

So deeply that I prayed that I found myself in a trance. My hearts pounded faster and faster, my breath coming in deep, shuddering pulses. There was a sensation of being pulled forth off my feet, wings unfurling slowly, my mouth slightly open as I let out a soft, high-pitched squeak as I embraced them into my soul. I felt my surroundings whirl and spin, as the Ancestors spirits swirled around me, searching me, becoming one with me.

Darzhja...

The voice came clear and echoing deep within me. The Ancestors, they had spoken!

"I hear you..." I whispered, both enraptured and more than a little frightened.

Will you pledge your soul to us, that your faith will be undying and unquestioned from this point forward?

"You have my soul, and shall devote myself to your will, so when the time should come that my spirit departs from this mortal body, that mine will be worthy to merge with yours in the afterlife to guide those that follow," I answered.

Now, open your eyes my child...

I slowly lowered myself from my stance of prayer, before opening my eyes. I took in a breath. I was no longer in the chamber, but found myself upon a large glowing platform. Beyond the platform was a swirling vortex of purple mist. My eyes widened and I took in a deep breath as I tried to rationalize where I was.

The Dragon Faith spoke of a place known as Convexity, that vague state of purgatory where ones soul was judged by the Ancestors before either moving on to join them, or being cast down to the Powers Below. Thus, it would be inaccurate to say that I was in a tangible place, but rather it was more a state of consciousness.

So much to do...

The voice no longer came from inside my head, but echoed all around the dream world. I gazed about, but could find no discernable point of origin.

So little time...

"Ancestors? Is that you? What do you mean?" I called out.

Are you afraid?

I was a little bit afraid. Yet I forced myself to take a breath and regain my composure.

Then step forward Darzhja, can you do it?

It seemed like a simple enough request, yet my claws seemed strangely heavy. I did step forward, pledging my faith that these were the Ancestors speaking to me and they would not lead me astray.

Great power sleeps within you. If you give it form. It will give you strength...

I stared down at my claws.

Use your power to protect yourself and others...

Suddenly, from scattered points on the perimeter of the platform, glowing pillars of energy burst from the ground. When the glowing ceased, I saw what appeared to be trolls made out of clay, armed with weaponry, armor and war paint of the last Great Troll Rebellions.

There will be times where you'll have to fight... Keep your faith burning strong

I bent downwards into a fighting stance. This was what I knew how to do, and my muscles twitched, ready to pounce. There was always that slight fear, but more so that anticipation that flowed through my body.

I let loose a roar as I leapt forward to slash the first troll manequin, which burst into a mist of energy and then dissapating into the air. I quickly spun around and swiped at another two, and in one motion, swung my tail forward and caught several more. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw what appeared to be a hand axe spin through the air end of end, quickly deflecting it away deftly with my wingtip, before charging forward and slamming into it with my horns.

There was no time to celebrate my victory, as there was another burst of light, revealing more humanoid looking opponents. Wasting no time, I charged forward and dealt with them before they could attempt to attack. No sooner had these been defeated when there was another burst of light. There were more of them, and this time they surrounded me on all sides. I dealt with the small crowd on my back, as the others rushed forward from the other three sides. Noticing how they had gathered into a group, I unleashed a burst of flame, incinerating them into proverbial dust, before mopping up the rest.

"How was that!!" I called out triumphantly.

Not all triumphs will come so easily... To overcome you must push yourself to the limit...

I crouched won and prepared myself for another fight, expecting to see the pillars of light again. However, my feet suddenly came out from under me as the platform I was standing on suddenly shattered like glass as I let out a cry of surprise. I frantically began flapping my wings and steadying myself.

No sooner had I managed to steady myself in flight did I sense the air above me shift. I looked up, to see a large shape approach from above. At the last moment I managed to fold my wings and veer sharply to the right. I curved around to see a dragon shaped opponent. Like the humanoid clay fighters, the dragon had no face and was likely a construct rather than anything that possessed free sentient will.

I curved around to face my opponent, but then out of the corner of my eye I saw more dragon-shaped constructs approach from the swirling mists. Fighting masses of relatively fragile humanoids was one thing, but dragons was another matter all together. They were closing in rapidly. I had to make a decision fast.
11412111111111112212.title: The Trial, Part I

choices: You awake in the Temple Shrine
114121111111111122121.content:
Never being one to turn down a brawl, even when I was at a disadvantage, I looked the the incoming faceless dragons not with fear - well, maybe a little fear, but a little fear is always a good thing - but with a grim certainty and expectation. I pumped my wings, pulling myself higher in the swirling mists of the void surrounding me. "Show me what you can do!" I roared in challenge. And they did.

I was already higher than the one closest to me. Up close, my opponents were not much to look at. They had wings, four claws, a tail and a long neck with a fang filled maw at the end, but everything else was indistinct. The scale color was barely discernible, shifting hues from red to blue to green to black, but always behind a thick layer of grayish haze. They lacked the normal distinguishing features of a dragon, the horns, the eyes, the shape of the snout and the wings. It was almost as if it were merely the hazy memory of a long forgotten dragon opponent. As I swept down towards it, I supposed that could be exactly what it was.

The first one was clearly inexperienced, it realized too late that I had the height advantage. It tried to dive, but I was already on it. I swept in across the dragon's back at an angle, it was a little smaller than me as well. I ripped the wing membranes under me, ahead of the spine with my fore-claws, behind with my hind-legs. I passed in what seemed an instant, leaving the crippled dragon to plunge down into the mists. But there were more, more dragons flapping their way towards me from whatever direction I cared to look.

My wings burned as I pulled myself higher still, but my next two opponents matched my efforts. One was coming straight on, the other maneuvering around to flank me. I roared and charged toward the incoming dragon, claws outstretched. I folded my wings to protect them as I slammed my body into the dragon like a missile. It's wings surrounded me and we began to fall. the momentum of the charge bowled the dragon over backwards, we were belly to belly, spinning head over heels. My neck heart pumped to deal with the g-forces as we grappled, biting and clawing one another. I bashed my skull against the creature and used the split second lapse to pin its forelegs. It struggled, but I was stronger. Using the leverage I had by holding onto it, I lifted my hind-legs and dug my claws into its belly. Something wet and warm came out as I gutted the thing, but felt more like viscous jelly than actual entrails. The creature writhed and went limp; I let it fall.

As the wings came clear of me, I spread my own, swiftly correcting my spinning. But the world had changed. Now instead of a shapeless void, I was in the midst of some unknown mountain range. Stone walls soared all around me and lightning flashed in a stormy black sky. I saw my attacker only due to a fortunate flash. It was diving down at me, so I spun just as he was going to hit me. Instead of hitting my back, he slammed against my chest. I tried to grab it, but it was moving too fast and my claws slid across the scales. I turned to pursue but was assaulted again from the other side. The blow was like a battering ram to my flank; again my attacker did not stay for close combat. Flapping wings filled the night sky and they were all heading for me.

"What am I supposed to do?!" I cried to the formless, seething heavens. I couldn't possibly defeat all of these dragons by myself. Three of the dragons circling me began to dive, I could tell by the way the shape of their wings changed. I did the only thing that I could do. Continuing to flap wearily through the rising mountains around me, the diving dragons adjusted their courses. When they were close enough, I folded my right wing and sent myself careening to the left. The three hurtled by where I just was, opening their wings far below me. But there were more out for my blood, always more and I found it was all that I could do just to avoid their attacks

Bravery is not measured in heads and broken bodies… Only the true warrior understands the value of life…

Everything in me wanted to take the fight back to those dragons, but this was a fight that I clearly could not win. I thought of Ophelia back at the orphanage, now straddled with a responsibility the young dragoness felt she wasn't prepared for. I thought of Blaze, who remained missing, maybe scared and alone someplace, wishing for his family, maybe dead. I thought of Iskierka who would never fly again. They all still needed me, in one way or another. We needed each other. Where each of us had lost our families, we'd built a new one out of the wreckage. They, and Lady Ramoth, and all the other orphans, they were my family. And it was then as I drove myself onward through the cold air, ducking and diving and trying to stay alive, that I realized that the same could be applied to the whole of dragonkind, and perhaps the whole of New Alveri as well. They were my family and they all needed me, just as I needed them. Was this what the knights were talking about when they spoke of their honor and their duty to protect others?

I breathed a deep draught of breath and I was suddenly showered by a thick rain. I felt the drops bouncing off the leather of my wings and they had the nasty side effect of dampening my sense of the air currents above me that I'd been relying on to dodge attacks. "I have to get out of here." I told myself. I dove straight down, racing the droplets on their way to earth. And I did see it below. Spiky protrusions that could have been either rocks or trees rose from the mountainside below. I let myself fall until I was only about a body length above their tops. The dragons no longer dove at me, as a missed attempt would now result in death. I beat my wings furiously to keep aloft, driving myself forward and away from my pursuers. Four dragons were tailing me, the rest seemed to be lost in the mists and the storm.

I blinked my water lids rapidly for the deluge pouring into my face, but I dared not close them completely because I couldn't afford to blur my vision now. I weaved left and right. Now sinking below the tops of the spikes, then rising. My pursuers followed me with the intent of the damned. I was getting tired and there seemed no relief in sight. I wasn't strong enough.

Trust in one's friends is the truest form of strength...

And it was then that I saw three dragons approaching in front of me, one red, one gold and one green. What shocked me more than seeing my three best friends suddenly appear was seeing Iskierka with her wing strong and restored. Though I was tired and beaten, I wanted to cry with joy. I turned and rose with my comrades, each of us facing an attacker head on. Blaze, if not as good a fighter as I was, was certainly flashier. The young fire-lord caught hold of his opponent's claws and before they could begin to grapple in full, spewed gallons and gallons of burning, molten death onto his opponent's chest, neck and face. The display illuminated the entire area with a magnesium intensity as the dragon fell like a flare. I had crashed into my attacker at an upward angle. I pumped my wings, continuing upward and I jumped higher when I got my hind legs on its shoulders. I wrapped my tail around the dragon's neck and slit its throat as I pulled myself past with the edge of my serrated arrowhead; again, a dark jellied liquid poured out, like liquified dust.

To either side, I saw Ophelia and Iskierka trading blows with their opponents, circling far and coming together again in brief, but furious attacks. I looked to Blaze just a little below me. He nodded and angled off to help Ophelia. I turned to Iskeirka.

Before I could reach her, however, the grey dragon rushed her and bit deeply into her left wing. She screamed the same scream I'd heard when they'd sawed off her wing in the orphanage. Watching it happen again felt like dying. It was my fault... again.

Guilt is as deadly a poison to the soul as Hate... One must learn to forgive, not only others, but oneself...

I couldn't believe what I was seeing. "Not again. Not again!!" I howled, winging my way to the gold dragon. Her mangled wing fluttered uselessly in the air as she fell. The one who'd maimed her floated smugly in the air and began to turn towards me. Fire exploded somewhere behind me, and illuminated the grey dragon's face. Except he wasn't grey anymore, he was black now and he did have a face. A face that I had never seen before, or at least I didn't think I'd seen. He smiled cruelly, seeming to grow to incredible size. Dragon blood dripped from his claws though I hadn't seen him rip into Iskierka. 'Who are you?' I asked silently

Rather than face the enormous menace, I dove for Iskierka who was spinning toward the ground. The black dragon was coming down on top of me, his wings spreading to obscure the sky. The ground raced towards me, but I followed the gold dragon heedlessly. I grabbed hold of her about the waist just under the wing membrane. But too late, the ground was too near. My wings strained with the effort to slow us, but it was not enough. Behind me the black dragon laughed, so large he was more of a world than a dragon. The ground rushed forward to meet us, black against black. I cared about nothing except for holding on to Iskierka. I prayed.
114121111111111122121.title: The Trials pt II

1141211111111111221211.content:
I woke up, gazing about in confusion. I found myself in the middle of destroyed city of New Alveri. The sky exploded with lightning, while in the backdrop to the darkness and chaos, powerful vortexes sucked in the broken rubble of the city I knew into the abyss. Before me, was that giant black dragon loomed over me, oozzing dark energy. Yet the characteristic that chilled me to the bone was the fact it possessed but one good wing, the other broken and shattered; exactly how Iskierka's had been. The black dragon had consumed Iskierka, I realized, and now it was vengeful, hateful, despairing.

"Ancestors!! Help me!!" I called out. There was no response.

They cannot hear you here. They are deaf to you... Shadow Iskierka responded.

"W-what?"

Pray to them however much you want, for they have abandoned you. So prepare yourself to the abyss!! the shadow dragon snarled, Iskierka's voice interposed with a deeper, more sinister one.

My hearts sank with panic, as I fumbled for words, words that could express how sorry I was for the loss of her wing, finding none. I struggled to stay on my feet, as a horrible sense of shame and helplessness pervaded over my soul.

Focus Darzhja!! Focus!! I told myself. This was part of the test. I had to defeat this terrible foe, by the Ancestors, before I could move on.

"Y-you'll pay for that!!" I shouted, "For what you did to Iskierka!!"

Struggling to hold the rising tide of panic in check, I leapt forward toward the monstrocity. It seemed to take an eternity to close the distance, as if I was flying directly into a headwing, and indeed the closer I got Shadow Iskierka seemed to loom larger and larger. I didn't have any illusions that I'd be able to do much damage to it, yet I knew I had to at least try. I reared back to strike, and then found myself blown backwards by an invisible barrier.

My vision went red as I found myself careening back across the way I came, crashing through broken remnants of buildings and landing awkwardly on my side. I rushed forward again, only to found myself being thrown back again, and again. As I fought, images of Iskierka buried beneath the rubble, hearing her cry out and pain in despair, played out in an endless loop, sapping my resolve. No matter what I did, nothing seemed to be able to hurt it. In fact, its evil only seemed to grow more and more virulent, while I got weaker and weaker.

In the end, I collapsed out of exhaution, gazing up at Shadow Iskierka's despairing screech. Every bone and muscle in my body ached, and I spat out blood. Blood, how could I spit out blood? This was only a dream was it? I was really in the Temple!! Wasn't I? Wasn't this only a test?

I could no longer be sure now. What I did know was that I was trapped, helpless before this Shadow Iskierka, born out of my own guilt and despair.

You were the one who could not save me... Its your fault!! Shadow Iskierka responded.

"Iskierka!! Please!! Stop this!!" I called out desperately, hoping that the kind, quiet dragoness I had known all my life was still there.

Why should I?

"Because you're not like this!! You're my friend!!" I begged, hoping it would listen.

Friend? it scoffed, I always hated you Darzhja, your cocky self-confidence, your recklessness and how you tried to prove that you were better than anybody else...

I suddenly felt sad that she would say something like that. Yet I was sad not of the fault she was accusing me of, but that Iskierka would fall into such a dark pit of despair through the fault she attributed to me. I would not see that happen to her, no matter what.

"Maybe I am a lot of those things. I've done a lot of things that have gotten hurt, and maybe I'm the one who should have lost my wing instead of you. Yet this didn't turn out that way.... Sometimes...life isn't fair. If that means that I am the one you must hate for the rest of my life..."

"Then...I'm all right with that. I'll still do everything I can to protect you, and would give my life to protect yours if I must.
