Maybe I won't ever fully get over what happened, but I don't want the rest of your life to be a sad one. I know things won't be the same as they once were, before all this happened, but at the very lease, I hope that we can be friends again," I answered.

There was a pregnant pause. Its movements began to slow. Then, the Shadow quivered, as if in an immense amount of pain, before beams of white energy began breaking out all over its body. Soon, the Shadow was completely engulfed by the light. I turned away from the light blinding me.

I forgive you Darzhja... came Iskierka's voice in my mind.

With those simple words, I felt a huge weight lift from my soul.

When the light cleared, I found myself...
1141211111111111221211.title: The Trials, Part III

choices: Henceforth, you will be a Holy Knight
You will have to undergo further trials...
11412111111111112212111.content:
I found myself once more upon a levatating platform, where I had begun my test.

There will be times when you walk upon the valley of the shadow of death, and within the darkness our voices become dim. Keep your light burning strong, and you will see it through...

I nodded in relief. The Ancestors hadn't abandoned me after all, not that I should have doubted them in the first place.

Now, you will encounter our servant, the Chronicler. He has watched your journey, and through him, will judge whether you shall become the instruments of our will upon the mortal realm.

A glowing rune appeared at the center of the platform. I walked forward and stood at the center. At first, nothing happened. It didn't take me long to remember the prayer I had made to the ancestors within the shrine, that had taken me to Convexity in the first place. Perhaps the rune worked in a similar manner?

Thus, I twisted my neck up into the sky and prayed, allowing the spirits of my Ancestors to peer into my spirit. I prayed that I would be able to reconsile with Iskierka when I returned to the mortal realm, prayed that I would be found worthy by the Ancestors and thankful for all they had given me.

Once again, there was that odd feeling of being swept off my claws, spinning out of control with no knowledge of where I'd end up in. When the spinning stopped, I opened my eyes. I found myself standing upon a pedastal, glowing with a bronze light, mirroring the color of my scales. Torches hung suspended as if by magic all around the chamber, and surrounding me were rows upon rows of books. Directly in front of me was a large, grey dragon of unidentifiable element.

For a long time, I could only stare into the ancient dragons features, transfixed and feeling almost unworthy that I was in the presence of an individual directly chosen by the Ancestors themselves.

"Umm.... hello?" I asked, cocking my neck sideways.

"I greet you young one. I am the Chronicler, chosen by the Great Ancestors above to uphold the integrity of Convexity, allowing those who have not yet passed on to venture inside," he declared.

"I'm also the one who will evaluate you as a candidate for the Holy Knights," he said. The informality that he addressed me with in his second statement took my breath away for a moment. It also put me a little bit more at ease.

A thousand different questions bounced around my head. Here before me was a dragon who was ancient beyond reckoning, so ancient that he might have known Gyrimond himself!! So of course, I had to ask a fairly silly one.

"What's with all the books on the walls?" I asked, gazing about curiously.

"Part of my duties as the Chronicler, is to keep a record of our people; every dragon from the very first until the very last. You see these records as books, as it is the most efficient way mortals can rationalize this realm. Yet unlike the books in your mortal realm, these books are constantly being written and re-written, and contain nearly infinite possibilities of events that have yet to have occurred, of dragons yet unborn."

The Chronicler pulled out a book and placed it upon a pedastal, "So, you are Darzhja. You have lived 73 cycles, having had no knowledge of your birth parents, and raised in an orphanage, whereupon you have made the decision to join the Holy Knights."

"Wait, so you know everything about me in this book? Like who sired me, how exactly I ended up in the orphanage, things that would otherwise be unknown?" I asked.

"I do in fact, yet if I told you, then I'm afraid that I could not allow you to return to the mortal realm," he answered. He didn't necessarily sound threatening, but rather as a matter of fact.

I shrugged, "I figured as such."

"Anyhow, allow me to ask you a few quick questions. What is most important to you?" asked the Chronicler.

"Why do you ask? Don't you already know?" I wondered.

"Yes, but I would like to hear it anyhow, if only to appease the fancies of this old wyrm. Don't make the answers long winded, short and to the point," the Chronicler answered, deftly flourishing his ink brush in his claws.

"My friends and family are the most important," I answered.

"Really?" he replied. He scribbled something in his book, which momentarily glowed.

"Moving on, what is it you fear the most?" he continued.

I immediately pictured Iskierka having her wing removed, how helpless I felt that I was able to do nothing to prevent it from happening.

"That I would be unable to protect those I love. Being helpless in the face of evil." I answered.

"I see. Yet what do you ultimately want out of your life?"

Another vague question, one that I could have spent ages contemplating.

"Hmmm... something... that'd I'd want out of my life... is that through my efforts in the Knights I can help create and preserve a safe world for everyone to live in. As for what I want for myself... perhaps a mate one day, or being able to fight for fun once and a while rather than to protect the kingdom all the time, I'd like a bit of fame and I wouldn't mind a mural detailing my exploits, but I don't want it to get to my head."

"Interesting. One always finds the essence of somebody when they must answer on first impulse, rather than having time to prepare..." he answered.

"In any case, I could hold you here for quite some time, yet I suppose that mortals like you don't have millenia to waste philosophizing. Thus, based upon what you have answered, and comparing that to how you performed on your trial..."

I immediately stood up straighter.

"First of all, you possess an unparalleled raw talent in the facet of direct combat. When you know the foe it is you fighting and why you are fighting them, I would say you would be superb indeed."

"In comparison, your ability to manipulate the elements is but average."

"You were not the most pious dragoness when growing up, yet your spirituality has grown a great deal in a short amount of time. Having never known your birth parents, you value companionship especially, and vow to protect them by any means necessarily. When they get hurt, you agonize over their pain as if it were your own.

Your fate has many possible futures I see, many good, some great, some that may lead to despair, also possibly a combination of all these, yet which future depends upon the choices you make in life. I suppose you already knew all that, and again, rather than bore you with cryptic riddles and long-winded philosophy, I would suppose that you'd wish to know whether or not you've passed the trial," said the Chronicler.

My hearts pounded in anticipation, praying for acceptance, but also at the same time preparing for failure.
11412111111111112212111.title: The Chronicler

choices: Darzhja gets immediately assigned to duty
114121111111111122121111.content:
"Thus, I find that despite the rather unorthodox nature of your candidacy, I cannot help but be intrigued at discovering how you'll fare as a Holy Knight..." said the Chronicler. For a moment, my mind failed to register what the Chronicler just said.

"So...that means I passed?" I cried out.

"Was that not what I just said?" he answered.

A million thoughts passed through my head, all at once. I passed. By the Ancestors I'd actually passed, and now I was going to be a Knight. Like Lady Ramoth was. All the hardship, no parents, seeing my friends hurt, being rejected time after time... it had all meant something after all. My elation crested as I shut my eyes and let out a cry of joy, dancing around the pedastal where I stood, not caring whether my outburst was un-Knightly.

"Yes, yes, congratulations Darzhja," answered the Chronicler, seeming somewhat bored. After all, he must have seen these outbursts of joy all too often, having screened generation after generation of Knights. He waited until I had calmed myself before continuing on.

"Now then, I will return you to your mortal body now, and when you reawaken you will be a Holy Knight. Though you're now a Knight, consider this but the beginning of a new step in your life's journey. With that, I shall bid you farewell for the time being, and when the time comes that we reunite it shall hopefully after a long and noble tenure of service."

"Goodbye then!! And once again, thank you," I answered.

"Go forth young Knight," he chanted. The Chronicler's image faded away, along with the chamber that he had taken residence in, and once more I found myself swept off my claws, under the mercy of the Ancestors, swirling through Convexity while thanking the Ancestors for granting me the priviledge of becoming a Knight. Images flashed through my head, that spoke of honor, chivalry, sacrifice and upholding its sacred code, filling me with ancient knowledge of its rites. And there was power, a power that been lit within the very depths of my soul, now awakened.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------

Finally, after what had seemed like both eternity, and no time at all, I found that I could control my body again.

I opened my eyes. I found myself back in the Temple, standing before the statue of Gyrimond. Before me stood a small gathering of Holy Knights in full armor. I recognized Father Quazios among the Knights, yet I had no idea who the others were. I too was now clad in armor, yet felt more ceremonial than something I would actually fly into battle with. Yet I felt as if I belonged.

A black dragon in armor stepped forward.

"I am Lord Demios, one of the nine dragons priviledged to hold office within the High Council, and I bid you welcome, Darzhja of New Alveri, into the order Holy Knights of Nod, chosen by the Great Ancestors above to fulfill their will upon the mortal world," the black dragon spoke with a deep, noble voice.

For a while I wasn't sure how to react to the notion that a Deathwing was a Holy Knight, and one of such influence at that. Regal Bronzes and Deathwings traditionally never got along, and the few that I'd met always seemed bitter, gloomy and unfriendly. Personally, I didn't have anything against Deathwings, but Holy Knighthood didn't seem a likely profession for them. Apparently, I was wrong in that regard. Furthermore, perhaps the very fact that Lord Demios was a Deathwing and his element were known to have a malevolent reputation, he made extra effort to adhere to chivalry and formality.

"I'm... honored Lord Demios," I responded. The gathered Knights gazed at me, as if expecting me to give some sort of sacred vow, or its code. Of course, I didn't know any such code, having grown up in the orphanage of course.

"Forgive me, Lord Demios, yet I do not know any of its sacred rituals, nor any of its creeds. All I can promise is that I will protect the people of New Alveri, combat evil wherever it is found and that by the Grace of the Ancestors I have the strength and wisdom to do so," I answered with conviction.

Lord Demios nodded, "Scripture can be learned, yet what truly matters is that the Ancestors found you worthy of joining our order, and thus we are expecting many great things out of you."

He turned toward Father Quazios, "Now then, Holy Father, if you would be so kind as to administer the order of initiation?"

The deathwing stepped backwards, and was replaced by the old cleric.

"Now Darzhja, will you kindly lower your head," he said.

"Will you pledge your service to Nod and all its subjects, maintaining law in order in times of peace and defend them with claw, tooth, wing, tail and piety during times of war?"

"I shall..." I answered without hesitation.

"Will you faithfully adhere to our orders tenants, and live your life according to them?"

"I shall..."

Father Quazios chanted a few more proclamations, of which I answered affirmative to each one, before he laid a claw upon my head.

"Thus, I dub thee Lady Darzhja, Holy Knight of Nod, with all the responsibilities and priviledges granted as such..."

"Now rise..."

I did rise.

With that, the ceremony was largely over. It had been a rather humble ceremony; after all, while I was now officially a Knight, I had achieved but initiate status. As the Chronicler had said to me earlier in Convexity, this was but a beginning of a long journey, rather than the crowning accomplishment. There was still a lot I had to learn, and I would have to pay my dues and work tirelessly and even thanklessly in order for me to advance.

I spoke to a few of the Knights, once again congratulating me on my initiation. They asked me a lot about my time in the orphanage, and specifically the influence Lady Ramoth had upon me. I had quickly learned that during the time I had undergone the trial, all the Knights had learned of Lady Ramoth's re-emergence from self-imposed exile, and quickly, the focus of their conversation switched from myself to her. I didn't mind it that much actually. After all, my own ascension to Holy Knighthood had as much to do with her wisdom and guidance alongside my own merit, and thus deserved praise as such.

These Knights, I observed, were in their regard for Lady Ramoth very much like the wide-eyed younger hatchlings back at the orphanage, whole-heartedly believing my exaggerated stories of martial prowess and that I was an invincible conquering hero. Lord Demios, for all his power and influence, had been but a fledgling when Ramoth had left the Knights, and the others had only heard of Ramoth through her tales of heroism, having hatched after her departure, so to them she had a mythical quality.

"Indeed, she must be very proud to know of your accomplishment. Now then Darzhja," said Lord Demios, "I congratulate you once more on your initiation, yet I must return to my duties now."

He quickly turned to one of the Knights.

"Arathos," commanded Lord Demios.

A green dragon came forward, standing stiff in salute. "Yes my Lord!!"

"I'm placing you in charge of getting Darzhja oriented with her duties, as well as aiding her in getting her affairs in order," instructed Demios.

"Very well my Lord," he answered with a bow.

I switched my gaze over to the green dragon. He hadn't particularly stood out from any of the others during the post-ceremonial congratulations, yet he gave the impression of being the solid and reliable sort.

"So...what happens now?"
114121111111111122121111.title: New Awakening

choices: Ask to see something else first
1141211111111111221211111.content:
I followed Araphor over the Temple grounds, taking in my new surroundings. The Temple, I would be living here for many years, perhaps centuries to come, so one did not need to be the Chronicler to understand that I should familiarize myself with its layout as soon as I could.

"As a Knight newly inducted into our order, you'll be placed under a strict training regimen to better prepare you for the duties of Knighthood. This is required for all incoming knights, and failure to complete them within the required amount of time may get you stripped of your Knighthood."

"Stripped of my Knighthood?" I shrieked.

"That's only in rare cases. You'll find out exactly what these requirements are later on, but for now allow me to give you explain the layout of the Temple," said Araphor.

"Obviously, we don't have the time to cover every nook and cranny within the temple, and some of the places are currently forbidden, so I'll show you the places you need to know of..."

I followed Araphor close behind as he took off from the shrine.

First, I was led to a cave that had copious amounts of smoke seething out of it.

"This is the smithys, that deals with all the armaments and metalworking within the Temple. You'll receive a set of a suit of armor to use on missions, and they'll also fix any superficial damage received during missions."

"Would I be able to customize my armor as well?" I asked.

"For a fee of course," he answered.

"Anyhow, let us move on..."

I was then taken to another one of the large ledges.

"This is the medical ward. Should you get injured during a mission, or if you suffer an illness, you are covered free of charge. Furthermore, despite the fact you'd been chosen by the Ancestors themselves, you'll also be required to undergo a full physical examination to ensure your fitness for duty."

"An...exam?" I asked, feeling somewhat nervous. "What exactly goes on during this exam?"

There was a brief awkward moment, as Araphor curved his gaze away for a moment. "The specifics will be explained by the healers, and you'll be informed which results you wish to remain confidential. I'm not a doctor in anycase..." he added.

"So...moving on now, perhaps we should find a more comfortable setting to answer more of your questions. After enduring the trial, I'm sure you must be very hungry. Would you mind if I showed you the hunting grounds?" he asked.

Only now did I remember that I hadn't eaten anything since I was back at the orphanage, and after the euphoria of the ceremony had worn off, I was indeed famished.

"By the Ancestors yes!! I could eat a wyrern!! Show the way!!"

"Then follow me then," answered Araphor with a smile.

"These are the hunting grounds. You are permitted to hunt one adult beast per day free of charge, yet any additional animals will come with a customary charge," explained Araphor.

"Anyhow, once you've picked out an animal, meet me back by the rivers edge so we can discuss this further."

I was only half listening to him, as my eyes were fixed upon the giant herds of cattle below. Having grown up on dried meat, thin beef stew and other rather spartan meals, the sight of these large, fat cattle made my mouth water. They were all just standing there, waiting to fill my belly. A fresh, live, kill. My eyes grew wide and predatory as I circled overhead, watching my prey. I soon spotted a particularly tasty looking cow, landing upon it. It attempted to resist me, its legs futilely kicking about, and honestly I couldn't help but savor the animals helplessness for a moment, before I decided to slash out its throat. Satisfied, I picked it up and glided over to where Araphor was waiting, who had already picked out a large bull.

I took one bite of the cow, feeling its raw, blood go down my throat.

"Oh wow!! I've never tasted anything so great in my life!!" I called out.

I barely resisted the urge to simply bury my head into its juicy corpse and devour it, but though what little I knew of etiquette, it probably would have been 'unknightly'.

"The Temple employs the finest humanoid shepards to provide sustenence for the Knights. As you no doubt have already been able to tell, the humanoids provide an abundant number of essential services to keep the Temple maintained and operational."

Few dragons wanted to admit it, but without the humanoids to do the tasks that dragons found rather trivial, New Alveri would have collapsed into chaos and dragons would have been relegated to a society of disparate clans. Once again, dragons needed the humanoids as much as the humanoids needed us.

"I've also heard a lot about how dragons can partner with a humanoid Knight. I've heard how Lady Ramoth had a very deep relationship with Lessa, but most of the time I don't see the Knights accompanied with a humanoid rider. Can you explain how that works?" I wondered, after taking a few bites of its gut. I recalled how Lady Ramoth had possessed an extremely deep bond with Lessa, and that when she had died Ramoth had been devastated. While I had worked with humanoids within New Alveri, I was not willing to commit to that type of relationship.

"Ramoth's bond with Lessa is a rare case. Mostly, we are partnered with the humanoid knights based upon the particular needs of the mission. For instance, if the mission requires you to scout out a new area, the partner that will be assigned to you will be one that has expertise in scouting. Similarly, if you were to be called to battle, then a partner who is adept at martial prowess will be given to you. Once you've advanced enough, you can pick whichever humanoid you feel would help you the most within any specific mission, yet while you remain an initiate the humanoids you'll be working with out on the field will be assigned," answered Araphor.

"Who will be the one who decides the humanoids that are assigned?" I asked.

"Your mentor. While you are an apprentice knight, one of the more experienced knights will be assigned to further your training, provide you with wisdom, as well as serve as a guide you on your first few missions," he explained. "Make sure to heed the lessons of your mentor well, as they will decide how fit you are for further advancement within the ranks. Your mentor will also help you decide your specific area of expertise."

"So, like whether I'll be a fighter, or a defender, things like that?" I answered.

"Something of that nature. If I may comment though, I don't envision you specializing in any particular field of magic," added Araphor.

I took absolutely no offense at his observation. "Neither do I actually..."

By that time, I had stripped the animal all the way down to the bone, deeply content and satisfied with my meal.

It was well into the afternoon by then, so that led me to my next question.

"Araphor, where exactly will I be staying?" I asked.

"As an apprentice Knight, you will reside with the other apprentice Knights. These are segregated by gender, to ensure no illicit activities, and within your lair you'll have a lairmate. The lair mate you are paired with is selected based upon your attributes as a Knights, along with your personality and such. They'll also accompany you on many of your earlier missions. If you'd like Darzhja, I could show you to the lairs at this moment..."
1141211111111111221211111.title: Longwinded explanations

11412111111111112212111111.content:
Araphor directed me to the administrator of the apprentice lairs, a non-descript dwarven female. I thanked the green dragon, and watched him take back off. It took quite a while to get all the arrangements in order; one thing I was to learn about the Holy Knights was that there was as many tasks involving arranging paperwork as there was in physical training, mental conditioning and the sort. The lairs were arrayed all along the cliffside, lined up side by side next to each other in a rather spartan manner. I saw a few other dragonesses heading toward their respective lair, and I stopped to say hello to a few of them in passing. It was getting close to sunset, most of them were already on their way to their lairs.

The lair I had been provided was large, spacious and clean, and for an orphan used to having to twist my body into cramped spaces, having this much space to myself was paradise. Branching out from the main chamber was a watering room, along with a place to relieve ones self. I was also curious to meet my lair mate, whoever she was. I gazed about, wondering where she was.

“Hello?” I called out.

There was no answer. Maybe I didn't have a lair mate after all. Then out of nowhere, there was a puff of smoke, and I instinctually jumped backwards, my hearts pounding. When the smoke cleared, I found myself staring at a small dragoness. Actually, a small dragoness would have towered over her; in fact she was a tiny little thing, no larger than the size of a typical hatchling. Her hide was a light greenish color, interposed with slightly glowing stripes of every color. The Faerie Dragoness fluttered around in quick little circles around me; my neck swiveling in vain attempt to keep up, her eyes glowing with mischief.

"YYYYIIIIEEEEEEEEEEE!!!!" she squealed with a tone so high-pitched, that I wrenched my jaws together, "I finally have a lairmate!! By the Ancestors I've got a lairmate!! We're going to be the bestest of best friends!!"

By the Ancestors... save me... I thought, horrified.

She fluttered her overlapping, translucent, fragile-looking butterfly wings rapidly, literally bouncing off the walls, sending bright sparkling dust flying everywhere in excitement. When I inhaled a bit of it, it made me lightheaded and somewhat dizzy.

"I'm Linal'eiel!!" she squeaked excitedly, stopping a foot in front of my face, "But you can call me Lina!! What about you!?"

"Darzhja..." I answered stoically. Had I said anything more, I thought that I would go insane.

The Faerie dragoness, Lina, let out another girlish scream of pure, unrelenting joy, fluttering around so rapidly I thought she would have a seizure.

There was another poof. The Faerie Dragon had suddenly appeared on right on top of my back, leaning her tiny head forward so that it was next to mine.

"So!! Tell me everything about yourself Darzhja!! What's your favorite flower? Dandelions are my favorite!! Do you have a favorite type of gemstone? Any males you like?" she chittered, rattling of a series of the most random topics.

"Hey!! Get off me!!" I growled. I reached with my claw to grab her, yet once again she disappeared with a puff of smoke, giggling that high-pitched giggle of hers.

"You can't catch me!!" taunted Lina, flashing me a series of juvenile faces. She was taunting me. The little rascal was taunting me. If the Ancestors had established trials designed to test ones patience and restraint, sharing a lair with a Faerie Dragoness surely had to be one of them.

"Okay now Darzhja...calm down, it’s going to turn out all right. The Ancestors haven't abandoned me yet..." I whispered to myself.

"Ah!! Sorry about that!! Its just that I can get a little carried away meeting new people!" cried Lina.

Carried away? I had only known her for a few minutes now, and already I was on the verge of losing my mind.

"Well...I suppose it happens to all of us..." I answered, trying to compose myself and attempting to restore a sense of sanity within the lair; "I've never met a Faerie Dragon before until now."

"Then consider me your first!! Understandable really, since there aren't that many of us," she answered, appearing to have thankfully calmed down.

"Don't mind if I ask this, but are most Faerie Dragoness like you?" I wondered.

"Of course!! We're the ones who make your wishes come true!!" she answered. "If you’re wondering, the males are like that too. They don't get much respect from the others. Like my dear betrothed, Ein'theil, he got picked on a lot because everyone one thinks male Faerie Dragons are gay and effeminate, but I love him just the way he is!! Once we become mates, we're going to have four wonderful little ones!! And we're going to name them Tin'kerl, Bell'eithe, Orio'neitel and...well, we still haven't thought of the last one, but we're working on it!!"

"So...you've been arranged to be this... Ein's mate, I'm assuming that this was made long before now and probably because your kind is relatively rare. Still, are you okay with that?" I wondered.

"We were made for each other!!" she squealed, eyes glowing dreamily. She began singing a song similar to one of those nursery rhymes given to hatchlings, about how compatible she was with him.

"All right then..." I replied, eager to change the subject.

"So...any males you like Darzhja?" she asked.

"What?" I growled.

"There has to be somebody..." she inquired.

I rolled my eyes. I figured that I'd just answer her, or else she was going to be bugging me all night.

"At the orphanage, I did once like this older fledgling, but I quickly got over it. Blaze was like a little brother to me, and Kaj, the gatekeeper, like an older brother. As for here, I really don't know anybody. Araphor seems like the type that wants to help out everybody. Lorath seems friendly. As for Fangorn..."

My eyes furrowed when I thought of him, "He's a jerk. He called me a hatchling and he threw me into prison and took no small amount of joy seeing me chained up. I'd never felt so degraded and humiliated in my life. I hate him so much. He's arrogant, full of himself and - and, well at least he wished me good luck before the trial..."

"Really?" said Lina, leaning her head closer, starting to get excited, "And what else is he?"

My mind started to wander, as I suddenly started to feel light-headed again. I was about to go on when I noticed she was fluttering her wings softly, pouring fairy dust over my nostrils.

"Wait a second!! Why I am telling you all this!! I just met you!!" I wailed, eyes snapping back into focus. The only reason that came to mind was that the mischievous little fairly had gradually put me on some mind-altering spell. Could Faerie Dragons make one spill out their deepest, darkest secrets?

"You like him don't you?" she whispered, appearing ready to burst out in glee.

I sniffed out a plume of smoke at her, which of course, she fluttered away from. Could I see myself liking Fangorn? Maybe if he didn't act so arrogantly. Yet there was a lot to choose from though. I shook my head to rid myself of such thoughts.

"Lina, I know you find it fun, but I don't appreciate it when you play these types of mind tricks on me," I cried. Magic was a complete enigma to me, and Lina was bursting with it.

"Oh…all right..." she answered, her wings drooping.

I let out a breath. "I suppose being a Faerie Dragon its something you can't help about yourself. Just... try not to do it so often all right?" I replied.

"Okay!!" she squeaked. “Yet if you need to escape the burdens of the world, just remember that I'm always here!! Because with a tiny bit of magic, all your dreams can come true!!”

I felt my stomach cringe, “I’ll think about it…”

I suddenly let out a yawn. It was getting quite late. It had been a long, long day, and I had a feeling that I would be waking up bright and early the following morning. I laid myself on my stomach, only to find that a moment later a heard a 'poof', and discovered Lina reclining her body atop of me.

“Why are you sleeping on top of me?” I asked, tilting my head in her direction.

Lina let out a high pitched yawn, curling her lithe body atop my back, and laying her tiny head against the base of my neck, “Because you’re big and comfy Darzhja,” she insisted.

I snorted in annoyance. Then again, I didn’t want her pulling any more mind tricks on me, so I figured it was a reasonable request.

“Suit yourself then. Be warned that if I roll over while I’m asleep, then I won’t be able to guarantee that you’ll emerge unharmed,” I warned.

Yet I found that she had already fallen fast asleep. I let out an exasperated, exhausted sigh. What a strange dragoness.

With that, I prayed to the Ancestors, and fell into a deep sleep.
11412111111111112212111111.title: With a tiny bit of magic...

114121111111111122121111111.content:
I was floating on a golden breeze. The air holding me up smelled of lilacs and honey, a warm, hypnotizing scent. Dazzling electric blue flower petals danced through the air all around, floating down from the green and blue mottled heavens above. 'Wait' I thought dreamily, 'That's not the sky…' Ah, I was upside down. I reached my claws forward to swoop over backwards, but the tips of my claws touched the flowery, psychedelic scene in front of me like the surface of a pond. The world rippled and I found myself sinking in azure waters. I was not troubled by the prospect of drowning in the slightest, however, I swam through the placid abyss with the ease of a fish. Ahead of me I saw what I took to be a fish, but as I got closer, I realized that it was actually a tail, a bronze dragon tail. I had to check to make sure that it was not my own, I was feeling not at all my usual self. I swam closer, chasing the bronze dragon ahead of me with glee. When he turned, suddenly, it was him chasing me. I laughed, bubbled escaping upwards and swam as fast as I could, though he remained close behind, a gorgeous smile on his young, masculine face. "You can't catch me!" I called like a hatchling.

Fangorn said nothing, though his face remained intent on me. Then he uttered a single word, "Darzhja…"

"Darzhja… Darzhja!" the azure sea disappeared and I was rushing through blackness. I awoke with a start to the noise of trumpets filling the smallish lair.

"Owie…" sobbed Linda from the floor. Apparently I'd knocked the smallish dragon off my back when I'd woken.

"Sorry Linda." I said sincerely, though my head was still spinning from the incredibly vivid dream. "I was having such a weird dream…"

The faerie dragon bounced up into the air effortlessly, the moment she started flapping her wings, dust began to cascade off of them. "That's normal." she said with a smile. "You'll soon develop a tolerance. My dust is only mildly toxic to other dragons."

"That's… er, great Linda. Nice to know." I said, turning my grimace into a semblance of a grin.

Linda didn't notice my disembling however as she began flitting about the small dormitory. "Oh do you hear the trumpets, Darzhja?! I do so love the morning anthem!" It was impossible not to notice the militaristic tune emanating from the stone walls on all sides, so I nodded. "The caves are magicked to carry the sound all the way from the trumpeters downstairs." Linda explained. She rushed forward as I was rising to hover near my head. "You were sleeping like a log and I was afraid that you were going to miss them."

"You were the one calling my name?" I asked. The image of Fangorn and that look on his face was impossible to forget despite how I tried.

Linda did a backflip in the air, her butterfly wings rippling, "Of course, Silly! Do you see anyone else in here?"

I shook my head. "So this is my first day as a new Knight…" I couldn't bring myself to say 'Holy Knight' I didn't feel particularly holy. "What happens now?"

With a small *pop* Linda disappeared and materialized back in front of me. She scratched at a few of the many decorative green tendrils projecting from the back of her neck and down her spine with a foreclaw. "Well…" she said in her high voice, "In the morning, it's usually exercise and training for us initiates. Since this is your first day, they might have extra stuff for you to do as well."

I didn't have to feign excitement, my paws were almost dancing on the floor. I stretched my wings in the small chamber which was still larger and more luxurious than what I was generally accustomed to and found that I did, in fact, have enough room to fully extend them if I stood in the middle. Linda gave a small yip and popped up over me as I stretched, almost filling the little room. "What big, beautiful wings you have!" Linda exclaimed.

I tried not to blush, "Thanks, Linda. Your's are beautiful too." The faerie dragon spun and bounced on the air as I pulled my wings back, folding them to my back. "I'm so ready to get out there." I said, already walking down the small corridor that led into the common rooms of the female barracks. "Will you show me where to go?"

I turned my head to look for Linda behind me, but saw nothing but a tiny puff of smoke and her trademark *pop*. I whipped my head back around and saw the little dragon gliding down the rough stone passage. "You'll have to move faster than that, Darzhja! We're already late!"

I grinned and ran after my lairmate. Despite my initial misgivings, I thought that me and the little dragoness could be good friends.


As I ran down the twisting passage after my flitting companion, the corridor widened and opened into many side passages leading off behind me. Each side passage was inscribed with a number in Draconic above the entrance; I assumed that these led to other dorms. It was difficult chasing after Lina in the confined space. She glided openly down the descending passage while I had to run on all fours. Arriving in the common chamber, I saw that we were at the tail end of a mass exodus out of the caverns. "Linda, where-"

But the faerie dragon was suddenly at my head, tugging me forward, her little claws gripping one of my horns. "Come on! Don't stop here!"

I let the little dragon drag me ahead, though I coughed a little at the dust pouring into my face. Past the washroom with the stream flowing down the middle of a carved cannal and past the main chamber where there were large, flat rocks and rugs suitable for reclining was the landing where brilliant sunlight was pouring in. A silver dragoness who looked a little on the heavy side so that I wondered if she were carrying eggs jumped just as we exited the female dorms. The breeze brushing against my scales was cold, crisp and invigorating; just the way I liked it. Away and up the valley, I saw dragons of many, many colors and breeds soaring in the early morning air. I grinned at Linda, still attatched to my horn and took three quick steps forward before flinging myself off the ledge without spreading my wings.

The faerie dragon shrieked as we fell and I laughed, catching myself after twisting my body around. "Eiyah! Why'd you do that for?" asked Linda.

I was still laughing. As I angled myself towards where the other young dragons were going, the little dragoness detached and flew alongside me; though I thought that she left indent on my horn where she had been gripping with her claws. "Why not?" I answered and then Linda started laughing as well.

A short time later, I saw the dragons circling and landing in an orderly fashion on a barren field at the head of the volcano's crater, it was ringed with a simple rope fence and had two large pavilions at either side that I thought could fit several adult dragons within. "Is that where we're going?" I asked, inclining my head.

"Yep!" chirped Linda. "Those are the training grounds." Then Linda shrugged, "They're not that great. I'll show you the gardens after. The Knights keep all kinds of exotic plants, including many from my homeland."

I grinned, but trees and shrubs did not hold my attention, what did was all of those dragons assembling ahead. In my mind, I was already sizing up each one that I saw, both male and female. I hoped there would be sparing. I stole a glance at my much smaller companion, I supposed it natural that she not be so interested in fighting. But seeing as we would be bunking together for the forseeable future, I decided to make an effort. "What kind of plants come from your homeland, Linda?"

The faerie dragon smiled, clearly excited. She tipped a wing and fluttered a little way towards a large green ledge on the far side of the valley. "See, way over there, they grow an bush that's important for my diet."

"You eat bushes?" I asked dubiously.

"No!" she exclaimed, "I don't eat them, but I do eat the beetles that live in them. They are pretty powerful magic... and they keep my wings nice and sparkly. See?!"

Linda popped and appeared right in front of me, displaying the vivid display on her back. The crisscrossing, wavy lines were colorful enough to remind me of my psychedelic dream. I was showered in dust, however. I gulped a big breathe against my best efforts and sneezed horrendously, sending the smaller dragoness flying.

"Aiieeee!!!" she squealed as she tumbled through the air.

I snorted and blew my nose, sending the slime down to the ground far below. "Sorry!" I shouted, but she was gone again suddenly.

*pop* "It's alright. That one was my fault." said Linda with a giggle. And then suddenly she gasped. "Ein'theil!!" She dived in loops around my long neck, "Do you see him?! Do you see him, over there by the bushes!" She spared a quick look at me, but it was clear she was too excited to linger, "I'll catch you later, Darzhja! Have fun!"

"Bye, L-" But she had already popped away. I saw Linda appear about two body lengths away, but only momentarily before she teleported again. Thus, with several *pops* she traversed the considerable distance in just a few seconds. With the last, I saw her land on her betrothed's back in the distance before both went tumbling down into the greenery, laughing so loud it carried all the way back to me. I couldn't help but smile, though I felt a little relieved as well. I turned to face the other big dragons and got in line to spiral down.
114121111111111122121111111.title: Dreams and Dreaming

1141211111111111221211111112.content:
The trip down was a short one, me following the slightly bloated sliver dragoness who had been the last to leave the dormitories. The youth had gathered below, landing just outside the dirt field, folding their wings and walking forward to form clean, neat rows. There were three such rows, bisected in the middle by a narrow gap, males on the right, females left. Ahead of the young dragons were three larger veteran Holy Knights. Two were quite grizzled looking males with stern expressions as their eyes wandered over their fresh cadets like newly slaughtered meat; one was very muscular, clearly he had some Juggernaut blood in him, the other leaner, but with oversized, shovel shaped foreclaws - he was missing his left eye as well. The third was female, but, as I would eventually learn, she was the one to be most feared of all.

I would not find out this day, however. As I was stepping forward to join the ranks at the end of the last row, I was shunted aside by a wall of bronze scale. "Fangorn!" I hissed. I'd been seeing far too much of the arrogant drake lately.

"Darzhja, I need you to follow me. And be quick about it." He hissed right back at me without so much as a hello. He turned his big, scaly self around and began to trot off towards the interior of the valley.

I looked with longing to the other trainees who were beginning to perform calisthenics at the direction of the three sergeants. I hesitated, thinking seriously about ignoring Fangorn and forming rank with the others. It was a struggle not to heed the wild, impatient side of myself. I had to force myself to recall that I was a Knight now - a real Holy Knight! - and that I was not free to do whatever I wished. Fangorn was obviously still in charge of me to a degree. Besides, I had the suspicion that he was going to take me to perform some of the tasks that needed to be done to finalize my introduction into the knights. I jogged to catch up to the bronze male and spread my wings after him.

Once I'd sidled up alongside Fangorn, I asked rudely, "So what is this all about then?"

Fangorn frowned, "That is not the proper tone to address a superior cadet. Do you wish me to report you for insubordination?"

'Ugh… this power-trip is really going to his fat head. I thought with malice, but I also realized that he was completely right. "I'm sorry… Sir." I added.

Fangorn grunted for a reply. It was a minute before he answered my question. "I'm here to pair you with your mentor."

"My what?" I asked.

Fangorn glared at me and showed the canines the left side of his mouth in a clipped snarl.

"My what, Sir?" I corrected, barely able to avoid snarling myself.

"Your mentor will be your primary teacher for the duration of your training. You are responsible, in addition to your normal recruit duties such as morning drill and helping maintain the dorms and the grounds, for assisting your mentor in any number of tasks she may ask of you."

"I have a female mentor, Fangorn?"

The bronze didn't seem to mind the use of my name. "We typically segregate the sexes as much as we can. Hormones and such…" His eyes darted to me and lingered for perhaps a moment longer than they should have.

I was not so unhappy about missing the drill now as I winged my way back into the valley's interior. I was anxious to start my training for real. "Who is my mentor going to be, if you don't mind me asking?"

Fangorn just sighed. "You'll meet her soon enough. We're almost to her cave."

We didn't speak anymore for the next three minutes as Fangorn angled to a dark hole in the side of the volcano's interior walls. One of many such holes, I noticed again the style of placing a symbol above the entrance. However, in this case, there was not a number, but a personal rune, the dragon equivalent of a signature. It had no verbal equivalent, but I supposed I would soon meet the dragoness who was associated with it.

A worn rug just on the inside of the landing padded our feet as we entered. The place smelled worn in, the scent of the occupying dragoness ingrained into the very stone walls. It was possible she had lived here for centuries. Torches, though mostly unnecessary for a dragon's excellent night vision, cheered up the place and various shiny baubles and nicknacks placed on stone shelves around made the place seem warm and welcoming, quite cozy, really. Having made no slight amount of noise entering, it was not a surprise to see the occupant of the lair soon appear from deeper inside. Fangorn bowed at the knee and I copied his movements.

"Lady Scabia. At your service." said Fangorn, quite uncharacteristically humble.

"Be at ease, young drake." said the older female, waving her claw. She was quite large, though not as large as Lady Ramoth and younger than my former mistress and current sponsor as well. Her scales were a very dark shade of green and the shape of her eyes led me to believe that her line had crossed with deathwing in the past. She held her right wing a little crookedly, as if she couldn't close it all the way and she bore a burn pattern in the way her scales grew on her right shoulder. I was immediately impressed, my own burn on my neck now being mostly healed through magical and non-magical means. Whatever had inflicted such a mark on her had to have been foul indeed. I had learned enough by not to remain kneeling despite the fact that she had released Fangorn. "Is this Ramoth's child?" she asked in a curious voice as she lowered her head to take in my scent.

"Er… Lady Ramoth is sponsoring her, if that's what you mean, Lady Scabia." said Fangorn I felt my mentor's breath on the nape of my neck, but held still. "Her name is Darzhja, Lady." he added a bit late.

"Hm… I misunderstood, then." Scabia flexed a wing, "You are no offspring of Ramoth."

Suddenly, I was horrified by the prospect of being rejected. I supposed I could always be assigned another mentor, but a dragoness who obviously knew Lady Ramoth personally seemed somehow ideal. but I dared say nothing.

"If it pleases you, I can reassign her to anot-"

"Stop your sniveling, Fangorn, you're not fooling anyone." scolded Scabia dismissively with her good wing.

Rebuked, the bronze drake frowned, but I grinned with my head between my paws. "Rise… Darzhja." I complied and looked into Scabia's intense yellow eyes. "You may not be of my old friend's blood, but if Ramoth had seen fit to sponsor you, then… that will do. I shall have you as my apprentice."

"Thank you, Lady Scabia. It's an honor." I said with perfect honesty.

"Mhmm." acknowledged the older female. She turned, however, back to the bronze drake. "Has she completed her other errands?"

"She still needs to visit the Vault to collect her things and set up her account as well as receive a physical at the physician." said Fangorn. I held my wings close about me as he again mentioned the physical examination.

Lady Scabia came to my rescue. "You shall accompany the young female to the vault and nothing else, young lad. You shall let me attend to her personal matters."

"As you wish, Lady Scabia." said Fangorn inclining his head; he seemed ever so slightly deflated. I wondered if he was looking forward to seeing me in such a degrading situation, as if seeing me chained and in a dungeon cell was not enough.

The dark green dragoness turned her gaze on me once more. "Run along now, child. Return to me tomorrow morning after drill, I already have need of a swift flying new recruit such as yourself. Bring your lairmate, as well. Her name was Li- Ly-something?"

"Linal'eiel, but she goes by Linda." I provided.

"Yes, that's right, the squeaky little one. I've spoken to her mentor already. She'll be your partner for what I have planned for you."

My hearts beat faster with anticipation. I wanted to hear what she had for me that instant. Setting up account and having my body examined sounded like no fun in the slightest. I had to console myself with the fact that she was only asking for less than a day now. "Thank you, Lady."

The older female grinned for the first time since I'd met her and I saw that she had a good smile, the lines well worn into her face. "Well go on now! I have things to do, you know. No one can sit around these days." she dismissed us with a wave of her wings and we were soon again airborne and soaring over the green fields of the valley below. I was tempted to grin smugly at Fangorn, and I, in fact, indulged myself when I was behind him where he couldn't see. Very shortly, we landed in a wide opening not far from the grand entrance to the Shrine where I'd experienced the trials. The entranceway was also heavily decorated and hooded members of the Dragon Cult as well as armed and armored guards traversed up and down the smooth marble floor that spiraled in a long curve, descending ever downward.

"This is one of the entrances to the main keep." Fangorn explained. It was then that I truly began to comprehend what a magnificently large place the Temple was. In addition to the valley above and all of the dragon living areas carved into the walls of the volcano, there was a sprawling city - there was no other word for it - underneath all of that. Passage ways sprang off at even intervals, many of them guarded by either humanoid or dragon. But we kept descending, ever in the slight, wide spiral, into the bowels of the mountain.
1141211111111111221211111112.title: Lady Scabia

11412111111111112212111111121.content:
Finally, we arrived at the Vault. The guards down here were mostly Earth Renders, dragons at home deep underground, interposed by their dwarven auxilliaries. They were the meanest and most menacing Knights I'd ever seen.

"State your business here..." an Earth dragon asked.

"Lord Tanaroth, I have brought Darzhja here to open an account. Lady Ramoth is sponsoring her, so Darzhja's information would be under her account."

The dragon performed a spell, and began scanning his gaze over something that I couldn't see.

"Very well now, I'll have one of my representatives go over the details with her..." said the Earth Dragon. "If you are her chaperone, which it appears you seem be, I must ask you to wait outside the vault, unless you have anything of concern over your own account Sir Fangorn..."

"Not at all my Lord..."

The earth dragon growled, before gesturing for a dwarf came forward.

"Darzhja now is it? My name is Gaelin, come with mae..."

I followed the dwarf down a passage, leading to a large chamber. Upon the vast wall, were rows upon rows of intents that had glowing runemarks upon them.

"This part of tae vault deals with the personal accounts of the Dragon Knights. If yae see these runes; only tae dragon whose account it belongs to can open tae account, and woe to you if you aren't tae dragon the rune is set for..." he said.

So basically, what he meant that there were security measures of the sort that not even the most experienced criminal or mage would be able to steal from them, and that the consequences for attempting it would be steep indeed.

"Whenever you conduct a mission, the payment will be directed straight to your account. Your wages will automatically be placed within this account as well, as do any expenses you incur will also be taken automatically from your account. The Vault will be sending you a parchment every season detailing how much money you have in yer account. Some of yer wages e'll be deducted in the form of taxes to tae Temple treasury of course, a necessary evil to bae sure..."

As I continued on, I was given more details about the nature of my account, such as regulations, laws that needed to be followed, when I could or could not withdraw gems, what would happen, if by the Ancestors forbid, that I went into debt, and other important details. Finally, I was led to an corner of the Vault, where there were mostly empty spaces. I made sure to memorize the route I had taken, as well as the number in Draconic above it.

"Now then, may you place your claw upon the rune for mae?" he asked. I did so, and I watched with fascination as my claw sank into the rock, feeling like clay. The wall glowed for a moment, identifying me as the owner of the account.

"Yer sponsor had been keepin all your belongings in a temporary account, yet now dat ye have one of yer own, these are automatically transferred tae yours."

"Now, open it..."

I pressed the tip of my claw upon the rune, and watched it glow for a moment, before the wall dissapeared to reveal a room about the size of my current dorm. All of my valuables were already stored there.

I looked inside. The hoard I had accumulated thus far was quite small at the moment, comprising about fifty pounds worth of gemstones at the moment (though for a humanoid, they'd be fairly well off, but then again the costs of living for dragonkind were far larger in proportion); comprising of the prizes I had accumulated from doing various odd jobs within the market district. Even so, it didn't stop me from sorting through the gemstones I had, making sure they were all present, and checking again until I was absolutely content. Unlike humanoids, dragons were only content with their wealth if they could actually see the hard evidence of that wealth in piled up gemstones. I had absolutely no idea how the humanoids could possibly trust those easily meltable coins they used, much less those flimsy, easily burnable paper slips with number values printed on them.

My list of possessions wan't particularly large either. There was a small collection of trophies that the impressed city-folk of the merchant district had given me for placing first in the amateur sparring tournaments that I'd taken part in, where I'd gained a small amount of fame as a 'fledgling prodigy' of sorts. I also had a few baubles that I received as gifts for completing a particularly hard project with the city folk.

Still, carrying them all to my dorm would be a rather cumbersome trip. As if anticipating my question, the dwarf stepped forward.

"If you like, we could have a crew transport your belongings up to yer dorm, with yer permission of course..."

"How will I know you won't try and steal from my account?" I asked. I didn't think they would, but it was more for knowing how the whole process worked.

"With tae security measures installed into the runes, plus the hazards of stealin from a dragon... trust meh, you don' need to worry a bit..."

"Very well then, I'll let you have a team take my belongings to my dorm..." I answered. Besides, I had a lot more to do still.

I returned to the reception area of the vault, where Fangorn was waiting nervously and anxiously.

"Did you get your accounts settled?" he asked.

"That is affirmative...sir," I answered, searching for an alterior motive. You never knew with Fangorn.

"Anyhow, with that matter settled..."
11412111111111112212111111121.title: The Vault
