114121111111111122121111111211.content:
I grunted an affirmative when Fangorn said he was going to take me back to Lady Scabia. Inside, I was glad to soon be rid of the annoyingly arrogant bronze drake and the way he eyed me when he thought I wasn't looking.

The walk back up through the bowels of the Temple was far more of a hassle than coming down. It seemed as though we had climbed down the entire height of the mountain itself and the entire journey had to be made on foot; space was obviously at too much of a premium to allow any but the smallest dragons room for flight. While I considered myself quite fit, I was a beast made for the open air, not for crawling on the ground like a mule.

The curved hallway we had come down, one of four main entrances at the staggered points of the compass - north-east, north-west, south-west, and south-east - seemed to drag on forever, always curving away up and to the left. Numbers at each landing - not in Draconic, but in the Common tongue - informed the weary traveler of what level they were on as well as direction, north or south, east or west. As we passed a very small entrance which led to what appeared to be some sort of humanoid mess hall through which a party of elves in leaf-green leather armor were proceeding, Fangorn snidely noticed my lagging behind. "You will get used to walking up and down through the Temple, Darzhja. Morning drill will help you build the needed muscle."

A low grumble that was not quite a growl managed to escape my throat. My only reconciliation was noting the ginger way in which Fangorn still held his bandaged tail; I hoped my bite still pained him.

Whether for the sake of my education or to further degrade me, Fangorn continued, "Over there, on the inside wall, you will notice the little glass doors on each floor. They're there so you don't need to walk all the way around the place next time."

I wanted to ask why then I had to descend all the way to the bottom level of the Temple in the first place, but realized that given the secure nature of the vault, they probably needed to see me in person… also, they probably knew that I would want to see my gems for myself. So instead, I walked up to the square glass panel opposite the landing on the north side of the spiral. I looked into it, but saw only my reflection… followed by Fangorn's as he slid in beside me. I took a side step to increase the distance between us and said, "So how does it work?"

Fangorn gestured with his broad nose, "All you need to do is say the name of the person you are looking to contact or the name of a department and then say your name. If you are cleared for access, then an imp will appear."

"A what? Imp?" I asked, very confused. The Temple was turning out to be far more magical than I was used to down in the city.

Fangorn sighed, though a look in his eye told me that this was the response that he'd been looking for. "A messenger imp, a minor demon. It will receive your message and deliver it to your intended destination."

"Demon…" I said slowly. Demons were among the last things that I had been expecting in the Temple of the Holy Knights of Nod. I wasn't sure I wanted anything to do with the mirror's polished surface anymore. Demons and other evil spirits were featured in children's folk stories the world over, no matter the species.

Fangorn smirked at my trepidation. "Don't worry, it's perfectly safe. The binding spells are airtight and the imp is compelled to immediately return to the mirror once it's delivered your message. It's really reduced the paperwork that used to flow through here in the last fifty years. Here, let me show you." Then Fangorn looked deeply into the mirror and intoned, "Lieutenant Hazzorah from Fangorn."

I couldn't help but flinch as the glass went dark and a tiny, red skinned creature appeared, no larger than a human child. Its eyes were like green embers, it's body hazy and indistinct, as though made of gas, though clearly humanoid. It waited expectantly. I found it a little unnerving as Fangorn spoke, as if dictating to this Lieutenant in person. "I have completed escorting Darzhja to the Vault, Sir. Her mentor will see to any additional responsibilities. Over."

I watched avidly as the smokey apparition vanished, leaving the mirror clean and reflecting once again. I turned my head away, but stopped when I saw Fangorn waiting, still looking at the mirror. "If your target person is near one of these mirrors, they can give a response, otherwise the demon will just whisper your message in their ear." explained Fangorn.

Just a few moments passed before the smokey imp reappeared. In a wheezy, whistling voice, the imp said, "Lieutenant Hazzorah for Fangorn." The mirror then issued a gruff, masculine dragon's voice. "Acknowledged. Fangorn, return to my Lair immediately, I have an assignment for you. And don't tell me you are on medical leave. It's been terminated prematurely." The bronze dragon's jaw dropped and I could not stifle a chuckle. "You don't need your tail for what I have for you. Over."

Shoulders slumping, the bronze drake said into the mirror, solemnly, "Acknowledged. Over."

"At least it's not guard duty, Sir." I said with an unconcealed smile.

Fangorn hissed at me and turned to go, clearly displeased for what had transpired. He walked briskly up the curved corridor, clearly no longer caring if he left me behind or not. I pushed myself, though and managed to keep up as we walked all the way back to the surface. The drake began to spread his wings on the landing without a word and though I was panting, I managed to sprint ahead and put a wing on his back to make him pause. "Where… are you going?" I panted.

"You heard the message. I have a new assignment. You can find your way back to Lady Scabia now." said Fangorn and then he shrugged off my wing and jumped into the air. I was left in a state of both boiling rage at his rude departure and perverse relief that he was now gone.

I caught my breath on the landing, leaning against a cold, damp stone wall and watched other dragon Knights come and go. It felt strange to be on my own for the first time since I'd been released from my cell... How could it be that so much has happened in less than three days since an explosion rocked New Alveri to its foundation and changed the world as I'd known it forever? The feeling of being overwhelmed was almost enough to make me sag to the ground, the weight of the past few days seemed like a mountain on my back. And yet... and yet, I was a Knight, at long last. I was what I had been working my entire life since I could remember to become. Still my future spread out ahead of me, shrouded in mists so that I did not know what would happen in the next hour, let alone where I would be in the next few years. I sat, my back to the wall and looked out over the edge of the landing, though at surface level, the broad stone landing was still a good twenty feet off the ground. The green feilds spread out ahead, the single river flowing down the middle of the valley from the basin damed up in the north face of the circular cauldron. I breathed, taking in its beauty. I prayed to the Ancestors for the strength to deal with all the things that were happening. Though I was no longer in the Shrine, I thought I could feel their caring eyes on me, filling me with a warm sensation that, somewhere out there, someone cared.

There was a *pop* and then a sudden weight on my back. "Surprise!!" shouted Linda, her thin legs around my neck.

I gave a yelp and shot forward as if someone had stuck an iron prod into me. I still wasn't used to the way the faerie could simply appear like that. "Yieee!" squealed Linda and suddenly she was gone from my back, fluttering her wings in the air a short distance over the edge of the landing. I skidded to a hault, my fore-claws digging into the stone at the very edge. I breathed a sigh, my hearts thundering in my ears. "Oh, I thought you were going to dive over the edge again." Linda said and laughed as she spiraled closer.

"Linda..." I breathed, "You can't scare me like that, I'm not used to it." And it was true; in my book, surprises were usually immediately followed by a blow to the head or a weak point like a wing.

"Oh, I was just having a little fun." Linda brushed off. "But hey, I have some important news, that's why I came to find you."

I cocked my head to the side and looked at her with an eye. "Really?" I asked. It seemed my private time was to be cut short just as Fangorn's had.

"Yes! But it's good news!!" Linda chirped and fluttered over backwards before popping to the other side of my head. She told me...
114121111111111122121111111211.title: Time Off Canceled

1141211111111111221211111112111.content:
Soaring over the green pastures far below, gaining height from a strong thermal at the the valley's wall, I could not imagine what would have compelled Lady Scabia to call be back so soon after I'd left. I clearly remember her telling me to return the following day after drill. A shiver crawled up my spine, I hoped that it wasn't the physical.

The green faerie dragon flitted by, sparking dust trailing from her wings; they were too small in proportion to her body to allow her to soar as I was doing, but she didn't seem to mind. I was reminded that she was coming along with me, so it couldn't be the physical, not unless they wanted to see us both at the same time.

When we reached the hole in the valley wall that was Scabia's lair, I landed lightly, flapping my wings as I came in hindlegs first and bracing my wingtips against the side of the cliff. As I busied myself about folding my massive wings, Linda was already walking in, apparently she simply popped herself to the floor. I smiled at her convenience; landing was probably the hardest part of routine flying. I walked in after her.

I had no sooner crossed the threshold of the cave than Lady Scabia' started speaking. She'd been waiting for us in her cozy greeting chamber. "I apologize for calling you back here so soon, but a situation has arisen that must be dealt with immediately."

I sat down, my eyes wide and sparkling in the torchlight. I could barely sit still for the anticipation. "What has happened, Lady Scabia?"

With her wing, the older female ushered in a humanoid. Studying his features, I had to guess he was half-elf, half-human and about middle aged, though the lines on his face made his expression hard. "Elandor here has uncovered a potential lead that I would like you to investigate along with your lairmate as your first mission." She turned her head, angling her face down to the half-elf. "Would you be so kind as to reveal your face to Darzhja, Elandor?"

Frowning, the humanoid acquiesced by withdrawing a small crystal vial from his coat pocket and drawing forth a small nondescript bronze pendant that he wore around his neck. If he was a spy, I naturally assumed that he would be using some sort of spell to disguise his appearance, but as I soon discovered, this spy was utilizing no mere glamor. Elandor unfolded a small prick at the rear of the pendant and I watched in surprise as he drove it into the skin of his chest. Grimacing in obvious pain, he then undid the stopper from the small vial and poured several drops of the contents onto the smooth surface of the undecorated pendant. I smelled dragon blood. The ruby blood scattered across the surface of the pendant in obviously arcane lines and tiny, finely scrawled runes before leaking down into tiny holes at the sides. When the blood had past, the half-elf's features softened sickeningly, like clay. His ears elongated, his eyes angling and his chin and nose becoming finer. The whole time, he had that pained look on his face. I did not envy the elvish spy in the least for his transformation.

"As you can see, Elandor has gone to great lengths to disguise himself. This method defeats any casual observation and leaves no magical aura behind. With a false identity provided by the Temple, he can become completely inconspicuous and untraceable. I only asked him to revert so that you may know his true face before we begin the investigation."

"And if I may ask, who are we investigating, Lady Scabia?" I asked, the tip of my tail dancing on the floor.

"I'll get to that in a moment, dear. But first, what do you know about the attack?"

I shrugged, wings inflating a little and settling back, "Next to nothing, Lady Scabia. I was there right afterwards, but…" My words faltered, my mind filled with fire and black smoke and Iskeirka's screaming.

Scabia lowered her head and looked away, understanding. "Of course… and I'm afraid to say that, despite all of our best efforts, we know little more than the average citizen. No group or organization has come forward to claim responsibility and that worries the Nine deeply."

At that moment, Linda fluttered up to eye level, a worried look on her thin face. "Some are saying that this is an enemy from within, Lady."

The dark emerald dragoness growled openly and turned on the faerie dragon, "Be wary where you say such things, little one. Very wary."

Linda sank back to the floor, deflating and Scabia continued. "Our scryers at the scene have come up with no leads and none of the sooth sayers have found a soul in the afterworlds knowledgeable about the attack or willing to speak of it. Not a single scrap of the device which caused the explosion has been recovered for study by the alchemists guild, so the magician's guild have been the most successful so far in their efforts." I remembered that pitiless elf badgering Lady Ramoth, his soulless black eyes and the way he packed Iskeirka's wing into a crate and shipped it to be dissected and sold for parts. My claws dug into the stone at the memory. "Their spellweavers have detected the auras left behind at the scene and concluded that the bomb was elemental based."

My ignorance of magic was beginning to seem like a severe handicap. "What does that mean, Lady Scabia?"

The female dragon drew in a deep sigh. Elandor at her side had finished his changing and I saw now a fair-haired, full-blooded elf. "It means," said the elf, "that this was likely an attempt on the part of our enemy to develop a weapon of mass destruction. Their silence on the part of their crime lends strength to the idea that there may be another such attack already in motion."

Both Linda and I gasped. I refused to believe that another day like that one would happen again. I'd sooner die than live through that again. I had to push down the tears deep inside. Lady Scabia needed me to be strong. Iskeirka and Ophelia and poor lost Blaze needed me to be strong.

Lady Scabia spoke heatedly, "And that is why we are doing everything in our power to track down the culprits and deliver unto them a dragon's vengeance."

"I'm ready, Lady Scabia! What will you have us do?" I nearly roared.
1141211111111111221211111112111.title: A Mission

choices: A warehouse at the edge of the city
A caravan about to depart from New Alveri
11412111111111112212111111121111.content:
The older female smiled, her thin scaly lip folding gracefully back over her yellowed fangs. "Ah to be so young and full of spirit…" Her eyes drifted away dreamily for a moment and I wondered if she were thinking of Lady Ramoth, "But we do not have hordes of trolls to send young drakes after, not this century. Your job is to be much more subtle. In fact, you shall be Linda's partner in this. She has much more experience and natural ability in the skills you will be needing."

My heart fell like a stone. I hadn't realized it, but I had been expecting to take the lead, despite the fact that I had been here for scarcely a day.

Linda was turning a backflip and squealing girlishly as Scabia continued, "We are experiencing a crime wave down in the city. The criminals think they sense weakness and are taking advantage of the chaos left over after the attack. The militia are barely able to keep the trade district from devolving into looting and rioting while the excavation teams are still digging through the rubble in search of survivors. In particular, we have received evidence of slavers moving through the city and the refugee camps. We would normally have our claws too full to deal with them, but Elandor here has discovered that they are attempting to move several clutches of dragon eggs and perhaps even a few young dragons out of the city."

My jaw dropped and my hearts pounded in outrage. I wanted to claw and tear and rend until there was nothing left. I was left embarrassed when Linda asked the most intelligent and level headed question, "For what purpose, Lady Scabia?"

"It is still unknown at this time, but we have to recover the eggs and any captive hatchlings before they get out of the city and beyond our reach."

Elandor spoke, "Given our tightly stretched resources at the moment, I wouldn't have advised direct action at this time. However, I found that the smugglers have somehow collected a staggering number of eggs, and as you know, dragon eggs are far too precious to let go, so this is worth breaking my cover for."

I felt that a single egg would have been worth ruining an investigation, but I didn't voice my heated opinion. Instead, with my hearts still filled with the hurt of the smoke and the inferno, I said, "But Lady Scabia, what does this have to do with the attack?"

"Perhaps nothing." said the aged dragoness, "Or perhaps everything. We are stretched to our limits, Darzhja. In times past, you would not have left this valley for anything other than training for at least ten years. As things are, we need even recruits like you to do work in the things that we simply do not have the dragons or the men for." I set my wings stoically and inclined my head in understanding. Lady Scabia gestured at me with her good wingtip, "You will be providing Elandor with transportation for this, Darzhja. He will guide you and take your lead from Linda as well. You shall be their muscle should things go rough, but you must try to be subtle with this matter." The elf walked forward and smiled up at me. I inclined my head and smiled back, he did have a nicer face now to my eyes; he put a hand on my foreleg and rubbed up and down in a friendly manner. "But remember, the first priority is to get those eggs back. Do what must be done."

Both Linda and I nodded and Lady Scabia retreated back into the depths of her lair, leaving the three of us behind. I looked down at Elandor. "Ready to leave?" he asked in passable Draconic. I grinned toothily down at him in answer and lowered my chest to the ground so that he could ride on me at the base of my neck. His weight was like a feather, though he gripped me tightly with his knees. The elf obviously had no use for a saddle as I'd seen other riders use at times. In response to my question of destination, he answered that we were to be heading for...
11412111111111112212111111121111.title: The Missing Clutches

114121111111111122121111111211111.content:
"We're going to be headed for a warehouse out just beyond the city gates. Most of the guilds of consequences usually use these areas as storage space for merchandice before preparing them to be shipped out to the Kingdom's other cities," explained Elandor.

"And you believe that some of these slavers are using the storage warehouses to conduct their smuggling operations?" I answered.

"I believe this to be the case Darzhja. Let me fill you in on more of the details. Most of these slavers pose as subsidiary shipping companies for the larger guilds. By paying these companies to do their shipping, they not only cut costs, but they also don't have to necessarily take responsibility for their activities. That also means that the guilds may not always know what activities these shipping companies may conduct on the side. While we may or may not find the eggs here, what we need to find out is which guilds have contracted the 'shipping companies' recently, and from there we can connect their illegal activities to their sponsors."

"The 'shipping company' that I suspect may be involved in smuggling activities is called the Mevlevi Keepers. I figured it sounded somewhat cultish, so I took the liberty to investigate the location in secret, and discovered evidence of unethical business practices. I will speak with the proprietor of the warehouse and ask him to give me a full inventory of the goods at hand, along with all their recent business transactions."

"But won't they be hiding all their illegal goods, if they think you're a regulator? Won't they deliberately be telling you that they have nothing to hide?" I asked.

"Thats where I come in!!" chirped Lina. "Sometimes they'll use a charm to make a door look like a bare stretch of wall. I can detect these charms easily, along with the magical essence that any dragon egg would give up, and if I detect anything like that it means they would have something to hide. I can disarm these charms and return them to their natural state. I'll be hidden though with a cloaking enchantment. Because Fairy Dragons are rare, most storage facilities don't have the necessary runes that would detect our particular signature. However, even I have a limit to my magic!! If I get detected without having found the eggs, then by law we would be convicted of illegal search methods," said Lina.

"So there's a time limit, what if we find the eggs though?" I wondered.

"Then, they'll be placed under arrest, or they might decide that the only way to shut us up would be to get rid of us," answered Elandor.

I clenched my claws, "And that's where I come in..."

"Indeed. Yet for this mission we cannot give you armor as it would reveal you as a Knight, rather than a bodyguard for a regulator. If things go wrong, I've also contacted a small number of humanoid knights on standby to help us fight them and cut off any escape routes. Hopefully, it won't need to come to that. However, with the increase in looting and the such, many of the comapnies have increased their company security forces in order to better protect their assets from 'theives and bandits', so we have no jurisdiction over them..." he answered.

I growled. So they would hire mercenaries to protect the slavers and bandits these companies claim to be protecting their merchandise from? How deceitful. Frankly, if they were even suspected in dealing in the smuggling of dragon eggs, their entire facility deserved to be burned to the ground. I had to be patient though, discipline was the name of the game.

The storage warehouses were located in the Industrial district of New Alveri on the eastern side of the city. I had been there a few times to pick up some goods for the various merchants in the Merchant guilds, and had escaped the brunt of the attacks. Many of the larger storage companies had facilities large enough that a full family of dragons could have lived comfortably in. In fact, an entire section of cliffside was devoted to this form of storage; the slavers must have believed that with the Knights currently stretched thin, they wouldn't be able to check them all.

Elandor directed me to land upon the ledge leading to the inside of the 'Mevlevi Keepers'. The entrance to the lair was wide enough to accomodate a dragon, while a large metal gate covered it. It looked tough and secure, in that I'd have a hard time breaking through it. I also took note of the location of the armed guards, and the weapons they carried, in case that I would have to fight them.

The gatekeeper of the storage facility was a female goblin that spoke with a scratchy voice.

"State your business..." she hissed.

Elandor dismounted me gently. "I am Ealstan... an inspector of the alchemist guild," he said, showing a fake ID, "I understand that we have a contract with your company concerning the storage of lay-line maintenance parts, and in these troubled times I merely wish to ensure personally that all the agreed upon goods are accounted for. The dragons here are for my protection and aid in my inspection. Thus, I wish to speak with the proprietor of this facility..."

I noticed that he did not mention me as a Knight. I wasn't wearing any battle armor, which immediately would have given me away, and with Lina hidden, I could pass as simply a hired mercenary. The goblin checked the identification.

"I'll contact Mr. Skarnu now..." she said.

A few minutes later, an elf came forward. He was dressed extremely professionally, as if he wanted to emphasize that his business was truly professional. Frankly, I thought he was overdoing it, which was suspicious in my eyes.

"Yes, how may I help you?" he said. He spoke far too smoothly for my comfort.

"I'm here to take a quick inventory over the merchandise for this guild. My benefactors are expecting that everything be in order,"

"I already sent the guild a full report on all the inventory I have in stock. I assure you everything is secure and accounted for," said Mr. Skarnu.

"I believe you good sir," answered Elandor, walking alongside the elf, "Yet in these chaotic times one must be especially careful wouldn't you say?"

"Very well then. Anyhow would it be all right if you left the beast by the gate?" he asked.

I couldn't help but growl. Elandor placed an arm on my leg. "I'm afraid I cannot. Again, these are desperate times, and one must proceed with extra caution. I assure you that it is fully under my control and will not bring you harm. Now, come along then dragon..."

I dared not speak a word as I followed Elandor inside. I had to play the role of dumb beast, which made me boil inside, yet I had to discipline myself and play along for the sake of the mission.

When I followed Elandor around the facility, it didn't look like anything suspicious. What I saw were parts of lay-line cables just like Mr. Skarnu claimed. Yet even so, I still couldn't help that there were quite a number of security guards for a mere 'shipping company', and Mr. Skarnu, he seemed to slick, too well-polished and silver tongued. There was just something about him that rubbed me the wrong way.

"Mr. Ealstan?" said Mr. Skarnu, "That's what you said your name was?"

"Correct,"

"Forgive me if I say this, but you don't seem to be any regulator to me. You search too thoroughly, and no regulator brings a dragon with him..." he said. My hearts skipped a beat. If he was a slaver, apparently he was sharper than I imagined. Yet Elandor took it in stride. The elvish spy master...
114121111111111122121111111211111.title: Regulators

1141211111111111221211111112111111.content:
"Ah, so you've caught me." said Elandor, the tall elf - well, taller than Mr. Skarnu who walked beside him anyways - while I lifted an eyebrow in mild panic. The warehouse owner was extremely canny if he was able to pick apart Elandor's cover story so easily. I prepared myself for immediate battle, though I gave no outward sign as I plodded slowly behind the two humanoids.

"Well, you really can't expect a business owner such as myself to get along without having some skill in this area." said Mr. Skarnu, showing extreme arrogance in his discovery. He suddenly stopped in his stride. "Care to tell me who you really are, Ealstan, or shall I show you and your… pet off of my private property?"

While I was struggling not to tear the small elf in the fancy pant suit to pieces while Elandor said, "Well, I wasn't lying when I claimed to be here to inspect your goods." Mr. Skarnu lifted a highlighted eyebrow. "I just lied about who I represent."

"And who is your employer then?" The warehouse owner peered deeply into the elf's face across from his.

"I actually represent a group of… ah, potential buyers." said Elandor without so much as twitching a single facial muscle. "You are aware of the havoc being raised in the underground markets, yes? With Kulver and Sons being forcefully put out of business, my employers have suddenly found themselves bereft of essential supplies."

For the first time, Mr. Skarnu actually looked interested rather than casually aloof. "Yes, I heard about Kulver. When is he due for the chopping block, again?"

"Sometime next month." said Elandor, and he should know, having captured the infamous opiate and rare animal smuggler himself. "But he is hardly irreplaceable. In fact, I hear that there are loads of new suppliers springing up around the city, ready for financial opportunities."

"People say a lot of things… these are hard times." said Mr. Skarnu, though he began to walk through the aisle of towering boxes once more. While it irked me not to be part of the conversation, I had the feeling that I would blow our cover almost immediately. As the two elves talked, feeling each other out and trying to trap one another in a deadly game of words, I spared a glance to the warehouse proper.

I thought I might catch a glimpse of Lina as she moved about the stacked boxes and stone walls of the vast chamber, but I saw nothing. I supposed that was a good thing after all. I was still deeply impressed at Lina's innate magical skills. I had been expecting a concealing glamor to allow her to pass unnoticed by those who observed her, but no, Lina had shimmered in the air above the landing and completely disappeared. True invisibility. I hadn't been able to detect her since, through either the flapping of her wings or even her distinct, vaguely fruity scent. I wondered how long she could keep up such a potent spell and if she had found any secret rooms yet.

"…His own sister? Truly? I never would have guessed." laughed Mr. Skarnu in an aristocratic sort of way.

"Yes, Hephaestis turned out to be quite the scoundrel." chuckled Elandor. Both elves stopped upon reaching a dead end, stone wall on one side, the wooden sides of boxes on the other two. "It seems we can go no further…" said Elandor with a vague, cautious suspicion. He casually put a palm on his sword hilt.

But Mr. Skarnu smiled disarmingly, "Well, perhaps your beast can go no further. I still don't understand why you brought that smelly thing along with you. Magic carpets are not as expensive as they once were and they require far less maitainence."

"I wasn't lying when I said it was for protection. But this one has been trained for a special trick as well."

"Oh?" asked the warehouse owner with skepticism. I wanted to grind him into wet paste with my paw.

"It can identify true dragon components from knock-offs. See?" Elandor reached into his vest pocket and withdrew his vial of dragon blood. He lifted it in the air. "True blood or false?" To Mr. Skarnu he added, "It grunts once if it's fake, twice if it's real."

It was probably the most degrading thing I'd done in my life, and I'd spent entire days emptying selling lots of week's worth of manure in the city and cleaning the orphanage cesspools; dragons were not known for their perfect bathroom hygiene. I made a show of lowering my head to Elandor's upraised fist and sniffing. I grunted twice.

Mr. Skarnu, however, cocked his head. "And how am I supposed to know that is real dragon blood?"

Elandor carefully let a single drop of the dense, precious ruby fluid pour out onto his fingertip. "Taste it."

As an Elf, who were not generally concerned with close proximity between males of the species, Mr. Skarnu carefully took Elandor's finger and licked the single drop off of it. The warehouse keeper shivered, "Ah, that is very fresh, and very pure." He paused momentarily and looked at Elandor suspiciously, "What reason do you have to keep such valuable material at hand?"

Elandor looked at Mr. Skarnu with a grin on his face. "Virility." he said with a wink.

Mr. Skarnu grinned conspiratorially. "You are my kind of buyer, Ealstan." At last he looked strongly at the elf before him, trying to judge something I could not see. Then he gave a strange whistle, clearly a specific tune. Suddenly a door opened in one of the boxes ahead, not magic, but extremely well made so that it blended in with the irregular wooden surface. "This way, Ealstan. I'll get you acquainted with the merchandise we have in stock." Mr Skarnu spared a glance up at me, the first time he'd looked at me since we'd arrived. "The beast will have to wait out here."

Elandor looked for a long moment up at me. Then he said, "There's no need. It will clearly not be able to fulfill its purpose in here. Return to the entrance and await my return."

"I will not have that thing galavanting about my warehouse unattended!" said Mr. Skarnu.

"Rest at ease, friend." said Elandor, "It is well trained. And I will pay for any damages that it causes, but I assure you there will be none." he said the last strongly looking up at me. As if I would exact petty revenge by flattening a few boxes here and there... well certainly not while we were working.

The two elves started chatting again as they entered the box. From what I could see inside before the door closed, Elandor had not entered a secret room so much as a secret complex, built into the piles of boxes which filled the vast chamber. Where it would lead, I couldn't fathom. I wished him good luck and for his safe return.

So it was that I was feeling quite useless as I plodded my way back to the main landing. I could see the iron gates built into the cave entrance over the boxes and the sunlight filtering through. It was hard to believe that it still wasn't even noon. Before I'd even gotten halfway, back, however, I head a tiny voice in my ear. It was Lina! I forced my expression to fade after my momentary excitement. "Where is Elandor?" I was about to answer, but she spoke again, "Wait! Don't answer, you're still being watched." I had the vague feeling that Lina was flitting about my head, but I knew only because I could feel the air moving about me slightly. Lina's spell still made her virtually undetectable. "Just listen, I..."
1141211111111111221211111112111111.title: The Buyer

11412111111111112212111111121111111.content:
"Turn left ahead." said Lina and I complied with my unseen companion's instruction. It felt odd, especially since the faerie dragon was alternately on one side of my body or the other, barely disturbing the air as she passed, like nothing more than an ethereal spirit. Frankly, at that moment, I found myself quite jealous of my lairmate's natural abilities. As for myself, I could not even speak aloud for the eyes of humanoids sitting atop high stacks of crates were on me at all times.

Lina knew of my instruction to head for the landing - I supposed Elandor had known that Lina would contact me at some point between here and there - and guided me in an off center course towards it. "It's just off from the center of the room. Thank goodness for the smell, or I would never have found it…"

I burned to ask Lina what she had found. Fortunately for me, she elaborated as I continued to pad slowly and calmly down the wide aisle of stacked shipping crates. Their tracking runes and serial numbers glowed faintly in the gloom. "I've had a hard time in here." whispered Lina, "It was a while before I figured out that the smuggling areas aren't hidden by magic. That I could have detected. They have just crafted the entrances into the sides of these boxes to look like the regular sides of the box."

I took in the irregular shapes of the crates. I don't know why I didn't notice it earlier. Some of the wooden structures had obviously been here for many years, dust and cobwebs were evidence of that, while a normal warehouse, while never empty, would usually be completely turned out at least once every couple years at the very longest. Some of the boxes also, though it was a little hard to see with the crowding, were exceptionally large. One I saw within the inter of a log rectangle of stacked boxes, the corners formed by aisles, was even large enough to admit a creature of my size. I knew of no creature that could shift or carry such a burden, for while dragons were extremely strong, we had notoriously small airborne weight capacities. These warehouse operators were obviously hiding something, practically in plain sight. I saw an orc above notice my lingering gaze on the boxes, he scowled, showing his yellow fangs and leapt down from his perch, disappearing behind the boxes.

Lina apparently saw him too, for she said, "Hurry, Darzhja, I don't think we have much time left."

The last turn led away from the main entrance and down a narrow aisle that I had to squeeze into in order to pass. I hugged my wings to myself and stepped forward hurriedly, one paw in front of the other; the space was wide enough for perhaps a horse and rider, or a faerie dragon for that matter, but it was very cramped for a Regal Bronze such as myself. "Ahead on the left, Darzhja." said Lina, just a notch louder.

I sucked air through my nose. I no longer needed Lina's direction. I knew the smell of my own kind. Ahead, the boxes got higher and higher, but I didn't slow. I steped on a small crate, it burst under my weight like a grape. Some copper tubes, as if for an alchemical set, tumbled out, rattling on the stone floor as clear as bells. Someone shouted in the distance. "Darzhja!" said Lina, but I already understood. I raced forward as fast as I could, my nose leading the way.

I stopped, my snout pressed against a section of wood box that was identical to all the rest around it as well as the boxes before. But I could smell the dragon scent, pungent, and sulfurous, familiar. And not just any dragon, young dragon. Some instinct told me that this was not at all the place where these scents should be.

Lina suddenly reappeared on the ground in front of me. She let out a sigh of relief as she allowed herself to lapse the concentration needed for her invisibility. "Darzhja, there's something behind here, but I couldn't open it. It's not magic so I-"

I smashed the side of the crate in with my front paw. Wood splintered and cracked and I saw metal hinges and some sort of locking mechanism bend away amongst the debris. Dragon scent poured out. Lina was shocked, but definitely not as shocked as the smallish humanoid - halfling perhaps - who was sitting on a stool just inside the crate. He had his mouth hanging open at the sight of Lina and the side of my face, which was just about as large as the entrance I had opened, a glass mug of a foul smelling brew fell from his grubby hand and shattered on the hay strewn floor. In the corner of the small hidden room was a brazier, a coal fire under it smoldering while on top, an iron brace cradled a single, precious egg.

Both Lina and I growled. The halfling let out a choked yelp and made for a side exit into the box complex. "Lina!" I said, but she was already darting forward.

She tackled the little humanoid and despite Lina's diminutive stature for a dragon, she was still a giant compared to the spec of a halfling. Pinning him to the floor in a way that I could not have done without killing him, Lina quickly extended her wings and flapped them vigorously, showering the hobbit with glittering dust. The tiny man gasped and stopped struggling, a dreamy look and a dopy grin overtaking his features. Lina got off of him, though her prey remained prone. "Hopefully I haven't given him a lethal dose…" she gave a sidelong look to the halfling who was now studying the lines on the backs of his hairy hands with extreme fascination.

I didn't care in the slightest if the man lived or died, not when he was in the same room as a precious egg, no matter if it was properly warmed or not. I stuck my nose into the room and sniffed heartily. "There are more eggs, I can smell others." I said with urgency, wishing I could fit into the tiny space.

Lina looked down the passage further into the compound. "Maybe I can find them..." At that time however, a deep brass gong began to sound in the distance; an alarm. she looked up at me with panicked stricken eyes, "We're out of time Darzhja!" The faerie dragon rounded on the single precious egg, her tail spinning and sending the table and chair flying against the wall where they broke into yet more splinters, and carefully took it in her forearms. Effortlessly, she fluttered up and out of the room. "We have the proof we need now. Let's rescue Elandor and alert the other knights so they can raid this place."

I growled, aware that every second the guards were marshaling their forces and also knew exactly where we were. But the other eggs... "Lina, I smelled other eggs, maybe hatchlings too. We have to find them, they might be moved out of here before the other Knights get here."

Lina was torn. but her sense of duty to the Knights was perhaps more strongly engrained that mine, "I… I know, but we can't help anyone if we're dead… and…"

Lina was hesitating, I could see it in her eyes. She didn't want to kill, even with proof that these humanoids were egg stealers and trafficking in our kind's young. As a faerie dragon, perhaps it was not in her nature to stand and fight, so I suppose I could forgive her, but right now, every fiber in me called out for the blood of these would be egg snatchers. But she did raise an important point. Elandor remained missing, worse, perhaps in the hands of the warehouse owner by now. The instinct to go after the eggs was strong, but so was my urge to see my new elven friend and partner delivered from danger. Either way, I knew I wasn't going with Lina.

"Lina," I said. "Take the egg and get back to our strike team. I'm going to…"
11412111111111112212111111121111111.title: What the Boxes Hide

114121111111111122121111111211111111.content:
-Written by Shalion

"But what about Elandor?!" Lina cried as she hovered in the air, holding the single recovered dragon egg which was damning evidence of wrongdoing in the warehouse. "He was with those men when you last saw him wasn't he?"

I bared my teeth. The elvish spy had indeed gone with the smugglers and entered the box complex. It was very possible that he was now a hostage and in need of assistance… But somehow I doubted it. Elandor was quite skilled and experienced after all, I could tell in just the short time that I'd known him. The eggs, on the other hand were helpless.

"Elandor can handle himself. Saving the little ones is our first priority," I said gruffly, not inviting debate. The alarm was still sounding, gongs echoed from all corners of the vast chamber. I had to move and so did Lina. Still, the faerie dragons seemed torn. I gently prodded her with a wingtip to restore her senses.

"Come on Lina. You have to get the egg away from here."

My lairmate seemed to focus. "Right, Darzhja." She afford me a long look, full of concern, "Stay alive, OK?"

I grinned up at her and motioned with my snout to get going.

A small smile crept onto Lina's face. "Close your eyes, Darzhja. I'm going to give us both some cover to get out of this hole."

I immediately followed her instruction. There was no longer any doubt in me as to the potency of the small dragoness's abilities. I heard Lina flap her way up and there was shouting all around. The guards who had been placed at high points in the forest of boxes all immediately began to train their crossbows on the small green dragonesss. While most humanoid weaponry was more a nuisance than a threat to me, Lina was another story...

Just as they began to fire, however, there came a blinding light of the intensity of the sun. I could feel the heat of it through the scales on my face. Humanoids all around staggered and moaned in agony at the sudden brilliance, covering their eyes and often dropping their weapons. I could see the light even through my scaly outerlids, I could see the tracelines in red around the scales which shone a metallic bronze.

The flare lingered for several seconds and I did not waste a single one of them. I groped my way up the mountain of boxes, my claws crushing and sinking into the wood as I dragged myself up. As soon as I felt I was at the top of the narrow aisle, I spread my wings and launched myself forward, in the direction that the tunnel in the small room below me had been leading. The light now behind me, I ventured to open my eyes a little. I could see the boxes passing swiftly below me. To the sides, most of the guards had abandoned their posted or were lying in fetal positions, their faces protected in the crooks of their arms.

One flap, two, then the flare extinguished itself. I had precious little time before I would draw fire from the whole rest of the room. I just hoped that enough of the guards had dropped their weapons or been blinded by Lina's light. Ahead of me, I saw the unusually large box that I had passed earlier, the one that looked more a house than a shipping container. It was almost directly ahead of me and I'd been following the flow of boxes, keeping a mental picture of where the aisles were which would break any possible hidden path, so I knew that it had to be part of the system.

I built up some reckless speed, flapping my way to the large box, and I began to receive some half hearted crossbow fire. I paid it no heed, the side of the box rushing towards me. At the last moment, I closed my eyes and covered my face as I slammed into the side of it like a battering ram.

I met more resistance than I thought I would, but still, I was a large enough projectile that I sheared off half of the roof of the large box. My forequarters were inside of the box proper while my hindlegs still rested on the boxes, or rather box debris at this point piled up against the outside of the extra large box. I coughed with the wood dust filling the air and looked down. There I saw the shocked faces of several shady looking humanoids, but also...
114121111111111122121111111211111111.title: Warehouse Confrontation Part I

1141211111111111221211111112111111111.content:
A large clutch of eggs. My eyes went wide in absolute shock and outrage. With an innate instinct that only a dragoness possessed, I could sense the fear and uncertainly emanating from the unborn souls of the little ones, pining for their mothers. I'd never felt so violated in my entire life.

I turned to face the infant stealers, and roared at the top of my breath, only inches from their faces. The humanoids stared up at me, shivering and babbling in panic. They backed away as far away as they could from the eggs and huddled in the corner of the box.

"I-I'm sorry!! Please don't kill me!! Please don't kill me!! Please don..." begged one of them.

Yet I was in no mood for negotiation or mercy. The poor mothers who'd had their babies stolen from them screamed for bloody vengeance.

"Save your pleas for the ancestors egg-stealers!! You have sealed your fate!!" I screamed.

Consumed by rage, I reared back with my claw and swiped at the gathered group. I caught the entire group with my claw, lifting them clear of the large box and sending them flying in all directions. Their bodies broke with sickening cracks against the walls of the various boxes, crumbling limply to the floor all around.

I immediately shifted my gaze back toward the inside of the box, where the little ones lay packed in straw like nothing more than brass tubes or alchemical equipment. I reached out with my neck brushed my nose against each of them.

"Its okay little ones... Mommy is here now. I'll protect you..." I reassured. The aura of fear from the unborn dragons lessened slightly, knowing that at least somebody was there now.

Yet my attention was diverted by a sharp pain against my side. A crossbow bolt had lodged itself between a crack in my scales at the base of my tail, I immediately swung around and noticed a humanoid leaping across a pile of boxes attempting to get away. He wasn't fast enough, as I charged forward and slammed onto the pile of boxes, sending bolts, metal parts and wood chips flying everywhere. More importantly, the crossbowman lost his balance and fell with a dull thud to the stone floor below. He tried to limp away but when my shadow hung over him, he curved his head back toward me and screamed. I crushed the rat with the flat side of my tail, unable to help but feel a distinct satisfaction at the sound of the egg stealer's bones snapping underneath, and blood spattering and staining the ground.

Looking to the side, I saw what appeared to be the entire company mercenary force was gathered down below, and began to climb over the hills of boxes. I snorted with anger and contempt.

Let them all come, they would all learn the fatal mistake of taking on a Knight in battle!!

I gazed about, looking for something that could make their climb a bit more difficult. A great pile of wooden bits, metal parts laid scattered about the floor. An idea formed in my mind.

I swept my tail forward, sending a massive hailstorm of metallic bits into the air. I heard a scream of panicked humanoids below as they attempted to cover themselves. One of the metal projectiles caught an axeman directly in the forehead, sending him tumbling back toward the ground. Another had had his belly sliced open by a shard of wood, his guts spilling out. Several more lost their balance upon the boxes they were scaling and tumbled all the way back down to the hard stone ground.

Yet the mercs still continued on. One thing I'd learned about the humanoids, both good and evil, was that they could be surprisingly stubborn in the face of suicidal odds.

"Form up you cowards!! Anyone who flees will see their families have a hard time of it!!" shouted a scrubby looking orc, who appeared to be the leader of the company mercs. That still didn't stop a few, who immediately ran for it, but the threat of retribution against their families kept most in line.

I snarled. Coerced or not, I was not about to let any of these theieves near the eggs. Thus, while the merc leader was busy still trying to instill backbone into his comrades, I reared my neck forward and breathed a plume of fire at the gathered humanoids. It was the first time I had ever used my fire against sentient beings in anger, and immediately a large group of them was engulfed in the flame. They screamed and wailed and fell to the floor, the smell of burnt flesh instantly filled the cavern. The boxes caught in the blast began to burn merrily, filling the chamber with an acrid smoke.

Seeing this dramatic display of carnage was enough to send half of the remaining mercs running for their lives, screaming in panic. Yet the remainder clutched at their weapons, approaching me carefully. I realized I'd made a mistake. The mercenaries had purposely placed their inferior troops up front to absorb the brunt of the breath weapon, leaving the more hardened and experienced veterans to deal with me.

"Form up mercs!! The beast can only use its breath weapon once every few minutes!! We can still put it down and escape with the cargo before the Knights arrive!!" screamed the apparent orcish sergent.

I was left facing three groups of four mercs each. Obviously, they were trying to surround me from all sides so I couldn't get them all, or that they might be able to sneak through the forest of boxes behind me and snatch an egg before I could respond. I later learned that was the usual strategy for stealing dragon eggs; usually it was a dragoness whose mate had left her; the male would usually guard the entrance itself to prevent any crooks from infiltrating the cave in the first place, but when a female was alone she had to stay right on top of her eggs, but in doing so allowed enemies to flank her.

I immediately lashed at the group on my left with a quick swipe with a claw. Three of the mercs staggered out of the way, but one was knocked aside, having lost his balance where my claw crushed the wooden floor under him. The hairy man with his sword and his spear fell down the slope of the stacked boxes, fortunately, for me at least, landing on his helmet at the bottom and breaking his neck. The groups at the center and right immediately tried to close in. I lashed out with my neck and snapped my jaws, forcing the center group back momentarily, and in a single motion, swung with my flexible tail and caught two of them with the blade, their bodies cleaved in twain as the weight of it plunged into boxes under them. My tail came away draped with bloodstained wool blankets, utterly unsuitable for market at this point.

Yet in that time, the left group had managed to close in. I was unable to dodge as one of them brought their great axe down on my flank. I let out a roar of pain, and lashed about, smashing a few boxes under me, before in a rage, I whipped my head forward and took the offending human in my jaws. He let out a scream as he vainly tried to pull himself free, but I broke his worthless life with a single bite and tossed the puppet-like body far away into the neighboring pile of boxes.. The flesh wound bled more than a little, yet it only served to make me angrier.

Seeing that they wouldn't just be able to get by me in one quick charge, the remaining mercs kept their distance. They waited tantalizingly out of range.

"Come on cowardly beast!! Are you going to let a group of scum like us taunt you like that!!" the orc who I'd first seen taunted. I wanted to jump forward and shut him up for good, but I was disciplined enough to realize that it would have given the other thieves a chance to jump in and snatch one of the eggs.

"Aren't you all so proud of yourselves? Working for a scumbag like Skarnu?" I answered. I realized that all I had to do was keep them away and buy time. Whenever one of the groups crept forward, I slashed at them to make them jump back. Every so often, I managed to get one of them, but there was always one or two more guards climbing up the side of the pile to take their place it seemed. I also made sure to periodically take a quick look at the eggs down below, to make sure they were all there. It would be a disaster to discover that I had held off the troops only to find they had managed to sneak away with the cargo from under my haunches. The process repeated itself for quite some time. The one thing about humanoid opponents was that there always were a a lot of them, and that there never seemed to be a limit to their numbers. As far as I was concerned, they may have well sent the entire company security forces to secure their 'cargo'. Yet they could all come, I was not going to fail in my duty.

Then, coming from the edge of the hall, was a chorus of alarmed voices. At first I couldn't make out the quick alarmed common, but after listening in I found that
1141211111111111221211111112111111111.title: Warehouse Confrontation Part II

11412111111111112212111111121111111111.content:
An alarmed looking mercenary called up from the aisle below, "Mosgov!!" shouted the merc to the orc standing in front of me, still brandishing his long spear, "Government forces are here!! We've got to get out of here!!"

"What? Already!! Can't you hold them off? We've got to secure the cargo!!" the orcish leader insisted. If they had had any chance of escaping, they should have started running now, yet their leader's reluctance to leave the fight cost them.

There was another series of crashes, this time they came much closer.

"Too late!!" yelled another gruff looking warehouse guard who had dropped his weapons and was running flat out towards the back of the warehouse.

Immediately, no fewer than twenty humanoid guards in full armor came flooding up the aisle beside the huge stack of now mostly shattered boxes I was balancing on; off and away, I saw the outlines of dragons landing on the shelf where the sunlight was pouring into the chamber through the entrance. They were dropping off their passengers and then winging their way into the warehouse. With alacrity and glee in my hearts, I roared down to the shining soldiers below. "Up here!" I shouted

Turning back to the rather disheveled looking guards in front of me, I was intent on making sure they didn't try anything desperate now that the warriors of the Holy Knights of Nod were upon them. But then, suddenly, Lina was there, having flown in along with the rest of the strike team. I noticed that she was no longer carrying her single dragon egg.

"Throw down your weapons now mercs!!" shouted Lina, hovering above the crowded humanoids opposite from me so that they were quite surrounded. I had thought that she must have been intent on preventing any bloodshed to our own troops, but the grave look on her face told me that she had been predicting what was to come next.

The rough looking soldiers-for-hire gazed back in forth with alarm, their tall boots shifting on the wooden debris and metal parts under them, seeing that there was no way out of the situation. I watched them all begin to reach for daggers sheathed in their breast pockets in a grim, practiced sort of way; after all, dead men couldn't be interrogated. The orc leader stared at me with with a black fire in his orange pupiled eyes as he reached for his own dagger.

"I don't think so!!" squeaked Lina and she dove into the crowd.

She flapped her wings above them, her downstroke very nearly brushing the tops of their leather helmets, and showered them with her mind-altering dust. They all began to wobble unsteadily. Wasting no time, the humanoid Knights finally came up over the edge of the stack rushed forward to quickly tackle and bind the former warehouse guards and now prisoners of the state.

With that, I finally was able to relax a little bit. The sounds of battle, ringing metal and occasionally the sizzle or whistling of a spell, filled the chamber, but my part in the battle was done now that the eggs under my tail were safe. And the battle was certainly not a long one. Any resistance that there was had been defeated in about a minute judging by the sounds echoing through the large chamber of the warehouse. With a heavy sigh of relief, I turned about, letting the armored Knight haul away the dazed guards. Carefully, so carefully, I brushed away the wooden splinters and debris that had fallen on the crates containing the precious eggs with the back of my claw which seemed mammoth and clumsy in comparison to the tiny, fragile things.

Lina helped me in moving the eggs down into the aisle as I no longer felt that they were safe in the greatly damaged remnants of the large box I'd fought over. I did not trust anybody else but another dragoness to aid me in this task, fearing they might drop the little ones or that they were perhaps theives in disguise. When they were on the stone floor, I wrapped my body around them, surrounding them with my warm flesh so that they might not die of cold. I couldn't help but hum contentedly, basking in the aura of the relieved and happy little ones.

An indeterminate amount of time later - for me anyways - a large blue dragon clad in armor found me and Lina. Even under that armor, I recognized him. It was Lorath, that companion of Fangorn that I had briefly met before heading for the trial. Honestly, had it been Fangorn and had he seen me guarding over a clutch of eggs, I wouldn't have known how I would have reacted.

"Darzhja, are the eggs secured?" he asked.

"They are, thank goodness..." I panted, lifting my head.

Lorath grinned in relief, "That's a relief. You did an extraordinary feat holding them off for us Darzhja. I'd say that I now see why Fangorn was so intrigued about you," he answered, grinning slightly.

I couldn't help but avert my gaze for a moment.

"Never mind about him anyhow. Give me the details of the attack..." said Lorath.

Quickly and in the professional way of the Knights that I was still learning, I told him everything that had happened since we entered the warehouse; how Lina had found the secret door and the single egg, how I had crashed into the large box and found the hidden clutch, and how - I realized with a hiss through my sharp teeth - how Elandor was still missing and the circumstances in which we had departed.

Lorath frowned, "You shouldn't have left your partner like that. Even though he was the senior member of your team, as a dragon, you have certain responsibilities to your assigned rider." His sea green eyes were hard under his metal helmet. "That was terribly irresponsible of you to leave him. We can only hope that the spy master was skilled enough to avoid being captured."

The brazen part of me wanted to stand up and shout, to defend myself. After all, Elandor had all but commanded me to depart. But I took the captain's rebuke in silence, I hugged myself about the eggs a little tighter.

Then Lorath's eyes softened, his eyes no longer a hurricane so much as a slow mist. "But I expect that Elandor has eluded capture, Darzhja. He has something of a reputation for miraculous escapes." said the large blue drake with a grin, "In fact, he may even be in pursuit of this 'Mr. Skarnu' character as we speak, though I doubt that is his real name."

I grinned up at Lorath and Lina fluttered down to the stone floor and pressed herself against my foreleg. Lina said, "Regardless, we have men searching every corner of this building. Chances are, that both of them have already been found."

Just then, another humanoid guard rushed towards us from around a corner, he had to vault over some fallen timbers clogging the aisle.

"Sir Lorath!! We've managed to round up the last of the mercs and we're sending men to look into the hidden chambers!" shouted the human Knight.

"Good!! Take them into custody immediately so that these egg-stealing scum can be questioned!!" growled Lorath. I couldn't help but be impressed by his professionalism. He'd been very laid back before, yet he knew when to be serious.

"Anyhow Darzhja, I'm loath to have to ask you this, but now that the eggs are secured we need to have them taken back to the Temple's medical wing to care for them, along with hopefully getting these hatchlings back to their parents," said Lorath calmly.

"Oh...okay...sir..." I said hesitantly. It was extremely difficult for me, as a young dragoness, to simply step away from the eggs that I had spent the past several minutes guarding, even though they weren't my own. Still, I was very much appreciative that Lorath recognized the situation I was in. Fangorn probably would have said something either very callous, me being insubordinate, or perhaps something perverted.

I watched as the humanoid guards carefully secured the eggs and store them. The little ones didn't want to leave my warmth, and I could feel them pine to stay with me, and even though I knew they were being taken to a safe place, my instincts still gnawed at me to snatch them away from these potential egg stealers and keep them safe.

"Its going to be all right Darzhja," assured Lina, "They'll all be back with their mommies soon!!"

I only hoped she was right, though my mind told me that inevitably, a few of them might be orphaned, as I had been. If they were, then at least I knew of one place where they would surely be safe...
11412111111111112212111111121111111111.title: Reinforcements

114121111111111122121111111211111111111.content:
Suddenly, I felt the pain in my side, and I winced. In my rage, I had not noticed how the axe wound that one of the mercs had given me had been aggravated a bit.

"Darzhja!!" squealed Lina with shock and concern, "What a terrible wound!!"

I fixed my teeth together. It was still bleeding, perhaps worse than before although the blow had been a rather small one. "Its nothing... I can still perform my duties without any hindrance."

Lorath came forward and sniffed the wound in my flank, I could smell the oil of his gleaming armor and the slightly musky scent of his scales, "That may be, but you still need to get that fixed up right away. I don't want to alarm you but the weapon that inflicted that may have been poisoned. Its probably nothing major, but I'm ordering you to head for the Medical ward straight away just to make sure."

I clicked my teeth together. I wanted to help out more, but even if I was uninjured I probably wouldn't have been doing much anyhow now that all the mercs had been subdued. I was a fighter, and wasn't quite as good with the investigative stuff.

"Very well sir," I answered.

"As for you Lina, I'll still need your services to help us interrogate these mercs. Your fairy dust will be able to get their gums flapping quick..."

"One batch of fairy dust coming right up!!" exclaimed Lina, turning a flip back into the air. The tiny dragoness then turned back toward me, "Sorry if you're feeling a little left out Darzhja. Anyhow, I'll see you back at the dorm later tonight!!" she squeaked, smiling.

I smiled back, and headed back outside. When I got outside, I saw a number of humanoid soldiers forming a perimeter around the entrance of the warehouse, keeping the curious onlookers away. I noticed that when I got up into the air - my side aching quite a bit more than I thought it would - there was still quite a bit of daylight left. Though the whole investigation and the fight had seemed to have lasted a long time, really, no more than a few hours had passed since I had spoken to Lady Scabia about the mission. I figured that she probably didn't expect that the investigation of the storage facility would transform into a takedown of a major smuggling company, as well as the capture of slavers. Yet as I flew back to the Temple, I couldn't help but feel proud of myself, that already I had done my part to protect Nod from evil, and felt very Knightly indeed.

The medical ward of the Holy Knights of Nod was clearly marked, the large landing, upon which multiple injured dragons could be treated if they were unable to be moved further in if need be, was painted in severe tones of red and pale yellow strips. I landed heavily, clutching my side, I could feel the blood welling between my digits, thick, gooey and dark as it clotted. I'd taken worse than the axe wound in the course of my sparring career, so I was not terribly concerned.

Just inside, there was a large open chamber, color coded strips lead from the main entrance along to floor and into the branching tunnels beyond. Everyone here, from the humanoid physicians to the dragon orderlies moved professionally and briskly to their destinations. The place was unsettlingly quiet for a chamber with so many occupants. I thought back to the overcrowding of the orphanage, which was still doubling as a makeshift infirmary, and how many of those patients could have fit in the ward. Then again, the interior of the Temple of the Knights was a rather exclusive place compared to the city at large.

At my feet, there was a long stone desk made for humanoid height. Standing behind a counter covered with sheafs of paper and parchment was what first appeared to be a female human, though her olive skin and slanted eyes hinted at some fey blood in her background. "Greetings, Lady…"

"Darzhja. Just Darzhja." I said, introducing myself.

"I'm Adrial." said the clerk in a cheerful voice. I was still rather unused to humanoids being so familiar with dragons here in the temple, the human female seeming perfectly at ease with me towering over her. A drop of blood fell from my flank and landed on the cool, but perfectly dry floor. Adrial sniffed. "It seems you are in need of some patching up, Darzhja."

I grunted an affirmation. "My captain also mentioned something about… poisoning?" I said a little unsurely, not wanting to sound like a hypochondriac.

"I'll let your physician be the judge of that." She shuffled among her papers, the documents tiny and the letters indecipherable scrawl from my vantage point. Grabbing a quill, she asked, "Now can I just get your ID number and your mentor's name? I assume you are a new recruit, yes?"

I took a step back. "My mentor is Lady Scabia… but I don't know my ID number…"

The clerk sighed. "Well, I need your ID to know what care you are qualified for. If I don't have it, I will have to charge you the full price out of your hoard account."

I grimaced, showing my fangs. "Really?" I did not want to contemplate a single gem going missing from my minuscule hoard. "What if… I…" I hesitated, trying to figure out if I could just turn around and lick my wound like a dog rather than face some outrageous bill for getting stitched up.
114121111111111122121111111211111111111.title: Just a Flesh Wound

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
"Her number is 10278." said a gruff voice from a tunnel off to the side.

I turned my head. Of all the dragons that had to make an appearance, it had to be Fangorn. He looked somewhat pallid shambling into the lobby, holding his tail well off the ground and very stiffly. A female dwarf followed him hurriedly, struggling to keep up with the dragon's large stride. "Corporal! Wait! I haven't finished the dressing, you're going to rip your stitches again!"

Fangorn sighed raggedly and came to a stop. He took a few steps to the side and laid down with this back against the wall. My eyes narrowed suspiciously "How is it that you know my identification number, Fangorn?"

The corporal cleared this throat and ignored me as the dwarf busied herself about the red and raw wound on the underside of the drake's tail.

I had to take a deep breath to calm myself, "Fangorn, sir!"

The bronze drake smirked, but then twitched as the dwarf pulled on one of the thick black cords which was currently binding his flesh together. "Hold still!" she chided, "You squirm worse than a hatchling." It provided me some small satisfaction to see Fangorn in pain, but then I looked at the wound I'd inflicted on him in my fervor to join the Knights, and it was far more severe than I'd realized. I saw that I'd actually lifted a flap of skin and flesh away from his tail. About 80 stitches lined the wound, holding down the flap so that it would heal seamlessly, although likely still with permanent scarring, I was shocked as to the damage I'd caused him, though I couldn't be moved to feel badly for him.

Fangorn was long in replying, as if considering the benefits and risks of conversation with me. Rather than addressing my question, he decided to address my staring in the rudest possible way. "Do I detect amusement with my predicament Darzhja?" Admittedly, I did, yet I wasn't about to let him know about it with a reply.

Yet I was certainly not prepared for what he said next, "You like what you see? I certainly know a few better places than this for me to give you a better look." he finished with a chortle.

My eyes grew wide as saucers and let out a hiss. With my right wing, I slapped him on the snout. The dwarf backed away from the two dragons with a practiced agility as Fangorn shifted his weight with the blow. He growled and lifted a claw to his scaled cheek. "A bit touchy now aren't we?" he said, as if I were the one overstepping boundaries.

I didn't care if I was. Even though I assumed that one was not supposed to hit a superior officer, Fangorn was an arrogant jerk, always bringing up those rude insinuations and the irritating way he kept popping up at the most random times, he deserved it.

"Just admit it, Fangorn. You're stalking me." I accused.

I saw his eyes slip to the female dwarf at our feet; her arms were crossed in front of her generous bosom. Then he loosened his wings in a disarming shrug, retreating. "So, you would believe I would rip my stitches on purpose just so that I would be here waiting for you? A bit paranoid now are we?"

His excuse sounded reasonable enough, yet considering that it was Fangorn, I wouldn't have put it past him to intentionally injure himself to meet me on false pretenses.

"Tell me how you knew my ID number." I demanded for the second time.

Fangorn hesitated for a brief moment, before composing himself, "I was your escort…" said Fangorn, "It was my job to know certain details about you, to help you through the integration process."

"Then why couldn't you just say that!" I hissed.

"I thought you would have already figured it out Darzhja…" he replied.

I snorted, "Maybe, but you don't have to be such a jerk about it. Why can't you be kind and understanding like Lorath is?"

"What?!" said Fangorn, his jaw dropping. "Lorath?"

There was a startling intensity in the drake's eyes. I seriously hadn't expected Fangorn to be jealous of Lorath, but now that he was truly riled, I was going to milk it for all it was worth.

"That's right Fangorn, I'm working for him now. Unlike you, he actually cared enough to send me here after getting injured, or perhaps you just didn't notice me bleeding all over the floor where I stand?" I growled.

Fangorn's claws dug into the stone as if it were little more than brittle chalk. His wide eyes expression was so full of shock and anger that I was actually rather afraid of what emotions I'd sent into play within the unstable Knight. Yet Fangorn being Fangorn, he quickly screwed his jaw back to its usual self-assured expression, "Well, Lorath has always been quite the charmer, but don't think for a moment that he's as pious as he'd like everyone to believe."

My hearts were pounding. What by the Ancestors was wrong with Fangorn? I was fully set to defend Lorath despite the short time that I'd known him and the fact that it had been basically Fangorn who'd introduced us. I had gotten the sense that while their personalities had been different, Lorath and Fangorn were actually pretty good friends.

"What's wrong with acting nice... Sir? Besides, I'm better off with the people I'm working with than with you."

However, before we could launch into a tirade on the absent drake's credentials, I felt a wing gently pull me to the side, a familiar odor basking over me.

"Come along now, Darzhja." said Lady Scabia. I relaxed unresistingly into her grasp.

Fangorn, however was still smoldering. "Lady Scabia, me and Darzhja were just having a brief word. If you could-"

The green dragoness turned on him, "You're dismissed, corporal. Or perhaps I should ask your nurse here what sorts of topics you two were exchanging before I dropped in?"

Fangorn hung his head in a most satisfying manner. "No madam."

"Then I suggest you take your treatment and move along. In fact, I think I will have a word with Lieutenant Hazzorah if you continue to linger here. Everyone's too busy to afford slackers shirking their duties in the medical center."

Fangorn swallowed in obvious fear. "That won't be necessary, Madam."

"Then I suggest you let your nurse perform her duties and be on your way." said Lady Scabia as she ushered me away down a tunnel on the opposite side of the lobby. However, before I turned away, I couldn't help but take a moment but to stick my tongue out at him. Fangorn merely snorted, seeming rather amused, before turning his head away; the dwarven nurse moved back in to finish dressing his wound. If he were but a tenth as nice as Lorath, I probably would have liked him a lot. I let out a sigh. Things were always so weird with Fangorn. As things turned out, however, I was merely trading one uncomfortable position for another.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Fangorn being Fangorn
