I've got no choice but to report you
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
I tried to keep my thoughts off of any potential encounters with Thereesa. Yet the more I tried to banish these thoughts, the more they would return, more potent than ever.

“You know what Lina? Maybe I have you to blame for this, but I can’t help but be curious now,” I admitted, surprising myself at how casual I sounded.

Lina gasped, “Really?”

“All I was thinking was that I should keep my mind open to new things, even if they are rather strange. Who knows? It might be interesting to try once…” I added. Lina started giggling again.

I let out a yawn. “Anyhow, I’ll think about it. Its getting rather late anyhow, so we should get some sleep…”

Lina hummed in agreement. “Sweet dreams Darzhja…”

“You too Lina…” I yawned. I curled up into a ‘C’, Lina taking her customary spot atop me, before I fell asleep.


-------------------------

When I woke up the following morning, I woke up knowing for the first time as a knight what I could expect and what my routines were. I raced down the corridor with Lina. Tsarra gave me her customary bitchy taunting. Thereesa not so accidentally rubbed against me and giggled. Then I took my place on the training grounds.

“Recruits!! Given the increased troubles that have been going on in the city, I have deemed it fit to intensify your training regimen accordingly!!” hissed Shadia. Part of me was thrilled because it would get me into the action sooner, but on the other claw, it meant spending more time with the hated Lieutenant.

“Now, instead of only training in the morning, all Apprentice Knights will undergo an additional three hour training session during the afternoon, unless otherwise notified by your mentors. If you think I’ve been harsh so far…trust me, you haven’t seen anything yet…”

“I still expect you to perform your other daily duties without fail, and those who shirk their duties will suffer accordingly!!” she screamed.

Lieutenant Shadia had not been kidding when she said she would intensify our training. Now, every day was like that horrible first day of training when Shadia had taken it upon herself to torment me. One day was dedicated solely to strength and conditioning. The day after that, she had us practice various maneuvers in flight. Then, there was a day at the obstacle course, navigating through treacherous terrain. Another day was dedicated toward endurance.

Thankfully, sparring session was something that I looked forward to, and in that aspect I could say without false modesty that I excelled above all the other initiates. I was too strong for the medium sized dragons, too skilled for those that were my size, and too fast and agile for the Sky-Swallowers. While the initiate Knights were all proficient with standard defense techniques, having had these drilled while they were adolescents, what separated me from the others was my array of unconventional dueling techniques that I’d learned working for Mr. Marcus in his small fighting ring in the market district. For instance, I would kick up a clod of dirt with my wing at my opponent, which would distract and disorient my opponent enough for me to close in and pin him or her. Or, similar as I had with my battle with Kaj, I would hook my tailbone around that of my opponent, and then maneuver myself to a favorable position.

I took particular satisfaction in beating up that vile, poisonous whore Tsarra. Had she actually been allowed to use her poison, it would have been far more dangerous, yet as it turned out her raw fighting technique was frankly inadequate. She was the one who always spread those poisonous rumors about me, and the fact that her parents happened to be influential Knights seemed to give her the right to look down on everybody. While she and many of those in her clique still despised me, I did gain quite a bit of grudging respect, if only I because I was able to always put them in their place during sparring.

Thereesa was pretty much fawning over me after these fights, and seemed to grow more and more determined to... cuddle up with me. I hadn’t told her I was curious on taking up on her offer, however, she seemed to be able to sense it. She would always know exactly when to give me those subtle little winks, or lick her chops, for the express purpose that I would think about it.

Still, I had quite a bit I needed to improve upon. Taking note that I might have started to grow a bit cocky, Lieutenant Doom-and-Gloom had taken it upon herself to fight me in the ring. She knocked me out in exactly three moves, and then for the rest of that training session decided to torment me.

Yet out of all the recruits, poor Helenia had the roughest time with Shadia. Ever since that day I did inspection, she truly was trying her hardest. However, she remained by far the worst out of all the initiates, and Lieutenant Shadia personally made sure to make her miserable.

“Are you telling me that you’re already tired you fat bitch?” she hissed.

“I… I…” stammered Heliana’s, absolutely exhausted.

“Then get up!! If you have a shred of self-pride, get up you worthless piece of shit!!” screamed Shadia.

“I-I’m not a piece of shit Lieutenant!!” she wailed, tears streaming out of her eyes.

Shadia seemed to pull back for a moment, and I nearly thought she was about to take sympathy for the overweight silver dragoness. Yet she only drove the wound in deeper when she spat back, “No, you’re not a piece of shit. You’re a crying, worthless lard of fat who won’t improve no matter how much I push you. Why am I wasting my time getting you in shape? You’re only going to pig out like you always do!! Get out of my training session!! Go ahead and eat until you’re a ball!! See if I care!!”

Thus, Helenia laid there limply on the obstacle course crying her eyes out. Apparently, Shadia had known of Heliana’s stealing habit the entire time, and instead of simply turning her in, decided to break her spiritually instead, so that she would up on her own accord out of shame. I truly began to wonder if she wouldn’t be able to make it. She was a kind natured dragoness, and didn’t take well to harshness. Personally, I had to reluctantly admit that Heliana wasn’t Holy Knight material, yet at the same time I didn’t want her to give up either.

Yet I still wondered… After that training session, and a long cold shower (in which Thereesa had all but waited for me to arrive and watched the whole while) I decided to head toward Heliana’s chamber while it was unoccupied. I lifted up the boulder she had used to hide that contraband food. To my dismay, I discovered that indeed she had hidden a cow torso within, and I shook my head.

Then, Heliana came into the chamber.

“Darzhja!! What are you doing in my…”

Then, she saw the food I had discovered.

“You were stealing food again weren’t you Heliana?” I sighed.

She didn’t even try to deny it this time. Instead, all she did was give me that pitiful look of hers. Indeed, I was tempted to lash out at her at this act, like Shadia would, but I feared that if I did, it may well have broken her entire psyche. I took a deep breath, and said…
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Training intensified

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
She'd given me little reason to be lenient with her or to put my neck out on the line for her. The fact that she continued to steal food and overeat despite the clearly obvious fact that it was doing her and her body no good should have been enough to tell me that she was not cut out to be a Holy Knight. But there was something…

Maybe it was in her eyes, the way they were filled with pain and hopelessness, the same hopelessness I'd felt when I was tackling an armored and far more skilled Fangorn with my bare teeth and claws; a hopelessness that had been intensified when I'd awoken in chains with him staring down triumphant at me with his hungry eyes. Or perhaps it had more to do with the fact that she was still here. For the past week, Shadia had been driving us like a demon, driving me and Heliana the hardest of all. Me because I was perhaps the most talented physically of the new recruits - or so Lina kept telling me - Heliana because she was the least. But maybe it was just because Heliana was a good dragoness and by this point, she'd become my friend.

The silver was sitting before me, her big tummy resting on the stone floor, white skin showing between the scales all across her midsection like an engorged snake's. Her forelegs were shaking, perhaps out of fear, but more probably because she was exhausted and worn to the bone. "Heliana, this has to stop, today." I said.

"I've tried! I've tried quitting, but… but I can't. It's been worse than ever. I can barely move at night, I can't sleep, and I'm so hungry…" She took a deep shuddering breath and then wailed, "I'm useless aren't I? It's all true, what Shadia says about me. I'm heavier than I've ever been in my life! I'm a useless pile of stinking dung!"

As she began to sob, I stepped forward and batted the back of her head with my wing. She squeaked like a much smaller dragoness. "Cut that out!" I demanded. "You are not useless. You are a beautiful young dragoness. I'm going to show that to you."

"You're what?" she asked timidly, and looked up at me with her light colored, watery eyes.

"I'm going to help you see the kind of dragon you can be." I said, hardly believing the words that were coming out of my mouth. I had no idea if I could help her. Heliana was very, very out of shape, but it was plain that she needed somebody's help or she wasn't going to make it. "I want you to start meeting with me just before and after feeding." Heliana swallowed. "No more stealing." I intoned.

"I…" her eyes darted about, but finally settled back on me, rising to meet my amber eyes. "I won't steal anymore. I promise.

I grinned down at her and rose. Heliana rose as well, the scales rasping softly as they rubbed the insides of her thighs. "Then lets go and bury this cow before it gets too late.

I made Heliana carry it out of the cave. I noticed the way she had to concentrate on walking and holding the dead beast, what with her teeth puncturing its soft, flabby hide and making it bleed on her tongue. She didn't dare to take a single bite with me watching, so she had to resist. That was good. As we exited to the landing, I saw out of the corner of my eye violet scales reflecting the torch light which illuminated the common area. Thereesa watched us go.

We buried the cow in a remote area of the valley which was well forested and peaceful. The trees around us were ancient and large, certainly aided by elf-magic if not truly elf-born trees themselves. I patted down the earth with the flat side of my tail blade.

I broke the silence which surrounded us when we had finished moving the earth. "Heliana, why do you want to be a Knight?"

"What?" she asked, startled. I glared at her softly until she sighed and said, "I came because my father wanted me to come. They wouldn't take a middle aged dragon like him, so I guess I was the next best thing to becoming a Knight himself."

"If that's the only reason you're here, then you should go home." I said bluntly.

Heliana hissed, "Darzhja!" The trees seemed to whisper as a breeze flowed over the crowns above our heads.

"You need to find a reason to be here for yourself. You can't do this just so that your father will be happier. It's wrong of him anyway to live vicariously through you." I said.

Her claws shifted, tearing the turf under her weight. She turned her head to the side. "I do want to be a Knight…"

"Why?" I prodded. "And don't tell me just because it's a good career with a good wage. You can make money in other places."

Heliana opened and closed her mouth. She looked at the ground, her eyes distant. I wondered if she was recalling her Harrowing under the immortal, penetrating gaze of the Chronicler. I hoped she would not break her oath not to mention him. She swallowed again and spoke with a dry voice. "It's something inside of me that's always been there. Ever since I first looked up to the soaring mountain of the Temple. I want to do good, I want to help people. Maybe if there were more Knights, then my sister wouldn't have lost her husband in the attack…"

I inclined my head. There probably wasn't a dragon here who had not been affected by the sudden, devastating attack on New Alveri. Heliana was no exception. Extending my neck, I rested it against the silver's in a warm embrace. "I understand." I said simply.

Coming back, Heliana asked, "How are you going to help me, Darzhja?"

In the cold hard truth, I had no idea. I was not a fitness trainer. And we both got plenty of exercise as it was during the day. I did not know where to start in helping to get Heliana's waistline under her control. So I said, "Anyway that I can." Then, grinning foolishly, I slapped her on the back and lifted myself into the air. "I bet you can't catch me!" I shouted. Heliana smirked and came up after me. The trees shook with our passage and were still.

The veins in my wings were livid when we came back to the dorms quite late. The torches were all extinguished and I knew that we would both have a hard day tomorrow. It was fine though. Dragons could operate on little to no sleep for limited periods of time… we just had to make up for it later.

Heliana panted happily. I'd pushed her, I knew, but it wasn't the same as when Shadia demeaned her and wore her down body and spirit. In fact, Heliana seemed in as good a spirit as the first time I met her. "Good night, Darzhja." she whispered to me.

"See you tomorrow." I whispered back, just a little sharply so she knew I was expecting her.

We separated then. As I was walking back to my lair, full of thoughts of Lina and if she were wondering where I'd been...
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Under My Wing

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
I almost stumbled into Thereesa's indigo bulk. She didn't seem to mind, simply smoothing the scales on her shoulder where I'd bumped her with a smooth, almost sensual stroke. "That's really nice." she said.

"What?" I asked. I was indeed tired and wasn't thinking straight. I breathed in her odor, how full of feminine musk it was. I wanted to get away. I'd lost enough sleep as it was.

But Thereesa had boldly extended a wing, being more forward with me tonight than she was usually with her off-hand comments and knowing looks. "You know what. That's really kind, how you are helping Heliana. Nobody else will touch her, they know that the Black Bitch has got it out for her."

I snorted, "She's got it out for me too…"

Thereesa harumphed, "Don't make this about yourself, Darzhja." That closed my snout. She looked at me deeply, studying me, as if there was something new in my eyes that she did not understand. "Why are you helping her?"

She was not ridiculing me, I knew that straight away. It was a pure, honest question. I could only give my pure honest answer, "Because she's my friend."

Thereesa grinned, showing her serrated teeth. Her eyes seemed heavy with knowing, understanding, perhaps more deeply than I understood myself. I was suddenly a little afraid. Thereesa was a master of not only magic, but she held her own in the ring. I'd beaten her, as I had the rest, but her fighting style was unique, fast, adaptable, though there had been something missing; I could tell during our spar. I bet it was because she'd been barred her magic. I wondered if I would even stand a chance if it was a no-rules fight. She was twice my age as well and this combined made her suddenly intimidating despite the fact that I was taller than her by a head and longer by a fourth.

"Lina's not in your lair." she said suddenly. "She decided she needed to share the good news with her betrothed earlier and she has not returned. I assume they have both found some little hallow somewhere to share the night."

There was a wide grin on Thereesa's long, narrow face, though her news deflated me somewhat as well as making me grin uncomfortably. I was looking up the dark, empty hallway when she hit me with the question.

She withdrew her wing first, no longer barring my way forward. "You are welcome to share my lair with me tonight, if you like, Darzhja."

The air hissed between my teeth with my sharp intake of breath. There was no one waiting for me in the lair, but then I'd just planned on going straight to sleep. The violet dragon's smell called to me in an interesting, homely manner that was not at all like a male's. Like with like, though I knew that Thereesa had a much different and deeper way of expressing passion that I had ever experienced before. Still the curiosity tore at me, and I did like the set of her eyes, that black tongue of hers was a conundrum. The threat of experience hung over my neck like a blade.

All I knew for sure was that if I went with her, there would be little sleep for me this night.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: The Captivating Dragoness

choices: That is The First Mother, Paxi'Andrianth
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Thereesa brushed her tail against my cheek as she turned up the branch that lead to her lair. After a moment, I followed.

I had never thought that my life at the orphanage was particularly sheltered. I'd grown used to living in near constant poverty, every garnet that I gathered was needed to procure enough food to keep me healthy or else sent to my tiny hoard that I built bit by grueling bit. There was always something that needed doing. And also, there was always Lady Ramoth there looking out for us, but also disciplining us with sometimes a heavy claw; although never unfairly. There had been no sexual overtones to my life previously; there'd been no time for it. Of course, as a young dragoness, I could not escape the passing glances, the comments and requests of the opposite gender, but Lady Ramoth had instilled in me… well, some might call it prudeness, but she called it 'respectability.'

The thought of what I was about to do, what I was going to welcome into my life stunned me as if walking into a brick wall as I was treading up the sloping, narrow tunnel. I almost turned back, but I looked forward again and saw Thereesa's whip-like tail, unadorned with a weapon at the end, but rather a single fin which could be opened and closed at will. Her haunches sauntered with an easy grace as she walked up ahead of me and I could not bring myself to turn away now.

I was like one dying of thirst, except it was a thirst for I knew not what, nor that I even had this thirst in me until so recently. It was born when Thereesa caught me in the showers… had rubbed her claws on my back so briefly. No. It was before then, born with those soft, concerned eyes and kind words from a blue scaled, handsome face concealed by a silver helmet. Or maybe even before that? In hot, angry words and intense, burning eyes in a bronze scaled face like my own, but not at all like mine. I wondered at the fact that their faces even came to me, and I recalled their scorching, masculine scents even as I was entering into a dorm where I doubted any male of my species had ever set foot or ever would.

The glowing lavender runes on the walls of the vaguely round chamber seemed to intensified from what I remembered; did they anticipate what was to come? It didn't matter if I outweighed Thereesa by 50 stone, I felt small and unsure as I walked in. I breathed and the very atmosphere was different, charged by magic, perhaps. In the incandescence, I felt transported to another realm, and perhaps I was. Thereesa certainly seemed alien enough at times. She grinned at me and I noted her numerous small, sharp teeth.

"I'm glad that you decided to come." said the violet dragoness.

I turned my head slightly aside and said guardedly, "I haven't yet decided on anything."

But she was too clever by half and could tell that I wasn't going anywhere. Not until I knew. Knew for sure. She stretched her wing and laid it against my flank while simultaneously touching my claw with her own. "It's alright. Just relax. This is a good place."

And surprisingly, I did relax. The light from the many runes decorating the walls and ceiling cast a dim glow which was not overpowering, but revealed every contour of the room and its occupants to my sensitive eyes. I was still weary for my day's training and flying and romping about with Heliana afterwards. Her wing against my side was warm and it felt nice. I relaxed into it, letting myself become limp and I sighed and closed my eyes.

I felt Thereesa's chin against my shoulders, her neck against mine. She was quite warm and her scent was intense with that exotic flare which was uniquely hers. I heard her breath and knew that she was savoring my scent as well. But thereesa's scent, though interesting, was so mild. It was not hot and rank like a male's, almost leaping into my nose as they would leap upon me given half a chance; or at least as Lady Ramoth would have put it. It did not electrify me the way that Lorath's - or Fangorn's, I had to admit to myself - did. But I did so like the care and gentleness with which Thereesa rubbed her scales against my own.

Her wings around me, so that the light from the runes illuminated the veins in the leather walls surrounding me, I sat on my haunches as Thereesa ran the backside of her foreclaw down my chest. The knuckles clicked as they past each row of the shaggy, bronze scale mail that I wore at all times. She drew her head back and looked at me, her claw still moving down, down. "Do you like that?"

My eyes drifted down from her long face, took in the shape of her shoulders and her shallow chest, her trim waist below and her flat tummy. I thought I did, but then I thought that I was making myself like it. "I don't know…"

Thereesa licked her chops with that black tongue of hers and my hearts rose in pitch for a few moments. Her wings folded from around me and the small cave was revealed again. "There's no need to hurry." she said and got to her feet. She walked a few paces to a worn looking corner of the floor. She padded a bit, turned around once and laid down upon the stone. "Let's just talk."

I followed her lead and reclined on the floor opposite her. At the opposite end of the room, Thereesa wrapped her elegant tail around mine which at the moment felt heavy, clumsy and only good for smashing things. "Anything you'd like to know?" she asked.

There were a million things that I wanted to know, but they were not the things that Thereesa would be able to answer. How could one know another's heart when one did not know it herself? So I looked about the walls. I was far from a scholar, but I could tell one rune apart from another and could see where one string of characters began and another ended. There was on character which seemed to start the lines of almost all the strings which wrapped around the walls. "There," I said, indicating a rune with my claw, "What does that one mean?"

Thereesa grinned at me with happy surprise. "Ah, I hoped you would notice that one."

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
"What is it?" I asked while I stretched my weary legs.

"You mean, 'Who is it.' That symbol represents Paxi'Andrianth, First Mother, Mother of Wisdom and of Patience."

All I could utter was, "Who?"

Thereesa grinned and looked away, to the walls covered in glowing writing. "I'm not surprised you haven't heard of her. Most people either pray to Gryakrond or else the Ancestors as a collective." She pointed her snout at me, dipped low and looked at me with large eyes, "She was Gryakrond's first mate."

I, like most any other dragon who was aware of our cultural origins was aware that Gyrakrond, or the First Dragon, lived in a primordial time beyond reckoning when there were no other mortal races, not even the ancient elves. There are multiple origin myths, but everyone agreed that he was a being of terrible wrath and power. He was the embodiment of aggression, lust, pride and invincibility. He took a harem of wives in his time, claims ranging from a dozen to a thousand females, all shaped or sired by himself; the fact that our patron god essentially raped his own daughters and ate his sons was fairly good evidence that our stories were handed down faithfully from much darker times. But I'd never known any names given to the few first females he was said to have shaped from air, earth, water and fire.

But the fact that they would have had to had names did make sense, although what Thereesa was saying was making me feel uncomfortable in a spiritual sense. I'd just had my faith in the Ancestors reawakened after having lain dormant in the back of my mind for most of my life. Now I felt as if I were on the verge of heresy. "I-I didn't know." I said a little shakily. "But why is her name on your walls? Is it part of your magic?"

Thereesa nodded her head solemnly. "In these written spells, her name is evoked as a source of power. Her will helps guide the energies that I create, and if I have her blessing, perhaps she adds some of her energies as well. She gives shape to the spells that I write in the Unseen World beyond what I could do by myself. Wizards often do the same with a familiar, but an ancestor spirit is a much more potent ally and she is wise enough to guide me and correct me, instead of just blindly following direction."

There was obviously more to magic than I'd ever dreamed of. I didn't understand a lot of what threes was talking about, especially with 'energies' and 'guidance and shaping.' And I still didn't grasp the central idea. "Why?" I asked, "Why do you call on a specific ancestor? Wouldn't the ancestors as a whole be even more powerful?"

"Oh certainly. By far." said Thereesa with perfect ease. "The Ancestors as a whole are just as powerful, or even more so than any of the other major gods in and outside New Alveri, subsiding as they do on dragons' collected faith as well as the faith of the dragon cult."

I turn up a palm, "Then why-"

"Why take only one." said the violet dragoness, nodding her head as if asked this same question before. "I'll admit, it's unorthodox. But the thing you have to realize is that the Ancestors, although they have your wellbeing in mind, is only a generalized well wishing. They are interested in the wellbeing of dragonkind not necessarily the wellbeing of a specific dragon. This is because their consciousness is composed of so many, many dragons of all types and temperaments that they are neutral in almost every respect. A single, specific ancestor, you'd probably have more luck dealing with, and I think that I have so far."

I almost gasped, hearing Thereesa speak so frankly about the Ancestors. She hadn't said anything really negative, but after a lifetime of knowing only praise for the wisdom and guidance of the Ancestors, what she was saying now really did sound almost like heresy. The first thing out of my mouth, however was, "Then why not call upon Gyrakrond?"

Thereesa tittered as if the answer was obvious. Then she said, stretched her paw out against the ground towards me. "Oh, don't get me wrong, I have called upon him before in the past. But he's so… so… explosive. And I mean that literally, he once made a rune circle of mine explode. He's also very dominating and tends to overwhelm my own energy and take over the spell himself." She shook her head, "I just don't think our spirits are very compatible."

This was all so overwhelming. Before I'd walked into her lair, I'd no idea that the Ancestors I'd worshipped could be tied directly into the working of magic. Lina didn't seem to call on anyone to work her skills nor had I seen any magician call upon gods when they called upon anything at all. Perhaps it was because this was magic in the written form, the more disciplined organized school of magic. But I had no way of knowing for sure, and I didn't have the energy to puzzle it out right now. In fact, I hardly had the energy to feel more than mild shock at Thereesa's unusual style of magic and I did not want to get into an argument with her. Sources of magic aside, I asked, "So what sorts of things can you do with your spells, Thereesa?"

The violet female fluttered her wings a little where they rested folded against her back. "Oh, many of the usual things you'd expect from a humanoid magician. I can store things here on a rune and summon them to me anywhere else. I can change the shape and nature of objects - that's called transfiguration, by the way. Runes are particularly good at defining boundaries and creating order. Keeping things in, keeping things out, separating things, that sort of stuff."

As my tail was becoming increasingly occupied with thereesa's, I gestured with a claw to the walls. "And these here? Do they protect you against spirits or something?"

"Actually no." said Thereesa. She raise a wing and touched the bony spur to the wall where the glowing column of runes increased their light five-fold. "These are all mostly to capture and store energy that I can use later on the field." When she removed her wing, the glow slowly decreased back to its original intensity.

I swallowed. "And… where exactly do you get this energy from?" Looking at the surrounding walls and their bright glow, it certainly looked like a lot of stored energy.

Then Thereesa scrambled forward on her elbows, her tail suddenly tight around mine like one snake strangling another. She put her foreclaws on mine, I could feel the talons putting pressure on the scales of my wrists. with a husky, breathy voice, she asked, "Would you like me to show you?"

Her feminine musk showering over me, I said breathlessly, "Yes."

Thereesa's eyes were large deep with knowing, with experience, and I knew that my own inexperience showed as she looked at me and I looked at her moving her head slightly on her long neck. Without words, the violet female across from me stretched her neck out and rubbed her cheek against the whole length of my neck. As her head rose, one of the horns spiraling back from the crown of her head brushed my cheek. Her claw rose to grip and run down my shoulder and nervously, I tried to reciprocate, reaching out with my own paw to touch Thereesa's leg, moving up gently. I could feel the firmness of muscle under her scales which were smoother and less shaggy than my own. Thereesa purred and pushed herself closer still, levering herself with her chin against the base of my spine. As she pulled herself to me, so our chests touched, her tail entwined aggressively around my own, squeezing it and moving further up its length.

I was nervous. I didn't know what I was doing. I was afraid that Thereesa would say that I was not doing something right. But at the same time, I also felt overwhelmed. The violent female now opened her mouth and let that thick black tongue slither up the back of my neck and as she did, became more forward with the rest of her body as well, pushing against my scales and running her claws over my shoulders.

Her wings opening a little in her obvious state of excitement, I said. "Thereesa… I don't…" The shame of admitting it filled me, "I don't know what to do."

Her tail loosened a little from around mine and she pulled away from my neck to look at me. Her eyes were still slanted, alluring and full of desire themselves. "Don't worry about it. Let's just make tonight about you."

I gave a little nod and reclined further back against the wall and its glowing runes. Thereesa's tail squeezed mine again, as if signalling the return of play and moved a little more up my own length. Her fin now brushed the backs of my haunches, the ends far more substantial than a feather and vaguely aquatic. Rather than returning to caress my neck and shoulders, however, the violet female shook her wings out a little more. She reached out and touched my back and my own folded wings with the bat-like appendage, the boney digits and warm purple leather sliding against my skin and scales. She put her foreclaw on my ribcage.

I huffed a breath as she pulled herself up over me and on top of me. My natural instincts said to fight back and Thereesa must have sensed my stiffness. "Relax." she commanded again and I did as she told me, swallowing my hiss, though her weight was far greater than Lina's.

Thereesa folded her legs and settled onto of me. Our entertained tails formed an open circle of sinewy muscle and vertebrae behind us since my partner had spiraled hers down from the tip. Squeezing hard now, the female onto of me forced her tail around mine once again with obvious effort on her part. "Darzhja." breathed Thereesa. "I want you to take a deep breath."

Scared and excited, impatient and timorous all at once, I closed my eyes and breathed in. Thereesa's tail then found its way between my haunches, it pressed up against my nethers and the air caught in my throat. I clenched my teeth and turned my head away. Just feeling the side of her tail against my privates elicited a stronger sensation than I'd known during my physical last week. It was unfamiliar, it was powerful and thought devouring. It felt like oblivion, it felt like utter bliss. I wanted more. Thereesa obliged.

She drew her tail backward against me, the smooth, firm surface of her tail forcing from me the breath I'd been holding. Thereesa leaned down over my writhing neck and ran her thick, black tongue over the thin scales of my cheek. I barely felt it.

As the end of her tail withdrew, I uttered a soft, "Don't…" I didn't want that feeling to cease.

Thereesa grinned down at me. "As you wish…" Her tail tightened brutally around my thicker one again and the violet female's stiff fin came down hard against my soft spot.

I threw my head back against the floor so that my horns scrapped against the floor, making a horrible sound. But I didn't care, I was lost in a fog of pleasure. I reached up blindly to the dragoness ontop of me and pulled her down onto my chest. Thereesa tittered in surprise and then purred, rubbing her cheek against mine even as she pressed down still harder against me.

However, despite the fact that I held her in my arms, despite the fact that her scent was showering down on me and filling the small room, my thoughts were not on Thereesa. Rather, in my mind's eye, I saw watery azure eyes. The same ones who cared when I was injured after my battle in the warehouse, the same ones which belonged to a large, well muscled, blue scaled figure. It was my first time, I was greedy and soon merely brushing and pressing against the surface of my yielding nethers was not enough. My nature commanded me and dictated what was supposed to follow, but was frustratingly not being delivered.

"Lothar!" I breathed in a state where I was not completely sure where I was at. I only knew what I wanted and that what I was receiving was not the whole experience.

The motion and the pressure and the friction stopped to my utter horror as Thereesa's tail withdrew from between my thighs. It felt like I was falling, like some sort of life essence were leaking out of me. I was panting, but in a few moments, I'd regained most of my faculties. When I did, I saw her violet face looking down at me.

"Did you say what I think you said?" said Thereesa with a complex expression. It was as if she were disappointed, off-put, but had been expecting it all at the same time.

I rolled over partially so that I was on my side again. Thereesa sliding off of me, her tail unwinding gently from my own; the return of the flow of blood to the muscular appendage sent a chill up my thickly muscled tail. "What did I say?" I asked, though I knew, or at least thought I knew.

Thereesa just smirked with her knowing grin. "You love him don't you." said the dragoness across from me, our legs still touching, "...Or at least you want him."

Despite what we were just doing, I was shocked at her bluntness. But I could not summon up the old Darzhja who would have balked and denied and changed the subject. It was as if a layer of insulation between us had been stripped away after Thereesa had had her tail between my legs. "I do." I said simply. "I really do, but that doesn't mean that I don't like you, Thereesa."

"Perhaps as a friend, Darzhja. But you don't see me the way I see you, and I don't think you can." I was about to protest, but she placed her tail fin against my snout to still me. "It's not your fault." Now she turned her snout away and sighed. "I didn't think that you ran in my direction, to be honest. But you are such a handsome dragoness..." Her eyes flared, taking in my sleek, bronze scaled form, "I couldn't help but try to lure you over to my side. But we can't fight our natures. I can't and you can't either."

I looked at her foreclaws, her thin, elongated digits and her black claws, shining, perhaps polished. The truth was staring me in the face, but I didn't feel upset or embarrassed or uncomfortable about what me and Thereesa had just done, or attempted to do. She had allowed me to see at long last a part of me that I didn't even know was there. Still, behind those violet eyes which were no longer quite as captivating as they were before - though they still exuded a wonderful exotic beauty - I saw his azure eyes waiting for me; and behind those, perhaps the burnt orange eyes of the one who still haunted my thoughts and darkest dreams. "I think... I think I understand." I said sollemly. Then I flashed my sharp teeth and touched her snout with my own playfully. "But I still want you to be my friend Thereesa."

The violet dragoness giggled and poked a ticklish spot in my armpit with her folded tail fin. "Well who wouldn't want to be!?"

I laughed and rolled onto my side. Thereesa rolled over as well, folding her wings and resting her back against my belly. I asked, "Do you mind if I still spend the night here?"

Thereesa lifted her head slightly and looked at me sidelong, her long thin snout pointing skyward. "Only if you promise to tell him how you feel." she winked at me slyly. I gasped softly and she then brushed her wing partially against my flank. "I just want you to be happy, Darzhja."

"I want to be happy too..." I said quietly, but still felt timid. Thereesa was easier to feel emotionally, the male mind remained intimidatingly obscure. How such a large dragoness as myself could be so timid when it came to matters of the heart when I was capable of leaping fearlessly into battle was beyond me.

Thereesa allowed us to lapse into silence. The runes on the walls, which had been glowing brightly with our passion dimmed and eventually became dark. Our breathing slowed, Thereesa pressing her back into the hollow of my tummy and I resting my claws on her shoulders. Eventually I slept...

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
That morning, when I had emerged from my lair with Thereesa, the other dragonesses had gave me this look. They didn’t say a word, yet there was this knowing look on their eyes. Especially Tsarra. The look upon her gaze was utterly… poisonous that morning. If I were to ever get into any sort of confrontation with any of them, she’d use that episode with Thereesa to blackmail me out of the Order.

I had also expected Shadia to learn of what went on that night, yet strangely, and in fact, ominously, she treated me just as badly as she did any normal morning. Perhaps she was saving it for a time to really embarrass me? The lieutenant was very crafty in not only inflicting suffering, but knowing the opportune moment to inflict it to cause maximum humiliation.

However, during meal time, when Lina had heard of what had happened between myself and Thereesa… lets just say that she was utterly excited. She instantly dropped the scarab she was feasting upon and began squealing uncontrollably for a few minutes. Meanwhile, Lina huddled right next to Thereesa, looking like two thieves ready to break into the Vault.

“So Thereesa, tell me about the whole thing. Step by step. I want to know all the juicy details…” whispered Lina. I could only watch with horror as the two began whispering to each other, yet deliberately loud enough that I could clearly overhear what they were gossiping. I snorted; they’d surely make a far better ‘couple’ rather than Thereesa and myself.

I took a bite out of my steer. “We didn’t do that much really,” I replied, keeping my head turned away so she couldn’t see the anxiety on my face.

Thereesa instantly sabotaged whatever meager efforts I’d made to downplay it. “Come on beautiful, you know that you liked it,” she giggled, “Oh Lina, you should have seen her when she threw her head back and listened to the wonderful sound she made last night!! By the Ancestors it was the sexiest thing I’ve ever seen!!”

Lina giggled wildly, while I wished for nothing else but to return to my eggshell.

“If I’m not seeming too forward, considering that my dorm is right next to Thereesa’s, I did seem to find you weren’t really protesting her advances” said Heliana mildly. “I did not envision you the type that would possess that kind of orientation…”

She closed her eyes sheepishly, “I actually think its nice that you’re able to explore that side of yourself.”

My face scowled into one of annoyance, “I’m not a lesbian…” I growled back, with a bit too much force.

“Indeed. That is quite a shame…” purred Thereesa, “However, maybe when you’re having your season and you need someone to help you relieve your tension…”

“You’re never going to stop coming after me are you?” I cried. I didn’t feel particularly surprised at that at all. “A dragoness as beautiful as you are, never…” giggled Thereesa. “Yet I suppose you would prefer to do this kind of thing with Lorath though…”

I nodded rapidly, glad to take my mind of that weird experience last night and instead envision that kind dragon instead.

Yet once again, Lina had to throw a wrench into that plan.

“Oh, is that what Darzhja told you?” she snickered.

My eyes instantly began to widen with dread; I knew exactly where Lina was going to take this next.

“Don’t you dare Lina!!”

Yet it was too late. “Actually, the drake that Darzhja really has the hots for is Fangorn…” she giggled. Thereesa now looked quite surprised, so much so that she let out a gasp.

Heliana put a wing to her mouth. “Fangorn!?” she shrieked.

I instantly froze, as whatever fantasy I’d had of Lorath was replaced by one with Fangorn. The harder I tried to wipe it out of my mind, the worse it became.

“No!! Fangorn’s a jerk!! I hate that arrogant stalker!! I’ll never like him!! Never!! Never!! Never!!” I retorted.

“What was that you were saying about me?” said a voice. I turned around, and I let out a gasp, wings unfurling and tail rising over my head to strike. By the Great Dragons above, it was Fangorn. He looked both alarmed with my outburst, but also, a little intrigued. For a long moment, I could only stammer, my hearts pounding. He always had to pop up at precisely the wrong moment. I turned around to where my friends were, only to see that they had backed away at a safe distance, giggling and gossiping to each other like spectators about to witness a volcanic eruption.

“Fangorn!! What are you doing here anyhow!? Sir….” I cried, trying to keep a straight face, but more than likely not succeeding. I knew full well how much Fangorn loved seeing me ‘vulnerable’. I curved back to meet his gaze stiffly, into those eyes of his. Why did he have to be so good looking?

“I’ve come to deliver to you a rather interesting proposal,” said Fangorn, suave as usual.

“Hmmm?” I growled, “First of all, how did you manage to sneak up on me like that!! Its creepy!!”

“With you ranting and raving like a crazed cinnabar addict, it wasn’t that hard at all,” he snorted.

My eyes narrowed, “Jerk…”

Fangorn humphed. By now, he always seemed to take that as a compliment. I had to think of a new insult from now on. “So, now that you’re here, what do you want?” I snapped.

“To be certain, it does have a lot to do with my more mundane duties. Lieutenant Hazzorah requires more time out of my schedule to take part in a project of unspecified nature, so therefore I need someone to take over gate watch for a few afternoons out of the week,” said Fangorn.

"Does it have something to do with the attack?" I wondered.

"I'm sorry Darzhja, but unfortunately I am not alowed to reveal any specifics about the investigation. Now before you decide to lebel me as a 'jerk' as you so fondly love to disparge me as, the reason is because you are not of high enough rank nor do you possess authorization to receive any details of my project," he answered.

“Of course....sir," I answered, "Anyhow, why are you offering this to me?” I wondered. One always had to be suspicious of Fangorn.

“Are you telling me you would turn down a little bit of extra pay for a bit of petty pride?” snorted Fangorn. I rolled my eyes. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black. “Besides, I thought you might appreciate the irony of the situation, plus I think the job is particularly suited for an individual of your temperament. Furthermore, I already checked your schedule and found the days I have in mind fit in nicely.”

I was speechless for a long while. That last statement encapsulated all of Fangorn’s obsessive ness, his overly clever comments and how he just seemed to be particularly adept at irritating me.

“If you wish to know, it was Lorath who initially brought forward this proposal, however given his other duties at the moment he wanted me to bring it up to you,” he answered, looking a bit glum.

“Of course…” I said with a would-be sweet voice, “Because Lorath is too decent a dragon to be an obsessive stalker like you are…”

Fangorn’s gaze hardened and I heard him utter a soft yet threatening growl. Apparently, the mere mention of me uttering the word Lorath was enough to raise his hackles.

I grinned, turning my body away from him. “I think about it then…”

“Let me know by tomorrow then…” he replied, seemingly calm.

Fangorn looked somewhat relieved. I made my way back to Lina, Thereesa and Heliana, keeping my gaze on Fangorn as he took just a bit too long to stare at me, before heading off to whatever he was going to do.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: The gang's all here

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
The following afternoon after training, I found myself at the southern gate, clad in my full armor. I’d already asked Lady Scabia about the proposal and she had agreed. It was a way to earn a few gems and taking part in active duty, while not interfering with my training schedule. Plus, with the Knights needing all personnel to deal with the smuggling ring, they still needed qualified personnel to do the more mundane tasks.

Fangorn was present at the gate to give me a quick run-down on my duties. As much of a jerk he was, he took pride in his work, however mundane garrison duty was.

“First of all, you are not to let any non-Temple personnel inside, unless they possess a permit," he began.

He gestured toward one of the human garrison guards, who quickly showed me what it looked like, "These are made by the mages within the Temple itself, so you need not worry about any counterfeits."

"Yet if you're still not sure, ask Sir Lawson over there," said Fangorn, pointing toward a human male clad in armor. "Sir Lawson is in command of the humanoids protecting this gate, he's been at this almost as long as I've been a Knight, which is quite a while for human standards, and he'll be able to get even somebody like you up to speed in no time."

"Got that, but what if anybody asks if the Holy Knights are recruiting?" I asked. Fangorn gave me a look. It was a memory he did not want to remember.

"Then direct them to the civilian militia so they can immediately be put to work. If they continue to persist, then you may use non-lethal force to subdue the troublemaker in question. I don't imagine you'll have much trouble, your appearance represented a highly unusual circumstance...”

“Yes…that must have come as quite a surprise…” I replied, my eye not so subtly shifting toward his still-bandaged tail.

“Indeed, the Temple must have figured that it would be safer to have you working as a Knight rather than terrorizing the good people of New Alveri," added Fangorn.

"Thanks Fangorn, you can count on me..." I answered. He flew off, to do whatever that secret task he'd been assigned.

Thus, I stood watch at the gate, watching the humanoids walk by and going about in picking up the pieces. Every so often, a humanoid would come by, flashing a permit, whereupon he or she would be allowed entry. Most of these were suppliers, ferrying raw materials and other essential goods in and out of the Temple. The humanoid guards would check the materials for anything suspicious, for which there was none. Other times, there would be the odd humanoid troublemaker who inadvertantly sneak too close. There was also a rather silly attempt by a group of dwarven children that tried to sneak into the temple; I'd actually heard them planning their rather silly plan in one of the small alleyways, and then when they attempted it, I pretended not to notice until they actually thought their plan was going to work, when I scooped them all gently with my tail. They screamed, scared stiff, and one of them begged me not to eat them.

Of course, I promised I wouldn't, because fortunately for them I wasn't hungry at the moment, after which they all scurried away in exaggerated panic.

A few minutes later, a familiar face appeared at the gate.

“Well, if it isn’t you DD…” said a familiar voice.

I shifted my gaze downward. “Markus!!”

It was the grizzled old human that I had fought so many times for in the small fighting ring of his. He’d also been the de-facto strongman of the streets in the poorer areas in the merchant district; the person that everybody usually turned to whenever they had a problem.

“Look at you!! A Holy Knight!! You really look good in that armor. I always knew that you were something special!! To be honest I was rather worried when you decided to confront that guard directly…” said Markus.

“Oh…you mean Fangorn?” I retorted, my eyes narrowing.

“Fangorn?” said Markus, a strange gleam in his eye.

“Yeah, I’m taking over for him between my training sessions. Gave him a nice bite in the tail, so he had no choice but to let me in” I replied quickly.

"So that's how ye ended up in the dungeon...."

"Well, that was thankfully taken care of, now, I do find it kind of ironic that I’m guarding the same gate I was trying to barge into earlier.”

“Strange how the world works doesn’t it?” answered Markus.

“Indeed. Being a Knight is a lot different from what I’d thought it be,” I answered. I thought back to that encounter with Thereesa, the fight in the warehouse, the ‘physical’, the weird encounters I’d had with Fangorn. I had changed quite a bit since I had first challenged Fangorn to that fight.

“In any case, how has the rebuilding process gone?” I asked.

Markus paced about, “Eh, its been quite a undertaking I’ll give you that. There’s still a whole bunch of petty thieves and troublemakers making life difficult in the Merchant district. Yet for the most part, Kaj and his militia have managed to keep things under control and putting people back to work. If you want my opinion, a dragon as strong and talented as him is wasted as a militia dragon; should’ve been a Knight instead.”

In my opinion, I had to agree. Kaj was more than a match than any Knight I could name. I couldn’t help but have an image of him beating up Fangorn the way he deserved to be beaten for pestering me all the time. However, Kaj seemed to find more fulfillment out in the streets helping the citizenry directly than the stiff rituals of being a Knight.

“Anyhow, what brings you here? If you want to get into the Temple, you’re going to have to show me a pass even if you are a long-time friend,” I replied. Knowing Markus for as long as I had, I doubted that he was here just to say hi.

He provided a pass, “Can’t give you the details, but its concerning the fate of the merchant guilds. I know I don’t look anything like a merchant, but I do keep tabs on the market after all. I’ve got to speak with a certain individual within the Temple and negotiate a series of contracts and information with him,” said Markus.

“So you’re saying that one of the Knights has a connection with the merchant guilds then?” I inferred.

“Aye, that’s right. Again, I’d like to tell you more, but I’m not supposed to…” said Markus.

I nodded. “I understand. In any case, speak with the messengers so that they can process and communicate their message.”

“Thanks Darzhja,” said Markus, before he was escorted in by a squad of humanoid Knights.

The rest of the day was rather peaceful. I wondered what the details of Markus’ mission was, and made me aware that while I was now a Knight, I still was only privy to a small part of a much larger and complex situation. What was truly going on in the city? What was the relationship between the merchants and the Temple? Perhaps these were questions I would learn in time. Yet for now, I still had to perform my duty to the upmost, no matter how trivial it seemed.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Temporary Gatekeeper

choices: Wait for the situation to simmer down
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Lina was very happy with herself lately. Granted, she felt heavier than she was used to feeling, but it was a good kind of heavy. It meant her little ones would be healthy and strong once she laid them.

She couldn’t wait for the day they would hatch, and she would get to see their shining little faces!!

Yet it had been a little while since she’d seen Ein’theil. He’d been busy with his partner in his magical studies, but she figured now would be a very nice time to surprise him.

Her eyes twinkling, Lina poofed her way over to Ein’theil’s lair. The first thing that struck her was his scent. She grinned, perhaps he was getting ready for her tonight… Yet then, she started to hear voices, and she got confused.

“Oh Peter…stroke me right there… That’s really nice…” she heard Ein’theil’s voice cry out.

Lina’s eyes went wide, and slowly made her way inside. She was shocked at what she saw. Ein’theil was crouched over a mount, similar to the ones used during the physicals, his mouth open and panting. Below him, sitting on a stool, was his partner Peter, using both hands to stroke his cock, and worse, the halfling was not wearing any sort of clothing at all. She could only watch with a perverse fascination as the humanoid stroked him, until he let out a cry and of relief as he spurt all over the ground.

“Peter, that was wonderful…” purred Ein’theil. There was a dreamy look in his eye, one that was usually reserved for her. When that happened, she couldn’t take it anymore. She burst into the chamber and let out a scream of pain and fury, tears bursting from her eyes.

Ein’theil slowly turned to face Lina, with a look of pure horror.

"Why Ein'theil!?"

“L-Linal’eil, I-I can explain…” he stammered. “W-we need dragon semen for the next experiment…”

It was a very lousy excuse and Ein’theil seemed to know it.

“By the Ancestors Ein… I knew this was going to happen eventually,” gasped Petering. He instantly rushed in front of Lina.

“Lina, I’m so sorry about what happened. I should have known better, I was…”
--
“Leave now!!” Lina hissed. Peter backed away, put on his clothes and rushed out of sight. It was pitiful that it was the halfling that had been the first that had tried to take responsibility, as in fact; all her rage was reserved for Ein’theil.

“Why Ein’theil? We made babies together!! I thought you loved me!!” she wailed.

“O-of course I love you Lina!!” stammered Ein’theil, yet his voice was hesitant. He tried to move forward to embrace her, yet Lina was too disgusted and turned him away.

“No!! You love your human more than me!! You only wanted me so we could continue our race isn’t it!?” she screamed.

“That’s not true!!” insisted Ein’theil. “I do love you!! Yet I also love Peter as well!!”

Lina sniffled and trembled. “H-how can I trust you Ein’theil?”

“Lina… I-“

Lina hissed, “I guess I was the foolish one then, being so blindly in love as not to think it through. Better…better I should have stayed in the forest then…”

She began to turn away back to the dorm.

“Lina!! Wait!! I’m sorry!! I should have-“

Lina didn’t want to hear about it right now. She’d never felt so betrayed in her entire life. How could he have done this to her? She’d trusted him blindly, and she’d gotten burned. Had Ein’theil just been open about it and told her, she would have been fine with it, but since she had to discover it… and the possibility that he had just used her as a breeder was the part that was painful.


---------------------
That night I returned to the dorms, tired after a long day.

Lina was present to greet me as usual. She seemed her usual bubbly self.

“Darzhja!!” she squealed, “So how was your day!!”

“I met up with an old friend, Markus, who ran the fighting ring. Other than that, guard duty was rather uneventful,” I replied.

“What about you Lina? How did your day go?” I asked.

Lina jerked backwards, “O-oh…” she cried, seeming surprised by this question, “It went all right I guess…”

Now I knew something wasn’t right. Usually, she’d be squeaking about how wonderful her day was, but she seemed strangely hesitant for some reason. Her eyes were reddened.

“D-did something happen today?” I asked.

Lina took a deep breath. I’d never seen her so unsure of herself before.

“Its…its…its…nothing...” she stammered, curving her gaze downward.

“Perhaps you don’t want to talk about it. Maybe you can go see Ein’theil and talk to him instead…” I suggested.

Her eyes began to water, her jaw quavering. That’s when I realized it. “Did something happen between you and Ein’theil?”

“I-I saw him Darzhja. I caught him making love with his halfling partner… He…he…” she squeaked with a small voice. Then, the dam broke, as she threw herself against me and began weeping, screaming at the top of her breath. All I could do was hold her against me as if she was a hatchling, trying not to cry myself. It hurt me deeply to see Lina hurt like that. Rage began to build within me toward that cheating little runt. How could any male do that? Abandoning one’s mate, especially when they were pregnant with little ones…

“D-darzhja… I-I…don’t want you to get involved in this. H-he apologized…but…but…” she stammered.

“He’s not getting away with this Lina… he can’t…” I snarled.

Lina sniffled again. It was apparent that while she’d been cheated on, she still loved Ein’theil and didn’t want any harm to come out of it. These types of quarrels were something I had little experience in dealing with, and there was a real chance that if I got involved, I could simply make it worse. Maybe I should let the situation sort itself out before deciding to lash out? Yet still, it was against my nature to passively sit on the sidelines and do nothing…
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Cheated on

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
I immediately rose up out of my haunches, rage consuming me, my wariness from the day evaporating. It didn’t matter if it was the middle of the night; my friend had been hurt and she needed somebody to stand up for her. Nobody was going to stop me until the situation was made right again.

I flew off toward the cheater’s lair. It wasn’t hard to find, since the specialized lair that was provided for Ein’theil was near the mage’s guild, while the size of the lair itself was also crafted to accommodate the size of a smaller dragon that specialized in magic instead of combat. Unfortunately, that meant I could only stick my head through the opening of the cave.

“Ein’theil!!” I snarled, switching my gaze toward the fairy dragon. The small dragon leaned up against the corner and began babbling incoherently.

“Get out here coward!! How could you do such a horrible thing to Lina!! She loved you so much and you cheat with a male humanoid of all creatures!!” I roared.

“I-I-I-I c-c-can explain… I didn’t want this to happen. I…I…” he stammered. He then curled up into a ball and began bawling pathetically.

“Wait!!” cried a voice from behind. “Don’t hurt him!!”

I switched my gaze toward the direction of the voice. It was that mage, Peter, or whatever his name had been, and likely the humanoid lover Lina’s cheating mate had cuddled up with.

“Out of my way halfling!! Unless you wish to suffer my wrath as well…” I snarled. Frankly, it was one thing for a humanoid to be led astray into this sort of relationship, because they were often blinded by their reverence for dragon-kind and didn’t really know any better. I’d actually thought him rather irrelevant mostly, as humanoids consisted merely part of an amorphous mass compared to dragonkind. So, I was more than surprised that while Ein’theil cowered in the corner, it was the halfling who held his ground.

“L-look, I know your after Ein’theil and you’re going to give him a piece of your mind for hurting Lina, but please, hear us out first,” he cried. While I couldn’t help but feel a vast amount of disgust at the small humanoid, I also had to grudgingly admit that had he actually climbed the entire way up without the aid of a dragon just tointervene on Ein'theil's behalf.

I snorted, “I’m listening…”

“I’m probably in no position to explain things, but…please forgive us.”

“How long have you been doing…this sort of thing together?” I asked, trying to keep the obvious disgust out of my mouth. Ein'theil remained silent and ashamed.

“Ein’theil, don’t make me be the one to have to face her alone. Please, we’ve got to take responsibility for this mistake,” said Peter.

Ein’theil sniffled, and rose back to his feet. He still seemed scared out of his mind, but at least he seemed to have recovered some composure. Apparently, his partner seemed to give him the courage he lacked on his own.

“Before I met Peter, I was…well, a wreck. I was always alone and scared and got picked on all the time. I thought…about killing myself a few times, and one time I was about to go through with it, but for reasons that I don’t fully understand to this day, Peter happened to be there and he stopped me. He was only a child back then, but he seemed to understand me better than anyone had before. Peter… he was my first real friend, and I’d never had a friend before. He told me I wasn’t a worthless piece of trash, and that I actually could become a Knight, and because of him I was able to become a Knight. Its also part of the reason how I was able to meet Lina…” said Ein’theil.

“So, you obviously care about Peter. Then what is Lina to you? Is she only a means for continuing your race?” I snarled. If it was, then he was going to get no mercy from me.

Ein’theil stammered for a moment. “I…had never seen another Faerie Dragoness before, at least not one my age. I…didn’t know what to do at first. Yet, when she got so excited about me…it became infectious. I knew I’d never wanted to be with any other dragoness in the world. When I found out I was going to be a father, you have no idea how happy I felt for both of us. And yet…”

“Part of its actually my fault,” cried Peter. “It’s a bit embarrassing to admit, but at the time, I couldn’t help but be a little bit jealous that Ein was spending more and more time with Lina. I probably shouldn’t have felt that way, but he felt bad that I was feeling that way, and well…”

“So you decided to take your relationship one step further?” I snorted.

“I thought Peter and I would be able to keep this sort of relationship secret. You’d think that we should have known better and that Lina would find out eventually right? In fact, it probably would have been better had we been brave enough to tell her straight up, but I was too scared that if I told her our relationship wouldn’t be the same anymore,” said Ein’theil.

My teeth became clenched again, “You are an idiot, you know that? Even if you do make up, she’ll never adore you with the same blind devotion again,” I spat acidly.

Ein’theil nodded glumly.

“You still haven’t answered the question though. Who is more important to you, Lina or Peter?”

The answer should have been obvious, yet once again Ein’theil could not speak. He looked deeply agonized.

“That’s not a fair question to ask Darzhja,” cried Peter, “Why should he or anybody be forced to choose between one or the other? You probably think that such sentiments would be utterly insane, but its true. Its not about who you love more, its just a different sort of love, that’s all. Still, if he ever had to choose, I’d rather him choose her over me. I’ll be dead in sixty years anyhow…” he cried.

“Don’t you dare think of it in those terms. I’ll always treasure you even when you grow old and gray,” insisted Ein’theil. I imagined the faerie dragon getting pleasured when the halfling was near death’s door. It was not a pretty thought at all.

“Look Darzhja. I messed up really badly. I could give you all the reasons I can give for why I did it, but that’s irrelevant at this point. Somehow, I’ve got to put things right. She’ll hate me now, but I’ve got to take responsibility for what I’ve done,” said Ein’theil. There was a resolve in his eyes now that wasn’t there before.

“Then you’re going to have to tell Lina what you just told me right now. She deserves better than what you put her through. It will be up to her to decide whether you are still worth having. Yet if I find out you’ve hurt her again, you’ll have to answer to me understand?” I growled.

“Yes…” he answered solemnly.

I still felt as if not much had been resolved, in fact I was under no illusions that things would just turn happily ever after. This was but the start of a long healing process, and ultimately I had already done most of what I could have possibly done. It was up to Lina and Ein’theil ultimately to make up…
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Who do you value most?

choices: Can you teach me a little magic?
Do you have any advice about what to do with Lina?
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
The days that followed Lina's revelation to me and my confrontation with the cheating Ein were long and disturbingly quiet. My fairy lairmate, although far from stoic, did not pester or tease me as much as she used to; nor did she bother to drug me into deep, borderline hallucinogenic dreams. Strange as it sounds, I found myself missing the way that she would poof in front of my head and grab my face as I was walking into the common room, the way she would stick her tongue in my ear, but most of all her chiming, wind bell laugh.

I caught her more than once staring blankly at a wall or a small pebble on the ground, her wondrous wings closed to her scaly back, wrenching her tail in her claws. When she noticed me she usually bounced up into the air, told a joke and quickly gave me several other things to think about. Though once she simply poofed away, I knew not where, and I didn't see her again until late that evening.

It was with monumental effort that I restrained myself from asking her about her and Ein everyday. Every time she left my side I imagined her reconciling with the father of the eggs which were growing every day inside her creamy scaled tummy. Every time she returned, she had been away on some chore for her mentor, or catching a scarab to feed her high metabolism, or practicing her magic. If she refused to bring it up on her own, I was not going to press her. Surely she knew by now that I'd pressed Ein to confront her with the truth.

And I knew that he had because for one, Lina was no longer bawling or depressed, despite how she was now acting quiet and withdrawn compared to her usual self. And for two, I knew that he did not dare tempt my wrath. I was sure that even he did not know enough magic to keep me away from avenging Lina's honor.

No, I had the feeling that Lina was confused. Perhaps confused about what had happened, what had driven Ein'theil into the arms of a male halfling of all things. Maybe she was confused about whether she wanted the father of her eggs to be around anymore, and if he deserved to be a part of their lives. But, honestly, I thought she was confused about if she could possibly forgive him.

With Lina struggling with her personal issues and no real way for me to help her, I found better company in Thereesa and Heliana in the week following the incident. Thereesa proved to be quite knowledgable in advanced culinary skills suited for dragon pallets as well as a queer stretching exercise that was challenging, but without the cardiovascular strain that we were all forced to suffer for much of the day as it was.

It was late in the afternoon, a few hours after our secondary afternoon drill and Thereesa laid her languid self on the grass. She had her right foreclaw stuck straight up and her right wing pointed in the direction of her toes; something quite difficult to accomplish. Her haunches were twisted so that her right hind paw was on the floor, the left stretching out behind her, the top of her foot brushing the grass. She balanced the awkward position with her tail. "This is called 'Drawing-Down-The-Sun.'" she said in a voice like a sigh.

Heliana and I stood across from her, imitating the older dragoness's motions. Heliana lacked much of the range of motion required for the stances and frequently fell on her face, as she was almost doing now, every few seconds as she waggled her thick tail behind her. But Thereesa said that it didn't really matter, so long as one stretched the muscles. Frankly, I was little better than Heliana. Sometimes it was as if Thereesa were asking me to dislocate my wing or one of my legs. The things that girl could do with her spine…

Thereesa caught me looking and licked her chops, eyeing me. I laughed nervously and moved my foot a little more into the right position. Pain shot up my torso, along my right flank. I cried out and fell in a jumble of wings and scaled legs. Thereesa slithered up to me. "Did you over extend your latisimus dorsi?" she asked, as if I had any idea what what was.

I hissed and rotated my aching arm. "I'll be fine." I said, struggling to my feet. I folded my wings with as much dignity as I could muster, though Heliana's bright clear eyes were obviously amused. I limped a little to the hole we had dug in the earth. "When is this going to be done?" I asked

Heliana's still oversized gut growled loudly, scaring away three birds from a nearby tree. The silver laughed it off and patted her large midsection. "Honestly, I'd have been fine with it raw."

Thereesa knelt down and lapped from the pit into which we'd dumped two butchered cows, several crates of assorted vegetables and enough water to make it into a stew. Runes glowed softly around the perimeter of the pit, both to keep the food insulated from dirt around it and to keep it suspended over the fire below. Heliana, as it turned out, had already mastered a small cantrip, "A trick from my father." she had said, though she still refused to talk about him much except that he fought in the troll rebellions as a civilian conscript. The silver had breathed fire over the bottom of the pit excessively until the very stones were glowing. she'd uttered a single word to shaped the spell, 'Fire,' in Old Draconic, and now she could keep her dragon's breath burning in the same spot for as long as she maintained her concentration. She'd said it was a trick her father had picked up out on the plains were there was little in the way of firewood to keep watch at night.

As for my part, in addition to feeling increasingly useless for knowing nothing of magic, I was unsure of this new diet. We'd traded a cow for the grains and vegetables for the stew and Thereesa had transported the water from the showers using a small Rune-gate. It reminded me of the lean times in the orphanage when we'd had to stretched the meat for many mouths. "This is cleansing," insisted, Thereesa, "The vegetables and grains help flush the system."

As far as I was concerned, eating the stomach of the cow gave all the fiber a dragon really needed, but then I was not much of an expert on anything… except maybe sparing.

When Thereesa claimed that the stew was done, the three of us gathered around the pit and lowered our heads, biting and slurping the meal. It was thick and tasty after all. Although Heliana had a tendency to eat too fast. Twice I batted her on the flank with my wing to remind her to share. She looked at me sheepishly and paused before lowering her head again. Thereesa… she seemed to enjoy watching the two of us eat as much as she ate herself; or perhaps it was just me. I could not stop myself from shuddering a little.

As I ate, I thought about the routines that had crept into my life. My mornings were spent being browbeaten by Shadia who was still more demanding of me and Heliana than any other recruit, especially now that we had formed our alliance with each other. Always she sought to break us apart, punishing Heliana the more I succeeded, or punishing me the more she lagged behind. But what the lieutenant didn't realize that she was only driving us closer together. And Heliana was not doing so terribly anymore. She was much more emotionally stable now and had even lost 3 stone in the last week.

Then four days out of the week, I had guard duty. I was excused from afternoon training, but as a downside, I had to meet at least passingly with Fangorn as the shift was changed. I met Markus most days as he was now busy bringing supplies to his mysterious merchant guild contact in the Temple. There was obviously something big going on. I would have bet half my hoard that it had something to do with the power vacuum left in the wake of the three guild leaders' deaths. Three ancient, powerful dragons, the youngest of them was still over 800 years old, gone overnight. I was sure that there was a lot of paperwork to do. It would probably take years to sort it out. Then at night I rested, the familiar weight of Lina lying on her favored spot curled into a ball in the hallow beneath my arm and over my ribs. I had no days off. These scant hours represented my only free time to spend with my new friends. I couldn't be happier to have them

I lifted my head from the chow and looked across at Thereesa who was actually bothering to lap up some food rather than eat me with her eyes. "Um... Thereesa..." I said hesitantly.

"Hm?" the violet dragoness hummed.

I opened my mouth and asked... "
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Dinner with Friends

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Heliana was noisily gnawing on a thick thigh bone of a steer when I asked Thereesa if she could teach me some magic. Even the silver bothered to lift up her head on her thick neck to glance at me.

Thereesa looked at me candidly. Apparently, I'd taken her by surprise. "Magic? Well… I probably could…" she hesitated and looked askance which worried me because the violet female was always so smooth and controlled. "But I really don't think rune-magic is the sort of thing for you Darzhja."

I frowned, though Thereesa already looked uncomfortable having said that. "I'm not smart enough is what you mean." I said it harsher than I meant to and immediately regretted it.

Thereesa's finned tail twisted on the ground in her discomfort. "No. That's not what I meant." She did a good job of sparing my feelings, but the guilty look in her eyes told me that it was indeed true, or at least partially. With some finality, she forced her tail against the ground, "I meant that rune magic is all about symbology and the history of runes. There's obscure texts to memorize in disused or forgotten tongues. It takes ages to learn how to do anything useful with it."

I cocked my head and flipped a paw. "Again, you don't think I'm smart enough."

Thereesa's jaw dropped and Heliana hid her face behind a wing as she was about to suffer a fit of giggles.

"I… oh…" Thereesa turned her head to the side. "I just don't think you'd have the patience for it, Darzhja. That's all I meant." She turned her face back to me, a slightly fervent glean in her eyes. "I don't think you're stupid!"

I just stared at her for a moment over the now mostly empty pit of eaten beef stew. Then I broke into a toothy smile, "I know you don't." I relaxed my thin jowls back over my fangs, "But still, I keep feeling out of place because I don't know any magic."

Heliana reached out a wing and touched my back, "You know, most dragons don't know any magic, Darzhja."

That was a fact. In the lower tiers where I'd grown up, magic was an obscure, mysterious tool that was mostly for the rich and affluent of New Alveri, among humanoids and dragons as well; perhaps even more so due to our proclivity for physical labor and fighting. "But is that true of Knights?" I asked disdainfully. "Almost everyone I've met here knows at least a little magic." My voice was strained, I didn't even know how much my ignorance was bothering me.

The two other females stared at me. Thereesa's tongue flickered out, like a snake poking its black head out of the ground, and she looked at the surrounding trees in thought. "Well… there is one thing that usually comes naturally enough to any dragon." said the violet female.

I looked at Thereesa with wide, hungry eyes.

She winked at me and stretched her neck up and out. But the muscles contracting at the base of her long neck, I could tell she was summoning her fire. Heliana saw it too and ducked her head. I flinched. Having grown up in a city vulnerable to fire, fire-breathing was never something done lightly or without reason.

Thereesa's neck bulged in a controlled way and then she belched a column of flame into the air. Except it was no flame as I'd ever seen it, at least from a dragon. The flames were bright green and stank of chemicals, like disinfectant. At the edges, crackling yellow sparks shot out like firecrackers. The display lasted about one and a half seconds and Thereesa closed her smoking jaws with a click of teeth snapping together. Heliana and I sat in stunned silence. And why shouldn't we have, Thereesa had just shot green fire and fireworks out of her mouth!

Smoke still streaming out of her nostrils, Thereesa said, "Always a good party trick."

"How on earth did you do that?" the words tumbled out of my mouth like stones.

The violet shook out her wings a little in pride. She was always happy to be the center of attention. "It's actually pretty easy, well, the basics are easy. That… that took some practice to master." she laughed. "You just need to understand one thing. Dragonfire is inherently magical."

"Really?" I asked dumbly. My fire had always been explained to me in terms of ducts and fire glands, and sulfurous oils, usually for the purposes of hygiene. My fire breath seemed as natural to me as the functioning of my ear, or perhaps more appropriately, my urethra.

"Yes!" said Thereesa vehemently and snaked her tail forward to bat my shoulder. "Maybe the physical base is totally natural, but the way that it burns is magic and it is tuned to your emotions."

Heliana nodded, stretching her neck into the conversation. "My father told me that he was instructed to work up a rage to destroy and kill with his fire. He told me how the flames burned through and ate up the magic wards the troll shamen put up to protect themselves, but only if he was angry enough."
