"Yes, our fire burns hotter with our passion… but not just anger works, though perhaps it is the most potent and useful emotion for battle naturally." Thereesa turned to look at me squarely. "You need to swallow down your emotion, bottle it up in your chest." She placed her claw against her breast. "Then, at the right moment, release it up and out with your breath, your fire. I know some breathing exercises also, if you are interested, Darzhja."

I nodded my head thanks, having learned now to take advantage of Thereesa's wealth of information. Later the conversation turned to a message Heliana had received from her mother over the semaphore. This was the first that I'd ever heard of her mother, since the heavyset silver was stll shy about her background. Apparently she lived in the major port city of Nod, Damescara. It lay far down the eastern trade route out of the city so they did not get to see each other much. It was a short message. "My mother is a fisherman and doesn't make a lot of money…" said Heliana briefly. "But she's so happy to hear that I made it into the Knights…" the silver was quiet a moment longer, but looking into the warm faces of her friends gave her the confidence to continue. "She says that she's holding up well, and wishes that she could visit me…"

Heliana was obviously emotional over the contact. Both Thereesa and I embraced her with our necks. Our scents intertwined.

Soon after, we filled in the pit along with the dregs of the stew and the coals under it. As soon as the runes around the pit were disturbed, the glass-like field of force disappeared and allowed us to fill it.

After the good time with Thereesa and Heliana, I was a little hesitant about returning to my lair, despite the fact that it was after dark. And I felt horrible that I felt that way. Especially since this whole mess was not at all Lina's fault. still, I wished for resolution between her and Ein, one way or the other. I wished for my old Lina back.

When I entered the lair, I found Lina sitting on the floor, gnawing on one of the magic beetles which kept her fairy magic strong. She leapt up in greeting, but still it somehow seemed half hearted. "I have news, Darzhja." she said.

I began to curl myself up in the smallish chamber. "Really? Is it something that I'm going to like?"

Lina snorted as she circled about the room. "Maybe…" She landed on my bronze hide heavily, causing me to chuff. "Actually, I don't know. I was just told to tell you to meet with Lady Scabia after tomorrow morning's drill."

I lifted my head in surprise and anticipation. "Oh! Do you think it is another mission?"

Lina shrugged, already twisting around on my chest, her little claws clicking against and tickling my scales. "Probably." she said indifferently. "But whatever it is, it's just for you."

"Oh…" I mumbled, unsure whether to show the excitement I felt if Lina were not to be included in my upcoming experience; whether it was a mission or whatever else. The chamber settled into silence. I tried a last ditch effort, unable to stand it for long. I reached up with a claw and brushed the smooth side of it against Lina's abdomen as she lay curled on top of me. "Someone's looking a little rounder. How are those eggs coming along?"

Lina trilled loudly and stumbled on top of me, spraying dust every which way before being forced to poof into the air to escape my pestering claw. She harumphed down at me and struck the side of my snout with her soft, curving tail as she flew past, accosting me for my juvenileness. I stuck my tongue out at her.

She landed on her haunches and sat straight up, looking at her midsection which was creamy scaled, contrast to the emerald color on the rest of her. She moved her neck this way and that. "I've been feeling heavier than usual..." she said unsurely. "Do you really think it shows?"

It was honestly hard to tell. Lina remained still a hatchling to my eyes, despite how I'd grown used to her dirty, adult jokes. Perhaps there was some loss to the normal abdominal tuck-up below her rib cage. However I said, "Oh yes, Lina!" I said enthusiastically, bending my neck down as if to peer closer. "You look fit for carving on the Harvest Day Festival!" I laughed and poked her again gently in her midsection. She bent over, grasping my large hand with both of hers, flashing me the dirtiest look. Then she burst out laughing. The stones walls rang with our mirth, however brief it was that night.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Dragon's Fire

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
"…And the recruit who flew the obstacle course in the shortest time, only two minutes and thirty-eight seconds was…" The tall black scaled lieutenant leaned her head down and squinted at the sheet of parchment held aloft by the small humanoid beside her, "Gazzer-leb."

"Ma'm," spoke the thin male in the third row who was apparently the dragon she was referring to, "Actually its Hazzor'leh…"

But Lady Shadia was already moving on, not paying the slightest attention. A young dragon beside him chuckled under his breath and slapped his friend's flank with his tail. 'Gazzer-leb' hung his head in shame.

I would not have been able to resist a snort of laughter myself, but the Black Demon Queen herself was strutting down the aisle to the female half of the recruits. She stopped at the row ahead of me and glared down at us females, somehow even glaring down at the sky-swallowers. "And who do we have dead last, as always? Need I bother mentioning her name at this point?"

Lady Shadia had made it a personal point of hers in the last week to tell everyone exactly how much Heliana was lagging behind, in some new twisted campaign of humiliation in the face of the silver's increasing confidence and motivation. Shadia walked between the rows until she stood directly before Heliana. "What's your excuse today, you sagging excuse for a knock-off leather handbag? Up too late with your head in the trough? Can you explain why you took over five and a half minutes to get through the simple little obstacle course?"

Heliana looked ahead blankly. If she lowered her head, Shadia would wallop her over the skull with her tail; as had already happened more than once in the past. "I got stuck, Ma'm." she said in a tiny voice.

"What was that? No one can hear you over the sound of your reeking failure!" Shadia hissed, her deathmask of a ruff shaking like a snake's rattle

"I got stuck!" Shouted Heliana, "One of the logs was too close to the ground and I couldn't squeeze under it! Ma'm!" Fresh tears were coming down her snout both ways, but she kept her head high and her face straight ahead.

I winced on Heliana's behalf.

There was a metallic *clink!* as Shadia rammed the end of her sword pointed tail into Heliana's armored and protruding midsection. The silver scaled female crumpled onto the ground, drawing ragged breaths. "You couldn't fit because my course was designed for future Knights. Not hippos." Shadia stalked off, apparently satisfied for the moment.

When the Black Bitch's back was turned I stretched out my wing and touched Heliana's flank. She shivered under the contact and lifted her head to look back at me. We shared a small smile before Heliana wiped her tears off on the grass and got up to her feet to stand in line once more.

When that morning's training finally ended, Heliana came straight to me, exhausted mentally as well as physically, but with an optimistic expression planted painfully on her face. I didn't want to hurry off, but I had no choice. Lady Scabia was expecting me.

I appreciated Heliana's efforts to be enthusiastic for me. "Darzhja, that's terrific. Do you think that you're going to get another mission?"

The air around us was filled with dragons departing in every direction. The resulting wing stirred the light fronds at the back of my neck. "I don't know for sure." I admitted, "But I think so!" I was not so worn out by morning exercise as Heliana was, and I couldn't help but tread lightly on my claws. It felt like a strong wind would carry me away. My wings itched as I held them half open.

The overweight silver seemed to realize that she was holding me up, but she asked, "Will I see you this afternoon?"

By that she meant around dinner. I had hoped that she was starting to feel more confident about controlling what went into that wide maw of hers… but apparently she still felt she needed the support of her friends. "I really don't know, Heliana." A stiff breeze blew down from the north over the hills at the edge of the caldron and really forced me back for real. I planted my claws in the earth. "Ask Thereesa if I don't show. Maybe she'll serve you some onions and roots for dinner!"

Heliana made a gagging sound and bid me goodbye with a smile. I leapt up backwards and soared south like a kite in the breeze.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Those Who Finish Last...

choices: Ramoth quit the Knights after the deaths of her loved ones
Ramoth was honorably discharged under suspicious circumstances
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Lady Scabia's lair was more than halfway across the width of the long dormant volcano. Fluttering to the landing shelf, I gripped the stone in my claws as I landed. I breathed in Scabia familiar scent, but also caught the strong musk of a male just recently past. A male I knew.

I extended my neck and let out a loud warble, common Draconic for a visitor (female) entering another's home. Lady Scabia chirped back twice with her deeper, maturer voice: acknowledgement and assent. I crossed the threshold into the unlit dimness within.

No one was in the circular entry room, so I padded on down a curved, horizontal tunnel. Still more mementos and curios decorated the walls within recesses set in the stone; a collection obviously spanning multiple hundreds of years. Quickly I came into another chamber. I had just identified the other guest of Scabia's by his scent as I walked in on the pair.

Next to Scabia's dark green bulk reclined a smaller male against the wall nearest the entryway. He had left his silver armor behind, but the blue scales gave away his identity. Lorath. I had to bite back a sigh. What a surprise! what did this handsome drake have to do with this? I wondered.

"Ah, welcome Darzhja. Good to see you again." said Lorath.

Gingerly, I stepped over his long, straight tail as I entered the generous, though low ceilinged cavern. My eyes traveled farther up to the base than might have been polite. His masculine scent filled the room, overpowering Scabia's; I couldn't help but drink it in. "It's been a while…" I managed, averting my eyes to Lady Scabia to keep myself clear headed.

As I walked past and settled myself against a stone wall, I couldn't help but notice that I did have Lorath's attention, though perhaps only because I'd just walked in the room. Still, I found myself swishing my tail just a little bit more than needed, and holding my wings out just a tad from my body. His nostrils flared and I saw just a tiny half smile lighten the corner of his mouth.

Lady Scabia spoke. "Darzhja, as you might have guessed by now, I'm offering you a mission." She rolled her eyes and added, "Well… not exactly a whole mission. You are to be assisting Lorath with his. Lorath?"

The blue male took his cue and turned his liquid eyes on me. I thought of sea foam and dark tide pools, or at least pictures I'd seen of them. I've never been very far from New Alveri. Still, I had to concentrate to hear his words, my hearts were beating too loudly! "You know about the aftermath of the warehouse incident right? How we used our unearthed information to smoke out several other places where the smuggling cartel has apparently been operating?"

I nodded firmly. I kept my eyes on his face though they kept wanting to drift down to his broad shoulders.

"Well, we've found yet more dragon eggs."

That was news enough to shake me from my embarrassing physical attraction. "That's great! More little ones delivered from whatever ghastly fates awaited them!" I exclaimed with real enthusiasm, even bringing my fist down on the floor. A relic wobbled uneasily on a shelf nearby, however, and I was forced to give Lady Scabia a sheepish look. The elder female just snorted.

Lorath, however did not share my excitement. He turned his snout away. "That's just the thing, though. Many eggs have been claimed by their worried parents, but a surprising number of them have not been picked up yet."

"What?" I asked, It was unthinkable that any mother could leave their unhatched offspring behind. Most any drakka I knew would rather die than surrender her eggs, it was the natural reaction. "How many?" I asked guardedly, not really wanting to know the answer.

"Almost half." said Lorath, his eyes haunted. "The dragon cult members have been diverted to build fires to keep them warm, but we simply don't have the facilities for the eggs. It'll be even worse when they hatch."

I let out a hurt sigh, already knowing where this was leading. Painful childhood memories came up unbidden in the back of my mind. "They'll be orphans then…" I said regretfully.

Lady Scabia picked up the conversation with her usual authoritative tone, "Indeed, Darzhja. And the Temple only has a single nursery and that is reserved for active duty Knights and their young. These unclaimed eggs will have to be sent to orphanages."

I felt my face flush under my bronze hued scales. Damn the Knights and their partisan preeminence. These hatchlings need a home! Then I thought of Lina and other female drakka like her who, by the very Temple itself, were not exactly discouraged from procreating, or in fact outright encouraged. Should she have to sacrifice her progression through the ranks, her career, to settle down and build a nest? Something in me, ancient instincts which were not so deeply buried in dragons as in most humanoids, thought that it was appropriate. But it still rankled with unfairness, especially in regards to the male half of the equation.

And besides nothing I said would change the system overnight. The eggs needed homes and care now. I shook my head, knowing what was coming. "Lady Ramoth…" the name slipped between my scaled lips.

"Yesss." Scabia said with a slight hiss. "We need her help desperately with so many eggs going unclaimed."

"But why!?" I said rather too loudly, thinking of so many young ones destined to the same rough life I'd been forced to live. "Where are the parents?"

Lorath stepped in, "We think that they are dead, Darzhja." I flicked my head to the blue male, eyes wide. He continued, "Many died in the attack, we still haven't accounted for all the missing dragons, though the rubble is mostly cleaned up now. It is possible that these smugglers have been preying on eggs they know belong to dead or missing dragons."

"That can't be the whole story…" I rankled, conspiracies and dragons held hostage ran though my mind, as irrational as it was. "What about the missing adolescents around the city?"

"Occam's Razor, Darzhja. That wise Alchemist stated not to multiply entities needlessly. We have no proof that the two occurrences are related. For now, the simplest explanation is the best." said Lorath, and though I had no idea who this Occam fellow was, I felt some of my fervor evaporate in the face of Lorath's unshakable logic.

My eyes fell and then drifted back up, taking in both dragons to either side of me, "You are going to have a hard time with Lady Ramoth. Her orphanage is still overcrowded, though perhaps not so much now if some of the injured dragons have recovered…"

"What's that, Darzhja?" asked Scabia. I quickly related my experience with the crowded orphanage before my acceptance as a Knight apprentice. How the poorest dragons injured in the attack sough sanctuary when the hospitals turned them away. How the hatchlings were forced to reside in the hallways. I mentioned nothing of the blood money Lady Ramoth had accepted in return for the corpses of the stricken dragons, however.

I watched as Lady Scabia's face darkened. I was only glad that I was not the target of that elder's ire. She seemed suddenly as scary as Shadia… well almost as scary. Then Scabia unexpectedly stretched forth her good wing and rested it upon my flank. "You can rest assured, Darzhja. The Nine have already promised considerable financial backing for any organizations who can take these eggs."

"Money is fine and good." I said, "But it still takes time to turn that into bigger and deeper caves and more dragon cult members. Lady Ramoth will be heavily burdened in the short run, no matter how much the Temple promises."

"Natrually," said Lorath. "But we can work out those details later, with Ramoth herself. However, where we really need your help, Darzhja, is with certain political complications that are going to arise because of this…"

Again I was stunned, not only because this should only have been a simple transition, but also because both Lorath and Scabia seemed to think that I could help in some way. "What sort of complications?" I asked cautiously.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Eggs, and What to Do with Them

choices: Raiders try to steal the eggs!!
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
“The complications have to do a lot with the circumstances in which Lady Ramoth left the Knights,” said Lady Scabia, with a very troubled expression, "After the final battle against the Witch-Doctor’s horde, she lost a lot of people whom she held dear in her heart, and as a result Lady Ramoth began to doubt her own conviction in serving as a Knight, and became increasingly disillusioned with the Nine as a result. One day, she left without a word and was not heard of again until she sent that letter informing us that she was now running an orphanage and that she was willing to sponsor your training.”

I hear the obvious reluctance in Lady Scabia’s voice to tell me even this watered down, abridged explanation of Lady Ramoth’s exodus from the Knights.

Still, I couldn’t help but feel a little bit cheated, slamming my closed claw against the ground. “Lady Scabia!! You knew her when she was a Knight!! Don’t tell me that’s all you know!!”

Lorath raised his wing and placed it against my flank. “Calm yourself Darzhja!!” he growled.

All my anger instantly evaporated under that firm yet sympathetic gaze of his. “Most of the other Knights know as much as you do about the exact circumstances. Lady Scabia has her reasons for not revealing the specifics. I can only assume she does so out of respect for Lady Ramoth.”

Scabia looked deeply relieved that she had not needed to be the one to scold me. She gazed at me solemnly.

“I apologize I can’t give you any more specifics than that Darzhja,” said Scabia, “I only wanted you to keep in mind that there are circumstances that may make her uneasy about working with the Knights again.”

“Maybe you can ask Lady Ramoth if she is willing to share that story with you,” Lorath suggested.

“Do you think she’ll tell me?” I wondered. I knew how prideful she was and did not like to admit weakness of any sort, and the situation in which she left the Knights was one of uncertainty for her.

“I cannot say for certain Darzhja,” said Scabia, “Yet what I can say for certain is that you are a dragon that she deeply cares about and trusts. If she knows that you are personally involved in this mission, she’ll be assured that the Knights truly do care about the fate of the orphans and that our pledge to give her the resources she needs to care for them properly is sincere, rather than seeing this as a way to earn a few political points.”

I couldn’t help but feel very warm inside at that sentiment.

“Now then, I feel that we have wasted enough time here as it is,” said Scabia, her expression hard and firm again, “You’ll find the eggs at the southern gate ready for transport. A squad of humanoid knights will also be present to help you escort the eggs to their intended destination.”

I let out a plumb of smoke after hearing this. Frankly, I did not trust armed humanoids of any sort anywhere near an unhatched little one. In my eyes, they all had the potential of being egg-stealers.

Lorath placed a claw upon my shoulder, and I felt my hearts skip a beat, “Don’t worry Darzhja, I’ll tell the humanoids to make sure that they keep their distance.”

I couldn’t help but blush deeply, nor help but fantasize that the clutch of eggs that we would be protecting may one day be our own. Those thoughts danced in my mind as I made my way toward the southern gate with Lorath at my side.

Upon arriving, I found the eggs arranged neatly in a large wheeled carriage. Underneath it was a magically conjured fire; one that would warm the eggs but not burn the cushion that they lay upon. The humanoid Knights were wise enough to immediately get out of my way as I rushed forward and placed myself right next to the egg carriage. I lowered my head and placed my nuzzle upon each of them, murring protectively.

Fangorn happened to be on guard at the gate that afternoon. Whether it was by design or coincidence, I'd never know, yet once again, the enigmatic yet agonizingly handsome Bronze Drake always knew when to select the most awkward moments imaginable to show up. I watched as he and Lorath merely stared at each other for a long while, neither knowing what to make of such a situation. Then he turned to face me, and when he did so, there was this most awkward feeling, something between anxiety and distaste while blushing all the while. I expected Fangorn to make one of his patented perverted jokes, yet that gaze of his, there was so much turmoil in those eyes.

Then, I saw Lorath lean his head forward and begin to whisper something I could not hear to Fangorn. The bronze dragon tensed up noticeably for a moment before facing me again.

“Darzhja, I-I want you to know that…that” cried Fangorn. His voice seemed to lack its usual biting edge, no doubt because of Lorath’s presence.

I cocked my head sideways, more than a little put off by Fangorn’s awkwardness, “Yes? Is there something you wish to tell me? Can’t you see that Lorath and I are on an important mission?”

My voice came out extremely harshly; perhaps it was because I was on edge that I was watching the eggs, or it was just an automatic response for anything Fangorn said and brining up Lorath's name was a defense mechanism. Or maybe because his eyes burning with an intensity that almost made me faint, and that the only way for me to settle myself was to lash out in desperation. Whatever the reason was, somehow, I regretted the tone that I had taken, as it seemed as if Fangorn looked like he really wanted to say something and appeared as if he’d been stabbed by a ballista.

“I just… never mind…”

Fangorn then made a concerted effort to appear as if he were addressing any other individual passing through, “I… apologize for interrupting your mission. You have clearance to continue on with your cargo into the city.” He then stepped aside with a pained deliberateness. I couldn’t bear to see the expression on his face. It was shocking how much I was tempted to shout out and have Fangorn tell me whatever intended to tell me, even if it turned out to be something rude and perverted.

As I passed by into the street, I couldn’t help but grit my teeth together.

“Fangorn… why do you always have to be so…so…” I said with a quiet voice. I couldn’t find that last word though. Right when I thought I had Fangorn figured out, he would pull off something like this. He always made me feel, unsure and insecure. I shifted my gaze back toward Lorath, hoping that would distract me from this emotional turmoil. It made it worse. I wanted nothing more than to simply screa in frustration.

Instead, I shifted my gaze back toward the little ones. Somehow, they seemed to have sensed my emotional turmoil through their eggshells.

“Little ones… it would seem that I’m not ready to care for ones of my own yet…” I sighed.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Various complications

choices: A young drake Darzhja had never seen before
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
The egg cart rumbled along the paved stones of the street pulled along by two oxen. Unable to help myself, I kept looking over my shoulder for hidden dangers lurking in the tall buildings all around as I came up the rear of the small procession passing down the teirs of New Alveri; I winced everytime the wagon hit a bump or loose cobble and cursed the ineffectiveness of humaniod ground transport. I was being paranoid I knew. The eggs were safe from all foreseeable harm what with Lothar in front, myself in the rear and a full squadron of Knights in and around the wagon. It would take a small army to capture the eggs now... Even so, I would not feel safe until they were secured at the orphanage.

Walking down the tiers from the height of the Temple entrance at the very peak of New Alveri seemed like a chore compared to flying. We were forced to walk quarter turns around each tier, passing lower through several guarded gates into lower tiers on a zigzagging path. Still it was the only way, though my nerves were half frazzled by acute hyperawareness by the time Lady Ramoth's orphanage came into view. Upon arriving at its entrance, the first thing that struck me was just how small and cramped it seemed in comparison to before I left. It wasn’t that I had grown physically larger in any dramatic sense, rather it was that up until that day, my life had been a simple and routine one.

I felt oddly nervous as I stepped forward then. The archway leading into the complex of caverns was perfumed with Lady Ramoth’s familiar scent, as well as those of the orphans and the humanoid priests that provided for them.

A young green dragoness stepped forward out of the gloomy passageway. It was Ophelia. I studied her for a moment. She seemed older and far more mature than the last time I’d seen her, likely having grown into her new responsibilities for the younger orphans.

“Yes, h-how can I help you?” she asked. She seemed a little bit intimidated standing in front of a pair of armored Knights alongside their humanoid auxiliaries.

“Ophelia!! Don’t you recognize me?” I cried, stepping forward.

She studied me for a moment, looking beyond the heavy armor which covered my hide, then Her eyes went wide, “Darzhja!?” she called out. My jaw curved into a smile. She rushed forward and threw her head against mine. I caressed her with my wings.

“I-I-I was worried about you Darzhja…” stammered Ophelia.

My wings unfurled a little, “You were worried about me?”

“Last I heard was that you got in a fight with a guard and got thrown into a dungeon…”

“I don’t mean to interrupt,” said Lorath, as he stepped forward, “Yet we are here on an important mission.” It might have seemed insensetive of Lorath to interupt, but I realized that it was I who was out of place. This was offcial business and there was a certain propriety that had to be upheld, especially in front of our humanoid peers.

“O-oh…” said Ophelia, taking a step back, her gaze eying Lorath wearily. I stepped back, but surprisingly, Lorath came forward to address Ophelia directly.

“Lady Ophelia,” he said, performing a dramatic bow before the green dragoness.

Ophelia angled her head away and let out an embarrassed ‘eep’, and folding her wings against her back, “You…really don’t have to call me that…” she stammered unsteadily. I couldn’t help but rumble with amusement; Lorath was irresistible for dragonesses of all ages, shapes and sizes.

“Ah, but I insist,” he answered, “I am Sir Lorath, if it is not too much trouble may I speak with Lady Ramoth, the matron of this facility?”

“Oh… all right…” she answered.

Ophelia flashed Lorath one last bashful look, before dashing back inside the orphanage and was for a few moments again the rambunctious immature drakka that I remembered. We had only to wait a few minutes, the magicked brazier under the wagon behind us crackling merrily, before my former mistress came forth. When I saw her, I couldn’t help but call out with glee.

“Lady Ramoth!!” I called.

“Darzhja!! It has been far too long. I’ve missed you so much…” she answered, giving me that soothing, grandmotherly winged hug of hers I had missed so much.

She took a step back and scanned her gaze over me. Her eyes glowed with pride. “You look all grown up now Darzhja. A Holy Knight!! I trust that you have behaved yourself thus far?”

“Mostly…” I answered with a half smile. I couldn’t help but think back to that ‘time’ I’d had with Thereesa, no doubt it was something that Lady Ramoth would have disapproved of. Lady Ramoth gave me that piercing look of hers, as if she could relive every exact moment I’d spent with the Knights thus far.

Lorath then stepped forward, and bowed.

“Lady Ramoth. It is indeed an honor to finally meet you in person,” said Lorath in deference.

“Yes…yes…" answered Ramoth, her eyes narrowing slightly, "You must be… Lothar if I’m not mistaken?”

“Lorath my Lady,” he corrected.

“I’d heard of you from Scabia that you’d be the head of this little envoy. Quite the charmer I see?” answered Lady Ramoth with mildly veiled skepticism. Judging purely by her tone of voice, one would have thought that Lorath had come recruiting for young drakka for the cinnabar dens. I could only wonder how she would have reacted to the temple dispatch had I not been present.

“Some would say that indeed,” answered Lorath with a smile, calmly ignoring Lady Ramoth's tone. “In any case, as you may have heard from Lady Scabia, we have recovered a number of unborn hatchlings from smuggling rings all over New Alveri. However, a large number of these have not been reclaimed by their parents, and thus, the Knights have humbly requested of you to take them in and care for them, if you are willing.”

Lady Ramoth held her gaze over the unhatched little ones with a loving yet weary gaze. She was the sort of dragonesses that when things got tougher, she worked even harder than she did before.

“I will never turn away hatchlings in need of caring,” said Ramoth. Her head then darted toward me and Lorath, “However, I’ve come to understand that there are a few contracts for us to go over I’m sure. The humanoid Knights will wait outside to keep watch so we aren’t bothered,” she ordered.

Ramoth sighed, first toward the sacks of gems that were to be her compensation, and then toward the large basket of eggs snuggled in hay over the warmth of the brazier. “I suppose I am in no position to refuse am I? Rest assured that my staff and I will do all we can to care for them,” she said.

“By the Ancestors, we thank you deeply,” bowed Lorath.

“Very well then. I suppose I should start getting the paperwork and all that other bureaucratic nonsense taken care of.” Lady Ramoth seemed already partially drained by the exchange. I couldn't help but notice the way she faced me even while speaking to Lorath. It seemed rude, but then perhaps to her Lorath represented the Temple and a whole lot of bad memories.

Lorath then switched his gaze toward me.

“Since we are beginning a more formal association with Lady Ramoth's organization, we also need to know the names of all the fledglings in the orphanage so they can be properly accounted for in our records. Darzhja, can I trust you to inspect the premises?” said Lorath.

“Yes sir,” I immediately offered. While Lorath was a chivalrous dragon, I got the impression that Lady Ramoth wasn't comfortable enough to allow him in the company of the orphans themselves. Lorath was smart enough to recognize this.

“Darzhja, I’ll get someone to help you out,” she cried. Lady Ramoth curved her head into the hallway. She called forth...
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: The return

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
“Callisto!!” she cried shrilly, “Come over here now!!” she cried out.

A young silver drake I had never seen before rushed out of the hallway.

“Yes Lady Ramoth?” he answered. I studied the silver dragon. He looked smart and capable, so much so I wondered how he’d ended up in the orphanage in the first place. In many ways, he reminded me achingly of Blaze. Not that there were many physical similarities between a silver dragon and a fire dragon, but there was that trustworthy younger brother quality to Callisto that reminded me of the still missing Fire Drake.

“Would you be so kind as to assist Darzhja in obtaining a record of all the orphans?” said Ramoth.

“You can count on me!!”

“So you must be Darzhja then!! In the short time I’ve been here, I’ve already learned how all the orphans hold you in very high regard,” he cried. “I heard a lot about you from Ophelia, especially how you wanted to become a Knight…”

“I’ve still got quite a ways to go though,” I answered, thinking of Lady Ramoth, “Its only been a few weeks since I left to become a Knight, but it feels like I’ve been gone much longer. There’s a lot of new faces here, like yourself for instance.” I answered.

“Yeah…I’ll introduce you then…” he said.

Callisto took me through the rooms. The younger wingless orphans that I recognized screamed excitedly when I passed by, and I took the time to address them like a conquering hero. However, there were quite a few, as many as a third of them perhaps, that didn’t know whom their longer tenured fellows were talking about, and gave me rather scared and frightened looks.

There were about twice the number of both humanoid and draconic staff now, hired in the wake of the disaster. The place was bustling with engineers and their crews also as they dug and chiseled in hallways and rooms that had not existed a few weeks ago, digging ever deeper down into the depths of the mountain. The by now familiar wing and talon tattoos of the ubiquitous Dragon Cult covered the forearms and scalps of nearly all of the workers. And the work is still far from done. I thought sardonically as I was led past them, thinking of all the new hatchling that were to be added to the already crowded complex. It was also apparent that the older orphans, like I’d seen with Ophelia greeting us at the door and Callisto showing me around, whom informally categorized as those whose wings had emerged, were by now de-facto staff members as well.

“Darzhja, this may sound like a pretty random question, but do you know a dragoness named Heliana?” asked Callisto, his eyes lighting up hopefully.

My eyes went wide at the recognition of the chubby silver drakka, “Heliana? Yes I know her!! She’s one of my friends in the dorm!! Are you related to her?”

Callisto grinned, “She’s my cousin.”

“Really?” I cried.

Callisto looked a little bit embarrassed, “Technically, she’s my aunt, but mother’s about a hundred years older than Heliana, she’s a lot closer to my age than her own sister. Last I saw her was about a year ago when we had a sending off party for her when she was going to join the Knights. Yet last I heard was through a writing skin delivered before the attack,” he answered.

I remembered Heliana telling me that her sister’s husband had died during the attack, and that was her main motivation for being a Knight. Yet still, assuming that Callisto was being truthful with his relation, which I saw no reason why he wasn’t, and that Heliana’s family, while not exactly being rich, weren’t destitute either so it seemed odd that he would be in a place like this.

“Don’t mind me asking, but since you still have family, how did you end up in the orphanage?” I asked. Instead of answering verbally, he sighed and led me into one of the occupied rooms. I instantly wished that I hadnt asked. There was a silver dragoness lying there on her belly, her eyes vapid and uncomprehending, as if her soul had already been sucked out of her body. A team of humanoid priests was attending to her, as if she were a hatchling just out of the egg.

“Mom…” said Callisto, forcing a smile, “This is Darzhja. She’s a knight, and she’s a good friend of Heliana’s.”

For a moment, I thought I saw the inert dragonesses eyes waver in recognition of that name. A sobering reality took hold. This was Heliana’s sister, but the chubby dragoness hadn’t shared that fact to me; only that her mate had died.

“Lady Silvania…” I bowed, taking a look at the name plaque beside her cot, “Your sister has improved quite a lot. She’s fighting for you every day, and wishes you well… So please, don’t give up.” I said encouragingly. Callisto’s mother let out an incoherent noise, and Callisto answered her back with encouragements. I couldn’t help but be both saddened but at the same time amazed that he managed to keep up his wits about him.

Callisto had to take a breath after leaving the room so we could continue the evaluation.

“H-how did she end up like that?” I stammered.

“Dad was bleeding to death, and Mom went hysterical and tried to use her magic to keep his spirit attached to his body, but she lost her mind doing so." Callisto's eyes were distant at he continued, "The fire gutted our home and our bank as well. All of my parents' records and things were gone. I-I tried to get someone to help us get our money... b-but Mom can't identify herself, you know..." The young drake had to swallow and pause. He sniffed and then continued; I didn't know how he could be so strong, having no memory of my parents seemed peaceful, sublime compared to this.

"The social worker I spoke to said that with the Trade prince Dek'saird gone, there was going to be a lot of confusion until things settled down. Someone will get our savings straightened out eventually. But it might be a long time until then... In the meantime, I didn’t have any way to take care of her or transport her back to Damescara where Grandpa is. I had to literally drag her through the streets for a few days. The alchemist guild creeps were always hanging around like vultures; telling me that it would better if she were killed her for parts than dragging her around. Lady Ramoth was the only one who was willing to take us both in,” he answered.

I then thought back to the time when Heliana had told me that her sister’s husband had died during the attack. Evidently, she had hidden the fact that her sister had also gone crazy nor any mention of an orphaned nephew. I wondered if she hadn’t heard, but more likely, it was perhaps too painful for her to share to me back then. It also added to the list of reasons why Heliana had been comforting herself with food before I’d decided to help her. I also wondered why Heliana’s father hadn’t been able to ensure that at the very least that her oldest daughter would be able to afford a better hospital, or ensure that Callisto would not have to live in the orphanage. Perhaps they had spent all of their hard earned savings to ensure that Heliana would get the opportunity to become a Knight, and left only enough for themselves to survive. Callisto was obviously a very smart and capable young drake, and I wondered if he resented the fact that he was left with virtually nothing after the disaster. Yet if he did, he sure hid his resentment quite well.

“Didn't mean to get you all depressed Darzhja. Mom seemed quite happy knowing that Heliana’s doing better. Next time you see Heliana, tell her that we both said hi all right?” answered Callisto, trying to screw his expression into a cheerful one.

“I sure will…” I answered. Heliana would definitely be glad to know that her cousin, while not in the most ideal circumstance, was doing more than all right considering what they were.

Later as I walked down a long hallway, I spotted a slim figure within one of the storage rooms out of the corner of my eye. I slowly turned around.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Callisto

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Callisto led me through the rest of the orphanage, as I made sure that everything was properly recorded. One of the humanoid priests had accompanied us to write it down on paper. There was only one corridor left. As I walked down the long hallway, I spotted a slim figure within one of the storage rooms out of the corner of my eye. I slowly turned around.

It was Iskierka. Though I shouldn’t have, my gaze switched right toward the amputated wing joint. Fastened with a series of rough leather straps to the still stitched and livid stump was a rather crude wood and canvas simulacrum painted gold. Her body was still covered with a number of bandages from the other wounds she had sustained during the attack.

I thought back to how much she had suffered, the pain she was in when she had lost her wing, never to fly again. Yet she stood, calm and serene. She was busily and contently rummaging for her drawing skins, like she had prior to the attack. She had always been such a wonderful drawer, not to mention the best singer out of all of us; and, as much it was painful to admit now, probably was the prettiest among the orphaned drakka before she had lost her wing.

Right at that moment, Ophelia rushed into the storage room, “Iskierka!! Should you be up and about right now?” she cried.

“I’m all right Ophelia. It doesn’t hurt so much to move around anymore… In fact, I thought it would be nice if I could start drawing again!!” said Iskierka, gesturing toward the leather skins. She sounded resigned to her fate, yet hid whatever despair she felt about losing her wing with that soft smile of hers. That was when she saw me. "Darzhja! Ancestors! It's been a long time. I haven't seen you since you saved my life."

I grimaced, feeling terrible for the gold drakka's jubilant expression. I had not seen her since I'd held her down so that the doctors could saw off her wing. I'd been too afraid to face her. My voice shook. “Iskierka… When I left the orphanage… I should have stayed and said goodbye to you. Yet I was a coward…” I choked out, “I couldn’t bear to see your…your…”

Her face suddenly grew concerned, “Darzhja, don’t blame yourself for what happened,” she said, placing her head next to mine. “In fact, I’m lucky that you were there for me that night, and that you got me out of the artists guild. I’m still alive because of you.”

I was amazed that she could remain so poised after such disasters. Perhaps it was because of the fact we were orphans and expected tragedy, and thus were able to bounce back better when it actually occurred.

Iskierka was quick to shift from this most depressing topic, as she gazed up and down my armor and cried, “I’m also glad that you were able to fulfill your dreams and become a Knight!!” she said with an encouraging smile.

“Its a lot harder than I thought it would be. In training, there’s this evil Deathwing Lieutenant named Shadia who drives us as if we were her slaves...” Was it a crime to complain of such trivialities to one who was maimed irrepairably? Still, I could think of little else that Iskeirka would be able to relate to.

“Is she really that evil? Perhaps she’s doing so only because she wants all of you to be as strong as possible,” said Iskierka.

“I suppose so, but its hard to tell knowing her.” I said, ducking my eyes and thinking of the time she'd hobbled my wing with a leather holster and forced me to glide and climb through a course meant for flying. Though I ought to be grateful I had a wing... {i }Great Ancestors above! Will I ever be able to stop thinking about her wing?!{/i } I chided myself, wishing things could be as they had been between us. I wanted to change the subject again.

Thankfully, Callisto broke the silence, sensing the awkwardness that had taken hold. He’d been eyeing the sketches that Iskierka had been working on. “Wow Iskierka, I didn’t know you were such a skilled drawer!!”

“Oh…its nothing really…” she said Iskierka bashfully, folding her one good wing behind her back. The few open skins at her feet displayed a watery stylized version of New Alveri as seen from the cliffside landing, I knew; it captured both the soaring heights of the upper tiers and the Temple as well as the dimmer dregs of the levels below. There was also something that looked to me to be abstract, though I caught traces of what might have been wings or claws moving through the fluid landscape. Then again, it might have been upside down for all I could tell; I had about as much aptitude for art as I did for magic.

“Come on Iskierka!!" Ophelia interjected as Iskeirka was moving to gather her fallen skins, "You’re a wonderful artist and we all know how much it means to you!! How about we help you move your art supplies back to your room?”

“Y-you really don’t have to…” said Iskierka, curving her head away, modest as always.

“No, we insist,” I answered, “It’s the least we can do…”

Callisto, Ophelia and I carried Iskierka’s art supplies back toward the small private room she’d been given where the priests could attend to her injuries, located back in the direction of the entrance; the dragon cult priest that continued to dog my steps was too small and frail to help with the heavy skins and tools. As we headed there, I spotted Lady Ramoth and Lorath continue to conduct negotiations in the chapel. I was relieved that Ramoth looked a lot calmer than she did earlier, and also toward Lorath for that matter, for he was always calm and endlessly patient, even toward the most irascible people.

Both Iskierka and Ophelia stopped right outside the chamber to gaze at him dreamily, purring slightly and wagging their tails back and forth, like love struck human maidens waiting for their dashing prince to come along and whisk them away in those fairy tales that Lina told me about. Lorath briefly turned in their direction, flashing that suave, friendly smile of his and raising his wing slightly, much to the annoyance of Lady Ramoth, and causing the two young drakka to yelp and skitter into the room.

“By the Ancestors Darzhja, is that Knight that accompanied you?” cried Iskierka, smiling indolently.

“That’s Sir Lorath. I’ve worked under him for a couple missions now,” I answered, trying not to blush or squeal in glee myself.

Suddenly, there was movement outside the chamber.....
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Serenity

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
“By the Ancestors Darzhja, is that Knight that accompanied you?” cried Iskierka, smiling indolently.

“That’s Sir Lorath. I’ve worked under him for a couple missions now,” I answered, trying not to blush or squeal in glee myself.

Right then, Lorath walked into the chamber, and I nearly shrieked.

Fortunately, Lorath didn’t seem to mind at all. “Darzhja, do you have that inspection records I asked for?”

“Yes sir!! You will find both the original and copies of the full medical records and documentation of each of the orphans, along with the evaluation of the orphanage’s facilities,” I cried, trying to keep myself as composed and professional as possible. I gestured toward the humanoid priest who’d I had help me write it on paper, and after making sure he had properly recorded what I had asked, gently slipped the stack of paper it into a small leather satchel strapped down close to his breastplate.

“Thank you kindly Darzhja,” cried Lorath appreciatively.

Lorath then shifted his gaze toward the other orphans. “So I’m guessing these are your old friends?”

“Yes sir. I apologize if I did not let you know in advance sir, but I wished to make sure they were doing well…” I answered.

“No offense taken at all Darzhja. In fact, I was hoping to stop by to greet you all for a brief moment,” said Lorath. He first turned toward Ophelia, “Lady Ophelia, I must once again thank you for being such a charming hostess for us today,” said Lorath, bowing again, which made Ophelia grin extremely wide. His gaze then shifted toward Iskierka, “And may I have the privilege of your name young dragoness?” said Lorath. From the jaw of any other drake, it would have sounded superficial and corny, yet with Lorath is was actually genuine. The way I could tell, was that there was not the single moment in which his gaze lingered on her missing wing, which made Iskierka swoon all the more.

“I-Iskierka, my Lord Lorath…” cried Iskierka, her eyes sparkling. Lorath’s switched his gaze toward Iskierka’s sketches. “By the Ancestor, I am quite amazed at what you have managed to create with only wax styluses. I wasn’t sure it was possible to combine the bold style of Lord Pentangelor with the graceful texture of Lady Karla in that fashion.”

Personally, I didn’t know the first thing about art, but I was surprised that Lorath would be so informed and knowledgeable about these type of things. The fact that he did meant that Iskierka looked ready to faint from glee, “You really like them that much!!” squealed Iskierka. “Y-you’re not just telling me this to make me feel better are you?”

“I would never give false critique in that manner. You have a rare artistic talent indeed Lady Iskierka. Don’t let anybody else tell you otherwise,” he encouraged. Iskierka nodded briskly, seeming more confident and encouraged, as she had ever been at any point since the attack.

Callisto, more than a little squeamish from the lovestruck behavior of the young drakka, opted for a more conventional introduction, “I’m Callisto. I just got here right after the attack…” said Callisto.

“A pleasure to meet you. Maybe its just me, but you resemble…what’s her name… Heliana right?” said Lorath, tilting his head sideways.

“That’s right,” nodded Callisto, “She’s my cousin…”

“Well, she’ll be happy to know that you’re safe,” answered Lorath. Callisto merely nodded with a grin. He wasn’t quite as skilled in charming drakes as with the drakka, in which I could honestly say if he had, it would have been more than a little unsettling.

“In any case, I’m going to discuss a few more details with Lady Ramoth. Darzhja, we’ll be heading back to the Temple right afterwards.”

“Do you need any help sir?” I offered, even if contract negotiations were far from my strong suit.

“Thank you for the offer Darzhja, but I’ll be all right. I’m nearly finished anyhow. Why not share to your friends what the Knights have been like so far?” said Lorath.

“Thank you sir.”

Lorath then switched his gaze back toward the orphans, “Its been a pleasure to meet you all, I hope that I will be able to see you again soon!” he cried. Ophelia and Iskierka leaned against each other and waved exuberantly, while Callisto contented himself with just a respectful head bob.

“By the Ancestors Darzhja!! I’m so jealous that you get to be around such a comely Drake all the time!!” Ophelia interrupted, her eyes sparkling, “It must be so hard to concentrate on your work!!”

Callisto rolled his eyes as he pretended not to have heard the drakka giggling, as he busied himself with setting up Iskierka’s art stand on his lonesome.

“It can be hard to maintain my discipline at times…” I couldn’t help but admit. I tried to act more mature and less smitten than Ophelia and Iskierka were; after all I was officially a Knight, but I wasn’t quite sure if I succeeded.

“Is he your… you know…”

My hearts skipped a beat, “Lorath? Well… I’m not sure about that yet… He’s a very chivalrous dragon to work with and he genuinely cares about me. And if things turned out that way, I wouldn’t mind at all… He’s kind, polite, caring and respectful,” I cried.

“Way better than that jerk Fangorn…” I added, without thinking. I realized only after that these dragons would have no idea who I was talking about.

“Fangorn? Who’s he?” asked Ophelia, extending her neck inquiringly.

I let out a grunt, “Remember when I told you how I challenged a Knight at the gate? That’s Fangorn. He’s a paranoid, perverted stalker with dominance fantasies whose sole purpose of existence is to make my life miserable. He always pops out of nowhere and says extremely rude and perverted things to me…” I snarled.

“He can’t be all that bad…” cried Iskierka, shifting her gaze away, “Maybe he just doesn’t know how to express himself very well. And perhaps in reality he likes you…” Iskierka's eyes slanted in the way that I knew so well. She was teasing me, like she had 30 years ago when we were both having our little crushes on the mature drakes, and the males our ages were having crushes on us.

I knew this, but still, I responded as if she were serious; Fangorn's name was like nail caught between my scales. “Trust me, he’s a jerk…”

I swept my wings open in irritation, “Arrgh!! I don’t want to talk about Fangorn right now!!” I snapped, perhaps a bit too violently. Ophelia and Iskierka continued to giggle with intrigue. Perhaps they were using the subject of Fangorn to be in a more favorable position to command Lorath’s favor?

Callisto, eager to get in on the conversation, but also wanting to move it away from drakka gossiping, then asked, “What other interesting people have you met so far thus far?”

I shared to the three younger orphans my friendship with both Lina and Thereesa, making sure to tone down the rather weird shenanigans that each of them faced, in Lina’s case being her cheating mate and Thereesa her unusual sexual preferences.

However, while we were reminiscing and engaging in a rather light tone of our conversation, I suddenly became aware of the one individual who was missing among this clique of older orphans
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Heartthrob

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
“Darzhja. Did you ever find out whatever happened to Blaze?” asked Iskierka.

I shook my head in regret, “No, we haven’t been able to find him…”

“Blaze?” said Callisto. “I remember the two of you telling me that he went missing during the attack…”

“He was kidnapped…” I snarled with an absolute certainty.

“What makes you think that? I know you may not want to hear it, but could he have been killed?” answered Callisto. I ground my teeth together. Considering how many dragons had died during the attack, it certainly was a possibility. Yet in my gut, I doubted that was the case.

“I don’t think so,” I growled, “Maybe its just me, but had he been killed, I would have found his body or at least detected his scent. He was definitely kidnapped…”

Callisto still didn’t seem convinced. He certainly wasn’t the sort of dragon to take any sort of intuition as tangible evidence.

I took a deep breath, gazing about the small chamber to ensure nobody was overhearing us.

“I will let you three in on a big secret. You have to promise not to tell anybody...”

They all nodded.

“My first mission as a Knight was supposed to be a routine inspection of a storage facility in the Industrial district…”

“Wait, won’t you be kicked out if you tell us this?” said Callisto, barely keeping his voice to a whisper.

I hesitated for a moment. “The consequences of not telling you could be worse, so please hear me out,” I whispered. “During the inspection, we discovered that they had hidden a number of dragon eggs in a secret chamber. Instead of surrendering, the smugglers called forth their entire mercenary force to silence us. We were able to beat them, and when they were interrogated we learned that there was an entire underground smuggling network, other warehouses with stolen dragon eggs.”

“So the poor little ones, the ones that you brought to us here, were stolen from their parents?” murmured Iskierka, quavering. I felt bad for having to frighten her like this, but there was no way that I would allow my fellow orphans to remain ignorant.

Callisto took a breath, “What were they planning on doing with so many stolen eggs?”

I sighed, “We’re still trying to find that out, but I have no doubt it is for some terrible purpose…”

“But what does that have to do with Blaze going missing?” said Ophelia.

“Wait…I think I know what you’re getting at…” murmured Callisto, his brows furrowing. “If these smugglers are capable of kidnapping that many eggs, and do so while hiding their operations, who’s to say they aren’t capable of kidnapping young dragons as well?”

His teeth snapped together, “In fact, I wouldn’t be surprised if it was those same people that orchestrated the attack. I mean, it’s a lot easier to get away with these kind of things when things are in chaos…”

There was a long dark silence that permeated through the chamber.

I stepped back and focused my gaze on each of the three orphans, “Now you know what’s at stake. I know that the streets are filled with all sorts of unsavory individuals, but this is entirely different circumstance all together. What happened to Blaze could happen to any of us if we’re not careful.”

“But as long as we’re here in the orphanage we should be safe right?” said Ophelia, though she didn’t look convinced by that in any stretch.

“That is true to a certain extent,” I admitted, “We’ve always relied upon Lady Ramoth to keep us safe, and we can continue to count on her. In fact, Lady Ramoth used to be a famous Holy Knight before she opened the orphanage…”

The eyes of the three drakes widened with shock, but I held up a claw to prevent them from accidentally crying out and blowing our cover. “Yet not even Lady Ramoth can be everywhere at once. Nor for that matter can the people of New Alveri idly assume that the Knights will take care of everything sooner or later.”

“That’s why I’m telling you all this, because I need your help to ensure that the younger ones remain safe in the orphanage, and to make sure what happened to Blaze doesn’t happen again…”
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: The state is set...

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
The glade where I was currently resting was filled with the scent of freshly spilled blood, a bullock’s blood to be precise. It was late autumn and the now thoroughly deceased steer was particularly fat and delicious. I felt that cooking it would only spoil the fragrant, tasty juices, so I tore into it raw. After I had easily snapped the smaller animal’s neck with a twist of my jaw, I opened its abdomen to get at the succulent liver and vitals. Needless to say, I had soon made a horrific mess. No one seemed to mind, however, particularly Lorath who lay beside me; though noticeably just out of range of the splatter.

We’d developed the habit of taking our meals together. We both had our own different schedules, but this way we always got to see each other at least once every two or three days. We descended upon the Temple’s cattle fields before twilight. I enjoyed watching the fierce orange sunset behind the mountains surrounding us whilst dining and then spending the starlit early evening with the comely blue drake before we each inevitably had to part. I did my best to delay each departure until it became habit. As far as I was concerned, we could remain in the windswept damp field until morning every time we met.

As for Lorath, his steer was still sizzling a short distance away. He’d breathed on a stone until it had glowed and then stuffed it in the belly of the carcass to cook from the inside. The blue drake had at least had enough sense to enjoy the liver fresh. He lay sprawled casually on the grass opposite me, his wing carelessly draped over his thigh. Tail flicking idly through the grass behind him, he reached out with a claw to pluck a small cluster of tiny white flowers, which grew at the end of long stems. He asked absently, “Are you the sort of dragoness who enjoys flowers?”

I lifted my bloody face from the now mostly empty interior of my steer. “Those aren’t flowers, they’re weeds.” I scoffed with a bit of smoke from each nostril and then clamped down on a haunch and tore.

Lorath flicked his scaled digits and the clump of flowers fell softly to disappear amongst the grass. He heaved a sigh. The sound came as loud as a thunderbolt to me and I started upright. Though there was blood dripping from my chin and bits of gristle stuck in my fangs, I let my concern show on my face. “What’s wrong?” I asked. I got up and trotted over to where he was laying, I brushed my wing against his side. “I’m sorry that I called them weeds, they’re… pretty.”

Lorath smirked. “To be honest, I didn’t figure you’d like them, I know you’d prefer a good sparring match any day of the week. That’s why I like you Darzhja, you’re different from any drakka I’ve ever met.” I couldn’t help but beam at his statement. Then he looked up and met my eyes. “Come to think of it, how long have we been seeing each other now?”

I grinned toothily. “You mean since I started seeing you, or you finally started seeing me?” I laughed. I never kept it a secret that I’d had my eye on him almost as soon as we were introduced… nor let him live down how long it had taken him to finally notice my attentions.

He chuckled as well and straightened his wing. “You know what I mean.”

I lowered myself down on my belly so I’d be level with him, although as a blue dragon and a male to boot, his was still rather smaller and lighter than I was, but not by a whole lot. I lowered my head onto my forepaws and looked up at him. “It seems like forever…” I said dreamily.

“Well… it’s been three summers since that night.”

Oh yes, that night. Unbidden, a goofy grin spread itself on my bloodstained chops. Lorath was of course talking about the night, about three months after our first real mission together to Lady Ramoth’s escorting the precious dragon eggs, when I’d finally snapped and gushed my heart and soul out to him in his lair. It’d started out as a silly dare from Lina which she’d given me after weeks of - recognizably in hindsight - annoying whining and complaining that he would never notice me. She’d dared me to go to his officer’s lair after dark, and I did and naturally Lorath had caught me almost instantly. What had started out as a game had quickly and heart-poundingly become serious and just then, I hadn’t been able to take one more second of secret and unnoticed emotions any more. I’d laid my heart out on the floor for him, and even broke down in tears while doing it. Lorath could have snapped me in two, right then and there. To think, a drakka so foolishly pursuing when it was her job to be aloof and make him pursue.

But Lorath had reacted favorably and so began many a night of long talks and neck embraces. The relationship had grown further through our mutual work with the Knights; it was always a joy to work under him. It’s still sometimes hard for me to believe that I’d once been an orphan with little more prospect than whoring myself out on the streets for food. Though I was looking off into space for a moment as I recalled this, I soon returned and gave Lorath a friendly sock to his shoulder. “Why are you asking me questions you already know the answer to?”

The smaller blue dragon lifted a claw and rubbed at his shoulder, more for show than anything else; I hoped. “Well… I was just wanting to say that I really enjoy what we have together.”

I kept my face calm and relaxed, but inside, I felt a sinking sensation. Despite our fondness for each other, it was still hard to pick up the nuances of his thought process. “Well, I really enjoy what we have as well, Lorath. I’ve never met another drake like you.” It was hard to fight the temptation to gush. Ancestors! One would think that I would’ve gotten better at this with time! I paused for a moment, then when it became clear that Lorath wasn’t going to speak, I asked, “Is there a reason why you’d bring that up now?”

Lorath lifted his head on his long neck up a little straighter. His powerful azure eyes seemed strained and I saw something in them that I wasn’t used to: fear. “My brother’s become engaged.” He said.

“Loken?!” I asked, suddenly excited. “When? To who?” It took me a moment to notice that Lorath was not exactly excited for his brother.

He let a breath escape through his teeth and then said, “He’s going to be mated with Slytherilia. She’s the heiress of a major clan under former Trade Prince Rek’thalanar.”

“Rek’thalanar…” I said, rolling the vaguely familiar name off my tongue. “Isn’t he in charge of those black dragons?”

“Used to be. Remember, he was killed in the blast along with the other Trade Princes…” Lorath hung his head slightly. He didn’t need to mention that one of those trade princes had happened to be his esteemed grandfather, whom Lorath had loved dearly as a family hero even if as the second son of his second son, he’d received little personal attention growing up. Who’d have thought that the second son would now be in control of a vast trade empire, a full quarter of the Empire’s entire economic might? It was still daunting realizing just how much wealth Lorath’s clan possessed, especially with the fact I had grown up with nothing. Though both his grandfather and his uncle were killed in the awful attack that had rocked New Alveri to its foundations, the chances of Lorath putting his claws on that inheritance remained miniscule. His older brother and his offspring would now have that privilege… in the coming centuries it would take for Lorath’s father to become elderly and infirm.

“That’s right…” I said dumbly. “…So what’s the big deal with the pairing? You don’t seem too happy about it.”

Lorath shrugged. “Of course, it is going to be a rather joyous occasion, with lots of pomp and circumstance, but to be honest I really don’t know how I should feel… You know why they’re getting matched up right?”

“Lorath, please, I have no mind for politics and you know it.” I pleaded.

The blue drake chucked and reached out to cuddle my head with his wing. “Maybe your skull’s too thick for your own good.”

“Come a little closer and I’ll show you the merits of having a thick skull.” I growled playfully. I almost reached out to grab him for a quick tussle, but he simply laughed and folded his wing.

“I’d prefer not to find out the hard way thank you very much, certainly not now considering you’re our ‘Most Prospective Rookie’’”

I tossed my head away bashfully, “It’s an informal title. It doesn’t really mean anything.”

“Really? Words gone around that you almost pinned Shadia.” Lorath purred.

I let the stones in my crop grumble and grind together. “Almost is most certainly not the same as definitely, especially with Shadia. I still think that she was simply luring me into a false sense of victory before she reversed my hold on her… She’s as slippery as an eel you know.”

Lorath laughed at my wide-eyed expression, though for me, Shadia was and still remained a personal demon of my everyday life. Seeing the risk of losing tract of the conversation entirely, I said, “So why exactly is Loken marrying Slytherilia?”
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: A New Venture

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
“Hopefully it’s going to bring more money into our family and shore up our relations with Rek’Thalanar’s clan, although some are saying that they are showing signs of internal division. Honestly, I think Honored Grandfather would have done a better job situating my uncle, but although Loken now holds the same position as he had, he still seems a bit like second prize, unfortunately. I’m sure that Father did the best he could do…” Lorath rattled off.

It pained me severely that I could barely follow half of what Lorath was saying. This was important stuff to Lorath’s background and I realized that all this time I’d been admiring his personality and physical traits, I’d learned only the bare bones of the complex politics that Lorath was - even marginally - involved in. I supposed that I’d thought that since he’d devoted his life to being a Holy Knight rather than working in the family trade empire it didn’t really matter. It obviously did still affect him emotionally, though as was now plainly obvious. “So… you think your brother could do better? I ventured haphazardly. I had nothing against black dragons as a breed, though of all the ones I’d met so far, none of them had struck me as a potentially good mate.

“No. It’s not that,” Said Lorath firmly. “It’s…” But Lorath just gritted his teeth and then rose to his feet. I watched him pace away from me a few steps while he ruffled his smooth, luxurious wings before I rose to go after him.

Although it was obvious, the only thing I could say was, “Something’s really bothering you about this.”

He inclined his snout grimly. “It doesn’t make any sense for me to feel like this but…”

“But what?” I prodded.

It took a few moments, but he finally released his burden. “I’m afraid… for us.”

I looked at his handsome, blue scaled face, but he was looking off into the dim, shadowy valley where the plump shapes of bovines could be seen, well away from the dragon scent, slumbering on their heavy hooves. “You think you’re going to be forced to marry, just like your brother.” I said, hoping that I was connecting the dots correctly. Sometimes I wished Lorath would be a little less enigmatic.

Lorath sighed and sat down on his haunches, though he kept his head high. He turned to meet my wondering, fearful eyes. “Yes. But it doesn’t make any sense for me to feel this way. All of the power will be Loken’s and then only if father meets a premature end. More likely his hatchlings will be the eventual inheritors. It makes no sense for me to be married off and yet, I still…”

“…can’t help feeling the way you do.” I finished for him.

“Exactly.” He breathed, and then sighing again, he leaned towards me and placed his head against the side of my neck. I cradled his horned head under my jaw, relishing in his rich, pungent male odor.

I didn’t want the embrace to end, and neither did Lorath apparently because it was I who first broke it. I pulled away and said, “Well, if it is so unlikely that you’ll be obligated to marry for your family, why choose to be worried about it?”

“That’s just the thing, Darzhja. I’m not choosing to. I’m just filled with this sense of forboding, ever since I first heard of my brother’s engagement. And I can’t make this feeling go away, no matter how I try to rationalize it.”

I reached out and stroked the underside of his throat with the tip of my nose. Lorath purred like a large cat as I did. When I’d finished, I asked, “Did that feel better just now?”

For once, he let an unreserved smile spread across his face. “Yes.”

“Well, maybe it has nothing to do with the pairing at all.” I reached out and laid a wing across the drake’s shapely, slender back. “You’re as tense as a cow in labor. Maybe all you need is some personal time to relax and take your mind off of things.”

Lorath’s eyes darted away but then lit up. He spoke excitedly, so that his perfect white teeth showed as he spoke, “Do you remember what next month is?”

It took a moment for my brain to process this sudden turn in conversation. I flicked my tail several times and then answered. “It has to do with that millennial thing right?”

“Actually, it’s a tri-millennial and it’s a week long celebration of Si’Hazethant’s victory over the ancient blood mages who’d sought to enslave us.”

That jogged my memory. “Oh yeah, that’s right and not only did he win back freedom for the dragons of Nod, but he enslaved those blood mages in turn. That’s the ancient foundation for the Dragon Cult.”

“Indeed. And did you know that it’s formally, a week long celebration? That’s how long the last siege of the last holdout of the blood mages took… Although there’s likely to be festivities pretty much all month long.”

I tossed my head eagerly. “Oh, this is great! Isn’t this celebrated only once every hundred years?”

“That’s right. But since this is the third millennial, it’s bound to be a huge celebration.” My eyes were already lighting up with images of banners and lights and parties and plays and parades… and the feasting. Second only to once-per-decade event celebrating the rebuilding of the Temple and the symbolic start of the New Alverian Empire, this was the big dragon holiday in Nod. While I was sitting there raptured and wondering how I could have forgotten such a major holiday - although to be fair, it had not yet occurred in my lifetime - Lorath spoke. “I’d really like it if you’d spend the holiday with me.”

Slightly startled by the question, nonetheless, I murred softly and rubbed Lorath’s back with my wing, my talon brushing against the upraised ridges of his spine. “You don’t even need to ask, silly! Of course, I’ll be with you.”

Lorath grinned hugely. “That’s great news. I’ll let my people in Damescara know that I’ll be bringing a guest.”

“Wait, what? Damescara?” I stammered. The name of the Empire’s primary coastal and trade city had dropped on me from out of sky it seemed.

“Of course Damescara. That’s where the biggest celebration will be. The blood mages had holed up in the sea caves to the north of what’s now the city, where they thought fire couldn’t reach them, didn’t you know?”

I didn’t know that bit of trivia, in fact. But it was the name of the city which was echoing around in my skull. Damescara… Damescara… Even the name sounded vaguely foreign. And yet it was the place where my current lair mate Heliana originally hailed from and where her cousin Calixsto’s sole remaining family - aside from his largely comatose mother - resided. The poor brave child still lingered in the orphanage, clinging to the hope that his mother would eventual recover or that his family funds would finally be unlocked from the confusion and burned documents left behind in the wake of the bomb. “Lorath…” I started slowly, “I’ve… I’ve never actually been very far from New Alveri.”

To his credit, Lorath did not make light of my confession. He just grinned and leaned in closer, pressing his shoulder against mine and placing his paw over mine. “That’s alright. I’ll make sure you don’t get lost or anything.”

But still, it seemed like the horizon was opening ahead of me and as I looked at its bare, naked surface, I realized something unsettling. I was afraid. “I… I don’t know… Are you sure it will be better in Damescara, I mean, New Alveri is the heart of the empire.”

Lorath smirked and punched my foreleg. Though I growled at him, he said, “You don’t think those wings on your back were meant to get you from the upper tiers to the lower ones, do you? Trust me, dragons fly from one end of the country to the other. Getting to Damescara will be easier than snapping a calf’s neck.”

“Hmm…” I growled, considering Lorath’s words. Though I already knew that I’d follow Lorath anywhere he cared to lead me. “But do you know what’s even easier than snapping a calf’s neck?”

“What?” asked Lorath.

I grinned as I snaked my tail up behind him. “Getting the drop on you!” I grabbed the base of his neck with my tail and pulled him down as I rose. I laughed as he growled and recovered quickly. Of course, Lorath was an officer of the Holy Knights and well trained, but since we were wrestling and not actually fighting, I had a huge weight advantage over him. He squealed deliciously when I finally pinned him down under my bronze bulk, though technically he was still able to flap a wing in my face.

“Mercy!” cried Lorath and I let him stand. He shook the grass and dirt from his scales like a dog and I laughed. Prissy about his appearance as always.

We both stood and panted at each other for a while, both grinning like idiots. I honestly don’t think I could have loved him anymore than I did right then. Lorath sniffed and rubbed the side of his snout with a paw. “I think my bullock’s gone cold now because of you.”

I sauntered back over to where the remains of my kill were waiting for me. Training had hardened my stomach and despite the tossing and turning just now, I wasn’t willing to let the rest of this particularly tasty ration go to waste. “I told you just to tuck in!”

Lorath slowly shook his head as he walked back to his meal. “Just like a beast, my darling.”

“But I’m your beast, and don’t forget it.” I answered and before more words could be exchanged, I was digging into the carcass’s meaty hindquarters and swallowing large chunks of muscle.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Planning for the Holidays

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
I returned to the barracks that night, beaming. Lorath had invited me to Damescara for the holidays!! The thought of it was both scary and wonderful at once, and sent my hearts pounding. Heliana was already waiting for me at our lair.

“Oh!! Darzhja!!” she cried excitedly. Though she’d been my lairmate for the past few years now, I still found myself half expecting Lina to poof in front of me, giggling, while sprinkling mind-altering fairy dust all over me. Nonetheless, I gave her a warm smile, and always looked forward to having her company, no matter how much some of the other drakka disparaged her for her weight. Of course, Tsarra and her whores never called us the ‘fat sisters’ directly to my face, lest she receive a sounder thrashing than usual on the sparring ring. Besides, Heliana had lost quite a bit of weight these past couple of years, and while she would never be trim, she could keep up with the pack in most exercises now, and Shadia didn’t nearly torment her as much now. That being said, as I came inside, Heliana had to scoot over to the side a bit so that the two of us would have enough space to lay side by side.

“You certainly look happy today, might it have something to do with Lorath?” she asked.

“Mmmmhmmm…” I purred, his image forming in my mind. “Lorath’s invited me to Damescara for the Third Millenial!!” I squealed with a higher pitched voice than usual.

“Really? That’s wonderful!!” she cried, placing her head next to mine. I couldn't help but shudder inside.

“I’m actually rather nervous…” I admitted. “I’ve never been outside the confines of New Alveri before…”

Heliana puffed, “You’ll be fine Darzhja. Damescara is only half the size of New Alveri, and besides, it’ll be good to see new places. As it turns out, I’m headed there also to visit father and the rest of my family.”

“Really?” I said, my head perking up, “Since we’re both headed there, why don’t you come with the two of us!!”

“Lorath won’t mind will he?” asked Heliana apprehensively. The last thing she wanted to be was a third wheel, but considering that Heliana was a very close friend and didn’t really have any serious designs on Lorath besides the usual admiration of his good looks that wouldn’t be a problem at all.

“Lorath was the one who asked me to go out with him, so therefore if I decide I want to bring a friend along, he’s in no position to refuse. Besides, I’m sure he’d love to have you along!!”

“You really mean it!?” she replied.

“Of course!!” I answered, giving her a reassuring smile. Having her along also eased a lot of the worry and uncertainty I had for going alone with Lorath, so things wouldn’t be quite so tense and formal.

“So tell me what happens at the festivities?” I couldn’t help but ask.

“Well, I’ve never been to one of the big celebrations, but they do have smaller celebrations once every five years. Usually, they have a parade down the mainstreets and fireworks at the docks, but this party is going to be a million times bigger!! Oh!! I don’t know where to even begin!! A week is hardly long enough for me to show you everywhere!! There’s going to be shopping, wrestling competitions, parades, but most of all feasting!!”

Heliana’s eyes grew big at the thought of her favorite pastime, “Chefs from all over the world are going to come!! The jungle orcs from the south are preparing a herd Water Buffalo!! Fresh porpoises caught straight from the sea!! Big horn elk from the north!! I heard that the most famous chef from the far orient, Lung Chi-fan, is bringing over an entire ship of the most exotic animals from his homeland for us to sample!!”
