My jaw was all but watering with a savage hunger, this despite having just eaten only a couple of hours before. “Oh Darzhja!! I can already taste them!!” she swooned. Yet as it always was with Heliana and food, she took things a step further, as while lost in her fantasy of feast she lowered her neck and began nibbling at my arm as if it were the leg of a prime steer.

“Heliana, I’m not on the menu you know…” I said with a slight annoyance.

“Oh…sorry…” she apologized playfully, lifting her jaw away. I stuck my tongue at her, and we burst into a fit of laughter.

Right then, Shadia burst into the entrance of our lair, as usual looking as if she brought the souls of the condemned with her.

“Excited for the holidays are we hmm?” she said with her oily tongue.

“Well, yes Lady Shadia…” I couldn’t help but blurt out. Even her presence couldn't shake me out of my good mood.

“Yet its not the holidays yet is it?! Torches out in 10 minutes understand fat sisters?!” she shrieked.

“Yes Mam…” we responded simultaneously. Shadia scowled, before storming away to repeat her message to the next pair of recruits.

We let out a sigh of relief. Even though Heliana had improved, Shadia was still the hardest on the two of us. Then again, every drakka in the dorm swore that Shadia made a special exception for them. Heliana angled her head toward the switch that activated the glowing torches, making a concentrated expression for a brief moment, before the switch flicked off, leaving the room dark. It was a little trick that she’d picked up a couple of years ago, and now she could do it easily, though whenever I tried that same rudimentary magic trick I still looked as if I were trying to lay an egg.

“I still don’t get how you do that so easily…” I whispered.

Heliana merely shrugged, “Well, since you’re so good at sparring its only fair… anyhow, good night Darzhja…”

“You too Heliana…” I answered with a smile. I closed my eyes. Yet it was quite a while before I was able to fall asleep, my mind fantasizing about the festival and the time I would spend with Lorath.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Holiday plans

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Although I was still wrapped up in the excitement of Lorath’s offer the following morning, I still had to endure the same routine of a cadet in the Holy Knights as I had for the past few years now. Wake up to the morning call filling the caverns, walk down stairs through the showers and shuffle along with everyone else as well all moved towards the large landing platform set in the inner wall of the Temple. The exhilarating sensation of falling and the cold wind blasting into my face never ceased to shake all remaining sleepiness from my eyes, however, the sheer joy of flying to the training grounds had lost most of its former joy through sheer routine.

On the grounds, we lined up, drakes on the right, drakka on the left, as always and smallest to biggest. Shadia, as always was there, and also the shovel-clawed sergeant Fathgar barking orders at us as we stretched the kinks out of our bodies and then performed rigorous exercise to strengthen them. All of us were stronger now, that is the ones in my original class who were still here. Some had graduated, like Thereesa, and were now full fledged Knights and had other business than to exercise with the recruits; not that they were not expected to remain physically fit as well of course. But others had indeed dropped out when the training had proven too much for them. It pleased me to no end that of Tsarra’s Bitch-cliche, two had not had what it took, reducing her and her one friend down to the bitch-duo; which unfortunately did not roll as easily off the tongue, even in Draconic. New recruits filled the positions of those who left so it seemed that the rookie group remained at about the same time always. Though the new faces that turned up always seemed to surprise me.

What surprised me even more was the fact that I was viewed largely as a senior cadet. Thereesa had had to explain to me that progression in the cadet level was based on performance, not simply seniority. A dragoness could spend a decade or two in the cadet level - although if one did not eventually progress, that dragon was usually dropped after a certain period of time - whereas another might spend half that time. Exceptional dragons were advanced more quickly, the better to be of use to the Order sooner. So it was that when Shadia hounded me, called me an oversized lizard and as slow as a frozen shit sluice, I still saw a black-eyed demon, but I also saw something more. I saw someone who was going to get me to where I wanted to go faster than I could have ever done on my own.

After exercise there were drills and also classes. The drills were not at all dissimilar from what our humanoid counterparts went through. We simply moved in formation, practice for following orders and moving in a group, however, moving on the ground was the smallest part of it. We flew in several different formations and had to reorganize on command. For the humans, drills were mostly psychological work and practice for ceremonies. For us, these airborne formations had very practical use. The classes were my least favorite part of the whole experience. We divided into subgroups, usually about twelve dragons each, and suffered through lectures from both dragon and humanoid instructor. Unless there was some equipment needed, lessons were usually outside and conducted on large chalk boards wheeled out onto the field. I was told that our education was equivalent to pretty much the best available in the upper tiers. But the nuances of Ancient and Modern Draconic and even of written Common were tedious and mathematics made my head hurt. The worst was Magical Theory which didn’t even have the decency to include practical spells. However, through intensive practice, I picked up a cantrip to stop a cut from bleeding during a First Aid lesson; it helped that I accumulated lots of opportunities to practice during training and sparing. The only class in which I was vaguely interested in was Alverian History, which sadly was among the lesser taught subjects.

I still had guard duty at the front gates three days a week. I’d progressed to the point where sometimes I wasn’t even supervised. Although both my partner and I were fairly confident that I could take and would-be trespassers at this point. I hadn’t yet been tested, but I figured it was only a matter of time.

So it was that it was mid-afternoon when we were released from lessons. It seemed a minor reward to be released on time. We were usually penalized as a group for poor performance and when Heliana had been struggling - and I defending her - staying late had been the norm almost since the start. But she’d dropped a lot of weight that first year and although she was still pretty heavy for a drakka and had shown less progress this past year, she was gaining steadily in both stamina and speed. Despite her ample waistline, she could keep up with the group now, and I’d say she was a ready match for most in old fashioned grappling; save for yours truly, naturally. And those times when we were matched up for sparing, despite the fact that she was rather soft under the scales, she threw her weight around effectively and I had to be careful and play against her weaknesses, like her smaller center of gravity.

I wasn’t surprised when Heliana dropped next to me like a boulder smacking the earth as I was pacing away from yet another dull class. She greeted me enthusiastically and then added, “I just can’t stop thinking about this trip to Damescara!”

I grinned, it’d been on my mind all day too… that and Lorath’s pleasingly cut and shapely form. I sighed, “I know, but thinking about it is just making the time go by slower. I could barely stay awake as Dr. Evermore droned on about acceleration, vector shift, and derivation.”

“Darzhja!” Heliana scolded slightly. “That stuff’s important!”

“For what? I’m not going to be a scholar… hey!” I remarked and receive a cuff from Heliana’s wing as a reward.

“Every time we fly, we take those sorts of things into account, even if we don’t know them. I for one, find it neat to explain what we do everyday in a rational sort of way.”

“That’s nice.” I sneered, “I’d rather go flying.”

Heliana, however batted me again. “You might be an ace out on the field, Darzhja, but they are going to keep you here as long as I am if you can’t pass the classes.”

I snorted roughly, but there was truth to what the Silver was saying. I tossed my head, “Urgh… can’t we talk about this later?”

“Sure. Want to join me on the hunting ground? The steer look especially juicy right now.”

Think back to last night I could not help my mouth watering. “I know. I had one last night.”

Heliana chuffed, “I figured as much, I forgot that you only take meals with Mr. Handsome, Rich Blue Drake.”

I growled at my friend, “Don’t tell me you’re jealous.”

She stuck her tongue out at me, “Of course I’m jealous, who wouldn’t be!” My eyes widened, but then she wrapped a big wing around me, “But I’m also happy for you.”

I smiled and was comforted by Heliana’s warmth and soft figure pressed against mine. As the silver withdrew her wing, she said, “Say, have you told Lina yet about your plans?”

I rolled my eyes, “It’s not like I’ve had the chance, you know.”

“You could have spoken to her through one of those mirrors…”

Heliana was referring to the demon powered relay devices set up all around the Temple. Perfectly harmless, or so I’d been assured. But they delivered voice messages only and only in tandem; actual conversation was impossible. “Oh, those things are so impersonal. No, I’ll have to see Lina face to face.”

“Alight then, sounds good to me. Tell Lina I said hi and I’ll be expecting to hear how much her hatchlings have grown when you get back!” said Heliana, apparently thinking that I’d meant that I was leaving to see her right now. However as she spread her large wings and lifted her large body into the air with a mighty leap from her thick haunches, I thought that visiting my former lair mate was actually an excellent idea. Hopefully the guard at her nook wouldn’t give me any trouble…

With that, I too leaped into the air, spreading my wings to catch me and support my weight on the wind. I climbed, angling towards that characteristically leafy perch where the beetles Lina and her offspring required for their diets were farmed in bushes transplanted from her verdant homeland. As I flew, I was already imagining with joy those tiniest of tiny dragons, hardly larger than a dog, rambunctiously chasing each other through the leafy overgrowth and their mother’s cozy lair, all of them poofing and teleporting like mad though their double sets of wings had yet to emerge. However, I also thought that I’d rather not see Lina’s clutch father Ein - short for Ein’theil - there if possible. Though it seemed that Lina had largely forgiven him for his cheating on her - with a human male of all things - I hadn’t, not really. I supposed it was for the best, seeing as their species was endangered, but still, the sight of Ein made me angry inside, all the more because I had to hide it from Lina to be pleasant. It’d be better if he was away during my visit.

Unfortunately, the universe rarely rewards us with our preferences.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Before Holiday

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Instead of one of the nesting guards, I found Lina’s mate Ein’theil guarding the entrance to the lair.

“Ummm…. Hi Darzhja!!” said Ein’theil, trying to sound friendly but clearly coming off as nervous.

“Hello Ein’theil,” I replied, trying to keep myself calm. I probably wouldn’t have been able to remain calm had his human ‘partner’ been with him. From what I’d heard, ever since the scandal, Ein’theil had made an effort to distance himself from the human, and Lina along with her mentor had made sure that the mage apprentice would remain ‘pre-occupied’ with his studies within the mage tower to be able to visit often, of which I was glad. “Would it be all right to come in?”

Though there was no trace or scent of the offending human, Ein’theil nonetheless shifted his gaze evasively. “Er…about that…” he stammered, “Um…”

That hapless, guilty look always irritated me to no end, and always made me wonder if he was hiding something. I lowered my head down at him and frowned.

“No its nothing like that. I just wanted you to know that she’s…got, special visitors!” He choked out from under my shadow.

I grunted again. I wasn’t going to allow Ein’theil to start procrastinating again. Yet right then there was a couple of poofs and a pair of tiny humanoids with wings, even smaller than the half-lings, appeared in front of me. I cocked my head sideways. Like the faerie dragons, Sprites were amongst the rarest of the humanoids, so rare that many weren't even sure they even existed, and surely a pair of Sprites was the last thing I had expected to see.

“Leave Linal’leil’s mate alone you big monster!!” screeched the tiny humanoid, the female one, fluttering up between my eyes to face me. “And if you’re here to eat her little ones I’ll make you go ‘poof’!!”

I didn’t know whether to be amused or contemptuous at the tiny humanoids threat, considering that she was about the size of a human child. “S-sister…” squeaked the male humanoid, “I don’t think it was a good idea to provoke something that big…” Clearly, the male Sprite looked petrified, in quite a similar fashion Ein’theil always seemed to be anxious around me, while the female seemed to be too brave for her own good.

“Wait!!” cried Ein’theil. “Xanna, Isidiel…” gestured Ein’theil to the two fairies, “This is Darzhja. She’s Lina’s best friend amongst the Knights…”

The female fairy instantly perked up, “Oh!! Then any friend of Lina is a friend of mine!!”

“Well then, that’s good enough for me. Yet if you don’t mind me asking, from where did you make Lina’s acquaintance?” I asked.

“My grandfather discovered her egg when he was a boy and she grew up with the rest of us Sprites in the Agogo Forest. We didn’t hear that much from Lina in the years since she’d left, as we hardly let any visitors or news from the outside into the forests to begin with, until about a month ago when Ein’theil came to our forest to tell us that Lina had little ones. Therefore, grandfather sent me and my brother to travel all the way here to help her out on behalf of the clan…” Xanna explained.

“Oh!” I answered. "Well I thank you for coming here to help Lina!!"

“S-s-so…she’s not here to eat us?” said the male Sprite, Isidiel.

I gave the tiny Sprite an odd look. “No…”

The Sprite male didn’t look too reassured. It was Ein’theil who broke the silence.

“Anyhow Darzhja, you’re always welcome to see the little ones. Sorry if I acted all panicky at the gate. Just wasn't sure how you'd react when you saw those two without you knowing they'd be there. As for the little ones are having their nap right now, so be careful all right.” said Ein’theil. He then curved his gaze toward the two sprites, “Anyhow, why don’t you two help me fetch some glowing scarabs for the little ones?” suggested Ein’theil.

“They’re as good as caught!!” squealed Xanna. “Come on brother!!” she cried, pulling her brother by the wing. “R-right behind you sis!!”

I nodded, and made my way inside. When I took a moment to think about it, Ein’theil had made a shockingly thoughtful gesture brining them along. It was loathing to say it, but perhaps he wasn't as bad as I thought.

As always, I could only make my way halfway inside before the quarters became way too cramped. Yet I was able to extend my neck through the leafy, and rather allergenic undergrowth to find Lina with her little ones. I always made sure to be extra careful, worried at how easily the tiny and fragile hatchlings could be badly hurt with but a single sneeze.

Lina was perched upon the center of her nest, giving me a big smile when I entered. Her four little ones were asleep against her side, dozing underneath her translucent wings.

“Darzhja!! Its so wonderful to see you!!” said Lina with a whisper.

I extended my neck to gently nuzzle her, careful not to stir the sleeping hatchlings at her side. When awake, the four of them were unbelievably hyper and out of control. The last time I had visited, little Tink’erl had teleported straight into my nostril and gotten stuck; by some miracle I hadn’t sneezed or else we’d have had a real mess on our claws.

“So I see you’ve met Xanna and Isidiel.”

“Mhmmm… They’re a bit odd, but they seem pretty decent for humanoids,” I admitted. It only occurred to me then, that while Lina was one of my closest friends, I still knew very little about the circumstances in which she grew up.

Lina giggled, “Well, Xanna’s always been the one to boss her brother around. Its amazing how much they’ve grown up while I’ve been away. Of course, I still remember when Arie’del was trying hide me from the clan elders…”

“Arie’del, you’re talking about the leader of the Sprites I take it?” I assumed.

“That’s right. Things happen so quickly amongst the humanoids don’t they?” admitted Lina. “Hopefully, he’ll still be alive by the time the little ones are old enough to come with Ein’theil and I to visit the forest,” replied Lina. It was astonishing and a bit sobering when I thought about it. Lina and I were young dragonesses, coming into our own as adults, while the humanoids who had lived the same number of years were either old or dead. Like Markus, for example, whom I had first met as a young man when I was a fledgling whose wings had barely emerged, and through my sparring career had helped him build up a fortune in the arena business, and was now a retired, wealthy old man, while I was just beginning my own professional career.

“Anyhow, enough with that mushy stuff!! Are you going to do something fun with Lorath over the holidays?” she asked, the mischievous gleam back in her eye.

“In fact, I am!! He’s invited me to Damescara for the millennial ceremony!! Heliana's coming too” I cried excitedly.

“Really!? That sounds like quite a lot of fun. As for Lorath, I bet he probably has some private villa on the Cliffside he’s planning on taking you to…” she whispered with a titter.

A wild cascade of kinky fantasies poured through my mind, leaving my thoughts cloudy and faint. “Oh…that would be very nice…” I purred.

“Should I take this to mean that when you come back from the holidays that I should not be surprised to her news of you taking up the large breed nesting grounds?” she teased. Immediately, a fresh wave of fantasies burst through my mind, my tail wagging back and forth. “Well…I don’t plan on having little ones, at least not until I become a full Knight, but if that circumstance were to come about with Lorath during the holidays, it wouldn’t be quite so bad at all…”

“You're really thinking ahead aren't you Darzhja? I'm happy you like him so much. Still think Fangorn’s more your type though,” she added teasingly yet also somehow forebodingly.

“No, he’s not…” I snorted crossly and far more violently than I intended. Even though I’d been steady with Lorath for the past few years now, Lina always loved to tease me about Fangorn precisely because the admittedly handsome yet infuriating drake irritated me so much.

“Anyhow, I really hope you have fun while you’re there Darzhja. I really wish I could come too, but as you can see…”

She shifted her gaze toward the little ones, both lovingly and wearily. I curved my gaze back to her sleeping little ones, those tiny, fragile little lives, utterly dependent upon the care and love of their mother. Seeing Lina care for little ones made the notion of me doing the same much more tangible in my mind. Yet Lina would be spending the vast majority of her time within her little nest for the next half-decade at least; until they were old enough to be transferred to the fledgling grounds where they would begin their education to become Knights of New Alveri.

Overall, I was happy that Lina had managed to find contentment with her motherhood. Despite a rather flaky personality not to mention his single, scandalous affair with his mage partner, Ein’theil admittedly had made a genuine effort to be there both for Lina and the little ones he helped bring into existence. Thus, as I left and said goodbye to Lina, I hoped that I would at least manage to find a similar contentment when my own time came.

I thought about Lorath again, purring as I flew back to the lair. Indeed, Lorath was definitely was the one. Yet I could never quite shake the feeling or the worry that things might not go the way I had intended.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Lina's little ones

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
The last week before the holiday month of Octilis - simply the eighth month of the dragon moon calendar - was excruciatingly long and tedious. The days I spent standing guard outside the front gates of the Holy Temple crawled by and every time I twisted my neck to look at the water clock in the nearby gatehouse, the large arm seemed to scarcely move. Shadia, sensing the upcoming jubilation, seemed to go out of her way to ensure that it was balanced out by an overabundance of pain leading into it. For my own personal torment, she put me against Heliana in the sparing pit for close combat no less than twice that week. Normally I’d wear her down into submission with repeated tail and wing strikes, utilizing my superior stamina and speed against my stockier opponent, but Shadia in her wickedness decreased the size of the rope circle set in the sand so there was no room to maneuver. I had to grapple with Heliana and combat her weight with my size and muscle. Thus, while normally it would be I having to succor and lick Heliana’s bruises after such times we were forced to spare, this week we comforted each other. And that, I supposed in retrospect, was not so bad.

On the dawning of the new month, I groaned myself awake and twisted the kinks out of my long neck. With a hind paw, I scratched at my still-sore shoulder where Heliana had bashed me good. Some of the scales there had been deformed by the force of the impact and would not lie down straight with the others, leading to irritation. Hopefully I could find a dragon cult member around with a set of pliers and a strong arm to wrench the nuisances free. Heliana rested against my back, her soft warm bulk by now feeling pleasant to snuggle into during the night. I supposed it was only fair considering that I’d provided much the same service to my last lair mate. Carefully, I extricated myself from the heavy Silver and trotted downstairs to shower.

Cold water awakened and invigorated me as well as easing some of the residual pain from yesterday’s sparing. I was not the only one in the common shower. Drakka of many colors and breeds were steadily filling the rough granite chamber, a sense of excitement and anticipation shared among us all. There were many new faces, new drakka just joined two months ago at the annual selection ceremony; something I hadn’t had due to my unusual acquisition by the Holy Knights. I still hadn’t yet learned all their names. Other faces were missing and one in particular I wished I could still see prowling these halls. Thereesa had graduated over a year ago to become a full fledged Knight. Her magical prowess with runes and cryptography set her apart as a prodigy and there had been many awards handed to her during the ceremony. I’d been so happy for her then, despite the fact that in a dragon’s sense of time, she was still a very new friend. I heaved a sigh as the cascade of water poured down on me from the dwarf-made chute. Despite her initial advances and constant teasing thereafter, she was a very good friend and I wished I got to see her more often. Lina too if truth be told.

There was, however, one dragoness in the shower I’d have rather seen gone. That venomous - litterally, she had venom in the quills layering her body - bitch Tsarra lifted her head and sneered at me when she entered the room. I lifted my lips and showed her my fangs. She just did an about face and showed me her vent, remaining in the position while she showered. I tried not to let her irascibleness get to me. This was supposed to be a happy day, the first of a whole month of celebration.

And the sense of commemoration hit me anew as I padded down into the common room after shaking myself off in the shower. Humans were decorating the walls with heavy cloth sashes and banners, blood red, trimmed with gold filigree. On the wall next to the exit to the landing platform, three men were busy painting a mural depicting some sort of of scene from history. It was in its early stages yet, but as with all things related to the holiday, it favored tones of red and orange. I found myself eagerly looking forward to what the skilled hands of the humans would produce. As much as I wanted to stop and ask what it was that they were paining, I had an appointment to keep. I walked around the corner of the mural and built myself into a run as I approached the edge of the platform beyond. I leaped and then spread my wings later, enjoying the rush of the momentary free fall. The air was delicious, clean and cold as I winged my way to Lothar’s quarters.

The blue drake still hadn’t told me when exactly we were leaving or what the plans were in any detail. I’d poked and prodded, but he seemed to want to keep it a surprise. I wasn’t much a fan of surprises myself, but I was willing to trust that Lothar knew what he was doing.

Lorath’s quarters were set slightly higher in the mountain side than the communal drakka recruit den and on the opposite side of the caldera. One of five such complexes in total, the officer’s quarters shared a single entrance on the interior side of the mountain as well as an anterior one which led into the bowels of the labyrinthian complex of tunnels below. When I alighted on the platform, what I saw was a dim corridor, dwarf straight, though obviously large enough for two dragons to walk abreast. Off the sides of this unerringly straight cubical hallway were the officer’s apartments. Each portal was inscribed with a draconic name above and each apartment entrance had an identical twist in the entrance to ensure privacy. A recent addition to the hallway were the gleaming demon mirrors. In addition to their normal functions, these were instructed to display the apartment owner’s face if they were present in their room and remain empty otherwise. The way Lothar made it sound, the magic seemed highly convenient, but every time I looked at a mirror and realized that there was an entity inside - no matter how mechanical or uncomplicated - gave me a shiver.

Lorath’s chamber was four portals down and on the left. I noted that he was present and slipped inside. Compared to someone important like Lady Scabia, Lorath’s chambers seemed remarkably spartan. There were shelves with objects and knickknacks - some magical, some not - lining them, a sooty pit in the center to light a fire - smoke escaped through an air vent in the ceiling. There was space enough for three large dragons to lay around it, though there was no furniture; such as dragons have “furniture.” A small opening in the opposite wall opened into a private sand pit and an adjacent portal opened into his sleeping chamber. In the three years I’d been steady with him, I’d shared that chamber with him exactly once and largely by accident after we’d both imbibed entirely too much wine. It was a fuzzy, though secretly cherished memory by me; however, I sometimes wished I’d taken more advantage of that slip when I’d had the chance.

The blue drake lifted his head when I entered, a man sitting on a stool in front of him turned his head in surprise. His shaved head and tattoos set me at ease, another dragon cult member. “Darzhja!” greeted Lorath, forgetting entirely about his prior human guest. “Good to see you. Happy Festivus!” cried the blue drake, using one of several terms to refer to the holiday month.

I did not pay the tattooed human much mind myself. Among dragons, it was his place to remain quiet until addressed, even though I’d obviously interrupted a previous conversation. I bowed a little and clasped my wings tight to my body - it was appropriate to show some respect in another’s lair. “Happy Festival Days to you too.” I said, moving more into the room. As I was arranging myself opposite the cold fire pit in the center of the room, Lorath surprised me by introducing the human seated in the chair before him.

“This is Sir Danielson.” The man, who’d stood when I entered the room, bowed low. “He’s been informing me of the status of the preparations I’ve made for our Holiday in Damescara.”

“Hmmm…” I purred, more interested in Lorath than the man before his claws, “Preparations that you still haven’t told me anything about.”

Lorath smiled a dragon’s smile. “All in due time, dear one.” He made a show of drawing a deep breath. “And might I say that you smell absolutely exquisite this morning.”

Lorath, whose distinct sulfurous tang elicited more visceral reactions than purely cerebral pleasure from me, smelled like one who had not had time to leave his stuffy chambers in a long while. Because of this, I decided to tease him, “I’m sure I smell like a breeze of fresh air in here. I believe that your human guest will soon keel over in the fumes.”

The man cleared his throat and although I could detect a whiff of sweat under his collar, he said, “I assure you Mistress, I am perfectly content and healthy - it was frequently important to declare one’s state of health to dragons as human beings were rather delicate creatures in comparison and a dragon’s eye could not often detect the nuances in posture or coloration which indicated stress or illness - I’ve developed quite a tolerance to dragon-smell during my years here at the Temple and I say that my overall constitution is stronger for it.”

A flatterer, like most in the church. And like most dragons, Darzhja was happy to indulge in even such general praise and reassurance; something of a guilty pleasure in these more modern times and a remanent of times in which such servileness was required in order not to be eaten.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: First of Festivus

choices: At the gate of the Temple...
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Despite the fact that Sir Danielson was a human - and therefore the effort to get to know him would be wasted due to his short lifespan - I felt a peculiar interest in the man standing between two large scaly predators as an equal; mostly. I lowered my head closer to his level and breathed the man’s mammal stink of oil and sweat and unseemly secretions. It was a little difficult to say, but I guessed that he was tall for a man; he was taller than my elbow when standing, and that was more than could be said of some. Sir Danielson was broad-chested and muscular in his shoulders and arms as well, but not overdeveloped like a smith. This plainly was a fighting man, albeit currently without the usual accouterments of weapon or armor.

“Your constitution is not in question here… Sir Danielson.” I said, taking a moment to recall his name. Human names had a tendency to wash over me and off like water. I turned to Lorath. “Would you care to introduce me to your guest?”

The blue drake inclined his head. “Sir Danielson is a close associate of my clan as well as the Cult. His family has served for generations, traceable until a mere 800 years after the founding. His family have specialized in serving dragon families, both in domestic and protection capacities.” Although he’d yet said anything about Danielson himself, I was already deeply impressed. While individual humans came and went like the rain, their liniages had far more weight on a dragon’s mind and certainly it could be said that some human lines were more productive than some dragon lines. “Sir Danielson himself has loyally served us with his sword arm and his wits for more than half his life. I can easily say that he’s contributed more than his fair share to our collective wealth.” While he spoke Danielson crossed his arms and shifted his weight as if slightly uncomfortable having his doings recounted.

Danielson bowed again to me, lower than the first time. “Lord Lorath is too kind to his humble servant by far.”

“And you too modest.” And although physical contact between dragons and humans was somewhat taboo - unless initiated by the human - Lorath gave the man a friendly snout bump against his shoulder; against which the man swayed only slightly.

Grinning slightly, I asked, “So what have you and your patron been up to here this morning then?”

Danielson spread his arms, “Why we’ve…” then he paused, looking uncertain. He looked over his shoulder to Lorath and the drake gave him an almost imperceptibly small shake of his head that he probably thought I didn’t notice. “We’ve been discussing matters related to his, and your,” he added hastily, “holiday in Damescara. I can assure you that everything has been taken care of.” He swept his hands out in front of him. “My son, Beneford, is waiting at the flat for your arrival.”

“Flat?” I asked, interest peaked. But Lorath growled at Danielson and the man shut up tighter than a clam. He tugged at the collar of his shirt and sweated some more. Clearing his throat he pointed and said, “Your scale looks rather rough on your shoulder there, Mistress. Shall I attend to them before you depart?”

Oh, how I wanted to pry more information out of Lorath’s assistant, but the grating scale - the edge of one digging into the relatively tender skin underneath - did indeed require some attention by delicate hands. In the end the desire for proper grooming outweighed my desire to spoil Lorath’s surprise. “You may approach, Sir Danielson and thank you for the offer.”

“It is my pleasure, truly, Mistress Darzhja.” Said Danielson and went to grab a small leather case off one of the low shelves. I lay very still, almost completely on my side while the human crawled up and on me. He knelt with his knees on my forearm and hand against my warm bronze scales as he extracted some pliars and a file. Humans tend to fidget so much that had there been creatures of similar smallness compared to them, this procedure might have been difficult for them. Fortunately for Danielson, however, dragons usually find it easy to remain perfectly still for long stretches of time.

I snaked my head up at Lorath without moving the large bulk of my body. “Flat?” I repeated again.

“My family has a private residence in Damescara. Surely this doesn’t surprise you?” said Lorath, obviously trying to brush the slip off and subtly putting me off revealing the extent of my ignorance as well.

Frowning slightly, I allowed the ploy to work. “So what…” I grimaced as Danielson grasped a large shoulder scale, as large as his own palm, and tugged, hard and sharp. I felt the broken scale come free with pain and relief like loosing a sore tooth and he pressed a cloth to my side to absorb the trickle of blood. “… About your brother’s wedding? Seems a fine time to have a pairing.”

“Indeed, it is. They have decided to hold it on the 25, near the end of the month.” I nodded, that would be when the celebration would be approaching its climax, but not so close as the celebration itself would take priority. “However, there’s been a slight complication. Axel Xion has announced his intention to attend.”

I cocked my head. On my shoulder, Danielson was using his pliers and a pick to move surrounding scales back into order and smooth them. “Why does that matter?” Axel Xion, as everyone in New Alveri knew was one of the four trade princes who collectively controlled nearly all the private wealth in the empire, furthermore, he was the only one of the four who has survived the devastating terrorist attack on the city. It was also interesting to note that of the original four, Axel Xion was the only non-dragon trade prince.

Lorath shrugged and sighed. “Politics. Slytherilia is not at all fond of Axel Xion and her family shares her opinion… or rather she shares her family’s opinion.”

“Black dragons being speciesist,now that’s a surprise,” I thought sarcastically. “That’s hardly fair. What is he again, orc or something? That’s no reason to exclude someone from a wedding.”

“Actually he’s dragonborn.” Lorath corrected and I swallowed. It didn’t make any difference theoretically, but it was well known that dragonborn as a race harbor fairly intense animosity towards dragons in general. Maybe people on both sides have tried to quell the feud, but still the hate was there, even if it was more a smolder at this junction in time than a blaze. Lorath continued, “And the issue is more complex than that.”

“How is that?” I asked, again feeling woefully naive about the nuances of Lorath’s world.

Lorath hissed through his teeth. “Axel has been cutthroat in his business dealings the last few years. He really took advantage of the aftermath of the attack to expand his own trade clan. We’ve all been on the defensive with the loss of our patrons and in-fighting over who would lead next. He used to be restricted to the textile manufacturing market and recently began to dabble in overseas trade.

Now he has a near monopoly on out-of-empire trade and has been expanding steadily into overland trade as well. He’s got his claws in everything nowadays, from mining to cattle and even magical research. Some of the more conservative derail him for moving wealth out of dragon hands, while many also feel that he is a champion of humanoid equality.”

Sir Danielson snorted, clearly declaring which side of the argument he was on. He took out his file from the pouch and began trimming the scales for a more a more elegant look. It would have been easy to see this Axel as a villain from Lorath’s description, but I’d lived my life in the lower tiers and seen the suffering of the poor, dragons and humanoids alike. Despite the squalor, it was actually pretty rare for a dragon to starve. There was almost always a use for a dragon, and the desperate could resort to selling teeth or toes to magicians for money. Humanoids didn’t even have that measure to rely upon and I’d seen them wither away in the streets. Therefore, I took a neutral position. “He sounds like a complicated humanoid.”

“He is, and like most persons with power, he has his own controversies. Some won’t even admit that he’s a real trade prince.”

“How’s that?”

“Axel rose to power quickly by banding together several wealthy investors into a large fund of which he was placed in charge. It can be argued that none of the wealth is really his… But I don’t think that really matters. It’s not like he’s going to gather it all up into a pile and sleep on it.”

My eyes rolled playfully, however the thought of my small pile of gems in the Temple bank underground expanding into a room filling hoard made me salivate more than a little.

“Anyways, it’s quite a tale, if you want to know more, you ought to read his auto-biography.”

“Biography?!” I scoffed. Biographies on humanoids in New Alveri were usually written after they were dead. How else could you have enough material to work with otherwise? “Anways, what’s Loken to say on the matter?”

“He’s unsure, but I think he’ll insist on sending him an official invitation eventually. We can’t afford to isolate our clan from his at this time, I think.” Lorath said thoughtfully.

Again, for me, this was all much too over my head to consider and I was tired of trying. Danielson dabbed at my shoulder again with the cloth and then stepped off my forarm. “Everything laid smooth?” I asked while lifting my head to inspect his work.

“Perfectly, Mistress.”
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Sir Danielson and son

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Once we had finished with our preparations, Lorath and I headed toward the front gate of the Temple. As always, one always had to check out with the sentry there before heading off, whether it be for a mission or for this case a holiday. Unfortunately, yet perhaps not surprisingly, the irascible, stalking but admittedly very good looking bronze drake guarding the entrance was Fangorn. I figured that by now he would have found some other recruit to pester, but if anything he'd become even more of an irritation, which forced me to conclude that he had some sort of personal vendetta against me.

As we passed underneath, Fangorn was doing his best impression of a statue. “Good morning Fangorn…” greeted Lorath.

“Morning Lorath, Darzhja…” he answered. “Hello Fangorn…” I replied, with as neutral a tone I could muster. Fortunately, Fangorn seemed content to remain silent, in which not a small part of the reason why was because Lorath was there.

Lorath tried to start a conversation. “You never shared to me what you plan on doing for the holidays Fangorn…”

Fangorn seemed to lighten up slightly. Lorath had somehow kept up a friendship with the irascible Bronze Dragon and I could only wonder how he could manage such a miraculous feat. “I’ve been kept on active duty throughout the holiday. After all, someone still needs to keep watch and maintain public order while everybody else is out cavorting without a care in the world…”

“I suppose that none of us are quite as dedicated or patriotic as you are Fangorn…” I said with a roll of the eye.

Fangorn snorted, looking as if he wanted to say something more, but deciding not to.

“So, are we cleared to leave sir?” I said.

He swallowed visibly. “Actually there's something you should know…”

“Yes? What is it?” I growled harshly. “What you should know is that you should keep alert if you’re headed to Damescara right now…” he said.

“Thanks for telling us that Lord Obvious, but I think we can take care of ourselves thank you very much…”

Fangorn’s eyes narrowed. “That’s not what I mean Darzhja. What I’m trying to say is that, well, I’m not allowed to give too many details, but my department has been investigating the New Alveri attack, and that with the hoidays, this would be as prime time as any for them to stage a second attack, and that certain pre-eminent individuals are responsible for it…”

“You’re not making sense Fangorn…” I snarled. It was very like Fangorn to talk in circles, likely in an attempt to confuse me and expose just how ‘uncultured and ignorant’ I was.

“Fine, let me put it in terms that even you can understand. Again, I can’t reveal any specific details, but based on data I’ve analyzed and my own personal opinion, I think its better that you canceled the trip…”

“Cancel the trip?” I snapped, “By the Ancestors you’ve got to be joking!!”

Lorath raised a wing to hold me back, which I was thankful that he did or else I would have pummeled Fangorn right then and there. “Fangorn, I can understand your concern that the gathering of my clan would constitute a certain level of risk, but I am obligated to attend my brother’s wedding.”

“That may be, but its probably better if you didn’t take Darzhja along…” he growled back.

I couldn’t stand any more of this. I spun toward Fangorn and slammed my claw against the ground.

“Oh!! I see how it is now!! The only reason you’re doing this is because you despise Lorath and jealous of the fact that he is a kind and considerate drake while you’re nothing but a stalking, perverted wretch!! All you ever do is bug me and make my life miserable!! Since you are so fond of your conspiracy theories, why don’t you go back to your cave and sulk where nobody can see you?”

“Do you really think me so petty Darzhja?”

“Yes!! I do Fangorn!!” I snarled, wings unfurling, “That’s all you’ve been doing ever since I arrived at the Temple!! I don't know what you have against me and I don't care to know, but just because you like to be boring doesn’t mean I have to be, so if you’re so determined not to let me go, I dare you to try and stop me!!” Fangorn's eyes went wide, and for a moment I actually thought he did want to fight right then and there.

“Come you two, lets not start a fight here…” said Lorath.

“Look Darzhja, I know its true that I’ve put you through a lot of crap. Yet…the truth of the matter is that…I’m telling you this because…”

“Because you what!?”

“Because I care about you Darzhja!! More than anyone else in the world!!" Fangorn shouted.

A choked, high pitched noise came out of my throat, hearts beating a million times per second as I could only stare at Fangorn, whose eyes glowed with a mad, desperate intensity. I didn’t know whether to hit him, to scream at him or cry. More than anything else, I was frightened. After all his posturing, Fangorn had finally cracked.

“Why? W-why do say this now?" I stammered. Before I could stop myself, I lifted my claw and smacked Fangorn across the face with my open claw. Fangorn just stood there and took the slap, not moving a muscle and as if he did not feel the sharp, piercing sting.
You’re such an idiot Fangorn!! If that’s really the truth, then you sure have a nasty way of showing it!! If you were even a tenth as nice as Lorath is I probably might have liked you, but you’re not!! You’re a jerk and you haven’t tried to show yourself as otherwise!”

Fangorn continued to stare at me dumbly and just take it. For a moment, I even felt bad for him. That’s when I realized it. He didn’t act high and mighty because he thought himself superior, but because he was a recluse who had few friends and insecure of himself.

Lorath walked forward to confront Fangorn forlornly, “Look Fangorn, you’ve been a good friend to me for a long time, since we were both lairmates. You were there for me after my grandfather and uncle died, so I know that you are sincere in your sentiment of your warning. Yet, it dismays me to see you acting so hostile and unbalanced. I know you’re better than this. If you had concerns, why didn’t you say anything before rather than wait until this inopportune moment to put us in this awkward position?”

“But you don’t understand…” Fangorn looked as if he wanted to say something more, but Lorath stopped him.

“Enough Fangorn…” retorted Lorath, “I know you’ve got your problems, we all do, but leave Darzhja out of them understand?”

Fangorn took a deep breath, looking defeated. I thought I’d be happy to see Fangorn finally give up, but somehow, I felt empty.

“Anyhow, you’re both free to pass now. I apologize for my behavior earlier. It was immature and unbecoming of me…”

“I hope you have a safe and happy festivus.”

Fangorn sounded shockingly and even despairingly sincere about that last point.
“I wish the same to you Fangorn,” answered Lorath, but his heart didn’t seem in it.

Lorath turned back toward me, with a grin that looked forced, “Sorry to keep you waiting Darzhja. Lets…lets just go…”

All I could do was nod back. I couldn’t find it within me to nuzzle him or whisper something sweet to rub it into Fangorn; it would have made a toxic situation worse.

Fangorn stood there like a statue once more, staring at those two fly off and away. Once again, just like every time that he tried to express himself, everything went terribly wrong. Yet this time, when he’d laid himself all out, the bottom had fallen off. Yet it wasn’t Lorath’s or Darzhja’s fault; the fault was entirely his. Time and time again he had failed, and this time it seemed that he had failed for good. It was sadly ironic, because he’d graduated close to the top of his class, acknowledged as a superior fighter, a great organizer, a quick thinking tactician, and a keen mind for academics, yet now he finally realized the reason why he was still doing guard duty while others in his class, like Lorath, were headed for greater responsibilities.

He was a jerk…

---------------------------------------

Neither Lorath nor I said anything for about a minute following the awkward encounter with Fangorn.

“Do you think Fangorn could actually be right about a possible attack upon Damescara?” I couldn’t help but ask.

I expected Lorath to say something reassuring as he always did, but he seemed equally at unease. “Its certainly possible. We cannot rule out the possibility…”

“Yet the way I see it, even if there was danger of an attack, I’d be going anyhow. I’m not going live in fear of shadowy assassins. I came with you so we could have a fun time together!! What better way than to show those who hate our civilization that no matter what they do, we will hold on to our traditions and take part in festivities!!” I answered. As far as I was concerned, all that stuff about Axel Xion, shadowy attackers, family intrigue and politics could go to the powers below. Perhaps that made me blissfully ignorant, but it was better than to live in a shadow of fear.

Lorath smiled back, seemingly reassured, “That’s one way to look at things. Not that I disagree. Maybe it is better to just forget all ones worries of the world and just have fun…”

I murred contently, leaning up against him. By then, we were at the outer walls of New Alveri when someone called out to us.

“Darzhja!! Lorath!! Over here!!” cried a voice. When I turned, I saw that it was
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Fangorn cracks

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
At the last gate set in the outer wall of the city of New Alveri - where Lorath and I had to show our identification one last time before exiting the city - I found a familiar face I had not had the chance to see in quite a while.

Kaj, the sky swallower captain whose job it was to guard the eastern gate, sat on his perch above the ground level portal, as huge and impressive as ever. My feet felt light as I danced my way over through the crowd of other dragons and humanoids at his beckoning. "Well, aren't you a sight for sore eyes, you overfed brown serpent."

"Classy as ever, eh, Darzhja." The very large dragon brushed off casually. "I see the Knights haven't taught you any manners yet!"

I bent my legs and dropped into a crouch, tail high. "But they've taught me to fight!"

Kaj's chuckle sounded like boulders grinding together. As he slipped off his wide perch, the traffic below gave way naturally to his great bulk. Though it seemed unlikely, Kaj appeared even larger on the ground than above. He all but towered over me, his shoulders reaching the height of a horse over my own withers with a chest twice as broad as my own. He was a worthy specimen of his kind and definitely worthy of his title, which was practically the highest a technical "civilian" could achieve in the city militia. "You've grown." I observed with a tone that could be construed as either compliment or ridicule.

Kaj decided to take the former. "Thanks." He said and bowed his great head a little. He raised his claw and pressed a knuckle against my breast, "You have too, Small Fry."

I smirked, twisting my head away, all but preening, "What can I say, the Temple serves us an excellent diet."

We both laughed and Lorath took the opportunity to step forward. I realized with a start what this might look like to him. Hurriedl'y I sought to make his introduction. "Kaj, this is Lorath, Lorath, Kaj."

Kaj, though snorted, "Oh, Darzhja, I know who Lorath is. An outstanding junior Knight if half the tales I've heard are true."

"And who could mistake the formidable size of the Guardian of the East Gate? You were the Edifice of the Tartan Pass, if I'm not mistaken? During the west Empire skirmish?"

Kaj beamed at mention of his past exploits. His large round eyes drifted away momentarily as he recalled, "Held the pass alone against the Sardishian Calvary. For a month, I sat in that valley, eating charred horse meat and not suffering one to pass and live. Eventually, they just gave up and decided to hike over the mountain, but by then, our own ground forces were able to flank them."

I had known of the story, of course, but right now, with the misty look in the large dragon's brown eyes, and perhaps still frazzled by Fangorn's warning, it struck me anew what it must have been like. And the exploratory force from Sardish to the far west of Nod was routed only 50 years ago. Suddenly, danger seemed to be near and present, however much I wanted to deny Fangorn the pleasure of rattling me and spoiling my vacation with Lorath.

A part of me still thought that this was the intent of Fangorn's plea, but I had to let go of my suspicions for the moment because both males were looking at me. Realizing that I'd spaced out for a moment, I was pressed for an answer. I coughed and then looked up, ruffling my wings slightly and said, "So what are your plans for the holiday, Kaj? Me and Lorath are heading out to Damescara."

"Ah, Damescara. I haven't been there in a century." Kaj lowered his head though and looked at Lorath in a new light however. Ever so subtly, his wing shifted to a protective stance over me. "You two be careful down there. The water dragons there are fiercely territorial and like as not to kill you if you trespass on their reservation. I learned that the hard way myself when I tried to take a bath in the ocean!" Kaj shook his head sadly, "And I'd thought I'd finally found a pool big enough to stretch out in. Ruined the whole trip." I laughed and sat on my haunches as Kaj addressed my first question. "Well, as for little old me, the Guadian of the East Gate can't just shirk off his duties…" I was slightly crestfallen to hear that my old mentor too would not be able to join in the holiday month, but then he went on, "But I managed to swap a week at the end with an old pal of mine. That's my favorite part of the month anyway."

That's great!" I exclaimed, giddy for the behemoth who would have time to celebrate and probably get drunk on barrels of wine as well.

As if trailing on the edges of my thoughts, Lorath spoke, "If you find yourself without enough to eat or drink during the holiday, feel free to look up my clan here in the city. They'll treat you well."

Now Kaj looked surprised. "Are you sure?" he asked, humbled. It was well know the appetite of a sky swallower, especially one of such generous size as Kaj.

"Just tell them Lorath sent you. And please feel free to splurge. This is a holiday after all!" Then he said more quietly. "Besides there are always so many leftovers afterwards anyway."

A wide grin spread on the brown dragon's face. "I can promise you that you won't have that problem this year!"

We laughed, though I wondered just what force of nature Lorath had frivolously invited to his family and business parnters' tables.

We shared some more small talk and caught up with each other some more. Kaj was delighted to hear how far I'd progressed as a recruit, already with a successful mission under my belt and furthermore with a job guarding a gate. The much larger gatekeeper beamed and was set to practically gush tips and "tricks of the trade" before Lorath saved me.

"My friend, I'm so happy we got the chance to meet, but I'm afraid if we stay any longer, our whole itinerary is going to be ruined."

Kaj looked down at me and Lorath in turn. And although the size disparity wasn't so bad between Kaj and Lorath as say me and Lina, Lorath looked so small and frail compared to Kaj's towering bulk. It was little wonder he'd earned a title such as "Edifice." As he spoke, he winked at me. "Well, I can see that you two lovebirds are eager to be off. I won't keep you any longer."

But then Kaj lowered his great, multi-horned head very close to mine and all but wrapped a huge wing around us. I could see nothing but rich brown leather, red tinged with veins through the sunlight. Kaj said very quietly, but very seriously, "You be careful out there, Darzhja. I'd die if anything happened to you."

The sunlight returned, banishing the moment and leaving me stunned, wondering if what had happened really did happen. Then I saw Kaj moving away with Lorath and had to leap after them. Kaj could barely fit through the portal he guarded, hunching his wings close to his body and lowering his head under the jagged tips of the raised portcullis. Lorath walked a fair distance behind the large dragon's waving tail, and of course, their passage and mine caused a small traffic jam in the constant flow of wagons and people in and out of the city.

Outside, as always, I felt exposed, what with the safe walls which usually constantly surround me absent. The vast flat horizon, speeding out over a golden ocean of fields seemed to glare at me, offering impossible distances and impossible danger. The sky too seemed too big somehow and I almost felt like it would swallow me up should I arrogantly step up into it. I tried to hide the slight shiver in my legs, but couldn't. I'd faced down a small army of mercenaries, and yet couldn't shake this stupid fear of open places. Pathetic.

Kaj sat in the dirt outside the city and scratched at his neck like an overgrown dog. A few scales the size of dinner plates fell to land in the road. A human with a pike scrambled out to collect them for Kaj who would undoubtedly sell them for a few silvers later; and tip the man who retrieved them of course. Out here, he was still huge, but lost some of his building-like stature. I suddenly realized that the wilderness was vast enough to swallow up even one as enormous as Kaj. My shaking got worse.

After a few last goodbyes, me and Lorath threw ourselves up into the air. I was in a hurry not to show Lorath what the outside world was doing to me. We spiraled up, gaining altitude on rich thermals that smelled of crushed wheat. We danced about each other for a while and then when the air was chilly about us, Lorath lead the way, following the broad east road which would lead to Damescara and the ocean beyond.

The first segment of the journey away from the city was uneventful. With my training, I was prepared for the long hours of flight, though perhaps less prepared for the tedium. My fear and growing anxiety as the towering bluffs of New Alveri disappeared behind me helped keep me from being completely bored however. We traveled past dusk to make up for lost time. Bonfires on the ground alerted us to the first way station. I wasn't looking very forward to landing, but at the lodge, I was in for a pleasant surprise.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Goodbyes to Kaj

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
The waypoint could have been called a small town, in fact Lorath told me that it was not uncommon for the bigger ones - like the one we were currently gliding towards - to house in excess of four thousand humanoids. The key feature that distinguished the way point from any other town was the landing arena. For all it's humanoid habitation, there could be no doubt that this place was designed to meet the needs of traveling dragons first, house smaller beings second.

The arena was highly visible, even in the gloom of night. It was ringed with bonfires in a highly specific pattern that Lorath told me was common to all way stations: two gently curved rows and a smaller curve at the bottom; horns and a nose ring, which to a dragon was synonymous with dinner. And honestly, after a full day of flying, the thought of fresh bloody beef before me was greatly welcome. It sat in the middle of the settlement. Around the flat, lit arena were the largest buildings, dragon taverns and stalls for sleeping. Away from these hulking structures, the size of the buildings gradually decreased, eventually leading out into the fields and pastures which liberally filled New Alveri's breadbasket. Though, after only a day of flying, I was already bored with the sight of never-ending fields of wheat and corn; less so with equally endless pastures filled with plump cattle.

Dust rose in a cloud around me as I alighted heavily on the trampled earth of the arena. Graciously, I folded my aching wings and hung my head doggedly waiting for Lorath, who was still circling overhead, to land. Before he did, however, there was already a large shape moving out of a tall, barn-like structure towards me.

I hunched my shoulders, but my nose belayed my cautious first reaction. I lifted my head and smiled, "Greetings Heliana!"

The large silver walked briskly over and rubbed noses with me briefly, then she scolded me with a harsh look. "You were supposed to be here hours ago! I was sick to death waiting for the two of you! Where's Lorath?"

Lorath alighted gently on his hind legs and let himself down easily, holding himself up with two careful flaps of his wings. He scarcely marked the ground under him as he did so; show-off. "Did I hear my name just now?" he asked, smiling at the heavyset drakka.

I could tell that Heliana was struggling to hang onto her affrontment… trying and failing in the face of the comely young drake. "I was just telling Darzhja how you and her almost stopped my hearts worrying about you." She said, though from her tone of voice I thought she'd pretty much already forgiven us.

Lorath stepped forward and affectionately touched Heliana on the shoulder with his wing. "I'm sorry we're late. But I am glad to see you safe and sound here. I hope things haven't been too unpleasant here."

Heliana rolled her eyes slightly, but she certainly didn't flinch away from Lorath. "Well, I have to say that the station has better accommodations than I was expecting, and they had an excellent beef stew." she said thoughtfully, and even licked her chops once without thinking about it.

I grinned, "Well that sounds excellent. I could really go for some thick meaty st-"

Heliana's tail flicked in front of my nose, "Well, then I'm sorry to say that there'll be no stew for either of you. They stopped serving dinner an hour ago." She lifted her nose in the air and snorted, "Serves both of you right, anyways."

I was actually crestfallen with the prospect of going to bed hungry, but Lorath just thought it was a joke. He harumphed and said, "I think we'll both live. Now why don't you lead us in since you've had time to settle in?"

"Oh… I suppose I can do that. Anything for you, Lorath." And she licked her chops at the blue drake as a way to tease me. I gave the heavy silver the evil eye as she led us out of the circle of flattened earth.

Heliana's thick tail waved ahead of me as she lead us to a large outdoor counter adjacent to one of the large barn structures. Red paper lamps hung from the rafters overhead, illuminating the slight, off-green form of who I could only imagine was one of the innkeepers here at the station. The angle of the dragon's face and its proportions spoke feminine, but when the innkeeper spoke, I was surprised to hear a masculine baritone.

"You're looking for lodging? Unfortunately they're all checked out..." the stationkeeper said with a bored sounding voice, not bothering to look up from his perch.

"No lodges!?!" I called out in dismay, wings unfurling.

"Well, if you two had arrived here earlier than there would have been rooms available!!" said Heliana heatedly.

"Are you absolutely certain that there are no more rooms available?" asked Lorath calmly. "Not for an esteemed member of the Dak'saird clan and his guests?"

The innkeeper finally shifted his gaze up at us. "Ah!! If it isn't Lord Lorath!! I admit it has been quite some time since I've seen you last, not since we learned you became a Knight!! It would seem that you have developed a peculiar taste in drakka since then..."

I tilted my head sideways and uttered a slightly hostile, inquiring growl, unsure if he meant it as a veiled insult or not, as did Heliana.

"I meant unique of course!!" he replied placatingly. It didn't quite satisfy me, but I was willing to let the issue slide.

"Nice to see you against Sidor. These two are Darzhja and Heliana, both of whom are up and coming Knights," answered Lorath pleasantly.

"A pleasure to meet you both!!" He then sifted through the long flat sheets of leather parchment with deft claws, "In any case, now that I think about it, perhaps there is one more room available that I overlooked...."

"I thank you greatly Sidor," replied Lorath, grinning contently, "Anyhow, so, how has business been going at the station?"

"Thankfully, the holidays have provided us a nice boon of profits, given the number of guests coming from New Alveri. Axel Xion and his mob had been growing increasingly aggressive in trying to buy control of the waystations. He's already taken down many of our usual suppliers along the route. I dare hope that your brother's marriage with the Shadowfang heiress can reverse this worrying trend...": he replied.

"Indeed, ever since the New Alveri attack, Xion has sought to take full advantage of the vacuum. Of course, were I in his exact same position, I'd be trying to do something similar, though perhaps not giving the impression of being quite so eager to profit from tragedy..." added Lorath. Heliana and I stared at one another, shurgging. While Heliana's family were merchants, neither of us could really begin to comprehend these sort of matters. The two of us were Knights; dragons whose duty was to protect the Alverian Empire from her enemies through our prowess in battle.

"I'll definitely bring up these matters before father and the rest of the clan, rest assured Sildor. Now then, its been quite a long day, would you mind showing me and my guests to our quarters?"

Sildor, the innkeeper, perked up in a pose of almost exaggerated erectness, "Oh yes!! Right this way..."

The walk was a rather short one, and I couldn't help but shift my gaze a bit nervously at Heliana. There was only one room, and the two of us drakka. The resting station wasn't particularly large, with just a few torches and a central resting chamber. "I apologize if the accomodations aren't quite so spacious, Lord Lorath," said Sildor.

"Don't worry about that. I'm just happy to have lodgings for the three of us at all...." After all, it was only meant as a transit point, and thus not much had been placed for luxuries.
Lorath looking rather sheepish between the two females, both of whom were larger than he, exclaimed "Well, I hope the two of you don't mind sharing the room with me tonight..."

Of course, since Heliana and I had been lairmates since Lina had left, it wasn't as if we weren't familiar with each others presence, but Lorath hadn't been part of the equation either.

"Doesn't seem like we have much of a choice either..." added Heliana, trying to sound ambivalent but I could tell she looked thrilled with the prospect. "Fine by me... just for tonight though" I added, for emphasis, perhaps a bit more forcefully than I intended. While it was extremely unlikely that Heliana was actively trying to steal Lorath's heart away from me, privately I was a little concerned that Lorath had no problem at all with sharing both me and Heliana, and the fact he'd introduced us both collectively to the innkeeper instead of emphasizing me exclusively as his guest of honor. Perhaps it was more Lorath being his usual generous self and not wanting to put Heliana in a position of feeling left out, but I did vow that once we got to Damescara that his attention would be devoted fully to me.

In any case, all three of us were too tired to really make too big an issue on the sleeping arrangements. Thus, I snuggled up next to Lorath and closed my eyes, as did Heliana, in which the compartively slender drake found himself squeezed between the bulk of the two drakka.

Lorath looked a little bit apprehensively at the two females squeezing against him from both sides, both of whom had begun snoring quite noisily. Regardless of whatever else happened, this was going to be a holiday unlike any other.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Rest station

choices: to pay the difference between the new and regular price of cattle
to request an official audit to look into the matter
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Dark Blue. That's all I could see. As I awoke, I was filled with disconcertion until I realized the obvious. It was only Lorath's wing covering my face. "Ugh…" I sighed groggily and carefully moved the blue drake's wing away from my eyes. My other two roommates were clearly still sleeping, judging by the soft snoring still filling the bare wooden stall; though in Heliana's case, the din she produced wasn't what I would have called "soft." I lifted my head a little and was rather shocked by what I saw.

Lorath, his slender shape smushed between the two larger drakka, had rolled around completely on his back in his sleep. At first I felt sorry for what must have been an uncomfortable position, but the more I looked, the more I saw that he was clearly favoring Heliana in his awkward recline. His chest rose and fell slowly, his claw resting on Heliana's well rounded withers, as the rest of him was cozily nestled against the silver's admittedly soft flank. A scowl formed on my lips when I saw that he was resting his hind feet on the strong outward curve of the still-paunchy silver's abdomen.

Strangely, although I was miffed that Lorath would choose - even unconsciously - to snuggle with Heliana over me - although to be fair in these cramped conditions, a lot of the blue drake was still resting against me - what angered me the most was that I couldn't confront him with this. I knew exactly what he'd say. He'd say, "I was sleeping, I didn't know what I was doing." And Heliana would do what she was best at, diffuse the situation with a joke at her cost, likely along the lines of mentioning how she was a much better pillow than I was, due to the rampant softness under her scales. And was it really wrong of Lorath to want to be more comfortable?

I turned my eyes away. Now I was doubting myself. I wasn't the sort of drakka to hang on to useless anger, so I decided to allow myself a petty revenge and let the matter slide. I stood abruptly, yawning, which resulted in Lorath fumbling off of Heliana and awakening with a shock as he hit the scratched and pitted wood floor beside me. "Umph!" he grunted and lifted his head to look around blearily.

"Oh, I'm so sorry, Lorath!" I said with mock dismay. "I'm so clumsy!"

Lorath was still too sleep muzzled to notice my sarcasm, which I found both gratifying and aggravating at the same time. "No worries, no worries, my Dear. I'm fine…" he punctuated his sentence with a huge yawn with showed all his rows of sharp teeth. I unwittingly received a blast of rank morning breath.

I waved a wing in front of me, moving away. "Ugh, Lorath, go scour your teeth or something before we all pass out."

The blue drake just smiled at me and turned in a tight circle to exit the open chamber, stretching his finely crafted wings out behind him the moment he passed through the portal. I had to acknowledge in my heart that I'd already forgiven him.

As Lorath began to wash his mouth and face in the handy trough outside the door, Heliana began to stir, awakening reluctantly as was her habit. I moved over to her and rubbed her shoulder with a paw lest she slide back into slumber as she was prone to doing. For all her dietary reform and exercise and her dramatic improvement in physical prowess, the silver dragons remained more than a little chubby, and I could feel it on her shoulder as I shook her. I thought it likely that she would probably remain like this, especially since she hadn't managed to drop even a half stone in the last six months. And as I saw her eyes flutter open and a grin spread on her face, crinkling her somewhat fleshy cheeks completely oblivious to what I saw just moments before, I thought I didn't mind that at all.

Heliana, either because she was comfortable in being herself around me or because she was used to filling the role of the quirky friend, said, "I smell cattle."

I laughed, hard. Because it was just like Heliana to mention food in her first breath of a new day and because suddenly I had the mental image of Lorath sleeping on top of Heliana when she'd been much heavier a few years ago like a mattress. I thumped her across the skull playfully, "Always thinking with your stomach. You know, if anyone should be thinking of food at this early hour, it ought to be me and Lorath. We actually missed a meal!"

Heliana got up, grumbling and rubbing the top of her head though I knew I hadn't hurt her. For good measure, I prodded Heliana on the side of her tummy with my wingtip, saying, "You be careful, girl, or you are going to undo all the hard work you did over the holiday."

Heliana glared at me and then burst out laughing. Grinning, she sidled up to me and said, "Alright, I'll be mindful of my diet. Ugh… But you know that you ought to be careful yourself, Darzhja. Who knows what feasts Lorath is going to be showering you with all month long while I'm with my own little middle class family? You may be bigger than me by the time we're set to head home to the Temple!"

I smirked and pushed her away with a wing. "If that is the case, Shadia will work our tails back into shape within a fortnight. You can be sure of that!"

Heliana toothy grin faded into a half-smile. Rarely did she find anything at all about the frightening Shadia to be funny.

We both walked out of the bare room and washed our mouths and faces with water. It was delicious and cold, pumped out by a stablehand as we quaffed water by the gallon. As I thanked the lad cursorily and set about scouring my teeth with the white sand from a handy tub, I heard a loud voice nearby.

"What's this?! This is nearly double the price per head that I paid last year!" I immediately recognized the voice of the effeminate innkeeper who Lorath coerced into giving us our tiny room for the night. I wandered over and quickly saw that the blue drake was ahead of me.

On the tavern side of the large building, behind the kitchen stood the innkeeper who was conversing with an orc with a greying mane sitting on a tall wagon. The innkeeper's slight frame was such that the two of them were nearly eye to eye. I slid up next to Lorath and watched the orc respond. "My price of corn and hay has gone up and so I have to increase my prices, Sildor. You know it's nothing personal."

But from the way the dull green drake was shaking, it was clear he was still outraged. He all but shouted at the orc in a voice that would have set his harnessed bull to flee if not for some soothing strokes from the young orc seated next to the seller. "I didn't see Reiloth handing over this much for his cattle!"

The orc raised a meaty arm and rubbed the back of his balding head in a way that I knew meant that he was harboring some guilt in the matter. "Reiloth has a special discount. Xion is compensating me for selling to his partners."

"What?!" shrieked the smaller dragon and now the bull did start to move of its own accord. The orc pack leader tugged hard on the reins to keep his animal under control. "You can't be serious. This is going to put me out of business. How can this be legal?"

And before I knew what was happening, Lorath was striding forward. "The simple answer is it's not." said Lorath and both Sildor and the orc turned to face the newcomer.

The orc cocked an eyebrow, cautious as he should be between two dragons. "And what say do you have in this matter, Stranger?" he asked not impolitely.

"I am Lorath of the Dak'Saird clan who owns the lease on Sildor's inn. His business is my business also." said Lorath, all but strutting. Sildor shrank aside before the blue drake, and suddenly, Lorath appeared very large in my eyes. "What is happening with your cattle, Herdmaster?"

"Nothin' that hasn't happened before or won't happen again. Prices on my feed have been raised. I simply can't sell my cattle for the same price. No matter how much you dragons drool over them."

Lorath cocked his head, "And don't you wonder at all who owns most of the corn and hay you're buying?"

Sildor spoke up, "Axel Xion! That's it! He wanted to buy my lease just last year, even offered me a better interest rate, but I wouldn't have him. I wouldn't have anything to do with his underhanded business tactics!" cried the innkeeper, obviously now hamming it up in front of Lorath.

The blue drake just spoke thoughtfully, "And now an obviously engineered price hike on beef… Herdmaster, this discount you mentioned… It wouldn't be that its about the same amount as the amount you've had to raise your prices would it?"

The orc seemed genuinely to be thinking about this for the same time. "Actually, now that you mention it, its about as you say, give or take a few drachmas."

Sildor turned to Lorath and spoke in beseeching tones. "Master Lorath, its obvious that Axel Xion is forcing me to either let him buy me out or go out of business. Isn't there anything your noble trade clan can do for a humble innkeeper?"

Sildor's flattery disgusted me, but Lorath hung his head, and said grimly. "If this is true, then Axel Xion is engaged in unscrupulous business practices. It may even be illegal."

Sildor's face lit up and he shook out his wings, "Then I can buy my cattle at the normal rate?"

Lorath turned and I could see from the sidelines that his face was dark with thought. Perhaps he was trying to gauge just how much of his clan's power he could exercise here, given his own somewhat distant affiliation and unofficial standing. Finally he decided...
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Morning Concerns

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
(Written by Shalion)

After several moments of thought, Lorath spoke in an authoritative tone that I was actually surprised to hear out of the thin blue drake. "I believe it is clear that Axel Xion is trying to put Sildor and the other tavern keepers here who won't cooperate with him out of business." Now he looked directly at the greying orc on the wagon, "Dak'Saird will pay for the difference between this year's and last years cattle. Same as Xion."

The orc was indifferent. He threw his hands up at said. "Make no difference to me. So long as my expenses are covered."

Lorath turned to Sildor as the herdsman began to nosily creak away on his bull driven cart. He lowered his tone, though being a dragon, he was still quite audible, "Sildor…"

The slight green drake lowered his head subserviently, "Yes, Lord Lorath?"

"You should know that while I promise that we'll be looking into this, and it's important to us to keep our foothold in the waypoint, you should keep in mind that this isn't free money and I can't tell you how long we'll be able to subsidize you. Someone higher up may decide to overrule my judgement in this affair, so be prepared for that."

The hopeful gleam which had infected the green drake's eyes became more subdued, but Sildor seemed mature enough to handle the decision. "I understand, my Lord. But I hope that you understand as well that Axel Xion is a menace to us simple common folk and we don't have a lot of options."

Lorath nodded his head grimly. "I do understand and that's why when I get to Damescara, I'm going to let my clan know the specifics of what is happening out here personally."

That seemed to assuage any doubts that the innkeeper had. It moved me that this drake had such confidence in Lorath, although it wasn't too surprising. Lorath seemed to exude a natural aura of competency… though it also helped that his features were cut so fine as well.

I sidled up alongside the blue drake as he left the innkeeper to shout orders to his humanoid staff as they wrangled the fresh cattle into the pen behind the tavern kitchen. "You handled that very well." I observed.
