"Perhaps... But only if my order isn't immediately dismissed when Sildor goes to collect his reimbursement."

"That won't happen." I assured, though I had absolutely no grounds to base this off of. "You're important in the clan. They'll go along with your decision."

Lorath grunted assent, but from the way he hung his head, I thought he had some lingering doubts. We rejoined Heliana by the water trough - now gone grey with our washing in it - and I filled the silver dragon in on what she missed. Heliana showed a considerable amount of outrage when she'd heard what happened. "Axel Xion..." she said, her whole body quivering with anger, "That's just like a big corporate mogul to go stepping on the commoners to rake in a little bit of extra profit". Her eyes popped though when she remembered whose company she was currently sharing. "No offense to you though, Lorath." she added sincerely.

The blue drake just grinned, "None taken. I'm not a corporate mogul as you put it. I'm just a Knight like the rest of us."

I couldn't help but think that was a little untrue. Lorath's family was among the richest and most powerful in the empire. Not even joining the Knights could erase that background and indeed it proved to have its uses as clearly seen just now. And then Lorath had seems pretty quick to step up and exert authority on behalf of his clan. Would I be able to leave behind such wealth and power? I was afraid to answer myself, which of course was in itself an answer.

"I'm tired of talking about Axel Xion." I declared as Heliana and Lorath started to build into a tirade against the trade prince whilst we reclined around the water trough.

Lorath looked at me with a knowing glance, but if he thought he knew where my thoughts were roaming, he was wrong, "Darzhja's right. We really ought to be going. We don't want to arrive late to our next stop. Ancestors help us if Heliana misses dinner!"

"Hey!" complained the silver as we laughed, but I threw a wing over her withers to stop her pouting. Once we finished our quick bath, the three of us bid the innkeeper farewell and took off back into the sky. The flight to the east was very similar to the first days flight. Row upon row of farmland extended infinitely below us. As we passed overhead, the people would wave at us and point with a sense of wonder and awe. Unlike in New Alveri, it wasn't often that such rural folk would ever see dragons in the sky, and it was heartening to know that we were appreciated. The further we went, I could feel more and more in my bones the sheer size and majesty of the Empire that we knights had been sworn to protect.

Gradually, the air began to grow warmer and more moist, to the point where it almost felt like I was inside the wash room back at the Temple the entire time.

Heliana panted visibly.

"Now I remember why I decided to become a Knight. To escape this blasted humidity," she panted, as water dripped from her as if she just jumped out of the shower.

"Come on, its not that bad..." gestured Lorath. "You've got to admit that at least it never snows as it does in New Alveri..." he added. Then again, neither myself nor Heliana were part water dragon like he was.

By the late afternoon though, the weather had mellowed somewhat, though by that time I had grown hideously thirsty. However, I grew hopeful when more and more dragons were beginning to appear in the sky, and as it turned out, up ahead was...
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Subsidizing

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Flying over long distances was new to me, but fortunately my Temple training had me in good enough shape to keep up with Lorath and Heliana. It continually amazed me, as we flew in a straight direction, to see more and more land stretch out under me, seemingly without end. The fact that it was nearly the same patchwork quilt overlay of fields and pastures the entire time helped emphasize the illusion of endlessness. But I knew that the land did eventually end. As the air grew thick and close, and the people far down below stooped over fields of hot peppers, eggplant and okra, sheltered under hilariously wide brimmed straw hats that nearly hid their whole bodies from my vantage point, I caught my first whiffs of salt tang in the air.

It'd been four days since we left Sildor and his inn. Four days, and four way stations and over a thousand miles with the autumn winds at our backs. I'm afraid to say that my reaction, upon first tasting the scent of the sea was less than modest.

"What is that smell!" I roared over the tearing wind in my face. I fell more than a tail length, breaking my position in front of the other two smaller dragons. "Is that the sea?!"

Lorath called to me as I flapped erratically below him, and there was a chuckle in his throat as he spoke, "Yes, Darzhja! But we are still a few miles off from it still."

The salty tang to the air filled me though it was but a trace in the atmosphere as yet. I sniffed great draughts, trying to gather it all into my nose. The freshness, the clarity. Stories of sea surf, shells and underwater dragons, which before seemed merely words on the page of a book to me now took on fresh life. And that was before I even saw the ocean.

Heliana sank a little and let her tail drag across my back as she passed. The contact sent a shiver up my spine. "Look over there, Darzhja, to the south of true east. You can see it."

And there, between two lines of green covered hills I did see it. As first, I thought it was a flat plain poking over the horizon, yet not even the plains of New Alveri surrounding the lonely mountain on which it was constructed were so flat. The level of the horizon was sharp enough to balance a dwarves level. And furthermore, it was blue. Granted, my first impression was silver, but that was only the sun reflecting off the surface of the water. underneath the shimming was a dark, rich blue. I was simply awestruck, and my condition only worsened as the blue sliver expanded larger and larger until the entire eastern half of the horizon was dominated by the silver shimmering waves.

With Lorath now taking the lead, I fell behind Heliana, the air current broken so I could focus on taking in the landscape which was so utterly new to me it was almost alien.

I managed to recover enough of my facilities again to be able to be sufficiently amazed as we came across the sight of Damescara itself.

The city lingered long on the horizon as little more than a grey smudge. It took several hours of flight at high altitude to be able to resolve the many tall buildings in the center. However, most of the buildings in the city were no more than a few stories tall, although its sprawl was at least three times that of the staggeringly high New Alveri. Thus, it was not until we were practically on top of the city that I could take in its full granduer. Lorath took us on the circuit of the city twice. Something he later called the "grand tour"

Probably the first thing I noticed about Damescara was the lack of planning. Unlike the strictly ordered tiers of New Alveri, the streets of Damescara were an organic sprawl that reminded me of the way a tree branch spreads out from the core of the trunk. Damescara was obviously a living and it was still growing. There were city walls, like back home, but these seemed mostly for appearance only at this point as there was a mighty stretch of buildings that extended far beyond them in all directions the water allowed. I say this because plowing to the south side of the city was a mighty river which dumped its contents over the side of cliff of black stone.

The cliff was an oddity to be sure. Most of the landscape leading towards Damescara had been soggy marsh. But here, the land rose in a great hill which was broad if not overly tall, at least compared to New Alveri standards. Lorath would later tell me there was a legend that it had been raised by magic, but the presence of other such hills along the coast led me to believe it was simply a natural phenomenon. The hill cut away sharply at the sea, as if a giant claw had divided the hill in twain and dragged the latter half into the ocean to keep for its own. I could see why this place was chosen for a city. It was naturally defendable, especially from the marshlands surrounding it. In addition, the river generated a wide delta which jutted away from the cliffs a long ways. It was heavily farmed and also provided handy shelter for the legion of ships moored in the shadow of the wall of black stone.

Lorath, with his claw, pointed out the ancient keep which still stood despite having been burned out and partially demolished several times over the millennia. The many fountains that abounded in the city were also to be cherished and the vast warehousing district at the base of the cliffs and even extending a ways out into the water were in many ways the heart of New Alverian commerce and our only (peaceful) contact point for the rest of the world. But the most comely feature I found in the city were the cliffs themselves which naturally housed the vast majority of the city's draconic population.

Damescara housed barely a tenth of the dragons who lived in New Alveri. However, the dragons who lived here had taken pains not to be overshone by their cousins in the capital. Holes in the side of the cliff abounded with landing platforms built to jut out from the cliff ace. The matieral of choice was marble, which despite the expense was striking against the black backdrop of stone. Dragons eyed us from the openings into their chambers, and a few gave a friendly wave of their wing. Conciuous of being observed, I forced myself to be more composed as we flitted past the many openings.

Dargons, and I noted a disporportionatly large number of blues and silvers, darted between the cliffs and the sea and the dock district as well. There were dragons fishing as well as operating as mobile cranes for unloading ships. Dragons also carried the city's own goods up through the air to the city proper above and beyond the black wall. I took it all and far more in with silence, afraid that when time finally came for me to open my mouth, I would be unable to stop myself from gushing. I needn't have worried, because after our two circles about the city, Lorath led us away.

I took me several minutes to realize that Lorath was not leading us to stay in the sea side cliffs, even when we had left the lowest of them behind us. In fact we flew to the north and were sailing now over some more wet farmland and drained pasture. I was close enough to smell the patties now, as we'd dropped in height to less than twice the height of a tree now. And still Lorath led us on.

I was begining to think how inconvenient it must be to live so far from the city proper when our party was suddenly intercepted from above. A large blue drakka, much larger than Lorath, though not as large as me, dived down among us and scattered us. Clearly it was a challenge. "Fly no future!" she roared throatily, "Identify yourselves and state your purpose!"

This drakka was obviously ready to fight and though three against one seemed poor odds, I did not doubt for a moment that she had unseen assistance, likely circling far above us. Flaberghasted at first by the sudden appearance, it took a few moments for my training to kick in. Fortunately, Lorath caught himself immediately in the air and dipped a wing to circle the new female. Though the fire was hot in my throat and my claws ached for something to tear into, Lorath seemed blithe as he glided slowly around her. Just as well I wasn't leading the group then.

"Azura'lii, Surely, you recognize Lorath of the clan?" The drake called, displaying his flank and belly to her as he flew past.

Immediately, this Azura'lii retracted her previously aggressive flying posture and lowered herself to our height. She glided smoothly alongside us as we angled back into a group. I thought she might apologize for scattering us like we were no more than a flock of geese, but apparently she thought her response was appropriate. "You are late, Lorath." Was the first thing out of her mouth.

Lorath sighed loudly and beat the air with his wings. "Not even a hello, cousin?"

The blue drakka harumphed audibly over the rush of wind. "Do not forget that you are a Knight, cousin. Do not suppose that family ties can be turned on and off at it pleases you. You decided what was more important."

And with that cold introduction, she plummeted from us and darted expertly under the tree cover. Lorath came over to me so that our flapping wings were almost touching. "I sense some unresolved family issues." I said.

Lorath hissed through his teeth. "Don't worry about it, it's nothing important."

Despite his reassurances, however, I was quite keen on learning as much as I could about the family from which Lorath hailed. Even if, by joining the Knights, he had technicaly severed all his previous bonds. I wondered briefly if it hurt to leave a family behind. I thought it must.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: The City of Damescara

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
(Written by Bmao)
We followed Azura’lii through the small canopy of trees, and when we emerged from the trees, I first caught sight of the Dak’saird estate. All by itself, it could have been a sizable town. The cliffside in which it had been constructed was not dissimilar from the city we’d just left, though on a much smaller scale. It had also been completely smoothed out for it lacked the slightest dent or imperfection. Similar to the Cliffside of Damescara, the estate possessed numerous smooth outcroppings facing the ocean. On the higher ones, I imagine one could see the top of the port city rising over the trees to the south as well.

“You…you actually live here?” I choked out with disbelief turning to Lorath.

“Actually this used to be the winter residence for our clan, as our primary headquarters were in New Alveri, but those were destroyed during the attack, so since then we’ve made this place the clan headquarters,” explained Lorath. If this had been merely a ‘winter home’ beforehand, then I could scarcely imagine what the primary headquarters would have looked like. 

I landed upon a sanded ledge, and was directed under a large golden archway into the estate itself. A pair of smallish drakes guarded the main entrance to the estate, but both had a steely convicted look in their eyes that one could easily find in the guards to the gate of the dragon temple. 

Fortunately, they didn’t give us trouble as they’d been expecting us.

The first thing I remembered the moment I stepped inside those golden archways was my jaw literally dropping to the ground with an audible clang. Arrayed before me in all its profligatry, were walls made of pure crystal in which one could nearly see their reflection upon. Smooth and ululating, like the esophagus of some unimaginably enormous beast, the crystal lining of the hall seemed to shimmer in the sunlight spilling into it. I could see rainbows inside each curve. At the time, I thought it must be magic, later I would learn that the crystal had been painstakingly melted into the walls with dragon breath; no humanoid had a hand in making it, Lorath would tell me with some small pride.

“Well…as you can tell,” said Lorath, tilting his head away in no small amount of discomfort, “My clan has always been quite fond in displaying their riches.” I had grown up in a life of poverty, where one had to share a room with all the other orphans and had to stretch out a slab of meat over a week, and here it seemed that Lorath’s clan had far more wealth than they knew what to do with. 

“Just be sure that your…guests just look but don’t touch understand?” growled Azura’lii, and in a manner that seemed to emphasize the difference in her social status from mine. 

She then curved her gaze down one of the halls. “Danielson!!” she growled. A small human clad in a plain brown robe scampered across the hallway. “You called mistress?” Squeezed between all the gathered dragons, he seemed pitifully tiny indeed. However, I recognized the name, and realized it must have been either the son or some other younger relative of the human I’d met back at the Temple.

“Escort my cousin and his girlfriends to the greeting room!! I need to go get my scales polished before the banquet!!”

“Yes mistress…”

With that, Azura’lii strutted out of the chamber. In my opinion, she would have fit right in with Tsarra’s clique of stuck up whores.

I growled under my breath as she left. “Darzhja!!” hissed Heliana.

Lorath grunted, “Actually, Heliana’s assessment of my dear cousin is fairly accurate. I apologize that she was unwelcoming, but she wasn’t always like that. Now, I’m not going to bore the two of you of the details that made her that way, but I assure you that not all my family is like that, my older brother Loken and my father are much more welcoming.”

The meeting hall was a gigantic underground chamber with multiple tiers. Real sunlight poured in through a massive crystal skylight above. Raised upon the central tier was a middle aged blue drake, whom I could only guess was Lorath’s father.

“I greet you, honored father…” bowed Lorath after he had stepped before the central dais.

The dragon stepped forward to embrace his son. “By the Ancestors its great to see you again my son…” he answered and to my surprise, his voice was rather youthful and alive, if a bit weary.

“I was getting worried that you weren’t going to make it tonight for the banquet!!” continued the new trade prince.

“Well, I apologize for the delay…” said Lorath.

“I also see you brought you honored guests along! Care to introduce me?”

“Darzhja, Heliana, this is my father Lord Lo’rek; father, these are my friends from the Knights, Darzhja and Heliana…” said Lorath nodding his snout to each of us in turn.

“Its good to meet you My Lord…” I bowed. Hopefully, I didn’t look silly doing so.

“Pleased to meet you as well Lady Darzhja…” answered Lo’rek. I wondered briefly about the similarity of names of Lorath and his immediate family. Perhaps it was some sort of tradition.

“You mentioned something about a banquet right?” cried Heliana.

“Why yes, a ‘celebration of the return of the prodigal son’,” answered Lorath’s father with a deep chuckle in his throat.

“By the Ancestors, yes!!” she shrieked, flapping her wings enthusiastically. 

“Just be sure to leave some for us Heliana…” I quipped, not so subtly nudging her on the belly.

Then, another drake came forward to nudge Lorath on the side. “Well I’ll be, if it isn’t the almighty Holy Knight!!” growled the drake, but more in a teasing manner. 

“Hello esteemed older brother…” answered Lorath in overly proper Drakine, not so subtly feigning courtesy. 

Lorath’s brother, Loken, shifted his gaze playfully toward the two of us, “Looks like you finally picked up some drakka little brother, a rather odd taste if I may say so myself.” His gaze began to drift… “Personally, I prefer the more petite types…”

I snorted smoke out of my nostrils, “Want me to beat you till you’re a new shade of blue?” I said with silky ease.

Of course, that would be utterly inappropriate, but honestly I couldn’t help but feel that this philanderer needed a good kick in the balls. However, as I’d learned to my detriment with Fangorn, he might take a perverse pleasure in this sort of thing.

“I’m sure you could Darzhja, but I’d rather not have to go through the trouble of scraping his bloody remains off the pantry. Seriously brother, you’re still going on about your conquests when we’re about to have your wedding ceremony?” cried Lorath. 

Loken gave a casual shrug with his wings, “Hey, don’t get me wrong. Sly’theria can be a cute drakka when she doesn’t have that dark cloud over her head. I mean, I’ll try to make the whole thing work and make her happy, but…you know…”

He shook his head, “Bah!! I’ll deal with it when the time comes… anyhow, your guests look quite hungry, perhaps we can talk more at the banquet?”

I followed Lorath toward a large ledge overlooking the Cliffside. Upon a huge raised table was an entire zoo worth of ornately prepared beasts, from water buffalo steaks, two-second flamed deer, roasted pig on a stick, steamed porpoise, every non-humanoid animal imaginable. A myriad of human servants were busily preparing the final touches to the meal. 

“Ancestors take me…” moaned Heliana, her eyes glazed and her jaw salivating.

A blue dragoness was at the head of the table. She was rather plump, like Heliana was nowadays, but radiated an aura of kindness similar to my friend. “Go right ahead, there’s plenty for everyone!!”

Heliana looked like she was ready to explode in happiness, as she immediately dug her head into the food.

“Looks like you were right to overcook dearest,” said Lord Lothar.

She hummed contently as she nuzzled with him. “Lorath!! Its so wonderful to see you again…” she cried.

“Hi mom…”

“Your girlfriend really likes to eat doesn’t she?” she snickered. Lorath curved his gaze awkwardly, “Actually, Darzhja my date. Heliana’s her friend from the Knights…”

The blue drakka then turned to me, “Oh!! I apologize!! How silly of me!!”

I decided not to hold it against her, “Nice to meet you as well Lady…”

“Azur’iel!!” she answered. I tilted my head sideways. “Yes, I know you might find it a bit odd that the females of our clan start with Azure, long tradition. More importantly, I hope that my son has been treating you well, he can be rather timid at times but I’m glad he’s finally found someone he likes…” she said.

I couldn’t help but feel my stomach flutter somewhat, “Well, I’m really glad to hear that. Honestly, I’ve felt rather nervous of coming here but the people here seem nice…”

I gazed around at the assorted guests, and I couldn’t help but get the sense that I didn’t quite belong. 

“Well, I’m sure you’ll get to know everyone in due time!!” she cried cheerfully. “Its been nice meeting you Darzhja!!”
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: The Estate of Dak'Saird

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Lorath was glad to see that Darzhja and Heliana were getting along nicely with the clan (except for Azur'lii of course, but then again his iracible cousin didn't got along with few people in any case). He'd been rather worried at how well Darzhja in particular would fit in, and her manners at the porchside had a lot to be desired, but there was a sort of rustic charm about her. It was refreshing that she didn't pay heed to the nuances and
often stifling etiquette of the merchant clans.

Currently, she was chatting it up with his mother, who was rather fascinated to hear of her lifestory of coming from the orphanage and rising to become a Knight. While she was chatting it up, this gave Lorath an opportunity to bring up a few issues concerning Axel Xion with his father.

"Father, could I speak to you for a moment?" asked Lorath.

His father lifted himself from his dish of steamed porpoise to address him, "What is on your mind my son?"

"Axel Xion is slowly taking over our holdings in the countryside. He's driving our clients out of business by skewing the prices on their supplies. I've already promised Sildor that I would subsidize him until we can get the situation sorted out, but if this keeps up then eventually we'll be placed into big debt and he'll either get bought out by Xion or be forced to close down..." explained Lorath.

"Yes...yes, a truly vexing matter," cried Lo'rek, "I think you have the right idea of subsidizing our clients for the time being. Xion might be trying to undercut us, but his pockets are not very deep. Xion is far from the first uppity humanoid merchant we've ever faced. Its true that humanoids like him can get money quickly, but because of their impatience and lack of discretion they can lose it just as quickly. Furthermore, compared to the wealth of the Dak'saird Clan, which has been established for millenia, this upstart will find himself short of cash eventually."

"The theory is sound, but we have not been able to buy him off or negotiate with him. You are right father in mentioning that humanoid merchants come and go, but Axel Xion is far more ruthless than any humanoid merchant we've faced in quite some time. Considering the way he has ruthlessly exploited the aftermath of the New Alveri attack, I'm beginning to get suspicions that he might have played a hand in it. Rather than letting him do more damage to our enterprise I say we should act proactively and take him down as soon as we can," said Lorath.

"I understand the sentiment, but that would only gain Axel Xion notoriety. He may be on the offensive now, but soon the humanoids will realize the type of fraud he is. At worst, all we need to do is wait a few decades before Xion dies of old age, and without this charismatic individual at the helm, his empire will start to fall apart, and we'll be there to claim his holdings. I do admit that this will affect our finances adversely for the short term, but your brother's wedding to the Shadowfangs will further improve our financial situation and minimize whatever scheme will wither before long..." father assured.

"That may be, but I still have a bad feeling about him. I believe that it would be a good idea to revoke his invitation for my brother's wedding, nor allow any individuals from his affiliated companies access to the wedding either." explained Lorath.

To his dismay, his father wouldn't have any of it, "What message would that send to the humans? That the Dak'saird clan is admitting that it is vulnerable and that it fears the ambitions of a short-lived humanoid? Aye, if he really does have these violent tendencies, it might be in fact better to invite him so we can get a better idea of his intensions. As the old saying goes, keep your friends close but your enemies closer," he cried. His father had a decent point. If Xion was away from the wedding, then he would be out of sight and free to do what he wished, and furthermore it would clearly signal that the Dak'saird clan was now openly hostile to him. If one could pretend that they were still on good terms with Xion, then he might grow complacent and would make it more likely that he would slip up.

"Forgive me if I have been too forward," said Lorath, bowing down in apology, "As you are the clan leader, the decision ultimately lies with you."

Lorath supposed that he should be happy that father was even willing to hear out his concerns in the first place. As he had joined the Knights, it meant that legally he was no longer a member of the Dak'saird Clan and that he would have no say in how the clan conducted its business.

"That is so, but I find great value in your input my son. You have a no nonsense view of the world and don't take anything for granted. Its a pity that you decided to join the Knights..." sighed father.

Lorath groaned, he wasn't about to have this talk again. While his parents hadn't been outright hostile about him joining the Knights, they certainly had been reluctant about it.

"No, I've gotten over that," said father, as if reading his mind, "Its your dream to pursue, and I'm glad that you have found fulfillment in it. Yet...if for some reason that anything were to happen to me, then your older brother would be in control of the clan. While he is entitled to the position in terms of rights, personally, I'd feel more secure if you were there to advise him."

Lorath immediately cut his father off, "Look father, I don't want that type of power, and that's why I became a Knight. I've set down roots there and made many close companionships, and I would prefer not to have to leave that behind. Besides, you'll life a long and healthy life, and by that time Lo'ken would be able to step into the position and by then he'd have a capable heir as well."

Of course, the real question was what would happen if if something were to happen to father right now. As it stood, there was no way that Lo'ken would be able to lead the Dak'saird clan, due to his brother's profligatry and his preference to want to stage parties rather than actually govern. Back when grandfather was alive and seemingly would continue to go on forever, that really hadn't mattered, but now it was down to father, Lo'ken and himself. Personally, he hoped that it wouldn't have to come down to it, but if it did...

However, his ponderings were interrupted with a loud burp. It had seemed that Lo'ken and Heliana had emptied the vat of firewater, and were both rather tipsy now. Furthermore, all the food was pretty much devoured; apparently mother had underestimated the extent of Heliana's appetite.

To Lorath's dismay, Lok'en, being the smaller of the two, was the one who was far more drunk. Father let out a sigh, but not really having expected anything different, "Lorath, could you take your brother to his room so he can recover?"

"Yes father..." sighed Lorath. Like he had done many times before, Lorath grasped his brother so he wouldn't stumble around.

Before he left, he turned to face Darzhja, who appeared rather disgusted at his brother's behavior, while also a bit disapproving of Heliana as well. "I apologize for the inconvenience Darzhja, but could you escort Heliana to one of the guest lairs?"

"Guest lairs?" cried Darzhja, rather confused.

"Yeah, she needs a place where she can get sober. I'll definitely make it up to you all right?"

"I'm holding you to that!!" she cried, in a way that almost sounded threatening.

Lorath called one of the humans over, "Could you show them where one of the guest rooms are?"

"Very well my Lord..." the human bowed, "If you would please follow me..."

He then curved to his brother, who was now drooling from his jaw. "Come on brother, you need to rest. Can't be looking like this for your wedding you know..."
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Prospects of succession

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
I was overwhelmed by the many scents of cooked food almost the moment I stepped outside onto the wide, open patio. The long table, carved to comfortable height for a reclining dragon of average build all but groaned under the weight of food on it. And these were not simply giant cauldrons of beef stew either. There were delicacies here that I'd never seen before; in fact almost all of the dishes were unrecognizable. It was a carnivore's banquet though, as most of the dishes consisted mostly of meat, but the sauces they were cooked, steamed and poached in were pungent and varied. Heliana beside me couldn't close her mouth at the sight of it.

And although the sight of the food was welcoming, the assembled blue dragons were less so. I was actually scared out of my wits meeting Lorath's family. What if I said something wrong? What if I came across as foolish or simple, just because I didn't have the sort of entitlement that Lorath had grown up with? What if I made such a bad impression, Lorath didn't want to be seen with me again?

It turned out that I needn't have worried so. The first person I was introduced to was Lorath's mother. She was a kindly dame, much older than Lorath's father and I would later find out that he was her second mate. Azura'lai was down to earth, homely and welcoming and seemed genuinely interested as I began to tell of the long tale that led to my becoming a Holy Knight. And she wasn't alone either.

I soon found I had a small audience around hanging on my every word. So much so, I hardly touched my food as I recounted my trials and adventures. I looked at the guests in turn, trying my very best to remember them, for they would surely remember me. A silver drake with a characteristic blue streak down his spine stuck out first in my mind. He had inherited the comely looks that seemed to flow in the males of Lorath's family. His name was Alastair and it turned out that he hailed from a lesser branch family from Lorath's. "We and the other two lesser families fill out most of the niche rolls for Dak'Saird. Courrier work mostly, but also private guarding and advising. You might have seen my older brother Alastein outside the portal where you landed." he told me.

I nodded and agreed when he gave me a description and I couldn't help but think what a tight nit group Dak'saird must be. Even though he personally had no change at the prestige of the controlling family, he didn't seem to mind at all giving his whole self over to the betterment of the clan.

In addition to Lorath's mother, there were two other drakka listening to my tale. One was Azura'lii's professed sister. "Though not of the same sire, mind." she told me. "Azura'lii's clutch unfortunately suffered a blight almost as soon as they were out of the egg. She was the only survivor, bless her heart." She told me not to mind her half-sister's rudeness, as she had certain "trust issues" as she put it. While Azura'lii's sister was positively bubbly, the other drakka watched me with a steady glare, saying little the entire time.

That drakka's name was Azurel'lia and she had distinctive silver markings on her face, like human freckles. She seemed self conscious about them and turned her head away when I pointed them out. I'd embarrassed myself, I knew, but I'd thought they looked stunning. I would learn much later that she was the product of an affair between Azura'lai and an adventurous young drake from the city while she'd been with her first spouse. It was perhaps little wonder why she was a little more subdued than the rest. During that dinner, however, she had a tendency to eye Heliana, who was making out like a fiend at the platters upon platters on the table and had a tendency to ask me more slightly embarrassing questions about my eager companion than myself. I suppose I should be grateful her attention was elsewhere. She had a cold logic that rubbed me the wrong way. At least Azura'lii was straightforward about who she didn't like.

I didn't pay much attention to anyone outside my little group, but I was forced to when it was very apparent that both Heliana and Loken had gotten more inebriated than was seemly. I saw Loken sidle up beside Heliana as the great silver plucked thick slice after thick slice onto her heavy wooden platter for the umpteenth time. I'd seen him down the last of the fire brandy when Heliana hadn't been looking and when he exhale, the vapors were plainly visible on the air, making for a very different sort of flame. His eyes were half lidded and he swayed slightly where he stood.

He brushed a wing up Heliana's generous flank. "Did I mention that I like a drakka with shome meat on her bones?" he slurred.

Heliana for her part started at the physical contact, but she sidlided up closer once she realized who it was and what he'd just said. "Well, I… You are too… kind… really…" she flustered, hiding an obvious grin behind her wing. But then she seemed to have a sober thought that straightened her back and made her step away. "Hmph. I remember you mentioned to your brother that you liked the petite type better."

This all but cause the drunken Loken to stumble. He caught himself, though and withdrew his questing wing. "Oh, Heliana, that was just a joke. Besides… I can say with absolute honesty that you look…" His eyes crossed just the slightest bit. "R-ravishing!" he exclaimed with not a little animalistic growl.

Heliana for her part was too inebriated to resist. I could see the reservations melting out of her and she stepped closer. Almost immediately, Loken's tail moved over to carress the swell of Heliana's tummy. I saw red.

"Excuse me." I said to Azura'lei and the others as I got to my feet and began to pad around to the other side of the table, more than ready to shed blood if I had to. Lorath saw me, though and with a panicked look in his eyes raced over to prevent my bloodlust… or perhaps prevent an incident. I wasn't sure which was more important.

Lorath did an admirable job separating the two and got his brother half holstered on his withers while I gathered up a slightly more resisting Heliana.

"Hey… Hey, where's Lo-lo-Loken going?" Heliana asked with some amount of fervor. She might have still thought she was going to get lucky with a handsome drake, but I wasn't about to let her honor be spoiled, especially not to the philandering male who was supposed to be wed in less than a week.

"He's going to go get a cold shower and a long night's rest, honey." I said calmly as I escorted Heliana to our guest quarters deep inside the cliff ace. Fortunately for me, Lorath had had the foresight to assign me a human servant who led me and Heliana to our chambers. I was too occupied with keeping Heliana from wandering off after "Mr. Hansome Blue" to even ask the poor lad's name, however.

"Ohhh, poo…" muttered Heliana with a long face. I almost felt sorry for her, but then she'd rather made a pig of herself at the banquet, so I wasn't bashful in pushing her through the dimly lit cave's opening and instructing her to lie down.

She seemed to forget about Loken and his unfulfilled promise when she hit the stone floor. She rubbed her belly absently with both forepaws. "Oh Darzhja, that was such a great dinner!" she exclaimed and rolled onto her back.

"I know, Heliana, I know…" I said, but the only answer I got was soft snoring. I couldn't help myself. I started to giggle.

I went over to her and rest my back comfortable against her. I thought I couldn't resent Lorath for not missing a good thing when it was right there. Heliana made quite the nice pillow. I fell asleep and dreamed of blue and silver bodies drifting in a vast sea. One was exceedingly familiar, and he welcomed me down into the dark depths. I sighed with pleasure and was gone for a time.

In the morning, I was already surprised to see we had an attendant. He'd been waiting for us while sitting on a stool out in the corridor. His face was familiar, why it was the servant from last night, but there was something more as well. I'd been introduced to this human, and his face bore a striking semblance to someone else I knew. I lifted my scaled lids slowly, waiting for it to hit me; why my human name be so hard!

As for the servant, he slowly turned the pages of a leather bound book he was studying. On its cover there was the crest of the Dragon Cult. "Danielson?" I muttered, mouth feeling dry and sticky. I'd consumed my own fairshare of the firebrand last night as well and hadn't escaped some of the after effects. Of course, I didn't envy Heliana at all when she'd finally wake.

The human closed his book with a snap and stuffed it into the pocket of his long sleeve. "Mistress Darzhja! Glad to see you awake. I trust you have had a pleasant rest?"

I licked my chops and gave a great toothy yawn. Danielson averted his face and I felt bad for showering the lad in what must have been rank breath, even for a dragon. I muttered an apology and yawned again before rubbing some crust from my outer lids with the back of a paw. "I didn't get the chance to say so earlier, but I met your father in the Temple before I left."
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Stories and Drinking

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
That put a smile so wide on the man's face that I thought it might crack. "Papa! Ah, how is the old man doing? He's very stingy with his letters."

I smiled and lowered my head down closer to his level, my body still resting against the bulk of a snoring Heliana behind me. "From what I saw of him, he was doing well. He helped arrange my and Lorath's vacation here and Lorath seems to have a great deal of trust in his competence."

Praising the value of a Dragon cultist's work was the best way I knew of to praise them. This man surprised me a little by not retreating into the ever repeated, "You are too kind's and Thank you's" Then he surprised me even more when he said. "I'm glad to hear that. For my part, I thought you did a marvelous job out there. Everyone was hanging onto your every word. I knew it wasn't a bad idea for you to come here."

"Oh?" I asked, curiosity piqued. I nosed my face a little closer to the standing human. If I rested my jaw on the floor, we could just see eye to eye, though my snout was just as long as the man's whole body. "And do I owe you any thanks for my being here now?"

I intended to put him a little off nerve; just a little. But he responded strongly. "None that you need to voice, My Lady." he said with a low bow. "To look upon your elegant form is thanks enough. Besides Bronze is such a nice change of pace from all the blue and silver, I think."

I couldn't help but purr. "Oh my, you do know how to flatter a drakka." I said with amusement.

The man laughed and it was a rich sound from the man's belly. I couldn't help but think that this man's family might be worth getting to know. Especially if there were a couple more like this.

“Actually, I do have a favor that I wish to ask of you,” he asked, sounding more serious though.

“Hmmm?” I inquired. One of the reasons why humans all too often went out of the way to praise dragons was in hopes that the dragons would reciprocate. This could mean anything as trivial as proffering a loose scale to lending part of their hoard.

“In case you are unaware, today marks the two thousanth anniversary when Father Nodalisk and his nine disciples exorcised the blood mages. I was hoping that you would do us the honor of participating the commemoration ceremony at St Jarico’s basilica.”

At first, I was a bit confused about Danielson’s request, but when I took note of the human’s robe I realized what he was.

"St Jarico's Basilica? That would be where the former Blood Mage cult was located correct? That would also make you a priest from the Dragon Cult!” I replied, intrigued. “A cleric of the Followers of Nod would be the more proper term,” Danielson corrected. “There’s a difference between a cleric and a priest, but basically the easiest way you can tell a cleric apart from the common priests in that we don’t have to keep our heads shaved any longer…”

I couldn’t help but snort with amusement. Frankly, I had always found the almost desperate piety of the shaved headed priests rather amusing. “Lorath did mention something about a commemoration ceremony when we were headed off toward Damescara, and he did say something about attending in the morning.”

“That’s true, but you wouldn’t be able to get into the inner sanctum without the presence of a clegymember, so not everybody could get access,” answered Danielson.

Yet I didn’t doubt that Lorath wouldn’t have been able to get in anyhow, given the influence of his clan. That being the case, I found it a little odd that Danielson would specifically bring the matter up. I couldn’t help but get the sense that Danielson was testing me somehow, withholding information until I solved this mental riddle. Behind me, Heliana murmured something in her sleep; she wouldn’t be waking any time soon, nor would Lo’ken or likely the rest of the Dak’saird clan for that matter. After the excessive banquet, none of them would probably be able to attend the ceremony on the morning of first day, so it would probably be only Lorath and myself. Looking back upon it, Lorath had been having some very feverish discussions with Danielson’s father, and my gut feeling had told me that it hadn’t all pertained to vacation plans.

I lowered my neck to stare directly into the human’s eye. “Perhaps it is a hunch, but I gather that you’re not only here to ask me about attending the ceremony now is there?”

Most humans would have flinched at my display, but to his credit Danielson did not.

“You guess correctly Lady Darzhja. I cannot give you the exact details here, but the name of the dragon who brought up this matter is a dragon by the name of Lord Ral’pherinox, a famed engineer who is affiliated with the Dak’saird Clan, and its regarding the matter of Axel Xion,” said Danielson.

Hearing the name of the infamous tycoon instantly made me aware that this was actually quite a serious and potentially quite dangerous matter. From what I had seen of Axel Xion, he had left a rather negative impression and wouldn’t have been all too displeased if this uppity rascal were to meet an untimely demise.

“So, this was the matter that Lorath was conversing with your father about back at the temple no doubt?”

As if on cue, Lorath came into the room. He was already wide awake and seeming ready to head off for the morning ceremony. “That’s right Darzhja. I’m sorry I didn’t tell you any of this beforehand but Danielson’s matter is of a very urgent importance. Again, I can’t give any details until we’ve met with our client, but basically we’re hoping to take Axel Xion down… I know that this seems rather sudden, and you’re not obligated by any means to accept until you’ve at least heard our client’s testimony, but nonetheless I was hoping you could help us Darzhja.”

I thought long and hard about it. I couldn’t help but feel somewhat betrayed that Lorath wouldn’t tell me anything about this sort of thing, and that basically by accepting that it meant that the vacation was basically over. Yet at the same time I could understand why they would keep it under wraps, and there was also an opportunity to get some real action.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Danielson's proposal

choices: Darzhja has to challenge one of the fighters to earn a spot
Danielson has everything set up already
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
We arrived at a small shrine sequestered at the outskirts of Damescara, resembling more the cave of a typical draconic family’s home than a church. Thus, there was a rather quaint feel when I entered, in which the only evidence that it was a church were the murals and the presence of the humanoid priests. I followed Lorath closely and a bit to the left down a long, wide pathway which bisected the chamber. Danielson walked between the two of us, careful not to accidentally get kicked or smacked by Lorath’s slightly swaying tail. On either side, there were various human worshippers, none of them seeming particularly well off, dressed in simple peasant clothing nor were they particularly clean, but I felt heartened of how they lightly bowed their heads in reverence when we passed.

However, not all the attendees were at ease with what the Ancestors had blessed with them at the moment. Up at the front of the chapel was a thin, middle-aged fire drake whose head was lowered in respect to a large statue of Gyramond. After finishing his prayer, the drake lifted his head and let out a resigned sigh, as if he expected nothing else but more disappointment and despair. I felt for him, wondering if there was anything I could do to help him.

He turned around to lift his head and perked up a little. “Oh…Hello Lord Lorath, Sir Danielson,” he gestured, “What would bring you here today? Surely, you could be attend the grand ceremony at the St Jarico’s Basilica’s shrine now could you?”

“I could, but I prefer to be able to conduct my prayers to the Ancestors with a measure of solitude instead of the huge public frenzy,” answered Lorath. “More importantly though, Danielson and I have been looking into the disappearance of your son and the possibility that it may be linked with wrong doing on Axel Xion’s part, and thus I brought somebody here that could help us achieve this task.”

The thin fire drake craned his head upwards to gaze at me skeptically, “This dragoness?”
“Yes,” clarified Lorath, “She is someone you can trust. I’ll tell you a more after the conclusion of the ceremony…”

“Very well Lord Lorath…” bowed the fire drake.

As for the ceremony itself, it actually wasn’t much different in terms of style than the prayers Lady Ramoth had led in the orphanage once every weekend morning. I lowered myself to the ground as low as I could, as did Lorath and the skinny fire drake, so as to allow Danielson to be able to stand up on the podium and be visible to all the human worshippers as he led the prayers. The list of prayers I gave to the Ancestors was usual; to be able to find Blaze, that the orphans would remain protected, that I would be able to protect the denizens of the Empire from her enemies, etc.

Once the ceremony was done, and that we were able to get to a place free from any prying eyes and ears, we began to discuss in length the plot to take down Axel Xion.

“Anyhow, now that the ceremony is over, perhaps you two could introduce yourselves to each other…” said Lorath.

“I’m Darzhja, a Knight in training from New Alveri… I’ve come to understand that Axel Xion has troubled you in some way, and as Lorath pointed out earlier, I’m here to help out,” I introduced. In all honestly, I wasn’t sure how much I really could help, as I wasn’t necessarily the sneaky sort of dragoness.

“A pleasure to meet you Lady Darzhja. I’m Ral’pherinox of the Redforge Clan. Our family has served the Dak’saird’s overseeing their engineering and construction projects for many generations…”

“So, you’re a builder then?” I cried, tilting my head sideways.

“Well, I design all the blueprints and arrange the logistics,” he clarified.

“Oh!! Alright…” I replied, still not really comprehending what he meant.

“Anyhow Ral’pherinox, perhaps you would like to share your story of how your son went missing with Darzhja…” said Lorath in a comforting manner.

He heaved a long painful breath. “Very well then. Its…its regarding my son, who has been missing for the past three years now. Ral’pherinox, who shares my name… I was raising him to one day take my place as the chief engineer. He’s a very smart young drake, naturally inquisitive and took to the craft with energy and enthusiasm, yet we had a terrible argument one day. He told me that he was interested in taking a very lucrative position for Axel Xion’s Guild when the business mogul went and purchased the colloseum from the Firestone Clan, and that they needed his talents for the renovations. I told him that it would be betraying our sponsors, and that if he worked for Axel Xion I would cut all ties with him.

Of course, I regretted the incident, and headed toward the Guild offices in hopes I could apologize. A representative told me that he didn’t wish to speak to me, so at first I assumed he was still angry. This was only about a couple weeks before the attack, but when the attack came, once again I attempted to contact them, but they gave me the same answer, and that in addition that he had signed a clause saying that he wasn’t allowed to contact me.”

“What? Even I know that you have to be at least 65 years old before you can sign a contract like that without the consent of a guardian!!” I burst out. That put him around the same age as Blaze.

“So he was kidnapped then…” I spoke with absolute certainty. “Like Blaze was…”

“That’s what I began to suspect as well, so I came to the Dak’saird’s to see if they could find anything, and thus we’ve been working to solve this case ever since… Yet anyhow, tell me about this Blaze.”

I explained to the middle aged drake about how Blaze had gone missing during the New Alveri attack, and my involvement with dealing with egg smugglers and how it could be connected to the disappearance of his son.

I focused my gaze back toward Lorath and Danielson. “Look, I know I’m not the smartest dragon around, but I know when something isn’t right. I’ll do whatever it takes to get Blaze back, and if Axel Xion was involved with this I’ll make sure he pays.”

Danielson came forward, “Anyhow, let me explain where you come in. I’m sure that you already know that Axel Xion is sponsoring a fighting tournament at the Coliseum,” he started.

“Yes!! The tournament commemorating the battles against the blood mages right?” I answered.

“That’s correct Darzhja, I was hoping that you’d be willing to register as a combatant, or do I even need to ask?” he finished rather teasingly.

Lorath was right in that he really didn’t need to ask. I loved wrestling, of matching strength upon strength, the thrill of competition and striving for the top. “I’m always up for a good fight, count me in!!"

"Yet how will participating in the tournament actually take down Axel Xion?" I wondered.

"Let me explain Darzhja," began Danielson, "If Sir Ralphernox’s son went missing around the area of the coliseum, we also suspect that there would be evidence of his criminal activities as well. I’m going to be leading a team to discover evidence of Axel Xion's wrongdoing's within his archies, yet we need a way of getting in without seeming suspicious, so with you being a fighter, why, you'll also need a competent handling crew correct?"

"Oh!! I think I understand. The more opponents I beat in in the ring, the longer your team can investigate."

"Precisely, Darzhja. In addition, with your increasing success as a fighter, Axel Xion might start to take an interest in your fighting skills and perhaps discuss the possibility of you joining in with whatever he is plotting and that he might also reveal his future plans.”

“So, I’ll pretend to go along with him and then you’ll be able to find incriminating evidence against him? Then, this evidence can be presented before the Knights, and then Axel Xion will be arrested, and also we’ll learn about where Axel Xion’s people have taken Blaze and Lord Ral’pherinox’s son?”

“That’s the plan," said Lorath, "As for my role, you remember how Axel Xion had been invited to my brother’s wedding right?”

“So you’re planning to get him there?” I inquired.

“Hopefully, but leading up to the wedding we’ve been trying to give Axel Xion the impression that we want to cooperate with him,” added Lorath. "A lot of business is done during these types of social gatherings, and once we present all this incriminating evidence against him, he’ll then have no choice but to cooperate with the condition of turning over all his business to us and revealing his entire plot in exchange for house arrest, or public execution. Either way, once these crimes are revealed all of his investors will leave him and all the dragons who were employed by him will quickly disassociate themselves from him…”

“Ancestors hope we would be that fortunate,” said Ral’pherinox, “Do keep in mind that he didn’t become as powerful as he has by being stupid. He might smell a plot and attempt to counter against us…”

A slight bit of doubt crept into my mind at the aged dragon’s warning. I knew full well that ever since the New Alveri attack Xion had already evaded all the best efforts of the Knights and the Merchant Princes to stop him. Yet one thing I had learned when I was young, and reinforced during my time as a Knight was that one could not afford to hesitate.

“I say bring it on!! The quicker we get started the quicker we can take him down!! Where do I go to become a fighter!?” I demanded.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: To taketh down a business tycoon

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Lorath responded to my enthusiastic reply with a slightly hesitant voice and an eye that wouldn't quite meet my own. "There's just one major problem with getting you into the arena, however. All of the tournament positions have been filled years in advance."

"Years?!" I cried.

Lorath shrugged, "It's only to be expected, really. Everyone's been looking forward to this celebration, for some it's been over a century."

I let my wings sag across my back and I cocked my head, looking at Lorath beside me. "Then why even bring this up, if it's hopeless?"

The answer came from my other side where Danielson stood upon his speaking box. "Ah, but it's not as hopeless as it seems, my Mistress. There may be no more positions open for the tournament, but it is possible to join nevertheless."

I canted my head down at the small man. Lorath beamed in a way that suggested he already knew this part, but across from me the esteemed Ral'Pherinox seemed as ignorant as I at the moment. "And would you care to explain how this might be, Danielson?"

The human priest and servant of the Cult smiled broadly up at me, showing off his many flat white teeth. "It is possible for you to take one of the current fighter's positions, My Lady." My eyes opened wider, I think I liked where this was going. The human continued, "You see, the fighters are all honor bound not to fight one another before the tournament; in fact, they are discouraged from even meeting each other. But they may still get into fights with nonparticipants before the games begin… and this is where things get interesting.

"Obviously I don't need to explain a dragon's sense of honor regarding things like ritual combat, but a certain amount of drakine 'common sense' is written right into the rules of the tournament. Each of the participants went through a lengthy weeding process long before this tournament even had a designated arena. This was to ensure that no weaklings were present to embarrass themselves when the real fighting began." I nodded silently. To my dragon-sense this was less an inconsideration to the average participant than a way to avoid embarrassment and shame later on… and also to do better service to the bloodlust that most dragons feel regarding this most ancient and revered sport. "Now, this isn't an explicit rule, but the guidelines mention that a participant who is "shamed" before the tournament may be disqualified and it would then be necessary to find a replacement."

With my keen sense of ritual combat, I thought that I already saw where this was going. However, there was another problem, "Wouldn't they pull a new replacement from the list of dragons who just barely didn't make the last cut, though?"

Danielson made a Cult gesture with his finger, 'right on the nose.' "Usually, that would be exactly the case, however, if a participant were to come to shame through losing to a recognized and public fight, well… this is were things get murky. Because of the fact that there is another prescedent in the guidelines that allows for 'heroic citizens' to enter the tournament, should they be short on fighters for any reason. And which do you think is more preferable to the judges, one of the dragons already disqualified, or one whose already proven strong enough to take down a contender?"

Ral'Pherinox snorted derisive purple smoke. "To think that one can simply walk up to one of these barbarians, knock them down and take their place." It was clear that the older drake expected more from a religious holiday.

Danielson raised a hand in plea, however, "No, Master Engineer, it is not like that at all. In the act of provoking a fight with the sole objective of entering the tournament in that specific manner, the challenger automatically disqualifies him or herself."

"But what if the participant is the one that provokes the fight? I’ve seen a lot of fighters who like to bully and pester the population for no good reason other than wanting to throw their weight around. If I stand up to such a fighter and prevail wouldn’t I get into the tournament?" I asked, eyes slanted while my tail curled behind me in excitement.

Danielson turned his odd flat face towards me again. "Certainly, but considering the prestige of the event the participants aren’t likely to throw away their spot by some petty misdemeanor, especially this close to the tournament itself."

“Then how are we going to start a challenge with them?” I cried out.

Well, I was thinking of staging an incident instead. With the help of my fellow priests, we can rile the participant where he starts harassing us, and Darzhja would come to defend us from their harassment…” said Danielson.

“That sounds fairly feasible, but would that not place you and your priests in significant physical danger?” said Ral’phernox. That was a point; humanoids were extremely fragile in comparison to dragon kind, and if things went wrong it could easily prove fatal for one of them.

“If it means taking down Axel Xion, then we’re willing to take that risk…” said Danielson.

"Maybe so, but how can you be sure that they will take the bait?" he added.

"This close to the tournament, we don't have very may realistic options, and its the best plan I have got," answered Danielson.

“Isn’t there another way that doesn’t have to risk the lives of innocent humanoids?” I wondered.

“The other way would be to put the participant in such a position where their honor would be questioned and they would have no choice but to accept our challenge,” said Lorath.

“So we would need some sort of grievance that would put the participants honor into question I take it?” cried Ral’Pherinox.

“Indeed,” finished Lorath. “I'd come up with an alternate plan, one that would not put Danielson’s priests in physical harm, would guarantee a challenge and psychologically rattle the dragon in question to the point where it would guarantee a victory, but the way of going about it would have completely new complications that I'd much rather avoid.”

I shifted my gaze dubiously at Lorath, who tapped his claw anxiously on the stone floor. “If it would guarantee a challenge we do have to consider the option now do we?” cried Ral'pherinox.

“It would indeed, yet I would prefer not to have to use it… In fact I would rather not say at all…”

My jaw tightened as I glared at Lorath, “Please tell me Lorath, I'd rather hear it than have things constantly hidden from me… Like the Master Engineer said, if its a chance to stop Axel Xion and also find his son and Blaze, then I'd like to hear of it.”

“Are you sure Darzhja?” replied Lorath with a great deal of trepedation.

"Tell me..." I growled impatiently.

Lorath shifted his gaze at Danielson and Ral’pherniox, “Would you please leave us for a few moments if you would?” he said.

The two nodded solemnly, before turning away out of sight, so it was only myself and Lorath now.

“Darzhja, you’ve heard of Sir Cronos have you not?” began Lorath.

“Of course I have!! He’s only one of the most famous fighters in all of Nod!!” I cried. Anybody with any sense of being a fighter in the ring would have known of the 'Drake of Steel', of his prowess, his wealth and his larger than life, cocky persona. He'd travel to the furthest corners of the globe searching for the strongest fighters, and would detail his exploits through song and lore.

"Why do you bring him up though?" I wondered.

“Despite his fame, his advancing age makes him but a shadow of what he once was, and that this is to be his last fight in any case. So, I believe you would be able to prevail in a challenge I believe.”

“I'm flattered you think that I'm that skilled, but he has to accept the challenge in the first place right, and that you have a scheme that would give him no choice but to accept?” I said.

“That’s right…” answered Lorath. “So let me flesh out the scenario. During his younger days when he was in his prime, winning tournament after tournament, Cronos was also infamous for his sexual exploits in every city he went, and furthermore that he sired countless hatchlings with various mistresses throughout his career as a fighter. He never provided for any of them either, instead using his money to ensure these mistresses remained hushed up and never going public. As for where you come in Darzhja...”

"Actually on second thought its probably shouldn't say anymore..."

“You've already said all I need to hear!!” I wailed angrily.

“You... you want me to go up to Cronos and claim that I'm one of bastards he sired during his fighting career, and call him out on how he never took responsibility and that I had to be raised in an orphanage. People...people would find that a nice juicy drama to bite into wouldn't they? Who wouldn't pay loads of gems to see that fight? Of the vengeful daughter coming after him to make him pay for his sins! They'd believe it also, because he's a Bronze Dragon like myself and that I'm certainly young enough also wouldn't it?!"

“Look Darzhja, I should never have brought it up…” said Lorath. His apology felt hollow though. I felt dirty, like I was being used. Yet I had demanded that Lorath tell me of this alternative, and he had told me even though he had warned me about it. What was worst was the notion that it could actually be true.

I shifted my head away, "No Lorath its not that...I...I... I just need time to be alone for a while..."
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Dragon's honor

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
I left Lorath and the rest of them after that, needing to think. I felt hurt by Lorath's suggestion of such low tactics, even though he hadn't exactly sprung it on me so much as I myself had insisted he tell me the alternative to our fragile human allies placing themselves in mortal danger. Outside the smallish humble church set into the windswept hillside, I walked through the other worshippers, not seeing them. I spread my wings, and above the treetops, I saw that it was still morning, bright and sunny and cruelly inconsistent with the way I was feeling just now.

I circled aimlessly for a while, climbing until the air was thin and cold, but not really going anywhere. I wanted some distance between Lorath and myself, but was still aware that I was in an unfamiliar countryside and would be easily lost without him. I breathed deeply, relishing the chill on my wings and scales. I passed up into a cloud and the world vanished.

Water beaded on my skin and ran in rivulets from my jaw to my shoulders and down my long sleek body. breathing was as much drinking, but it was the best tasting water. I set my wings and drifted through the pale blankness, thinking.

That Axel Xion needed to be taken down was no question; not when he had Blaze’s blood on his dirty hands not to mention that of countless other dragons. Logically, I knew that Lorath’s plan was the best chance to get into the tournament and take down Axel Xion. While Danielson and his crew’s determination and courage were admirable, I didn’t want them to throw their lives away so easily. From a dragon’s perspective, humanoids were all too often perceived more as an amorphous mass in which their individual lives seemed insignificant and exceptionally fragile. A human should not have to die just to maintain a dragon’s image and ego, especially not when there was an alternative. Yet what Lorath was asking me to do though…

Sir Cronos had been one of my idols while growing up. He had been the epitome of strength and honor, chivalrous in victory and also congratulatory to his opponent during the rare times he lost. Yet now, apparently, this hatchling hood hero was a lecher and a cheat behind the scenes. In a way, I should not have considered this particularly surprising; after all, having been raised an orphan I was by no means naiive, but it was nonetheless a blow.

Nonetheless, I resented the fact that Lorath had to be the one to sully one of my idols, and that I felt dirty of having to blackmail Cronos in such a manner. Yet the fact was that maybe it was my fault that I had decided to make Cronos one of my idols. After all, it had been an open secret that Cronos had attracted a crowd of drakka wherever he went; in fact when I had been very small I’d had these silly fantasies of how I would marry the fighter and be his bride.

Yet being a fighter myself, I felt I had a good grasp on their psychology. They liked to show off their power quite a bit, and Cronos demonstrating his prowess not only in the ring but with the drakka seemed all too likely. It was sadly easy to envision him siring a bunch of hatchlings and leaving the poor mothers with nothing and completely disassociating with them. That’s how so many dragons had ended up in orphanages; like myself for instance.

More disturbing and infuriating was the small but frightening possibility that Cronos truly was the drake that had sired me. If so, what made me angry wasn’t necessarily the fact he had abandoned me and my mother, but the fact that he had done so when he clearly had the means to support us and hadn’t while all the while had used that same money to hush it all up.

Of course, there was also the possibility that these allegations weren’t true, at least concerning myself, and that I’d just be outright blackmailing him to get into he tournament. Yet again, if I didn’t do that, I’d have to sacrifice human lives into the tournament, or worse if I did nothing Axel Xion would continue to scheme against the Empire I was sworn to protect and many more could die because of inaction.

I let out a sigh, gently tilting my body around so I was floating upside down. The cloud I was in enmeshed me almost like a security blanket.

I was a fighter, a warrior, a knight. I was trained to fight an enemy whose sinister designs were clear and not bothering to hide their ill intensions. Seek the enemy, fight them and then either gain victory and glory or death and defeat. All this shadowy intrigue and backroom dealing wasn’t who I was. That was what dragons like Lorath dabbled into.

Having seen that side of Lorath now, I realized that I had become smitten with Lorath without really analyzing his inner character. All that meant was that Lorath, like every other dragon in the world, had his share of personal flaws and that I needed to understand him more as a person now as the relationship got more serious. Because I had no doubt in my hearts that Lorath genuinely cared about me, and that he ultimately wanted to do the right thing. Or rather, I desperately wanted to believe that was the case, that he truly saw me as something more as the same way I saw him and that I wasn't just being used by him.

Right then, I felt a shift in the wind come from below. I twisted my body in that direction, and my eyes widened when I quickly spotted Lorath’s distinctive blue hide half hidden by the mist.

“There you are Darzhja…” said Lorath. We began to circle higher up in the air so we wouldn't lose each other.

“I wanted to apologize for having to put you in this sort of position,” he said. “For planning this sort of scheme behind your back and then expecting you to go through it..”

“Its not necessarily your fault Lorath. I suppose I just wasn’t prepared psychologically as I believed, that the manner would be simple and without complication. In fact, I appreciate that you considered my feelings before telling me the plan you had in mind. To tell you the truth, I'm aware of the fact I'm not as...what's the word, keen on my surroundings as I could be. I see the enemy, I fight them straight on and don't really think too hard on why they are the enemy. I couldn't have thought of any of this nor would these things have occurred to me before,” I admitted.

Lorath let out a grunt, “In a way, its probably better you are the way you are, and I mean that in a good way. You have a very clear sense of right and wrong, and a strict sense of honor. I really felt bad that I had to put you in the sort of position where you'd have to potentially compromise these values. I really don’t want to feel and I don’t want you to feel as if I’m just using you as just a pawn in a bigger scheme."

I let out a breath. The thought had crossed my mind a few times now. Perhaps it was an inherent mercantile trait within Lorath, having been part of that lineage that stretched back countless generations. Yet Nod needed all sorts of dragons for the Empire to survive, whether they be fighters like myself, magicians like Lina or Thereesa and planners like Lorath.

“Axel Xion needs to be stopped, and compared with allowing him to remain free risking my reputation is but a small thing.”

“So you'll agree to the plan?” cried Lorath, looking wary again.

“Yes, I shall..." I vowed, "Yet promise me one thing Lorath…”

"Name it..." answered Lorath.

“Promise me that you’ll always be truthful with me. You’ll always be truthful even during those times you believe I may want to hear it, because it will hurt me more if you lie to me. So long as you tell me the truth, I can live with whatever outcome comes out of it, but if you lie to me I’ll never forgive you…” I cried.

Lorath closed his eyes, and then stared back at me. “With my Ancestors as my witness, and with you, I’ll always be truthful with you Darzhja, and may the powers below take me if I’m not…”

I instantly felt a huge weight lift off my wings after he said that. Now, I didn’t have to doubt him anymore, as I flew forward and placed my head against his in midair.

“Thank you Lorath…”

It was a warm embrace, one of trust and understanding more than one of romance, but I appreciated that more. After a while, we separated, and the two of us stared at one another again.

"You know Darzhja, after putting you all through this, its only fair that I should have to make it up to you during the festival…”

“Oh? So you’re going to be asking me out then?” I replied, sounding intrigued.

“Well yes, that is why I invited you to the festival is it not?” he answered, smiling encouragingly. I couldn’t help but respond with an elated grin.

“Of course I’ll go with you Lorath…” I answered with a smile.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Clearing the air

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
"Well, here is Cronos' estate Darzhja," said Danielson, indicating it with his finger. "Even though I'm your 'fight coordinator', I won't be able to be seen officially as such until you actually manage to get the spot in the tournament. Once you are finished, contact me and I'll inform Lorath of what took place..."

Danielson walked away and blended back into the ubiqutous crowd of humans, as I headed toward Cronos' estate. Being a dragon of considerable fame and fortune, there was a couple of guards awaiting the entrance of the lair, which was nestled along the cliffside. I took in a deep breath and then decided to approach, it wasn't necessarily the fight with Cronos that I was worried about, but whether I had the guts to carry through with the plan I wondered if I would have the guts to be able to carry out the plan that Lorath had designed for me.

More than three quarters of a century ago, apparently, Lorath had explained that Cronos had had a rather serious affair with a drakka named Prideth, but that Cronos' philandering ways had destroyed this relationship between the two. Nobody had known exactly what had become of Cronos' favorite lover after the fallout, as Cronos' press corps had deliberately obscured the affair in order to preserve the fighter's reputation, but there had been rumors that she'd been heavy with a clutch at the time, nor was anybody sure if she was even alive anymore. Admist the uncertainly, gave Lorath the opportunity to construe the scheme which I could pass myself off as Cronos' daughter, and leave him no choice but to accept my challenge.

I was also a bit ill at ease by the fact that Lorath or even Danielson couldn't be here with me. The town was quite unfamiliar to me, even though I had Danielson as a guide to get me to Cronos' lair. However, if Lorath was seen as a conspirator then it would unravel the entire plan to get into the tournament and take down Axel Xion before it even had the chance to start.

"Look drakka, autograph time is over. If you want to see Cronos you'd have to see him in the tournament; not that the likes of you would have a ticket that is," the guard on the left snorted dismissively. "However, I suppose that you are pretty enough that you might be able to gain entrance in that manner..."

I dug my claws into the dirt, ready to launch myself at them right then and there, but I forced myself to be calm.

"I would never lower myself to such a degree, and besides, Lord Cronos will not be in the tournament, on account of the fact that his daughter will be taking his place," I answered, attempting to sound as cool as possible.

"Oh? I've never heard of Cronos having a daughter..." the second guard answered, still dismissively but also sounding a bit curious now.

"That's because he hushed up my mother, Prideth, after she threatened to expose his affairs with other drakka after he told her that he would not be taking responsibility. So I, Darzhja, am here to call him into account... and shall challenge him in the ring so that I may take his place in the tournament. I will meet with my father, even if I must have to go through you two."

Being as strong as I was in a fight, I was by no means intimidated by these two admittedly imposing dragons. However, having been fighting since I was out of an egg, I easily tell between the look of a professional and those who simply tried to intimidate.

The guards glared at me, "You've got more guts then sense drakka, making a claim like that. I ought to have you arrested..."

I glared back, "I'd like to see you try..."

The guard made a move toward me, yet without batting an eye I twisted around, knocked him off balance and sent him sprawling on his side. The other guard, rather than challenge me, could only gape with astonishment. Obviously, neither of the two males had imagined a female being so capable in a fight.

"I still think you're trying to clamor for attention, but by the Ancestors I can see you can certainly fight."

The guard called forward a human serant, whom I followed into the lair. Compared with Lorath's estate, the lair in which Cronos dwelled was spartan in comparison. However, lining the wall were murals depicting the great bronze dragon's victories in battle, crowing triumphantly to the crowd as he was pinning his dazed, opponent, while below each mural encased in a crystal case were the accompanying trophies. Hanging above them were huge posters made painstakingly of leather and vinyl, posters that would have been placed at the entrance of the stadium promoting the big fight that was yet to come. This was the Cronos I had grown up idolizing, back when I merely wanted to be the greatest fighter there ever was, and before I'd gained my true purpose as a knight.

My hearts were pounding against my chest when I heard the weary sounds of grunting and exertation. I followed the human servant around a corner, out onto a large ledge overlooking the oceanside. It was, in fact, an outdoor gym of sorts, complete with a sand pit, dragon shaped dummies that could have easily been decades older than I was with scratches, claw marks and chips. Yet in the center of that sand pit was Cronos, the Drake of Steel, himself. Only, it wasn't the Cronos that I had seen in the murals, not the Cronos immortalized in bronze statues. I could see the technical skill which he performed his signiature moves, despite his age, yet it wasn't so much the lack of physical prowess but the way his moves almost seemed half hearted, revealing an old wyrm that had seemingly lost his purpose with the weight of the world on his shoulders.

It was only then that the old dragon seemed to notice me. Almost deliberately, he shifted his gaze toward me. I couldn't help but be frozen by his gaze, almost as if subconsciously I was telling myself that this dragon actually was my father.

"Aren't I little bit too old to be the target of a drakka like you?" he cried with a light smile, in a way that might have meant to be teasing but reflecting more a weary nostalgia than anything else. Even now, he was a very imposing fellow, with none of the fat or flabbiness typically associated with dragons his age, with a hint of the dashing handsomeness that would have attracted countless drakka to his lair about a century or so ago, though his scales certaintly lacked the luster that say...Fangorn's would.

I puffed a bit of smoke out of my nostrils to refocus my thoughts, "Indeed, you are...Cronos, or should I say, father."
