There was a thick, preganant pause before I continued, "My name is Darzhja of New Alveri, Prideth was my mother you know... I was only told that was the case, since I grew up in an orphanage."

I couldn't help but feel a little dirty of having to say that to his face. I expected him to immediately start to become hostile or insult me for being a liar or a blackmailing slut, but to my surprise, his expression suddenly grew haunted, as if he were staring straight at the judgment of the Ancestors themselves. "Prideth..." he said with a low voice.

"You must have been told that I was an abusive drake who cheated on drakka and dumped her out. I do not deny it, I cast your mother out because I was selfish and believed myself to be the living embodiment of Gyramond himself. Trust me, not a day goes by that I could go back to that day and wish I could have done something different. Thus, as I grew older I realized that the Ancestors would one day judge me for the sins I committed then, and thus here you are Darzhja, to wreak vengeance upon your miserable wretch of a father..."

His self deprecation caught me off guard. This was not the cocky, invincible dragon I had idolized, or even the vain, disdainful old wyrm I'd prepared myself for, but a dragon who'd realized the scope of his sins and could never escape them. Moreover, it sounded like a dragon who had somehow become convinced in his mind that I was indeed his daughter, even though logic would argue that the chances of that being the case were quite small, and that his gaze was not necessarily seeing me but a reflection of that particular dragoness.

"I do not desire that kind of revenge? What I want is to take your place in the tournament..." I answered.

The old bronze dragons eyes began to glow with life, "Is that so Darzhja? With words like that I suspect you'd be here for a fight!!"

He puffed his chest out, seeeming more energized and full of purpose in this fight with no witnesses than in the actual tournament itself, "It would be a honor to do battle with you Darzhja, daughter of Prideth!! Do you have the strength and courage to take your father's place in the grand tournament!?"

I dug my claws into the dirt despite the whole awkwardness of him actually calling me daughter. By now I had scrapped the whole plan of actively shaming him and making him relive the whole moment of cheating on the dragoness I'd claimed to be my mother oer and over, but instead found myself playing into this whole narrative. Better to have him as a possible ally than a dragon who would hold a grudge, even if it did mean I really did have to pretend that I was actually his daughter as he envisioned it in his mind.

"By the will of the Ancestors, we'll just have to find out then won't we?" I answered.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Sins of the father

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Chronos stared me down, eyes heavy with the weight of three quarters of a millennium's worth of pride, victory, guilt, shame, but never defeat; at least until now or so I hoped. His eyes, which were a deep ochre not unlike my own, though hazy with age, seemed filled with a depth I had not anticipated in an old fighter. When I responded to his question with an exuberant cry of my own, I felt something, almost like a connection to the dragon who I was currently lying to and yet had believed me without a second thought. I couldn't stand to think of the lie, so I had to push it out of my mind entirely.

"Follow me then, offspring of mine." said Chronos as he began to walk back into his estate. As a dragon of his wealth and stature, there were already three or four humaniods at attendance at the entrance back into the interior of the cliffside. He mumbled something down to them and they went scrambling off in different directions both down the main passage and the smaller servant ways.

As we started walking through the old fighter's estate, I asked, "Where are we going?"

The old dragon chuckled, "Well a fight in my private gym doesn't mean so much. We have to make this public. There's a field up on top of the cliff we can use. My neighbors will be witnesses to your challenge as well as anyone else who's around."

I grunted affirmation as we began to ascend a long set of stairs. My blood had been primed for battle right then and there, it was a bit of a shock to be delayed even a short time. Of course, I knew that a veteran fighter like Chronos would have no such trouble summoning the rage and strength he would need without notice. I had to keep my concentration. But right now, it felt less like I was preparing for battle than walking with a mentor in the winding halls of the Temple.

Surprisingly we ran into another dragon on the way up. This one seemed to have half the bulk of Chronos, but was only a little shorter than him. "Hello, Chrysthaline, old friend."

The drakka frowned, "I thought we already had a talk about sneaking through my side passages..." she glanced over Chronos' shoulders and glared at me, "Especially with young drakka in tow."

"My dear, that was over two hundred years ago. This is an entirely different matter. It's a matter of honor."

"Don't tell me one of your bastard egglings has finally come back to haunt you." trilled the older drakka. The hallway was deathly silent. "No... really?"

"It's true. This is my daughter, Darzhja, by Prideth. She grew up in an orphanage in New Alveri and only recently learned of her heritage. She's come to challange me for her birthright by ancient custom." Said Chronos, almost pridefully, I thought.

The drakka clicked her tongue. "You old battlehorse. You don't have to solve everything by fighting. Just give the youngling her share of inheirtance and let that be that."

I shoved my way forward so that I was beside Chronos. "I'm not here for money. I'm here to challenge him for the right to fight in the tournament."

The drakka looked at me levelly, suddenly seeming shrewd and snake-like. "Unorthodox, but potentially worth more than gold... if you honestly think you can win that is. Such a young thing, but you've got meat on you. There's a resemblance to your father in that regard..."

I didn't know if that was a compliment or an insult. "We're going upstairs to settle the matter right now."

Chrysthaline looked at me with half lidded eyes, "Oh, then I mustn't miss this historic battle!"

Though her voice was dripping with sarcasm, Chronos seemed pleased to have run into Chrysthaline. As we moved up the last section of stairs, he followed her and watched her tail as she walked. I couldn't help but feel almost certain that these two dragons have known each other intimately in the past.

The passage open up onto a high ledge that was hardly a tail's length down from the grassy top of the cliffside. We climbed over it. scarcely a minute had passed before two more dragons landed down on the knoll. One was another bronze, the second was a blue water dragon.

"Regilius! Myranzi! I'm glad you two could come on such short notice."

The bronze dragon, who was larger at the shoulder and the waist than Chronos, rumbled, "I'd be skinned before I miss seeing you knocked down by your own bastard child, Chronos!"

Chronos just laughed and then turned to me. "We have our audience then..." he heaved a sigh then met my eyes with sudden intensity. "Darzhja, you have the right to chalenge me by brithright. Name your prize."

"I claim your right to fight in the blood festival tournament." I cried. I saw the other dragons' eyes widen, though Chrysthaline just nodded slowly.

"Your terms are acceptable. Now let's begin."

Chronos didn't waste anymore time on ceromony. He threw himself into a charge, his claws tearing into the turf. He was very fast for such an old dragon, but I was faster. I sidestepped him without trouble. However, he kept going right past me. He dove right over the edge of the cliff and opened his wings.

"You're losing the high ground, drakka. Better get after him." said Regilius from my right. Gritting my teeth, I ran ahead, spread my wings and went after Chronos.

I'm not sure why I'd been expecting a wrestling match on the ground, though there was yet time for that. Perhaps I'd just assumed that as a young drakka, I'd have the natural advantage in the air over him and that he'd realize this as well. I grew suspicious right away of Chronos' choice to take to the air and followed him cautiously as I fought for hieght advantage.

A coastal thermal carried us high over the knoll and we circled inside of it, each of us straining for height. Chronos's massive wings ripped through the air with strength, but after a year of training with the Temple, I was just as strong. I gained the advantage without tiring myself overmuch. With Chronos below me, I began to drift over. I could strike from above and ride him down to the ground where the impact would stun him.

As I was about to close my attack, however, Chronos rolled over in midair with alarming dexterity. He breathed a gout of fire up into my face. I quickly banked to the side to avoid the worst of the flames and then was startled to see Chronos above me.

We impacted with his chest on my shoulder, Chronos' great weight bearing down on me. He went for my wings, but I grappled up at him, sacrificing lift to get a clawhold on him. We snapped at each other in a violent embrace. Then Chronos bashed my right wing good with his own. It buckled and we began to fall, spinning as we did.

Only my rigorous Knight training enabled me to keep some semblance of direction as we fell turning head over heels. Chronos pulled a deep breath for fire at point blank, but I punched him in the throat and forced him to swallow it. The old fighter, however was full of tricks. His best years may have been behind him, but his technical skill was superior to mine. I must have turned the wrong way, or perhaps he subtley coerced me into it, but I found myself with him holding my neck and right wing tightly with him behind me, unable to reach him with my foreclaws as we continued to fall.

"You know what comes next, right, lass?" he said into my ear.

I growled in response. He was going to ride me down to earth like a battering ram, just as I'd been planning to do to him. I struggled for a moment or two, but I could tell right away that he had me good. "I..." I gasped into the on rushing wind, "...I think I do."

With a stroke of inspiration, I reached around with my tail and bashed it against Chronos' left wing. He recoiled and I extended my own wing, fighting the older drake for control of the fall. The result was that we began a corkscrew spin, tails first. Looking below, the ground was dangerously close for such a manuver, even if we weren't attatched to each other.

Chronos realized this and with a vicious snarl, he released me and sought to catch the air again with his empty, flapping wings. I gasped relief at the release, but I too was desperate to catch myself before a bone breaking fall.

We both hit the ground hard. I managed to skid into the knoll, tumbling a couple times; a stray breeze managed to find its way under my wings and I used it as much as I could to angle out my fall. Chronos, however, stuck more inland and did not seem to fare as well, landing more like a meteor. It didn't seem to faze him however as he extricated himself from the shallow depression his huge body had made in the soil.

"You oaf, if you damaged my solar, it's coming out of your hoard!" cried Chrysthaline from the sidelines.

Chronos just shook her off with a laugh, though. "My hoard could suffer a little dimishing dear."

He began heading towards me while I was still recovering, My rough roll had bruised one of my wings pretty good. However, it seemed that Chronos did not intend on another air battle this round. "You remind me of your mother, Darzhja. She was unconventional in her fight style as well."
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Moving on Up

choices: Suddenly Darzhja is joined by Danielson
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
I sneered, but could not hide genuine interest. "I never knew Prideth. Did you two fight?"


Chronos paused in his advance, "Did we fight!? Ha, she was as vicious a female as they came in a fight. Scrappy and tough, but beautiful as well."


It was a struggle to hold onto the righteous anger that I was supposedly feeling, but I did manage to shout a question as we began circling each other. "Then why did you leave her?"


Chronos didn't lower his head, but his eyes did falter. "I didn't leave her. She left me. It was no secret I saw drakka on the side... lots of drakka. After half a century, I'd thought she was fine with it. I was wrong."


Chronos' admition was honest and guiltridden and it was easy to sympathize. Though it hurt me, I needed to push that aside and focus on the anger I needed to win. "You were wrong." I emphasized, "And what about all those other drakka? How many more of me are there out there?"


Before he could respond, I leaped across the distance between us, claws forward. I raked him on the a foreleg and we began to snap at each other. We did this for a few moments, and then Chronos released a gust of wind with his wings, kicking up dirt into my eyes. Fortunately there wasn't a lot of loose soil on the knoll, so I saw his teeth coming. I didn't see his tail, though.

With an agility that was astounding for a dragon his age, his tail imapacted right upon my neck and then all in one motion tried to wrap it around in a chokehold. My first impulse would have been to immediately try and push myself out of the grapple, and had I not gone through my training that was what I would have done. It was a move that Shadia had pulled on me quite often, yet one that Bronze Dragons didn’t normally have the flexibility to pull off, and thus I gambled that his grasp would be tenuous. Instead, I struck out with my own tail; I didn’t really intend that it would do any damage, but because of his odd position he would recoil and give me a split second to get loose. The maneuver worked, as I backed myself away and gazed back at him.


I could see the tension in his eyes. “To answer your question Darzhja," he said as we began circling again, "The fact is I do not know… none of the others cared what I was doing on the side but Prideth… she was the only one who called me out on it. She was the only one who cared enough to, I suppose..."


“She was the only one to call you out? Or maybe she was the only one you cared to notice!” I retorted, digging my claws into the dirt. Chronos grunted, tossing his head as if to rid himself of this uncomfortable question, before charging forward recklessly to slash at me. He didn’t attempt any kind of deception, thus I dodged to the side and turned to face him again.


So it seemed that Prideth was still a sensetive topic for the old dragon. However, why did he even bring up the subject? I wondered. Maybe Chronos wanted this pain. Maybe some part of him wanted me to punish him for his past sins. The thought made me hesitate, but upon seeing Chronos turn to face me again, I recalled just what sort of dragon he'd been in his younger years. Maybe he could do with some punishing. "Getting slow in your elder years, old wyrm?" I jeckled.


Chronos bristled, "Come a little closer and I'll show you how slow I am, lass."


I stepped forward, tail carefully raised. "Like this?"


Chronos grunted and loosened his wings, raising his tail defensively. He kept his knees bent as he prepared to counter me.


But I didn't attack. Instead, I said, "Did Prideth leave any of those old scars on you, Chronos?"


Chronos grimaced, his stance changing altogether. "More than you know." he muttered. Then, he actually raised a claw unconciously to touch a long knotted scar that ran down from the left side of the base of his neck to his breast.


I clenched my teeth and seized my chance. I leaped at Chronos, slamming my outstreatched claws into his shoulder. He went down under me, though he beat at my face and flanks with his wings. He struggled under me and while it was difficult trying to pin a slightly larger opponant - though he was only slightly larger than me - he really didn't seem to put up much of a fight. I was almost dissapointed really.


After half-heartedly trying to push me off, Chronos let out a grunt, grinning pridefully.


“I believe you have me my daughter…” he said almost casually.


“Indeed I do…” I replied, keeping my gaze focused upon his.


“Unbelievable showing!! She truly is your daughter my old friend!!” said Regulus.


“Yes…yes…indeed,” agreed his smaller, web-clawed counterpart Myrzanti, “While her fighting style could definitely use some more polish, I say she’ll have quite a showing in the tournament…”


“Quite…anyhow Darzhja will you please let me up?” said Chronos.


“Does this mean I have your spot in the tournament?” I wanted to emphasize. Though I was pretty sure that he was beaten, I wanted to words officially out of his mouth so he couldn’t claim he had technically never said it.


“Clever drakka you are Darzhja. Yes, you shall take my stead in the tournament,” he cried. Slowly and cautiously, I released my hold on the dragon who I claimed to be my father. He wearily pushed himself back to his feet. Now with the adrenaline rush fading away, his age started to really catch up to him, as he was huffing and puffing.


I moved forward to lend a claw in case he needed it, but raised a claw to hold me off.


“Now now… no need to rub it in my daughter. There’s still some vigor left in the body of this old wyrm…” he replied. Off to the side, Chyrsthaline rolled her eyes. “Don’t let that oaf fool you Darzhja. He’s broken the hearts of too many drakka with that stare of his.”


I couldn’t help but snort in response, “Oh, I’m well aware about that…”


“Humph…that’s what they all said…” she replied ominously


Grimacing slightly, I turned away from Chrysthaline. "Is there anything else that needs to be taken care of, Chronos?"


Chronos, still puffing, sat down on the scarred surface of the knoll. His tail curled around to wrap itself about his right foreleg in a characteristic manner. "Hrmh... nothing that you need to worry about, daughter. The human padfoots shall run the necessary papers to the tournament office. They shall be alerted to the change shortly I imagine." Chronos release a boistrous laugh. "Not that they'll enjoy the sudden paper work this close to the start of the tournament. Nor, I imagine, losing a famous old fighter such as myself in return for some unknown upstart."


Before I could voice my opinion, Chrysthaline laughed, "Nobody was looking forward to your fat ass ambling its way into the arena, trust me. I think they'll consider it a blessing from the Ancestors to have a reason to replace you."


Chronos rumbled and growled as he turned on the female. Regilius and Myrzanti looked at each other and chuckled knowingly. Just as Chronos looked like he was about to spit fire in her face, he lost his compusure with a smile, saying, "You think I'm fat?"


"As a corn-fed sow." said the drakka with a wink and then she brushed her cheek against Chrnos' neck in a little more than friendly way.


Just as I was begining to feel a little uncomfortable, Regilius stepped beside me and ushered me away with a wing. "Young lass, I hope you have an inkling of what you've just gotten yourself into."


I swallowed, "A chance for honor and glory." I said aloud, and added to myself, 'and a chance to get close to an industrialist tyrant and probable kidnapper of hatchlings.


"Aye, and you shall have that chance now." But the heavy set old bronze lowered his head close to mine and added quietly in my ear, "But truth be told, Chronos will be perhaps the least of the challenges you will face before the championship."


I move a step away from Regilius, who smelled like he'd just gotten through two or three casks of wine. "Well, I don't necessarily need to win the whole tournament to earn fame do I?" Although the idea certainly was appealing.


Regilius seemed taken aback, as if the idea of aspiring to anything less than final championship was unthinkable. "Well, yes, I suppose, but..."


Myrzanti stepped in, he was so quiet, I hadn't even heard him approach my other side. "But the glory and fame earned by winning the tournament is ten-fold compared to even second place. And only the champion's names are written down on the Bloodstone to be remembered for all time."


"Bastard, loner, wilding or yes, even orphan, it doesn't matter who you were before winning a tournament. If you manage to claw your way to the top, you become immortal. It is the ultimate glory for any fighting drake."


"Or drakka." I added in automatically.


Regilius coughed, "Erm, yes, of course. drakka too."
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Past Wins Out

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
Suddenly, I was joined by a third party, except this one was human. Looking down, I saw Danielson puffing, clearly having raced up the steps from the ground level. For a humanoid, his stamina was admirable. I waited a few moments as he bent over, hands on his knees and caught his breath.

"Do you know this human?" Regilius asked.

"Yes." I said hurriedly, "He's um... my thrall, yes. His name's Danielson."

"Hrm... You're doing quite well for an orphan if you can afford your own thrall, Darzhja." observed Mryzanti.

I let out a nervous laugh, "Oh, well, you know he came cheap. A little touched in the head, you see." The look from Danielson could have melted lead, but honestly I didn't know what to say. I was unpracticed in lying, and I didn't want it known that I was a Knight of New Alveri. I could tell though that none of the gathered dragons believed that story for a second.

“I trust that he’s reliable and dedicated though, for none of my human associates come running all the way up here at full sprint just to be at their lady’s side. Why, I believe he must have been enthralled by your incomparable beauty my dear daughter!!” said Chronos.

Off to the side, Chrysthaline let out a dismissive scoff, but Danielson let out a laugh. “I admit that was part of the reason my Lord Chronos. However, I sensed Darzhja was a very hard working and dedicated individual, and that she also respects me and my efforts, along with a number of my colleagues who are not present right now but also feel similarly,” he answered, as graciously as he could. I felt heartened by his compliments. Indeed, Danielson and humans in general worked very hard, bound by their limitations.

“Is that so? Then I must say that you are fortunate to have such loyal peons at your side my daughter!!” replied Chronos, “Why, I can never get mine to get anything done in due time!!” I quickly snuck a sympathetic glance at Danielson for being called a ‘peon’ and apparently Chronos’ casual disregard of humans in general as an amorphous mass whose sole existence was to do dragon kind’s bidding. Danielson just shrugged; apparently he’d expected as much.

“As a matter of fact, I believe you and your minions will fit in here with us in no time at all!!” said Chronos.

“Fit in? Wait a moment, you’re actually asking me to live with you now?” I retorted incredulously. Regilius and Myrzanti also snapped their heads toward Chronos questioningly.

“Why of course my daughter!!” he replied, placing a friendly wing around my back. “By taking my spot in the tournament, I will have to legally adopt you and having you around the premises will not only make this easier, but also help build up attention from the media of this monumental event. Secondly, though I might not be the drake that I once was, I still have a number of tips I could give you to help you train and prepare for the tournament. Why, by the time I'm done with you my dear, with your loveliness combined with the techniques of the Drake of steel, none would be able to stand before you!! As for quarters you’d have your own private lair and washroom along with reasonable accomodations for your servants!!”

“A drakka being able to bathe in your complex without being watched? There’s a big fat lie…” snorted Chrysthaline, almost certainly speaking from personal experience. I too was quite familiar with that uncomfortable feeling of being watched from hidden places, no thanks to a certain unbalanced, perverted, irascible yet heart-stoppingly comely bronze Holy Knight who would not be named.

Chronos snorted, “Normally I’d just have to admit you’re right, but this is different considering Darzhja’s my daughter.”

I pulled myself away, desperately wanting to get back on task, “In any case, I thank you for the offer but I already have a place to stay…”

Chronos shifted a glare toward Chrysthaline, as if that was the reason I was reluctant to stay, but then calmed himself to gaze back toward me. “I understand the desire to want to stake out on your own, but to be perfectly honest, this old drake would feel much more content to have you around Darzhja. More practically, I assume that as an orphan your finances are rather limited at the moment, at least until you’re awarded your prize money at the end of the tournament. So until then, instead of having to rent out a lair at one of those Dak’saird Clan lodges, and during the tournament those rates are certainly going to increase, you’d have much better living quarters free of charge.”

“Give me a moment to consider this…”

Right then, I suddenly understood what Chronos’ real intent was on trying to get me to stay at his lair. First of all, he wanted to live out the fantasy he had of actually being a father, after years of living a irresponsible carefree lifestyle, and to be honest part of me wanted to know what having an actual father felt like. More dangerously though, was that by referencing the Dak’saird Clan lodge that while he probably didn’t know that I was actually working with Lorath, it was also clear that he had come to some sort of realization that there were a few holes in my story and that he wanted to keep me around so he could know my true intensions, that it wasn’t only to find my long-lost father and gain glory. The longer I stayed with him, the more likely he’d discovered what these intensions were, and to be honest from his position I couldn't blame him for wanting to do so. Certainly, Chronos could not know I was involved with Lorath unless I wanted to take the risky step of trying to get Chronos in on it, and since I'd told him I was an orphan he rightly assumed that my finances would be limited, and accepting the offer should have been a powerful incentive. At the same time, by deciding not to accept the offer, I could end up insulting Chronos, after he had agreed to allow me to take his spot in the tournament, and alienating him and making him an enemy was also a bad idea.

Ultimately, I had to decide what would allow me to continue my mission working for Lorath to expose Axel Xion. Personally, I couldn’t decide, but what I also knew that the success of the mission was also dependant upon how freely Danielson could operate. Furthermore, I didn't feel confident enough to give this decision and back them up with reasonable assertions without potentially compromising more of the mission.

“Danielson,” I asked, bending my head down to his level.

“Yes my lady?”

“I am undecided, therefore, I would like to know what you think I should do, stay with my father or continue to live the way we’ve been living, where you’d only have to serve me,” I asked.

“You would actually ask the opinion of a human on this issue?” said Myrzanti, puzzled at the notion.

“Yes, I would. I would not have made it this far in life if Danielson wasn’t so touched up in the head as to decide to follow me. Therefore, I believe it would be generous to give him a choice to speak on my humans behalf,” I replied. After all, Danielson was Lorath's servant, not mine, and given that Danielson was operating with Lorath's authority, by extension Danielson's decision to stay with Chronos or not was actually Lorath's. On a personal level though, I already trusted Danielson to a level I never had with any other human, percisely because he was so essential to the mission.

So humble as always, Danielson lowered his head and replied, “Well my lady, you are free to disagree with my humble opinion, but I believe it would be more beneficial to….
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: To stay or not to stay

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
“Stay with your newfound sire. After all, you can learn a great deal about fighting from this dragon and thus more likely to win the tournament as a result!!" answered Danielson.

“Ah you see!! Your servant agrees that staying with me is the best choice of action!!" cried Chronos, a bit too enthusiastically. I took in a breath. In fact, I was actually beginning to wonder if Lorath had made connections with Chronos earlier, and that rather than my presence in Damescara being an excursion with Lorath, that Lorath had actually planned out this scenario for me long before. "All right father, I'll stay with you at least for the duration of the tournament, until I get my huge gem prize so I can get a real place to call home,” I answered.

“As for Danielson, I re-emphasize that he and the others joined me willingly. As an orphan, they were not bequeathed to me for generation after generation, but I had to earn their trust, so therefore I would ask if you allowed them free access to the complex, and to be able to travel throughout the city to visit friends and relatives at the time of their choosing.” I replied. Now that I wouldn’t be able to speak with Lorath directly for an indefinite period of time, I’d have to rely on Danielson and his crew to communicate with him, and this was the only way I could think.

“Why of course!!” answered Chornos, “Any friend of my daughter is a friend of mine!!”

“I thank you Lord Chronos,” Danielson responded with a bow.

“Now then, since we’re all become buddy-buddy, maybe now would be a good time to get those bruises looked at?” snorted Chrysthaline. I curved my gaze toward my wing, which I had unknowingly been holding up somewhat gingerly since I’d crashed onto the ground, along with a myriad of other bruises I’d sustained. Bronze dragons, known for their physical prowess, were known for their ability to ignore pain, and I was no different.

“Oh yes…right… Chrysthaline dear, will you please take a look at her?” said Chronos.

“Very well then, but you make sure that someone patches you up also Chronos all right?” answered Chrysthaline. “Rigilius, make sure that oaf doesn’t leave your sight during treatment…”

“Hey now, I got over my voyeuristic phase more than 150 years ago,” chortled Chornos. I couldn’t help but form an image of a young Chronos sneaking behind young females with a crooked grin, very much like a certain perverted bronze dragon I knew back at the Temple.

“What about me?” asked Danielson.

Myrzanti angled his head downwards, “I’ll take you to the records room so you can help us sort out Darzhja’s registration into the tournament.”

"Very well then, I shall entrust myself under your care..." answered Danielson, taking a seat upon Myranti.

"Right then!! Darzhja my daughter, once all this is hopefully cleared up I will see you again tomorrow for a day of hard training!!" he said.

"I'll be counting on it!!" I cried eagerly as he made his way off.

That left me with the aged female Chrysthaline. I did my best to hide the unease I felt being with her. I got the sense that Chronos had done so as a way of learning more about me and my intensions, and that Chrysthaline’s somewhat toxic nature would cause me to let something slip. Therefore, I decided to take the initiative instead, “So, how long have you known Chronos?”

“Quite a long time,” answered the drakka, “Since the beginning of his fighting career in fact. I’d studied to become a cleric, but Chronos spotted me one day after one of his fights and offered to hire me as his personal physical therapist…”

I couldn’t help but let in a grunt.

“Were you also one of his lovers?” I asked nervously. Honestly, I wasn't sure why I'd chosen to blurt out that particular question.

“Obviously…” she sniffed with an eye roll, “While I am very good at my craft, you don’t know how many times after I patched him up after a big fight he’d immediately want to shove his cock in me afterwards…”

“And you just let him do it? You never felt…degraded whenever he did it with you?” I snapped. I couldn’t help but feel increasingly irritated as Chrysthaline shared her sexual exploits with a drake that was by all accounts my father.

“You’re seriously asking me this? Wait, you’re a virgin aren’t you? A drakka who comes from an orphanage? That’s almost unheard of!!” she cried with some great deal of amazement.

I felt my face heat up, “J-just answer the question…”

“Well yes. If you’ve noticed I’ve made myself quite a decent fortune tending to Chornos’ various ‘ailments’, much more than I would have made at a standard practice,” she replied, extending her neck as she pointed out the size of her estate. “Your father might be a cheating wretch, yet by the Ancestors he was like Gyramond himself in the lair!!”

“Yet how could he attract so many drakka, knowing that he was cheating the whole time?” I said.

“Part of the reason Chronos was able to attract so many young drakka was not only because he was quite a studly specimen of a dragon, and by the Ancestors he was quite handsome back then, but also because he’d hire those drakka to perform his tasks. He’d pay one drakka to do promotion of his fights, another to set up his training course, at any one point he’d have something like 5 or so drakka. In fact, your mother started the same way as well, but she worked harder than anybody else and was the only drakka who was willing to be a sparring partner for him. She was determined and tough, but also surprisingly naiive and foolish, very much like you in fact.”

“What about all the bastards he sired?” I added.

“What about them? If you must know, there were a great number of drakka who actually wanted little ones, and what better way to ensure they’re going to hatch healthy and strong by having Lord Chronos, the Drake of Steel, sire them? So they’d work for Chronos for about five to ten years or so and earn money, then get themselves knocked up, and then head somewhere out in the mountains and build themselves a nice secluded lair to raise their little ones without the distraction of a male. For those that didn’t necessarily want them, Chronos would also pay them off. Again, your mother was the exception than the rule…”

“Do you think my mother was a fool then by thinking she could change Chronos?” I asked testitly. I was curious about this dragoness I had never suspected was my mother, but I also needed to know where Chrysthaline stood.

“To be perfectly honest yes, but I do think it took someone like her to actually change him. After she left him, all the other drakka worked out their contracts and he never hired anybody else. I was the only one who has stayed all these years…”

“Then why did he keep you around?” I wondered. Chrysthaline glared at me as if I’d grown a second head, before she lifted her head into the air and let out a screeching laugh. "For business reasons obviously. Even though we don't get cozy like that anymore, your father does seem to realize that without me he would have squandered all his gems. As for you Darzhja, daughter of Chronos, I do suspect you have your own reasons for taking his spot in the tournament. Maybe its just me, but you don't seem the type that would bask in vain, selfish glories.”

I moved my jaw slightly, trying to think of some sort of reason but then thinking better of it. Unlike Lorath, I was a notoriously bad liar.

"So long as Chronos continues to pay me, whatever your business is not my concern, yet be careful young drakka. Too many young dragons have fallen prey to this game of shadows, including your mother..." said Chrysthaline. I tried to keep my gaze passive, but to be honest I felt like a lost hatchling now.

With that finished, I was led by one of the servants to a guest lair. I had expected it to be lined with fine jewelry and cloths as it was at Lorath’s yet the lair was rather Spartan. Essentially, it was a larger version of the dorm back at the temple, being mostly bare except for a few trinkets, but also possessed an exercise machine. Yet whatever misgivings I had about the venture, it was too late anyhow. I had to see through my task to the finish, and I had to hope that there was something left to save at the end of it. Lorath had warned me about the risks, yet I had stubbornly asked him to take this chance to be able to expose Axel Xion.

Knowing how bad I was at maintaining a deception, there was little chance I would be able to keep up this lie for long. Eventually, Chronos would figure out the true reasons why I decided to take his place in the tournament. As I laid myself down on the cot, the only way I could be able to wiggle myself out was if I truly played out the part of Chronos would imagine his daughter to be like, so much so that eventually this falsehood that Lorath had helped me come up with to get into the tournament would become true.
1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.title: Game of Shadows

1141211111111111221211111112111111111112.content:
I had ended up staying with Chronos for a couple of days before I managed to get back into contact with Lorath. It was

“Congratulations for getting a spot in the tournament Darzhja. From what I’ve heard from Danielson, its sounding like Chonos is really buying that you are his daughter.”

“He really is. Chronos is being far more accommodating than I imagined that he would be. He’s been kind to me, and warm and… he truly believes that I am his daughter.”

Lorath let out a breath.

"I take it that you'll be staying with your 'father' then? I think it works out better for us. Its more... professional..." said Lorath. While Lorath was in fact my drake friend, I was starting to feel more than a little awkward being a guest at his place, especially with those relatives of his.

“In all seriousness Darzhja, are you thinking of him as your father Darzhja?” asked Lorath.

I stared at Lorath long and hard. “I’d never had a powerful senior male figure into my life up until now, and in many ways I looked enviously on others who do. There is a big part of me that does wish that Chronos is in fact my real birth father, and its agonizing for me to contemplate finding out for sure that I would not be.”

“Worse is the fact that I am essentially deceiving him; playing with his very soul, and then pulling the string on him…” I admitted.

Lorath let out a sigh, “To be honest, I didn’t think that things between the two of you would go as deep as they had. One might almost say that the mission to get you into Chronos’ compound has been too successful. That being said, don’t forget your mission Darzhja; and that is to find information about Axel Xion and connect him to the attack on New Alveri.”

“I know…” I answered.

Lorath gave me a hug. “Things will turn out all right Darzhja. Instead of worrying about what’s already done, lets think of the opportunity we have here. Since Chronos holds you in such regard, you would be able to ask him so much more about the whole situation, find out about his contacts. In fact, we might even be able to bring Chronos on board with the investigation and help hunt down Axel Xion’s network.”

The thought of being able to get Chronos in on it, so that I would no longer have to lie to him any longer, filled me with a fresh sense of hope.

“How are things coming along on your end?” I asked.

“On schedule. Heliana and I have continued to investigate and make additional contacts throughout Damescara. You worry about preparing yourself for the fight.”

“All right then. Take care of yourself then,” I replied, giving him a hug. I then returned to Chronos’ estate.

“Ah!! You’re back Darzhja!” said Chronos in his fatherly way.

“Anyhow, I’ve managed to find out who your first opponent is going to be for the tournament.”

“Oh?”

“It won’t be an easy one,” said Chronos, looking troubled. “As you know, the tournament is arranged to be a best of sixteen tournament. If I am going to be bluntly honest, the reason I was still in the running at all was out of respect for the dragon that I used to be.”

“So you were ranked rather lowly…” I realized glumly.

Chronos shuddered. “Ranked fourteenh out of sixteenth. That means you would automatically be placed against the 3rd best fighter in the first round.”

“I see.”

I knew how these sort of tournaments worked, in which the best fighters would be placed against the worst ones to start out with, enabling the tournament to weed out the weaker fighters and usually leaving the best for last. For Danielson and his team to be able to get into the colloseum itself and begin uncovering the needed evidence, I had to at least win two, or ideally three fights.

“Then whoever my opponent is will be in quite the surprise. Who wouldn't want to be amazed at seeing an underdog rise to the top!”

Chronos smiled. “When you put it that way, I.”

“Now where was I? Oh yes. Your first opponent is an old pupil of mine. Sauroth the Punisher.”

My father’s expression grew grim and protective, and I shuddered inside. Sauroth the Punisher was one of the most powerful professional brawlers in the entire Kingdom, not to mention one of the meanest. He was also said to be the sort of dragon who gathered dragonesses to himself. That only gave me extra motivation to beat Sauroth, to put that philanderer in his place.

“If he is the dragon that I will have to face, then I will face him. You were once his teacher were you not? Can you teach me the best strategy how to beat him?” I asked. “I’ll prove that I am a worthy successor to you.”

“Good. So listen up. There’s a number of techniques that Sauroth is known for, and if you’re going to be ready, you’re going to have to work hard."

"Do your worst!!" I dared.

"That's what I like to hear!!"

Thus, over the next several days leading up to the tournament, I spent the time training mercilessly. My fath... Chronos was a strict trainer, and I expected nothing less from the dragon known as the 'Drake of Steel'. He did not insult me the way Lieutenant Shadia did, but he was constantly demanding and methodical in how he trained me, not to mention endlessly patient.

"I must say Darzhja," said Myrzanti, one of Chronos neighbors, "I have not seen the old wyrm this motivated in years. You've been a good influence on him, and frankly I think he would have had a happier life had he raise you from the egg."

"T-thank you Myrzanti," I answered. Everyone now truly believed that I was Chronos' daughter. Surely, I hadn't actually managed to fool all of them. Or maybe, maybe they knew that my plan to pretend to be Chronos' daughter was a farce, in that I need not have to pretend at all. I definitely could not go on like this, trapped in this sort of lie. It made it difficult to focus, and deep in my heart, I knew that I would have to reconcile this with Chronos before the fight began, otherwise that sort of conflict in my heart would consume me.

Yet as time passed by, I noticed not only the growing pride, but also a great fear from the old Drake. An anxiety that I could not quite place, something haunting in his gaze.

As for Chronos, beforehand, he had pretty much resigned himself that he was likely going to lose to Sauroth, being as old and slow as he now was. Sauroth was the younger, faster fighter, and it would be seen as a changing of the guard. However, now that his daughter had taken his place in the tournament, he was suddenly afraid. Sauroth was the sort of dragon that he had used to be before Prideth; dallying with one female after another. Yet Sauroth was particularly bad to females, and the thought of Sauroth trying to punish his daughter, being as young and pretty as she was, made him want to tear his scales off.

Darzhja’s considerable skill in the ring aside, this sort of sordid life as a professional mercenary and wrestler had not been one Chronos wanted for her. It had been why he had not trusted himself to take care of her from birth, because when a dragon like Chronos had been in the business for that long, one tended to accrue many enemies...

As Darjhza and Thereesa did their thing a meeting was taking place in the main tower of the Temple. Four dragons and five humanoids were bickering about current events. Pairs arranged them. It started with an Earth Render and a Dwarf, then a Golden Mane and a Human, after was a Juggernaut and an Orc, last were a Screeching Ridgeback and an Elf. The last humanoid was a rather large Dragonborn sitting on a throne.

“So what we be doin now?” The human asked out loud.

“Hell if we know Kleave.” the Orc responded.

“But that’s just it, we don’t have a clue to what we need to do.” the Ridgeback replied.

“Your one to talk.” The dwarf said.

“Hay, enough with that! My partner did everything in his power to help your family Ortho.” The elf retaliated.

“Would both of you Shut up for a second!” the earth render roared.

All the Juggernaut did was look at the earth render for a moment and everyone backed off. However it all continued seconds later with a whole lot of nonsense. This lasted to long, so thought the golden mane.

“Would you all stop and listen!” He roared.

Everyone did just that. The dragonborn then got up and walked to the center of the group. Everyone bowed at him and together spoke “Sir Xion.”

“Rise, we need to get this started.” the dragonborn said. All did as he said. “Now first thing on the list is the up coming War.” He said.

“War?” a few of the party members gasp.

“We know it’s coming. We need to be prepared for it.” Xion said.

“Which means we need more Knights?” asked the Orc.

“Why?” Kleave asked bluntly.

“Wow, really Kleave.” The golden mane replied.

“Anyways…” Xion interrupted. Yes it kind of does, all though, that in it self is a dilemma.”

“Why?” Kleave said again.

And again the golden mane sighed. “How we’re partners is beyond me Kleave."

“Ditto Jarico.” Kleave replied with a toothy smile.

“Right.” Xion sighed.

The conversation finally got itself on track and the nine spoke of potential strategies, current paths, a lot of what ifs, and a lot more that lasted for quite some time. When the mention of the recruits came up, all agreed that none of them were ready for war. They just had to suffice with what they had all ready, little as it may be. The reasons why it so small is cause of the attack cutting a lot of them out and many of the remainders were charged with missions. The fiasco with the eggs didn’t help either. When it seemed as if the meeting was over Sir Xion stopped them all.

“We need to talk of one more thing Knights.” He said. All paid close attention to him. “We need to find our selves replacements for the Head Knights we have lost.

“Your right Sir Xion but how are we supposed to do that?” the Elf asked.

“The old fashion way Zora. We start looking.” Xion said. “We’re looking for a total of two humanoids and three Dragons.”

Everyone gasped and started to uproar. They all knew what that meant. A total of fourteen head Knights. That’s seven dragons and seven humanoids that made the Head Knights, which basically means that Sir Xion just said an extra dragon was gone, but none of them knew whom.

“There’s no need to get into such a rut. Compose yourselves My Knights.” An old feminine voice came from behind the throne and out from the darkness came a rather old Seraphan slowly walking to the group. The third dragon will be my replacement my Knights.

“Lady Alvana.” gasped everyone as they bowed.

Lady Alvana is the leader of the Holy Knights and as you my have guessed, Sir Xion is her Rider. Once Lady Alvana and the Xion Family was respected by most and fear by all their enemies, but these two beings are rarely seen now a days. Once one of the strongest beings alive now at the end of her rope, dieing, simply out of old age. How she maintained her memories let alone her sanity is beyond comprehension.

“My Knights, hear me. This cannot be the end. Please do not give up. I am dieing, that is true, but none must waiver. None can afford to. Especially at a time like this. She gazed upon them all then to just the Dwarf and Earth render. “Ortho and Colzumn. Two of the most stubborn beings I have ever seen in my life. You two have made a difference in this world that neither one can see and you proved that anyone can indeed become a Knight, and Ortho…” The dwarf looked up at the old dragoness. “I know what your planning, and I need to say. That is the most blasphemies thing you could ever do. Live! Live for your family’s sake. She ended it with a smile. Her gaze moved to Jarico and Kleave. “You two… You two are absolutely nuts. Don’t ever change. The two just bowed in response. Her eyes moved to the Juggernaut and the Orc. “Golgrin, It would’ve never worked out between us.” The Juggernaut just tilted his head. “Really? Nothing? This whole time, I’ve been trying to make him laugh or at least crack a smile. Come on Golgrin smile, just once, as a dieing wish. The dragon just looked down, looked as if he was unsure about himself. “As for you Phoebus, work on him, will you?”

“I will Lady Alvana.” The Orc replied.

She moved to the last pair and simply said. “Horrora, Zora, as the women of this party, I wish of you, to take care of these so called men.”

“Will do.” Both said smiling.

The Seraphan slowly moved over to Sir Xion. “Come with me Axel. I wish to speak in privet. Everyone may leave now.” And everyone did just that. Once Lady Alvana and Sir Xion were alone she laid down with Xion in front of her. “I wish to ask about the recruits…

1141211111111112.content:
Civilian dragons were laboring here and there in the blackened debris of the district, but they were organized by trained Knights. I decided to find one and ask about the recruitment. I circled for a while but I eventually found one. I landed, but the Knight had his back to me, helping out with moving the rubble at the time.

“Hay!” I said running up to the dragon. “Your one of the Knight recruiting new members right?” I asked as I came up behind him.

“Yes I am.” He said turning around.

The both of us were shocked to see each other. It was the Knight from yesterday, still hanging his head high as if he were the strongest in the world. I just turned and started to walk away.

“Hold up, please?” He asked but I just kept walking. “Look…” he started.

But before he was able to say much else I quickly turned to him. “You Look… I can’t talk to you!” I roared.

the Knight looked a little confused by that. “Why? Please say it wasn’t because of yesterday?” He asked.

“Of Course its because of Yesterday!” I kept roaring. I don’t mine losing, however you took it further then that, Insulting me the way you did. How can people call the Knights Holy, with beings such as you?” I snarled. all the humanoids around us by this point were just watching the show, and the Knight heard little whispers here and there.

“He insulted her?” “I thought the Holy Knights didn’t do such things?” This one can’t be a Knight?” and more was said by the humanoids.

“Everyone please.” the knight said. She’s the one who challenged me. I had to teach her…” but he was cut off.

“Darjza is always like that, you could have just beat her to a pulp and she wouldn’t mine.” one said.

“Wait? This is Darjza? The Darjza you recommended to the Knights?” He asked looking at a human I now recognized as Markus. I was so relieved to see him alive.

“Yes, DD is more then qualified.” Mark said. “Knight? what did you do to make her so mad at you?”

“Enough Markus. Please.” I said.

All the humanoids looked over at me, seeing I wanted a rematch. All of them backed off. The Knight wondered why in till he to looked at me. “Oh.” He said as he looked down and was about to say something else but I lunged forward and clawed the side of his head, tearing off a chunk of his helmet then jumped back a little.

“Turn away from your opponent again and there will be more of that.” I said.

The Knight looked up at me and was about to attack but something more interrupted him.

A Grayish blue dragonborn, a rather large horn coming from the tip of his snout. He stood out from the rest with his armor shining in the light, his wings acted as a large cape. The both of us was about to fight when I heard him yell out, “What the hell was that Squire!?” We both stopped before even attacking and stared at the dragonborn. So did all the humanoids. Everyone near him gasped and quickly moved away. I looked at the Knight for a moment and saw him trembling. I’m sure everyone else did too. “What are you doing!?" the dragonborn roared. “This is no time for meaningless brawls!”

“Yes Sir Ingrid but…” The knight started to say.

“What the hell are you doing here?” the dragonborn asked sternly.

People who use the phrase "dirty fighting" just aren't trying hard enough to win. Hate is easy to carry in your heart and your enemies list is a mile long. You're not afraid of using any means to make those who cross you suffer.

With your breath weapon, you can lay waste to your foes from afar, but be careful, even your supply of fire isn't indefinite. Those huge flames sacs take a lot of nutrition to sustain, however, giving you an appetite equal to a quite large dragon. Elaborate coat markings of black, red, orange and even yellow give this breed away.

The Deathwing: These dragons have a sinister appearance with their elongated snouts, huge horns and the spikes at their knees and shoulders. A fleshy ruff around the face can create a presentation that will stop a man's heart cold in fear. But more fearsome is their reputation for ruthlessness and guile. Muscular, but not brawny, quick, but with enough weight to get the job done, these intelligent creatures are the objects of horrible fairy tales and superstitions the world over. And that suits them just fine. Always solid black, you are a hunter of the night and while you can see into the blackest abyss, your eyes are sensitive to bright lights without the time to acclimate. A single sharp prong for stabbing exists at the end of your long, elegant tail.

The Nettled Reaper: You have a fantastically dangerous appearance with a body covered in venomous quills. Down the neck, across the torso, limbs and tail, colorful quills protect your body and advertise a warning to would-be dragon slayers. Known for a foul temper and easily provoked, the quills on the tail are loose and can be launched a projectiles with a simple flick. Lacking a breath weapon, your venom nonetheless is potent to render even a large dragon unconscious in minutes and will kill humanoids outright. A fair flyer, you lack speed for the disturbance your quills cause, but make up for it in maneuverability. You are also smaller than the average standing about 15 feet at the shoulder.

Ah, The glory of battle! Surely there is no better way to make a name for one's self than vanquishing your opponents. But where your rivals are blood-thirsty, you understand there is no honor to be won in slaughtering the weak.

Now the fun begins! What breed of dragon are you?

The Geminate Drake: They say that two is better than one and this is a truth with which you are intimately familiar. As a Geminate drake, you have never had to worry about being alone because, as with all members of your breed, you were born as a twin. Geminate drakes reproduce in twos, no more, no less and each set of twins is intimately linked throughout their lives. The depth of the connection is such that Geminate twins are often referred to as a singular being and the custom is to have a single name consisting of two parts for each pair of drakes (for instance, a set of twins might be named Mal’Drak with one twin being named Mal and the other named Drak). Pairs of Geminate drakes are usually inseparable; they hunt together, sleep together, live together and usually take mates together. All of this is due to a strong mental link between each dragon, the strength of the link varies from pair to pair ranging from the simple sending and receiving of messages to merger on the extent that it seems that there is a single entity occupying two bodies. Sibling rivalry is rare to the point of extinction, but famous cases have emerged in history; always it has ended in tragedy. Geminate drakes can typically be found roosting in mountain ranges, the dryer the clime, the better. As for size, the typical drake tends to be on the large size, dwarfing land bound beasts and mortals. While not exceedingly strong or fast or possessing fiery breath of significant note, your strongest strength lies in your constant companion and your ability to fight as the ultimate tag-team.

The Regal Bronze: One of the largest casts of dragon, you tower over your opponents on the field of battle and have the force of well toned muscle behind each of your massive blows. You are called regal for your long legs and tall stature, you carry your head high and proud when you grace the land with your presence. Your kind are mortal enemies of Deathwings (but then again, who isn't?). Your brawn and their speed are evenly matched. While it isn't necessarily truth, the appearance of battling the Deathwings has given your kind a vaguely chivalrous reputation, a reputation that many individuals chose to uphold on their own. Your tail ends in a serrated arrow-head that is capable of slicing through fully grown trees and of course, your hide comes in only one color, a luminous bronze.

The Golden Mane: A strange looking dragon from a foreign land, you are the only dragon possessed of hair, a full mane that is always a shimmering golden color. Your elongated body is rather like a serpent and forshortened wings are used mainly for maneuvering through the air rather than to generate lift. You stay aloft rather by segmented hydrogen gas chambers lining both sides of your snake-like body. Thus you have potentially the most available fire out of any breed, but using up your gas also decreases your ability to fly... Your limbs and claws are small compared to the size of your body, but that's ok because your method of hunting is to coil around your prey and constrict the life out of it. Your kind is noted for a particular like of pearls, especially large ones.

The Earth-Render: You are a unique class of dragon. Rather than living in high mountain lairs, your kind prefer to burrow into the earth. That doesn't mean you don't share the same lust for treasure and glory as your fellow dragons however! Normal size for a dragon, your wings are shaped to allow you to move through the earth with ease, but makes your slower and clumsier in the air compared to others. Your knowledge of the deep places gives you special advantages, however. Your hide is tougher than usual and more heat resistant. It is even said that your kind can cause pits to suddenly open in the earth, change the foundations of the rock even alter the course of underground water. You hide has a pebbly texture and comes in various shades of brown from clay to light green. Your head is smooth and no spur or weapon lays at the end of your tail, but your large fore claws are good for more than just shoveling earth.

Your elongated body is rather like a serpent and forshortened wings are used mainly for maneuvering through the air rather than to generate lift. You stay aloft rather by segmented hydrogen gas chambers lining both sides of your snake-like body. Thus you have potentially the most available fire out of any breed, but using up your gas also decreases your ability to fly... Your limbs and claws are small compared to the size of your body, but that's ok because your method of hunting is to coil around your prey and constrict the life out of it. Your kind is noted for a particular like of pearls, especially large ones.

The Seraphan: A more majestic breed of dragon you will have difficulty finding on the planet than the Saraphen. However, this breed of dragon is almost never glimpsed by earth-bound mortals. The sky to a Saraphan is more than a convenient way to get around, it is there one and true home. The average Saraphan, in fact, only touches the ground when it dies; they are born, live and breed all in the soaring heights above the clouds. Though it may be rumor, some Saraphen are said to grow to magnificent sizes, such that their wings from tip to tip would cover an entire estate. What is not rumor, however, is the clear fact that for their size, the Saraphen weigh extremely little, able to float on the breezes as the feathers that cover their bodies. You might wonder what it is that you eat if you never set your clawed feet on the ground, well the answer also lies in the sky for unlike any other dragon, you feed off the glory of the sun herself and in the distant heights above the clouds, you never have a want for food. Always a stunning, glowing white, a Saraphan is a glorious specimen of dragonkind sporting not one but two pairs of feathered wings, in fact, most of your kind tend to look down on other dragons who spend only part of their time in the sky and rarely ever enter into your lofty domain. As for other beings… well, have you ever paused in your stride to avoid stepping on an ant? I didn’t think so. While not truly aggressive, a Saraphan will never back down from a proper challenge, attacking with their claws, complete mastery of flight and vastly superior speed. Also, the Sarahen tend to hold grudges as well as the angels to which they are often compared. There is no getting off their shit-list once a Saraphan has decided that you have wronged them.

12311.content:
This is a continuation of sorts of Darzhja's timeline, featuring Fangorn:

-----------------------------------------

The wind flowed across his body as Fangorn Irontail swept through the skies over New Alveri, the grant capital of the vast Draconic Empire. Down below, the vast myriad of humanoid races, millions upon millions of them lived out their short and content lives, counting on dragons like Fangorn to protect them from threats. Fangorn was far from alone in the skies either, for many of his kind flew by from one place to the next, with tradable goods, ferrying human passengers, or simply flying for the sake of flying.

As for Fangorn himself, why, he was a Holy Knight of New Alveri, an elite brotherhood of warriors chosen by The Ancestors to protect the Empire from its enemies. Like his had descended from a long distinguished line of bronze dragons, serving the Holy Knights of New Alveri since the very beginning. Both his father, also named Fangorn, and his mother Jariziya were from a long line of Knights, and from the day he had broken out of his shell, Fangorn was to become a Knight. One would think that every once and a while, Fangorn would have doubted the fact that his fate would be decided at birth, but he never did. He took great pride in that fact, and indeed being a Knight and fighting the enemies of the Empire had fascinated him from an early age.

As Fangorn grew up, he made his parents proud. When his father had died when Fangorn was young, he redoubled his efforts. He was always at or near the top of his class in all he tried, in battle tactics, combat, scholarship and leadership. He was well regarded by his peers, and by the time he had matured into a powerful and muscular young dragon, he was on the fast track to become a general.

However, he found that his expected fast promotion didn’t come as quick as he planned. For the first half decade or so, Fangorn would find himself guarding gates and conducting routine patrols, far from the great battles he envisioned. At first, Fangorn imagined that these seemingly menial tasks were meant to humble him, to prevent him from growing cocky, but then he started to wonder if there was something missing about him, but just could not quite identify what it was.

He flew over a section of town that was in the process of being rebuilt. Ten years ago or so, it had been blasted sky high, by a group that had still not been identified. Tens of dragons and thousands upon thousands of humanoids had been killed or injured in that devastating attack. Fangorn had helped out during the attack, evacuating civilians and helping maintain order, but felt he should have done more. If there was an attack, would there not be an enemy to punish?

The situation was being investigated, his superiors had said, continue your normal duties and wait for further orders. So, being the loyal knight, Fangorn obeyed, and obeyed... and obeyed. But by the Ancestors, it was frustrating. So frustrating. So it frustrated him to no end that he was still stuck performing patrols like this.

He remembered the culminating event of that day, when he had met a dragoness named Darzhja. An orphan dragoness, she had lost her friends and family during the attack; and had walked right up to the gate and demanded that she be made a Knight immediately, otherwise she would fight him until she did. That had been nonsense, how could anyone just walk up to the gate and ask to be made a Knight?

Then, the willful dragoness had proceeded to do just that, challenging Fangorn to a brawl and leaving him with a painful gash, and then by the Ancestors, she had been rewarded for it by being anointed into a Knight! Worse, Darzhja was then put on the fast track, being assigned important missions outside the capital that were well beyond her rank. Right now, she was on a mission in Damescara, investigating corruption in a gladiator ring that involved a potential backer of the attack on New Alveri. That should have been him! Not that upstart dragoness!! He couldn't help but resent that; that she would be rewarded for misbehavior while his loyalty relegated him to such low duties.

Part of that, he had to reluctantly admit, was that she had decided to form a relationship with a dragon that he had once considered his best friend, Lorath, a dragon from a long time merchant clan. Oh, how she would rub it in his face, of how Fangorn was rude and vain, while Lorath, on the other claw, was kind, agreeable and better looking.

He let out a grunt. She would find out the hard way about that charlatan, of how he took dragonesses one after another. Surely, he would break her heart, and leave her humbled.

Fangorn wondered why he cared what happened to her in that regard. By the Ancestors, he should have gotten over his irritation over Darzhja by now, but he found that he could not. Because there was always something about her, something he could not identify, that... simply made her fascinating to behold. She stuck out from everybody else.

Part of him hoped that she would come back just so Fangorn could have another shouting match with her. If for no other reason to break the cycle of monotony he'd endured now.

The sun was beginning to set now. The end of his patrol. Time to return to the temple now, another day in the life of a Knight. So, the large bronze dragon whipped around in the sky, and when he landed, he saw that...

123111.content:
"Ah, hello again Sir Fangorn," bowed the human auxillary with customary reverence.

Fangorn stared down at the human, "Hello Sir Barrigan. I have completed my rounds of New Alveri, and will document the days events for record keeping."

He dully went over the events of the day; a few petty crimes that the humanoid soldiers dealt with easily, but the most noteworthy being a pair of fledglings deciding to take a fight out into the streets and stopping them from destroying humanoid property.

"Another one of those days eh?" said Barrigan.

"By the Ancestors yes," sighed Fangorn.

Then, out of the corner of his eye, Fangorn suddenly caught a large shape heading straight toward the landing pad. His body stiffened. Was it an attack? Yet when his gaze narrowed, he recognized the dragoness coming forward. It was Darzhja.

You have got to be kidding me...

The dragoness, without so much looking as to where she was going slammed onto the landing platform, uplifting bits of rock when she landed and making the surprised humanoid scurrying for cover. Her momentum kept hurling forward, forcing Fangorn to spin around and stop her from crashing.

"Darzhja! What by the Ancestors were you thinking? You know better than to just come crashing in to a landing zone!! You could have hurt the humans!!" he bellowed. Only later did he realize that this was precisely the wrong way to address her.

Something didn't look right though. Her eyes were filled with fury... and pain, similar to what he had seen during the attack on New Alveri itself.

“Fangorn, if you’re here to call me names like you usually do or give me the run around of how I'm breaking this protocol or that, I don’t want to hear it!!” she snapped. Without pausing, Darzhja turned to a large faucet of water and began drinking feverishly. How long had she flown without stopping? She looked terrible. So Fangorn took the time to let her recover first.

Fangorn took a breath.

"What happened? You're not supposed to be back from your mission. Where is Lorath? What became of the investigation?" said Fangorn. Normally, one would send a messenger first to announce their imminent arrival, but Darzhja was never known to follow protocol, though in this particular case, Fangorn was greatly concerned of the possible reason as to why she had done so. Something had gone wrong, terribly wrong; so wrong that perhaps she felt she could not trust the normal messengers.

"Lorath... he's not coming back to the knights..." said Darzhja with a low growl. Fangorn's eyes widened. Lorath had been his lairmate and his best friend with the knights. While they had had a falling out, if Darzhja had come back alone...

"What... happened? Is he?" said Fangorn, his heart pounding.

"He's taking over for his clan..."

"But that's impossible, both his father and his older brother have precedence..."

"They're both dead," said Darzhja, panting.

"Wait what? So there was an attack on Damescara then? How did that happen?" bellowed Fangorn, his wings unfurling. His once dull day had now become anything but.

Darzhja turned her head away.

"Darzhja," said Fangorn, forcing himself to calm down, "How about we get inside? If things are as severe as they are, lets inform our superiors immediately so we can discuss what happened in a more secure setting. My mentor Lord Ragnor has been paying attention to the case and needs to know what happened..."

Darzhja stared long and hard at Fangorn. Fangorn suddenly realized how bad things had gotten between the two, that when it came to things of such magnitude, Darzhja was hesitant to speak.

"Can I trust you? Sir?" she said, glaring at Fangorn and placing bitter emphasis on his rank.

The words stung far more than he ever imagined. Did she despise Fangorn so much that she would rather see one of the major cities of the Empire burn rather than even contemplate seeking out his help? If so, then Fangorn blamed himself, because if he had to think about it, he had treated Darzhja rather badly.

"Darzhja," said Fangorn, "Lorath was still my friend, and if something has happened to him, I still feel that I have a right to know what's going on. Furthermore, I know we haven't gotten along at all, but... when something like this has happened, we need to let our superiors know about it. My mentor Jereforth has been investigating the case as well. I can help."

“I may be able to help you.” The stranger said.

“How? Are you a Wizard?”

“No, but my brother could very well do something for you.”

“Is he a…?”

“A wizard? Some people believe he is.” The stranger said with a grin.

I said nothing, not daring to believe there was hope.

“What?” The small man, at least relatively speaking, seemed suddenly anxious, “I guaranty he is! But before anything, do you think you can do me a favor?” He gestured meaningfully with his head

I lay in the middle of the road facing the stranger, with tall trees all around me and a canopy growing overhead. A trail of destruction spread off the beaten path behind me, trees broken in half or knocked down all together, as if a huge force had plowed through, which in fact was the case. As it happened to be, I was quite an enormous creature as such things were measured here on the Earth. The stranger was standing in front of me, tied up to a thick tree with stout ropes. He was looking at me and waiting for an answer.

With one of my claws I cut the ropes holding the human to the tree and saw him fall on his knees out of exhaustion. At that point I wondered why humans turn on each other so easily, but then after a moment thinking on it, I realized it was most likely the same reason why my own race had done so to me. Looking at the human in front of me, I was skeptical but at the same time curious.

“So you think this wizard can give me back my home?” I asked glancing up at the sky; or at least what was visible through the thick canopy.

The human looked up as he stood and figured out what I meant. “I’m dead sure of it.” it said with a humble smile towards me. “Think we should get going, Dragon?” the human said after a brief pause. I realized I’d drifted off slightly, staring at the strange clouds and thinking how strange it was that I was underneath them.

“Agreed, however if you please, don’t call me Dragon. It feels as if you were belittling me. I have a name, you know.”

The human took a step back, overly cautious. “I’m sorry ‘bout that, it’s just you didn’t tell me your name yet. Um… Mine's Isaac… Isaac Xion.”

When I scented his fear I backed off, not wishing to intimidate the tiny creature. “My apologies. I’ve been dealing with these other humans for a while now. They just don’t seem to take the time to listen to my words…” I sighed as I explained to Isaac. “I am Nodalisk.”

It was hard for me to stand back up. For one, all the cuts and bruises I’d accumulated from running through the forest, hadn’t started to heal yet and then the fact that I never had the chance to actually stand straight and look around with the trees all around forcing me to crouch and stoop. I was still quite sore for the awkward run, and yet at the same time, getting to my paws felt wonderful, as if the simple act of just standing there was making me stronger in the wake of my recent trials.

“Um Nodalisk?” I hear Isaac say from near the ground. “What of your… er… Worshipers?”

He just made a very good point. However, for a moment, no matter what I thought up, the future for those humans I left behind seemed grim. ‘Wait a moment,’ I thought, twisting my head down to look at the scraggly bearded man, ‘how did he know about them?’

“I don’t know… If I stayed with them, they would eventually realize I’m no god and perhaps try to kill me,” I said, pretending like I didn’t notice the discrepancy in our conversation, “And since I left them, they are most likely following me right now and maybe going to kill me once they caught up… How did you know they were people of worship?”

“It was how you said it. You sounded annoyed and, just guessing, not much would annoy a dragon of your stature. Men of faith, especially the villagers nearby, I heard are total nut cases.” He chuckled at that for some reason. “Hell, I know they're crazy. I’ve been here for almost two days because of them. I was supposed to be an offering or something… most likely an offering to you.”

I simply nodded at his logic. It was nice being around someone who was not absorbed in verses out of a dusty old book.

“Why don’t you just kill the people behind you and be done with it?” Isaac asked.

I hissed and the pearl white feathers around my neck ruffled at the thought, “I’ll rightly defend myself, if I’m caught, but if there is no need to kill, I don’t. It’s as simple as that. Besides I doubt that any human would dare try hurting a Seraphan.”

“You’re a Seraphan?” he asked me.

“Yes?” I questioned I thought my brilliant coat of feathers and two sets of wings would have given me away immediately… then I remembered that I didn’t quite fulfill the second descriptor anymore.

“It's just... you’re the first I’ve seen, ever. It’s rare to even glimpse at one, yet I’m a few feet away from one. From you…” Isaac’s eyes grew wide as he spoke.

“Are you going crazy like the others as well?” I asked, my tail lashed to the side and began curling around the trunk of a tree.

“No. Of course not. It’s just amazing is all being so close. It is said to be a sign of great luck to even see a Seraphan No wonder those people thought of you as a god…” he replied, clearly eyeing my plumage.

“Then Isaac, let’s be off.” I said beginning to trot off down the road. I felt uncomfortable with the man’s eyes on me like that. Stopping for a moment, I looked behind me and saw the damage I had done in my haste, then back at the road ahead of me. It was quite narrow for me but it seemed I could fit in either direction.

“Something wrong?” Isaac asked.

“In which direction does your wizard live?”

“That way.” He pointed behind me. “Although, that way leads right past the town whence you came. I really don’t want to run into those people again.”

“That’s understandable.” I full heartily agreed with him. “So then, what of the other way?” I asked.

“The city of Bellwood. That’s where I was headed before I was forced to… Stay put as it were.” Isaac answered. “What do you have in mind?” He asked.

“As of now, I just want to lose my Followers.” I said with a little sarcasm. “So that means as of now, our only two choices is either this Bellwood place or past that Village we both were at before. Well I know half of those villagers are behind me right now breaking their way through the forest, so backtracking could be safe, I think. It might even throw them off our trail altogether”

“Either way, I do suggest we hurry it up. I mean you just said those nuts are following you right?! And exactly how long have we been standing here talking?” Isaac said.

“You’re right…" I said, lifting my nose to the direction we would travel.
