“Well because of our size difference I’ll be a lot slower then you, that’s all. I mean, well, if it offense you…”

“Stop.” I said without meaning to sound so strong. It was a little annoying though, I mean did I really need to repeat myself?

“Yes!” He said with a cracked voice. He then proceeded to curl up in obvious fear.

I rolled my eyes as I turned to him, not caring if I knocked over anything in the process. “Wow, really that’s all I can say. A second ago you were fine around me. You think I’m like lesser dragons? That I’d kill you, even after I said I wouldn’t kill needlessly?”

Isaac looked at me.

“Better. Now hope on” I said extending one of my claws and placed it down in front of him. I saw him cringe a little but he did clime on. I lift my claw off the ground and gazed at Isaac. “you think you could tell me why your so afraid of me all the sudden?” I ask plainly.

“I’ve been scared this whole conversation, Sorry.” he said

“No worries I think, we just met after all.” I said happily, hiding the fact, that I was hurt, yet at the same time, I did understand a little. After all, who in the right mind wouldn’t fear the unknown? Plus the fact that I was bigger then one of those things they lived in. I placed him on my shoulder and he walked a little ways to the middle of my upper back.

“Aah, Nodalisk?” he asked. “Why go to Bellwood? You said back to the village maybe safer right?”

“I do know both ways will lead to problems but in all truthfulness, I too don’t want to deal with those people back there.” I said as I turned back around and proceeded to walk again. “He got over it pretty fast.” I thought happily. “Now then, if you don’t mine. If you want to talk, climb up to my head. It’s hard enough to hear something so small even if it’s right in front of me.

I made great care not to leave a trail, of course that was a lot harder then I first thought. The road itself was rather large for humans but for me, a whole other story. I needed to squeeze through these trees without touching them and they were just tall enough that the sun couldn’t help me much. At least I’ve stopped bleeding by this point. Another is that it took me about an hour to get use to walking. I kept tripping on my own feet every now and then plus of course he asks me about it. I was thankful that he done what I asked of him and climbed up first and sat down.

“So, I take it you never walked this far before?”

“I barely walked at all.” I said. His look I imagined was that of confusion. “You said it before, We Seraphan are rare to even have a glimpse at. Why you think that is?” I asked

It was quiet for a moment. The only sound that was heard was my footsteps.

“Everyone that said saw one, the Seraphan was always spotted in the sky…“ he said. “Wait one guy said he saw one dead on the ground.”

“Why is that?” I asked

It didn’t take him long to figure it out. Showed me he can solve puzzles well enough. “The Seraphan live twenty-four seven, up in the sky!” he yelled. I laughed at his revelation, making him trip up and almost making him fall. I felt him scurry back to the middle of my head. “Close one. From this height I could die.” I heard him say.”

I apologized and I was a bit impressed that he still wanted to be up there. Considering he kept asking me question after question and I kept giving him riddle after riddle in till I found the amusement was gone from it.

“Enough Isaac, please.” I said

“Ok then, I guess I’m satisfied with what I got. Thank you Nodalisk.”

“Your welcome” I replied. I then felt Isaac heading down my neck. “Wait Isaac, if you please.”

He stopped and as he climbed back up he said “What’s up”

“How much longer in till where out of this place?” I asked

“We’ll be out of the forest in about a day or so maybe more. I know that it‘ll normally take me a week on foot, butt…” he answered.

“I haft to keep walking like this for a day?” I complained

“Like what, you mean this isn’t you just walking?” he said. I thought this was your normal way of walking, I mean you just said before that Seraphan never come down to earth so I simply thought that this was your walk.”

“I didn’t want to leave a path for them to follow.” I replied.

“You been walking this way for a few hours, right?. The sun is past noon and I see or hear no one. I think we’re fine. Relax.”

He was right. What the hell was I doing at that point? It was foolish, so I did what he said of me and relaxed. I spread out my legs and my overall mass was definitely wider then the road I stood on. I bent the trees on both sides of the road. I then proceeded to walk normally.

“Damn!” Isaac said.

“What is it?” I asked.

“You’re a lot faster this way. It could take us mere hours now!” he cried out.

Of course I was leaving a trail of bent or broken trees in my wake. “I hate the forest.” I stated out loud.

It was just like Isaac said. After three more hours we finally made it out of that wretched place. Just to be out in the open made the burns I got on my sides from the constant rubbing of the trees was worth it. Isaac was on my back walking up to my shoulder as I looked up to the sky. It was dusk at that point. I sighed and slowly laid down. “So, I think I’m going to rest for a bit.” I said to the air

“Right, first could you let me down?” Isaac asked.

“Right.” I sighed as I put up a claw for him. He climbed on and I put him down.

“If you care to take a look.” Isaac said. So I did. He was pointing to a mountain with lots of tiny lit up holes all over it. “That there, is Bellwood. I’m heading there for the night and most the morning. Is that ok Nodalisk? I mean I’m asking if I could go?”

I sighed in annoyance. “Please stop that. You don’t have to fear me. Your not my slave Isaac. Ok?”

“Right, sorry.” He said smiling.

“Thanks for telling me however.” I replied.

Isaac just nodded and headed to Bellwood as I laid there tired of all the walking. I just watched the tiny thing grow even smaller in my vision.

Isaac Xion??? What a strange creature he is.
123212.title: Off to Bellwood

1232121.content:
I pondered on the human for a while, thinking that I knew nothing of this world. He was asking so much on what Serapham were and talked little about himself. “He’s hiding something.” I thought. At the moment all I was able to do was think. I didn’t feel at all sleepy, exhausted yes, but not sleepy. I’ve come to realized that I didn’t get to much sun either, ever scents I crashed on land I’ve been mostly covered by something, so the sun was doing vary little for me. “Damn.” I sighed. “I can last till mourning.” I thought as I wondered how I lived through all the crap I had to deal with for the past few days. It was just one thing after another. But enough on that, it be another story I’ll tell some other time. I looked around me, happy to find that most of where I laid was open, barely a tree in sight. Just the forest behind me. It was night when I decided to get further away from it, however I found it even harder to get up. Wondering why didn’t stop me and I walked a little ways, mainly just to get away from the trees. When I felt far enough, I laid back down. An hour of me just staring off into space past by in a blink but I finally fell asleep.

I awoke to find myself soaked. Water was coming from the sky. It was puzzling to me at first but I soon spotted clouds overhead. I do in fact know that clouds have water within them. I flew through a few in my lifetime. Anyway. It was refreshing to feel something from home but it was lasting longer then I wanted. After twenty minutes of being drenched, it took its toll on me. Too much of a good thing. “Your mocking me, aren’t you?” I said in frustration. A moment of silence past by… I Roared! It was the loudest I have ever been in my life. I then proceeded to claw the ground beneath me, vigorously. Over and over again, in till I wiped myself out. I moved a little to the left then collapsed half way in the pond I made. I passed out after a moment.

I woke back up when the sun’s light peeked through the mountaintops. The clouds and the water were gone say for that newly constructed pond and found that Isaac wasn’t back yet.

…

Once Isaac left Nodalisk he found himself walking a great distance. For some reason, he started running as if his life depended on it. Running like that with no signs of stopping. It took him a mere hour to get to Bellwood. At the front gates, wheezing to catch his breath, sweat stunk the air around him and his legs in pain from over use. One of the two guards placed at the gates came up to Isaac and said the typically cliché thing any guard would say. “Halt, who goes there?” Isaac rolled his eyes before looking at the guard coming up to him. Still breathing hard he said. “I’m… Edward… Ingrid I Must see… I must see… The lord of… Of Bellwood… Straight away.” The guard just looked as Isaac with disgust and said the other typically cliché thing a guard would say. “State your business.” Before he gave his answer he took a breath and started to breathe normally. “I need to speak to the Lord directly, it’s urgent!” He yelled. The guard hit Isaac in the gut and he when down on his knees. “Learn your place nave!” The guard sighed and started back to his post. “THE DRAGON IS GOING TO KILL YOU ALL IF YOU DO NOT LET ME IN!!!” Isaac screamed.

Later in the Lords throne room. It was raining outside by now. Lord Theodore sitting on his throne, Isaac standing in front of him but across the way. “Quite frankly, I don’t believe you.” the Lord said bluntly.

“I understand my Lord, I do. However please trust me, I Beg you.” Isaac replied.

“I don’t believe you because you said all it wants is some gold. Gold, a human currency. An expensive human currency.” Theodore stated

“Look my Lord. I understand why you think I’m lying but please, I’m trying to save your people.” Isaac pleaded.

“No, Guards” he yelled. As they came in the room he then said. “Take him away.”

As soon as they grabbed Isaac to pull him out of the room and Isaac screaming, saying to not do this and that, everyone went pale. The reason was because everyone in the city of Bellwood heard the most gut ranching roar any of them have ever heard; Even Isaac almost pissed his trousers.

“Was that Nodalisk?!” Isaac thought.

“Was that the dragon?!” one of the guards yelled in Isaac’s ears.

Shaking a little Isaac said. “I believe so… You think your willing to help now?”

…

When the sun was half way up in the sky. That’s when I saw him, walking back, but with other humans behind him. There was something the humans were carrying. A crate of some sort. It took then four humans to hold it up. I saw Isaac say something that made the others stop. He then ran to me. “What’s going on?” I asked as I moved my head to the ground in front of him.

“Not so loud Nodalisk.” He said.

“Why?” I asked.

“Please. Look, I’ll tell you everything later but for now I’m Edward Ingrid and you want that crate… Please help me?”

I stared at him coldly. “Why?” I ask more forcefully.

“Please Master!” he yelled.

“I told you…” I started saying.

“I know you did, you wanted more, but that’s all they had, please take it and spare them!” He yelled. It was obvious that Issac wanted the other humans to hear him.

I was getting what he wanted me to do. So this was the type of person Isaac was. I looked at the other humans and decided to…
1232121.title: Rain and Rained upon

12321212.content:
The trivialities of the human race were getting more and more complex. First off I didn’t know what was so important about that crate that Isaac wanted me to lie for. The second thing was the humans behind him, scared out of their minds. I deduced, part of that was my fault. However, was my fit last night really that loud? Then there was Isaac himself. Fine with me one moment, afraid of me the next, lying to his own race after that. Was he lying to me as well. This whole time? I didn’t know. I decided to tell the truth. Mainly because Isaac lied to me, wanted me to lie for him, and I realized that I trusted him to quickly. After all, it’s only been a day.

“People of Bellwood.” I spoke with the calmest and softest voice I could muster. “I am Nodalisk.” The humans scared out of their wits but slowly calmed down as I spoke. “And I’m simply passing by trying to get home. As to whatever my companion has done to you to make you all walk here and be frightened of me. Whatever it was. I Am sorry for what he has done.” At this point all the humans calmed down enough. Isaac on the other hand had an opposite effect. He slowly became nervous over the course of my apology. As if he thought I would help him out.

“What about last night Dragon?” Lord Theodore hesitantly asked me.

“I assuming your talking about my little spat. That’s all it was.” I said frustrated. I gave them my name before anything else. “Plus, I did say there was no reason to fear me… But I take great Pride in my name, use it, please.” I said as I lifted my head and moved it closer to Theodore. Some of the other humans fainted from... I don't know... I guess me being to close to them.

Lord Theodore gulps then said. “Yes Sir, uhh Nodalisk.”

As I moved my head back I noticed the unconscious humans. “Damn it” I thought to myself, not wanting that to happen. “Now, will you accept my apology for my friend here?” I asked.

A few seconds past by and then Lord Theodore smiled and said…
12321212.title: Apology

123212121.content:
Hour 1

“No.” Lord Theodore said with wavering eyes.

I sighed knowing that this was the outcome.

The people still conscious started up roaring, saying stuff like heathen, liar, and other things that rubble in comparison. It seem like they forgot about me altogether. The rave continued for all but 10 seconds. That’s when Lord Theodore said “Enough.” and all went silent.

“What needs to be done now is the punishment.” Lord Theodore stated. “What you think my people? Banishment would be too easy, of course death would be too harsh, all he did was lie after all, yet how he scared my people and I…” he looked up at me and continued. “Dragon, ahh. Nodalisk, if you would be so kind as to hand your friend over.”

“And what pray tell are you going to do to him?” I asked plainly.

He will be imprisoned.” He replied plainly. “He will live, he will get out one day, but he will suffer.”

I looked down at Isaac then back to Theodore and lifted my hand away from Isaac.

“Wait, Nodalisk, what are you doing? Wait! Stop! I just wanted to help! Please Nodalisk!” Isaac begs as a pair of the other humans walked up, grabbed him and started to drag him off.

I couldn’t help but to feel sorry for Isaac, think that prison was overdoing it a bit. Some of the other humans who fainted woke up and Theodore ordered them to help carry the crate back to Bellwood.

I just laid there, watching the tiny creatures grow smaller in my vision, pondering the facts. One is, I need Isaac. So far he was the only one who wanted to actually help me, and I just let him go. “Damn it.” I sighed.

Hour 2

As Isaac was being dragged back to Bellwood. His thoughts running past his eyes as he realized what he just did last night. He started to mutter to himself. “Of course, he’s a dragon, guessing he’s prideful cause what he said bout his name and guessing scents he let Theodore take me, he is most likely honor driven. Great…”

“Shut up prisoner!” one of the guards dragging him along yelled. “If you can speak, you can walk yourself.” He stated.

“Well if you would let me go then?” Isaac said.

“Like Hell!” the other guard said.

“Then keep dragging me.” Isaac argued.

“My Lord? Could we just kill him and be done with it?” Isaac cringed at the thought, not really wanting to.

“No.” Theodore said.

“Pardons My Lord but why not?”

Theodore turned to look at the guard talking to him. “Because of his friend, you fool.” the guard went wide eye for just a second, knowing he meant Nodalisk and the Lord continued. “He was defending this man, means the dragon wants him for some reason. Why it gave him up is beyond me truthfully. Prisoner, if you care to answer me?”

“He’s a Knight.” Isaac said loudly, making everyone stop.

“What makes you say it’s a Knight?” Theodore asked.

“First I say stop calling him an, it. You’re belittling him and he hates that.” He said as he stood on his own and I know this for a fact. “Two, I say Knight, figuratively. What I know of him so far is he is both prideful and honorable.” Isaac then started walking on his own to Bellwood, realizing that he should stop playing around.

Hour 5

I laid in the middle of nowhere, soaking up the sun’s heat. Bellwood in front of me, the forest behind me, my wounds slowly healing. Thinking that I needed to move as soon as possible, do to the group that was following me. I had about a week or so before they reached me, that is, if Isaac words were true. First things first, I needed to gain my strength back. I noticed the humans still asleep as my eyes wondered the lands. When I realized that Theodore left his own people behind I began to think that Theodore wasn’t any better then all the other humans I met, say for Isaac. Isaac couldn’t be the same. He was the only one who spoke to me as if I was an equal to him. Suddenly I heard a scream and looked down to find one of the humans awake. “Am I really that terrifying to humans?” I ask as more woke because of the first cries of terror. Instead of an answer I get screaming and running. “I guess so.” I said annoyed.

Hour 6

Within the Bellwood prison, Isaac sat in the middle of a cell, smiling evilly. “Now this, I can work with.” he said.

“Work with what?” a boys voice said from the cell next door.

Isaac jumped a little. “Damn! Thought I was the only one.

The boy laughed a little. “No worries sir, just trying to think of a way out myself.”

“I can help with that.” Isaac said as he got up and started rummaging through the little clothing he had on and found himself a pair of lock-picks. “So, rather young voice to be in prison. What you do?”

“They think I lied to them.” the boy said.

Isaac chuckled a little as he started picking the lock.

“Something funny.” the boy asked.

“I’m in here because I lied to them.” Isaac said. “Though, the people of Bellwood must be idiots, if lying is a cause for imprisonment.

“I don’t care to much if they are, I just know I can’t keep my Master waiting any longer then he half’s to” the boy said.

“A master… Interesting.” Isaac said as his cell door just opened. “Well then, your turn stranger.

“Your quite trusting, sir?” the boy said

“You’re a kid, that’s really about it.” Isaac answered coming up to the cell next to his. “So, what’s your name anyways? I’m Isaac.” He asked while he started on the lock.

As Isaac worked. A figure from the cell’s shadows started to emerge.
123212121.title: In just 6 Hours

1232121211.content:
The lockpick snapped just as the latch on the door turned. Isaac cursed under his breath as he pulled the iron ring on the heavy wood door of the cell; without the thinner pick, the larger one he used to hold down the lever mechanism was useless. Out of the cell walked a young man, a boy really, in Isaac’s judgment, but he carried himself as if he were far older.

“I’m Tobias.” Said the young man. “Thanks for getting me out of there.”

Isaac would have responded, but he was occupied with looking at the boy’s strange garments. Despite the boy’s sun darkened skin, he wore the dress of a noble, and certainly not any noble that Isaac was familiar with. His silken suit was pitch black, the collar of his coat decorated with white thread forming a bat wing pattern. The shirt he wore under his coat was dark orange, bronze perhaps. It too was heavily embroidered with numerous divots in the front where it was exposed, scales maybe? The color theme reminded Isaac of something one might see at a Harvest festival, though the richness of the fabric and the embroidery was far beyond the rags people typically wore.

Wide-eyed, Issac finally asked, “Who’d you steal that getup off of?”

Tobias, who was almost as tall as, but not quite, Isaac smoothed the front of his shirt with both hands. “I didn’t steal this. It’s mine.”

Isaac, who himself was dressed in little more than undyed linen and some rabbit hide boots smirked at the young man with a knowing grin. “Right… I’m sure you found those in an irrigation ditch.”

Tobias was looking around the small room outside the locked cell doors, apparently not interested in further discussion of his garments. “I… I’m not sure of the way they brought me down here. There were quite a few corridors.”

Cautiously, Isaac moved with his back to the stone arch which led to the cells. Peeking around the side of the wall, he saw that he rough hewn passage beyond was lit with sputtering torches spaced so widely that there were gulfs of blackness in between them. Save for the drip of water in the distance, the corridor seemed empty. Turning back to Tobias, Isaac whispered. “Seems to be clear. Just follow me and don’t get in my way.”

Tobias nodded and began to walk quietly behind Isaac as he sneaked into the stone passage. In truth, Isaac had no idea where he was going, they’d put a sack over his head as they’d led him to his cell. It was obvious, however that they were in some sort of tunnel complex under Bellwood, or at least Bellwood’s keep. There was no telling how large the system was. It ran, in part, into at least one natural cave, which was fortunate because Isaac figured that he could follow the path of the dripping water back to the surface.

The kid behind him moved with an easy grace, his steps quiet, but not as quiet as Isaac’s. The conman stole a look back to the pretender. “Kid’s got some gall trying to pull off a costume like that.” He thought, “If he’d waited a few more years, he might’ve made it. At any rate, he might make a decent diversion if I run into any guards…”

The path split, one lit and one unlit. Isaac, smelling the air from the lit shaft detected a mild odor of woodsmoke and soup. The Kitchen. The conman took the other path.

Tobias whispered from behind as Isaac put his hand on the wall and walked into the velvet black. “Why are we going this way?”

“Do you want to go back into the keep, or do you want to get out of here?” hushed Isaac. The boy fell silent as he felt his way forward.

Under the earth was eternal night. It seemed, after a while that the blackness was almost solid and threatened to crush him on all sides. Isaac was afraid that this was what a tomb felt like. Footsteps ahead. Isaac froze and Tobias walked into his back. The boy cursed and Isaac reflexively elbowed him in the gut, knocking the wind out of him. Tobias staggered back and Isaac turned and put his hand around his mouth, listening. The steps grew louder. Tobias stopped struggling and went slack as he heard the noise as well.

Torchlight emerged from around a corner, as if recreating the world as it neared. Isaac was as relieved as he was terrified. Still holding Tobias, he pressed himself to the wall. “If there’s one, I’ll get around behind him and choke him.” He thought. “If there’s more, I’ll toss the kid into them and run like hell.” Isaac saw shadows on the wall now. He hardly dared to breathe. It was…
1232121211.title: The "Noble"

choices: The stairs lead into Bellwood's treasury
The stairs lead into the Baron's bedchamber
12321212112.content:
The kid did, in fact, make a decent projectile as it turned out. Isaac pushed the lavishly dressed youth forward into the oncoming guards, knocking one of them down completely. It was bad luck that it hadn’t been the one carrying the torch, the prison escapee would have preferred the cover of velvet dark as he ran back down the tunnel. It was still dark, however and he stumbled on the wet, slippery ground, he swallowed back a yelp as he twisted his ankle. Eyes squeezed shut – though it didn’t really matter if they were open in this tunnel – he held his ankle as he cam up on one knee. He sighed softly. ‘I suppose I had a good run, at least.” He thought with absolute certainty that he would soon be caught.

Footsteps up the corridor. ‘I wonder if it’ll be hanging or the axe…’ thought Isaac, praying that he wouldn’t be drawn and quartered or burned alive. However instead of the guards he had been expecting, he saw first the polished boots of Tobias. Looking up, he saw the young man framed by three men, two of similar age to Tobias and the third older and more battle worn. The ‘guards’ were not in uniform, though they wore dissimilar leather armor covered with crude chain links beneath their tunics; it was the sort of armor one would find cobbled together by some backyard rustic blacksmith. “Wha-“ Isaac managed to ask.

Tobias looked down at the conman with his twisted ankle and wordlessly extended a hand. Isaac glanced at it and then took it. When the older man was on his feet, however, Tobias drew back his fist and socked him squarely on the jaw. Isaac saw lights brighter than any torch. “Now we’re even, Isaac.” Said Tobias shaking his hand as the older of the three new men caught Isaac and saved him from falling onto the floor.

The man holding Isaac looked to Tobias and asked, “What should we do with him, Sir Drakling?”

“Bring him along, Christopher. He got me out of my cell and that’s more than I could have done on my own.” Said Tobias.

Isaac looked from one man to the next, mouth hanging agape. It was difficult to phathom that the kid had been telling the truth, but plainly these three men were loyal to him. “I’m… sorry, Tobias.” Said Isaac

Tobias ignored him. “How did you three get down here anyways?

The young man on Tobias’ right snorted, “It’s quite an unbelievable tale, M’lord.”

Tobias looked to the other man on his left as the former was still in a fit of laughing, “Since Jacob’s brain is obviously being eaten by cave mites, would you mind telling me what happened after I was incarcerated, Michael?”

Michael was the one holding the torch. He scratched at his patchy, immature beard. “It is an interesting story, like Jacob said.” He turned to face Tobias as they continued stepping down the unlit path, “For starters, did you know there is a dragon outside of Bellwood?”


* * *

“So then what happened next?” Isaac asked with avid interest as he continued to lean on Christopher’s shoulder.

The dark tunnel seemed to extend into infinity, but Tobias’ three guards seemed comfortable enough as they led the former prisoners back the way they’d came.

“Well obviously, we had ourselves more than the shock of our lives when we blundered into the fellow while we were looking for the cave entrance in the woods. We didn’t know what to do, but we eventually figured out he wasn’t feral.” Jacob paused to lean to the side and soc Christopher in the shoulder, “But not before the mighty dragon slayer here went and tossed his sword at him!”

Christopher groaned and put his square face in his palm. “I’m never going to hear the end of that.”

Michael picked up the tale, “It just bounced off his hide anyway” he said with a wave of his hand, “He didn’t seem to mind too much, though and he told us his name was Nodalisk, so we gave him ours. We told him how you’d been taken down into the prison, Tobias, and he seemed really interested in that. He told us he lost a friend down there too and then led us to the cave exit. He said if we run into an Isaac, tell him sorry and something else I can’t remember.” Isaac looked at the young man speaking crossly, but didn’t say anything, “Anyway, that dragon has got a pair of legs on him, he easily kept pace with the horses and we were running them. However, I wonder why he just didn’t fly over here. Would’ve been a lot faster.”

“He can’t fly.” Isaac said.

“Why not, we all saw his pair of wings.” Michael asked.

“He’s a Seraphan.” Isaac replied. The other four men paused in their stride to look at him with curious glances

“What’s a Seraphan?” Tobias asked.

“It’s a race of Dragon that lives in the sky, never touching the ground and I think have two pairs of wings, right?“ Surprisingly it was Christopher who answered.

“Yeah they do.” Isaac said.

“Amazing... I never heard of anything like that.” Michael added.

All of them started walking again. “Is he still here?” Isaac asked.

“Maybe. But when we left him to go into the tunnels, he was talking about trying to convince the Baron of Bellwood to let you go.” Jacob said. “I think your friend is pretty soft for a dragon.” He said this looking heavily back at Isaac.

“You’d rather die then?” asked Christopher at his side.

“That’s not what I meant.” Jacob replied.

“Anyways.” Michael said, breaking in between the two other body guards. “After we entered the cave, we started wandering around in the tunnels searching for a backdoor as it were, and then ran into you. You thought we were guards I take it.” Michael said, winking at Isaac, “That’s why you threw Tobias at us and started running yes?”

Isaac looked down in shame. He couldn’t remember what it was like to have people you could rely on, people you could trust with your life. These people, especially the three younger men, really seemed like they trusted one another, even when they were bickering and socking each other. Isaac couldn’t help but noticed how Jacob and Micael were especially chummy with Tobias. “Yeah…” said Isaac quietly

Tobias put an arm around Isaac, “At any rate, we’ll all soon be out of here and you’ll have your freedom too, Isaac. I won’t forget that it would have been easy for you just to have left me in my cell.”

Isaac was about to say something, but the tunnel suddenly came to a fork. The opening was small and secretive, but it was not the rough hewn passage that continued on into the dark. It was carved stone and opened into a small alcove in which there was the bottom of a spiral staircase; it would have been easy to walk by without seeing coming from the other direction. Four of the group continued down the main way but stopped as Isaac jumped off Christopher’s shoulder and hopped to the small, narrow arch, placing a hand against the wall.

“What are you doing?” Tobias asked.

“I can’t go yet.” Isaac answered.

“Why not?” asked Michael.

“I need to figure something out first.” Isaac said. “Just get out of here you all, all right?”

The other four just looked at him. “Christopher, you go with him, OK…” Tobias instructed.

Isaac started to protest, and Christopher looked upset to be sent away.

“What is it your figuring out anyhow? What’s more important than getting out of this weird little town?” Tobias asked.

“There just isn’t something right about this place...” Isaac said. The strangeness had been in the looks people had given him in town and in the queer architecture of the houses and the lavish stone buildings. It almost seemed to hang in the air, even down here in the dark caverns under the town. “Five years ago, Bellwood was nothing but an oversized logging camp, but now there’s a keep, high walls and stone buildings everywere.”

“You want to know how that’s possible…” Michael said.

“Make sure your friend doesn’t wait too long Isaac.” Christopher said putting an arm under Isaac’s shoulder and supporting his ankle

“Nor us.” Added Tobias with a significant glance to his elder bodyguard

Isaac and Christopher looked at each other and then started off up the stairs while the rest of the party kept going down the tunnel.

**originally written by Kleaver and edited by Shalion**

Isaac and Jacob were climbing the seemingly endless spiral staircase in near total darkness. The only reason they could see, Michael had taken the torch with Jacob and Tobias, was that the white marble of the walls spiraling upward glowed with a miniscule luminescence. It was obviously enchanted. Such was not unheard of, but even a simple glow woven into the stone would have cost a fortune. The dark still hung around the two men as the hobbled upward, one supporting the other, but they could at least see the wall itself rather than be enveloped in total black. Christopher looked at the smooth white stone with apprehension, but Isaac only focused on climbing; almost as if he knew where he was going. It seemed extremely convenient that no city guards were placed on the hidden stairwell.

“You’re not really here to discover any mystery, are you?” Christopher asked suddenly.

“Nope.” Isaac answered without bothering to look at the other man

“Then… Why the hell am I here!?” Jacob yelled a whisper.

“You can go if you want.” Isaac replied. “However I really am curious on how Bellwood was build so fast. And I knew as soon as I saw this stone that there was something up here. Something good…”

Christopher sniffed and ran his hand along the cool stone as he continued to climb. “Probably… And I do have to agree with you about the town. I never even heard of Bellwood till today.” Jacob replied. They both kept climbing.
* * *

I was very agitated with Lord Theodore, Baron of Bellwood’s stubbornness. He just wouldn’t see reason. I didn’t know a whole lot about human laws, but it rankled that no matter what I said or how I explained the situation, the man refused to even consider releasing Isaac into my custody. It was as if Theodore just wanted Isaac to keep. I rested my head on the ground as I lay between the trees, feeling wretched. ‘I should never have let Isaac go with those men…’ I thought miserably. I’d been mad at my little pet companion, but I never realized that he might be taken so completely out of my control.

It was at that time that three of the five humans I’d been expecting since I’d returned from my last misbegotten session with the Baron emerged from the miniscule hole I’d found in the woods behind Bellwood. Two of them sighed in relief.

“Jacob, please wait here for the others.” Said Tobias as he climbed carefully over the rocks, he’d spotted me almost immediately, but then a huge, white feathered dragon was rather hard to miss. “I’d like to meet with this other dragon.”

The two humans walked up, the one I knew from before, but the other was new. It had to be the trio’s missing friend, he was certainly dressed well enough for a noble, though I’d been expecting someone far older than a mere human boy. Tobias approached me standing tall, however even as his companion slouched and avoided my gaze. He seemed remarkably comfortable around a dragon many, many times his own size. “Greetings. You must be the one called Nodalisk, correct?” I nodded slightly, “I am Sir Drakling and it is a pleasure to meet another glorious member of your species.”

I lifted a feathered eyebrow. This kid has met another dragon?

* * *

I listened to ‘Sir Drakling’s’ explanation of his origin and his current mission to the capital city of Lyrond with avid interest. Another dragon out on the frontier with a whole village of humans under his command… Why hadn’t I thought of that? Then I remembered what had happened the last time I’d been in a figurehead position. It was an interesting tale, especially since there didn’t seem to be much evidence of other dragons elsewhere in this country dominated by tiny bipeds. It occurred to me that perhaps I should seek out this “Lord Ladonius.” Then I remembered bitterly the stumps where my first pair of wings should have folded. I’d be at a fatal disadvantage if this bronze proved to be territorial as it was said that terrestrial dragons often were. He was male too, so it seemed even more likely that this boy’s sponsor would gut me and slash my neck open as soon as look at me. I had better hopes following Isaac to his distant brother’s as I’d set out to do in the first place.

At any rate, this Tobias was regal and very courtly and flattering in his speech. He gave me the proper respect I deserved, but didn’t cower when I looked at him or made a sudden movement. It was an exquisite change of pace. Perhaps Tobias could train Isaac a bit for me.

We had been sitting by the opening in the stone for a long time. Tobias was entertaining me with a native folk story featuring a dragon whose tail had been stolen by a large catfish. When he had finished, however, one of his companions interrupted.

“They’re taking too long.” Said Jacob. “I’m going back in.”

“I think you shouldn’t.” I said.

The three humans looked up at me. “Why not Nodalisk, Isaac is your friend too, right?” Michael asked me.

“I honestly don’t know at the moment, but if he wanted to stay in there, I think it must be at least important.” I said. The three just continued to stare at me. “What?” I asked.

“You don’t know much of Isaac do you?” Tobias asked.

“Not much… but we only met about a week ago.” I answered.

“We think Isaac maybe a Conman Nodalisk.” Chris said.

“What’s a Conman?” I asked them.

The three humans just sighed. My tail began to lash and accidently felled a large tree when they told me.

* * *

Isaac and Christopher came panting to the top of the spiral staircase at long last. As they stood at the top, they found themselves facing a solid stone wall. They both stared at it. “Now what, genius?” asked Christopher heatedly.

Isaac just put his hands forward against the stone unbelievingly. How could they have climbed all this way just to face a wall at the end. He shoved against the stone. “No one builds a magic glowing stairwell that leads nowhere…” he said, straining against the wall.

Christopher growled at him, but then slowly set his shoulder against the stone too. He could see the logic in Isaac’s statement. Slowly, with a noise of stone grinding against stone, the section of wall pushed outward. Both men stopped when they had enough clearance to slide through. Isaac found himself looking into a small windowless room with a heavy oak door at the far end. He was in Bellwood’s treasury. Isaac’s jaw dropped.

However, now that he looked at it, there wasn’t all that much to the treasury of Bellwood. In fact, the place was almost empty. There was a book shelf against one wall with a collection of books with years listed on them: tax records. On the opposite wall was a bare wooden desk and chair with a set of scales on it as well as a basic alchemical set Isaac recognized for testing the purity of gold. A few coins lay scattered on its surface. Isaac looked around frantically. He spotted a couple likely looking coin purses on the book shelf as well as two more lined up at the back of the desk, but each was smaller than a tomato. “Where’s the gold?!” he hissed. Christopher just sighed, waiting for his companion.

Then Isaac spotted it, the chest from before. The one with the ransom he’d demanded from the townsfolk under false pretenses. He hobbled over to it. Getting on his knees, he lifted the heavy cover and saw the large sacs within. “Bingo.” He said. But when he lifted one, the sackcloth tore as they were wedged in the box very tightly. Rather than the glittering of gold coins, out spilled nothing but sand. Isaac’s eye twitched, he felt like he was going to lose his mind.

The theif’s hands shook as the contents of the weighted bag slipped through his fingers. Christopher strode over and kicked the sand across the floor. “Satisfied, now, Isaac?” asked Tobias’ guard, “Bellwood’s bankrupt. The Baron probably borrowed a ton of money to get this place off the ground. They’ll have his head on the gate outside this time next year.”

“Th-that’s impossible…” said Isaac, in shock.

“Let’s get out of here.” Said Christopher, putting a hand on Isaac’s shoulder, but Isaac pulled away.

“This can’t be right! It takes more than a loan to raise walls and a keep. There has to be something, there has to be...” he turned back to Christopher, “How the hell does Bellwood do so well with this little?” Isaac asked.

“I’d rather know why there is a secret staircase leading down into the tunnels from here.” Christopher replied.

Continuing to look around Isaac saw something totally out of place in the entire room.

It was...

1232121211211.content:
A rusty sword was sitting in a bucket and Isaac just stared at it. “What is it?” Chris asked.

Isaac snapped out of it and turned to him. “Tell me, this room is empty, but is pretty, vary nice looking and say you, right?” Isaac asked.

“I guess so, why ask?” Christopher said.

"Then what is that horrible looking thing doing here?" Isaac asked as he pointed to the sword.

As Christopher looked at it he started to wonder if Isaac was crazy. “It’s just an old sword Isaac. What’s the big deal?” He asked.

“But that’s just it. For what I know of Theodore over the past few days. He’s not one to keep trash laying about.” Isaac said as he moved to it.

“It’s most likely something precious to him.” Christopher said as he followed Isaac.

“All the more reason to actually take it I think. At least for a bit.” Isaac replied.

Christopher sighed as Isaac picked it up. “Right, shale we go now?” Chris asked but Isaac just stood where he was. “Isaac?” he asked. Isaac was turning it slowly right and left. He didn’t seem to hear Chris at all. Isaac, what’s wrong with you?” Christopher asked as he walked up to Isaac. As he walked around the man he felt something. It was a faint feeling but it was definitely there. Dread. “Isaac. We need to go.” Chris said grabbing Isaac’s arm then pulling him to the secret passage.

Isaac finally snapped out of what ever he was in and with the sword in hand, he followed Christopher. “Ok, your right, lets go.” He said.

When the both of them crossed through the door in the wall, they heard the wooden door across from then unlock and heard the voice of Theodore on the other side.

“Escape… Hell!” Theodore said as he opened the door. Isaac and Chris already moving down the secret stairway. “What the Hell!” Theodore yelled. the two guessing he saw the mess Isaac made. “Where is it!? Where is It!? Where the Hell Is My Sword!!?” the two heard him scream.

“Told you it was precious.” Chris said and Isaac just laughed as both moved as fast as they could.

…

“Sorry bout that Nodalisk.” I heard Tobias say.

I just laid still and silent for a moment. “Did he lie about helping me get home?” I asked looking down towards the humans before me.

“Maybe.” Jacob said bluntly. but that’s when Michael punched him in the face. “Ahoch, My nose! Damn it Michael!” Jacob put his hands on his face in pain. “Oh, I’m bleeding.” I barely heard him say. I also heard Tobias laughed the whole time, but quickly compose himself after so.

“Nodalisk. There really is no way of telling what a conman will do for his friends. Sorry.” Tobias said.

“Only known him for a few days… Oh well. I guess I really have no choice in the matter.” I said.

“What you mean?” Jacob said.

It was Tobias who spoke next. “He needs to trust Isaac, in order to get home. Right?”

I just nodded. Suddenly we heard bells start to ring over Bellwood. I and everyone else instinctively looked over at the city. “You three think they were caught?” I asked.

“If they were I’ll be pissed off. That means we now need to plan out a rescue party.” Jacob replied.

“I don’t think Christopher could be caught so easily.” Michael stated.

“But Isaac is with him.” Tobias added. “and he did sprain his leg.”

“Wait… Isaac hurt himself and you let him go?” I asked.

“Yes we did. Nodalisk. Isaac is one who won’t change his mind so half-assed. He would have found a way to do what he wants.” Michael said.

“Most con-men are like that actually.” Tobias added.

“So then, what do you think I should do?” I asked the group.

…

Back inside Isaac and Christopher ran into a little trouble with a few guards that caught up to them. the pair stood in front of four of them.

“You good with a blade?” Chris asked Isaac.

“I dabble in it from time to time.” Isaac replied.

“That’s gunna half to do I suppose.” Chris responded.

All four guards lunged at them. Three of them went after Christopher. They knew from the brief talk the pair had, Chris was better with a sword then Isaac. The three attacking Chris didn’t take long to fall on the ground. Moving gracefully and dispatching three out of the four guards with what looked like one fell swoop. the fourth fighting Isaac had a harder time then he thought he would. Isaac holding his own well enough but couldn’t do much other then that. He stopped when Isaac saw the guard’s head fly off. Then seeing Chris behind him Isaac fell and took a breather. His joints already hurting from that short time fighting.

“Lets go Isaac.” Christopher said lending a hand to Isaac.

“Sure thing.” Isaac answered as he took Chris’s hand and was pulled up by it.

The two started running. after a couple minutes Chris suddenly realized that Isaac was keeping up with him. He didn’t bother stopping but he did ask Isaac, “How are you running normally Isaac?”

Isaac stumbled a little now realizing himself Chris was right but kept running. “I don’t know, I guess adrenalin maybe?” He questioned himself.

…

We were waiting just a little longer when two humans popped out of the secret entrance to Bellwood. Tobias and his group all greeted each other with Hellos, what happens and a short explanation from Christopher. Isaac just looked at me smiling. I on the other hand stared back at him with immense disapproval. The four others noticed me and Isaac but Chris interrupted the silence.

“Sorry to spoil the moment for everyone but we need to leave now. he said.

“Your right, Theodore knows of this passage and I’m certain he is headed this way right now.” Isaac added.

“Then we best be off.” Tobias said.

Everyone and I agreed.

As a noble dragon, you disdain unnecessary fights. Bloodshed is pointless when conflicts can be reasoned out with words. And everyone knows you can be counted on to keep your promises. It's better to make friends than enemies.

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon are you?

The Golden Mane: A strange looking dragon from a foreign land, you are the only dragon possessed of hair, a full mane that is always a shimmering golden color. Your elongated body is rather like a serpent and forshortened wings are used mainly for maneuvering through the air rather than to generate lift. You stay aloft rather by segmented hydrogen gas chambers lining both sides of your snake-like body. Thus you have potentially the most available fire out of any breed, but using up your gas also decreases your ability to fly... Your limbs and claws are small compared to the size of your body, but that's ok because your method of hunting is to coil around your prey and constrict the life out of it. Your kind is noted for a particular like of pearls, especially large ones.

The Earth-Render: You are a unique class of dragon. Rather than living in high mountain lairs, your kind prefer to burrow into the earth. That doesn't mean you don't share the same lust for treasure and glory as your fellow dragons however! Normal size for a dragon, your wings are shaped to allow you to move through the earth with ease, but makes your slower and clumsier in the air compared to others. Your knowledge of the deep places gives you special advantages, however. Your hide is tougher than usual and more heat resistant. It is even said that your kind can cause pits to suddenly open in the earth, change the foundations of the rock even alter the course of underground water. You hide has a pebbly texture and comes in various shades of brown from clay to light green. Your head is smooth and no spur or weapon lays at the end of your tail, but your large fore claws are good for more than just shoveling earth.

The Sky-Swallower: So named because when you take to the air, your wings seem to swallow the sky to lesser earth-bound mortals. An enormous breed of dragon, your strength is matched only by the Juggernaut, and your sheer size by none. You and your kin have often been mistaken for small hills while you lay dormant in hibernation. You bulk is such that it can literally flatten a small village under it. All that bulk means a big appetite, however, so big in fact, that you have to spend the majority of your year in a state of hibernation to conserve energy. But the more food you can get your giant claws on, the less time you have to spend sleeping and the more time you can spend chasing down loot!

12421.content:
Mud, dirt, rocks...
They were about all you could see down here.
Not that being underground offered much in the way of scenery, and you were far too busy digging away to care.

More digging... more rocks, in a higher density this time.
It'd take a while before you could get through all this, so now might be as good a time as ever to take a break...
You look back at what you've already done; the tunnels seems... unending, only darkness can seen, even through your eyes...
Hard to believe you've dug so far...
Far from...

* * * * *


It was a peaceful day with your family; your mother had just returned home from hunting, and your father was busy as usual expanding the burrow. You, and your brothers and sisters, were ecstatic to see her again... and your father always seemed relieved too (you always thought that was because of how easily he tires out).

You're a young Dragon, still in your child years. You haven't even learn't to speak yet, not that it helps being the youngest of the litter. Regardless of your speaking prowess, the rest of your body was still on track; your wings are almost fully functional, your teeth are useable, and your scales were already hard as rock (a rather weak rock at that, but still a rock). Your family's colours were almost the same as the dirt you lived under, which gave some great camouflage... and also opportunities for games such as hide and seek.

"Honey! Kids! I'm Home!"
A resounding choir of 'Mommy!' followed shortly after.
From the looks of it, her hunt had gone well, as she arrived with 3 Deer carcases in tow (one appeared to had been mostly eaten already).
Now that your teeth had some time to develop, your mother had approved to moving on to more 'solid' foods. The first time you had tried meat, it seemed like a delicacy... it was something to savour for a life-time.
Your first BONE on the other hand...

"Nice to see you dear." Your father replied.
"You too. The kids didn't give you much trouble did they?"
You mind quickly switched to the deer you were currently eating; it's soft fur... tender meat... blood still dripping... the tough bo-BONE! Avoid! AVOID!
Your sudden shock caught the attention of your entire family, causing you to blush furiously in embarresment. You could even heard the sound of your siblings as you try to resume your meal.
"You win this round..."

"Oh, I see..." Your mother sighed.
You think they've switched to conversation to you...
But then she giggled as she walked towards you.
"Hmhm, don't worry though, that just makes you so much more cu-"
A roar in the distance had cut her off, causing hers, and your father's, eyes to widen in shock.
Though you and your Siblings had nothing but curiosity for this sound; none of you knew what it meant.

In fact... you're still not even sure what happened...
everything in between's been a blur...
...panic, screams... the glare from an unknown face...
...escape...

* * * * *


You try and bring yourself awake after remembering that dragon's gaze it had on you, sending shivers through your spine just by thinking about it.
Nothing had changed since you had dozed off; same old tunnel... same old rock...
You take another look back. Your father always wanted an escape tunnel... but your not sure if this is what he had in mind...
You try to get back to digging your way forward, but your body's still numb from your previous work, even after the nap.
So you give up that idea and go back to sleep; it'd take a lot more work to get through here...

...How long have you been down here anyway...?

125.content:
You believe that is is better to act by a code of conduct when dealing with humanoids and your peers, but feel free to twist the meaning of the conduct to suit your purposes when the need arises. It is important for others to know that you are an honorable dragon, you just make sure that that doesn't stop you from getting what you want.

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon are you?

The Fire-Lord: You are a bit scrawny for a typical dragon and almost half the normal size standing at a mere nine feet at the shoulder. None dare mock your skinny frame or over-sized wings however as the bulbous sacs to either side of the base of your neck contain liquid, molten death. With your breath weapon, you can lay waste to your foes from afar, but be careful, even your supply of fire isn't indefinite. Those huge flames sacs take a lot of nutrition to sustain, however, giving you an appetite equal to a quite large dragon. Elaborate coat markings of black, red, orange and even yellow give this breed away.

The Nettled Reaper: You have a fantastically dangerous appearance with a body covered in venomous quills. Down the neck, across the torso, limbs and tail, colorful quills protect your body and advertise a warning to would-be dragon slayers. Known for a foul temper and easily provoked, the quills on the tail are loose and can be launched a projectiles with a simple flick. Lacking a breath weapon, your venom nonetheless is potent to render even a large dragon unconscious in minutes and will kill humanoids outright. A fair flyer, you lack speed for the disturbance your quills cause, but make up for it in maneuverability. You are also smaller than the average standing about 15 feet at the shoulder.

The Regal Bronze: One of the largest casts of dragon, you tower over your opponents on the field of battle and have the force of well toned muscle behind each of your massive blows. You are called regal for your long legs and tall stature, you carry your head high and proud when you grace the land with your presence. Your kind are mortal enemies of Deathwings (but then again, who isn't?). Your brawn and their speed are evenly matched. While it isn't necessarily truth, the appearance of battling the Deathwings has given your kind a vaguely chivalrous reputation, a reputation that many individuals chose to uphold on their own. Your tail ends in a serrated arrow-head that is capable of slicing through fully grown trees and of course, your hide comes in only one color, a luminous bronze.

You value your ability to think on your toes in a fight. Your adaptability and ingenuity in combat always keeps your foes guessing what you're going to do next! Nothing excites you more than cleverly outwitting a clumsy opponent.

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon are you?

The Deathwing: These dragons have a sinister appearance with their elongated snouts, huge horns and the spikes at their knees and shoulders. A fleshy ruff around the face can create a presentation that will stop a man's heart cold in fear. But more fearsome is their reputation for ruthlessness and guile. Muscular, but not brawny, quick, but with enough weight to get the job done, these intelligent creatures are the objects of horrible fairy tales and superstitions the world over. And that suits them just fine. Always solid black, you are a hunter of the night and while you can see into the blackest abyss, your eyes are sensitive to bright lights without the time to acclimate. A single sharp prong for stabbing exists at the end of your long, elegant tail.

The Fire-Lord: You are a bit scrawny for a typical dragon and almost half the normal size standing at a mere nine feet at the shoulder. None dare mock your skinny frame or over-sized wings however as the bulbous sacs to either side of the base of your neck contain liquid, molten death. With your breath weapon, you can lay waste to your foes from afar, but be careful, even your supply of fire isn't indefinite. Those huge flames sacs take a lot of nutrition to sustain, however, giving you an appetite equal to a quite large dragon. Elaborate coat markings of black, red, orange and even yellow give this breed away.

The Crovey: The Crovey are a species of dragon with a reputation almost as dreadful as the feared Deathwing and whose reality is definitely more horrifying for the average mortal. The ancestral home of this breed of dragon is a vast underground cave complex, which exists under an equally vast mountain range commonly referred to as Umbra veil (Land of Shadow) by the dwarves and other beings. The Crovey, if you ever get a chance to see one, are slender of build, almost sickly and possess a short wingspan, which is more suited for short bursts of flight or assisted leaping than prolonged gliding. Boney spurs at the elbows aid in self-defense and another spur at the end of the tail curves upwards as the dragons are known to strike over their heads rather like a scorpion. They lack the ability to breathe fire so it would seem on the surface that they would be forgettable. However, living in the dark these hardy fiends gained a unique ability to sense the life force of others at a distance, and even to feed upon it directly. Similar to a pit viper’s sense of the body heat of its victims, the presence of life “glows” for the Crovey in the dark of their world. With time, their auras have grown incredibly malleable and they are able to extend it at will far from their bodies, thus are they able to feed on the life force of others, assuming the dragon can overpower the spirit, of their intended prey. If a Crovey cares to be subtle, their prey can begin to weaken and die without ever knowing the dragon was present at all. The Crovey do not eat, but do require a steady source of fresh water. They can feed on any form of life, even cave mold and fungus can be sustaining in times of famine, however, living creatures usually have the most abundant life force.

“I was once a man with honor and nobility. I was once a man who had everything. I had money, power, love, but the dragon didn’t care at all. It killed everyone. My friends, my guards, me… Yes people. I am dead. The dragon killed me too. I speak to you in a way not even I understand, but please hear my story…”

“Oh, Shut… Up… This is why I dislike feasting on you humans all at once, always with these echoes…”

“Hay! Don’t say I’m just an echo in your head, If I were how come I have a conscience?!”

That'll pass, you said it yourself. You're dead.”

“So then what? Am I simply fading away even as we speak?!”

“Yep.”

“Wait, that can’t be right! I don’t want to die again.”

“What do you mean, you’re already dead.”

“Shut up Shut up Shut up!”

“And you’re wasting the rest of your energy by even speaking. If you want to exist longer then shut your Pie-hole and accept faiths hand.”

“Like hell I will! I’ll fight you!”

“By all means… Try. The faster you eat up your energy, the faster I can be at peace.”

Suddenly I heard nothing.

“I really hate when I talk to myself.”

Hay!”

“I Said Shut up! Damn it. Can I just get some peace after a good meal?”

“You thought I was a good meal!?”

“Yes I did, but now I’m wondering if I should have just killed you with my bare claws!”

“You don’t haft to be an ass to the dead you know.”

“Oh, now you believe you’re dead. Finally.”

“Well I’m just a voice in your head by this point right?”

“Right…”

“Then let me do the only thing I can.”

I just sighed as I listened to the dead man’s story. He spoke of him being a prince and how his kingdom was going to be in ruins soon, and if that goes, what most likely will happen was a world war and he told me even I will be affected too. I doubted that but he just kept going. He told me what I had to do but I wasn’t paying to much attention to him. His chatter finally ceased after about an hour. I thought it would never stop but just before the voice went away, I heard his vary last thought.

“Oh, Oh My beloved Angela.”

Another problem I have when taking in a whole soul of another, is feeling the emotion of that soul’s final moment before their existence is no more. In this case, it was undying Love and Loyalty. I just shook the feeling away. I personally didn’t care what would happen to the human world so long it doesn’t affect me. Little did I know at the time, but I had just screwed the world over.

The truly clever recognize the value of patience. While your foes go to and fro about the land, you carefully lay your webs and draw the trap ever tighter all without them ever realizing it. The shadows suit you comfortably.

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon are you?

The Sea Stormer: While your kind don't actually live in the sea, long have you been associated with the surf and the pounding waves. Weather just has a way of worsening when you are around and often, just the sight of you flying nearby is a reason to harbor the ships and close the storm blinds. You don't spend much time in the water, but usually nest in seaside cliffs and dine primarily on fish caught at sea. Of course, there is little wealth to be found at sea, unless you are looking for ships. Instead of breathing fire, you can fill a very large sac at the base of your throat with water and expel it at high pressure. Your kind have often been blessed by farmers looking for rain, but equally you have been blamed for creating cyclones and water-spouts... Typically your kind comes in a light blue and white matching sea foam. Pearly horns jut back from your head and fins at the end of your tail aid in both sky and water.

The Golden Mane: A strange looking dragon from a foreign land, you are the only dragon possessed of hair, a full mane that is always a shimmering golden color. Your elongated body is rather like a serpent and forshortened wings are used mainly for maneuvering through the air rather than to generate lift. You stay aloft rather by segmented hydrogen gas chambers lining both sides of your snake-like body. Thus you have potentially the most available fire out of any breed, but using up your gas also decreases your ability to fly... Your limbs and claws are small compared to the size of your body, but that's ok because your method of hunting is to coil around your prey and constrict the life out of it. Your kind is noted for a particular like of pearls, especially large ones.

The Faerie Dragon: Despite being the smallest breed of dragon, there are none who take your kind lightly. About the size of a large horse, your lithe, colorful body is supported by two pairs of elegant and overlapping wings resembling that of a butterfly. 14111.content:
The irritably familiar sound of metal boots clanging down the lengthy cave that lead to my hoard jars me from my slumber. "Humans." I muse to myself as I stand. Digging a small hole behind me, I send my tail underground and maneuver it beneath the mouth of the cavern.

 A minute later in typical shining armor, the human stands at the mouth. "Dragon! I …" The human doesn't get much farther as my tail shoots out of the ground and wedges itself in a gap and flips the human over. The rest of my tail bursts from the ground and stabs forward. I slash once to the left and once to the right, knocking away their sword and shield. "Let's see the face of the one brave enough to dare to attack me in MY OWN HOME." I roar the last words and, using the tip of my tail, remove the helmet.

 Long graceful hair tumbles down her back as she glares at me with icy blue eyes. "Come closer, girl. I want a better look at you." She reluctantly approaches and I circle around her. "I remember you from somewhere, don't I?" I quickly go over my more recent memories. "Ah, yes. Now I know where you're from. You're that girl from Ravira. Your father was also a knight. Wasn't he?" "Yes, you slaughtered him and my mother in front of me." The lady knight spat at me. "Just so we're clear, we are talking about the father who use to beat you because you were a girl instead of the son he wanted and the mother who neglected you for the same reason. Correct?" Some of the anger drains from her eyes. "Well, looks I was right." Her behavior instigates a chuckle from me. "What do you want?" She asks abruptly. "Why do you think I want something?" "I'm still alive." I laugh. "Yes, I suppose I would have killed you if I hadn't." "Yeah, so what do you want?" "You." I answer bluntly. "What?" "I need someone to champion on my behalf and I think that someone is you. There is another reason but that's not important right now. Be my champion and I can guarantee you powers beyond your wildest dreams."
14111.title: Home invasion

141111.content: "Fine, I'll be your champion." She agreed, sounding almost disappointed in herself. "Good. But if you are going to be my champion, then you're going to have to carry my insignia." I motion towards the flag on the wall, a giant black triangle surrounding a red dragon skull. "And as my champion you shall have these." I grab a new sword and shield and unceremoniously drop them in front of her. She picks up the sword and examines it. "Isn't this a Deathwing tail blade?" "Yes, it used to belong to my brother until someone came into his lair and chopped his head off. The shield is made up of some of his scales." Taking the sword in her right hand and the shield in her left, she looks back up at me. "What now?" I grab her in one of my hands. "Hey! What is this?" "Just be quiet and don't look down." I flap my wings to gain some lift then shoot down the tunnel and, once outside, plotted a course towards an Orc camp. Their war leader runs to meet me as I land. "Revered Lord of Fear Calemvir, your presence is always welcomed but what is the reason for this visit?" The green-skinned humanoid prostrate himself before me. Placing the girl on the ground and prodding her towards the Orc camp, I told the worshiping warrior that the human was to be taught how to lead a force and that if any harm happened to befall her, I would destroy the entire camp and butcher any survivors. He hastily agreed and led the girl back to the camp. The acidic smell of smoke attracted my intention and without another word I flew off towards whatever was on fire. Arriving at the source a hour later, I discovered that a city was being raided and on further inspection, found out that the city belonged to…

14211.content:
One day you find yourself soaring majestically away from your previous lair in search of a new home. As you come around a towering mountain, you can see smoke rising from some settlements in the distance. This might be a great chance to prove yourself after the mishaps which have driven you from your home. You settle on a ridge and lean against a great redwood as you rest your weary wings and consider your options. The sun glints off your marvelous bronze scales as you lift your head in thought.

Do you want to move forward or reminisce on the events that have brought you to this place?
14211.title: A Bronze Rising...

142111.content:
No. Now was not the time for pointless reminiscence. The past was dead and gone, however my future was another matter entirely. I gazed long at the settlement, watching the tiny creatures scurry back and forth. Pointless, meaningless lives. In a sense it was like watching fish in a tiny pool. Those tiny beings down there, sheltered in the confines of their artificial home had no concept of the vast world around them.

The trees, the wind, the sky. All beckon to me so that it was a challenge to even remain still and concentrate. I took the thought into my mind that I could decimate the village, eat my fill of livestock and have an afternoon’s worth of amusement as well. My head lowered and I lean more against the stout tree at my side, I could feel the roots straining under the ground as I press my formidable weight against the ancient tree. Burning the village too would be pointless, something that my brother would revel in as well. I resolved not to destroy the village, if only because it is something my hated sibling would enjoy.

But I was already tired of thinking of him. He was far away now and no longer a part of my life. My life… I had never been out completely on my own, I realized with a grim certainty. I’d been flying for my life for so long, survival had been the only goal. Now what? I turned my head back the way I had come and realize that the mountain at my back marked the end of the last dragon’s territory whose domain I’d so recently passed through. He’d informed me that beyond his domain, the land was hostile, populated by tiny thieves who delighted in stealing dragon eggs, slaughtering infants and emerging from the ground like ants despite every attempt to exterminate them. In other areas, they were properly tamed, but not there, he had said. Not here.

“Not properly tamed…” I thought slowly, the idea building up in my mind like a rising tide. I knew I needed territory and seeing as not an inch of proper real-estate was left unclaimed in all the lands I’d visited in my years of traveling, perhaps I could be the one to begin domesticating these “wildlands.” After all, I had no eggs nor young vulnerable to tiny thieves and assassins. The idea that an insect, even a multitude of insects no larger than the small claw on my hand could pose a threat to me was laughable.

Thus, I sat and turned my head back to the settlement tucking into a fertile valley between the towering mountains. It’s wooden shacks and campfires took on new meaning in my eyes. Perhaps my territory could be rich indeed someday…
142111.title: Territory

1421112.content:
I resist the temptation to simply fly down to the village, create a ruckus and position myself as the peoples’ new ruler. Not that I couldn’t, but that approach lacked finess and besides, they tiny things would probably attempt to kill me as soon as I shut my eyes; not that they would have a chance of succeeding, but still, it’d be annoying.

I knew from rumors circulating in dragon lands that this pathetic stain of a settlement in the midst of the clean wilderness was just the tip of a vast hive of tiny bipeds who in their numberless hordes were said to imagine themselves to be rulers of the world. I thumped my tail in a fit of amusement at the insane notion. Still… it was best to take my time settling myself into my new territory. The long centuries, millennia if I was lucky, stretched out before me. I could afford to wait and I knew my patience was a gift that the rest of my misbegotten family lacked and didn’t value. I would make full use of it here.

I spread my wings and felt my bronze scales rippling over my sleek and powerful form. Barely out of adolescence, I had come into my body since my expulsion and it had hardened and grown powerful during the course of my travels. I had nothing to fear in all the wide world, even other dragons would give pause before challenging me. But my strength was only a fraction of the power I could and would wield. If this was to be my new home, I would take the time to understand its intricacies as I took the time to study the patterns of migration of deer and other game back across the mountains and across the desert whence I came. The most potent weapon of all was information.

Tensing my hindlegs, I lifted up my chest and sprang into the air, cupping the wind with my wings and lifting myself up. My legs smoothed against my body and my tail lashed, balancing me as I turned to face the wind. The sensitive membranes of my wings told me how the air was moving and about the tiniest changes in temperature. I flapped, lifting myself higher and away from the trees. I saw a hawk rising in front of me and followed until I could feel the thermal lifting me higher; I set my wings and soared. I closed my eyes and reveled in the sensation, the air rushing past my face, the loving support of the wind under me. It felt good to rest, it felt good to rest.

I opened my eyes and circled for a while, just for the fun of it. The green valley under me was indeed fine country. I could only imagine what good food-beasts might be found here. But I couldn’t let my belly take charge, as much as I’d like to believe otherwise, this valley wasn’t my own just for looking at it. I scanned the valley, looking for the village’s outlying buildings and shacks… looking for potential prey. I didn’t have to search long before I found what I was seeking. A lone…
1421112.title: The Gift of Patience

14211121.content:
…human. Yes, that’s what they were called. I circled lower and lower sacrificing the height I had taken from the thermal. It gave me time to decide which direction from which to strike. I was well practiced in hiding myself on my approach. The trees surrounding the small field with give me cover once I was close enough. I tucked my wings close and jetted down, angling them so I spiraled in. The g-forces of my descent made my heart rush with excitement. I did not flap or brake, but re-extended my wings so I came rushing in over the trees. I was a little high coming in sacrificing concealment for a better margin of error. The human unfortunately was turned in my direction as the trees gave way instantly to plowed earth under me and it began to run. It stung a little that my ambush was not perfect, but it would make no difference, the tiny biped moved so slowly, especially in comparison to a fleeing deer.

The hardest part was not killing him. I slowed as much as I could by angling my wings upwards, it was a delicate maneuver when simply coasting. I stretched my hand forward and caught the human in my palm. It shrieked, in pain or fear, I could not tell. I flapped and lifted us both away. I think my tail accidently brushed against the wooden building on my way out, but I didn’t particularly care. The human was creating an ear shattering din with its wails. It took everything it had in me not to squeeze it until it was silent. I resolved to carry the noisy thing far away where I could conduct my business in peace. I tucked it to my chest and flew, cradling the dirty, struggling thing to my chest for ease of balance.

After the better portion of an hour, I found a likely ledge, though it was a bit too small to be comfortable. I landed awkwardly, bracing my wings against the mountain’s face to break my fall. I let the human drop and set about folding my wings. The beast immediately tried to run, though there was nowhere for it to go except over the ledge. I sat myself down, my tail draping over the edge for the lack of space. Then I did what I did best, I waited. It didn’t take long for even a beast as dumb as a human to figure out it was trapped. While I waited, though, I noticed the human’s strange appearance.

What I had taken for its filthy hide which had caught between and befouled the scales on my palms was actually some sort of loose material worn over the human’s skin which itself was as naked as a newborn mouse’s. It’s horried flat face was even more ugly in person, lacking a nose altogether save for a tiny protrusion rather like a cancerous lump in the middle of its face. Lacking hair everywhere save for a mop on its head, it was easy to see why they would wish to cover themselves. I hoped I was not wasting my time trying to understand such pathetic creatures and yet the rumors of wealth accumulated by the vast numbers of these things drove me on. I stuck to my original plan.

For the longest time after the human had stopped trying to climb down the sheer ledge, it refused to look at me. As if not acknowledging my presence would somehow change its situation. I snorted hard enough for the warm air to ruffle the thing’s shaggy head of hair.

When it turned, I spoke in the most recent slave dialect I’d learned. The one used most commonly on the other side of the mountains among the tiny populations of properly humbled and domesticated bipeds. “Do you understand me?” I asked in a low voice.
14211121.title: Kidnapping

142111211.content:
The human was so long in responding I began to wonder if the creature was even capable of speech. Where there, in fact different breeds of human as there were dragons? Perhaps I’d picked up a variety with no more sense than a rutting pig.

Oh well, at least I had myself a decent snack… Before I parted my jaws, I thought I heard some sort of garbled mumbling. “Did you say something?” I asked in my gruff baritone.

When the human spoke, it was in a voice unpleasantly high in pitch to my ears. Also, despite the fact that I knew the words that it spoke, the dialect it used was foreign and hard to decipher. The gist of the creature’s lament was: “P-please don’t eat me.”

I rolled my eyes and tried to speak slowly so that it would understand. “If I’d wanted to eat you, I’d have done it on the way over here.”

Perhaps my words came across as threatening for the human cowered again, scurring to the far side of the ledge and pressing its back against the wall. It hid its face between its knees and the human’s face became obscured by the unkempt mop of hair. A low grumble echoed in the confines of my throat. I’d been prepared to break down hostility and aggression. I wasn’t sure how to handle such overpowering fear. My tail lashed and struck the side of the mountain, causing a small rockslide which slid down into the valley below. Perhaps I should eat this one and try again.

Before I gave up, I extended my neck, deciding to get a good sniff of the human. I was not, after all, even sure they were fit for eating. I pulled in draught after draught of air into my long, proud nose. I smelled dirt ingrained deeply into the human and the scent of seeds – perhaps pumpkin – on its hands. Sweat, both fresh and stale was pungently emanating from the rags it wore about its person so that I was filled with the impulse to cleanse it with a good burst of flame. I tried desperately to find something good about this creature, but the stink was almost overpowering. Underneath, however, the skin emanated a sweeter odor, much different than the hot, sulfurous smell of a dragon. It was different too from the scent of a deer, less mossy and softer, more subtle. I inched my neck a bit closer, intrigued. The human only reacted by bundling up tighter, but this only increased my curiosity as it tried to hold in its scent. The tip of my nose was very close by the time I finally detected the human’s gender.
142111211.title: Scenting

choices: He shows tenetive interest in the offer
He's very interested in selling out his people for wealth and status
1421112111.content:
By the harsher scent, I could tell that the human was male. However, the scent of the human male was as meek as a drop of milk diluted in a bucket of water compared to the musk of another male dragon which capable, by pure biology, of filling me with an intense, uncontrollable anger and bloodlust. I felt not the slightest threat from the unfledged male cowering barefoot against the sheer wall of the mountain.

Uncertain of what to do, I withdrew my head. This alone seemed to ease the boy’s sobbing. “Why do you cry so, Human?” I asked because I was honestly confused in regards to his behavior. “I told you I am not going to eat you.”

The young man lifted his head and removed the shoulder length black hair from around his face with a sweep of his hand. The tears left clean tracks down his dirt-stained cheeks. His voice cracked as he spoke, “T-then I’m to become… a slave? T-they do that from t-time to t-t-time. Collect new slaves.”

I deduced instantly that the boy must mean that dragons came over the mountains periodically to collect fresh blood for those dragons who decided to keep slaves in the lands beyond. That was important news in itself. I’d have to figure a way to stop them doing that if this land was to be my new territory… or at least charge them for it. But I’d have time to dwell on that later. I seized the moment, deciding to try to assuage the human’s fears despite the fact that the word “slave” was fairly appropriate for what I’d like him and his people to become. “No, I am not going to take you over the mountains.” I said, trying to avoid the whole ‘slave’ discussion.
