142111211111112211221111112112221112121.content:
The news that Sir Henry had been found dead was not as distressing to me as the place where the Knight had been found. I padded the few steps to the crime scene, following Tobias between the tall trees that I’d relocated and planted myself. I growled softly the entire time. My head was still hurting from my hangover following last night’s party and worse, I had no recollection whatsoever of what had happened immediately following my drunken poem recital. I plodded after the young man as he jogged ahead of me; somehow, I knew where our trail was going to end.

Down the path, Tobias and I walked until we reached its termination in a thickly wooded roundabout, one of several of my possible sleeping places. Between the gently swaying boughs of the pine trees, there lay a nest of red gore. Sir Henry lay dismembered deep in the confines of my very own garden.

Or at least I assumed it was Sir Henry. To my eyes, there was little, if anything left that could possibly identify the corpse which had been spread so thinly over such a large area. I was grateful that my belly was still quite full from the sheep I’d eaten last night. The scent of blood might have elicited a natural response that I’d prefer remain hidden among my human subjects. I gave voice to my first concern. “How do you know this is Sir Henry?” I asked Tobias before we quite reached the others gathered around the bloody scene.

Tobias said quietly, “The head.” His voice was dramatically changed from his casual, usually optimistic tone, the notes flat like lead. He raised an arm slightly and I followed the gesture. “It’s over there, near the trees.”

All I saw was a cloth wrapped and bloodstained bundle at the base of a pine with several people gathered around, gawking at it. I had little need to imagine what lay underneath. A frown collected itself on my face. The gravity of the situation, if in fact, the Knight truly had been slain, was not lost on me, at least in regards to the other humans whom I’d been so involved with of late. If the Knight had been killed in the village, I would have left the affair up to Tobias to deal with, however, this human had been brutally killed while in one of my most intimate and sheltered areas. This was an affront to myself and my property in the least. The thought of other humans mucking about in my private space made me shudder with revulsion, no matter what activities they chose to undertake there. I paused just a moment, was I quite sure that other humans were necessarily involved? “How far has the news spread already?” I asked Tobias.

The young man looked up at me with watery eyes. The skin on his face had changed color again, becoming paler. It was easy to forget just how young Tobias was. “Men were sent to the village the moment he was found. There’s no way this could be kept quiet, Master.”

I lowered my head until the tip of my nose could have brushed Tobias’ shoulder. The breath from my nostrils steamed in the cold, winter air. This was a disaster, no doubt. But did it really concern me? The plans were made after all and all that remained to discuss was the relatively small matter of the tithe to Lord Dominic. This Knight... like the rest of the humans would hardly be expected to have lived more than another few decades. So what if he had died, perhaps being mauled to death by one of the bears in the area. In the grand scope of things, my life and my destiny included, his life meant little. I would shed no tears for the man; in fact, if he hadn’t laid in so many pieces, I might have been tempted to “dispose” of the body myself.

Still... the knight lay dead in one of the deepest parts of my own private garden. There could be unwanted associations made among my subjects if this weren’t handled carefully. Perhaps I should take a more active role in the investigation of Sir Henry’s murder...
142111211111112211221111112112221112121.title: Blackout

1421112111111122112211111121122211121211.content:
No. This affront could not be simply delegated to my inferiors. The fact that the Knight had been brutally slain in one of my private sanctuaries was too much to ignore. I would find the perpetrator of this crime and deliver unto him a Dragon’s vengeance. Ignoring the still-pale Tobias, I stepped forward into the turnabout surrounded by tall pines.

Silently, the humans who had gathered about and were conjecturing about the means and cause of the Knight’s murder gave way before my bulk, driven, undoubtedly by the vibrations they felt in the ground for my heavy, deliberate steps. Extending my neck, I sniffed the pile of gore which constituted the majority of the remains of the Knight. The stench of blood threatened to override all the other scents. I knew, from the few times that I’d stored killed game, that the body was certainly fresh, killed last night at the latest. By my best guess, I would have said that the Knight died in the earlier part of the evening; the smell of the torn guts was already well progressed. I had not seen the head the humans had apparently discovered off to the side, but I knew after a few good sniffs that this was, in fact, Sir Henry. His scent, smokey with whiskey lingering in the sweat, exuded from what remained of the torn clothing. My eye-ridges raised and I snorted into the air. Lowering my head so my nose snuffled against the dirt, I caught the scent of another human. One who I did not know.

The human around me were looking with wide eyes, much like rabbits. Tobias came walking along my body as I sniffed about with my long neck. I returned to him when he placed his hand on my leg. “You seem as if you discovered something, My Lord.”

I growled softly, “The scent of a man. Not Sir Henry and not anyone I’ve met from the village.”

“It must be the murderer!” exclaimed Tobias, announcing my thoughts.

I nodded once, not minding Tobias’ tendency to state the obvious in this case. After a few more steps around the area, I discovered the trail of the stranger leading into the turnabout from between the trees and exiting the same direction. There were no footprints in the area, either human or dragon, for the dark brown soil was set with numerous cobbles to accommodate my weight, but the trail stood out to me nonetheless as if the perpetrator had left a trail of white paint behind.

I looked to the tall trees between which the trail led. I knew each, having excavated each of them, and all the others, from the forest myself. It would be a shame to damage them by forcing my way through, just for the sake of a worthless human murderer. I growled with frustration. “Tobias. Surely, you can smell this man. His odor is very distinct.” I said, my head between the thick pine trunks.

Tobias alone remained near, the rest of the crowd having retreated to the far end of the clearing - a wise decision on their part as my tail was lashing, occasionally striking the ground in my agitation. From where he usually stood to the side of my left shoulder, he said, “I smell nothing but the pine trees... and Sir Henry. I’m sorry but humans can’t follow an invisible trail.”

I was about to take to the air and see if I could at least locate where this stranger had left the estate when Tobias spoke again. “But, My Lord, I do believe that trained dogs can follow a trail of smell as you describe.

I pulled my head out from between the trees, shaking my horns free a a few caught branches. “Hm...” I grumbled, doubtful that humans and their dogs could operate in this fashion. The canine certainly had a capable nose - I’d seen wolves track their prey for miles on end - but the dog could not talk and seemed as likely to chase a chicken as obey a command; I’d discovered this much in my time among the humans. “Regardless, go fetch Richard and a good woodsman. Perhaps the this man left a trail further out in the trees...”

“Right away, Master.” Tobias, the young Knight and the one human I trusted to be a faithful and competent servant, scurried off as quickly as his coating of thick furs would allow.

I left moments later, forcing the humans - the crowd seemed to be growing at an exponential rate despite the fact that this was supposed to be my private garden - to part again for my passage. With the edge of my blade-like tail spur, I scraped the remains of Sir Henry along the ground and flung them wetly off into the trees to the side. “Clean up this mess.” I said to a woman who I knew to be among the staff that now maintained the grounds here. The humans seemed shocked, but the devastated corpse had nothing more to tell me and since it was not fit for eating, it was only a stain dirtying my sleeping area and nothing more.

Instead of heading back to the amphitheater, I took a side trail and walked a spiraling path to another sleeping hollow. I sat on my haunches and opened my mouth, pulling in a drought of cold winter air. It was clean. Using my tail, I scratched at an itch on the back of my neck and stretched my still sore wings; I’d not be flying today if I could help it. What had I been thinking, sleeping on my back! The fact that this murder had happened during the several hours which remained a void in my mind could not be a coincidence. What on earth could have happened that would have prompted this event?

No answer presented itself. I paid minimal attention at best to the human affairs which did not directly affect me. A horrifying thought occurred to me. If I could not recall at all what had happened in those hours, it was possible, however remotely, that I could be somehow involved in the knight’s murder and simply not remember it. I had been so comfortable with the humans last night... perhaps I said something that I oughtn’t have? I shook my head. I was being paranoid. Still, the absence of memory was a new and unsettling experience. My mind made a number of unlikely scenarios to fill those lost hours to torment me. I needed to make sure to limit myself in the future... no more than three barrels of drink on any one evening.

The hastily made promise to myself was soon forgotten as I busied myself about what I should do next with Richard, my head of the militia, hopefully soon to be on the trail of the man whom I’d smelled.

14211121111111221122111111211222112.content:
An Act of War

Baron Crestwell interlaced his fingers, leaning his forearms on the edge of the table as he looked up at the enormous bronze dragon before him. “Lord Dominic was very concerned, to say the least.” He said, speaking of my taking control of the tiny village of Devonshire. “Especially the manner in which you have chosen to handle the situation... It is quite unusual for a dragon is it not?”

I rumbled deeply in my chest and I allowed more smoke to wisp from my nostrils, exhaust from my sulfurous twin fire-bladders at the base of my throat. I spoke casually from my throat, my voice breathy and soft and gave an underhand gesture with my paw. “Perhaps it only seems unusual because your knowledge of dragons is limited. We do tend to be quite... reclusive, when it comes to other races.”

Baron Crestwell grinned like a shark. “I am not sure I would describe it as such... but I do understand what you mean.”

I raised my eyebrows, “And what did Lord Dominic think of my apparent discrepancy in behavior?”

The Baron looked for a few seconds to Sir Kingsley at his left side. When he turned his head forward again, he said, “He thought that it was gracious of you to take the time to learn something of our laws and how we conduct business and diplomacy as well as meeting us equals in the political field. He thought also that you obviously have a benevolent streak as has been made clear by the open support you have obviously garnered among the village commoners and trades-folk. However...” Now the Baron’s voice dropped. “What you have done here by annexing the village of Devonshire cannot be counted less than an act of war against Lyrond.” Lord Thurman placed he meaty palms on the table’s surface, a slight frown on his fat face. The knights to either side gave no response, obviously they’d known the Duke’s instruction ahead of time.

I was careful not to give any obvious reaction, though my wings may have twitched a little in my agitation. The entire point of this exercise had been to prevent war. There was a part of me that imagined dashing the table aside with my tail and charring the plump ambassador to a crisp while flattening each knight beneath my paws. What could the humans do, anyway? Send an army of ants over the mountains? ‘Let them come!’ my dragon-blood screamed. And yet... here these humans were, having traveled this great distance to meet with me. I realized that Baron Crestwell had not specifically stated yet that Lyrond was at war with me yet. I mustered the calm I needed to respond from deep inside, “Hm...” I hummed as I considered the Baron’s words, “And still, Lord Dominic has sent you three here to my territory. He could simply have sent back my messenger if he meant only to make war on me.”

Tobias glanced up at me around his shoulder, but with a look, I sent him turning back into place. Baron Crestwell cupped his hands together. “Very prescient of you, Lord Ladonius. The Duke of Lyandar wishes to settle this dispute without further bloodshed. You have some idea of the resources we would need to devote to remove a fully grown dragon from an area as remote as this, I think?”

I snorted a cloud, oily and black. “I think I do.” I said deeply, some of my normal voice coming through.

Raising his eyebrows, Baron Crestwell shrugged, grinning plainly. “That is why we would like to spend the time that we will be inevitably trapped here discussing alternatives to open warfare between our two kinds.”

I looked away, studying the sea of faces on the tiers around me, taking in the discussion with almost complete silence. “You mean between your kind and me.” I said, “I can assure you that I acted independently.”

“Whatever the case may be,” said the Baron, “You have extended courtesy towards us and while my Lord cannot accept your proposal out of hand, he has invested in me and my companions power to grant a certain number of compromises; one of which, I hope, you will find acceptable.” Lord Thurman gestured with a thick arm to the papers resting on the table.

Before the human spoke again, I raised a claw, my curved talons pointing skyward. Why hadn’t I planned for this? I had thought that by setting my claim in the way that humans did, I would resolve this matter quickly. Was this hardly civilized valley really that important to the rest of Lyrond? They certainly had done nothing as far as I knew to curb the casual predation of dragons on the area. It seemed natural just to let me have it, just as a young dragon might claim a small area on the edge of an older dragon’s territory or between two adjacent territories. It usually wasn’t worth the trouble of dislodging them... as long as they didn’t overstep their bounds. I wished that I had time alone to speak to Tobias. Perhaps he had learned something in the larger city that would prove useful to me. I said after opening the pause, “Let us reopen this business after dinner. The matter will settle easier on us all with full, comfortable stomachs.”

I seemed to have said the right thing. Baron Crestwell smiled widely, clapping a hand on the table, “Splendid idea, my Lord!” The waiters came rushing forward unbidden, having been waiting for this moment. In just a twinkling, the table was loaded high with food, the mugs refilled with local beer. As for me, the roast pig, with only a few choice cuts removed was brought out steaming on a long wooden board. The entrails were missing, but otherwise, it was simply delicious.

142111211111112211221111112112222.content:
I studied Baron Crestwell’s features far longer than I usually spent examining a new human’s body shape and odor. Particularly, I lingered on the man’s face. It was scarred from battle, that much was obvious, but I had never seen the sort of wound before. The skin on the left side of his face was dark and thickened with scar tissue, especially about the neck. However, there were no gashes or cuts as if from a blade, it was obviously some sort of burn, but not such as I’d seen before and I had some experience with what fire was capable of doing to living flesh. For one thing, despite being an old scar, it was quite irregular, especially for flame, being pot-marked with divots and small craters, stained black in the center. I thought that it must have been excruciatingly painful, whatever sort of phenomenon had done that damage. Automatically, my dragon instinct told me to yield the human some measure of respect. Scarred dragons were not shunned in our society – such as it was, most dragons preferring a solitary existence or just the company of their mate – rather, their scars were often as badges of honor, making the dragon in question distinct and memorable as well as providing testament that said dragon had faced adversity and triumphed. Baron Crestwell had obviously seen some hardship in his past. As my eyes slid down, I noticed that emerging from the left sleeve of his simple, black attire was not a hand but a curved, three-pronged hook. The Baron’s own expression was severe as he studied my expansive form, but his eyes were softer perhaps.

“It is a pleasure to meet the delegate from Lord Dominic.” I rumbled softly. I’d grown used to speaking from my throat because when I spoke clearly, the sound was usually overpowering for a human in my direct presence. Besides, Tobias had related to me that the breathy softness of my quiet voice was at once disarming in its mildness and intimidating in its mysterious otherworldliness.

The Baron emerged from his bow and stood as the Knights to his side bowed and introduced themselves. Both Knights were taller than the Baron between them though not nearly as wide. Sir Henry was a younger man, though still clearly much older than my Tobias. He was blonde with blue eyes and a strong jaw. He spoke with an accent that I hadn’t heard before, but I basically nodded and agreed with what he said as I quickly attempted to decipher yet another alien presentation of the slave tongue. Sir Kingsley was the oldest of the three. He sported grey streaked brown hair proudly with a long, well brushed beard. When he spoke, his voice was clear and methodical despite his tobacco stained teeth. Sir Kingsley was quiet, and therefore dangerous. Though both men were dressed in clothing, they each had decorated swords at their sides to indicate their status.

After the introductions, a table was brought forth for the delegates as well as chairs. I continued to lounge easily on my side, occasionally stretching a leg when I wanted to remind my guests that I was more than just my animated head on my long, bronze-scaled neck. With a twitch of my finger, I invited Tobias to sit on my wrist, but my servant declined silently, remaining standing instead. Could it be that my young majordomo did not want to appear childlike in front of the important men? Perhaps he had grown up during the months he’d been away.

Somehow procuring a leather scroll case, Tobias popped off the lid and removed none other than my proclamation of sucession. It was only a little worse for wear as the young man smoothed it out over the table’s surface. A waiter decanted wine for the three men from a silver pitcher as Baron Crestwell removed several a sheaf of other documents from his robes, carefully untying the leather thong that bound them and exhibiting an incredible deftness with his prosthetic.

Tobias caught me eyeing the goblets of the men at the table, the bouquet rising from their contents intrigued me. However my servant delivered terrible news. “My Lord, I regret to say that we broke open the last cask of Sir Ronald’s wine for this occasion. I don’t think there would be enough left to more than wet your tongue.”

“That’s fine, Tobias. I’ve never had wine anyway.”

Sir Henry lifted his head from the Baron’s shifting of documents. “What is this? Are you saying that you’ve never had a drop of the shine before?” I gave the barest shake of my head. The Knight pushed his goblet away. “Then I shall not imbibe where our host cannot.” Sir Henry looked across the table to his counterpart. Sir Kingsley looked up at my, my scaled head rising over the table and then back to his glass. He pushed his away as well. Baron Crestwell was left to the last, but he did not bother to move his goblet. However, he had not reached for it when it was presented, nor did he resist or offer any sign of discontent when it was removed, so I was left uncertain whether the man had even intended to drink, let alone how he felt about sacrificing his portion for his dragon host.

Sir Henry smiled and looked to Tobias despite the Baron’s ambilivance. He gestured with a hand to the three large goblets. “See if you can mix these with whatever is left of the barrel. Surely we there will be a thimbleful left for Lord Ladonius.” Tobias was quick to move. When his goblet had been taken away, Sir Ronald lowered his head and muttered, “What a life… forever sober. Must be hell.”

I cocked my head oddly as I looked down at the younger Knight. “I wouldn’t know the difference.” I confessed.

Sir Henry snorted and raised a finger, “Which is exactly my point.”

Tobias returned toting a small cauldron which sloshed gently with its contents as the young man walked smoothed back to us. As Tobias moved, I heard hushed conversation from the tiers around us. It had already gotten around that the dragon was to have his first taste of alcohol. I didn’t know why it was such a big deal. True to Sir Henry’s words, the cauldron was little more than a thimble to me. Still, I’d seen Richard often enough in his moments of weakness, his stumbling, and his slurring of speech. I wondered if the tiny concoction could possibly have the same effect on me. I was suddenly apprehensive about the whole matter. What if my thoughts were clouded, just when the discussion of Devonshire’s future was about to be opened in a matter that would either so completely succeed or fail that the delegates left immediately, or far more likely, would stretch on through all the long months of winter. Sir Henry looked at me expectantly as the cauldron with the village’s last store of wine was delivered. I lifted it from Tobias’ grasp gently between my short thumb and first finger. I sniffed it again and was amazed at the complexity of the odor, which, unlike Lord Thurman’s hostile concoction of colognes blended together harmoniously, almost like the wine was singing to my nose. I swirled it a bit and them emptied the contents onto my tongue.

143.content:
As a dragon, you are the most noble of all beasts so it is only natural that others should bow before you. In fact it should be an honor to serve you and you can swiftly teach others this simple truth; in fact, out right worship might not be out of the question.

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon are you?

The Sky-Swallower: So named because when you take to the air, your wings seem to swallow the sky to lesser earth-bound mortals. An enormous breed of dragon, your strength is matched only by the Juggernaut, and your sheer size by none. You and your kin have often been mistaken for small hills while you lay dormant in hibernation. You bulk is such that it can literally flatten a small village under it. All that bulk means a big appetite, however, so big in fact, that you have to spend the majority of your year in a state of hibernation to conserve energy. But the more food you can get your giant claws on, the less time you have to spend sleeping and the more time you can spend chasing down loot!

The Screeching Ridgeback: As a rare kind of social dragon, what you lack in brute strength, size and speed, you make up with an ability to cooperate with your fellows. Growing up in a mountain colony, you learned that while individual strength is important, you also learned how to be a team player. Of course, you yourself aren't satisfied with being in the background are you? Otherwise you wouldn't have a story to tell! You don't breathe fire, but instead can emit a piercing screech that will travel for miles and allows long distance communication with others of your kind. At close range, the decibels you can generate are disabling and potentially fatal for humanoids. Larger dragons might be more trouble but you can certainly disorient them and who knows what you can accomplish by working together?

The Seraphan: A more majestic breed of dragon you will have difficulty finding on the planet than the Saraphen. However, this breed of dragon is almost never glimpsed by earth-bound mortals. The sky to a Saraphan is more than a convenient way to get around, it is there one and true home. The average Saraphan, in fact, only touches the ground when it dies; they are born, live and breed all in the soaring heights above the clouds. Though it may be rumor, some Saraphen are said to grow to magnificent sizes, such that their wings from tip to tip would cover an entire estate. What is not rumor, however, is the clear fact that for their size, the Saraphen weigh extremely little, able to float on the breezes as the feathers that cover their bodies. You might wonder what it is that you eat if you never set your clawed feet on the ground, well the answer also lies in the sky for unlike any other dragon, you feed off the glory of the sun herself and in the distant heights above the clouds, you never have a want for food. Always a stunning, glowing white, a Saraphan is a glorious specimen of dragonkind sporting not one but two pairs of feathered wings, in fact, most of your kind tend to look down on other dragons who spend only part of their time in the sky and rarely ever enter into your lofty domain. As for other beings… well, have you ever paused in your stride to avoid stepping on an ant? I didn’t think so. While not truly aggressive, a Saraphan will never back down from a proper challenge, attacking with their claws, complete mastery of flight and vastly superior speed. Also, the Sarahen tend to hold grudges as well as the angels to which they are often compared. There is no getting off their shit-list once a Saraphan has decided that you have wronged them.

144211.content:
There are tales within these lands of creatures large and small, terrible and innocent. Yet of all those tales none compare to the tales of the dragons of these mountainous hills which you call your home. Many of the tales were crafted around you and your presence as you would blot out the sky of the small human villages that lived within the shadows of these mountains.

Many of these villages consider you a threat and a danger due to your size and the fact that you require so much to keep your magnificent body in shape. However there are a few that see you as a blessing and that your presence is a sign from the gods that they are protected from what ever evils roam the lands.

Neither of them were wrong as true you have an previous years wiped out entire human villages in an attempt to stave of death from hunger. And you have as well driven out other dragons who wished to take your territory and other smaller creatures which posed a threat to your hunting grounds which some of the human villages happened to lie within (though you would never tell them that).

So regardless of any action you might do you always had "Visitors" who either wanted your head or some favor from you. Though it was neigh impossible to find you thanks to your hide blending in so well with the world around you while you hibernated. They somehow always managed to find you when you waked which was exactly what was about to happen today.
144211.title: Short History of Your Life

choices: Accept their offer assume the title of "Lord"
Decline their offer to many unkowns
1442112.content:
Your home the ancient range of mountains known to human's as Kinguard was one of the few places left to be truly mapped out as none alive had the resources or patience to map out its entirety. Yet what was known of Kinguard was that it was immense covering so much of land so as to act as a natural barrier between the northern and southern kingdoms and only had one single point of "safe" travel between the two. With safe being a relative term considering that the trail leading threw the mountains was always swept away by rock slides and avalanches and constantly under the predations of the unsavory side of civilization. But there was one safe place among the path between the mountains the city of Cragslaid, a city built into the walls of the mountain with walls stretching between the large gap between the eastern and western portion of the Kinguard mountains. Cragslaid has long withstood the test of time and has constantly passed threw many hands with none holding claim to it for longer then it took another to take it. Yet now was a "calm" cycle for Cragslaid as none were openly trying to claim it.

However as for you. You lived in one of the many valley's and long having already staked your claim for it several centuries prior and have lived there for the majority of your adult life. Your valley used to be an untamed jungle filled with prized hunting the likes of which you couldn't complain about. Yet now it has become the home of several humanoid villages you have tried the best you can to simply leave them be yet due to the nature of humanoids to be fearful of that which they do not know. Many of them have tried to remove your presence some even to the point where their whole village had gathered arms against you. Yet even with their combined might they would still fail and thus several of the villages have been removed from your valley by your own claws.

But not all of them feared you as you have on countless times saved several villages from dangers where they could not handle. Thus you had earned they're respect and in some cases love. Many of them have already asked you to move from your lofty home in the mountains to stay within the valley which you gave a quick refusal you simply couldn't bear to loose the lofty spot you had claimed as it provided you a view of your whole valley.

As you woke you noticed that it was now midday and as you stretched you couldn't help but look out over your valley. You could make out every human settlement within your valley and tell which had expanded and which had simply abandoned their homes to join another of the villages as they left their previous one to simply return to the jungle a fact which you very much appreciated. Opening your wings you readied to take flight and take your fill so to keep your massive frame moving taking in the scenery before you closing your eyes then leapt from where you were and fell towards the ground below feeling the wind rush by. Then pulling up you could feel as your entire body adjusted from the drop to the sudden leveling out. Gliding you looked for something to eat and found what you were looking for. Letting a tooth filled grin settle upon your face you swooped down as you grabbed four large wild boars they would keep you going for the next couple of days. After eating your meal you returned to your flight above the valley keeping a watchful eye over all within it, even the ungrateful ones that would hate and fear you regardless of anything you told them otherwise.

As you flew by one of the villages which was now growing into a well developed city you noticed them cry out not in fear or terror at the sight of you but actually in praise and joy.

"Ah the Melurians it would seem they have prospered in the few months I have hibernated." you thought to your self flying by them dipping a wing to show you had heard them

Yet not wishing to waste your energy you returned to your home up in the mountains where you saw a rather peculiar sight. A small band of humans had braved the journey up the mountains to see you curios as to their intent you landed slowly and gracefully so as to not blow them away but so that you could also impress them. After all who didn't enjoy a little praise?

"And to what do I owe the honor of this visit?" you asked your deep voice rumbled threw the mountain side as the humans bowed the looked up again

"Oh great and honorable one!" shouted one of the humans as if you couldn't hear him

"We have come to you beseeching a favor!" he cried out

"A favor? And how many times do I have to tell you that you don't have to keep calling me 'Oh Great and Honorable one'? Use my name already will you I promise it wont offend me." you sigh shaking your head at their use of that title

"Uhm... Very well then. Lord Martelus we have come here seeking a favor from you!" The human shouted saying your name though still adding in a title which still annoyed you to a small extent but no where near as much as the previous.

"Very well and what exactly is this favor you seek from me?" you ask laying your head down in front of them as you laid down so as to hear his request

"Lord Martelus our city has reached the point where if it were to reach any larger it would actually come to the attention of the lords outside of your valley." the man informed you

"So just spread your people out there are abandoned villages scattered threw out this valley." you informed him

"My Lord I don't think it will be as simple as you think it might be. For even if we do spread out there will still be the influx of more people coming to your valley which will still draw the attention of the lords out side of it." the human said speaking up

"Again seriously use my name. And what of them? I have no quarrel with them if they seek to take my home from me I shall show them the folly of their ways." you said lifting your head looking out over your valley

"Lord Martelus if the Lords outside this valley take attention of it they will see it without a ruling Lord and seek to add it to their domain. For I know that you do not have use of the materials within this valley but many of them are very valuable to the lands outside and will cause quite a stir to claim them." the human informed you

"So name one of your own as a lord then if it so pleases you." you almost yelled back understanding where this was heading and truly not liking it

"We would Lord Martelus yet it seemed right to give you the chance to assume the title of "Lord" over our city and the other cities within the valley as you were the first one here and have been a major influencing power in each of their developments." the human said repeating that which you already knew

"And why would you and the other cities be so willing to have "me" a nonhuman be your Lord especially since most of the other cities aren't especially happy that I live so close to them?" you asked him trying to figure out why they would ask you to do something that any human would leap at the chance for

"Lord Martelus again you have shaped our lives since we have settled here. You have settled disputes between our cities that seemed to be unsolvable and have defended us numerous times from dangers. How many of our kind do you know of that can claim to have done the same?" the human asked

"What is your name human?" you asked facing him bringing your head yards from his face

"M.. my name is Rizthovk." he stated gulping as your head completely filled his vision

"Very well then Rizthovk. I shall think upon your request and shall give you my answer upon a weeks time. Where upon I shall visit you city Meluria and inform you of my choice. Now leave you have given me much to think upon Rizthovk" you said retracting you head and returning to look out upon your valley

"Very well then Lord Martelus we shall await your arrival in a weeks time." Rizthovk said bowing with the rest of his fellows before departing.

As the humans departed your mind was set a buzz as you went over all the possibilities of being a "Lord" over a size able human settlement if the size of your valley was anything to go by. You would be in charge of one of the largest independent city states within the Kinguard mountain's. Yet that would also make you a bigger target to all the other dragons in the mountains who seeked such promising lands such as your own as well as the wrath of any human lord who found an offense to you a dragon ruling over humans.

But then again you could increase your already sizable hoard which you had stashed away within the mountains where none but you knew where it was located. Not to mention the foods that could be prepared for you on a call! Sure Boar and Xlith tasted great raw but the human's seemed to captured and increase their flavors ten fold when they 'cooked' it. That alone made your mouth water at the prospect, noticing that dusk had arrived you set out one last time to find and capture one last meal before you took a brief nap.
1442112.title: Your Lordship?!

choices: Later, bring more dragons into your operation
14421121.content:
Deciding to think upon the matter you decided to fly outside of your valley to take a look at the world around to try and get an idea of what was happening in the world. Needles to say your flight did not go unnoticed by those that also lived in the Kinguard mountains ensuring that no potential rivals would try to claim your valley in your absence you made sure to stop by some of your friends who lived close by. Though close was a relative term to dragons as anything that could be cover in a days flight as your territory. And considering how much you could cover in a single day your territory would in effect cover quite a bit of land. So any communication between you and your friends was actually quite rare in human terms was actually rather often for a dragon however it still did well to at least give them a fair warning that you would be crossing into their territory soon which you had done by giving a loud enough roar that would be sure to reach them wherever they were at that moment and have them come flying to intercept you.

You waited at the edge of your territory and that of your friends standing there waiting you turned your head to get a good look at the surroundings as it never hurt to observe the area around you. About an hour after giving the warning you noticed several figures approaching in the distance from the southern side came a wing of brown green and various other colored dragons that would be your Ridgeback friend Corlus and what you guessed were a small group of his friends from their clan. From the northern side came two green dragons that flew in a tight cluster your "friend" Gelna' Melsa the twins with a bond that allowed them to pretty much read the other mind and know what the other was doing. Though you always had trouble trying to talk to either one of them they had to issue and were understanding of the difficulty most dragons had when talking to them.

"Hello Corlus nice to see you again." you said nodding your head towards him and his fellows

"It's a pleasure to see you again Martelus it has been how long since you visited?" Corlus asked with a smile

"It has been a while hasn't it?" you said agreeing "Ah Gelna' Melsa it's a pleasure to see you two again." you said bowing to the two sisters

"Hello Martelus." they answered in unison

"So why are you crossing threw our territories Martelous?" asked the twins

"Ah to business then? Very well then. Believe it or not those humans who decided to call my valley their home have decided to try and name me their 'ruler' so they don't have to deal with some lord from the lands outside the valley." you told them after all if you couldn't trust your friends then who can you trust?

"You have to be joking right?" asked Corlus

"I think he's serious Corlus. He's not making any of his usual movements when he's joking." the twins said amazed

"I know I thought it was a joke as well but they were genuinely serious about it believe it or not. And then I got thinking that if I turned them down and those lords from outside the valley found an interest in them, I would never hear the end of it as they would constantly try to conquer them and attempt to push me out of my own territory. And we all know that when humans work together even they can over power a dragon. So I want to avoid such a possibility and need to learn just what is going on in the world outside our mountains." you told them looking to each

"Well Martelous you always wanted to be the ruler of something here's your chance. But do you really think this is a smart idea? I mean there are so many things involved with ruling are you sure your up to the task?" asked Corlus it was a genuine question after all he was the clan leader of his clan of Ridgebacks

"I believe so after all it cant be that hard can it? I mean come on their humans not orc's or troll's they can think for themselves. And any reason for me to even get involved in their affairs would be if something dire were to happen." you said not truly worried about this ruler job as you probably should have been

"Maybe Martelous but remember this your going to have more challengers for your lands soon then as well and they aren't going to be just from humans. But from other dragons as well, sure you might be able to fend them off but what about their damages to those under your charge? Being in charge means more then simply being able to insert yourself at the right moment or being able to diffuse situations between those under your care. You also have to ensure their safety, which you cant always provide and you know it after all you do have to hibernate for a time and during which challengers will come and wreak havoc amongst your charges." Corlus pointed out

"Well then I guess I would just have to ensure that they are capable to hold their own should they need to defend themselves I guess." you said actually not having thought of having to defend them full time a role you knew you wouldn't be able to fill as you hibernated not only to conserve your energy but to also allow the valley to reproduce and replace the creatures you would consume to keep yourself up and mobile.

"Look Martelous I am not going to stop you from becoming the "Lord" over the humans in your valley but I would strongly suggest you consider finding someone to help you defend it." Corlus finished giving you a look of all seriousness

"And what of you Gelna' Melsa? Any words of wisdom from you two?" you asked jokingly

"Yes, actually we do." They answered in unison as you cringed inwardly "Seeing as how your valley is quite large you might want to consider actually finding a way to get message between one side to the other otherwise you'll find yourself bogged down with request's to get word moved between places of contact." they said

"That it?" you asked hopeful

"Yes, we suggest you heed Corlus warning and advice. And we believe we might have an idea on how to address it yet it would probably be best for you to hear it after your trip to the human lands." they suggested

Very well then anything else?" you asked

"Nope" they answered in unison

"Alright then Corlus if it is alright with you I will go threw you territory to the southern human lands." you asked with a nod towards Corlus

"Yes, it is alright just please be mindful of the young ones they have yet to see one of your kind Martelous and will probably be more then a little curious." Coruls said with a laugh

"Well then I had best be off thank you you two for your advice shall we meet here in about a weeks time?" you asked them

"Certainly" Corlus said

"Definitly" replied Gelna' Melsa

And with that you all separated with Corlus returning to his clan and the twins to whatever they did. You traveled south visiting the human lands to the south and finding them in a relative state of peace as they seemed more focused on other things that you were not a part of. Though what you did notice was that the humans and other humanoid creatures like elves dwarves and some places orc's actually worked together. And in even rarer cases you saw your fellow dragons working with humanoids inside vast cities which made your valley look small in comparison and it was small by no stretch of the word. Yet you got the general impression that it might be a good idea to allow other dragons to live within your territory, if only to provide protection in the form of numbers yet you highly doubted you would have to worry about defending your valley from harm yet. However you did not put the idea out of your head and made a note to tell Corlus of a plan you had hatched in your head which Corlus had no doubt had a hand in planting in your head when you meet him at the start of your little journey.

Regardless you flew back to the Kinguard mountains after having made a few new friends in the lands to the south. Traveling threw the mountains you crossed threw Corlus's territory again went threw Gelna' Melsa's territory to the lands in the north. In the northern lands I found about the same thing as I did in the south only the humanoids were less cooperative with each other yet still seemed to heed their dragon allies. And after my visit there I decided to return to my home and give Rizthovk the answer he was waiting for so badly.

Meluria wasn't to terribly big of a city yet however it had the makings of one and already the signs that the city was growing and rapidly were evident to all who cared to notice. Yet they would go about their day's working as they normally did yet when you appeared above and blotted out the sky of their city all work halted as you gracefully lowered yourself to the ground listening to their praise. Ah what a wonderful sound you could get used to this! Thus when Rizthovk came out to greet you you gave him an answer finally.

"I have considered and thought over your offer Rizthovk. And I am pleased to tell you and all your people that I accept your offer as "Lord" over the human cities in this valley." you said with a serious tone

Needles to say they're reaction was quite predictable yet not unfounded. And you couldn't help but find yourself smiling as well when everyone began to cheer and celebrate.

.....

"Congratulations 'Lord' Martelous"
14421121.title: Greeting the Negihbors

choices: Just how many years have passed?

144211211.content:
The celebration itself lasted threw most of the night and well into the next day as almost all the inhabitants showed to celebrate. Though whether they were genuinely 'happy' that their new ruling power was a dragon or just simply playing the part. Was actually something rather difficult to distinguish thanks to something the humans called alcohol which seemed to make things happier to whoever consumed it which you did and in the amounts that would have killed a normal human. However when everything was said and done you were officially named the ruler over the cities and villages within your valley which the humans now called Fangoath seeing as you had never really thought of giving your valley a name previously always going by the name of valley easily accepted the new name for it.

Once the ceremony was completed everyone spent the next day recovering while you spent it flying threw Fangoath to see just exactly how many human cities were actually within your valley. And to your surprise there were actually quite a few of them that were well on their way to reaching the size of which Meluria was.

"It would seem there are more of these humans then I had originally thought." you thought to yourself flying over one of the cities below

You were reaching the other side of your valley when you heard the heads up yell coming from Corlus’s direction. Turning you headed to meet Corlus and speak with him and Gelna’ Melsa about a plan that would increase all our territories while providing us each with something we severely lacked. Both Corlus and the twins were already waiting for you talking with each other as you landed in front of them.

“By that look upon your face it would seem you accepted and have been coming to know your people?” asked the twins

“Yes I have.” You answered here

“Well then have you considered what we said last we spoke?” Corlus asked

“Yes I have. And after taking my quick trip to visit the human lands out side of our mountains I have to say there is Corlus not taking your idea seriously would be worse then reckless. The humans and dragons have learned to actually work together and built cities the size of which not even I could stand against.” You admitted which was something not most dragons did admitting something was stronger then them

“So then you’re going to do something about keeping your people safe so how are you going to go about doing it?” Corlus asked a smile barely creeping up onto his face

“Corlus if you weren’t my friend I would swear you were trying to manipulate me. But however as it is yes I do have a plan and I would like for you both to come visit me in my territory so I can better discuss it with not only you but with the others as well. Trust me this is going to make all of us very happy in the end.” You said with a smile

About a month later found you with several other dragons gathered within your territory sure there were a few high strung tensions as some still held grudges or dislikes for another yet none were willing to attack under one of the ancient draconic rites which you had invoked upon inviting each of them. The rite itself demanded that any and all hatred be put aside for a time being so that any gathering of dragons could work together towards a common goal. And those that did not observe it were to be considered outcast of draconic society as a whole. So gathered before you were gathered many different types of dragons. There were Corlus’s Screeching Ridgebacks as well as Gelna’ Melsa and several other Geminate Drake’s that they knew. But there were also several Fire Lord Dragons, Earth-Render’s, Regal Bronze’s, and Mountain Shadow’s gathered as well and after what seemed like an eternity of greetings things finally got into motion.

“Now then I know you all know the reason I have asked you to come here under one of our sacred rites as dragons. But I would like to share an idea with all of you that will be beneficial to all of us.” You said loud enough for all to hear

“For the last several centuries we have all managed to live with each other with relative peace. And have also done so with some of the younger races that also inhabit these mountains however what I propose will change all that.” You said looking at all of them

“Recently I took a trip and visited the human lands to the south and to the north and saw how they had banded together with the other races including our fellow dragons in grand cities that would be able to outstrip all of us alone.” You informed them and as you had expected many of them were already arguing that was not possible and untrue and many variations of disagreement

“Now I know certainly none of us is glad to hear such news however must take a closer look at what their joining together actually means as a whole. For one with the cooperation of so many races together in one place they are able to accomplish things far more easier then they would on their own. For example Trazja I know for a fact you and your flight have fallen upon hard times where the subject of food is required. However within these cities the humans and other younger races work together and provide vast amounts of food for their dragon counterparts.” You said nodding towards the rather diminutive Fire Lord

Trazja seemed rather agitated at your mentioning of a problem he could not settle on his own Yet he didn’t say anything as though he was agitated by that he was still impressed at the thought of food able to sustain him and his flight, as the area they lived in wasn’t really the best of hunting locations. And there were several other dragons as well who shared the same plight which was inevitably why there were so many disputes for territory with prime hunting grounds.

“However such benefits such as food enough to keep your families feed do not come cheap or easily for even those cities had dangers they faced. Yet even there the benefits of working with the younger races showed threw. For though the dragons provided much of the strength and backing of their military the younger races provided them with armor to ensure that no weapon could even come close to scratching their hides. And even better still there were members of the younger races that also volunteered to be apart of their military and protect their city along side their draconic allies.” You informed them looking towards the gathered dragons to them the thought of making their already impregnable hides even stronger simply filled most of their ego's. Yet there were still a few things that needed to be addressed as well as a few others that needed to be convinced before any would agree to anything.

"There was also one thing I noticed about these cities where both dragons and the younger lived races were able to share with their combined might and intelligence. They were also able to provide the kind of protection for their own that we as hatchling's could only dream of! Imagine being able to raise your family from tiny hatchling's to full grown adults and not have to worry about having anything threatening their safety. Our children would be raised to know all that we know given every chance possible to reach their fullest potential. Where you can also can become that old wyrm who has seen not only his childrens children. But also their children's children and you would be there to see them grow from the young hatchling to the adult that would make any parent proud." you told them already you could see many of the gathered females eye's glow at the prospect at being able to raise a family when ill fated seasons had wiped out entire nests of unhatched hatchling's or with the bold scavengers sneaking off with the young eggs. Or worse the other creatures that lived within the mountains that preyed upon the young dragons as well. That in itself was enough to win over a majority of the gathered dragons yet you sensed there were still a few who you knew wanted some way to increase their already exorbitantly sized hordes

"And lastly the revenue from working with the younger lived races would be as such that you would be barely able to count any of it within your life time." you said with a knowing smile looking at the few who you knew to be out for nothing more then the treasure and loot making them rather easy to control with a price

"So what say you all? Any against this idea please give your voice now." you asked looking at the gathered dragon's and were surprised when none made any noise

"All in favor of?" you asked tilting your head slightly and were taken back by the sudden chorus of resounding "AYE!" from the gathered dragons before you. So with a smile you looked upon all those gathered before you and gave one resounding bugle which the others followed suite making the sound carry forever onwards threw the mountains telling all that a new power had emerged and was willing to face the coming hardships together as one.

The next several years went by with a blur as you and your fellow dragons worked together with the humans and various other inhabitants of the Kinguard mountains that inhabited the now newly formed territory known as "Yurith" with the capital being Meluria inside your valley Fangoath correction it was no longer just your valley but also that of every dragon that inhabited Yurith as well as that of the humans, elves, dwarves and orc's and any other race that had the capacity to realize that refusal to join meant their being cast out of Yurith. But one thing was for certain you had created something that would undoubtedly succeed you long after you had joined the ancestors.
144211211.title: Founding the Future

1442112111.content:
Over the next fifty years it took all the combined efforts of all the dragons within the newly made Yurith to convince all the other race's that lived within its lands to join and make Yurith an contendable state to match the other kingdoms outside the Kinguard Mountains. Somehow though all the seperate races of human dwarf elf and Orc were brought together to work together on a common ground. Of course it wasnt all peace and flowers even after the agreement as many simply choose to work on their own ignoreing the others. So it was inevitable that the arise of discord and unrest was so prevelant within the first years of Yuriths founding.

Many such trouble spots was between the elves and dragons as one or the other could not stand the other. The elves unable to stand dragons being superior to them in just about everything and would always bend and break the laws of established magical theory by thery very pressence. While some dragons just couldnt stand the vainity cursed elves that seemed to want just a little more power and had threw ages past used parts of slain dragons to achive their ends even for such trivial a task such as flying! And those were just the tip of the crimes commited against dragon kind that the elves had done and that was only to adult dragons never mind the children or hatchlings or eggs! So it was to no small concession that any of the dragons had agreed to allow the elves into Yurith rather then simply pursuing them and crushing them from exsistance for past wrongs.

True there were hot spots all over with Humans and Orc's or Dwarves and merchents yet none were as explosive as one encounter between the elves and dragons as that which happened barely five years after the agreement of all races within Yurith to work together and put past greviencies behind them. For an rather sizeable community of elves living within Yuriths many mountainous trails had attacked and captured a dragon against all agreed rules and regulations as had been agreed upon by even their leaders. Needles to say many of the dragons were not happy and demmanded retribuition of the elves who had disregarded the agreement.

So in an attempt to reduce tensions to a more tolerable level and to prevent any further blood shed then had already occured. You flew to the offending community of elves with Corlus and the twins Gelna' Melsa as aide should anything go amiss which you hoped didnt yet you couldnt shake the feeling that before this event was said and done some one's blood would be stainning the ground before long.

"So whats the plan Martelus?" Asked Gelna

"Simple go in go in demand the release of the captured dragon and an make sure that those responsible are held accountable." Melsa said with an agitated growl

"No Melsa we cannot simply go in and demand we need to confront and talk to them and resolve this peacefully there cannot be anymore blood shed!" Corlus said staring at the two

"Actually we are going to have to do both ensure the freedom of the captured dragon and the transfer of the offending elves into custody so that they can be given a fair hearing back in Meluria all while ensuring we do not cause the spilling of any blood." you told them

"Just have to go the hard path dont you Martelus?" asked Gelna

"Yep and I am glad to have you three with me." you said with a smile

"There that should be where the elves are located at." you said nodding to a plateu on the side of a mountain where there was a forest and smoke coming out of it.

"Looks like it the scouts said they spotted the elves here previously."Corlus said taking note of their location

"Well now that we know where the elves are where's the dragon?" you asked yourself looking all over for him

"Maybe you can ask those elves when we land." Melsa said as you closed in on the plateu

The next several minutes went by in a blur as you and Corlus and Gelna' Melsa were suddenly hit with a massive hail storm that had gale force winds and were beginning to batter everyone's wings. Gelna' Melsa were almosted tossed into the mountain side by the strength of the winds but seeing their being tossed around you put you massive size and large wings to make a sort of wind breaker for them to stabilize while Corlus flew to your other side so that you all formed a wedge. Landing on a spot close to the plateu you noticed that the storm itself seemed to be increasing in ferocity and if it didnt pass soon even you would not be able to resist the winds that it had caused.

"Into that cave!" you roared over the screaming winds as you pointed out a hole in the mountain side As all three of you rushed into it you noticed you wouldnt be able to fit into it due to your size.

Well atleast I can make a great door stop you thought to yourself rushing to the cave and hoping that the side of you left out in the storm didnt get to badly injured

Once everyone was in and you had your body jammed against the entrance were glad you had grown some over the last few years. As you had grown into quite the dragon as you were now as long as twelve house's from head to tail with a wing span nearly double that, while standing taller then a five story buidling at the shoulder.

Your Stone Grey scales were harder then any rock found within the Kinguard mountains and impervious to just about any form of physical attack. Magic had little effect over your magic resistant scales as nothing short of a major spell would manage to get threw them. Yet even that was not enough to keep the cold at bay as though your body kept the cold from getting in to the cave you were still exposed to the freezeing winds.

"Some one make a fire quickly other wise i'm going to freeze" you asked looking at the other three

The twins looked at each other and nodded and breathed a small flame of green over your body that didnt hurt yet still kept you warm.

"There that should see you threw the storm." Gelna said with a smirk

"Great roasted dragon. Get some rest hopefully the storm passes tomorrow and we can continue to those elves." you said looking to them for an agreement which they did

"Sont-ils allés?" asked an elf from one of the trees

"La tempête a dû les effrayer mieux avertir les anciens." answered another elf from the ground below the tree

"Venez nous laisser ici." said the elf on the ground as both elves left the edge of the forest to head in deeper to the woods

145.content:
Power... You yearn for it and yet at the same time it is a terrible burden. Who can tell friends and foes apart nowadays? Your rule must be solitary and your very name enough to strike fear into those whose bodies your clawed feet tred upon. Fear is your only ally.

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon will you be?

The Deathwing: These dragons have a sinister appearance with their elongated snouts, huge horns and the spikes at their knees and shoulders. A fleshy ruff around the face can create a presentation that will stop a man's heart cold in fear. But more fearsome is their reputation for ruthlessness and guile. Muscular, but not brawny, quick, but with enough weight to get the job done, these intelligent creatures are the objects of horrible fairy tales and superstitions the world over. And that suits them just fine. Always solid black, you are a hunter of the night and while you can see into the blackest abyss, your eyes are sensitive to bright lights without the time to acclimate. A single sharp prong for stabbing exists at the end of your long, elegant tail.

The Fire-Lord: You are a bit scrawny for a typical dragon and almost half the normal size standing at a mere nine feet at the shoulder. None dare mock your skinny frame or over-sized wings however as the bulbous sacs to either side of the base of your neck contain liquid, molten death. With your breath weapon, you can lay waste to your foes from afar, but be careful, even your supply of fire isn't indefinite. Those huge flames sacs take a lot of nutrition to sustain, however, giving you an appetite equal to a quite large dragon. Elaborate coat markings of black, red, orange and even yellow give this breed away.

The Mountain's Shadow: The classical "dragon" mountain caves are where your kind dwell and carve out sometimes elaborate living spaces. You kind tends to keep away from humans, but the "hands-off" approach just isn't for you. Why make a life of dining on deer and tough, chewy mountain goats when there are fat cattle and sheep in the low lands for the taking; and that's not even mentioning the loot! Above average size, your kind comes in many colors and patterns from earth-tones to vibrant primary colors. While the horns on your head are decorative and mainly to attract mates, the six spikes on your tail are all business.

151.content:
Some call you mad, but they just don't understand your genius! Meddling into the unseen forces behind the world might sound dangerous, but you really know what you're doing right? Well... there'll be time to sort things out later even if you do make a mess.

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon are you?

The Regal Bronze: One of the largest casts of dragon, you tower over your opponents on the field of battle and have the force of well toned muscle behind each of your massive blows. You are called regal for your long legs and tall stature, you carry your head high and proud when you grace the land with your presence. Your kind are mortal enemies of Deathwings (but then again, who isn't?). Your brawn and their speed are evenly matched. While it isn't necessarily truth, the appearance of battling the Deathwings has given your kind a vaguely chivalrous reputation, a reputation that many individuals chose to uphold on their own. Your tail ends in a serrated arrow-head that is capable of slicing through fully grown trees and of course, your hide comes in only one color, a luminous bronze.

The Vishian Drake: Also known as the "wizard's drake" yours is one of the most poorly understood breeds of dragon. Smaller than average, your teeth and claws are well suited to your body and not over-sized like some of the more combat oriented breeds. Your scaly hide comes in watery colors of blue, green and even silver. Your wings are a marvel, appearing as crystalline webbing between the digits of your wings. Your fiery breath is mediocre at best, but your best trait and the one you are known for is the ability to disappear at will. In a process that you don't understand fully yourself, you can slip into a shadowy "in-between" to evade your pursuers, becoming invisible and untouchable. The world remains around you and you cannot pass through solid objects, but its inhabitants vanish and you are surrounded as if by mists. Reappearing becomes more difficult the longer you remain away so don't linger in your shadowy haven! Beware wizards because your kind are highly sought as the best of familiars. You don't want to lose your freedom do you?

The Crovey: The Crovey are a species of dragon with a reputation almost as dreadful as the feared Deathwing and whose reality is definitely more horrifying for the average mortal. The ancestral home of this breed of dragon is a vast underground cave complex, which exists under an equally vast mountain range commonly referred to as Umbra veil (Land of Shadow) by the dwarves and other beings. The Crovey, if you ever get a chance to see one, are slender of build, almost sickly and possess a short wingspan, which is more suited for short bursts of flight or assisted leaping than prolonged gliding. Boney spurs at the elbows aid in self-defense and another spur at the end of the tail curves upwards as the dragons are known to strike over their heads rather like a scorpion. They lack the ability to breathe fire so it would seem on the surface that they would be forgettable. However, living in the dark these hardy fiends gained a unique ability to sense the life force of others at a distance, and even to feed upon it directly. Similar to a pit viper’s sense of the body heat of its victims, the presence of life “glows” for the Crovey in the dark of their world. With time, their auras have grown incredibly malleable and they are able to extend it at will far from their bodies, thus are they able to feed on the life force of others, assuming the dragon can overpower the spirit, of their intended prey. If a Crovey cares to be subtle, their prey can begin to weaken and die without ever knowing the dragon was present at all. The Crovey do not eat, but do require a steady source of fresh water. They can feed on any form of life, even cave mold and fungus can be sustaining in times of famine, however, living creatures usually have the most abundant life force.

151221.content:
Deciding that it is best to confront this "problem" head-on, you leap from the tree branch you had been perching on. After all, the human had been proving himself annoyingly persistent in his pursuit of you. As the magics you were able to perceive surrounding the normally vulnerable human form attested, this was no amateur magician. A small stream of fire leapt from your open mouth as you screamed down towards the man waving his hands about and muttering words wings spread wide. Despite your size, you were quite a sight appearing with claws and teeth amid smoke and flames, the dreadful sound erupting from your throat and the man lost grip of his spell, the magical energies losing cohesion and drifting off into the greater nether. The whole problem might have just gone away right then and there, but as you had guessed, the man had prepared several potent wards about his person. Just as it seemed your fire was about to come into contact with the man's body, it was bifurcated as if by a sudden wind and passed harmlessly to either side of the man. You didn't come into direct contact with the wizard, but you guessed that your teeth and claws would likely be ineffectual as well.

Landing in front of the startled human, you hiss and mantle your wings carefully, a smug look on your face. You are ready to flee in an instant, but you need to find out why this man is hounding you so. The man raises his hands as if to begin an incantation, but you speak, "Human. You have chased me from my home and across two countries. I'll know why you persist in chasing me so."

The wizard lowered his hands and made a universal sign of parley with his right hand. Your wings relaxed and your lips lowered over your rows of curved fangs. The human, despite his ridiculously colorful garb, spoke in a deep and pride-filled voice...

1512211.content:
"My intent has never been to do you any harm, dragoness. Your kind is perhaps the rarest and most mysterious of your species. My master wishes to understand more about your kind, about the powers you wield. If you were to accompany me as my familiar, I dare hope you would learn more about yourself and gain a greater understanding of your own powers as well," said the wizard.

"A familiar?" you asked, tilting your head sideways, mystified at what the term meant. These wizards had strange ways, you concluded.

"They refer to rare supernatural beings with great abilities that assist our guild in the practice of magic. Obviously, it would be a travesty to refer to such a wonderous being such as yourself as a familiar, and I would feel honored indeed if you were to join us..."

The wizard bowed in emphasis.

He sure was a smooth talker, you had to conclude. By the tone of voice, and the aura you sensed, it appeared as if he'd meant what he said. At the same time, you werent quite sure if you wanted to help the wizards, not the least of which was the fact you couldn't go where you wished to go anymore. However, you weren't keen on having to be chased for who knew how long, as while you might be able to avoid this wizard there would surely be others.

15122111.content:
The proud dragoness spent a while in thought, eying the young wizard who, in the custom of Parley, kept his hands clasped together in plain sight rather than the potentially treacherous confines of his voluminous sleeves. In time, she settled onto her haunches and the wizard, for his part, sat down cross-legged on the leafy mattress of the forest floor while both parties waited to see if the chase would continue or be ended today.

Before the Vishian Dragoness came up with her answer, the man asked. "If you do not mind, it would be a great honor for me to know your name, fair dragon."

The female dragon rumbled deeply in her long, thin neck. Her slit-pupiled eyes turned towards the man, "Names hold great power as you must know, Human."

"A trade then? You may call me Virgil." said the young wizard with an open palm gesture.

The dragoness turned her head sideways, still wary. Just as it seemed she would not answer, however, she spoke. "You may call me Narcissa... Virgil." she added a tad late, catching the human's eye.

A minute more passed and then Virgil asked, "Have you considered my proposal?"

Narcissa bared her fangs again, "Do not rush me, mage!" However, she knew in her dual hearts that at this point she was simply dawdling. She was tired of running... bone tired. As a female, in order to mate, she had to have a stable territory and defend it from encroachers. She could not simply flit about like an empty-headed male, waiting to stumble into a possible suitor. She needed a home. And as long as she was being hunted, there was no hope of making one for herself; this fact, more than the fact that the last time she had even seen another of her breed had been in the nest with her clutch mates and her own mother - the toad sized creature she'd stumbled across once did not count in her mind - was more distressing to Narcissa's notions of making the best use of her available breeding years.

Her own mother had said to be wary of humans and yet... Narcissa did have little knowledge of the greater world beyond the topography of the landscape and wild places within several hundred miles of her hatching place. This might be an opportunity to learn about the world, however, it might also be the last decision she made as a free dragon... What she needed was a concrete hold over the man, no simple promise of being able to leave when she wished would do.

"Human... Virgil." said Narcissa and immediately the human rose, gliding up so effortlessly, the dragoness could not tell if he had assisted himself with magic. "I have decided to accompany you, for now, on your journey back to your master, assuming you will cease your attempts to capture me and place no fetters upon my person."

The young mage inclined his head deeply and the smallish dragon took that as meaning he agreed.

"Furthermore, should I decide to leave, I shall inform you beforehand and you must give me a day's head start before resuming your chase."

"Naturally." said the mage. "Why not make it three days? I am confident that you will be pleased with my company and the accommodations and privileges that we will afford you when we reach my master's estate in Devonshire."

Though she had never seen a man-made map before in her 60 years of life so far, she had accumulated enough hearsay to know the place the human spoke of. It would be a three day's easy flight due North-East from their present location, however, that included passing over a swamp and a broad river. Narcissa had no guess as to how long the journey might take crawling along the ground like a rooting beast.

The man had a gilded tongue, Narcissa had to give him that much. Now however, was the real demand. How would she bind this human to ensure his trust?
