choices: The pair begin their journey back to Devonshire
Narcissa discovers a secret Virgil was hiding
151221111.content:
The words came quietly from the otherwise straightforward dragoness. "Lastly... I want you to make a bond with me." Narcissa could hardly believe she just said that; and to a human no less! But she couldn't think of anything else to do to ensure his loyalty

"A bond?" asked the human mage warily. Narcissa apparently had finally caught him off-guard.

Blast, Narcissa was hoping she wouldn't have to elaborate any further. A Bond was something that was only usually shared between spouses, close friends and sometimes children. The dragoness stood up, though due to her height was still looking up at the human from about waist high, "A special bond, usually only shared between those who are very close among my kind. We shall imbibe of each other's auras."

The wizard's eyes flew wide and he took a step back. "Such is forbidden!"

Narcissa stood her ground, looking firmly at the human and his odd reaction to something that should have seemed overly intimate, but not obscene. "That is the cost of my accompanying you."

The man raised a pale skinned hand to his close shaven goatee. "It... You ask too much, dragon."

Narcissa took a step forward, she hadn't expected the human to react so negatively. She was worried that despite his graceful words, he would resort once again to force to bring her along. "Why is this idea so alarming to you, Virgil?" she asked, carefully enunciating the human's name.

The wizard looked away. "We... we are taught to keep our auras clean and immaculate, free of outside taint. Mingling auras... it is how one welcomes corruption into one's heart. It is how dark wizards and Abominations are born."

Narcissa was surprised to say the least. She truly did know little of the world. She spoke calmly and walked a little closer until she could feel the prickles of Virgil's protective wards tickling her scales. She was within arm's reach now, and he within reach of her claws. Sitting lightly on her royal blue scaled haunches, she stretched up her neck to look at the tall human. "I know not of any corruption in making the bond. It is simply a way to better understand one anyother, to truly understand. It is the only way I can know that there is no deception in your hearts. And you shall know that there is none within mine."

The man grinned oddly as he looked down at Narcissa's slight form, "It is said that a man has only one heart, and that none may truly know it."

Narcissa was befuddled by the man's words. "A mere difference in biology does not matter. I have wings and you do not. It does not mean that I have any less desire to be free and live as I please than you. And yet with your hunting, you bring me to either come with you or live my life on the run."

The strange look in the man's eyes faded and he took a step back to a more comfortable distance. "I am sorry, but I have been assigned this mission as my final test before proving myself worthy to ascend to the next level of my studies. I am to become a High Magister in exchange for returning with you."

Narcissa smiled shrewdly and cocked a wing at an angle. "All the more reason to accept my proposal then."

The man gritted his teeth. "You do not understand what you ask, though. If I am discovered to have mingled my aura with that of a dragon, I'll be killed."

"And yet you find it reasonable to chase me from my home with real intent to bring me to your masters as a slave, Virgil?" said Narcissa, cocking her head.

"You won't be a slave!" Virgil insisted. The young man was obviously loosing his former composure. He ran a hand through his now sweaty hair. "There are other dragons who live on the estate. You'll have a much better chance meeting a suitable mate there than out here in the middle of nowhere. You could live as a queen!"

Narcissa lifted a claw and looked at it mildly, "My offer still stands. Will you bond with me, Human?"

The human made a sound like he was trying to growl and then pulled at the hair at the nape of his neck. He smoothed his long black hair before acquiescing, "Alright, Narcissa. I agreed, but we shall never speak of this to anyone. It is very possible they will want you dead as well as I."

The human's last attempt as dissuasion did not phase the young dragoness. She was set in her mind now. "Good. Now kneel."

The human sighed but did as he was told. His robes bunches against the ground as he folded his legs.

"A little lower... now, that is good." said Narcissa when they were at last eye to eye. "Now you must release your wards. There cannot be any magic seperating us."

"But..." Virgil hesitated. "There will be nothing to keep you from killing me."

"Trust is the first step of the bond." said the dragoness, her mind now slipping into the proper mindset as she gazed deeply into the young man's eyes. "Put your life in my hands as I am putting mine in yours."

The wizard took a deep breath and nodded. He closed his eyes and with a steady outlet of breath, the wards dissipated. Narcissa could smell when the air was clean of magic, only the scents of the forest and of the sweaty human before her remained. The dragoness raised her wings and swept them forward, almost encasing the two of them in a protective den of crystaline webbing. "Beautiful..." muttered raising a hand as if to brush it against the many faceted membrane of Narcissa's wings.

"Do not touch." intoned the dragoness, and the man's hand lowered. "I am concentrating, as you should be. Calm your mind. You are in a safe place."

The wizard complied, though from the sound of his heart beat - with him so close, she could hear it clearly - it took a long time for the human to become calm with in the embrace of a dragon's wings. "Yes... clear your mind..." said Narcissa as she studied the man's face, the alien contours, the flat nose and mouth like a deformity to her eyes and yet tried to find something appealing, something she could latch onto. There.

And all of a sudden their searching minds met in the greater Nether. She could see his aura, and when he opened his eyes, she knew that he could see hers too.

"Oh my..." breathed the mage, "The colors..." as if he had never seen another's aura before; which might very well be the truth.

Narcissa herself had very limited experience in the art of reading another's aura, but she could tell right away that the man was honest and was true to his principles; even if those principles themselves might be misguided, Narcissa didn't know. The man had strong faith as well and was guided by it, but he also had a great desire for power and status. He was an ambitious man and was not afraid to be ruthless if he had to. In him, Narcissa saw the potential for a great leader. She liked what she saw. If the wizard received any information about Narcissa in return, she could not tell.

The man, however, seemed entranced by the display of lights coalescing about each other and bouncing off the translucent membrane of the dragon's wings. "What happens now?" he asked.

Narcissa leaned close, the tip of her snout bare inches from his nose. The colors rose from their bodies like steam after emerging from a hot spring. "Breathe... just breathe." she said and inhaled, taking some of the wizard's aura into herself. There were flavors and smells of things she did not know of. The smell of an old leather chair. Wood burning cheerily in a stone hearth. The sweat of a horse after a vigorous gallop; but not for eating. The scent of old paper in a vast library. Pleased faces she did not know clapping her on the back. A woman...

The two broke apart with a gasp. It was the human who had turned away first and broke the link. Narcissa busied herself with folding her wings agitatedly.

"You... you were reading my mind." said Virgil.

"I was doing more than that." said Narcissa, "But you were doing the same. What did you experience?"

The man was holding his forehead in his hands. "Forests... Mountains... Delicious cow meat... flying. Flying!" the man almost stood straight up, but the dragoness reached around with her long tail and placed it on the man's shoulder to keep him still. He looked at the small dragon, "My god, the sensation was incredible!"

Narcissa reached out with her thoughts, and found the human in the vast Nether much more easily, but he was a vague shape still, indiscernible. "Ah, you broke too soon. The bond is still weak. Come let us breathe some more." said Narcissa. This time, Virgil leaned forward much more willingly.

Wisdom can only truly grow with time. You know this as you seek to understand the world and its mysteries. Some may call you a hermit, but you have no time for petty squabbles among mortals and head-strong dragons hardly better than beasts. Peace and quiet are as good as riches to you.

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon are you?

The Golden Mane: A strange looking dragon from a foreign land, you are the only dragon possessed of hair, a full mane that is always a shimmering golden color. Your elongated body is rather like a serpent and forshortened wings are used mainly for maneuvering through the air rather than to generate lift. You stay aloft rather by segmented hydrogen gas chambers lining both sides of your snake-like body. Thus you have potentially the most available fire out of any breed, but using up your gas also decreases your ability to fly... Your limbs and claws are small compared to the size of your body, but that's ok because your method of hunting is to coil around your prey and constrict the life out of it. Your kind is noted for a particular like of pearls, especially large ones.

The Earth-Render: You are a unique class of dragon. Rather than living in high mountain lairs, your kind prefer to burrow into the earth. That doesn't mean you don't share the same lust for treasure and glory as your fellow dragons however! Normal size for a dragon, your wings are shaped to allow you to move through the earth with ease, but makes your slower and clumsier in the air compared to others. Your knowledge of the deep places gives you special advantages, however. Your hide is tougher than usual and more heat resistant. It is even said that your kind can cause pits to suddenly open in the earth, change the foundations of the rock even alter the course of underground water. You hide has a pebbly texture and comes in various shades of brown from clay to light green. Your head is smooth and no spur or weapon lays at the end of your tail, but your large fore claws are good for more than just shoveling earth.

The Vishian Drake: Also known as the "wizard's drake" yours is one of the most poorly understood breeds of dragon. Smaller than average, your teeth and claws are well suited to your body and not over-sized like some of the more combat oriented breeds. Your scaly hide comes in watery colors of blue, green and even silver. Your wings are a marvel, appearing as crystalline webbing between the digits of your wings. Your fiery breath is mediocre at best, but your best trait and the one you are known for is the ability to disappear at will. In a process that you don't understand fully yourself, you can slip into a shadowy "in-between" to evade your pursuers, becoming invisible and untouchable. The world remains around you and you cannot pass through solid objects, but its inhabitants vanish and you are surrounded as if by mists. Reappearing becomes more difficult the longer you remain away so don't linger in your shadowy haven! Beware wizards because your kind are highly sought as the best of familiars. You don't want to lose your freedom do you?

The hilly territory surrounding the high abandoned temple in which you've made your residence is full of twisty, turny passes and trails. Of course, with the gift of flight, these are laid open to you, whereas other lesser creatures must crawl through the unforgiving terrain on foot, not seeing the path before them. An excellent metaphor for mortals in general you muse.

Another dragon might have made a nuisance of herself by burning travelers within a wide range of your abode. Isolation from mortals is a prudent and cautious goal most of the time for any sort of dragon, however, aggressive action which drives away the hunters and thieves in the short run only returns to bite the short sighted dragon in the tail in the long haul as steadfast armies and sneaky assassins begin to replace nosy travelers and angsty juveniles.

Drifting leisurely at a high altitude, twisting your snaky body through the air, you sift the ground below casually in the ever ongoing search for prey. The activity is boring, but necessary. Your mind drifts like a cloud in the breeze as you allow your eyes to search passively for signs of movement which will betray a potential food beast. Hunting was never hard, but it was time consuming. You'd rather be down in the basement, tracing runes on the stone floor or else grinding berried into dye to continue writing your musings as well as your Heart-Song. It crossed your mind that this phase of your life may be drawing to a close, hampered in by growing ennui and indifference. Might it be time to begin a long and dangerous search for someone to share life with? A mate?

You filed the thought away as you saw something move far below. Your nose automatically tracked the source, drawn by instinct to prey. As a result you began to dive, even before you knew what it was below that had caught your attention. Vision resolved as you got closer. It was...

1521212.content:
A traveling wagon. You were both amused and surprised to see the rickety wooden carriage clamber noisily down the rocky, winding canyon. It seemed to be a in a mad rush. Riding up behind the caravan galloped a small group of horse archers.You let out a snort of amusement. Yet another episode of the fruitless bickering of the flightless humans. While you were still a rather young dragoness, you had already seen countless fiefdoms rise and fall, quarreling over increasingly petty differences.

Yet right when you were about to turn back and allow the humans to carry on their pointless struggle, there was a brief but unmistakable glint caught the corner of your eye. You instantly doubled around and decided to take a closer look. As the caravan swung back into the open, you caught another glint of the mineral.

There could be no mistaking it now. The caravan was carrying pearls!! From the moment you'd hatched, you had taken to searching for these precious gems. The dream of every dragon was to be able to collect a hoard so large they could literally swim in it, but up until now the amount you'd collected had been disturbingly few; not even enough to fill up one of the old altars.

However, caution still seeped into your mind. Was it worth the huge cache of pearls if it meant the possibility of becoming involved in the affairs of the humans? The last thing you wanted was for you to take the pearls, but then the humans to send a large contingent of soldiers to the temple. Then, things would get messy, and you may well have to abandon everything you'd built up over the years and start as empty as a hatchling again.

Yet then again, how often did a chance to snag such a large cache of pearls come along?

I awoke one day to find myself with sand all over the place, even on me. Also a woman on my back. She was standing with some lushes’ nobleman garments but had blood on it from head to toe and over freshly made corpses. What impressed me was, there was only one woman standing like a living piece of art and both dried plus fresh blood all over my back, a small wall of corpses on either side of me. I smelled the air around me. The odor of sweat and blood, traces of gunpowder all over the place and I think a little bit of the human filth, luckily tainted with the smell of salt. I assumed an ocean was near by. I smelt one other thing, faint but so familiar. It was coming from the woman. “Why is there so much human on me?” I asked her. I spoke using a different method. If I spoke to her normally I could blow out her ears.

“Shut up Dragon!” She yelled back at me. “Move it! Your not even supposed to be here!”

“Beg your pardons.” I asked a bit shocked. Apparently having a voice within her head didn’t faze her at all.

“You are laying on Xion’s Temple Damn it! Move!” She screamed at me.

I understood at that point who this woman was. “You’re a descendent of Xion aren’t you?” I asked her. Her reply however puzzled me.

I’m. I’m what? No. No I’m not a. A descendant of Xion. She said confused.

“If your not then you’re a grave robber.” I said.

It seemed she became more puzzled after that. She then said, “You have got to be joking!”

“Why would I joke?” I asked.

“First off, I know that which you lay upon is a Temple, not a Tomb. Second, I doubt a God could have kids, or want kids.” She replied.

I laughed at that answer, personally knowing full well that Xion was no god.

The woman didn’t take that to well. She picked up a sword that was close to her and proceeded to stab me with it. The blade did snap in half after a few times trying to get through my scales though. “Even though my family and I maybe human. We respected the belief of others. Don’t you Dare Dragon!”

“Then respect my belief, human.” I said sternly and out loud causing the woman to drop on her knees and cover her ears. I sighed and went back to mentally speaking with her. “Look, I’m not on it. I’m laying around it. Ok? Now, you think you can get off me?”

Why exactly should I?” she asked standing back up.

I sighed and stood up myself, sand coursing down my whole body. The woman lost her balance and rolled all the way down my side and to the ground below. When I didn’t feel any more meat roll or slide off me I shook off the rest. There were corpses and still wet clogs of bloody sand flying everywhere.

“That’s by far the nastiest sight I have ever seen dragon.” the woman said getting up as if falling from that height was nothing at all.

“Why say that?” I asked.

“Mainly because of what you mention, but there is more to it.” she said. “I’m bigger then a woman should be, stronger then a woman should be.”

“So did you kill all those other humans?” I ask a little hesitant. The woman by now was facing me.

“No, more then half that was already dead by the time I came. I think that all of them was killing each other, trying to get into the Temple underneath you.” She said.

I then realized that I must have been sleeping for quite a while. I also realized that I was hungry and that I stunk or maybe it was all the dead humans around me. I couldn’t tell at the moment. "Human..."

"Tabitha Ingrid." the woman interrupted me.

"What?" I ask.

"Tabitha Ingrid." She repeated. "That’s my name dragon.”

"Oh. Well, then Tabi..."

"You have a name too right?" She interrupted me again.

"Nothing you can pronounce." I answered. “Now then…”

“How bout…”

“How can we bath in the desert Dragon?” she asked me plainly.

“There’s an ocean nearby actually.” I answered her and started off.

“Wait dragon.” I heard Tabitha yell.

I didn’t stop as I said, “What is it this time human.”

“Could you help me a little?” She asked me pointing to the tomb.

I sighed. “Your still a grave robber to me Tabitha. You want Xion’s Tomb, you dig it up yourself.”

“It's A Temple Damn it!!!” I heard her scream.

I stopped for a second and sniffed around to find the direction of where the salt was coming from. The ocean was east of where I was. Before I headed in that direction I looked back at the buried tomb and sighed as I barely saw the tiny being digging her way down to it.

I decided to...

"You can tell this freeloader to get out of here!"
"You can tell this old fart to stop hogging the good logs!"

Alender recoiled slightly at the outburst. "Please, please settle down. This is not the way we do things around here."

"Maybe not for you, big fella with your fancy wings and flutter in' n' such." scoffed the older gnome. "But we down here on the ground have to scrap out a living. Do you know how long it takes to grow a decent mushroom?"

"It takes longer when you don't even have a place to spend the night. I've had to cover myself with lichen and pray that a fox didn't sniff me out every night for the past two moons!" shouted the younger gnome and before Alender knew it, the two were at it again. The sound of disharmony was distressing in the faire dragon's curled ears.

"Please, please listen to me." insisted the young dragon. "There is plenty of room in the forest. I am sure that we can find you a place of your own to live."

"Darn right, you best get off with you." muttered the old gnome.

But the younger gnome seemed more intrigued. "You mean you will find me a new place to live?"

"Yes, I can do that." said Alender, feeling calmer now that the tension in the situation was diffusing. "In fact, I know of a place where a young gnome is greatly needed. There will be work to do, however, for the good of the forest."

"As long as I have a spot to grow some fine mushrooms, I'll be dandy." said the gnome. And then Alender lowered his head and let the woody little gnome clamor up onto his snout and then the crown of his head. The carved wooden face of the gnome glistened with dew as it wrapped its little fingers about Alender's delicate horns. As the dragon spread his translucent wings, the gnome asked, "So where are we headed?"

"Someplace where the forest is hurting." said Alender, somewhat grimly and set off through the trucks of the trees, floating effortlessly on the moist still air.
154211.title: It's Always Something

1542112.content:
Alender flew to were he had smelled smoke form the forest. He thought with a little help from the gnome, Alender could fix it in no time, but when he got their it was worse then he thought. Alender would have not believed what he saw if some one told him. Once a proud forest was now a field of stumps. Nothing Alender had heard of would have ever deliberately done so much damage to the forest. Fear of a terrible monster had over come Alender.

"What is this place? I thought you were going to find me a new home!" exclaimed the gnome.

"I was, but now the place is completely destroyed!" Alender's anxiety could be heard in his voice.

"A fairy dragon afraid? What kind of monster terrifies a fairy dragon?" asked the gnome concernedly.

"I don't know what would have done this." Alender repaid.

"Then let's find out. With me at your side there nothing that we can't be beat." The gnome jumped off Alender and headed into the field. Alender got in front of the gnome before he got out of the woods.

"What do you think your doing? We don't have a clue what we are up against. We should stay hidden until we know what did this and how to deal with it." reasoned Alender. He never liked jumping into a situation and not having all the facts.

"Look, dragon, If we stay here more of the forest will be damaged." Being called dragon was one of the few things that angered Alender. He had a name and was proud of it.

"First, my name is Alender. Second, the trees look like the were harvested. If we follow the smell of smoke, we could find the creature that did this."

"Alright sounds like a plan." The gnome got back onto Alender. "I am Ivan, by the way."

"Nice to meet you Ivan. Now lets go." Alender followed the smoke to a valley with a river filled with logs. He saw a large group of bipedal creatures trimming trees down to logs and tossing them into a river. They were using odd looking tool to handle all their jobs.

"What are they doing?" Ivan was scratching his head. "The take all the trees then toss them away? These most be the dumbest creatures I have ever seen!"

"They know how to harvest trees and use tools, so they should be smart enough to talk. Maybe, they can be reasoned with."

"Or we could just use our magic to scare them off." offered Ivan.

155.content:
Dark things crawl like spindles through your deep and potent thoughts. Mercy is for the weak of mind who don't understand your works. It's all for the best though, you wouldn't want the unintelligent brutes of the world second-guessing your designs now would you?

Now for the fun part. What sort of dragon are you?

The Deathwing: These dragons have a sinister appearance with their elongated snouts, huge horns and the spikes at their knees and shoulders. A fleshy ruff around the face can create a presentation that will stop a man's heart cold in fear. But more fearsome is their reputation for ruthlessness and guile. Muscular, but not brawny, quick, but with enough weight to get the job done, these intelligent creatures are the objects of horrible fairy tales and superstitions the world over. And that suits them just fine. Always solid black, you are a hunter of the night and while you can see into the blackest abyss, your eyes are sensitive to bright lights without the time to acclimate. A single sharp prong for stabbing exists at the end of your long, elegant tail.

The Vishian Drake: Also known as the "wizard's drake" yours is one of the most poorly understood breeds of dragon. Smaller than average, your teeth and claws are well suited to your body and not over-sized like some of the more combat oriented breeds. Your scaly hide comes in watery colors of blue, green and even silver. Your wings are a marvel, appearing as crystalline webbing between the digits of your wings. Your fiery breath is mediocre at best, but your best trait and the one you are known for is the ability to disappear at will. In a process that you don't understand fully yourself, you can slip into a shadowy "in-between" to evade your pursuers, becoming invisible and untouchable. The world remains around you and you cannot pass through solid objects, but its inhabitants vanish and you are surrounded as if by mists. Reappearing becomes more difficult the longer you remain away so don't linger in your shadowy haven! Beware wizards because your kind are highly sought as the best of familiars. You don't want to lose your freedom do you?

The Nettled Reaper: You have a fantastically dangerous appearance with a body covered in venomous quills. Down the neck, across the torso, limbs and tail, colorful quills protect your body and advertise a warning to would-be dragon slayers. Known for a foul temper and easily provoked, the quills on the tail are loose and can be launched a projectiles with a simple flick. Lacking a breath weapon, your venom nonetheless is potent to render even a large dragon unconscious in minutes and will kill humanoids outright. A fair flyer, you lack speed for the disturbance your quills cause, but make up for it in maneuverability. You are also smaller than the average standing about 15 feet at the shoulder.

15512.content:
We were betrayed...

I should have seen it coming...

Who is it that ended up getting betrayed? My clan that is...

I could tell you the long story. Of my life, how I grew up wandering alone, then joining the clan, filled with wanderers and loners like myself, and finally the mishaps, the jealousies and schemes of the other clans and my own lack of foresight that ultimately led to the betrayal of my clan.

Yet my body hurts too much. Hurts too much from having to flee the chaotic, barren lands we called home, from being harrassed by other dragons that despise us, day after day as we tried to find a new home, how we were gradually picked off one by one and finally, how it ends up with me lying in this forgotten cave, broken and waiting to die.

Wearily, I gaze outside. A storms brewing up... In way its rather fitting and oddly, rather comforting that my last moments take place in the darkness. So thus I waited...waited for the end.
15512.title: Betrayed

155121.content:
The cold earth that surrounded me and the blackness that enveloped my body, the wind howling outside as if the world were being torn asunder… ‘Let the world fall to pieces.’ I thought spitefully. As for me, the only company I had was the pain.

No. That wasn’t quite right. I hugged the bleeding gash in my side with my one good leg. The blood was coming more slowly, but I feared it wouldn’t stop in time. Behind me, my broken wing spread unfurled in a shattered canvas of agony, I was unable to close it. It’d been a week since I’d last eaten, but strangely, the gnawing pain in my gut was nowhere to be found. I closed my eyes. I did have something else besides the pain, and right now, it seemed the better alternative to lying here and waiting for my hearts to finally stop beating after all they’ve been through. The pictures came easily as I fled from the pain into a darkness deeper than any cave. I drowned in my memories…

When I was young, there was happiness, however briefly it lasted. It was always dark, but we liked it like that. My mother was a world unto herself, so large that I could lose myself crawling up her scaly leg and wandering up and down her torso. The few times that I found her head, I pulled on her ruff with my sharp little baby fangs. She would purr softly and gently pry me off, depositing me back near her belly were my other siblings resided. She was the sole source of warmth in the world and all good things came from her. Except the meat. Father brought the meat from the Outside. For the longest time, I had no desire to travel to, or even much inclination to think about the Outside. Mother was enough world for me. Father was nice too, but he was gone so often, I never really got to know him. I wish I could have learned their names…

I was still little more than a wingless lizard, my dormant wings hidden under the skin of my back when the Bad Thing happened. My mother had been teaching us how to sing together, teaching us the songs that told us how to be good dragons. Barely half the size of the meat creature father called a “horse,” I was filled to bursting with the desire to be a great and powerful dragoness like mother. I was at the age when I finally started asking about the Outside, but Mother always told me the Outside was not for little dragons such as I. She always said that I had the sweetest voice of the clutch…

The Bad Thing started when Father stumbled into the cave, flapping wildly and landing so heavily on the stone floor that I was bounced clear into the air. I remembered landing on my tail and I’d started to cry. I cried because of the pain I felt and because Father looked scary. I smelled blood on him, but not the good kind of blood, it was his own. Father spoke frantically to Mother about…
155121.title: Memories...

1551211.content:
"Its the Shadowtooth clan..."

I could only watch behind a rock as I listened to father. Of course, I had no idea who these Shadowtooth clan was at the time, never mind whatever else they were talking about. Yet as I huddled with my siblings,

"How can this be? Shadowtooth has been our allies for nearly a thousand years!!" cried mother.

"Was..." father spat.

"I cannot believe that the Shadowtooth would betray us of their own accord. Some other dark power must be acting upon their will ffrom the shadows!!" insisted mother. She sounded pleading and desperate. Mommy was scared, and that was when I first truly sensed that something utterly terrible was going on. The protection that I had always taken for granted was gone.

"The time for reasons has past though. What matters is that they shall be coming for us, for you and the hatchlings. Myself and some of the others from our clan will hold them off. You must get the hatchlings out of here now!!"

Gritting his teeth, father flew off into the grey sky. My other siblings began to whine. Mother tried to calm us down, telling us that everything was going to be fine, that father was going to be home soon. Yet even then, as a little hatchling, I could sense the fear in her eyes, and that foreboding that this was the last I would ever see of father.

Unfortunately, I was right.

Mother began to frantically scoop the five of us onto her back, imploring us to hang on for dear life. I gripped as hard as I could, pressing my body as tightly as I could against her warmth. She rushed to the edge of the cave, and took off. That's when I saw outside for the first time. I was immediately assailed by a blast of cold. Water was falling, and I felt air bracket against me. I looked up. The sky was filled with dragons, circling above sharp craggy cliffs. They were shooting fire out of their mouths and slashing each other. I could hear them roar, and how filled with hatred and savagery this was.

'Outside' was a terrible place even for the big dragons, but for the little dragons...

One of my siblings had always been smaller and weaker than the others. He didn't have a name, but what I remembered of him was that he was quiet. He didn't like to play much either, nor could he really sing very well, but he would simply stare off into space for some reason. I also remember that whenever father brought us back food, he didn't eat that much, and would always give part of his meals to one of the other siblings.

Unfortunately, but perhaps inevitably, he was the first to have died. When mother was hit by an unusually strong gust of wind, the small one wasn't strong enough to hang on. He plummeted. The small one uttered but a slight whining noise as his body was skewered by a jagged rock.

Mother did not utter a noise, no screams of terror and dismay at the sight. She only gave one glance at small one before flying on. As for myself and the rest of the siblings, we mimicked our mothers silence. One would think that hatchlings would have cried and wailed at that moment, yet perhaps as Darkwings, our souls had been conditioned to expect suffering.

As I look back, I figured it was just as well that the small one would have died right then. He would not have lived more than a few days once he left the nest. Perhaps I even envy him, as small one was the one that ended up suffering the least out of all of us...

After a while, mother's frantic flight had begun to even out, as her breathing slowed and her muscles weren't quite as tensed as before. We had escaped immediate danger. Yet from then on, I realized why mother had never wanted us to go 'Outside'.

Then, mother suddenly snapped her head around...
1551211.title: 'Outside'

15512111.content:
We never stayed in any one place for long.

She would set us down in some hidden crevice, before scrampering off to hunt. The food we received from her was nothing like the tasty meat that we received from father. In these barren lands, there was nothing but small, skinny animals. The water was also dirty and fetid. We were always hungry.

Mother's behavior had also changed since the 'Bad' day. She wasn't so nurturing and caring anymore. Whenever one of us would misbehave, she would hit us. She didn't teach us how to sing together anymore, but now told us to stay put and be silent. As before, she would sing songs about how to be good dragons, she would warn us of the bad dragons who were out trying to find us and kill us. At times, we were just as scared of her as we were of the bad dragons that were after us.

During this time of wandering, another one of our siblings died. It was one of my brothers. As it so happens all too often to hatchlings, he got sick. Mother kept him seperate from us during the nights. He would cough up blood the entire night, while calling out for mother. For a while, mother did try and comfort him, but even so, we still had to keep moving from place to place. After a while, he soon became too weak to continue on.

One night he just didn't wake up. He was so thin, and all the color had left him. Mother only shook her head, before she implored us to latch on.

We continued to wander for another long while, before finally she found somewhere we could call home. By then, we had grown large enough that it was difficult for mother to carry all of us at the same time, but not yet strong enough to fly. Of course, it wasn't the same as when father was still around, but I was thankful we didn't have to go from place to place anymore.

It was only then when me and my remaining siblings were finally given names. Usually, the reason of that is in every clutch, a mother can expect that some of them would die of various reasons. Sometimes they were weak like 'small one', other times they got sick. In any case, it was nothing short of miraculous, given all that we had already gone through, that even three of us out of the original five were still alive by then. Myself. My sister... And... my brother.

My mother named me Mysteria. Perhaps it was because I liked being left alone, and that she loved my voice.

Mother named my sister Kursed. She was the one who was always unnaturally and annoyingly optimistic, especially when things were at their worst. Of course, one can appreciate the irony of her name, as overly cheerful Deathwing was not an ideal disposition for a long lifespan. For instance, up until the time the second brother got sick and died, she insisted that father would return and we'd all be able to go home. I figure she knew that, but it was her way of coping, or at least I hope it was. Kursed did last longer than I thought she would, and when she died it seemed only then she realized what a messed up and brutal world we live in, but that's for later though...

Mother named my remaining brother Smaug. I can say without any reservations that he was the strongest of the hatchlings. Especially since he was the only male, he tried to be what father was, and felt that he had to take it upon himself to take care of the rest of the family. Of course, that was impossible back then as we were still hatchlings, but since the 'bad day', he became...

The thought of what Smaug became made me gnash my teeth together. It was something I didn't want to think about at the moment.

Yet mother never told us what her name was. She always said she would tell us when we became old enough to fend for ourselves. In any case, the three of us settled back into a routine. Living at the edge of a cliff, overlooking the ocean, we were mostly hidden from the Shadowtooth Clan. It couldn't last... not in these lands...

Because that day...
15512111.title: Wandering

155121112.content:
My hearts raced in my thin chest and in my long neck as I raced down the shadow-covered slope of the mountain. I gathered the strength in my haunches and leapt across free space. The edge of the cliff slammed into my belly and I scrambled madly with my claws and tail, watching the thin, wretched goat becoming more distant by the second. Oh for my wings! Stabbing the sandstone with the sharp, bone prong at the end of my tail, I secured the tip and used the appendage to lever me up. My tail, like all deathwings, was very long and built for whipping rather than brute strength, but I managed the task by deftly twisting it and increasing its stoutness. I leapt forward as soon as my hind feet touched the ground.

The muscles in my legs that would one day propel me into the sky were still suitable for jumping and sprinting in my larval state, however, like a cat, I tired quickly. That momentary lapse in the chase was going to cost me this hunt unless I could move faster. I was so hungry… Determined, I ran flat out, jumping from rock to rock after the bouncing goat with all the skill I’d developed since we moved to this dry, desolate place. The goat dove into a crevasse, clever little food beast. I went down after it, heedless of the possibility that I might become stuck. I wanted to kill that goat. The goat stumbled down and hit the floor heavily, walking away limping. As for me, I was falling, and then I was not. My tail lashed against the rough sandstone, I wiggled frantically against the pressure I felt on both sides, I was just barely too wide. The goat, though injured, was slowly making its escape. I wanted to cry out, to roar, but Mother had taught us to be quiet, there were still hunters out there looking for our blood. Still, I longed to express my frustration, keeping it bottled inside was making me sour.

I slid down another half foot and I became more stuck, less able to even wiggle. Damn the Ancestors, the crevasse widened just another foot below me. If I could just move a little… But there was nothing to it. I began to chip at the stone with my tail prong. The goat was going to get away, but at least I wouldn’t die here; a few hours work and I’d free myself…

Just before the goat left my field of view, however, I felt a heavy thud in the earth. “Oh no…” I thought, intimately familiar with the way my heavier sibling moved. My brother hissed loudly and the goat turned blindly back into the crevasse, back to its doom. It stopped short of my free claw, however, and the other was wedged against my shoulder. Smaug strode into the crevasse. His muscular shoulders were so broad that they almost touched either wall even at the wider bottom. He turned his head up and grinned at me. Oh to simply twist my neck and die right then and there!

“Hi little sis.” He said in his gruff, oh-so-masculine voice. I didn’t answer, hoping that he might still go away. “Looks like you’ve found yourself in a little bit of trouble again.”

I hissed at him, the goat was bleating in rampant fear caught in between two dragons. “I don’t need your help. I’m perfectly fine.” I tried desperately to slid down the last foot to freedom, but I was caught as snugly as a bean in a pod.

Smaug grinned with that stupid smile of his, then turned his eyes to my goat. “Then you wont mind if I help myself a little, then.”

Before I could say anything, Smaug lashed out with a claw and raked the goat. It’s screaming hurt my ears in the confined space. The food beast staggered to the floor and my brother put his paw down on it until the cracking of ribs could be heard. The pathetic thing flailed back and forth, the sound was horrid. I hated watching my brother eat.

As my brother was breaking one of the goat’s legs between his thumb and first finger, I shouted, “Just kill the damn thing already!”

My brother looked up at me, his violet pupils round and shining in the moonlight. “As you wish… little sis.” With his tail prong, he reached over his head and stabbed the goat through the neck. At last there was silence. I thought that my brother might have been satisfied with this indignity so far, but I was wrong. He lowered his head and tore into the goat’s abdomen with his teeth.

My fleshy ruff raised from where it usually lay flat against my neck, greatly modifying the visual appearance of my head. It rattled with my fierce anger. “That’s my prey, you jerk!”

Smaug lifted his head and slurped some entrails into his greedy maw. “Oh really? From where I saw things, this little guy was going to get away if I hadn’t come around.”

“Better if it had.” I said. “Better if it’d fallen off the cliff and been eaten by vultures than gone into that gut of yours!” That wasn’t fair, Smaug wasn’t fat, but he was certainly muscular and much more stocky than either one of his sisters, even more than mother- at least relatively speaking – since she’d lost so much weight over the last several years.

That one stung, Smaug was very prideful of his sleek and impressive appearance. Spitefully, he took another big mouthful of the goat’s abdomen and swallowed it. Then he walked up to me, his big shoulders now touching the sandstone on either side. “Then consider it just payment for helping you out of here.”

Before I could argue, he grabbed hold of my dangling arm and pulled. I protested, his strength was horrid and I felt like my arm was going to be dislocated. But he didn’t relent. My scales were the only reason that I wasn’t flayed on each side as he forced me down the last bit of crevasse. The second I hit the floor, cradling my hurt limb, I flung my tail forward and hit the side of my brother’s head, slamming it against the stone. Before he could respond, I darted it forward and, with extreme precision, slid it between the scales on his neck. The tip of my tail spur was held against his rapidly beating neck heart. I refused to be bullied by him like Kursed was.

Smaug went slack, panic clearly in the big male’s eyes. I was growling, my ruff still rattling. “N-now, sister…” he stammered, “I didn’t mean anything. I was just having a bit of fun, you know. I wasn’t going to take your go-“

I pressed the sharp tip to the unprotected skin of his neck, I could see a bit of blood welling around it now. “Go, Smaug.” I said. “Just go.”

My brother shut his jaw and silently retreated. He stepped on the goat as he did and I could not tell if it was on purpose or by accident. Once he was free of the crevasse, I pulled my tail back and he rubbed the minor wound, looking hurt. “There was no need for that, Mysteria. I just wanted to come and tell you the good news.”

My ruff flattened. “What news?”

My brother lifted his head to the star filled sky and looked to the west. There were dark clouds gathering, a void in the sky. “There’s a storm coming. And I’m going to be the first to fly in it.”

“Goatshit.” I said, looked at my brother’s distinct lack of wings.

“I am.” He said. “Look closely at my back sister. I’ve begun to blister.” It was true, pale grey skin was exposed in two lines parallel to his spine. The fluid filled sacs where his dormant wings rested would rupture soon and he would be a full fledged dragon at long last. I wanted to spit in his face.

Without a word, I turned back into the crevasse. I hunkered down over the remains of my goat and after a time, Smaug left. Very quietly, I sang to myself as I ate my broken, lonely meal.

The sky, dear Hatchlings, is where we are free
To loop, spiral and dive is what it means
To Be...
155121112.title: The Crevasse

choices: The storm forces them out of the cave
A strange dragon lands on the shelf outside
1551211122.content:
Smaug had, in two bites, eaten most of the soft meat on the little goat. I was forced to lick the rough stone where most of its blood had been spilled and some traces of soft, nutritious entrails remained. I bit the head off and spat it to the side, the horns making it unsuitable for chewing or swallowing. Lacking molars, I used my sharp fangs to rip pieces off the carcass, swallowing them whole. Each leg was a bite, I didn’t mind the hooves. The rib cage was already shattered to pieces so it was easy to bite through. I gnawed on the spinal cord for some time before it broke. There was nothing left but red stained sandstone when I was done, but I hardly felt any better.

“Smaug doesn’t deserve to fly. He doesn’t appreciate it.” I fumed silently. I was angry at the unfairness of the world that my obnoxious sibling should have the honor of flying first when I...

“It’s only because he’s stolen so much food over the years, that muscle-brained dolt. He thinks that just because he’s bigger, it’s his job to protect us, but all he does is muscle his way into our kills!” I clawed at the stone, making a hideous sound and leaving four deep grooves behind. I wanted to roar, to howl; outside the crevasse, the wind was picking up, doing that job for me.

I decided I wanted to see my sister. Maybe her inexhaustible reservoir of cheerfulness would help put things in perspective for me... or at least help distract me from the unkind world for a few moments. I went out and a few drops of water fell of my dusty face, cleaning my jet black scales. I began to crawl up the mountain.

Climbing was easy for a dragon. Our limbs were proportionally short and muscular and our tailed helped a lot with balance and supporting ourselves while switching grips. Our claws dug into the stone so even overhangs were rarely a problem. Still, the going was hard because the water which so rarely fell here became to come down in abundance. Lightning flashed on the western horizon behind me, illuminating a churning sea. This was going to be a monster of a storm, it might even last for days. I climbed faster.

At the top of the cliff, I slithered onto the level ground. I was half expecting to see Mother, spread out in all her glory, but the shelf was empty. Beyond was a hole which Mother had dug herself until her claws were bleeding into the side of the mountain. While it had begun as little more than a stoop for her to hide in and store her hatchlings while she was away, we all had contributed to enlarging it over the years. It was still nothing to the home that we had shared with Father, but it was comfortable enough. Inside, I found Kursed.

My sister was black as pitch, just as I, my mother and my brother were. Her eyes, however were a soft amber color, starkly different from my own intense green. Before her was a log which was burning merrily. The light it gave off was so intense compared to the dark outside, I turned my head away. “What are you doing, Kursed?” I asked, a claw up the shield my sensitive eyes.

My sister’s eyes were slitted as they were in the daytime. “Why, hello Misty.” she said, using her nickname for me. “Look, isn’t it pretty? I found this nice dry log out on the mountain today.”

My eyes adjusted but slowly to the intense glow. The heat felt nice, however as I entered the cave. “It’s... nice.” I struggled, humoring my eccentric sister.

“Wouldn’t it be nice to keep these in here, Misty? We could keep the cave nice and warm at night.”

I suppressed a growl. If anything, it was too warm in here during the day when we were sleeping. As for the cold night, we should be out hunting. Running kept me warm enough. I changed the subject, though Kursed continued looking into the dancing flames curling up from the log, “Did Smaug tell you anything today?”

“Oh yes!” she exclaimed. “He showed me his back today while I was out hunting. I’m so happy for him!” Kursed extended her neck to embrace me, it took everything in me not to shrug her off. She continued in a high voice, “He’s going to be the first of us to fly, Misty! We’re finally growing up.”

I looked away. “Yeah, I guess we are.”

She noticed my expression. “Don’t be such a bitch about it, Misty. It was bound to happen to one of us eventually.”

I got up to leave, this was a terrible idea. However before I could, Kursed kicked the fire log towards the entrance. I hissed and turned from the horrible light, snarling at my sister who say primply upright. “Don’t leave, Misty. Tell me what you got under your scales.”

I sat, looked into the dark interior of the cave. My own shadow flickered and danced on the cave wall behind Kursed. I clenched my fist. “I’m so... angry at him, Kursed. And don’t tell me that I’m being a bitch. He doesn’t deserve to fly first.”

Kursed cocked her head, her tail lifted and fell a couple times on the floor as she thought. “Why is this so important to you, Misty? It’s not like like he chose to blister, any more than we could if we wanted.”

And that was the point wasn’t it, I couldn’t speed along my own development, not matter how much I wanted it. My head lowered almost to the floor, I looked at the floor that us hatchlings had smoothed after Mother had done the heavy claw-work herself. “I... I don’t know if I could stand watching him fly while I’m stuck on the ground, Kursed.” I said quietly. The hurting was so bad, like a dam had gushed forth its contents in my heart that a tear managed to escape the normally iron confines of my eyes.

Kursed extended her neck again and put her chin on top of my head. I felt her neck heart pulsating and the heat of her against me. To my surprise, I did feel a little better.

When we finally broke the embrace, Kursed looked me up and down. “Did you get enough to eat, today? You look worn out.”

I frowned, my sour mood coming easily back. “I made a kill, but Smaug ate most of it.”

My sister raised an eye-ridge. “That’s odd, he shared his kill with me after I lost the wolf I was tracking.”

I snorted. “No wonder he was so intent on my prey then, if he was forced to share. You know how much he cares about ‘adequate nutrition’” I said derisively.

Kursed frowned, “You know, Misty, if you made an effort to be nicer, you’d realize that Smaug isn’t as bad a dragon as you make him out to be. He helps me all the time.”

My head between my paws, I muttered, “I don’t need his help.”

“He’s our brother, sis. He’s going to be a part of our lives whether you like it or not.”

I was about inform Kursed of my little scheme to push Smaug off the cliff-face before his wings emerged, but was interupted by a crash from outside. My hearts rose as I saw the shape outside in the rain. Mother.

The great dragon folded her wings and without a moment’s hesitation, stomped the burning log into oblivion under her foot as she entered the cave. Though the chamber seemed spacious to me and my sister, she had to stoop to enter. Despite how rapidly we’d grown over the years, Smaug remained barely half her size and Kursed and I lagged behind him in our own growth. I wished I could be as strong as her one day.

“What’s this glow?” she demanded, dropping the scrawny antelope she’d caught on the ground, “Are you trying to reveal our location?” Mother spoke angrily. Her daughters both hung their heads. Despite the fact that I’d not been involved, I was not going to pin this solely on Kursed. She got in enough trouble with her odd fancies as it was.

I spoke up, “We just thought it looked nice, Mother. And it was warm with the rain and all.”

I knew what was coming before she even moved her tail. Its long, elegant length snaked around her body as if it were some sort of summoned serpentine servant. Mother clubbed me on the back, forcing me to the ground. Then, working the bone tip with as much dexterity as she did her claws, she spanked me on my haunch with the side of the sharp prong. I tried to be strong, but eventually I cried out, which is what she was looking for. I received nothing for holding on but more whips with the hard, boney spear length, but something told me that she approved nonetheless. Kursed received the same treatment and as always cried out much sooner than I. When I had recovered, she still lay sobbing on the stone floor.

“Don’t let me catch you two playing with fire here again.” she reprimanded us again. I felt angry at her right then for the unjust punishment, but had I known that was the last time I would feel her tail against my hide, I would have put up with far more.

When Smaug arrived in the den, it was filled to capacity. What remained of our family was together again. I wish I’d appreciated it more.
1551211122.title: Don't Be Such a Bitch

choices: The storm brewed up, forcing the intruder away
15512111222.content:
There is a saying amongst our people. That when things are starting to go too well, it all falls apart.

My hearts skipped a beat when a crash, louder and more distinct than the storm outside, shook our little cave.

"What was that?" I shrieked, snapping my head upwards.

Mother rose up on her haunches. To this day, I remember that haunted look she gave the three of us. She had known this day would come.

"Trouble," she said grimly. "Let me handle this intruder..."

The three of us huddled together when we spotted the outline of a huge dragon; one that dwarfed mother easily and perhaps even larger than father had been.

"At long last, I have finally found you dearest..." the dragon said. Kursed and I exchanged glances. What could that dragon be talking about? The only dragon that I had ever remembered that had called mother that was father, but this dragon was obviously not him.

"Did you waste all your time coming this way expecting that my answer would change? You think that I would want you, after you destroyed our home, killed my mate?"

The dragon snarled, "I always hated that goody-two shoes. You have no idea how good it felt to see him die..."

"Enough with your prattle..." snapped mother, "Do what you set out to do and let us be done with it..."

A big fight broke out between mother and the unfamiliar dragon. Mother lashed at the intruder with claw, tooth, tail and talon, yet the other dragon's skill was such that he seemed to be toying with her, as if to humiliate her as how weak she was compared to him. Kursed kept her head turned away, whimpering, while I could only watch with a sense of resignation.

Suddenly, Smaug shot out from the hiding place and raced forward to confront the strange dragon.

"Hey you!! I'm the male of this cave and if you want to go after my mom, you're going to have to go after me first!!" he roared at the top of his breath.

"Smaug!! No!!" I screamed, rushing forward.

I wasn't about to let Smaug get himself killed, so I jumped forward and snatched his tail with my jaw.

"Let me go sis!!" he snapped, beating at my face with his claw. Yet I wasn't going to let go...

Out of the corner of my eye, I spotted the outline of a tail blade descend upon the two of us. At that moment, I could only muse at how would be such a dumb way to die

Yet at the last moment, mother jumped in front of us. She let out a terrible shriek of pain as the tail blade slashed against her chest, literally showering us in her blood. Mother staggered on her feet for a few moments, before slumping belly first in front of us. I remember that my jaw was still clamped around Smaug's tail as this happened, while Smaug's jaw quavered, holding back tears as he glared up at the dragon. I also heard Kursed whine from the back of the room, curled into a ball. She was never meant to see such terrible things happen.

Mother's breathing was becoming increasingly ragged, as the intruder withdrew his tail blade. The intruder gazed at his own tail blade, watching it dripped with mother's blood.

"You know, it didn't have to end this way. You could have lived and shared in my power as my mate, but it seems like you chose death..." said the dragon to mother.

Mother's eyes were still defiant, as she tilted her neck to spit blood in his face.

Then, the dragons gaze switched toward Smaug and I. All my insticts screamed at me to cower, cry and shriek with fear, like Kursed was, yet I could not; that's not what mother would have wanted. Meanwhile, Smaug gazed up at the huge dragon, trembling with a combination of fear and awe at his power. We knew we were dead; the intruder had the only entranced blocked off.

"Please, leave my little ones alone..." gasped mother.

"Leave them alive? You are in no position to make demands of me now, and worse they also have his taint on them... You didn't think you'd be able to keep them away from me forever now did you?" he snarled.

"Bastard!!!" she strained.

"Perhaps I am, but since I am merciful, you will not have to see me kill your hatchlings in front of your eyes..." he said. With one quick motion, he slid his tail to her throat and slashed it out. Mother made a gurgling sound. And just like that, she was dead.

Strangely, I didn't feel anything at that moment. I didn't curl up and cry for my life, because I knew I was dead anyhow.

Then, something peculiar happened. To this day, I have trouble explaining why it happened, whether the gods wanted to play some game with us, or not, but just then...
15512111222.title: Skeletons under the nest

155121112221.content:
"So...y-you're going to kill us now aren't you?" said Smaug. Even now, at this grim moment, Smaug was still full of his insane and irrational bravado.

"Go ahead!! I'm not scared!! Not one bit!!" he shouted back. The dragon raised his claw, and I could remember my heartbeat slow down, and waiting for him to swipe and end it all.

"You are not even worth killing hatchling."

"What?" snapped Smaug, eyes widening.

"It would be far too easy to destroy you right now. Remember what you saw here tonight boy, that I, Shurikan of the Shadowtail Clan, killed your mother and father," he declared. Smaug glared at the large dragon, trembling with rage. Yet I sensed what angered him more was not that he'd killed both mother and father, but at the notion that he wasn't worthy of being killed. That he was nothing more than a hatchling rather than a full-grown dragon.

"Yes, you hate me don't you hatchling?" taunted Shurikan, "Then may I be the object of all your anger and your hatred, and once you grow up big and strong, I shall be waiting for you..."

At that moment, I watched with horror as Smaug's gaze shifted into a scowl. I could have sworn, that he was smiling.

"So, is that how its going to be then? Fine then. I'll remember this day, and once I grow up I'm coming for you and I'll destroy you," said Smaug.

Shurikan rumbled with amusement, "Will you now?"

"I will. So you better not dissappoint me then..." he said. There was absolute certainty in his voice. I only realize now what Shurikan was doing to my brother. My father had been a noble, proud dragon, or at least that's what I had seen with my newborn eyes and what mother had led us to believe in her stories (now looking back upon it, and having lived the life of a Shadow Dragon, he may very well have been as merciless), and what better way to tarnish father's legacy than ensuring that Smaug grew up to become just as evil, or even more so, than he was.

The big dragon grinned. "We shall see then."

Smaug's eyes narrowed. With that, he took off back into the storm, quickly fading out of sight. With that, our gazes switched back to the corpse of our mother.

Kursed finally emerged from her corner.

"Is the bad dragon gone?" she stammered. I nodded.

"I don't believe it..." I cried.

"She's...she's gone..."

I pressed my body against her, sniffing. Kursed was nearly beside herself though, "Its my fault that mother is dead Misty. If I hadn't lit that log, then we would have been safe!! Why!! Why!!"

"Its...its not your fault Kursed..." I tried to assure her, but I couldn't help but think otherwise.

"It doesn't matter now," snarled Smaug.

"How can you say such a thing?" I snorted. For all I knew, the thing that mattered more to Smaug was getting revenge on being slighted than mother.

"Look Mysteria, we all knew in the back of our minds that this was going to happen sooner or later. Mom's dead, and now we're on our own. So I'm not going to stand here and watch you two cry yourselves to death."

"But mother..." whimpered Kursed. Smaug made his way up to Kursed. Up until the day she died, Kursed was the only dragon that Smaug had a soft spot for.

"Kursed, there's nothing we can do for her anymore," said Smaug, "She wouldn't want us to stay here. We've got to move on, like we aways do..."

It was the same thing mom had said when small one and then our other brother had died.

"Y-you're right brother," she nodded, "We've got to move on... but...but..."

She curved her gaze back toward Smaug, "Her spirit, it must be in a better place now right?" she said.

"Of course she is..." he responded. Had he said no, Kursed likely would have broken right then and there. I hate admitting it now, but we both followed him at the time because when the worst possible thing that could have happened to us happened, Smaug was the only one who managed to stay focused and get us moving again.
155121112221.title: The circle of vengeance

choices: Led Kursed away along the coast
1551211122212.content:
I wanted to leave the cave instantly after Mother had been slain, but Kursed remained inconsolable and more, the storm outside was mounting into a typhoon. That night, we huddled in the corner of the cave that Mother had built for us where there had been nothing before. Kursed shivered and sobbed until dawn came, and by then, we were all so exhausted we fell into an uneasy and fitful sleep. Mother’s dragon-blood flowed across the floor slowly, and like mercury, it remained dense and fluid long after mortal blood would have coagulated. Years later, when I returned to the spot as a full fledged dragoness, I found that the blood had soaked into the stone itself, transforming the whole of the small cave into ruby studded granite where it had been merely brown sandstone before.

That day, however, I woke with a shock when my front paws became wet with her creeping blood. I couldn’t help myself. I shrieked and ran out of the cave, I saw blood, blood everywhere. Mother…

“Mysteria!” Smaug called after me, but I didn’t heed him. I flung myself outside, the cave no longer tolerable. Out on the shelf, despite the fact that it had to be midday, it was as dark as night. I slid across the wet stone as the gale pushed me to the side. I nearly went over the edge. Lightning struck the mountain less than a quarter mile away, rocks slid down the slope. The world had become a chaotic roiling of wind, water, earth and light, utterly unfamiliar. It seemed appropriate.

I looked over the edge of the cliff I was hanging on, it seemed almost a bottomless pit was under me. I stared for a long moment, the blackness calling to me, promising to erase the pain I felt, to bring me back to Mother. My grip on the cliff edge eased.

A strong claw, pulling me back. I fought it. I wanted to go over the edge, to fly for the first and only time. “Mysteria! Snap out of it!” Smaug’s voice was harsh as he tugged me back onto the shelf and threw me down onto the stone. He sat on me to keep me from fighting. I told him that wasn’t necessary, but he didn’t get up; he obviously wasn’t completely without a brain.

Despite the fact that the moments drew on and Smaug’s more than considerable weight slowly pressed the air out of my lungs, I couldn’t see the point in continuing. With Mother dead, there was nothing left, no hope. “You have no right to stop me, Brother!” I hissed.

“I can’t let you, Mysteria.” Said Smaug in my ear.

I growled, but he held my head down on the floor with a claw and my tail was entangled with his.

Then he leaned down to my head and said something that shocked me. “You can’t leave me and Kursed alone. It’s not fair.” I looked up then and saw Smaug’s heavy cut features framed against the thundering sky. His violet eye was fixed on mine with an intensity that matched the storm behind him. “She needs you, Mysteria.” He said again.

Straining against my brother’s weight, I tilted my head and saw Kursed watching us from the entrance to the cave where Mother’s body still lay cooling. Her eyes were wide and vapid, seeing, but unseeing, a mere shell. She’d die without a doubt if I were to take the easy way out. I sighed. Nothing for me, not even dying was to be easy.

With the floor saturated in Mother’s blood, the three of us were forced out into the storm, not even Smaug was apathetic enough to her demise to sleep in it. I hated to admit it to myself, but I let Smaug carry us through as we wandered down the mountain, seeking shelter. I was numb and exhausted after my attempt to take my life. Kursed… well, she wasn’t even there.

The mountainside was nothing but loose boulders and smooth sandstone. The waves crashed fifty feet into the air against the cliffs, so we moved further inland. The sea seemed intent on following us, however, rising with a jealous hunger to consume the lowlands. Animals fled or were drowned. At least we had no need to worry for food. Smaug, with his bulk and muscle proved to be an efficient windbreak while we were moving and always he went first, suffering the worst of the gales and chaotic winds which battered his body. I remembered seeing him take a boulder to his shoulder which made him stagger, but he said nothing of it and continued on as if nothing had happened. My brother seemed possessed by a spirit of purpose whereas before, he had appeared only vain, lazy and prideful to me. I wish I could have known the dragon my brother would have been had Mother survived.

We hiked all the way to the valley floor without finding any sort of cover suitable for three dragons. Though we were but hatchlings still, we were all very large creatures nonetheless. Before us, the sea had claimed new ground, the dry desert at the edge of the ocean was covered by sea surge. My brother looked at it as he had the dragon who’d killed mother: an opponent to be overcome and defeated.

“We’ll have to swim for it.” He said.

I was dumbfounded at his apparent change in stance on the topic of suicide. “Are you crazy, Smaug?”

My brother tilted his nose up at the cliffs we’d climbed down. “We all know there’s no shelter over here. We need to get away from this place.”

I’d never wanted to leave this place more than I did at that moment, but looking out to the churning waves then looked as sure a death as dropping from the cave shelf. I looked out along the water’s edge. “Why don’t we just follow the coast?”

Smaug glowered at me and in that moment, I saw the insanity which would one day overtake and destroy the brother I knew. He wanted to swim out there. Not because it was the easiest or the most sensible thing to do, but because it was the hardest. He felt a complex about proving himself that bordered on the insane. He turned away from me and Kursed. “I’m swimming.” He treaded out until he was knee deep in the sea water and turned his head back to us. His eyes were softer, that darkness gone for the moment, “Didn’t you ever want to see the other side of the valley?”

I felt my resolve weakening. Smaug promised to almost turn the misery of the world into an adventure. It was an escape that I desired intensely. Beside me, Kursed muttered, “M-misty…? Can we get out of the rain now?”

I wrapped my tail around her flank and hugged her close to me. “No, not yet, Kursed. We have more walking to do yet.” Facing Smaug again, who was lingering in the water, I…
1551211122212.title: Darkness Within

choices: Climb the mountain to the other side immediately
15512111222121.content:
"Look Mysteria," said Smaug. "I know you think I'm crazy wanting to swim across, but at least hear me out..."

"All right, tell me why we should get ourselves killed?" I snapped back.

"I know full well that it would be easier just to skirt along the coast, but if we always take the easier route, we're never going to get stronger. Because if you think its bad now, who knows how bad its going to be later on!!" he replied. He did have a point. Who knew what could be waiting later on the road. Perhaps it wouldn't be today, but down the line when we were older, that by challenging ourselves earlier we would survive a situation that we wouldn't have had we not taken the hard way.

Kursed stared at the water, trembling. "B-but I-I'm afraid of the water Smaug..." she whined.

I immediately expected Smaug to snap back at her, but he was sympathetic. "So am I Kursed... But that's why we're going to it!! Otherwise we'll be scared forever!!" he replied.

Kursed took a deep breath.

"Everythings going to be all right... We're going to make it. All three of us," he assured.

"If...if you say so brother," answered Kursed. Her trust in Smaug was absolute and total, perhaps as much as it was with mother. He could have told Kursed to jump off a cliff, and she would have done it with a smile.

"All right then. So follow me!!"

"You're going to be the death of me brother..." I snapped.

Smaug grinned. I hated the way he grinned like that. Yet worse than the churning waves and choppy seas was portraying myself as weak in front of Smaug. Thus we jumped our way out into the water.

We had learned how to swim, specifically, how to catch fish underwater. Yet that had always taken place during calm seas and under the close supervision of mother. Mother was gone, and tonight, the seas were anything but calm.

The biggest obstacle when crossing choppy seas wasn't necessarily being tossed about, trying to keep ones head above water, or any mere physical hazards, but fighting to keep from panicking. It was one thing to be scared, but once panic set in, you were done for. Smaug shot out in front, leading the way. I'd never seen him swim so fast, and I both admired and resented how much faster he was. I gritted my teeth as I blocked out the pain in my muscles, determined not to fall behind.

Yet I was most worried about Kursed. She struggled all the way through, and was never one that was high on will power. About halfway there, she grew tired, and then she panicked.

"Misty...I..c-can't..." wailed Kursed.

"Kursed!!" I screamed. I spun around to fetch her, but I was bracketed away by a wave. When I turned back, she was gone. Damn that Smaug!! Damn him!! Damn him!! Smaug had led her to her doom!! I felt absolutely helpless to do anything.

Yet then something happened that surprised me that day. Smaug turned back the way he came, and with no regard for his safety dove deep underwater. I waited. It was only about fifteen seconds, but it felt like forever. Finally, Smaug re-emerged at the surface carrying Kursed on his back. He gave me this look. This look that said he wasn't going to leave either of us behind, and how dare I think otherwise.

"I got you Kursed... Just hold on to me all right?" said Smaug. Kursed just nodded weakly. Thus, now Smaug had to brave the choppy seas while dragging Kursed. To my frustration, he was still faster than I was!! Yet I could not help but admire him at the same time. Because the easy thing to do would have been to let Kursed drown, but he hadn't.

Smaug would later tell me, that the harder you work, the luckier you get, and this time was the first instance of that statement coming into fruition. Not long after Smaug had saved Kursed from drowning, the storm began to peter out. The overwhelming deluge of rain slowed to merely a thunderstorm, what were once hurricane force winds slowed to merely a gale, and the tsunami like waves merely became choppy. While as before I had to fight for every stroke, I could now make my way forward with reasonable effort.

"Hey look everyone!!" said Kursed from Smaug's back, "I can see the coast!!"

I tilted my gaze up. The outline of the craggy coast could finally be seen, and thank goodness!!

"You see?" said Smaug, his smug confidence returned, "I told you we'd make it..."

I decided it was best not to comment at this remark.

At long last, we reached the other end of the shore. No sooner had I crawled ashore when I collapsed back first in complete exhaustion. Every part of my body hurt, in places I didn't know it could hurt, and even my non-existant wings hurt. Smaug and Kursed were sprawled next to me, equally exhausted. After about half an hour catching our breath, we all gazed back about the distance we had traversed.

"I can't believe we actually did it," I couldn't help but marvel.

"Yeah?" panted Smaug, "Well, we're still not out of trouble yet though, because look behind us..."

I did look. Now that the weather had cleared up to a mere grey, I could see all the way back to the other coast. I could see the outline of a few adult-sized dragons in the air, their gazes scanning about the coastline that I had suggested we traversed.

"Oh my goodness..." cried Kursed.

"That dragon who killed mother. He probably expected us to take the coastline," said Smaug.

My face blanched. Had we taken the coastline, we definitely would have been dead. Once again, Smaug had proved an uncanny ability to be right about these type of things.

"Yet why would that dragon be so interested as to send some of his minions just to kill us?" I wondered.

"I'd like to say its to test us, but there has to be another reason why..." replied Smaug.

"Like what?!" wailed Kursed, trembling.

"I don't know, but regardless of what it is," said Smaug, "I'm not sticking around to find out what it is, we've got to get moving..."

His gaze switched toward the mountain range we were now facing. That was the other side of the valley. It was a very steep climb, and after swimming across the ocean, I was so not willing to climb a mountain at this moment.
15512111222121.title: Follow me

choices: three weeks later, it's my turn.
155121112221212.content:
I fished a dead rabbit out of the water and gulped it down. The water steaming down my body and the chill of the blustery wind left me almost longing for the heat of the sun once again. It was night again, I supposed, though the cloud cover was still so dense it was hard to tell the difference. I was bone-tired for the journey we’d undertaken since Mother was taken from us, but I continued walking along the water’s edge, my thoughts as stormy and cold as the weather.

A shrew here, a fox kit there, the ground was littered with the corpses of the fallen and I fed on what I found. Back the way I’d come, I knew Smaug and Kursed were dining on a pregnant deer my brother had found wedged between two boulders. He probably had to force her to eat... Just like I forced myself to eat. I wasn’t hungry in the slightest, but growing up hungry had ingrained in me the instinct to take what I could when I could. Who knew when food would be available again. So I scavenged, no better than a common jackal or a vulture feeding on the dead in the wake of the devastating storm which was blowing itself out with as much speed as it’d come. But really, more than the meat, I was grateful for time to myself.

The concerns I’d felt earlier about Smaug flying seemed petty and childish now that Mother was dead, dead because she’d thrown herself in front of a blow meant for me and my brother. My sensibilities told me that she would have died in any case, but my heart felt like she died somehow because of my own mistakes. Perhaps if I’d extinguished Kursed’s log the moment I’d seen it... But who said that what happened had anything to do with the log? I’d spent a lot of time reflecting as I wandered apart from my siblings, but not out of sight of them, never out of sight. Were there any signs? How could Mother’s death have been prevented? What could I have done? But Mother’s death had simply fallen out of the sky, delivered by a dragon I’d never met before and knew nothing about. ‘Shadowtooth clan...’ I’d thought then. By the Ancestors, I wish I’d never heard of the name, or that I’d forgotten it as soon as I’d heard it.

My breath rattled in my throat, and I moaned, feeling the stone under me. I was conscious again. How long had I been lost in memories? It didn’t matter. My hearts fluttered weakly, my legs felt like they were made of stone. The pain... I was dying, and unlike the last time, there was no one left to save me. I wanted to weep, but my eyes were closed and I didn’t want to see, didn’t want to feel anymore. I felt myself slipping again. Good. I prayed I would stay under again permanently. My life had been tragic, but it was still better than... this. I thought I heard something move on the stone, but I was falling, falling away from that place.

On the third day after we’d swam across the valley, Smaug’s wings emerged. There was supposed to be a grand ceremony, but none of us knew the ritual. Instead, it had begun with my brother itching his rear end against a spiky tree.

We were high up in the mountains. The peak that we’d recently traversed behind us. It felt good having that sheltering bulk behind us, shielding us from the dragons we’d seen flapping about the coast and from the memories of our old home. The night sky was clear and the mountainside was blanketed with grass and violet desert flowers taking advantage of the recent deluge. With danger less imminent, Smaug was a little less intense, though he remained changed from the vain slacker he’d been before. With his support and mine, Kursed was a little more lively as well, though she remained depressed and didn’t speak much, just like I was depressed and didn’t speak very much; though that was more of a natural state for me.

“Great Gyramond.” cursed my brother, referring to the mythical father of dragonkind. “I feel like I have fire ants under my skin!”

I watched with a prude disgust as Smaug rubbed his backside against the tree, his tail twitching with obvious pleasure.
