The exposed grey skin on his back had grown to bulbous, translucent sacs which were hot to the touch... not that I wanted to touch them. They were weeping a clear, stinking fluid.

“Don’t be an idiot, Smaug.” I said, striding up to him, unable to watch anymore. “You’re fledging.”

Smaug ceased his rubbing and turned his head around to glance at his back. “You think so, Mysteria? You think it’s time?”

“Mother said that when they start to itch, it’s time.” I said.

Smaug grunted approval and continued to look at the disgusting sacs which welled up between the scales to either side of his spine. He stared at them, at the promise of what they held, with a mixture of hunger and... perhaps simmering rage. Then he brought his head back around and he was again the idiot that I remembered, “Um... what do I do now?”

I scoffed and turned my head away, laughing. “You mean you don’t know?” I hadn’t the slightest idea either, but I enjoyed the look on his broad face.

“Please tell me, Mysteria. Oh how they itch! I can’t stand it!” He resumed his scratching, but couldn’t angle his back very well against the tree trunck. Howling, he then rolled over onto his back, squirming in the grass. I thought that the sacs on his back would surely burst under my brother’s weight, but they didn’t and even as I watched, I saw that Smaung was even beginning to weep with his discomfort. I suddenly was not so anxious for my own fledging.

Kursed came up then, from further down the slope. She cocked her head, looking at Smaug rolling and tossing on the flowery meadow. She glanced at me and raised an eye-ridge. I smiled back at her and shrugged. I was enjoying the spectacle. My sister strode forward to end my fun. “Smaug, what’s the matter with you? Don’t tell me you’ve gotten scale-rot.”

“No, Kursed.” said Smaug, still writhing with his back on the ground. “My wings are coming it, but it burns and itches and Mysteria won’t help me! Arrgh!”

Kursed shot me a look and clicked her tongue. “Stand up, brother.”

Smaug did, but his legs were shaking with the compulsion to scratch.

“All you have to do is rub them against something sharp. Here let me...” said Kursed. I watched with avid interest as Kursed raised a claw and swiped it down Smaug’s back. Smaug moaned with absolute pleasure as the translucent skin split bloodlessly and Kursed was showered with an amber fluid that gushed out. It was fairly odorless, but I was intensely satisfied that I was standing off to the side. Smaug was left was a gaping wound in his back, but inside, I could see black scales shining, and more, boney digits and black leather.

“Ugh...” Kursed shivered, saturated with the slippery fluid from Smaug’s back, but she said, “N-now, pull your wing out. It needs to dry... and so do I.” she said the last in a small voice.

“Sorry Kursed.” said Smaug, but the grin he was wearing was anything but sorry. “Lemme give it a try...” And I watched as he twisted his face with effort and I saw twitching in the wound in his back. The wing emerged with a sloppy, halting gait and while it made a sucking, squirting noise as it did, it was the most amazing thing I’d ever seen. In moments, my brother went from a flightless, wingless lizard to a winged male dragon. To my utter surprise, seeing him with his - extremely - large wing extended into the light breeze, he suddenly seemed quite handsome, the single talon at the joint had a shape that nicely complimented the nest of horns on his head. I shook my head, clearing my thoughts. Smaug was still but half a dragon at the moment.

The wing membrane was pulled out after the wing and when it was fully extended, it pulled the wound in his back shut, like a reversed pocket. Kursed hopped up and down with excitement for the first time since Mother died. “Great job, Smaug. You’ll make a handsome dragon yet!”

Smaug beamed at Kursed’s praise and he angled his wing in the wind, feeling it as if for the first time. “That feels so nice... Hey Kursed, would you mind doing the other-”

Kursed laughed, “No thanks, brother. You’re on your own now.”

He looked at me pleadingly and I stuck my tongue out at him. A dragon should be able to handle himself. And Smaug did, probably too well in the end.
155121112221212.title: Wings

1551211122212122.content:
The three of us continued our trek through the mountains. Smaug of course, boasted about his new wings the entire time, to the point where even Kursed began to find it annoying. However, growing wings and flying were two different things entirely. For the first week, Smaug was having trouble maintaining his balance, or wary that he accidentally wouldn't get his wing talon hooked around a tree or a rock, never mind hovering a foot off the ground. It was apparent that he wasn't going to be flying anytime soon, or else Smaug's head would have exploded from an acute case of overinflation of ego.

No sooner did Smaug's wings emerge, when my back began to furrow as well. For a while, I celebrated that fact, at the notion that soon I would no longer had to gaze at Smaug with jealousy. That is, until my back also began to itch. It was every bit as agonizing as Smaug had described, not that Smaug was at all sympathetic to my plight.

"Come on Mysteria, suck it up!! It can't itch that badly..." grunted Smaug, with a dismissive wave of his wing.

"Oh...who was the one crying for us to help you a couple of weeks before?" I snarled back testily.

"And I'm sure you got a good laugh out of that. Now, I get to laugh at you now," taunted Smaug. Truthfully, had he suddenly decided to be generous, I would have refused because my pride wouldn't have let me, not to mention I would have thought something was wrong.

"No need to be so upset Misty," said Kursed, smiling indolently. "I'm sure you'll have such beautiful wings."

I wasn't sure whether to blush or wince at the corniness of her last statement. Speaking of which, Kursed's back too was starting to furrow now, but it would still be about at least a week before she began to itch. In a way, I privately admitted I was relieved that I wasn't the last one who would grow their wings, and had that been the case it probably would have bothered me a lot.

Smaug made this face.

"Anyhow, we should probably find somewhere to rest soon," said Smaug.

I couldn't help but agree. That way I could find somewhere to scratch to my hearts content.

"-we also still don't know what's out there so its important that we..."

Suddenly, I heard the ever so subtle shifting of rock. I couldn't tell if it came from behind us or from the side, but my hearts began thumping. While we were still preoccupied with the emergence of our wings, of greater importance was that since we had cleared the peak, we had no idea exactly where we were going. These lands were unknown to our clan, never mind a group of fledglings living on their own for the first time. For all we knew, the mountain range seemed to extend to infinity. And thus, like the fledglings we were without a guide, we ended up stumbling into a situation we hadn't prepared for.

"Quiet!! There's creatures about!!" snarled Smaug.

I kept my mouth shut as quiet as I could. Now, looking back upon it, I realized why that few dragons ever dared ventured to the mountain range that lay beyond the valley. Mother always warned us that a whole myriad of vile creatures dwelled in those mountains, the most dangerous of which were the orcs. They weren't especially large creatures, yet they were said to be a numerous, savage and primitive race of beings that had a taste for draconic blood. Of course, the three of us dismissed these as nonsense, as yet another reason for Mother to keep us compliant, but we found out that night there was truth behind that rumor.

Yet my itch continued to stab at me like daggers. My eyes teared up, as my instincts screamed at me to relieve that itch at any cost.

"I can't stand it anymore!!" I hissed, as I tumbled to the dirt and began scratching incessantly. I instantly regretted my impulse. Emerging out from behind boulders, grass and trees were these horrid looking creatures. There were about twenty of them in total. These creatures, possessed gray, wrinkled, rotting looking skin, clad in various fur torn off the bodies of animals, and sharp horns. They snarled at us with rotting teeth, thrusting their weapons at us threateningly

"I told you to stay quiet didn't I?" hissed Smaug.

"Shut up!!" I snapped, with anger mixed with shame. Smaug probably would have done the same, or at least that's what I told myself.

"What are we going to do?" whined Kursed.

They were all around us. We had to make a decision soon, because if we just stood there, that would be the end of us.
1551211122212122.title: For want of an itch

choices: Wait it out for a while for the orcs to pass through
15512111222121222.content:
The first fundamental rule when dealing with orcs, was that if one could see twenty orcs, that meant in reality there were something like two thousand. No sooner had we spotted the initial twenty, when we spotted the shadow of several more.

"Well, there seems to be quite a lot of them don't there?" said Kursed, sounding strangely detached and releasing a hollow giggle. Again, that was one of her mechanisms for dealing with fear.

For moment, Smaug unfurled his wings as if he were ready to take them all on by himself, but after nudging his head with my claw, he thought better of it.

"Right...lets get out of here!!" shouted Smaug.

Thus, we fled, fled for our lives. There is nothing like that wrenching feeling in ones gut, that combination of panic and the knowledge of being the hunted, when being chased by an entire horde of mindless, bloodthirsty orcs, charging forward without absolutely no regard for their own lives; a monstrous unstoppable tsunami of primitive rage and hate. For the first time, I knew what being prey felt like. And to these monsters, that's what we were. Meat.

We searched frantically for any pathway of escape.

"Over there!!!" cried Smaug.

Up ahead there was a narrow crevice that the three of us would barely be able to fit through. It wasn't the safest thing to do by any stretch, but at the very least we would be able to funnel them through a tight spot where their numbers would be more manageable.

"Kursed you first!!" said Smaug. Yet at that moment, Kursed stiffened into a babbling panic. As we had approached the crevice, she had taken that moment to curve her head back and face the horde that was rapidly closing in. It had happened at the worst possible time.

"Dammit!!" he snarled. He literally had to push Kursed through the opening, where she was shocked back to her senses. I immediately tried to follow, but I was greeted by a loud crash. I careened backwards and gazed toward the crevice, only to find that my escape was blocked off by a boulder!! A boulder of all things.

"Misty!!" screamed Kursed voice from the other side. "No!!"

I pounded the boulder a few times. It defied my efforts.

I curved my head and peered through the crack. Kursed had burst into a fit of hysterics, and even Smaug looked ready to panic. It was one of the few times I had ever seen Smaug indecisive.

"Smaug!! Get Kursed out of there now!!" I yelled at the top of my breath.

"You promise that you won't die on me now sis?" said Smaug.

"I'll find a way out!!" I cried back. Smaug could only nod numbly, before pulling my wailing sister away. Of course, I knew I was fooling myself. Not for the first, and not for the last time, I fully expected to die right then and there. Now, the horde was getting closer and closer. They could sense a meal. Frantically I made my way away from the crevice, trying to draw them away from Kursed and Smaug.

Then, I remembered my wings. Maybe I could fly!! Maybe, during this moment of danger, my wings would snap open and I'd be able to gracefully soar away from the orcish horde!! I strained my back as hard as I could.

"Open you damn things!!" I screamed. Yet no matter how hard I tried, they wouldn't obey me. Eventually, the horde cornered me against the face of a cliff. They quickly formed a semi-circle around me. I bent down and faced them.

"If you want a meal, then you're going to have to fight for it!!" I yelled. Once again, I found myself feeling strangely unafraid, knowing that my death was inevitable.

"Hey!! Look up here you idiots!!" cried an unfamiliar voice.

I did look up. There was a dragon. Or rather, that was the first time I ever saw him. He was a male dragon, and couldn't have been much older than I was, if at all. In his grasp was an orc covered head to toe with blood.

"You want meat!! Go get it then!!" he called out. With his claw, he tossed the still living orc into the middle of the horde of orcs. Immediately, the orcs spun away from me. I was then greeted by one of the most terrifying sights in my life. The orcs let out a collective, heart-wrenching sound, a terrible, screeching noise such that it would make a small hatchling lose all hope for life, as they turned upon each other for this piece of meat. I almost felt sorry for the orcs as his blood and guts flew in all directions, literally being eaten alive by the others. Then, as that orc's blood got splattered in all directions and splashed onto those orcs closer to them, those unfortunate orcs too became prey, until the horde degenerated into a chaotic mass of slaughter, as every orc became consumed into destroying themselves.

"What are you waiting for? Get out of there!!" said the dragon.

I turned away from the slaughter, concentrating on keeping my jaw shut as I made my way toward where the dragon was perched. I merely followed the unfamliar dragon, still shaken by what I had seen, until we reached this small cavern.

"Shouldn't you have known better than to be out and about during one of the orcs' blood runs?" the dragon growled.

I gazed at him with a quavering eye. "Blood runs?" I stammered, having never heard the term. Yet what frightened me more was the way the dragon put it into context, making it sound like something as common as the changing of the season.

"You're...not from around here are you?" he said.

I shook my head. "Me and my siblings came from the other side of the mountain. We'd never thought that orcs were anything more than a rumor to scare naughty hatchlings until now..."

He looked ready to laugh out loud, but unlike Smaug, he seemed to think better of it.

"Well, then you're lucky to be alive then," said the dragon.

I couldn't help but nod.

"If you haven't already noticed, the orcs have a taste for dragon blood. More accurately, if they don't drink dragon blood, they suffer for it. Every so often, the orcs work themselves up into a bloodlust, consuming everything in their path."

"Then how were you able to get them to turn on each other?"

"Easy," he answered. He showed me a small cut he'd made on his tail. "I covered an orc with some of my blood and threw it out in their path, and then their lusts get the better of them..."

I stared at the dragon for a long while. "Thank you for saving me, I don't know how I would managed to escape otherwise..."

He let out a snort. "Just don't do anything dumb like that again," he replied, sounding Smaug-like. "Anyhow, you said that you were traveling with your siblings?"

"Yes. Smaug and Kursed. I think they're safe though," I answered, or at least I hoped. Thinking about them made me think about what triggered the orcish blood run in the first place. Of course, my back decided that it would suddenly start itching like crazy again. I turned back toward the dragon that had helped me, and I felt more embarassed than I had ever felt in my life.

"Could you, you know..." I stammered, unable to say anything else.

"Ummm.... if you say so..." he replied, suddenly looking extremely nervous. His claw reached for my back as if he were ready to reach into a pile of orc blood. He sliced on the membrane slowly. I expected to splash all over his face like it had with Smaug, but he was very good with working with his claws. He then slowly worked his claw on my other wing. Afterwards, he stepped backwards to give me space.

With that, I opened my wings for the first time. It was a sweet feeling, a liberating feeling, and the cool, sweet rush of air against its twin black membranes. As for the other dragon, I could feel him gaze at me with a sense of wonder and awe. Nobody had ever gazed at me like that before...

"You know, I don't think I've introduced myself yet," said the dragon. "I'm Wyrrach..."

I couldn't help but smile. "Mysteria..." I responded.

At that moment, I felt as elated as I ever had. So much so that I broke into a song.

In the sky, what do you see
A dragon soaring, swift and free
Up above she sings a call
And all the world wish they were she...

--------------------------------------------------

Even now, at this final moment, it makes my heart shudder. The day I gained my wings, the day I met him. Of all the bad things that had happened thus far in my miserable life, and the calamities that were to follow, this was one of the few happy days that stand out. And in all those dark moments, they stand out all the brighter.

"Wyrrach..." I sighed silently, "I knew in the end you were too good to be true..."

I wept...
15512111222121222.title: Flee and be free!!

choices: Try to rescue Wyrrach's brother from the orcs
155121112221212221.content:
"So, this is where you got separated from your siblings?" said Wyrrach, pointing at the boulder.

"Yeah, Smaug and Kursed passed through there after one of the orcs dropped a boulder in its path..." I said.

"One moment..."

He breathed a small plumb of fire onto the boulder, getting it heated. After a while, he then slapped at it with his claw. The tough granite rock broke apart like it was made of sandstone.

"You heat it up and the bonds that keep the rocks together get weaker, and then all you need to do is give it a tap and you're through..." said Wyrrach. I couldn't help but feel deeply impressed, and I did get the notion that he was making an active effort to impress me.

"So where does this crevice go?" I asked.

"Its a secret entrance that leads to my cave. I'm almost certain that your siblings are there. I've always used it to escape the orcs, but since I've just gained my wings I don't think we'd be using it much longer," he explained. The crevice led upwards to a short, but rather steep mountain.

"Careful Mysteria, the sides are kept smooth so that the orcs have no chance of climbing it, so it might be trickier than what you're used to..." he explained.

"You doubt my climbing ability?" I replied. I didn't sound as annoyed as, say, if Smaug had said it.

"Not at all..." he answered. However, if Smaug and Kursed did come through this way, I could imagine Kursed having an accident. We reached the top. I spotted Kursed and Smaug inside, Kursed looking very shaken and Smaug doing his best to keep him encouraged.

"You first..." said Wyrrach, hanging from the cliffs edge. I ascended over the ridge and headed inside. I was immediately greeted by Kursed as she ran out to greet me.

"Misty!!!" screamed Kursed with hysterical relief, pressing her head against mine, "You're all right!!"

"I'd told you I would make it didn't I?" I answered, spreading my wings a little.

"Oh!!" cried Kursed, her eyes as wide as saucers leaning backwards a bit, "Your wings!! They're so pretty!!"

I couldn't help but curve my head away bashfully.

"Oh, did he help you get them out?" said Kursed with intrigue.

I quickly introduced Wyrrach to Kursed, and explained how he'd rescued me from the orcs and then led me back here. Yet Smaug didn't look impressed, in fact, he was fuming from the nostrils.

"Yes, yes, you think you're such a bigshot aren't you? Thinking you can just come in here like you own the place," growled Smaug. Wyrrach's gaze immediately snapped toward Smaug, and the two rose up on their haunches and stepped toward each other until their faces only about a foot away from each other, as if trying to melt the other with his glare. Their puffed their chests outwards, wings arched over their heads, growls emerging from their throats as they sized each other up.

"In fact, I'll have you know that I live here, so you're my guest. I take it that you're Mysteria's brother Smaug right?" said Wyrrach, his gaze not moving one bit.

"Yes... that's right. Now what was your name again?" answered Smaug.

"Wyrrach. Though I thought you'd be more grateful after I saved your sister from the orcs..." he retorted.

"Right...right..." answered Smaug, looking as if he'd rather eat his own dung than admit it. "I also see you've taken the opportunity to open Mysteria's wings."

"Oh? So you've only just noticed? I fail to see how this would offend you so much Smaug," retorted Wyrrach. Smaug only made a resentful rumbling noise as he shifted his body a little more erect.

"Misty, they're acting really weird..." said Kursed, curving her head next to mine. I couldn't help but sniff in agreement. I had expected it out of Smaug, but considering how mature Wyrrach had acted around me earlier, not out of him as well.

"It seems that once males grow their wings, they begin strutting around like they're Gyrimond himself," I growled.

Kursed and I could only watch with a preverse fascination as they began aruging over who was the better digger, the number of animals they could kill during a single hunt, who could climb faster and other rather petty things. While it was humorous for a while, I decided that enough was enough.

"Anyhow, Wyrrach, since you're around here maybe you can explain to us all about the orcs, and where we are..."

Smaug grunted resentfully. More than anything else, he hated being in a position where he was not fully in control.

"You wonder how this cave is big enough to fit all of us? Well, I used to live here with my mother and father. All the hatchlings from my clutch died, so they decided to have another when I was still very small, and the hatchlings from that clutch died except for my younger brother Vador. Anyhow, one day, our parents just dissappeared, which left only the two of us."

"Wait, you said you had a younger brother?" I said, "Yet that can only mean..."

I feared I knew the reason why... Wyrrach scratched his claw against the ground, "An orc raiding party came and snatched him away only a few days ago. Now its only me..."

"Oh...I'm sorry," I answered.

Yet Smaug wasn't at all sympathetic. "Coward..." he snarled.

"What did you call me!!" retorted Wyrrach.

"That's right, I called you a coward. You said that they captured your brother, but that has to mean that you saw them take him am I right?"

"There's nothing that I could have done..."

"That's bull crap. You don't know that for sure don't you? Since you know the land so well, if you cared at all for your younger brother you would have at least tried to rescue him wouldn't you? Something doesn't seem right about your story..." accused Smaug. He always had a knack at exposing these kind of things, and did so in a way that made you feel like a complete wretch afterward.

Wyrrach didn't have a response for a moment. "All right, here's what really happened. I got angry at him for being a brat while I was scratching my wings out and I told the little prick to run off and see how he liked it off on his own. I saw him crawl off from my perch and get lost in the woods, and I watched him get captured by the orc raiding party and get stuffed in a cage and get dragged away. I thought he deserved getting the shit scared out of him for an entire night, with orcs threatening to suck his blood out, and make him regret being such an asshole to me. Of course, I thought I'd be able to just go after those few orcs and destroy them before they got too far, but that's when I spotted that orc bloodlust raiders approaching, so I panicked and scurried back to the cave like a coward. There, that's what really happened then. Are you happy I said it then Smaug? Go and rub it in my face with your claw..."

Smaug did look satisfied indeed. Yet not even he was callous enough to rub it in at the moment. I did feel bad for Wyrrach though. That he may well have cast his brother to his doom because of a stupid fit of rage.

"Maybe we can work together to get him back?" I suggested.
155121112221212221.title: Now, its four of us

choices: They're about to kill Wyrrach's brother
1551211122212122211.content:
Wyrrach winced in surprise, as if the idea had not occurred to him until now.

“Get him back? A-are you serious?” he cried out.

To my utter surprise, it was Smaug of all dragons who offered his erstwhile rival sympathy. “Look Wyrrach. We know what its like to lose family. I don’t know about you but I’m not about to let those beasts do whatever they want to us,” he snarled, scratching his claws against the rock. I was in concurrence as well, yet I suspected that Smaug didn’t truly care whether Wyrrach’s brother died or not. To him, freeing a hatchling from the clutches of the orcs was but a challenge to increase his own power, but the thing about Smaug was that he could make others think that he cared.

I was quick to bring caution into the air. “I very much doubt that the orcs are just going to stand there like goats and allow us to kill them. We need to know where they are headed first and then decide how to get him out.”

Wyrrach raised his head, “I’ve dealt with orcs all my life so I’ll definitely be able to track them. We can catch up to them in a few days if we were to go at a reasonable pace. They’ll probably be at a campsite of some sort. Though they do see reasonably well in the dark, most of them will be sleeping anyhow, and that’s when we can attack to rescue Vador!!”

I nodded in agreement. While Smaug was definitely a superior fighter, Wyrrach was a far better planner.

Smaug unfurled his wings, “Why don’t we just fly there!! It’ll be faster!!”

Kursed lowered her head, somewhat shamefully, “I still can’t fly unfortunately…”

“We could leave her behind…” sniffed Smaug. Kursed shivered, looking deeply hurt. She was well aware of the fact that out of the four of us, she was the weakest.

“I-I know I’m not as strong or brave as you are brother, but I can still help out!! I’m not helpless!!” Kursed insisted. Her forcefulness surprised Smaug, but nonetheless appeared to be against it.

I stepped forward before Smaug could say anything more about leaving Kursed behind, “Smaug, we have to stay together, besides, I don’t think we’d be able to fly there anyhow, as none of us had our wings until very recently and I’ve seen your first few futile attempts at flight.”

Smaug ground his teeth, yet he did not argue with that fact. We would likely need an extra set of claws and teeth.

“Furthermore,” cried Wyrrach, “Even if we were confident fliers, they’d be that much more likely to see us. The orcs expect dragons to attack from the sky and have prepared themselves as such. If they do, they’d know we’d be after Vador and they’d kill him before we’d be able to get to him.”

Smaug looked as if he would rather eat his own shit, but he relented.
“Fine…we’ll go with your plan Wyrrach…” he snarled through gritted teeth. I could detect only the slightest hint of a smirk on Wyrrach’s jaw, before return to its usual serious expression.

“Very well then. Follow me, we have no time to waste…” he gestured.

The three of us followed Wyrrach down a series of winding mountain paths. Orc footprints were scattered, leading to all directions, but Wyrrach was able to pick up the right one by picking out his brother’s scent amongst the others. Once more, I found myself deeply impressed by Wyrrach’s instinctive knowledge of the land; he knew where all the hunting spots were, where the water was, places to rest a few hours during the day and spots to stay out of sight.

Before long, we spotted what looked to be an orc encampment. By the looks of it, there seemed to be anywhere from forty up to a hundred of them. Certainly that was no small number, but not insurmountable for a group of four young dragons, especially if we had the advantage of surprise. At the edge of my vision, I could see a reddish-black hatchling being kept in a cage at the center of the camp, looking fearful and lonely.

“All right…” said Wyrrach with a whisper, “It looks like they haven’t spotted us. We’ll stay close to the ground and get up as close as we can.”

Yet just when we were about to move out, there was an unexpected development…
1551211122212122211.title: Planning

choices: Tell the orcs to serve us now
15512111222121222112.content:
The orcs began bellowing more of their gibberish, and things grew more alarming as the chief raised what looked to be his war axe into the air. The small caged dragon whimpered with fear as the orcs began dancing around their leader, about to perform some kind of ritual.

“We need to move now,” snapped Smaug. Like that, he took off, and expected everybody to follow him. I found myself rushing straight behind him; Smaug had already led us this far and he had an aura of personality and perhaps, a bit of fear of what would happen if I didn’t follow him. Kursed came by afterwards; if Smaug told her to jump off a cliff she would do so with a smile. Even Wyrrach, who I already suspected didn’t have as much favor for Smaug, came forward, if for no other reason that he wanted to save his brother.

It was shockingly easy how quickly the orcs died before our claws and acid. As I clawed and rended and slaughtered it was strangely empowering, like being caught in a red haze as orc blood splattered everywhere. Yet Smaug took to the slaughter with a gusto that was both awe-inspiring and frightening, throwing himself into the thickest of action without regard to his safety. The orc chieftain posed a bit more of a threat, but this did not stop Smaug, in fact, it had only seemed to excite my brother, as he took a special pleasure in slaughtering him with particular violence. In fact, Smaug literally ate the orc chieftain raw and swallowed right in front of Wyrrach’s brother, and then let out a feral roar at what he had done.

"The camp is secured for now," said Wyrrach, considerably calmer and even keeled, staring with distaste at Smaug's tactics.

"Ha! Was that it?" scoffed Smaug, "I was expecting more..."

"That's enough Smaug," I cried, "We came out what we set to do, lets get Wyrrach's brother out."

Meanwhile, Vador had stared at Smaug with something approaching reverence and awe.

"Wow!! By the Ancestors that was totally awesome!!" he cried, gazing up at Smaug.

"This is only the beginning," said Smaug, as he broke the cage open and pried him out, "Soon, this entire land will be ours and all will bow down to us."

Let it be said that Smaug never thought small, and this was but the beginning of his quest for absolute power. At the time, I believed it was because that he wanted to avenge the death of mom by becoming powerful enough to destroy her killer, but what I didn't know was that wasn't the reason at all.

"Smaug!! There's more of them!!" cried Kursed with concern. I switched my gaze over the ridge, and indeed, there was perhaps an entire army of orcs coming at them. Ancestors, there was more, there were always more; far more than dragons could conceivably slaughter.

"Ancestors!! Lets get out of here while we can!!" cried Wyrrach.

"Don't be a coward!! We can wipe them all out!!" insisted Smaug. Already, both Smaug and Wyrrach were arguing, as males were wont to do - arguing over dominance. I had to speak up to break the deadlock, as otherwise, nothing would get done.

"Wait, I think I have an idea!!" I cried.
15512111222121222112.title: They're about to kill Wyrrach's brother

155121112221212221123.content:
Thoughts were swirling in my mind as I was faced with fighting perhaps a thousand orcs. But I was flushed with the recent combat and still tasted the orcs' black blood on my lips. We were five strong now, five dangerous young dragons and my venomous spray was not nearly tapped yet. Between my claws, my long tail and even my wings, I did not feel too threatened with my siblings and Wyrrach and Vador alongside me. "Will that blood trick work here again, Wyrrach?"

The young black and red stripped dragon looked up at the gathering horde which was spreading along the tops of the surrounding hills to surround us. "Perhaps, but they do not have the look of mindlessness about them this time. They're at least attempting to surround us." Valor pressed against his older brother, unlike Kursed his back was far from blistering and he was smaller by at least 50 stone, still head and shoulders over the head of an orc though.

"It doesn't matter." scoffed Smaug. He tossed his head at the corpses strewn about the camp around us. "Look how easily we can slaughter this vermin." As if to emphasize the point, he scooped up half a carcass and shoveled it down his maw, his muscular neck bulging.

"It's not wise to fight on a full stomach..." remarked Wyrrach. "It makes you slow and vulnerable should it come back up."

Smaug glowered at the other male, lifting his head and spreading his ruff. Meanwhile, the orcs were beginning to descend towards us now. Some stopped and began launching sticks towards us, but neither of the big males paid attention.

I stepped between them, slapping their snout with both of my wings. "You two can mount each other all you like after this is done!"

Smaug growled rough agreement and turned towards the approaching humanoids who were beginning to charge now, their shouts filling the night. "Sis is right. Let's kill this scum. Besides, I'm still hungry..."

Wyrrach let his distain for my brother show openly on his face, but turned to face the opposite direction at yet more angry orcs. I faced north and Kursed took her position south. Valor was left to fill what space he could and at the center of us, our tails mingled, but not for long as we raised them over our heads and shoulders for stabbing.

The night was a long mechanical grind of bloodshed and screams and roars and death. Despite their thirst for dragon blood, the orcs were not equipped with weapons which might have threatened us, not a one of them had a pole arm. The never got close enough to hack us with their axes and spiked clubs. I'm not sure at all why they rushed so eagerly to their deaths and towards dawn, I was filled more with pity for the sad creatures than anger. They kept coming, but slowly, their numbers faded, their strength totally ineffective against our scales our assorted weapons and deadly breath. Valor hung back, perhaps the only one of us really vulnerable, while Smaug practically charged forward after a while, seeking the thickest patches of orcs to lay into, as if he were jumping into a living pool of rapidly rended meat.

I watched Wyrrach hang back, slightly surprised to seem him so laconically handing out death, that is, until towards the end, he took to the air and began rounding up the stragglers from the surrounding hills, forcing them towards us and preventing their escape. Even Kursed fought elegantly, frequently skewering orcs on the end of her tail and flinging their bodies into still others. For myself, I grew bored of the killing despite nearly falling to their hands just over a day ago.

As the sun rose, we were all moving more slowly, but the remaining orcs no longer rushed us. In fact, it was all Wyrrach could do to keep them from bolting in all directions. We had moved almost half a mile from where the slaughter had begun and near the end, we had rounded up the last batch of orcs and cornered them in a small, wet gully.

Smug lay on the ground disinterested. He'd gorged himself and though he hadn't vomited as Wyrrach had warned, he seemed lethargic now, perhaps even vulnerable if the rest of us hadn't been there. Valor surprisingly stepped forward. "Let me get in there. One big blast of venom and they should be melted or dead for good."

Wyrrach landed with a thud next to him and slumped his head in exhaustion. "As you wish, brother..." I was sure that he hadn't actually heard what Vador had proposed.

As Vador went forward to finish the wretches, I checked him with my shoulder. "Maybe we can find a better use for them."

"What use are they other than food?" asked Wyrrach who finally bent his head to feast on a fallen orc.

I was slightly at a loss myself, but I felt sure now that I had bother to speak up. "Perhaps they can be trained."

"Train orcs? Like to sit and fetch?" laughed Kursed. The battle lust had already left her I noticed.

"Among other things..." I said, brushing myself against my sister. I was covered in grim, but felt the need for contact. She giggled again. "Let us make them our thralls. They crave dragon blood already and they have been humbled. They fear us. We can culture that fear."

"What good are a bunch of stinking orcs going to do us?" Cried Vador, still obviously upset at his recent imprisonment. "Let us end them now!"

I had to check him again with my tail, just like my mother once did to me. He whimpered, but Wyrrach did not move to defend him. I felt a keener regard for the winged drake at that moment. "Think about it." I said, turning to each of them. "We have no clan and these are not the only orcs in this area. This is just one horde we have dispatched." I gestured to Smaug and Wyrrach in turn. "We don't have the energy to keep doing this. But if we can make the orcs war against one another, perhaps we can have some peace, at least until we can grow up."

Smaug only grunted, "Do as you wish, sister." He seemed ready to drop into sleep where he lay. Wyrrach looked at me, his brown eyes meeting mine. I wanted to know more about his mysterious red markings, to touch them...

"Did you hear me?" he asked.

I shook my head. "Sorry."

"I said, that I think it's worth trying. One of us should go down there and see if we can subjugate them."

"It's pointless. They're barely more than food beasts." said Vador, seething, but the small drake sensed that this was not his decision.

We did not vote on who would go down to face the last of the orcs. I turned my back on the party and padded down the slope, my paws quickly damp and muddy with the stream at the bottom.

The orcs did not face me as warriors, rather they seemed resigned to their fate. I sat down and curled my tail about me, really studying them for the first time. I noticed that I had not yet seen a visually female version of the orc and I recalled something that had squirreled its way into the back of my mind. A song from my mother:
Silly drakka chase the greenskin
To rip and tear and take their meat in
Silly drakka grows sleepy one morn,
Unaware that their spilled blood grows more.

So that is why they fled here, where the ground is moist. I remembered that orcs grow from the ground, which explained their various sizes and why they were so careless with their lives. It also explained why no dragons had bothered settling this region. It must be soaked in orc spores. I switched to pigeon Drakine, a very simple language and spoke to the gathered orcs. "Do any of you speak?"
155121112221212221123.title: Birth of a Clan

1551211122212122211231.content:
"Yes... I h-h-hear you speak... great lizard thing..." said an orc. Now that the orc was before me, he truly seemed pitiful and helpless.

"Good," I answered.

"You have seen what happens when you attempt to hunt one of us. Only absolute destruction awaits. If you oppose us, you will be rendered as nothing more than fodder. Know that we can slaughter you all whenever we please, and that attempting to oppose us is futile," I said.

The orc before me continued to shiver, completely catatonic.

“P-p-please,” it begged, “Let live… me no want to die…”

I had to admit, I rather enjoyed the sense of absolute power I had over this creature and the all-encompassing fear it had of us; that it knew how helpless it was before me and that I could manipulate and control its entire pitiful existence, far more so than the rather dreary act of slaughtering them all.

“Oh?” I said almost playfully, tilting my head closer to the wretched creature, “You wish to live is that right? Why should I do that hmmm?”

“Please!! We do anything!! Anything to serve… oh powerful, great mistress!!” the orc stammered.

I felt my jaw arch into a grin, “Is that right then? You will do anything for us?”

"Yes!! Yeeessss!! We sserve!! We obey!!” he begged, wringing his hands together.

“Good,” I replied contently, “You shall serve us dragons without question or hesitation. In fact, if you pledge to devote yourselves to us, then we can promise you power, glory and supremacy above all the other clans.”

Immediately, I could see hope forming in the orcs eyes, and the thirst for power within this simple creature. If they could be granted but even a small taste of the power we had, then we had them.

“P-power? Y-you help Lugbug become mighty?"

I twisted my neck forward and spoke to him from the side, and then said with a quiet tone, “Oh indeed High Chief Lugbug. By serving under us, none will not have a chance against your might; you will be invincible to the others. All will hear your name for the ages, you shall be legend…”

Yesss… yes…” the orc grunted, “The Blackrock, Hellscream, and Dunmar clans… they will bow, bow before Lugbug!!”

"That's right Chief Lugbug, and all you minions," I said to the others. "The fact that you are all still alive against our wrath proves your superiority compared to others of your kind! By pledging your loyalty to Lugbug, and to us, you will all be stronger!!" I bellowed. It was almost absurdly easy to toy with the primitive emotions of these orcs, and I couldn't help but be amazed at how monumentally stupid and lacking in foresight these orcs truly were. Or perhaps I was better at this than I had previously thought and had actually managed to learn a thing or two from mother.

“Yess…. Yess!! RAAAGGGGHHH!!” bellowed the new chieftain, raising his axe into the air. They all let out fresh chants, proclaiming their power and also that of us.

“By the Ancestors Misty!!” cried Kursed, hugging me tightly, “There you are!”

“We’ve been looking all over for you Mysteria,” said Wyrrach. “We were worried…”

I felt my heart skip a beat for a moment and smiled. “Thanks for being concerned Wyrrach, but I’m all right.”

Smaug let out a snort. “What exactly were you doing sis?”

“Oh… I did tell you that the orcs could be trained,” I said a little smugly, just watch.

I turned back toward the assembled orcs, who were all already bowed low before us, gazing with a combination of fear and awe, “Who do you all serve!!”

“We serve you mistress!!” they all bellowed. I couldn’t help but feel a rush when I heard those words, knowing that all these scared, stupid little minions were now willing to do anything to serve us.

“They really serve us now?” cried Kursed. She curiously walked up to one them, as if observing a small pet.

“You orc!! Sit!!”

The orc in question sat without question.

“Stand!!”

Again, the orc obeyed. Kursed then proceeded to tell the orc to do all sorts of random acts.

“By the Ancestors, they really do obey everything we say!!” she cried gleefully.

I rolled my eyes, “They are very simple creatures actually. Give them a taste of glory and they’ll do anything for you…”

Wyrrach looked deeply impressed, and there was almost a sense of eye in his expression that made my hearts skip. “Don’t underestimate what you’ve accomplished Mysteria. Until now me and my brother have always just been on the run from them, but you’ve managed to turn the tables… In fact, with enough time, we might be able to control the entire marshlands!!”

Smaug, surprisingly enough, was the one to keep them in perspective. “Perhaps,” he snorted, “But you don’t seriously intend to keep your promises to those orcs do you? Encourage them too much and they might decide they’re strong enough to face us…”

That was a good point; despite Smaug being a bloodthirsty killer, he was a lot smarter and shrewder than others gave him credit for. I couldn’t help but smile, “Oh… I have no intension on keeping the full extent of my promises to them. Besides, there are always other clans, and if we can give a demonstration of our power to the others and plant the idea in their head to desire our favor they’ll all fight each for it.”

“Oh, I get it!!” cried Vador, “That means, if one group of orcs grow too powerful we can switch sides, and that way they all keep killing each other and not us!!”

“That’s right! We’ll say the same thing to the other heads of the clans, not to mention others within their clans, like immediate subordinates. Of course, they might eventually figure out the betrayal, but none of them are likely to live long enough and there are always other dumber orcs we would be able to control…”

Even Smaug looked impressed, “Wow, I’ve got to admit sis, I didn’t think you could be that much of a manipulative bitch. As Mysteria has shown, we can use these orcs, and in fact, I think this could be an additional opportunity for us. If we can help fight alongside some of their battles, we’ll also grow stronger in turn.”

At the same time though, I could also sense a bit of concern in Smaug’s expression. If I could manipulate orcs like that, who was to say that I couldn’t also manipulate other dragons? It was a question that hadn’t yet occurred to me yet in those early days yet it was something that Smaug always kept in mind as the years and decades progressed.

“Anyhow, I think its best if we all headed back for the time being,” said Wyrrach.
1551211122212122211231.title: The manipulator

15512111222121222112311.content:
Chapter 23

We left the orcs to pick up the pieces of their shattered clan and retreated to Wyrrach’s cave, or hole rather. No one could have mistaken it for a proper cavern especially given the large fissure in the ceiling which let in both light and rain water.

I imagined that it might have been a comfortable enough hidey-hole for Wyrrach and Vador, but with the addition of Kursed, Smaug and myself, we could scarcely have been packed closer. In fact, we only fit because Samug deigned to have Kursed rest her head on his shoulder and my tail drape over his haunches. Wyrrach held Vador close and despite the cramped conditions, no one protested. We were all bone tired and well fed to boot. But it was nice, I have to admit. It seemed like the first semblance of calm I’d had since mother had died.

We all must have slept for over a day. Smaug slept for two. I stepped out of the hole, carefully extricating myself and stepping over the small form of Vador, sometime after twilight had passed. Quickly, I clawed my way up to the top of the plato over looking the marsh. After relieving myself, I sat facing the marsh, a breeze flowing from my back where the coast was. The wind felt good on my wings and as I stretched them, dried orc blood flaked off. I told myself that I must find time to groom myself, but I did not feel like stirring just yet.

I stretched my wings until the leather was pulled taught and tried to feel the way the wing moved over their curved surfaces. Smaug, despite his own exuberance, could barely fly still and I’d only had my wings out for scarcely a few days. I wondered if it might be best to simply throw myself into the thick of it and trust my instincts. The fall from this ledge would surely not be fatal…

A dragon landed near me, kicking up grit and I hissed instinctively and arced my tail.

“It’s me!” laughed Wyrrach as he folded his large wings to his body.

I relaxed, embarrassed. “Sorry…” I said, lowering my tail.

“It’s quite alright. I’d worry more if you were not so quick.” said the drake as he padded closer to me. “I saw you down here.”

I realized that this was the first time that Wyrrach and I had been alone, at least in a case where one of our lives were not in danger. I swallowed. I did not want him to see how tense I was. “I bet it was easy for you, zipping around up there.” I realized how petulant I sounded the moment the words left my lips, but I could not take them back.

Wyrrach brushed them off, so much more cool headed than Smaug would have been. “I’m not a great flyer, trust me. I barely started a month ago.” He lowered his head nervously and looked just barely back up at me as he nudged himself closer. “I… could show you…” He coughed and straightened up again, “What I know… about flying that is… it’s not much… ugh…”

I couldn’t stop myself from giggling as bad as Kursed. I realized then that he was as nervous being around me as I was around him. “Haha, alright.”

“Alright what?”

“Show me what you know.” and I touched him with my wing. He flinched.

“Alright, first, let’s face into the wind.” We both turned around and faced into the breeze. Wyrrach spaced himself quite far from me to allow for both of our wings and began to talk to me about gliding and banking. “Flapping all the time is hard. I learned to fly by gliding first on the coast. It’s not so hard if you fall too.” He laughed and I joined him, it was surprisingly easy.

I was feeling a bit heady being around him so perhaps I acted a bit more rashly than I would have otherwise. But regardless, I felt suddenly that I could simply wait no longer. “Alright then, let’s try this!” and with a shout, I leaped off the precipice and into empty space. Wyrrach called for me behind, but he was already far behind, his voice fading into the rush of the wind.

It was as exhilarating as it was terrifying. I snapped my wings open, cupping the air and afraid to move them for fear that they would give way under my weight. And despite holding them open, I was still falling surprisingly rapidly. “Shit, Shit, Shit!” I chanted as the rocks below rushed past. A sudden breeze knocked into me from the side and I nearly tipped over. Some instinct saved me as I began flapping to stay afloat, but I seemed to gain no traction either in altitude or against the prevailing wind. At the very least, I did not experience any vertigo, I seemed to have a sense for the way my body was positioned relative to the ground, even as I was floating dozens of feet above it.

I was starting to panic, but then there he was again flapping hard, but breaking the wind for me with his body. He roared over the wind in Drakine. “Don’t fight the wind! Let’s glide down!”

I followed Wyrrach and mimicked the way he held and flapped his own wings and very shortly, I was coming to a rough landing at least a mile from where we had started. The wind had carried us out into the lowlands. I felt surprisingly tired and supposed that I needed to build muscle tone. With an effort, I folded my wings.

“That was quite reckless for a first flight.” said Wyrrach.

I shrugged, “I’m still alive at least. It’s more than can be said for many dragonlings.”

Wyrrach grinned toothily. “Aye. I think we’ve both had more than our fair shares of death in our time.” Wyrrach moved closer, a bright light in his eyes. We were alone in the marsh, a young drake and a young drakka after her first flight and things might have taken a predicable route had I not seen them.

“Look.” I said suddenly.

Wyrrach cocked his head. Together we observed several orcs plodding through the marsh. They spotted us and bowed low. I gave an assenting nod and they continued about their business, which apparently consisted of plucking at the ground.

“What are they doing?” I asked.

“I’ve seen them at this before. It’s a bit soon, but then we’ve soaked the ground in their blood.”

“What?” I was about to ask, but then I saw an orc pull an unusually large lichen from the ground, but rather than a root attached, there appeared to be a small humanoid with immediately began to write and complain. The orc stuffed it under his arm where there were already two other such creatures, still covered in peat and stinking. “Disgusting creatures…” I muttered.

“It’s good that they are replenishing their numbers. Our horde will not be effective without more warriors.” said Wyrrach who sat observing the procedure.

I took a seat beside him and mantled my wings, aware that though the orcs did not look at us directly, we were still being observed. I sighed roughly as they receded from us. “We are going to have to learn more about these wretches aren’t we?”

“Them. And others too I imagine.”

I cocked an eyebrow at the drake beside me.

“Our clan is never going to have the numbers to fight the shadow tooth. We have only two females. Our only hope of survival is to absorb what strength we can from these humanoids and I doubt that these lowly orcs alone will cut it. But they are not the only race that lives in the area, or so my sires have told me.”

I was rendered quite speechless for a time, surprised by Wyrrach’s foresight, but also by his audacity. Two females? He already counted me as his mate and despite my attraction to him, I could not help but feel anger at his presumption. But also, with Kursed being the only other option in terms of females, that left no one to potentially pair with Smaug. That was a prospect that I suddenly feared would enter his mind as well, if it hadn’t already.

155121112221212221123112.content:
I steamed, thinking a long time about this. Wyrrach had been a bit presumptuous, but not so presumptuous like my brother. If he wanted me, he would have to be patient, and to his credit, Wyrrach had shown patience. Maybe it had been because he had been the first male I had met that was my age that hadn't been my brother, but as time had passed, I had found myself more and more attracted to him.

As I thought back on him, I found myself continuing to gaze hazily outside my cave, wondering what was and what could have been. Smaug hadn't liked him. He was possessive in that sense, in which he could not bear to see anything he rightfully thought of as his fall out of his control.

Right at that moment, there was a thump at the foot of the cave. Wearily, I tilted my head. If something or someone had come to finish me off, I was in no position to possibly fight, as blood continued to slowly and steadily seep onto the ground. Then my nostrils caught a whiff of a familiar scent. A scent which I never wanted to hear from again. A dark, malevolent figure came in. He was powerful, strong, with a piercing gaze that could wrench the life out of any creature.

"S-s-smaug!!" I stammered weakly, but with as much anger as I could muster, "S-so, not satisfied with what you have already done, you have come to f-f-inish me off?"

The bastard had already taken too much from me, and now he wanted to gloat and watch his own sister die. I had always known from the very beginning that Smaug would do anything or kill anyone for power, with the malicious streak to match. I was already going to die sooner or later, so it didn't really matter what I said to Smaug anymore. It was liberating.

Yet to my surprise, Smaug was not in a boastful mood.

"Defiant to the end sister," he replied, "I always admired that about you. Yet I wanted to speak with you again," he cried.

"Can't you at least

Smaug then did something I never expected. He gave me a hug. I wasn't sure if he was mocking me or if I should feel touched.

"I always loved you Misty. You idealized everything that a dragoness of our race should be; strong, intelligent and manipulative. By the Ancestors you were manipulative Mysteria. None of the other dragonesses I've ever shared my lair with could possibly compare to what you would be. You were both my inspiration and my near ruin," rumbled Smaug.

I sniffed at him, "It wasn't nearly enough."

"No, it was not. In the end, there could only be one of us, but I do regret that it had to end the way it did. Had you not been my sister, I would have given everything to try and conquer you and made you my mate, and we'd have had strong little ones together." He gazed at me with those possessive, lustful eyes, and I couldn't help but feel sick, but in a strange way, touched. I suppose it was his way of saying that he respected me, but the fact he would look at me in such a fashion was both disgusting but somehow not surprising.

"You're sick Smaug... And you knowing the type of dragoness I was, you would have had to watch your back every single night..." I snapped.

Smaug couldn't help but grin widely. "Indeed, I would have, and we would have loved it every step of the way..."

I rolled my eyes. Was Smaug still trying to unnerve me like he could with every other dragon he had met.

"I could never understand why you liked Wyrrach the way you did," said Smaug. "More than once, I've wondered that you decided to take to him just because you wanted to make me squirm, and have him be a threat to my power..."

There was a long pause. "A dragon like you could never understand why I came to him and not anybody else. You were the one who chose to believe he was your enemy when he didn't have to be."

Smaug snorted, "You honestly expect me to believe this Mysteria? That Wyrrach was such a accommodating, good natured individual to not seek power for himself and how being with you could be a way to get at me? Come on sister. You're way smarter than that. The only real difference between me and Wyrrach was that Wyrrach was better at hiding his true ambitions from others. A dragon that you saw as worthy enough of being your mate could not possibly not have ambitions or plans of his own for power... In fact, you're the reason why he became as dangerous to my position as he did..."

I glared at Smaug, hating him for what he had taken from me, but at the same time I could take some solace that he had also feared both me and Wyrrach. "I wish that things hadn't ended up the way they had, but perhaps... perhaps it was inevitable. Yet what you did to Kursed... that I will never forgive you for Smaug..."

Smaug's smug expression instantly vanished. Kursed was the only dragoness that Smaug truly had a soft spot for. Kursed had been a rather poor flyer, not particularly strong, stunningly naïve nor had she been particularly intelligent; all the qualities that were fatal for a Shadow Dragon. She trusted others easily, and others had exploited that, including myself as I had to shamefully admit. And she had trusted Smaug most of all. Kursed would have done absolutely anything for Smaug, and she had suffered badly for it.

"Kursed wasn't meant to live the life we led. She deserved better," admitted Smaug. "Her egg should have been taken from our mother and raised to live far away, where she wouldn't have to worry herself about the troubles of the world. Yet she wasn't, and I tried to protect her the best I could..."

I couldn't believe the words he was saying, "Protect her?" I scoffed. "You, who took advantage of her more than anybody else!! She did absolutely anything for you and she died because of you!!"

"And she would have died sooner were it not for me!! Remember that storm the day after mother died? She would have drowned that day if it wasn't for me!! Yet there was only so much that I could have done!! Not without threatening my hold on power and thus risking her to some other dragon who would have taken even more advantage of her!!" retorted Smaug.

Even to this day, Smaug was using this same justification over and over to make himself feel better about what had happened to Kursed.

"You are lost Smaug..." I snorted, "How could you possibly say that. How dare you say that... especially after what you did with her!! How could you be so sick..."

"Enough!!" snarled Smaug. "You couldn't possibly understand."

"And I don't want to understand that type of thing Smaug, and I'll be glad to die not understanding why in your twisted mind you believed that you would do such a thing with Kursed... And if I hadn't been with Wyrach you would have tried to do the same to me," I retorted with as much strength as I could muster.

"Then I don't need you to understand," replied Smaug softly, turning his head away. "Yet in the time she was alive... she made life more... bearable."

That I could agree with. Yet clearly, 'bearable' to Smaug had a drastically different meaning from what I saw the meaning of the word.

"I suppose its useless now to imagine what could have been," said Smaug. "All I know is that I did what I had to do, regardless of the cost to myself and those around me. Only with an iron hand can our people can be united, and without it, there is chaos, disorder, strife."

Yet he did not sound like the triumphant conquerer as he must have imagined himself to be when we were all small. And so, as I laid bleeding out, I couldn't help but pose one question, "So, are you finally satisfied Smaug?"

Smaug had a forlorn look. "I'll admit that I will miss having these types of bitter arguments with you. Its rare nowadays that there are others who tell me to eat shit, so frankly, now that it will be gone... I don't know... I really don't know if I will be satisfied..."

"But I admit that the journey it took to get there... That was satisfying..."
155121112221212221123112.title: Black Rememberance

1551211122212122211231121.content:
I steamed as Smaug glared at me.

"W-why are you still here? Shouldn't you get to chasing down my little one? Its what you're best at right?" I snapped.

"I already got to him before I came to you Mysteria…"

"W-what?" I stammered. I tried to summon a bit more strength to confront my brother. "No! You... you kill..."

"I did no such thing Misty," growled Smaug. "I did worse."

"Worse?"

"You tried to raise Shurikan like his father, and I could never live for such an insult. So, I told your son that I had mortally injured his mother, I splashed your life blood in his face, and that he should look upon his uncle and sear that hatred into his memory. I mocked him, told him that he was weak and foolish, and so was his worthless father," taunted Smaug. "Then... I let him go..."

"Y-you.. you have made a terrible mistake then, by letting him go..."

"Oh no, I did so intentionally, just like the dragon who had killed our mother, and let us go. Do you see how strong it made us? Only through the fires of our hatred did we get to where we did... Your son realized what was happening too."

"No..."

I instantly realized what Smaug had done. I had taught my son to be good, like his father, but with his one act, Smaug had corrupted my son, and had taught him to hate, taught him to become a twisted fiend like his uncle. The cycle of hatred amongst our people would continue, and we would forever be slaves to it.

Smaug looked proud, "Hahahahaha!! And you know what he said back? He told me that once he grew up, he was coming after me to take revenge for his mother. He told me that I was making the biggest mistake of my life by letting him live, because once he grew up, he was going to destroy me. He was going to destroy me and kill all my sons, rape all my daughters and demolish everything I held dear and that I had built!!"

"You have no idea how proud I was of him when he had said that! You have a strong son Misty, and he will govern our people well!!" he cackled maniacally, his green eyes glowing.

I gurgled at him, and I had never hated a dragon more than I had in my entire life. I hated it, because I still wanted revenge on Smaug for what he was perpetuating in my son.

"So rest well Misty..."

Smaug made his way out, and I made to chase after him. But I was too weak. My body wouldn't move. I would slowly bleed to death over the next few hours, agonizingly. Too weak!! Not enough... It wasn't enough!
1551211122212122211231121.title: The cycle of revenge

1551211122212122211231122.content:
I left my sister behind, to die in that cave. At last, my ascension to power was complete. Everyone who had once opposed me was dead. In all honesty, I regretted that it had to end like this. Mysteria had been the only dragon who could compete at my level, who understood me the keenest; she was my sister after all. That had been what made her the most dangerous of all, as she was the one dragoness who could have jeopardized and destroyed everything I had worked to achieve. Yet her words nagged at my mind; was she ultimately right about me? She had warned me that this sort of power would leave me feeling hollow if there was nobody to share that with.

It was a foolish notion that one could potentially share power. There was only one voice that the shadow dragons could be ruled with; his, and there could be no others. There could be no disobedience, and transgression was marked with harsh punishment, because without it, my people would once again fall into chaos. My people hated me, feared me but ultimately respected me, and they understood that to defy me was like defying the Ancestors. In fact, at this point there was little distinction between the two; I had become the most powerful of my kind that had ever existed.

I ascended back into the sky and surveyed all that I ruled. I bestrode a great empire, with huge armies at my beck and call, riches galore, thousands upon thousands of slaves.

I suppose it was making me melancholic now, to really take the time to think back on my life, on how I got to this point.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------

"Well, that was a marvelous strategy you employed with those Ironscream orcs Wyrrach. I thought Smaug had that battle won but you turned the tables so quickly!!" said Mysteria.

Wyrrach shrugged, "Smaug's Bloodrager orcs almost had us there, but luckily the plan worked..."

I watched with great jealousy as Wyrrach was hitting up with my sister. He was saying the most corny things to her, and Misty had that dreamy smile on her face. I swear, Mysteria always enjoyed provoking my anger like this; she did these type of things to get on my nerves, rattle my psyche and perhaps even be in a position to oppose me one day.

In any case, let me explain the context here. some time had passed since Mysteria had solved the riddle of the orcs. It was surprisingly easy now that I thought back on it. Orcs were easily manipulated, and wanted power beyond all else.

So we came up with a system. We would rile up several distinct groups of orcs and get them to battle each other, promising their dumb, short-sighted chiefs power and glory. They would fight, and destroy themselves, and only the strong would remain. We would cultivate the stronger of the orcs and get them to fight still more orcs.

Mysteria then came up with the scheme at making the periodic orc fighting an actual contest. Wyrrach would command one band of orcs on one side, while I would command the other band of orcs, while Mysteria would referee. Each of us would build up our own 'orc army', select each of the chieftains, organize a battlefield, and each give the orcs promises of plunder and glory, and set them off against each other. The point was to make sure that we both learned how to direct the orcs in battle. The fact that thousands of thousands upon orcs were killed in this cruel, endless slaughter and bloodshed, and that we had created a situation where the orcs were dwelling in a state of constant battle slavery because of a contest between two growing adolescent dragons did not even occur to us. I mean, who cares about the lives of orcs anyhow? They'll just pull out more orcs out of the ground, and we just continue getting them to kill each other.

When there was one variety of orcs that showed themselves to be stronger on the battlefield, we encouraged them to breed more of them, but when there was one variety that we judged to be weaker; whether it meant they tended to be weaker in strength, speed or the fact that their type annoyed us just a bit more than the others, well, we would just slaughter their whole line and start over. Though I never said so to Misty, and especially not Wyrrach, I did have to admit that those organized orc slaughter contests were rather fun for us.

One would think that the orcs would catch on to the game we were playing with all of them and that we were just using them for our own power. But they never did. They were too pre-occupied with the short term, and the very few chiefs who did figure it out, well, there were always subordinates who wanted power and we always killed them off anyhow.

Yet my mind was still obsessed over Wyrrach, at how he had managed to both triumph with his orcs over me and impress Mysteria in the process. Damn him! He would pay for this! My nostrils billowed with black smoke, as I imagined spearing my claw through Wyrrach's heart and seeing his blood splatter throughout the floor, and then slapping Mysteria around a bit to remind her who was really in charge.

"Oh, come on Smaug, no need to look all angry," said Kursed with that vapid smile of hers. "I actually think they look so cute together!"

I gaped for a moment, but at the same time, I could never bring myself to be angry with Kursed.

"Cute?" I scoffed, "More like revolting is more like it..."

"Somebody sounds jealous..." giggled Kursed.

"As if..."

That was a lie though. It was bugging me that Wyrrach was getting closer and closer with Mysteria. Don't get me wrong though, Wyrrach was no scrub. He was a very capable dragon, someone who knew the area well, was disciplined and intelligent. That's probably why I especially hated him.

"You know Kursed," I said, "Ever since we met... Wyrrach and his brother, we haven't managed to find any other dragons. Granted, we've spent nearly all our time here, growing up and fighting with the orcs, but I am getting a bit worried. There can't just be the five of us. Can there?"

"Who knows for sure?" shrugged Kursed. "We have a nice group right here. Why would we even have to move from where we are anyhow? Its nice here, there's food and we have the orcs as a tool to protect us should anything go wrong."

"But the dragon who killed mom..." I snarled. "I promised that I would never let him get away with what he did..."

"How will we ever since such a dragon?" said Kursed. She didn't really show that much inclination for revenge that I did, and I suppose it was only natural for her to get comfortable here. Frankly, I wished that neither of my sisters would have to be involved at all, and that I would achieve vengeance on my own. Misty would be able to survive on her own; she was devious and strong, but Kursed... I knew she would not survive for long.

I suppose that's why I tolerated the situation at that point in time...

However...

info.brief_description: You are a dragon in a classical fantasy setting. How will you master the world around you?
info.description:
You are a magnificent Dragon. A wonder to behold!

This is your story of your rise to power and glory. There are many paths to power however. Will you be an unstoppable plague on the land? A compassionate warrior with a sense of honor? Will you have a host of fanatical minions? A vast hoard of gold and wealth? It is up to you to decide.

The setting is in High Fantasy. There are elves, dwarves, halflings and other strange and marvelous creatures to be found, but keep in mind that the world is mostly populated by humans. Magic is a powerful and mysterious tool known only to a small proportion of the population, but do not fear! A dragon's hide will deflect most cantrips and other minor magics, only the most powerful of arch-magi can hope to challenge a dragon on even terms... A dragon's hide will also keep out most arrows and glance aside blades, but beware of siege weapons such as ballistae and catapults as well as heavy piercing weapons such as lances.

Religion and gods are abound in the world, but they are known to bide their time and be mysterious in their workings. Fortunately for you, you are a dragon and care little for other mortals' foolish notions.

Dragons have a magic all their own though they do not will it into being like other simpler creatures. Often, mysterious things can happen around dragons when the situation is appropriate. Don't count on it to save you though! Your wings, claws and tail are far better allies. Remember always to keep your wits about you, there are thieves and assassins around every corner. While you may find that you befriend some mortal creatures, remember that you will always be apart from their world and will always be treated with fear and suspicion even by the stoutest dwarf or the most open-minded elf. Finally, beware other dragons! Just because you're the same species doesn't make you friends; everyone's out to build their own hoards and secure their own mates after all.

Finally, some ground Rules:
1) No sexuality or erotic content (Implied sex, like with a dragon mate is fine).

2) Killing the main character is ok, but must be thoroughly justified (either by persistently bad or extreme choices)

3) Maiming or crippling the main character is ok, but keep it tasteful and not needlessly gory. However there must not be complete incapacitation (loosing a leg is fine, neck down paralysis is not) and no mental handicaps.

4) Dragons are the top of the food chain, don't invent inherently more powerful creatures.

5) Romance between the main character and non-dragons is ok, but keep it to a minimum.

6) Be true to your Path and Personality. Keep both in mind when you are writing.

*Side note: If you want to create your own dragon breed or are otherwise unsatisfied with the choices presented, feel free to send me an e-mail and we'll see if a solution is possible.
